title: Question over who will fill Transfusion Consultant vacancy
author: Author not found
Content: Serious concerns have arisen following the recent vacancy that has arisen for the post of Transfusion Consultant, at the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital. The question is whether the health authorities intended fill that position with a ‘Senior Registrar’ or a retired ‘Transfusion Consultant’.    Sources yesterday (17) said that health authorities were filling in the vacant positions with Senior Registrars when regulations of the Post Graduate Institute of Medicine (PGIM) and the Specialist Registry did not sanction them to cover Consultant Posts. They lamented that the  National Hospital, Colombo the largest Teaching Hospital in the island and several tertiary care and specialised care hospitals in the country were sans transfusion consultants and had been forced to appeal to those who had retired from service and Senior Registrars awaiting their foreign training to fill in. Informed sources noted that while the NHSL had a retired Transfusion Consultant, the Colombo South Teaching Hospital, Teaching Hospital Peradeniya, Batticaloa and District General Hospitals Polonnaruwa, Moneragala and Ampara, Apeksha Hospital for cancer patients, Base Hospital Gampaha and District General Hospital, Kilinochchi were short of Transfusion Consultants and the posts were being covered by Senior Registrars. There were only three ‘Board Certified’ Transfusion Consultants according to the Replacement List for 2023. Of them one was still overseas.  Sources noted that the Senior Registrar serving as the Transfusion Consultant had joined the Sri Jayewardenepura University, while all others were either awaiting foreign training or had finished their local training in mid-August. They lamented that the State Health Service faced a serious dilemma as there would be no Transfusion Consultants serving the peripheries in the near future should this situation continue. However, the Director of the National Blood Transfusion Centre, Dr. Lakshman Edirisinghe, when contacted, noted that at present there were eight candidates to fill in the positions, while the Senior Registrars were also capable of covering the workload of the post transfusion consultant category as they were full-fledged medical doctors who had completed their period of local training.    He noted that the situation had only arisen when the Transfusion Consultant at Karapitiya Teaching Hospital had retired last year, while the Senior Registrar who had been appointed to the post had left for foreign training. But a replacement would be made to the position within the next few days, he added. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Nearly 1.6M primary students lag behind
author: Author not found
Content: Prolonged school closure has impacted 1.6 million primary schoolchildren in Sri Lanka, with 85 per cent of children in Grade 3 not achieving the minimum literacy and numeracy levels, a statement issued by the UNICEF revealed. A national initiative to help 1.6 million primary school children, impacted by prolonged school closures and sporadic disruptions to their education over the past three years, to catch up on their learning, spearheaded by the Ministry of Education (MoE) and UNICEF is currently underway. According to an MOE-led national assessment, 85 per cent of Grade 3 children are not achieving minimum proficiency in literacy and numeracy, which is essential in their transition to secondary school and beyond, both in life and work, a statement issued by the UNICEF stated. The event was held under the leadership of Minister of Education, Dr. Susil Premajayantha along with the UNICEF Representative for Sri Lanka, Christian Skoog, and was attended by government and development partners. Currently, Sri Lanka allocates less than two per cent of its GDP for education, which falls well below the international benchmark of 4-6 per cent of GDP and is among the lowest in the South Asia region. “There is an urgent need to increase the national budget allocation for education, especially for primary grades, where we need to boost foundational learning for children, while also ensuring the implementation of vital Education Reforms, so that we can build the solid human resource skills needed to support the country’s development,” said Dr. Premajayantha. The learning crisis has affected vulnerable children the most, including younger children in primary grades and those in plantation estates in the country. “The basics of literacy, numeracy, and social economic skills are the platform on which children build their own, their families, their communities, and their country’s future,” said Christian Skoog, UNICEF Representative for Sri Lanka while adding “We commend the MOE for its commitment to undertake urgent efforts to reverse the widening disparities in learning achievement for children who are lagging further behind, including slow learners, and missing out due to the continued hardship the country faces,” he said. In July, the MOE and UNICEF held a special briefing on ‘Learning Recovery’ to leverage the support of development partners, while more technical-level workshops were held across nine provinces, to identify gaps and prioritise actions. (GW)

title: India hands over substitute Dornier 228 aircraft
author: Author not found
Content: Commemorating its 77th Independence Day, India officially presented a replacement Dornier 228 maritime surveillance aircraft to President’s Senior Adviser on National Security, Sagala Ratnayake, yesterday (16). The handover took place at the Sri Lanka Air Force Base in Katunayake. This substitute aircraft is to be used by the SLAF to enhance its maritime surveillance capabilities. The new aircraft was provided as the previous Dornier 228, handed over to Sri Lanka a year ago, underwent obligatory annual maintenance in India. The discussions for this acquisition began during bilateral security talks between India and Sri Lanka in 2018. Responding to Sri Lanka’s request, the Indian Government decided to grant a Dornier 228 maritime surveillance aircraft from the Indian Navy’s fleet, free of cost for a two-year period. This gesture aimed to bolster Sri Lanka’s maritime surveillance capabilities. After its initial delivery, the Dornier 228 aircraft played a crucial role in various specialised tasks within Sri Lanka over the past year. It contributed to monitoring and safeguarding the country’s airspace and economic zone, conducting maritime and coastal surveillance, search and rescue operations, and monitoring maritime pollution. The official handover event was attended by a Sri Lankan delegation, including Senior Adviser to the President on National Security Sagala Ratnayake, High Commissioner of India to Sri Lanka Gopal Baglay, Defence Secretary General (Rtd) Kamal Gunaratne and other officials. The exchange underscores the strong diplomatic ties and cooperation between India and Sri Lanka in matters of security and defence.

title: Devananda informed fish prices reducing
author: Author not found
Content: Ceylon Fisheries Corporation (CFC) Chairman D. V. Upul yesterday (16) informed Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda that fish prices declining significantly and this would relief to consumers. Upul explained that a combination of factors such as adverse weather conditions, off-season periods and the absence of South-westerly monsoonal winds had led to a consistent increase in fish prices over the past few months. However, he highlighted that the trend has now reversed, leading to a reduction in fish prices. Presently, a kilogram of linno is being sold at between Rs 400 and Rs 500, while kelawalla, cuttlefish, and both tuna and cuttlefish are being sold at Rs 700 per kilogram, according to Upul. It is worth noting that previously, a kilogram of kelawalla was priced at Rs 2,200, and other varieties were being sold at Rs 1,000 per kilogram. This challenging scenario had caused difficulties for regular consumers and led to a decrease in fish consumption. Fisheries Ministry Secretary Indu Ratnayake and key officials from the Fisheries Ministry were also present during the discussion. By NaalirJamaldeen

title: No plans to align with the President – Sajith
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa said he has no plans to align with President Ranil Wickremesinghe, as such a move would be a betrayal of ordinary citizens. Premadasa’s statement came in response to remarks made by SJB MP Rohini Kumari Wijeratne, suggesting a unity between Premadasa and Wickremesinghe. Addressing the executive council of the opposition party on 16 August, Premadasa firmly voiced his stance. He asserted that there exists no accord or alignment with the present President-led government, which he claimed is “implicated in acts of genocidal and oppressive State terrorism.” The opposition party, he emphasised, stands for the third path rather than extreme leftist or capitalist policies. It is dedicated to safeguarding human rights, as well as the economic, social, and political rights of the nation’s populace. Premadasa also criticised the Government’s discussions about the 13th Amendment, slamming its lack of a coherent language policy. While he acknowledged that the Government is reluctant to forge ties with those engaged in false and deceitful political manoeuvres, he vowed to stand on the side of well-informed and constructive decisions for the nation. The prevailing administration, in Premadasa’s view, is steered by an unelected President, bereft of trust and recognition, indulging in political manipulations alongside an insatiable gang that has financially crippled the country. Their actions are rooted in personal greed rather than the country’s welfare. He condemned the proposed inhumane ideas affecting the working class, arguing that they undermine international principles, language policies, and fundamental rights. These adverse proposals would be staunchly opposed. Premadasa underscored the importance of generating wealth to foster prosperity and advocated for humanistic capitalism as a means of equitable distribution. He highlighted the skewed income distribution in the country, where the wealthiest 20 per cent amass over 52 per cent of the national income while the impoverished receive just 4 to 5 per cent. Labour security and wealth creation, in his view, should go hand in hand. The SJB aligns with the interests of the working class and seeks pragmatic solutions. It will not compromise with a government driven by ulterior motives. As a progressive Opposition, it stands resolutely for the rights of the working population and remains open to alternative positions that uphold the people’s welfare, he stressed.  By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Dr Ajith Mendis appointed SPC Chairman
author: Author not found
Content: Former Director General of Health Services Dr. Ajith Mendis has been appointed as the new Chairman of the State Pharmaceutical Corporation (SPC). Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella yesterday (16) appointed Dr. Mendis to the position whilst removing Sarath Liyanage, who has been accused of being involved in several controversial tender procedures for pharmaceuticals, from the post of SPC Chairman. A spokesperson for the Government Medical Officers’ Forum (GMOF) said that Dr. Mendis had a history of being a good administrator. However, the move looks like as though Minister Rambukwella has accepted the fact that there was corruption involved in the continuation of the emergency purchasing of medicinal drugs. But, unfortunately the real corruption is in the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA) where corruption takes place the most. It is ironic that the Health Minister has decided to take measures to allegedly rid the Health Ministry and its institutions of allegedly corrupt officials when he is about to face a no-confidence motion. He alleged that the Minister was looking for a scapegoat to convince the public that he was taking measures to cleanse the State health service of corrupt officials. Although emergency purchasing was excusable at the time the country was in the grip of an economic crisis, now, when the situation is more stable it is unwise to continue emergency processing, he said responding to questions. BY Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Motorcycle gunmen strike again in Kaduwela
author: Author not found
Content: Investigations have been launched by Tangalle Police following a puzzling shooting incident in Kaduwela, where the victim was found wearing a helmet, yet no motorcycle was found at the crime scene. The incident occurred on 15 August and claimed the life of a 35-year-old individual from South Nakulagamuwa, Kaduwela. Authorities suspect that the perpetrators arrived on a motorcycle and employed a pistol in the attack. Simultaneously, another shooting occurred on the same day in Bodarakanda, as reported by Dickwella Police. The deceased in this incident is Sanjeeva Pushpakumara, aged 43, a resident of Weragampita, Matara. Police Media Spokesman, SSP Nihal Thalduwa said there is presently no discernible connection between the two murders. He assured that further investigations will be conducted to uncover any potential links. Detailing the Kaduwela incident, the Police Spokesman said the Dickwella shooting involved the use of a T-56 assault rifle, with approximately 20 empty shell casings found at the crime scene. While the victim was found wearing a helmet, the absence of a motorcycle at the location raises suspicions. Investigators are diligently working to clear up this aspect. In the case of the Dickwella shooting, the Police suspect criminal involvement. Investigations have not shown any link between the two shootings, as one was carried out with a pistol and the other with a T-56 assault rifle. The victims of the two incidents also appear to be unrelated. Police are conducting investigations. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: No move to cancel leave – Health Ministry
author: Author not found
Content: The Health Ministry, yesterday (16), said no decision had been taken to cancel the leave of medical practitioners who were undergoing foreign training. Sources of the Health Ministry, responding to queries, said such reports may have been triggered by news regarding the present brain drain taking place among doctors. They stressed that no decision had been taken to halt doctors from going for foreign training either. However, it must be noted that Sri Lanka too had hospitals capable of providing such post-graduate training. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Dehiwala Zoo CSO killed in utility pole collapse
author: Author not found
Content: In a tragic turn of events, the Chief Security Officer of the Dehiwala Zoological Gardens, lost his life when a utility pole collapsed onto him on Tuesday (15) afternoon. According to the Dehiwala Police, a large tree fell, striking the utility pole, which then toppled onto the victim. The mishap was triggered by the uprooting of a large Cabovena tree located near the animal hospital within the zoo premises. This tree impact resulted in the dislodging of the pole connected to internal power lines. The unfortunate event occurred as the victim was making his way back to the zoo after purchasing his lunch. Despite his prompt admission to the Colombo South Teaching Hospital in Kalubowila, the 54-year-old Chief Security Officer’s severe head injuries proved fatal, and he was pronounced dead later that evening. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Continuous water supply to Colombo, Gampaha
author: Author not found
Content: The National Water Supply and Drainage Board (NWSDB), yesterday (16), confirmed its capability to maintain a continuous water supply to Colombo and Gampaha. Deputy General Manager of the Water Board, Ajith Perera, highlighted the construction of a sandbank in Ambathale as a strategic solution to address water level concerns in the Kelani River. Despite ongoing challenges regarding water supply to various parts of the country, Perera emphasised the Water Board’s competence in delivering essential water services to Colombo and Gampaha. The newly constructed sandbank at Ambathale effectively tackles two key issues: the receding water level and the potential contamination of drinking water due to saltwater intrusion, he pointed out. Perera cautioned that the present situation could escalate in the coming days due to heightened public demand amid the prevailing hot weather. In response, he appealed to the public to practise water conservation by limiting usage to essential needs. Further, Perera urged the public to actively contribute to water source protection by minimising pollution in rivers.

title: New pension scheme for private sector – Wajira
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe plans to introduce a new pension scheme for the private sector, UNP Chairman MP Wajira Abeywardena said yesterday (16). Abeywardena said this new pension scheme will be similar to the one received by fuel station employees. He was speaking during a media briefing held at Sirikotha. “The objective of this is to encourage the youth to work in the private sector, rather than trying to squeeze everyone into the State sector,” he said. Abeywardena said one of the most challenging aspects of democracy is accommodating diverse perspectives and voices. People approach problems from various angles, leading to differing viewpoints. In response to queries about differing opinions within the Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP), Abeywardena asserted that in a democratic nation, individuals have the right to express their views independently. He emphasised the need to avoid confusion arising from such statements. Regarding the 13th Amendment, Abeywardena conveyed that it is a legal norm. He highlighted the importance of transferring ownership of properties presently under Provincial Council (PC) members or affiliated officials to the public. “The privileges granted to PC members under the 13th Amendment should benefit ordinary citizens,” he added. He noted that certain factions might attempt to create divisions for political gain. According to Abeywardena, the President has taken decisive measures to safeguard Sri Lanka’s unity, encompassing the Northern and Eastern regions. Statements made by specific groups concerning the 13th Amendment are based on their understanding of the constitutional provisions. He emphasised the media’s crucial role in presenting accurate information to the public. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Feast of ‘Our Lady of Madhu’
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe participatrd in  the annual festival of the National Shrine of Our Lady of Madhu in Mannar on Tuesday (15) where he announced plans to transform Mannar into an energy hub. He participated in the morning service of the feast this year. The President revealed that an inter-city express train service between Thalaimannar and Colombo will commence on 15 September aiming at enhancing connectivity and to facilitate smoother travel between the two cities. Subsequent to the main ceremony, the sacred statue of Our  Lady of Madhu was respectfully carried in a procession throughout the church grounds to enable the devotees to pay homage. A significant number of devotees from various parts of the island gathered for the annual feast. The year 2024 marks the completion of 100 years since the enshrinement of the revered statue of Lady Madhu. The church management board has decided to hold services throughout the year to commemorate this occasion. Apostolic Nuncio of of the Vatican to Sri Lanka Rev. Dr. Brian Udaigwe also attended the main service. title: Lions 306 A2 -Installation Ceremony of Cabinet Officers
author: Author not found
Content: The Cabinet Officers Installation Ceremony and 1st Cabinet Meeting of Lions District 306 A2 was held on 22 July at White Haven Hotel, Panadura. The Chief Guest was Past International Director, Lion Vijay Kumar Raju PMJF from Visakhapatnam, India. He is the LCIF Trustee for the period 2021 – 2024 and Constitutional Area Leader of Campaign 100 for Constitutional Area 6. The District Leaders of 2023/2024 are in the picture (from right), 1st Vice District Governor, Lion Prasad Gamage, PMJF, Lady Lion Nimna, District Governor, Lion Nuwan Ballanthudawa, MJF, Lady Lion Piumi, PID Lion Vijay Kumar Raju, PMJF and 2nd Vice District Governor, Lion Priyantha Perera, MJF, MAF and Lady Lion Dushanthi. The Lions Club of Colombo Pride together with all members of the District 306 A2 wish you abundant success accompanied by excellent health and well-being!

title: LIOC donates wheelchairs to disabled persons
author: Author not found
Content: On the auspicious occasion of 77th Independence Day of India on 15 August 2023, LIOC donated wheelchairs to disabled persons from underprivileged sections of the society, which were  handed over by High Commissioner of India to Sri Lanka Gopal Baglay, in the presence of LIOC MD Dipak Das. The recipients were from across the country, such as Ja-Ela, Chilaw, Batticaloa, Pasyala, Kadawatha, Moratuwa, etc As a part of Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR), M/s Lanka IOC PLC has undertaken an inspiring initiative creating positive impact on the lives of individuals with mobility challenges. The company has embarked on a mission to donate wheelchairs to underserved communities, showcasing its commitment to making a difference. With a strong focus on creating sustainable and meaningful change, Lanka IOC’s latest CSR project aims to provide mobility solutions to those who often find themselves marginalised due to mobility impairments. The initiative’s core goal is to empower individuals with the gift of increased mobility, thus enhancing their quality of life and promoting inclusivity. On this occasion, T.S. Prakash, Chairman, Indian CEO Forum and Kishore Reddy, President Sri Lanka India Society (SLIS) were also present.

title: Ranaviru Seva Authority offers Rs 2.76M worth scholarships
author: Author not found
Content: The Ranaviru Seva Authority (RVSA) awarded Rs 2.76 million worth of scholarships to 23 children belonging to war veteran families, who excelled at the G.C.E. Ordinary Level Examination by obtaining 9 Distinctions, on 15 August. This event was held under the patronage of RVSA Chairman, Major General (Retd) Nandana Senadeera. Lally Kobbekaduwa, Manel Wimalaratne, Apsara Gunawardena and Rekha Senadeera joined the scholarship awarding programme organised with the aim of empowering these children through education. Italy-based Sri Lankan donors led by Priyantha Munasinghe extended financial support for the programme. Accordingly, a child of a war hero receives financial assistance of Rs 5,000 per month for two years (a total of Rs 120,000). Chief of Naval Staff, Rear Admiral Jayantha Kularatne, Chief of Air Staff, Air Vice Marshal Sampath Wickramarathne, RVSA Deputy Chairperson, Sonia Kottegoda, RVSA Director, Brig. Chandra Abeykoon, Secretary to the President, Brig. Nalin Madhiwaka and RVSA staffers, donors and parents were in attendance.

title: Sri Lanka-Cuba PFA focuses on strengthening bilateral relations
author: Author not found
Content: Attention was paid to the opportunities in order to further strengthen the bilateral relations between Sri Lanka and Cuba, during the meeting of the Sri Lanka-Cuba Parliamentary Friendship Association (PFA) held recently in Parliament. This was discussed at the meeting of the executive committee of the association chaired by Prof. Tissa Vitharana. Cuban Ambassador to Sri Lanka Andrés Marcelo González Garrido was also present on this occasion. Prof. Tissa Vitharana said Sri Lanka and Cuba have been friendly countries for a long time and this trend should continue. He also said it will be an opportunity for Sri Lankans to know about Cuba by starting Sri Lanka-Cuba friendship organisations in different provinces. Accordingly, he invited the executive committee members of the Parliamentary Friendship Association to start Sri Lanka-Cuba Friendship Organisations in their areas. Addressing the meeting, the Cuban Ambassador said the Sri Lanka-Cuba Parliamentary Friendship Association was established in the Cuban Parliament recently and its members are interested in strengthening the relations between the two countries. He also expressed gratitude for the solidarity extended by Sri Lanka in various challenges faced by Cuba. Also, the Cuban Ambassador said there are opportunities to improve bilateral relations between the two countries in the fields of sports and trade, and invited Sri Lankan businessmen to participate in the Havana International Fair to be held in early November. State Minister Dr. Suren Raghavan said there is a possibility of starting a Medical College in Sri Lanka in collaboration with the Cuban Government and a concept paper for this has already been prepared and is expected to be submitted to the Friendship Association. The meeting was attended by Vice President of the Parliamentary Friendship Association Weerasumana Weerasinghe, Executive Committee Members Jayantha Weerasinghe and Isuru Dodangoda.

title: Rural people ripped off by three-wheeler drivers – Wijerathne
author: Author not found
Content: The Lanka Private Bus Owners’ Association (LPBOA) said people in rural areas are being ripped off by three-wheeler drivers. It emphasised the need to introduce single-door buses to address this issue. Speaking to Ceylon Today, LPBOA Chairman Gemunu Wijerathne pointed out that drivers of metre-less taxis are cheating passengers. “There is a pressing need to introduce more single-door buses. Three-wheeler drivers often overcharge passengers for short-distance travel. To tackle this problem, we have the opportunity to introduce single-door buses on rural roads. We have engaged in extensive discussions with the Transport Ministry Secretary to implement this change,” Wijerathne explained. He also highlighted that they have been receiving complaints about people in rural areas being unable to afford transportation to hospitals due to prohibitive charges. “Even individuals in urgent need, such as patients, are facing serious difficulties as a result. Therefore, the LPBOA has appealed to the Transport Ministry to authorise the import of small buses, with a capacity of at least 10 seats,” Wijerathne said. He further proposed that the Government should launch night transport services using single-door buses. He argued that working-class passengers struggle to commute home, and many are forced to refuse late shifts due to poor transport systems. Wijerathne suggested that if necessary, a modest increase of 10 per cent in bus fares for night transport could be considered to ensure the efficiency of the service. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: SOC discusses film industry issues
author: Author not found
Content: The Sectoral Oversight Committee (SOC) on Media, Youth, Heritage and New Citizen took into discussion the development of the film industry in Sri Lanka. The Committee, chaired by Lalith Varna Kumara, met to discuss the issues and future proposals in the film industry. Officials of the National Film Corporation were summoned before this committee to discuss the aforesaid concerns. Accordingly, the officials representing the National Film Corporation explained the concerns surrounding the film industry. In particular, they pointed out that there has been a trend of shrinking cinemas and about five or six cinemas close down per year. The share of money received by the film corporation from a movie ticket and the difficulty in finding film producers was also taken into discussion. The revision of the Film Corporation Act was also discussed at length. It was also suggested that the registration fee for importing foreign films and the fee charged by the Film Corporation for one film should be revised. In addition, the committee also focused on the existing plans of the Film Corporation to deal with the popularity of platforms like Netflix. Furthermore, the present officials pointed out the need for filmmakers to prepare quality films. MPs Sanjeeva Edirimanna, Jayantha Ketagoda and Gamini Waleboda, were also present at the Committee meeting.

title: Intimidating doctors won’t reduce brain drain
author: Author not found
Content: Doctors, lashing out at the Health Ministry, said it would only aggravate the present brain drain amongst medical practitioners if the Ministry thought they could intimidate them and resolve the issue. Secretary of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA), Dr. Haritha Aluthge, speaking to the media on Tuesday (15), said the Ministry’s inefficient officials were unable to resolve the brain drain taking place amongst the medical fraternity. Referring to the interview given by the Director Tertiary Care on Monday (14), he accused the health official of merely grabbing the issue by its “tail” and toying with it instead of finding solutions. He said the particular Director’s comments would only result in the medical practitioners who had gone for foreign training with the intention of returning also making up their minds to leave for good. “Medical Administrators such as the Acting Deputy Director General (Medical Services –II) and the Director Tertiary Care depicted the tragedy in the field of medical administration of the island,” he said.  “The Director Tertiary Care should know that he is serving in the unit dealing with specialist doctors. The treatment that they receive when they seek the services of the Tertiary Care Unit could also contribute towards their decision to leave,” he lamented.  “We warned that the Health Ministry and the political authorities of this country have followed a very dormant policy while no matter how much the GMOA cautioned them, the Ministry of Health is following its ineffective policy as usual.” The GMOA Secretary lamented that whenever his outfit had brought up this issue, some people had used social media to settle their grudge against doctors. “In addition to so many issues plaguing the country’s State health service including the present medicinal drug issues and the cost of drugs, we are also faced with brain drain,” he said. The GMOA Secretary said they had submitted several proposals to resolve the issue earlier and they had proposed a special salary structure for medical practitioners in accordance with their market value and performance.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: 650,000 beneficiaries to get allowances – Semasinghe
author: Author not found
Content: The Government has chosen to maintain the present allowances for nearly 650,000 (total of 647,683) kidney patients, disabled individuals, and low-income elderly citizens until a new scheme is formulated, State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe said. This decision, as stated by Semasinghe on Twitter, comes with confirmed financial allocations for these disbursements. The breakdown includes 517,962 elderly citizens, 88,602 disabled individuals, and 41,119 kidney patients, encompassing both those enrolled and wait-listed in the ‘Aswesuma’ welfare benefits programme. The forthcoming days are expected to see the processing of these payments. Semasinghe highlighted the distribution process: elderly citizens can retrieve their allowances from post offices, while disabled individuals and kidney patients can collect their disbursements from Divisional Secretariats.

title: Hambantota Oil Refinery Project faces setback
author: Author not found
Content: The Hambantota Oil Refinery (Pvt.) Ltd.’s ambitious plan to construct a petroleum refinery with a capacity of 420,000 barrels per day in the Hambantota area, exclusively for the export market, has hit a roadblock, the Government Information office said yesterday. “The Cabinet of Ministers, following its approval on 17 September 2019, to forge an agreement between the Board of Investment of Sri Lanka and Hambantota Oil Refinery (Pvt.) Ltd., has now decided to cancel the agreement due to non-compliance with the stipulated terms,” it stated. Under the original agreement, the Hambantota Oil Refinery (Pvt.) Ltd. was slated to be allocated 1,200 acres of land on a 50-year long-term lease basis for the purpose of establishing the petroleum refinery. However, the project has faced delays as the project proponent has not secured the designated land on a lease basis and has consequently failed to initiate the project’s implementation. “Repeated attempts to communicate and prompt action from the project proponent have yielded no response, leading to concerns about the project’s viability and adherence to the terms outlined in the initial agreement. Despite multiple written notices urging the project proponent to adhere to the terms of the agreement, there has been no substantial progress on the ground. Given the non-compliance and lack of progress, the Cabinet of Ministers has approved a proposal put forth by the President, who also holds the role of Minister of Investment Promotion. This proposal advocates for the cancellation of the agreement between the Board of Investment of Sri Lanka and Hambantota Oil Refinery (Pvt.) Ltd.” This decision reflects the Government’s commitment to ensuring that projects aligned with national development goals are executed efficiently and in accordance with established protocols. The cancellation of the agreement underscores the importance of adherence to agreements and transparency in the execution of large-scale projects that hold significant economic and strategic implications. As the agreement is rescinded, the future of the Hambantota Oil Refinery project remains uncertain. This development also sheds light on the complexities and challenges that can arise in the execution of major infrastructure projects, particularly when key stakeholders fail to uphold their commitments and responsibilities outlined in the initial agreement. By Ishara Gamage

title: Minister Alles complains to CID
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles filed a complaint with the CID yesterday (15) over a statement made by Duminda Nagamuwa of the Frontline Socialist Party (FSP). During a press conference held on 12 August, Duminda alleged that Tiran Alles had invested money in a European island alongside the JVP. Following Nagamuwa’s allegation, Minister Alles lodged the complaint yesterday afternoon, urging the CID to probe the statement. The Minister emphasised his commitment to upholding the law without considering anyone’s status and he expressed his hope that this principle would also apply in this instance. Furthermore, Minister Alles stressed the importance of clarifying the truth or falsehood of such accusations promptly, believing that the public deserves clarity on such matters. BY Mithun Jayawardana

title: Failed radar project cost Govt Rs 78M – COPA
author: Author not found
Content: A substantial loss of Rs 78 million has been incurred by the State due to a failed project involving the construction of a radar system in Gongala. This was revealed when the  Auditor General’s report was taken up during a recent meeting of the Committee on Public Accounts (COPA). The endeavour had received support from the World Meteorological Organisation, a development highlighted by the Parliamentary media unit. The disclosure came to the fore during a session held on 10 August, when officials from the Department of Meteorology appeared before COPA. In a project initiated in 2008, records revealed an expenditure of approximately Rs 402 million on the radar system, with Rs 323 million sourced from the World Meteorological Organisation. Interestingly, it came to light that prior to bringing the radar system to Sri Lanka, a Department of Meteorology officer had assessed the machine and advised against its import due to its non-operational condition. Further investigation by officials from the Auditor General’s Department revealed that years were spent preparing a road to the designated location, causing the equipment to become obsolete. The already dire situation escalated when a crane transporting the load collapsed, damaging some of the equipment, while the rest remains unaccounted for due to the condition of the dilapidated road. Adding to the complexity, both the Police and the Bribery and Corruption Commission have initiated investigations into the matter. Consequently, the COPA underscored the pressing necessity for the Department of Meteorology to promptly execute effective projects using modern technology to ensure precise forecasts. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Gazette on relaxing Import Regulations on public transport vehicles issued
author: Author not found
Content: A Gazette Notification issued yesterday (15) relaxed import regulations pertaining to public transportation vehicles. This encompasses buses, lorries, tankers/bowsers and trucks, as part of a phased approach towards easing import restrictions. Notably, the relaxation extends to tankers and bowsers, featuring stainless steel tanks for the transportation of milk, as well as refrigerated trucks. The Ministry of Finance is the authority behind the issuance of this Gazette Notification.  As of June 2023, the Government has implemented a substantial change by lifting import restrictions on a total of 286 items. This inclusive list encompasses various categories like food and beverages, medicine and medical equipment, construction materials, raw materials for manufacturing, consumer goods, as well as machinery and equipment. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Three people seek action against top Labour Commissioners
author: Author not found
Content: Three individuals have filed a petition in the Supreme Court (SC), praying for an order, to Attorney General Sanjay Rajaratnam, to institute legal action against 34 top officials, including Commissioners of the Ministry of Labour. This is due to the Labour Ministry Commissioners and top officials, having allegedly held a protest opposite the Ministry premises, to oppose the arrest of current Secretary to the said Ministry, R.P.A. Wimalaweera, after the Horana Chief Magistrate’s Court had issued an order for his arrest, connected to an incident that had taken place at the Horana Rubber Factory, five years ago. The petition had been lodged with the Apex Court, by M. Susantha Ariyaratne, Lalith Karunathileke and W.A. Lal Jayatissa. The petitioners have also moved the Supreme Court, to issue an order, to the Attorney General, to file legal action against IGP C. D. Wickremaratne as well, after the latter had failed to heed the order issued by the Horana Chief Magistrate, to arrest the suspect Secretary, within a seven-day period and produce him in Court. They have mentioned in their petition, that former Commissioner of the Labour Ministry Ashoka Peiris and the former Commissioner General of the said Ministry and the present Secretary Wimalaweera, had been charged with intimidating and threatening Inspector of the Kalutara Rubber Factory Rukman Kumar Hemachandra, demanding that he produce bogus evidence, during the trial being heard connected to an incident, that had occurred at the premises of the Horana rubber factory, in 2018. The petitioners have further pointed out to the Supreme Court, that the first suspect in the case, Peiris, after being arrested in connection with the incident had been subsequently enlarged on bail, but that the second suspect Wimalaweera, though had been noticed to appear in Court, has continued to abscond case proceedings to date. They have informed the Supreme Court, that the suspect Ministry Secretary, had filed a petition in the Panadura Chief Magistrate’s Court, praying the Court to invalidate a notice issued to him by the Horana Chief Magistrate’s Court, to appear in Court, on 24 July. They have stated that the petition filed by the suspect Secretary, had been dismissed by the High Court Judge, ordering him to surrender himself to the Horana Chief Magistrate’s Court, forthwith and that without heeding that order, the suspect has continued to work at his Ministry. The petitioners have alleged that due to such a situation, a few Commissioners and top officers of the Labour Ministry, had staged a demonstration at the Ministry premises, during the afternoon of 27 July, opposing the order issued by the Horana Chief Magistrate, three days earlier, for the arrest of the suspect concerned,. They had added in their petition, that they were also in possession of video evidence, to further substantiate their charges, against the suspect concerned. The petitioners have mentioned that if anyone were to force, intimidate, threaten or coax, a person to submit fake evidence during a trial, it is a punishable offence and if found guilty, could be punished by imprisonment and a fine. By Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Harin, Manusha file FR Petition against SJB
author: Author not found
Content: Ministers Manusha Nanayakkara and Harin Fernando have jointly filed a Fundamental Rights (FR) Petition in the Supreme Court. Their Petition seeks to overturn the decision taken by the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB), to suspend their party memberships and disqualify them from their Parliamentary Seats. SJB General Secretary Ranjith Madduma Bandara is among those named as respondents to the Petition. On 18 July, the SJB Working Committee voted to expel both Fernando and Nanayakkara from the Party. Back in May 2022, the SJB had initially suspended the party memberships of these two parliamentarians after they accepted ministerial roles within the government. This action was taken by the SJB in response to their deviation from party principles. Harin Fernando was appointed as the Minister of Tourism & Lands, while Manusha Nanayakkara was appointed as the Minister of Labour & Foreign Employment. Fernando and Nanayakkara had explained that their decision to take up these ministerial roles under President Gotabaya Rajapaksa, was due to their intention to address the ongoing economic crisis in the country. They mentioned that their efforts towards a collective solution had not received a positive responses from other political party leaders. However, on 9 July 2022, both of them, along with the entire Cabinet, resigned from their ministerial positions following then President Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s announcement of his intention to step down. Interestingly, President Ranil Wickremesinghe, upon forming a new Cabinet on 22 July 2022, reappointed both Fernando and Nanayakkara to the same ministerial portfolios they had previously held.

title: Connecting SP to CEB Main Grid to be finalised by Sunday – Kanchana
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera assured that the remaining tasks, related to the installation of power cables, connecting the Southern Province to the primary transmission line of the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB), will be finalised by Sunday (20). The Minister made this announcement during a special media briefing held at the Ministry premises in Colombo. Challenges regarding the installation of these power cables, which were routed through a private estate in Siripagama, Ratnapura, were resolved on 11 August, the Minister said, adding that the Attygala family, who own the tea estate in question, agreed to the installation without seeking compensation from either the CEB or the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL). “The issue initially arose when the landowners demanded Rs 48 million as compensation based on a private evaluation. Later, they requested Rs 9.6 million following the criteria set by the Asian Development Bank (ADB). In contrast, the CEB proposed a compensation of Rs 1.6 million to cover the loss of land for laying a 630-metre power cable that would establish the connection between the Southern Province and the CEB’s main transmission line,” Wijesekara said. He also emphasised that, contrary to certain claims, there hasn’t been a necessity for scheduled power outages so far. He criticised certain groups for ‘misguiding’ the public on this matter. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Devananda aims to export 50,000 MT of shrimp by year end
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda announced that the Ministry of Fisheries aims to export 50,000 MT of shrimp by the end of this year. However, achieving this goal presents a significant challenge due to the proliferation of fungi and parasites. Urgent measures are necessary to address this issue promptly in order to safeguard the industry and the livelihoods of the farmers, he said. Devananda emphasised that swift action will be taken to resolve the challenges currently faced by shrimp farmers. He further highlighted that the Fisheries Ministry holds the responsibility of enhancing the infrastructure of shrimp farms to elevate their standards. This development is vital as shrimp exports contribute substantially to the country’s foreign income, following products like tea, rubber, and coconut. In a meeting held on 11 August, at the Fisheries Ministry in Colombo, Devananda engaged with representatives of the Sri Lanka Aquaculture Development Alliance (SLADA) to discuss numerous issues affecting the country’s fisheries industry. Devananda shared that SLADA representatives emphasised the need for collaborative research with the National Aquatic Resources Research and Development Agency (NARA) and the National Aquaculture Development Authority (NAQDA) to address the ongoing challenges. The aim is to implement the recommendations of these organisations to mitigate the situation. The Minister directed officials from NAQDA to work closely with NARA officials, facilitating research on the impacted shrimp farms until the procurement orders for necessary equipment are fulfilled. Devananda highlighted that Sri Lankan shrimp holds a strong demand in international fish markets, and safeguarding and advancing this industry is a crucial responsibility of the Government. The Fisheries Minister expressed concerns about potential international efforts to undermine this industry, affirming that the Government is actively monitoring such possibilities. Devananda also voiced apprehension that the disease affecting shrimp farms could resurface, underscoring the need for vigilance among NARA officials. Plans are underway to discuss with President Ranil Wickremesinghe, the possibility of removing import taxes on shrimp feed, further bolstering the industry. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Three new President’s Counsel
author: Author not found
Content: Experienced State officials Ajith Milinda Pathirana – Additional Solicitor General, S.A. Dilrukshi – Legal Draftsman and D. Damayanthi Kulasena – Additional Legal Draftsman accepted their letters of appointment as President’s Counsel yesterday (15) at the Presidential Secretariat.

title: One arrested with prescription drug
author: Author not found
Content: A coordinated search operation, conducted by the Navy and Food and Drug Inspector’s Unit in Anuradhapura on 14 August, led to the arrest of a suspect with 11,377 capsules of Pregabalin 150mg. The prescription drug had been available for sale by illegal means at a pharmacy in front of the Divisional Hospital Medawachchiya, when the arrest was made. The search operation was conducted by SLNS Pandukabhaya in the North -Central Naval Command in coordination with the Food and Drug Inspector’s Unit in Anuradhapura. The suspect held is a 40-year-old resident of the Medawachchiya area. Meanwhile, the suspect along with 11,377 capsules of Pregabalin was handed over to the Food and Drugs Inspector Unit in Anuradhapura for legal action.

title: Samaraweera appointed chair of Nat Heritage Caucus
author: Author not found
Content: MP Jayantha Samaraweera was appointed as the Chair to the Parliamentary Caucus, on safeguarding National Heritage. His name was proposed and seconded by MPs Sisira Jayakody and Weerasumana Weerasinghe, respectively. Meanwhile, State Minister Sisra Jayakody and MP Prof. Channa Jayasumana were appointed as Deputy Chairs of the Caucus.  MP Jayantha Samaraweera was appointed as the Chair to the Parliamentary Caucus, on safeguarding National Heritage. His name was proposed and seconded by MPs Sisira Jayakody and Weerasumana Weerasinghe, respectively. Meanwhile, State Minister Sisra Jayakody and MP Prof. Channa Jayasumana were appointed as Deputy Chairs of the Caucus.  They were proposed by MPs Gamini Waleboda and Udaya Gammanpila, respectively, with MP Wimal Weerawansa having seconded Jayakody’s proposal and MP Upul Mahendra Rajapaksha doing the same for Prof. Jayasumana. Addressing those present, the Chair revealed that the Caucus intends to establish a programme to preserve existing national heritages, as the non-preservation of these heritages have become a national problem. author: Author not found

title: Welfare Benefits Board Chair quits
author: Author not found
Content: Chairman of the Welfare Benefits Board B. Wijayaratne resigned from his post yesterday (15), claiming that there were several reasons behind his resignation that could not be disclosed to the media. Speaking to Ceylon Today, Wijayaratne however said, he had stated in his letter of resignation that he was resigning voluntarily. After his resignation, Retired Sri Lanka Administrative Service (SLAS) special grade officer Jayantha Wijerathne’s name was recommended for the position. Accordingly, President Ranil Wickremesinghe recommended to the Constitutional Council that Wijerathne be appointed as the new WBB chairman, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said. Meanwhile, the chairman who resigned alleged that owing to his resignation, the Aswesuma instalments could not be credited to accounts of beneficiaries as planned. BY Amith Madhuranga Gamage

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: IPESF commences in Colombo
author: Author not found
Content: The Indo-Pacific  Environmental Security Forum (IPESF) 2023, co-hosted by the US lndo- Pacific Command (INDOPACOM), Sri Lanka Navy (SLN) and Sri Lanka Coast Guard (SLCG) commenced at Shangri-La Colombo, on Monday (14). The inauguration of the forum, held in a dignified sequence, was graced by the US Ambassador to Sri Lanka Julie Chung, Senior Adviser to the President on Climate Change, Ruwan Wijewardene, Chief of Defence Staff, General Shavendra Silva, Commander of the Navy, Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera and a host of distinguished invitees. The four-day forum, from 14 to 17 August is also being attended by senior military personnel and top-level environmentalists in the Indo-Pacific region. The 12th edition of Indo-Pacific Environmental Security Forum will include presentations, panel sessions, and group activities to share lessons learnt and best practices among environmental security stakeholders. The first day of the forum focused on the theme ‘Climate Change and Security’ where the stakeholders exchanged views on developing actionable plans to address environmental security challenges. In the remaining days of IPESF 2023, the participants will continue to hold discussions under the themes of Maritime, Ocean and Water Security, Impacts of Urbanisation and Land Security and Building National and Regional Resilience. More than 140 senior officers from defence forces and top-level environmentalists from 28 countries in the Indo-Pacific are also taking part in this year’s Indo-Pacific Environmental Security Forum. Meanwhile, on the directives and guidance of the Commander of the Navy, the Sri Lanka Navy and Sri Lanka Coast Guard have made arrangements for the successful conduct of the event, in close coordination with INDOPACOM.

title: Blackout at NHSL disrupts services
author: Author not found
Content: Services at the National Hospital, Colombo (NHSL) were severely disrupted for nearly 10 hours, due to blackouts in various parts of the Hospital yesterday (14), thus, compromising the services provided in ICUs and theatres. Ceylon Today learns that by 10.00 a.m. yesterday (14) the NHSL started experiencing power outages at intervals in sections of NHSL, Colombo causing even the hospitals telecommunication system and the water supply to be affected in affected areas of the hospital. They noted that, ICU staff, the NHSL Blood Bank and some of the theatres were thrown into a dilemma as a result. Even major surgeries that had been scheduled could not be conducted. Certain operations were conducted by torchlight as theatre staff was faced with the quandary in mid-operation. Even the backup generators were not working during the period. The sources said that should the power crisis continue even after sunset the hospital’s situation would be more chaotic. NHSL has seven administrative officers, while one was in charge of maintenance and making sure that the even the backup generators were in working condition. Sources said that several complaints had been made to the Health Ministry over the months calling for the removal of that particular officer, whose lackadaisical conduct had resulted in hospital services being severely compromised, to no avail. The Hospital needs a more capable Administrative officer to ensure that such problems don’t arise. Even by 6.00 p.m. the power crisis in the hospital had not been settled. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: France to finance technical assistance to Sri Lanka – Pactet
author: Author not found
Content: Ambassador of France Jean-François Pactet, speaking at the 19th Annual General Meeting of the Sri Lanka-France Business Council (SLFBC), of the Ceylon Chamber of Commerce, which was held recently, highlighted France’s assistance in establishing Sri Lanka’s committee of Official Creditors, which it co-chairs with Japan and India and is playing a key role in the restructuring of Sri Lanka’s external official bilateral debt. Ambassador Pactet presenting the economic relations between the two countries, further said that through the French Development Agency (AFD) and the French Ministry of Economy France continues to develop its cooperation through grants in order to finance technical assistance in the agriculture, renewable energy and marine sectors of Sri Lanka. Detailing several planned initiatives in these sectors, Ambassador Pactet added that the Economic Department of the French Embassy is keen to work actively with the SLFBC to continue developing bilateral trade and investment. He mentioned the dynamism of Sri Lankan exports to France in 2022, resulting in a growing trade surplus of 432 million Euros in favour of Sri Lanka and his will to rebalance the bilateral trade by developing French exports to Sri Lanka. President of the SLFBC,  Ashiq Lafir, who was re-elected to lead the Council for the year 2023/24, highlighted the Council’s activities over the past year, including meetings with the new Ambassador, signing of an MOU with the European Chamber of Commerce, networking events as well as activities related to commemorating the 75th anniversary of bilateral relations between France and Sri Lanka. He added that the SLFBC is committed to fostering stronger trade, investment and tourism ties between Sri Lanka and France and looks forward to continuing its efforts in the coming year.(SRM)

title: SJB demands Speaker reveal experts who advised him
author: Author not found
Content: The Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) has raised further inquiries, urging Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana to disclose the identities of the experts he consulted with regard to his ruling on the Domestic Debt Restructuring (DDR) process. Speaking to the media yesterday (14), SJB MP Eran Wickramaratne referred to the ruling and called upon the Speaker to reveal the names of the legal experts he sought counsel from, prior to announcing his decision on the DDR motion in Parliament last week. Wickramaratne expressed the SJB’s interest in knowing the experts’ identities so that they could also engage with them. One of the key questions posed was whether the Speaker possesses the authority to rule on a motion based on legal advice. He offered a hypothetical scenario as an example: “if a motion were passed in Parliament to abolish the judiciary, would the government be legally obligated to implement it, akin to legislation?” Moreover, Wickramaratne proposed an amendment to the existing law, advocating for the introduction of provisions enabling a ‘post judicial review process on Bills’.  He highlighted that Sri Lanka lacks a mechanism for post-judicial review of Bills. Currently, there is no method to ascertain whether amendments made to legislations during the committee stage in the House align with the Constitution. Last week, the Speaker, through his ruling, emphasised that no Court established under Sri Lanka’s Constitution holds the authority to issue orders or judgments against a resolution that has already been approved by Parliament. This declaration has sparked debates over the separation of powers between the legislative and judicial branches of government. As the discussions continue, the SJB seeks clarity on the Speaker’s consultation process with legal experts and hopes to address concerns regarding the interplay between parliamentary decisions and judicial oversight. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Trapped child rescued by Fire Dept
author: Author not found
Content: A seven-year-old girl, who had been trapped between two walls of a school in Kalutara, was rescued by personnel from the fire fighting department of the Kalutara Municipal Council, according to Police. The rescue operation took around 30 minutes. The rescued girl was a grade two student of the Katukurunda Roman Catholic School in Kalutara. According to the Chief Fire Officer, O.V.I.P. Lakshan, the girl had become trapped between the school wall and the toilet system. An emergency ambulance from the Kalutara Municipality’s fire department promptly arrived at the scene. Utilising a specialised device called a ‘spacer’,” the emergency responders were able to carefully push apart the two walls and rescue the girl. BY Sumith Ranawaka – Pothupitiya

title: SDIG Tennakoon’s Fb page hacked
author: Author not found
Content: The official Facebook page of Senior Deputy Inspector General of Police (SDIG) for the Western Province, Deshabandu Tennakoon,  has been hacked. author: Author not found

title: Scanners at BIA departure terminal removed
author: Author not found
Content: In light of the prevailing peaceful environment in the country, authorities have undertaken measures to remove the scanning machines from the entrance of the Departure Terminal at Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA), Katunayake. These scanning machines had been installed at the airport during times of terrorist threats. As a result, significant congestion and traffic had been observed at the departure terminal until recently. This was due to passengers being subjected to scanner checks at three different points within the terminal, leading to considerable inconvenience for those travelling abroad. Consequently, on 8 August, the Airport and Aviation Services (Sri Lanka) Ltd. removed these scanners from their previous locations. This action will not compromise airport security or passenger safety. Instead, passengers will now undergo checks using specialised scanning machines at two specific points before boarding their aircraft, the Airport and Aviation Services (Sri Lanka) Ltd., says. To ensure comprehensive security oversight, a 24-hour monitoring system has been implemented at the airport. This system incorporates a panel equipped with advanced technology security CCTV cameras, totaling 446 in number, positioned throughout the airport. Additionally, the Airport and Aviation Services (Sri Lanka) Ltd. underscores the presence of a discreet airport security team comprising personnel from the armed forces, dressed in civilian attire. This team is actively engaged in surveillance operations within all terminals. The Airport and Aviation Services (Sri Lanka) Ltd. has introduced these measures also in line with the Civil Aviation Authority and International Civil Aviation Regulations, to eliminate inconvenience to the passengers and with an aim to offer efficient and enhanced services to passengers transiting through the terminals. Currently, the number of passengers utilising the terminal for overseas travel surpasses 15,000, as emphasised by the Airport and Aviation Services (Sri Lanka) Ltd. H. S. Hettiarachi, the Chief Manager of the Airport and Aviation Services (Sri Lanka) Ltd., said that the primary objective of these recent measures is to ensure utmost security and to take every possible action in facilitating optimal conveniences for departing and arriving passengers at the airport.

title: COPF displeased with failure to recover losses from Sugar tax scam
author: Author not found
Content: The Committee on Public Finance (COPF) has expressed its displeasure over the failure of the Ministry of Finance, to initiate action to recover the loss incurred through the Sugar Tax Scam in Sri Lanka. During the recent COPF meeting, the Finance Ministry was questioned on the matter. The Committee questioned why the Inland Revenue Department, in consultation with the Attorney General, has not yet taken action in this regard.  Accordingly, the officials present, to represent the Ministry of Finance, stated that they have been updating the Committee on Public Accounts (COPA) regarding the progress and that the Attorney General’s Department has advised that as there was a case pending in this connection, any action could only be taken after the determination of the case. The committee inquired whether action could be instituted if the relevant parties withdraw the pending case in Court. Accordingly, the Committee requested the Attorney General’s Department to inform them regarding the stated concern with immediate effect. The COPF also raised concerns over the failure of the Ministry of Finance to have the Committee informed, regarding the issues raised previously pertaining to the Regulations published in the Gazette issued under the Regulations, under the Imports and Exports Controls Act on wheat flour. The Regulations under the Imports and Exports Control Act, No. 1 of 1969, published in the Gazette Extraordinary No. 2336/45 which was presented to Parliament on July 18, taken up at the Committee on Public Finance dated 21 July 2023, was also taken up for discussion. Unless the order process of wheat flour has begun, the licence for the importation of wheat flour is restricted and the present context has created a flour duopoly. The Committee inquired about the action and progress in this regard, the committee said.  Moreover, the committee took into Consideration the Appropriation (Amendment) Bill 2023 which was approved by the Committee.  The borrowing limit of Rs.4,979 billion has been increased to Rs 13,979 billion under the Appropriation Act No. 43 of 2022. Accordingly, 9,000 billion rupees for re-issuance of debt ceiling needs have been revised. As a provision to the Department of Treasury Operations for repayment of loans of Rs 4,222.23 billion to Rs 13,222.23 billion expenditure limits will be increased by amending subsection 2 (4) of the Act and the Second Schedule. State Minister Dr. Suren Raghavan, MPs Major Pradeep Undugoda, M. A. Sumanthiran, Isuru Dodangoda, Kavinda Jayawardhana, Duminda Dissanayake, Rauff Hakeem, Premnath C. Dolawatte, Harshana Rajakaruna, Madhura Withanage, Chandima Weerakkody and Mayantha Dissanayake were present at the committee meeting.

title: Three arrested over attack on Prison officer
author: Author not found
Content: Three individuals were arrested, by the Homicide and Organised Crimes Division of the Police, in connection with the recent assault on a prison officer attached to the Galle Prison. The arrests, which occurred on 13 August, led to the confiscation of a three-wheeler and a motorcycle that had been used by the attackers. The detainees, whose ages range from 19 to 30, were taken into custody across locations in Weligama, Midigama, and Ahangama.  They were scheduled to appear before the Matara Magistrate’s Court yesterday (14). The incident transpired on 5 August when a group of ten individuals assaulted a 43-year-old prison officer of the Galle Prison while he was on his way home in a bus.  The assailants, wearing masks and armed with firearms, reportedly boarded the bus at the Weligama halt and carried out the attack.
