title: Pakistan’s 76th independence Day celebrated in Colombo
author: Author not found
Content: The High Commission of Pakistan and the Pakistani community in Sri Lanka celebrated Pakistan’s 76th Independence Day with traditional fervour and resolve to make Pakistan a strong, dynamic progressive tolerant and democratic Islamic welfare State. The High Commissioner of the Islamic Republic of Pakistan in Sri Lanka, Major General (Retd) Umar Farooq Burki HI (M) hoisted the National Flag of Pakistan in an impressive ceremony at the Pakistan High Commission in Colombo. The special messages of the President and the Prime Minister of Pakistan were read out to the audience. In his message on the occasion, the High Commissioner of Pakistan expressed his gratitude to “our gracious hosts, the beautiful nation of Sri Lanka, for providing us the opportunity to celebrate our independence on their soil.” He added that the bond between Pakistan and Sri Lanka runs deep in history, with shared values, and unwavering support for one another. “We are truly blessed to have such a steadfast friend in our journey towards progress and development.” He further said, “at the bilateral level, while we continue to nurture our diplomatic defence and cultural ties, we are exploring ways to broaden and deepen our economic connectivity, through enhancing trade and bilateral investment within the framework of the Free Trade Agreement that exists between the two countries.”  The event was well-attended by a good number of participants, including the Pakistani Diaspora, officials and families of the High Commission, local dignitaries, journalists and friends of Pakistan.

title: A Beacon of Hope for the Underprivileged
author: Author not found
Content: Security Force Headquarters  Mullaitivu (SFHQ-MLT) is responsible for coordinating and overseeing military operations, and maintenance of peace and security in Mullaitivu and Kilinochchi Districts. Being one of the regional command entities of the Army, in addition to its above-specified roles, the SFHQ-Mullaitivu has been effectively engaged in a multitude of community-oriented projects in order to boost existing civil-military relations further.  In the Mullaitivu region, where hope intertwines with hardship, a dedicated endeavour exists to alleviate the plight of needy families by providing them with safe and secure shelters. Recognising the fundamental right of every individual to a dignified living space, this initiative aimed to empower those facing adversity and help them regain their footing in life.  In addressing the multi-faceted challenges faced by needy families in Mullaitivu, on the directions of successive Commanders of the Army, the Security Force Headquarters – Mullaitivu with the support, extended by non-governmental organisations, humanitarian agencies, and local community groups has undertaken the responsibility to lend a helping hand to alleviate most burning issues, very much caused due to homelessness. The Army has throughout worked tirelessly to provide families with decent and affordable housing options, aiming to break the cycle of poverty and vulnerability.  To this date, Mullaitivu troops to their credit with their technical expertise and manpower had constructed 207 houses for deserving civilians and vested them in needy families. At present, construction of four more such new houses for the poor is underway under the guidance and selfless efforts of the Mullaitivu Commander, respective General Officers Commanding and Brigade Commanders serving under the Security Force HQ – Mullaitivu. During 2009 – 2023, Troops built those new houses for the underprivileged in Mullaitivu and Kilinochchi areas.  Housing programmes in the Mullaitivu area have made a significant difference in the lives of many poverty-ridden families. Through the Army’s dedication and commitment, these initiatives have borne fruit and turned beacons of hope, offering families a chance to rebuild their lives and envision a brighter future.  The Army, well-determined to create a better tomorrow for those poverty-stricken people in the Mullaitivu region by healing the wounds of deprived sections of our society, has round the clock lent their helping hand generously to the people in Mullaitivu in an attempt to promote ethnic harmony, reconciliation and peaceful environment in the country.

title: Japan spends USD 88,819 to develop two schools
author: Author not found
Content: Japan’s Ambassador in Sri Lanka Hideaki Mizukoshi, on 11 August, attended the handing over ceremony of two new school buildings in Kilinochchi, built with Japanese aid at a cost of USD 88,819, Japan’s Embassy in Sri Lanka said in a statement. The two new buildings are located at No-02 G.T.M School, Skanthapuram Village, Karachchi Division in the Kilinochchi District. It was implemented by an NGO under the Japanese Government’s Grassroots Human Security Grant Aid (GHSGA), it said. “Skanthapuram village was cleared of mines through Japanese grant assistance under the GHSGA, it added. “The project will improve the learning environment for approximately 250 students. The two school buildings, included a library and a classroom for students with special needs with a view to support families who have resettled in the mine-cleared areas,” the statement added. In addition, the project also supported the provision of equipment such as classroom tables and chairs, the Embassy further said.The project will contribute to students in the community to have a better access to quality education at school through the improved learning environment, the statement further said. The Embassy of Japan in Sri Lanka will continue to provide necessary support for sustainable development in Sri Lanka, the statement said in conclusion.(PA)

title: Document chewing lawyer allowed bail
author: Author not found
Content: Kekirawa Chief Magistrate Senarath Bandara recently enlarged on surety bail, in Rs 200,000, a female lawyer, who had been remanded on charges of damaging two documents signed and certified by the Government Analyst, related to a land dispute case being heard in the Court. The suspect, identified as Roshini Abeyratne, a resident of Sekkupitiya, Kekirawa, had attempted to forcibly take away the two documents certified by the GA and when her attempt had been thwarted, she had chewed the documents destroying them in the process. The Chief Magistrate also instructed the Kekirawa Police to submit a progress report on the case to him on 1 November. BY Upali Karunadasa — Anuradhapura

title: Lankans among 160 illegal migrants detained by Poland
author: Author not found
Content: Individuals from Sri Lanka were among a group of 160 illegal migrants apprehended by Polish border guards, while attempting to enter Poland from Belarus on 12 August, according Sky News. Polish media, citing border officials, has disclosed that the group, attempting to cross into Poland, included citizens from Somalia, Egypt, Ethiopia, and Sri Lanka. Additionally, the reports indicate that three Ukrainian nationals were arrested for aiding four Syrian and three Bangladeshi individuals in their attempted entry into Poland. This development further adds to the tally of over 500 individuals who have been detained this year for their involvement in facilitating illegal border crossings. The events of Saturday align with the overall trend that Polish authorities have been highlighting in recent weeks, indicating a significant rise in attempted crossings this year. The head of the Polish border guard has revealed that since January, a staggering 19,000 people have endeavoured to unlawfully cross the border. This figure marks a notable increase from the 16,000 attempts recorded throughout the entirety of the previous year. The surge in illegal border crossings has prompted officials to formally request 1,000 troops from the Polish Government to bolster border security earlier this week. In response, the government dispatched double that number of troops last Wednesday, aiming to curb illegal crossings and ensure stability along the border.

title: Three Iranians fined Rs 4.4M each
author: Author not found
Content: Udugama Magistrate, Udari Anupama Gunasekara, presided over the case involving three Iranian nationals and a Sri Lankan who were caught attempting to remove living and non-living animals and plant materials from the Sinharaja Forest without a valid permit. The suspects faced a total of 44 charges filed by wildlife officials. The Magistrate ruled that the three Iranians, namely Mohommad Erfan Arsalan, Fironzi Arsalan, and Hassangholi Arabzdeh, should pay a fine of Rs 4.4 million each. Additionally, a cumulative fine of Rs 132 million was imposed on them. The trial against Don Ashen Madhuranga Abeysekera, a resident of Kandana Hapugoda, who was the driver of the vehicle they arrived in, is still ongoing. The case report was compiled considering records obtained from the Entomology Section of the Department of National Museums and Peradeniya Botanical Gardens. The suspects were arrested by wildlife officials on 28 June evening near the Lankagama ticket counter, while they were attempting to enter the Sinharaja Reserve within the Neluwa forest. They were arrested on charges of possessing and transporting living and non-living plant materials without the required permit. Wildlife officials highlighted that this fine stands as the highest-ever imposed in the history of the department. By Farhan Nizamdeen – Galle and S. Deeyagamage – Ahangama

title: SLAF stays mum on Gota’s visit to Maldives following protests
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Air Force (SLAF) has been persistently delaying the implementation of the Right to Information Commission (RTIC) ruling regarding information concerning President Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s visit to the Maldives on an Air Force aircraft on 13 July of the previous year. On 1 June, the RTIC issued a directive to the SLAF, mandating that the “Air Commodore release this information by 4 July.” This ruling was also communicated to the SLAF via post. Despite the passage of 35 days since the deadline set by the RTIC, the SLAF is yet to provide the requested information. During this period, the SLAF has approached the RTIC on five separate occasions, between 2 July and 7 August, to seek an extension of the deadline. In the request letters, Air Commodore E.W.R. Jayewardene, the Information Officer of the SLAF, said, “We are seeking this extension to ensure accurate preparation of the information in a comprehensive manner.” The circumstances surrounding former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s visit to the Maldives drew international attention as he had travelled there shortly after protestors occupied both the President’s House and the Presidential Secretariat on 9 July, following a major demonstration in Colombo. Initially, both the Information Officer and the Designated Officer for RTI at Air Force Headquarters rejected the Right to Information (RTI) application seeking details about the former President’s visit to the Maldives. They cited Section 5 (1) (b) (i) of the Right to Information Act No. 12 of 2016 as the basis for not releasing the requested information. However, after four inquiry sessions, the RTIC issued a ruling requiring the release of information related to former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s visit to the Maldives. By Rifthi Ali

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Four injured in bowser – jeep collision
author: Author not found
Content: Four were hospitalised following a head-on collision, involving a jeep and a fuel bowser, on the Hatton-Nuwara Eliya road on Saturday (12). The accident occurred around 10:00 p.m. on 12 August, at the Dimbulapathana Junction. The jeep travelling from Norwood to Talawakelle collided with the bowser whichwas travelling in the opposite direction, from Welimada to Kotagala, according to Police. The injured individuals, all occupants of the jeep, aged between 20 and 30 years, sustained severe injuries in the accident and were admitted to the Dickoya Base Hospital. The driver of the jeep, who was among the hospitalised foursome, was allegedly under the influence of alcohol at the time of the collision, according to Police.

title: Don’t expect increase in apparel revenue
author: Author not found
Content: As economic issues prevail in Europe and the US, Sri Lanka should not expect substantial revenue from the apparel industry and foreign employment this year, President Ranil Wickremesinghe said. He was speaking at the 150th Anniversary celebration of St. Thomas’ College, Matale yesterday (13). “To propel the nation’s economic development, an annual inflow of at least USD 1 billion is essential. The initial step toward achieving this goal involves increasing foreign exchange inflows from existing sectors,” he said. President Wickremesinghe further said, “Our primary income sources are foreign employment and export earnings. Unfortunately, the economic situation in countries like Europe and America, particularly affecting the garment industry, has shown regression. Consequently, we shouldn’t anticipate substantial revenue from these sectors this year. Thus, our attention must pivot to tourism. Accordingly, we have devised comprehensive plans to significantly enhance our country’s tourism sector throughout this year and the following year.” Additionally, there is a pressing need to double our export revenue. To achieve this, attracting investors and providing them with the requisite facilities is essential. New initiatives such as the development of the Port City have been set in motion. Further, advancing rapidly over the next decade with technologies like Artificial Intelligence is paramount; our success or failure hinges on our ability to maintain this momentum, he pointed out. President Wickremesinghe highlighted that resolving the country’s economic challenges goes beyond the success of the debt optimisation programme. He emphasised the need to promptly initiate an economy-building strategy guided by sound decisions. He cautioned that failure to proactively adopt a new programme would inevitably result in the country facing another economic hurdle within a decade. The President expressed his vision of propelling the country forward through comprehensive modernisation. To achieve this, he announced the establishment of the Technology Promotion Council and the Digital Transformation Commission, aimed at accelerating the nation’s digital evolution. Further, the President unveiled a commemorative plaque that marked the school’s 150th Anniversary. He also posed for a group photograph with the Alumni Association of the school. During the same occasion, the President presented certificates to students who topped the district in exams.

title: Indian couple arrested with forged passports at BIA
author: Author not found
Content: An Indian couple, originating from Tibet, was arrested at BIA, Katunayake by the Border Surveillance Unit of the Immigration and Emigration Department for attempting to fly to the Netherlands using counterfeit passports. Both individuals, aged 43, hail from different Indian States – the man from Karnataka and the woman from Uttarakhand. Their endeavour involved utilising two falsified Chinese passports in their bid to reach the Netherlands. On investigation, it was revealed that the couple had been residing in Sri Lanka since 26 June, holding tourist visas. Their planned route involved a journey to Kuwait, followed by onward travel to the Netherlands. However, a pivotal moment arose when suspicions were raised at the Jazeera Airways counter. Subsequently, the Immigration and Emigration officials examined their travel documents, exposing the use of fraudulent Chinese passports. During the inspection of their belongings, authentic Indian passports were found, corroborating their true identities. The couple admitted that they had paid an individual USD 6,000 to obtain the two counterfeit passports. Subsequently, the couple was transferred to the custody of the CID officials stationed at the airport for an in-depth investigation. By T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: CEB limits power generation to peak hours
author: Author not found
Content: With the water levels of the Samanalawewa Reservoir experiencing a further decline, strategies are being devised to curtail power generation at the power plant beyond 15 August. The Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) has outlined a plan to confine power generation to peak demand periods for electricity, postulating measures to manage the reduced water capacity. In a move aimed at optimising resources, the CEB has outlined plans to divert the water utilised for power generation to the Udawalawa Reservoir. During periods of non-generation, the CEB has been consistently releasing 25 million cubic metres of water into the Udawalawa Reservoir. As per the revised blueprint, the CEB aims to limit power generation solely to peak hours until 20 August. As of yesterday afternoon (13), the Samanalawewa power plant was utilising a single generator, capable of producing 60 MW.

title: Another medicinal drug death reported – (MCPA)
author: Author not found
Content: Within 48-hours of Dedunu Committee submitting its report on the probe into the deaths, that occurred allegedly due to ‘substandard’ medicinal drugs, another death, which showed a similar pattern was reported from the Gampaha Base Hospital, the Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association (MCPA) claimed. MCPA President Dr. Chamal Sanjeewa claimed the reported cause of this most recent death was linked to a complication following the eleventh dosage of group 4 antibiotic known as Ceftazidime. He stressed that the Health Ministry ought to provide a clarification on whether it is within the realm of normalcy for nearly ten deaths, allegedly caused by allergies, to transpire within a mere three-month span. Immediate disclosure is warranted on whether patients in Sri Lanka are being utilised for medical experimentation, Dr. Sanjeewa said. “The investigation committee, appointed by the Minister of Health to scrutinise drug-related deaths, has affirmed that the primary cause for most of these fatalities was drug allergies. Interestingly, the Ministry has acknowledged that the complete report was not published. As per the relevant report, it has been disclosed that the root cause of these deaths is not substandard drugs, but rather allergic reactions to the medications. This situation is also posing a question mark in the eyes of healthcare professionals,” he asserted. “Over the past three months, the collective count of deaths, allergic reactions, and cases of blindness, attributed to antibiotics, anesthetics, and eye drops, is approaching 40. Hospital records additionally indicate that nearly ten patients have succumbed to allergies. The Ministry of Health has maintained that the demise of these patients is not linked to the quality of the drugs, but rather to complications and allergic responses,” he added Speaking further, he emphasised that if anyone deems it normal for almost ten patients to die due to medication in a very brief period, they should undergo an independent medical evaluation. He also pointed out that in the 74 years since gaining independence, such a distressing number of deaths due to drug allergies within a condensed timeframe has not been observed. Dr. Sanjeewa further highlighted that this situation is far from ordinary, remarking that the Ministry of Health has become a source of amusement for the public due to the selective media releases that aim to downplay real issues. Dr. Sanjeewa asserted that the Ministry of Health should promptly issue a statement clarifying whether patients in Sri Lanka are being subjected to medical tests, especially during economic difficulties, whether knowingly or unknowingly. He underscored the importance of citizens seeking legal recourse against such arbitrary actions and highlighted the necessity of strengthening the governmental system, through proper legal channels, to address politicians and public officials who are found culpable. BY Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: O/L exam to be conducted in Grade 10?
author: Author not found
Content: Education Minister Susil Premajayantha announced that the Ministry of Education is actively exploring the option of conducting the G.C.E. Ordinary Level (O/L) examination in Grade 10 of schooling. Speaking at an event held at Royal College, Colombo, he said historically, students used to face the O/L Examination in Grade 10, but it was later changed to Grade 11. At present, discussions are underway within the Ministry to potentially move the examination back to Grade 10. Minister Premajayantha explained that this adjustment would be implemented in three stages, encompassing primary, junior secondary, and senior secondary levels, covering Grades 1 through 6 and 10. He underlined the importance of adapting education to the rapidly evolving landscape of knowledge and society. Acknowledging the swift pace of change, he stated that necessary updates are being introduced. Further, Minister Premajayantha highlighted the need for a transformative shift in education. He emphasised the significance of providing the upcoming generation with a strong foundation that empowers them to make independent choices about their future pathways after completing the A/L examination.

title: CAA earnings from raids surpass Rs 132.6M
author: Author not found
Content: In the initial half of 2023, the Consumer Affairs Authority (CAA) reported the successful collection of over Rs 132.6 million through its vigilant shop raids. Throughout this period, a comprehensive tally of 13,493 raids were executed nationwide, with a significant 2,411 raids being carried out exclusively in June. Convictions in these instances resulted in fines totalling Rs 23.6 million. Further, the Consumer Affairs Authority said during the month of July, they intensified their efforts with 18 extensive raids. These actions were directed towards issues including, but not limited to, improper price display, the sale of goods above regulated prices, and the distribution of expired products.

title: Heroic railway gatekeepers prevent collision
author: Author not found
Content: The adept actions of the railway gatekeeper and the assistant gatekeeper played a crucial role in preventing a potential catastrophe at the Yangalmodara level crossing. As a prime mover, transporting a container and bound for Polgahawela, traversed the Yangalmodara railway crossing along the Colombo-Kurunegala main road, a critical situation emerged. Simultaneously, an inter-city express train, en route from Kandy to Colombo, was approaching on the same track. Responding swiftly to the imminent danger, the vigilant gatekeepers, armed with warning signal flags, positioned themselves on the train’s trajectory. Signalling a hazard ahead, they effectively communicated the urgency to the train driver, leading to a prompt reduction in the train’s speed. Concurrently, the assistant gatekeeper supported the driver in clearing a halted vehicle from the road, averting a potential catastrophe. By Jayantha Dissanayake – Boyawalana

title: Colombo Judicial Medical Office suspends Dr. Haq after eight months
author: Author not found
Content: The Colombo Judicial Medical Office suspended the services of Judicial Medical Officer, Dr. Ruhul Haq mid last week, adhering to an order received from the Sri Lanka Medical Council (SLMC) which suspended his registration for eight months since 20 December 2022. The suspension order will end this Sunday (20) while Dr. Haq allegedly issued two controversial post-mortem reports during his suspension, informed sources said. The Health Ministry, during an emergency media briefing, said Dr. Haq had received a suspension order from the SLMC for a case that had occurred 14 years earlier while he was serving in Nuwara Eliya.  However, informed sources added that Dr. Haq, having allegedly gotten into a heated argument with a person named S.A. Rathnasena, had involved him in a legal procedure that had lasted for a prolonged period. The complaint was filed with the SLMC only in 2019, they said. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Harry Jayawardena wins IP battle with Apple
author: Author not found
Content: A recent development in the Commercial High Court of Colombo involves the dismissal of a lawsuit brought by Apple Inc. against Stassen Exports Ltd. The case, numbered HC (Civil) 1/2020/IP and filed in 2020, aimed to nullify Stassen Exports’ ‘Hana Tea’ Trademark which prominently featured an image of a ‘bitten apple’. The dismissal came under the ruling of Judge Pradeep Hettiarachchi, accompanied by penalty costs amounting to 500 per cent. In response to the lawsuit, Stassen Exports submitted a comprehensive counterargument, outlining several key points. Those key points were Stassen Exports legally obtained registration of its ‘Hana Tea’ Trademark (No. 180551) for the category of ‘Tea’ under Class 30, effective from 23 May 2013, Apple Inc., being an Information Technology Company from the USA, is not involved in the sale of food or beverage items, including tea-related products, no direct competition or unfair competition exists between the products of the Plaintiff and the Defendant, given their vastly different natures and scopes and Stassen Exports’ ‘Hana Tea’ Trademark is distinct and not indicative of Apple’s products. Also, it was outlined the Plaintiff cannot claim exclusive rights over an image of an apple with a bite taken out, as this symbol is universally recognised and cannot be attributed solely to Apple and the Defendant highlighted instances where Apple Inc. has faced regulatory actions and legal challenges from customers and competitors. As part of the legal process, Stassen Exports presented interrogatories to the Plaintiff, seeking clarifications on various matters. They were whether Apple Inc. sells any food or beverage products, specifically tea, if Apple Inc. has a product range involving food, beverages, or tea, if Apple Inc. holds a registration for the apple mark under Class 30 of the International Classification, whether Apple Inc. has faced consumer lawsuits or regulatory actions in the past decade, if there were such cases, details and outcomes of these legal actions, whether Apple Inc. settled a litigation by agreeing to pay up to USD 500 million in relation to older iPhones’ performance, awareness of specific news articles pertaining to Apple Inc.’s actions and fines, whether French antitrust regulators fined Apple Inc. for anti-competitive behaviour and familiarity with news articles on Apple Inc.’s disputes over trademarks in China and Australia. Despite repeated postponements to respond, Apple Inc. failed to provide answers within the allocated timeframe. On 31 July 2023, the Plaintiff informed the Court of their inability to produce an affidavit to address the interrogatories. Consequently, the Court dismissed Apple Inc.’s action and ordered them to pay penalty costs for their failure to respond to the Defendant’s inquiries. In the courtroom, President’s Counsel Dr. Harsha Cabraal represented Apple Inc., accompanied by Nishan Premathiratne, Attorney-at-Law from Julius & Creasy, Attorneys at Law. On the side of Stassen Exports, President’s Counsel Nihal Fernando was assisted by Harshula Seneviratne, Attorney-at-Law, under the guidance of Upendra Gunasekera, Attorney-at-Law.

title: Export restrictions on public transport vehicles to be lifted
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance, Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said that while vehicle imports have been suspended owing to the ongoing economic challenges, there are plans to ease import restrictions for specific vehicles primarily employed for public transportation and cargo conveyance. Addressing the media in Ruwanwella, Siyambalapitiya said that a Gazette Notification, outlining the relaxation of import constraints on lorries, trucks and buses, designated for public transport, will be issued within the current week. Siyambalapitiya went on to explain that this decision is in alignment with the ongoing economic revival that the country is presently experiencing. Sri Lanka halted vehicle imports to face the economic crisis in the country.

title: COPA instructs CSD to prepare action plan
author: Author not found
Content: Chairman of the Committee on Public Accounts (COPA) Lasantha Alagiyawanna instructed the Civil Security Department (CSD) to prepare a programme of action. State Minister Alagiyawanna gave these instructions at the COPA meeting, held recently, to examine the Auditor General’s report and current performance of the Civil Defence Department for the years 2019/2020/2021. Alagiyawanna recommended that a report be given to COPA with a date before 11 September regarding the preparation of a legal framework regarding the Civil Security Department to suit the State budget. Officials pointed out that there has been no recruitment to the Civil Security Department for three-and-a-half years and that the Civil Security Force has now been designated as an attrition force. They also pointed out that 33,87 people are currently working in the Civil Security Force and also mentioned places and services where the people are assigned. The Secretary of the Ministry of Defence Kamal Gunaratne gave an explanation about the formation of this force and how it was done. State Ministers Prasanna Ranaweera, Chamara Sampath Dasanayake, Diana Gamage and MPs Tissa Attanayake, Niroshan Perera, Hector Appuhamy, Sahan Pradeep Withana, Isuru Dodangoda, Jayantha Ketagoda, Major Pradeep Undugoda were present at the committee meeting.

title: Susil presents certificates at Roots Salon graduation
author: Author not found
Content: Education Minister Susil Premajayantha presented certificates to individuals trained at the Roots Hair and Beauty Salon and Academy. This institution is endorsed by the Tertiary and Vocational Education Commission. The certificate ceremony took place at the Shangri-La Hotel in Colombo.

title: Navy conducts blood donation campaign in Talaimannar
author: Author not found
Content: As part of its social responsibility initiatives, the Navy organised a blood donation campaign at SLNS Thammanna in Talaimannar on 12 August. The donation campaign was held to replenish the stocks of the blood transfusion centre of District General Hospital, Mannar. The magnanimous initiative was held on the directives of Navy Commander, Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera and under the supervision of Commander North Central Naval Area, Rear Admiral Kanchana Banagoda. The blood transfusion centre of District General Hospital, Mannar turned to the Sri Lanka Navy for the successful coordination of the event, in which naval personnel from SLNS Thammanna, SLNS Gajaba and SLNS Pussadewa donated blood voluntarily. Further, medical staff of the District General Hospital, Mannar and Command Hospital of North Central Naval Command supported the cause.

title: Severe drought dries up Senanayake Samudraya
author: Author not found
Content: Senanayake Samudraya, the major irrigation scheme in Ampara District with a capacity of 770,000 acre-feet of water that irrigates all paddy fields in Ampara District, has experienced a significant decline to 154,000 acre-feet of water. Additionally, the water level of the tank, which was at 110 feet, has now dropped to 62.5 feet. This has dealt a severe blow to the local population, raising concerns that the water level might further decrease. While crops in certain areas are on the brink of perishing, many people in other areas are facing many challenges, including a scarcity of drinking water. If the drought persists, the situation is expected to worsen. According to Deputy Director of Disaster Management, M.A.C.M. Riyas, the Divisional Secretariat areas of Addalaichenai, Maha Oya, Lahugala, Thirukkovil, and Alayadivembu are the worst affected. To address their drinking water problems, Rs 2.1 million has been allocated to supply water through bowsers to these areas, on the recommendation of District Secretary Chinthaka Abeywickrema. The Pradeshiya Sabhas in the District have been instructed to deploy their bowsers to provide drinking water to those in need. Riyas said arrangements have also been made to provide water to livestock. By M.A.P. Deen – Ampara

title: Lankans involved in Türkiye bus accident recovering
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lankan workers who were involved in a bus accident in Türkiye on 9 August are now receiving medical attention and are on the road to recovery, according to a statement from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The incident occurred when a shuttle bus, carrying Sri Lankan workers, veered off the road and tumbled down a 6-metre cliff in the Eyüpsultan District of Istanbul. The workers were returning to their accommodations after completing their shifts on a construction project at Istanbul Airport. Among the 29 Sri Lankans who were in the accident, nine are presently undergoing treatment at different hospitals in Istanbul, as stated by the Foreign Ministry. The remaining 20, who were also hospitalised, were discharged on the same day. The Embassy of Sri Lanka in Ankara has maintained continuous communication with both the employing company and hospital authorities to stay updated on the condition of the injured individuals. They have been providing necessary support in collaboration with the relevant company. Further, the embassy is in contact with the Foreign Ministry of Türkiye to keep abreast of the ongoing investigation into the incident and to offer assistance to the affected Sri Lankans. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs has emphasised its active monitoring of the situation and its implementation of necessary actions in coordination with the Embassy in Ankara to ensure the recovery and well-being of the affected Sri Lankans.

title: Lanka Coffee Association successfully concludes AGM
author: Author not found
Content: The Lanka Coffee Association (LCA), Sri Lanka’s only national coffee association in promoting and advancing the coffee sector in Sri Lanka, is pleased to announce the successful conclusion of its AGM. The event, held recently at Taj Samudra, Colombo, brought together key stakeholders, industry experts, and coffee enthusiasts to deliberate on the state of the coffee sector and chart a course for its sustainable growth and development. The AGM proved to be a significant gathering, attracting a diverse audience including coffee growers, exporters, importers, processors, researchers, and cafes. This year’s AGM aimed not only to reflect on the accomplishments and challenges faced by the association and the industry in the past year but also to set a robust agenda for the year ahead. Rinosh Nasar, the Outgoing Chairperson of the Lanka Coffee Association, expressed his gratitude for the collective efforts of all stakeholders and their commitment to the industry’s growth. He remarked, “The Annual General Meeting serves as a testament to the dedication and unity within the coffee community. With a shared vision, we are confident in our ability to navigate challenges and seize opportunities that lie ahead.” A new Executive Committee was appointed at the AGM with Kushan Samararatne (Colombo Coffee Company) taking over as the Chairperson and Ashane Perera (J.M. Robertson & Co) being appointed as the Secretary. M.I. Izzadeen (Elpitiya Plantations) and Tharanga Muramudali (Helanta Coffee) continue for another term as the Vice President and Treasurer, respectively. The Executive Committee members for the year 2023/24 also consist of Shelton Thenuwara (Tree of Life), Asanka Kangana (Upcountry Brothers), and Najee Suraj (Aga Coffee). Kushan Samararatne, the incumbent Chairperson said, “The LCA has quite undoubtedly left a mark on the sector and has now established itself as a key player in the industry. The next year will be focused on uplifting the sector by further developing the Sri Lankan Coffee identity on a global stage through our various flagship events such as the Coffee Festival and also serving as a collective voice in advocating for the proper policy frameworks to be established both on a State and private sector level to ensure Sri Lankan coffee is of the highest quality and is able to meet the growing international market requirements.” The successful conclusion of the Annual General Meeting marks a significant milestone for the Lanka Coffee Association and the broader coffee industry in Sri Lanka. The association remains steadfast in its mission to foster a sustainable, innovative, and globally competitive coffee sector.

title: Navy rescues seven fishers on fire-hit trawler
author: Author not found
Content: In a dramatic operation, the Sri Lanka Navy rescued seven fishermen, who were on a local fishing trawler that caught fire about 58 nautical miles (approximately 107 km) off the Galle Lighthouse, west of Sri Lanka, on 11 August. The operation was mounted in coordination with the Maritime Rescue Coordinating Centre (MRCC) Colombo. The rescued fishermen were brought to the Galle Harbour on 12 August by SLNS Gajabahu. The distressed trawler ‘Ruhunu Kumari 6’ (IMUL-A-0738-CHW), had been at sea for a routine fishing expedition, having left Wennappuwa on 8 August. In an unfortunate turn of events, it had caught fire whilst at sea west of Sri Lanka and the Crude Oil Tanker MT SAIQ, having seen the fishing trawler in trouble, disseminated the distress call to MRCC Colombo at the Navy Headquarters. Responding swiftly to the distress call, SLNS Gajabahu was dispatched to the scene, following the directives of Navy Commander, Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera. Until the arrival of SLNS Gajabahu, the Bulk Carrier MV AFRICAN TURACO was directed to the scene and it had rescued fishermen from the fire-hit trawler. Having reached the coordinates, SLNS Gajabahu safely transferred the distressed fishermen from MV AFRICAN TURACO and brought them to Galle Harbour while administering first aid. Further, in collaboration with MRCC Colombo located at the Navy Headquarters, the Sri Lanka Navy remains continuously vigilant to offer assistance to any maritime distress situations within the Search and Rescue Region of Sri Lanka.

title: Directive issued to streamline passenger security checks at BIA
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Ports, Shipping, and Aviation, Nimal Siripala de Silva, has issued a directive to streamline passenger security checks at the Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA)in Katunayake, bringing them to a single location. This move aims to mitigate delays and inconveniences faced by passengers. The minister has mandated a comprehensive security screening of passengers at one designated point. This approach ensures that national security remains uncompromised while alleviating the inconvenience currently caused by the dual security checks that passengers must undergo at the airport. During a review meeting, while discussing matters between Airport and Aviation Services Pvt. Ltd. and SriLankan Airlines, as well as the progress within the aviation industry, the minister instructed relevant officials to initiate this consolidated process starting from September. Additionally, the necessary infrastructure facilities required for this transition are already in progress, the Minister confirmed. Furthermore, he underscored the importance of collaborative efforts between Airport and Aviation Services Pvt. Ltd. and SriLankan Airlines. He emphasised that the advancement of Sri Lanka’s aviation sector is contingent on the effective coordination of these two entities’ joint operations.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Directive issued to streamline passenger security checks at BIA
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Ports, Shipping, and Aviation, Nimal Siripala de Silva, has issued a directive to streamline passenger security checks at the Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA)in Katunayake, bringing them to a single location. This move aims to mitigate delays and inconveniences faced by passengers. The minister has mandated a comprehensive security screening of passengers at one designated point. This approach ensures that national security remains uncompromised while alleviating the inconvenience currently caused by the dual security checks that passengers must undergo at the airport. During a review meeting, while discussing matters between Airport and Aviation Services Pvt. Ltd. and SriLankan Airlines, as well as the progress within the aviation industry, the minister instructed relevant officials to initiate this consolidated process starting from September. Additionally, the necessary infrastructure facilities required for this transition are already in progress, the Minister confirmed. Furthermore, he underscored the importance of collaborative efforts between Airport and Aviation Services Pvt. Ltd. and SriLankan Airlines. He emphasised that the advancement of Sri Lanka’s aviation sector is contingent on the effective coordination of these two entities’ joint operations.

title: Police probe child’s hanging
author: Author not found
Content: The police have initiated a thorough inquiry into the suspicious demise of a nine-year-old girl in the Iranawila locality of Chilaw. Prompted by a complaint from the girl’s father, who stated that his daughter had been admitted to Chilaw Hospital after a hanging attempt, the Police have launched an extensive investigation. The girl’s mother is currently overseas. The post-mortem examination and the Magistrate’s assessment of the body was taken up yesterday (13). According to the Police, efforts are being made to ascertain whether this incident is a case of murder or suicide.

title: Minister Alles discusses Police powers with TNA
author: Author not found
Content: A meeting aimed at addressing concerns and exploring potential solutions, regarding the provision of Police powers according to the 13th Amendment to the Constitution, took place between a delegation of MPs from the Tamil National Alliance (TNA), Public Security Minister Tiran Alles and the Inspector General of Police (IGP), the Ministry of Public Security said. During the meeting, held on Wednesday (9), Minister Alles inquired about the reasons behind the TNA’s request for Police powers. In response, the TNA MPs underscored that even in well-developed nations like the UK and India, the devolution of powers had been executed exceptionally well. They explained that similar systems utilised in those countries could be adapted for implementation in Sri Lanka as well. In response, Minister Alles highlighted the marked differences in Sri Lanka’s political and social culture compared to those nations and said it was necessary to explore alternative approaches to addressing the concerns raised by the TNA, without resorting to devolving Police powers. Furthermore, the Minister questioned the rationale behind the Tamil people’s and political leaders’ call for the implementation of the 13th Amendment to the Constitution. The TNA MPs conveyed the challenges they encountered in travelling long distances from their districts to Colombo for the implementation of decisions made by district committees. They also pointed out issues related to the execution of decisions by certain Governors. Additionally, the TNA MPs emphasised the significance of establishing a Provincial Police Commission in conjunction with the existing National Police Commission. They highlighted escalating worries about drug trafficking and crime, especially among the youth, in the northern region. In response, Minister Alles assured the TNA members that pertinent information regarding these matters would be shared with the specialised Police Committee headed by Western Province SDIG Deshabandu Tennakoon for combating the drug menace and underworld activities. The meeting was attended by the Secretary of the Ministry of Public Security Viyani Gunathilaka, Western Province SDIG Deshabandu Tennakoon and other senior Police Officers. Representing the TNA were MPs M.A. Sumanthiran, Shanakiyan Rasamanickam, Dharmalingam Siddarthan, Charles Nirmalanathan, and Selvam Adaikalanathan. BY Mithun Jayawardena

title: Chamara Sampath says ready to surrender
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Primary Industries Chamara Sampath Dasanayake yesterday (10) stressed that he is prepared to turn himself in, if found to be involved in the iron selling scam at the Kankesanthurai Cement Factory. Last week Gamini Ekanayake, the former Chairman of the Sri Lanka Cement Corporation, lodged a complaint with the Criminal Investigation Department (CID) against Dasanayake, alleging that an extensive embezzlement, amounting to billions of rupees, had occurred at the State-owned Kankesanthurai cement factory with the endorsement of the State Minister. In response to this allegation, Dasanayake said in Parliament, that he is ready to surrender to the Police at any given time. “I intend to present myself to the CID, and thus, the Police are at liberty to apprehend me should they deem it necessary. I respectfully request the Speaker to authorise the Police to affect my arrest, in line with the protocol for detaining an MP,” the State Minister said. Deputy Speaker Ajith Rajapakse, who was chairing the Parliamentary sittings at that time, noted that the Police have the authority to take him into custody at any juncture, given the State Minister’s willingness to surrender. “As the State Minister is ready to voluntarily surrender, the Police have been granted the permission to arrest him,” Rajapakse said. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Sri Lanka’s bid to join RCEP poised to materialise
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe has revealed that Sri Lanka’s bid to join the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) is poised to materialise following the conclusion of credit optimisation initiatives, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said yesterday. Additionally, the President announced plans to initiate negotiations for the establishment of free trade agreements with corresponding ASEAN member countries. President Wickremesinghe’s statement underscores the country’s determination to bolster its economic connectivity within the broader Asian region. The President affirmed his alignment with the future vision of ASEAN for the Indo-Pacific area, pledging full support for the advancement of this strategic perspective, the PMD said. These proposed collaborations highlight Sri Lanka’s commitment to fostering economic cooperation and trade linkages, which are poised to open new avenues for growth and development. The President’s statements reaffirm the nation’s readiness to engage actively in regional economic partnerships to realise its economic ambitions. President Wickremesinghe made these remarks while addressing the 56th anniversary of the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) onTuesday (8) at the Embassy of the Republic of Indonesia, Colombo, according to the PMD. The President reflected on Sri Lanka’s economic history and the decisions that had impacted the nation’s progress. He acknowledged the efforts of former President J. R. Jayawardene, his father and other influential figures who advocated for opening up the economy and joining ASEAN during its founding years as well as the Shenoy reforms for liberalisation of the economy and to ensure the welfare programme stayed within the needs. The President remarked that turning down the opportunity to join ASEAN led to a period of socialist economic policies and limited capital formations, hindering the country’s growth potential. The President further explained the circumstance that converted into a source of profound regret. He said subsequently, over a span of three years, Sri Lanka transitioned into a socialist economic model, leading to the fragmentation of the capital formations, and has continued to progress in this trajectory.  “However, we find ourselves not entirely emancipated from the constraints imposed by that economic paradigm. At present, despite being positioned as one of the world’s major economies, poised to potentially ascend to the ranks of the fifth or fourth largest expanding economies, we now confront the disheartening reality of shaking on the brink of bankruptcy after 55 years of existence.” President Ranil Wickremesinghe praised the association’s remarkable growth and success as one of the world’s largest economic blocks. The President also expressed regret that Sri Lanka had declined an invitation to join ASEAN in its early years, citing missed opportunities for economic prosperity. However, he highlighted a new policy approach to collaborate closely with ASEAN to enhance Sri Lanka’s position in the global arena. In light of Sri Lanka’s recent financial challenges and the need for rejuvenation, President Wickremesinghe expressed a renewed commitment to pursue closer ties with ASEAN. “Amid the looming threat of bankruptcy, Sri Lanka has embraced the challenge head-on, aiming to move forward with inspiration drawn from proactive problem-solving approaches. This involves looking at the accomplishments of the ASEAN and enhancing collaboration with the organisation. Consequently, as Sri Lanka faces impending financial challenges, it is actively strengthening its bonds with ASEAN nations,” he said. One of the key aspects of the new policy is the initiation of free trade agreements with ASEAN countries. President Wickremesinghe revealed that Sri Lanka has already forged a crucial trade agreement with Singapore and is actively negotiating with Thailand. The President also announced that Sri Lanka has applied to join the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), recognising the potential of this vast trade block comprising major economies like China, Japan, and Korea. He urged the Minister of Foreign Affairs to facilitate regular ministerial-level meetings with ASEAN countries to address mutual concerns and discuss the way forward. He stressed the importance of upholding the ASEAN outlook on the Indo-Pacific and supporting Indonesia’s maritime fulcrum concept. He also called for joint efforts between ASEAN countries and Sri Lanka to combat climate change and explore the potential of the blue economy. Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena, Ministers Bandula Gunawardena, Keheliya Rambukwella, Vidura Wickramanayake, Nasir Ahmed, Jeevan Thondaman, Nalin Fernando, State Minister Taraka Balasuriya and other officials including Malaysian High Commissioner Badli Hisham Adam , Ambassador of Thailand Poj Harnpol, Ambassador of Vietnam Ho Thi Thanh Truc, Ambassador of Myanmar Mr. U Han Thu, Sagala Ratnayake, Senior Adviser to the President on National Security and Chief of Presidential Staff and many dignitaries including the Commanders of the three Armed Forces attended the event, the PMD said.

title: Talks between SL, Iran lead to release of nine Iranian prisoners
author: Author not found
Content: Recent diplomatic consultations, between Sri Lanka and Iran, resulted in the release of nine Iranian sailors who were imprisoned in Sri Lanka. The release was announced after discussions between the Foreign Ministers of both countries and was facilitated by the efforts of the Iranian embassy in Colombo. This event is significant because it marks the first time such consular relations have occurred between these two countries. The sailors were from the city of Chabahar in Sistan and Baluchistan, and they were released from prisons on the order of the Sri Lankan authorities. They were then handed over to the Embassy of the Islamic Republic of Iran in Colombo. Those Iranian sailors will soon return to their homeland and families with the coordination of the Iranian Embassy. Also, two Iranian prisoners will be transferred from Sri Lanka to Iran within the framework of the agreement on the extradition of convicts between the two countries and through the efforts of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Judiciary. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs considers following up on securing pardoning, release and transfer of Iranian prisoners and legal and consular support of Iranians abroad among its main programmes and serious measures. (Mehr)

title: SC rules Ayurveda Bill inconsistent with Constitution
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court has determined that the Ayurveda (Amendment) Bill is inconsistent with the Constitution, Deputy Speaker Ajith Rajapakse informed Parliament yesterday (10). As a result, the Bill will have to be passed with a special majority of Parliament and a referendum. Reading the Speaker’s announcement, Rajapakse said, 15 clauses of the Bill have been determined as inconsistent with the Constitution by the SC. Accordingly, Clauses 2, 3, 27, 29, 30, 31, 32, 33, 34, 35, 36, 37, 39, 40 and 41 of the Bill are inconsistent with Article 9 of the Constitution and can only be passed with the special majority required under paragraph (2) of Article 84 and approved by the People at a Referendum, by virtue of Article 83. Clause 46(4) of the Bill is inconsistent with Article 12(1) of the Constitution and can only be passed with the special majority required under paragraph (2) of Article 84. Clause 11(3) of the Bill is inconsistent with Article 12(1) of the Constitution and can only be passed with the special majority required under paragraph (2) of Article 84. Clause 13 of the Bill which seeks to amend the Main Act by inter alia, repealing subsections (e) and (f) of Section 13 (1) of the Main Act is inconsistent with Article 12(1) of the Constitution and can only be passed with the special majority required under paragraph (2) of Article 84. Clauses 24(1)(a), 25 and 46(2) of the Bill are inconsistent with Article 12(1) of the Constitution and can only be passed with the special majority required under paragraph (2) of Article 84. Clause 46(1) of the Bill is inconsistent with Article 12(1) of the Constitution and can only be passed with the special majority required under paragraph (2) of Article 84. These inconsistencies will cease if the relevant clauses are removed or amended, the Supreme Court has informed. The Ayurveda (Amendment) Bill sparked controversy within Ayurveda and traditional medical community as they alleged that the Bill violated the human rights of Sri Lankan traditional doctors. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Badulla Hospital faces total blackout
author: Author not found
Content: The Badulla Teaching Hospital faces a total blackout as it is in arrears on its electricity bill to the tune of Rs 70 million, according to informed sources. However, hospital sources revealed that due to delay in the payment of the outstanding electricity bills, the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) had disconnected the power supply to the hospital’s nurses training unit, doctors’ official quarters, and the nurses’ hostel on Wednesday (9) afternoon. This was also confirmed by hospital authorities. They added that if the hospital management fails to make the outstanding payments to the CEB, there could be a serious threat of the entire power supply to the hospital being disconnected soon. BY Nishantha Abeygunawardena – Badulla

title: BOC pledges Rs 5B at 12% for SME/ Startup loan scheme
author: Author not found
Content: The Bank of Ceylon (BOC), a State-owned banking giant, yesterday unveiled a groundbreaking endeavour aimed at revitalising the small and medium-sized enterprise (SME) sector and propelling rural development. This innovative initiative comprises a pioneering SME and startup loan scheme, underpinned by a substantial fund of five billion rupees and a notable expansion of the acclaimed ‘BOC Gammana’ rural development programme. In a resolute commitment to address the pressing needs of SMEs and marginalised rural communities, the Bank of Ceylon is embarking on a transformative journey. Ronald C. Perera, Chairman of the Bank of Ceylon, expressed the institution’s unwavering dedication, “We firmly believe in the transformative power of entrepreneurship and are steadfastly committed to uplifting our nation’s SMEs and rural areas. This initiative comes with lowered interest rates, offering significant benefits to the vital SME sector, thereby fostering growth.” Perera provided insights into the initiative, explaining, “Our recent undertaking involves a substantial allocation of five billion rupees aimed at stimulating entrepreneurship. The core objective of this venture is to empower both established MSME/SME entrepreneurs and nascent start-ups.” The allocated fund designates four billion rupees to bolster existing entrepreneurs, while a dedicated one billion rupees has been earmarked to foster the growth of start-ups. Start-up enterprises stand to access funds up to two million rupees, while established businesses can secure loans up to Rs 25 million. The offered interest rates for these loans range between 12% and 12.5% per annum, contingent upon the collateral provided by the loan applicant. Significantly, these interest rates are markedly below the current prime lending rate, which stands at 17%. Addressing the SME community, the Chairman issued a resounding call to action, urging entrepreneurs to seize the array of financial and non-financial assistance offered by the bank. He highlighted the tangible relief arising from prudent Domestic debt management under the government’s Domestic debt optimisation process, translating into reduced interest rates that will offer crucial support to SMEs and exporters. With fervour, the Chairman invited SMEs to harness these facilities and opportunities, amplifying their contributions to the nation’s economic trajectory. Russell Fonseka, the General Manager and Chief Executive Officer of the Bank of Ceylon, delineated the bank’s strategic vision. He underscored the institution’s unwavering commitment to support viable projects extending beyond traditional trading and leasing. This inclusive approach encompasses a spectrum of sectors, including agriculture, forestry, fisheries, industry-based ventures, and other service-oriented enterprises. Notably, the bank places a special emphasis on promoting women-led businesses, recognising the indispensable role women play in advancing the nation’s economic landscape. In the midst of prevailing economic headwinds, the Bank of Ceylon remains steadfast in its commitment to fortify the SME sector. Acknowledging the pivotal role SMEs play in a nation’s economic advancement, the Chairman emphasised, “The SME sector is the backbone of economic development in any country.” To underscore this commitment, the bank has introduced a series of measures aimed at bolstering the SME ecosystem: – Grace Period for Loan Repayments: In acknowledgment of the far-reaching impact of the Covid-19 pandemic, the bank has extended a grace period for loan repayments, extending crucial relief to struggling businesses.  – Concessionary Loan Schemes: The bank has introduced a suite of concessional loan schemes, including MELOC, Emergency Response, SMILE III, and Tea Loan, tailored exclusively for SMEs. These schemes offer favorable interest rates and terms.  -Non-Financial Assistance: The bank goes beyond financial aid, providing non-financial support through initiatives like SME Circle, which facilitates vital connections between SMEs and institutions such as the Export Development Board, Small Enterprises Development, and Industrial Development Board. – Skills Development Programmes: The Bank of Ceylon has pioneered skill development programmes aimed at enhancing financial literacy, fostering entrepreneurship, and nurturing financial management skills among SMEs. – Micro Financing for Rural Communities: The ‘BOC Mithru’ program continues to be a beacon of support, elevating rural living standards through micro-financing initiatives. At the heart of the bank’s corporate social responsibility lies the ‘BOC Gammana’ programme, an initiative designed to uplift deserving villages across each province in Sri Lanka. Several villages, including Medirigirya-Tissa Amuna, Mandram Nuwara-Hunukotuwa, Mullaithivu-Thirthkarai, Dehiovita-Meegasthanna, Nawagattegama-Kuruketiyawa, and Ella-Maduragma, have already experienced the transformative effects of this comprehensive programme. Under the ‘BOC Gammana’ banner, multifaceted development initiatives encompass education, self-employment, healthcare, and community engagement. The bank has been instrumental in establishing computer laboratories in schools, reviving libraries, promoting home gardening, organising maternity clinics, and launching other progressive projects. The Bank of Ceylon envisions the expansion of the ‘BOC Gammana’ initiative, with plans to select one village from each province for future development phases. Galle-Katandola, Nittabuwa-Attanagalla-Allawala, and Kantale-Rajawala have been earmarked as the chosen villages for the forthcoming stages of this programme. As the Bank of Ceylon strides forward with its visionary initiatives, it reaffirms its pivotal role in propelling SMEs and fostering holistic socio-economic progress throughout Sri Lanka. By Ishara Gamage

title: Man who allegedly threatened President Biden shot dead during FBI raid
author: Author not found
Content: United States law enforcement officials have shot and killed a Utah man who allegedly made threats against US President Joe Biden, Vice President Kamala Harris and Manhattan District Attorney Alvin Bragg, ahead of a scheduled presidential visit to the State.  The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), the domestic US intelligence agency, said its agents attempted to serve search and arrest warrants early on Wednesday to the residence of Craig Robertson in Provo, Utah, South of Salt Lake City. Unnamed law enforcement sources told The Associated Press that Robertson was armed when the incident took place. The FBI released a statement saying the shooting was under review. “The FBI takes all shooting incidents involving our agents or task force members seriously,” the agency said. The shooting comes amid increased fears of political violence in the US, particularly in the wake of the attack on the US Capitol on January 6, 2021. At the time of his death, Robertson faced three felony counts, including making interstate threats, making threats against the president and influencing, impeding and retaliating against federal law enforcement officers by threat. The criminal complaint against him highlighted social media posts Robertson made expressing violent desires towards the perceived enemies of former Republican President Donald Trump. The filings allege that Robertson took to Facebook on Monday to say he had learned of Biden’s visit to Utah and would need to “clean the dust off the M24 sniper rifle”. Biden stopped in Utah on Wednesday, as part of a trip through the western United States. In a previous post, in September 2022, Robertson allegedly wrote, “The time is right for a presidential assassination or two. First Joe then Kamala!!!” Bragg, the District Attorney, who filed the first criminal indictment against Trump in New York, was also a target, according to the Court filings. The FBI said it had been warned about Robertson’s activities in March after he posted on the platform Truth Social about wanting to “put a nice hole in his [Bragg’s] forehead”. Online, Robertson described himself as a “MAGA Trumper”, referring to the acronym for Trump’s slogan, “Make America Great Again”. Details about the circumstances surrounding Robertson’s death have yet to be released. But the shooting has drawn attention to the ongoing threat of political violence in the US. A report published by the Reuters news agency on Wednesday said that the US is currently experiencing political violence on a level unseen since the 1970s, with much of it driven by the far-right. (Al Jazeera)
