title: Norochcholai Power Plant breaks down yet again
author: Author not found
Content: Since the installation of the First Phase of the Norochcholai Power Plant or more proudly called the ‘Lakvijaya Power Station’ in March 2011, the Plant has continued to have endless problems and regular breakdowns. The first phase of 300 MW was commissioned in 2011, and the second and third in 2014. The total power generation capacity of this Plant is 900 Megawatt with an estimated cost of the project being USD 1.35 billion. The Contract for the construction and commissioning of the Plant was awarded to the China Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC). This is a Chinese State-owned enterprise. The Project was partly funded by the Exim Bank of China. This came in the form of two Loans, USD 300 million on terms of 20 years to maturity, five years grace and a rate of two per cent interest per annum. The Second loan of USD 155 million was a 15-year maturity, a 5-year grace period and six per cent interest. In simple layman’s terms, since the end of the grace period in 2019, our monthly payments on the Chinese borrowing of USD 455 million is approximately USD 4.25 million per month or Rs 1,360,000,000 per month. This is in addition to paying back the balance borrowing on the total project cost of USD 1.35 billion. I personally have no idea what the Warranty terms of this project were, nor do I want to speculate on inferior equipment used. However, the industry norm is that Coal Power plants are stable and rarely break down. Also, they have life spans of over 50-60 years. In this instance, I will even let the fact that these Coal power plants are extremely harmful to the environment slip. At this point what bothers me most is that who does the buck stop with here? The CEB had a senior technical team that signed off on this project, maybe it’s time the names of this high-level technical evaluation committee were revealed to the public and some accountability be sought out, even through our solid judiciary system in Sri Lanka. If it is found that the Chinese Government owned entity that was awarded the contract did indeed supply inferior equipment then like the much spoken about Express Pearl, they should be sued and compensation sought. Or maybe the generous Chinese Government who are continually looking for ways to help the people of Sri Lanka, should at least right off their component of US$ 455 million loan used for this project. Food for thought for the impressive and energetic Minister of Power and Energy? By Game Changer

title: Jumbo Agbo’s condition deteriorating – Pavithra
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Wildlife, Pavithra Wanniarachchi, revealed that the condition of Agbo, the injured elephant, which had recently garnered considerable attention, was deteriorating. However, Wanniarachchi said there was no need to obtain the assistance of foreign doctors to treat the elephant. “We are committed to nursing the elephant back to health, despite the serious gunshot injuries it has sustained. We have provided an initial sum of Rs 50,000 to the veterinary specialist entrusted with its care. Additionally, we are prepared to allocate further funds for its treatment,” the Minister said. She emphasised, “We are self-sufficient in our efforts to treat the animal and do not require foreign assistance.” Furthermore, Minister Wanniarachchi raised suspicions that certain groups might be orchestrating a fraudulent scheme through social media to collect funds purportedly for the welfare of the animal. She clarified that the government has not initiated any fundraising programme for Agbo. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Medical Help International donates Rs 42B worth medical aid
author: Author not found
Content: Medical Help International (MHI) is registered as an International NGO (INGO) in the USA with registered charity status. This humanitarian aid organisation is headed by Ayusha Amarakone – Founder/Executive Director along with Paddy Dassanayake – Director Operations & International Communications and commenced services globally especially extending medical services to Sri Lanka since Covid-19. MHI USA continuously provides emergency medicines and other medical supplies and equipment as donations from the USA, UK, Australia, Canada, UAE, India and Malaysia. At present, the MHI – USA Team is in Sri Lanka and paid courtesy calls on President Ranil Wickremesinghe, Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena, Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella and US Ambassador to Sri Lanka Julie J. Chung and the entire team at the Ministry of Health. Also, they made it a point to visit a few Hospitals in Sri Lanka. From April 2022 to date, MHI USA has donated emergency medicines and other medical supplies collaborating with other overseas international Humanitarian organisations, corporate and individual donors. The total value of medical donations has reached USD 128 million as of the date (approximately: Rs 42 billion). Besides, MHI USA was able to donate a 1,000 KVA generator to Karapitiya Teaching Hospital, worth LKR 41 million, which is a strong life-saving supportive instrument to the entire Southern Province including a few other areas covering the Monaragala District as well. Medical Help International USA has also partnered with Australia Sri Lanka Medical Aid Team (AUSLMAT) in many of the healthcare projects helping SL with large-scale donations. Dr. Erosha Premaratne, President of AUSLMAT is the Australia and Pacific Coordinator of MHI – USA. The donations to date are mainly towards Oncology, Cardiology, Antibiotics, Dialysis Solutions, IV Antibiotics Blood Bags and High-end Medical Equipment. Ayusha Amarakone, the Executive Director of Medical Help International – USA, a legally registered international humanitarian organisation, emphasised the importance of the Government’s support regarding the need for medicine and medical consumable donations as it is crucial for MHI to reach out to potential donors effectively. In addition to managing all logistical aspects of international humanitarian contributions through their partners with the Ministry of Health, MHI collaborates with donors to purchase essential medicines directly. Transport partners, including SriLankan Airlines, Expo Lanka, and EFL, generously facilitate air and sea cargo. Amarakone highlighted that all donated medicines that arrive in the country via MHI, are either FDA-approved or NMRA-approved with all necessary documentation submitted prior to purchase and importing. MHI closely works with SLMA, GMOA, and other intercollegiate groups to reduce miscommunication and increase the transparency of these donations. Besides the above, MHI also arranges medical missions and assists with healthcare capital, infrastructure, and equipment projects. MHI donated a power generator to Karapitiya Teaching Hospital as the backup energy for the entire Southern Province and covering a few districts in the Uva Province. MHI invites any individual or organisations who are willing to share their vision to make a difference in the lives of those in need through donations or spreading awareness, sharing knowledge, or your skills. Your support will be invaluable in helping us achieve our mission. Together, we can create a brighter future for all. Also, Paddy Dassanayake – Director Operations & International Communications – USA commented her service towards the country is the most selfless act she could get involved in and her mission is to make the biggest difference possible to help needy human beings. The Sri Lankan President, Prime Minister, Minister of Health and US Ambassador to Sri Lanka, praised the services and the donations extended so far which helped strengthen the Health Services of the country in these challenging times.

title: Chamara Sampath says ready to surrender
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Primary Industries Chamara Sampath Dasanayake yesterday (10) stressed that he is prepared to turn himself in, if found to be involved in the iron selling scam at the Kankesanthurai Cement Factory. Last week Gamini Ekanayake, the former Chairman of the Sri Lanka Cement Corporation, lodged a complaint with the Criminal Investigation Department (CID) against Dasanayake, alleging that an extensive embezzlement, amounting to billions of rupees, had occurred at the State-owned Kankesanthurai cement factory with the endorsement of the State Minister. In response to this allegation, Dasanayake said in Parliament, that he is ready to surrender to the Police at any given time. “I intend to present myself to the CID, and thus, the Police are at liberty to apprehend me should they deem it necessary. I respectfully request the Speaker to authorise the Police to affect my arrest, in line with the protocol for detaining an MP,” the State Minister said. Deputy Speaker Ajith Rajapakse, who was chairing the Parliamentary sittings at that time, noted that the Police have the authority to take him into custody at any juncture, given the State Minister’s willingness to surrender. “As the State Minister is ready to voluntarily surrender, the Police have been granted the permission to arrest him,” Rajapakse said. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: ‘Many experts lobbied politicians, political parties’
author: Author not found
Content: At the meeting of the Select Committee of Parliament to Investigate Causes for Financial Bankruptcy in April 2022, declared by the Government and to Report to Parliament and Submit its Proposals and Recommendations that was held recently, numerous participants, including professors from all Sri Lankan universities and economists highlighted several significant concerns and reasons. They pointed out that the influence exerted by various individuals lobbying for political parties and politicians had emerged as a noticeable contributing factor to the financial bankruptcy of the country. The committee was chaired by SLPP MP Sagara Kariyawasam. During the committee session, a Professor of Economics from the Department of Economics and Statistics at the University of Peradeniya, W.L. Prasanna Perera, highlighted that the economy was grappling with structural challenges and had repeatedly ignored early warning signals from both internal and external indicators since the conclusion of the war. The Professor elaborated on the presence of twin deficits. The Government’s spending, driven by the need to maintain a low productivity level, exceeded its revenue due to the complexity of the tax system. Moreover, there was a notable discrepancy between imports and exports, with the external sector primarily reliant on non-tradable earnings. He also highlighted that the real GDP growth rates were as follows: 8.5 per cent during 2010-2012, 4.4 per cent during 2013-2015, 3.6 per cent during 2016-2018, and 2.6 per cent during 2019-2021. In terms of the debt-service ratio, it stood at 16.5 per cent during 2010-2012, increased to 25.6 per cent during 2013-2015, further rose to 26.1 per cent during 2016-2018, and reached 31.8 per cent during 2019-2021. He also raised concerns about debt-driven unproductive mega-scale projects that lacked proper feasibility or procurement processes. He pointed out the rise in non-concessional loans after 2009, replacing the previously low-cost Government foreign borrowings with higher-cost ones due to limited access to concessional funding. Moreover, he emphasised that the previous Government’s economic mismanagement was evident. He also noted that the ban on imported chemical fertilisers: impact on tea and paddy, domestic agriculture (Loss of agricultural output + further decreases the export earning) also was one of the factors. There was also the fixing USD value USD 1 = Rs 203 (sacrificed foreign reserves, downgraded credit rating) which hampered the progress and the exhaustion of all debt management strategies without foreign or domestic financing except dependence on Central Bank money printing. He pointed out that the Easter Sunday bombing in April 2019, and the pandemic that followed further deteriorated tourism earnings and remittances, he added. He also stressed the Russia-Ukraine war in early 2022 – fuel prices and general price level and also there is continuous downgrading by rating agencies. Pointing to the level of corruption in Sri Lanka where in 2002 Sri Lanka ranked 52 and in 2021 at 102, and the bureaucratic system with non-market-driven public also had a say. He stressed that the policies discouraged foreign and local investment. He said, Debt to Repay: Total USD 91 billion (Foreign 36 billion – ISBs 13.574 billion); Average USD 5 billion per year, 2026 – USD 25 billion (Debt has reached an unsustainable level in the past two years due to the debt servicing challenges amidst low revenue mobilisation and limited foreign inflows to the country). Foreign reserves by announcing the bankruptcy: a significant depletion of gross official reserves after 2019 and that the USD 7.6 billion in 2019 and USD 1.97 billion (usable amount only around USD 400 million) in March 2022, he added. Professor Aminda Perera, representing Wayamba University, brought to attention a distinct divergence within the country’s financial and economic experts regarding the Light Rail Project. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: SJB must be careful when criticising President
author: Author not found
Content: UNP General Secretary Palitha Rangebandara on Wednesday (9), stressed that the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) and Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa should carefully consider their allegations or comments against President Ranil Wickremesinghe. Rangebandara expressed disappointment that Opposition Leader Premadasa, who was nurtured within President Wickremesinghe’s political camp for the past 20 years, has now become one of his primary adversaries without displaying any gratitude or respect for him. He remarked that both Opposition Leader Premadasa and the JVP appeared poised to exploit any problem arising in the country for their political gains, effectively creating chaos rather than offering practical solutions. Rangebandara criticised these shortsighted and politically bankrupt practices, suggesting they seem to be perpetually ongoing. He noted that both factions lack common sense and are resorting to using natural disasters as a means to remain relevant in politics, as it appears to be their sole weapon at present. While emphasising that the Government has taken comprehensive steps to enhance the nation’s resilience in the face of potential disasters, Rangebandara revealed the establishment of a committee led by UNP Deputy Leader Ruwan Wijewardene. This committee will conduct research into potential natural disasters that might occur in Sri Lanka, particularly in conjunction with heavy rainfall or drought conditions. He underscored the Government’s collaboration with the global community to minimise the adverse impacts of natural disasters. He asserted that the current drought situation is a natural phenomenon and neither the Government nor the authorities can be held responsible. He emphasised the Government’s commitment to safeguarding the populace, including farmers, through its actions. He criticised Premadasa and the JVP for exploiting issues faced by Udawalawa farmers for their own political gain, characterising such actions as contrary to the conduct of a genuine and people-friendly politician. He cast doubt on the intentions of these factions, suggesting they might be attempting to recreate the critical situation that occurred the previous year, potentially resulting in further loss of innocent lives. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Electricity Reforms Bill signals erosion of consumer rights
author: Author not found
Content: Former Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) Chairman Janaka Ratnayake alleged that the proposed Electricity Reforms Bill’s provisions signal the erosion of electricity consumer rights. Under the proposed legislation, the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) would undergo a transformation into 15 distinct private companies, a move that Ratnayake believes will have far-reaching implications. In a media briefing held on Tuesday (8), Ratnayake raised alarms about the potential loss of Rs 200 million in electricity security deposits for consumers and the dismantling of the consumer complaints and dispute resolution mechanism. The ramifications of these changes could be significant for electricity users across the nation. One of the most contentious aspects of the proposed bill involves the fate of CEB personnel. He said, the legislation’s stipulation that all CEB employees would be integrated into roles within the newly formed private enterprises. This lack of choice removes the ability for employees to exercise personal discretion, essentially nullifying their privileges as CEB workers. The bill’s framers have put both the electricity consumer and the CEB employee in a challenging situation, leaving them with diminished agency and control over their circumstances. He further stressed the importance of empowering employees to make informed decisions about their employment and compensation before the CEB’s dissolution. The impending transformation of this major public institution into private entities necessitates careful consideration of the implications for all stakeholders involved. He also added, the Minister of Power and Energy gets the power to decide electricity tariffs and that the EPF, ETF and pension of CEB employees will be under a private company. Another criticism was that if the new bill is enacted, all hydropower plants, coal power plants and thermal power plants will be under separate private companies. Ratnayake explained further that the proposed draft lacks any provision related to the handling of the Rs 200 million deposits by the electricity consumers. “According to Section 28 of the existing Sri Lanka Electricity Act, a clear provision mandates that electricity consumers are liable to get an interest on the security deposit. Presently, the cumulative sum of these deposited funds exceeds Rs 200 million. However, the new proposed legislation conspicuously overlooks the safeguarding of this security deposit, leaving uncertainties about the fate of this substantial amount unaddressed within the draft. Additionally, the prevailing legislation endows the PUCSL with the authority to safeguard the rights of electricity consumers. The current framework also establishes an effective mechanism to efficiently manage consumer grievances and conflicts through the PUCSL. This empowers consumers to seek resolutions for their complaints and concerns promptly and equitably, obviating the need for legal proceedings. Unfortunately, the proposed bill eradicates these rights, amenities, and protections, placing consumers in a vulnerable position in relation to private entities,” he stressed. Ratnayake also claimed that the authority to set electricity rates is slated to be transferred to the Power Minister as per the provisions of the proposed bill. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: PAFFREL hails decision
author: Author not found
Content: The Peoples’ Action for Free and Fair Elections (PAFFREL) said the Supreme Court decision regarding the amendments proposed to the Local Government Ordinance by MP Jayantha Katagoda to reinstate former Councillors of dissolved LG bodies was another victory for democracy. The Speaker announced to Parliament the Supreme Court decision regarding the petition filed by PAFFREL against the amendment proposed to the Local Government Ordinance by MP Jayantha Katagoda to reinstate former Councillors of dissolved LG bodies. The Private Members Bills presented by Katagoda were inconsistent with the Constitution and need a majority in Parliament and a referendum to be enacted. “This judgment is a great victory achieved in recent history by the people who value democracy in Sri Lanka. Also it is envisaged to achieve similar victories in respect of the other petitions filed by the PAFFREL and other parties in the Supreme Court in relation to the postponement of Local Government Elections arbitrarily. Despite there being a recent tendency among politicians to abuse parliamentary power and undermine democratic values to consolidate their power, this judgment emphasises that such practices could not be continued any longer,” PAFFREL said in a statement. PAFFREL said, it has repeatedly expressed its protest against the people’s representatives holding onto office beyond the time limit they were elected for by the people and the Councillors acting in an arbitrary and undemocratic manner. The petition was filed on 12 July where Katagoda and the Attorney General the named as respondents in the case. “The decision of the Supreme Court on this petition which has been referred to the Speaker included  that the Clause 2 of all three amendments proposed namely the Pradeshiya Sabha Act (Amendment), Urban Councils Ordinance (Amendment)’ and the Municipal Councils Ordinance (Amendment) which were challenged before the Supreme Court was inconsistent with Articles 1, 12 (1), 82, 83 and 104B of the Constitution, and therefore, the Supreme Court has decided that all three bills should be passed by a special majority in Parliament and also approved by the people in a referendum according to the provisions of Article 83 of the Constitution.” BY Sanjana Marzook

title: Ampara District hard-hit by severe drought
author: Author not found
Content: The Ampara District is presently facing a severe drought, and it has been reported that residents in certain areas are struggling to access even drinking water. According to Deputy Director of Disaster Management, M.A.C.M. Riyas, the Divisional Secretariat areas of Addalaichenai, Maha Oya, Lahugala, Thirukkovil, and Alayadiwembu are the worst affected. In response, the Disaster Management Centre has allocated Rs 2.1 million to supply water to these areas through bowsers, aiming to alleviate the drinking water crisis. This initiative comes on the recommendation of District Secretary, Chinthaka Abeywickrama. Moreover, the Pradeshiya Sabhas in the District have been instructed to deploy their water bowsers to provide much-needed drinking water to those in need. Deputy Director Riyas also said, arrangements have been made to provide water to livestock, recognising the struggle to access water. Due to the severe drought prevailing in Ampara District, the public is facing untold hardships.  By M.A.P. Deen – Ampara

title: Twenty IUSF protesters arrested
author: Author not found
Content: At least 20 were arrested yesterday (10) during a protest in Colombo, by the Inter University Students’ Federation (IUSF), against what they claimed as attempts to privatise education and establishing private medical colleges. Earlier in the day, both the Fort and Maligakanda Magistrate’s Courts had issued orders preventing the protesters from accessing specific parts of Colombo. However, the protest had taken place in the afternoon despite the Court orders and the Police deployed water cannon to scatter the protesters at Havelock Town and near the Town Hall. Pix by Sarath Kumara

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Prof. Jeewandara clarifies experts’ report
author: Author not found
Content: According to reports on the medicinal drugs that had been tested by the National Medicinal Regulatory Authorities (NMRA) laboratory, following the alleged drug related deaths, only one drug produced in Sri Lanka had shown a quality failure, whereas the other drug, supplied by two separate companies, had passed the quality test, Member of the Specialist Committee, appointed to look into the recent incidents of drug allergies and their after effects, Prof. Chandima Jeewandara said yesterday (10). Addressing a media at the Health Ministry, with regard to Dedunu Dias–led expert committee, appointed to probe the incidents of Anaphylaxis to drugs in several hospitals islandwide, the Professor in Immunology, Allergy and Molecular Medicine at the University of Sri Jayewardenepura noted that although the expert committee had not been tasked with looking into or testing medicinal drugs, the committee had referred to all the quality reports available.  “It should be mentioned that all suspected drugs were sent for quality testing and most of the reports were available for our assessment so it was easy for us to make recommendations based on those reports,” he said. He said, the action taken by the Ministry of Health, with regard to the controversy caused by medicinal drug allergies, is sufficient. “Contrary to what has been reported by the media, only two patients have died due to allergies, while others who experienced allergic reactions are still alive. Not all patients who experience allergies from medicinal drugs end up dying. The expert committee conducted its investigation using internationally recognised methods,” he said. Fielding questions regarding the quality testing, which had been carried out by the NMRA’s Quality Assurance Laboratory, he said, the two drugs considered had been Co-amoxiclav and Ceftriaxone. The latter drug was received from two suppliers, one from Germany and India. He noted that the antibiotic from South India had been used in local State-run hospitals for a long period. According to the Medical Supplies Division (MSD) more than 400,000 doses had been distributed to hospitals Islandwide without a problem till the recent death, following the administration of the drug, that was recorded, Prof. Jeewandara explained, adding that both the brands of the drug received from the two companies had been tested at the NMRA while both passed the quality test according to reports.   However, a batch of Co-amoxiclav brand Manufactured in Sri Lanka, tested by the NMRA Quality Assurance Lab, was not available at the time but they had a report from a different batch which noted that particles had been detected in the vials so that particular drug had failed in quality testing. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Ministry accepts Dr. Haq cannot continue working
author: Author not found
Content: The Health Ministry yesterday (10) accepted that Medical Practitioner, Dr. Ruhul Haq could not continue to work in a Health Ministry institution, when his registration had been suspended by the Sri Lanka Medical Council (SLMC), for a period of eight months. Dr. Haq’s name sparked controversy following post-mortem into the death of a child at Lady Ridgeway Hospital, Colombo following a kidney surgery. He also performed the post-mortem on businessman Dinesh Schaffter, that was labelled as contradictory by the Schaffter family lawyer. Fielding questions during a media briefing, Director Tertiary Care Services Dr. Priyatha Atapattu said, according to SLMC rules and regulations he could not practice as a medical officer. However, he noted that a person could continue in service following a Court decision. However, the Health Ministry has initiated a probe into the matter, he said.  “But since he is a JMO he could challenge these words in a Court of Law, therefore, we have given him instructions to work in accordance with SLMC provisions, he noted.  Dr. Atapattu noted however, that the Health Ministry too would act in accordance of the legal advice it received with regard to JMO Dr. Haq, he said adding that the Ministry was in the process of taking action in this regard. The SLMC had written to the Health Ministry informing it of an eight-month suspension on Judicial Medical Officer Dr. Ruhul Haq’s registration owing to an incident which had taken place 14 years earlier, at the District General Hospital Nuwara Eliya, Dr. Atapattu explained. As the Competent Authority, the Director General Health Services informed his superior at the Colombo JMO’s Office of the SLMC’s recommendations. Therefore it is the head of the Colombo JMO’s Office that should take action, he noted. He explained that even if the SLMC imposed a temporary suspension on his registration, Dr, Haq has the right to appeal. “We do not know what action he took but we have taken action in accordance with the SLMC’s communiqué to the Health Ministry, the Director Medical Services noted. Dr. Atapattu said in his preliminary letter to the JMO he had informed him that action was being taken with regard to his eight-month suspension. Also the particular medical practitioner was informed of the Ministry’s stance earlier this week. Fielding questions he noted that there were provisions in the Establishment Code regarding what action could be taken when an authoritative body such as the SLMC suspended the registration of a medical practitioner. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Report on recent drug allergies submitted
author: Author not found
Content: The Expert Committee chaired by Director of the Medical Research Institute (MRI) Dr. Dedunu Dias to probe recent incidents of drug allergies and their after-effects submitted its report to Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella at the Health Ministry.  The report noted that of the six cases analysed in detail, five had met the anaphylaxis criteria, which is a life-threatening allergic reaction that occurred swiftly. Among the five patients who had anaphylaxis, the causality assessment using WHO-UMC (World Health Organization – Uppsala Monitoring Centre) causality assessment criteria categorised four adverse drug reactions (ADRs) as probable due to the suspected drug. The 12 recommendations submitted by the Dedunu Committee include revisiting and establishing national and institutional guidelines/ protocols on anaphylaxis management/ emergency management. The re-emphasis of the practice of early recognition and treatment of anaphylaxis and immediate treatment with adrenalin while authorising the registered nursing officers of institutions to use 1:1000 adrenalin in the IM route in an emergency without the directions of medical officers. The Committee also recommended developing a mandatory continuous professional development mechanism or training programme for medical officers and nursing officers on emergency management of anaphylaxis. They called for a compulsory mechanism to conduct institutional clinical audits for all life-threatening adverse incidents reported to be instituted. Revision of the terms of reference of the Drug Therapeutic Committee (TOR of DTC) to include the development of institutional drug management policies (ex: Institutional Antibiotic policy, ADR audit policy, etc.) and to introduce institutional mechanisms to minimise medication errors. They noted that a network or pathways should be established for anaphylaxis survivors for subsequent allergy reviews. Also, a mechanism should be set up to educate year 10 and 11 students at schools from across the country on allergies and the safe use of medicines/antibiotics. A similar mechanism should be established to educate media personnel and the public also on the matter. The Dedunu report called for the improvement in the efficiency and effectiveness of ADRs reporting and response system by the introduction of real-time data-sharing mobile applications while permitting the public to report ADRs to the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA). The Committee also recommended taking speedy remedial action on procedural and/or financial issues that hinder the adequate supply of safe and effective drugs of acceptable quality to healthcare institutions. While the Health Minister observed on Twitter that the full report could not be published due to Doctor-patient confidentiality, the Academy of Health Professionals (AHP) urged the Ministry to take measures to publicise the report “as it was the only time the Health Ministry accepted that there was a fault in the State Health service and appointed a Committee to probe it.” Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella said on Twitter that while the Dr. Dedunu Dias Committee had officially submitted the report to him on Tuesday (8) the full report can’t be fully disclosed due to doctor-patient confidentiality.” But conclusions and recommendations, which are now part of public records, have been officially released, he said on Twitter.   President of the AHP, Ravi Kumudesh said the medicinal drug issue in healthcare accounted for only one per cent of the country’s health problems. Although the Dedunu Committee could not be expected to soothe overall health issues in the island, it was the only time when a study was conducted on the country’s health service and therefore the public needed to be made aware of the findings. He noted that the Expert Committee that studied the issue had not been able to do a technical or laboratory study. Is there any other option but to accept the information given by the relevant expert team regarding the professional errors that may occur in the pre- and post-procedure observed for the patient. Kumudesh alleged that the expert study had been limited to the refrigeration, distribution and post-marketing process that takes place after the delivery of the medicine. However, there is no account of how many medicinal drugs were studied, how many cases were studied, and what percentage of them were defective, as this is the most important information that can be revealed by this report. The AHP President urged the Health Ministry to disclose details in the entire report immediately. Media Committee Member of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA), Dr. Chamil Wijesinghe, responding to queries, said the report submitted by the Dedunu Committee had completely overlooked the issue which they had meant to address thereby the report that was submitted to the Health Minister was still incomplete. The Committee seems to have forgotten that there was a deep-rooted question regarding the quality of the medicinal drugs which had been used during the procedure of patient treatment. They seem to have completely overlooked the fact as to whether the anaphylaxis which they spoke of at length was a result of the drug quality itself. Therefore, the Dr. Dedunu Dias report was incomplete sans the report on the medicinal drugs that had been used to treat these patients. Also, the public was yet to know if the parties affected by the drug-related incidents were given justice. Minister Rambukwella spoke of compensation earlier when the incidences occurred but there were questions as to whose money he was going to use in paying that compensation, Dr. Wijesinghe pointed out. Minister Rambukwella on Twitter also noted he was awaiting the results of a quality test of the reported drug after a “thorough, independent exam by the National Drug Quality Assurance Laboratory.” He noted that it had been the reason for him to discuss the matter with President Ranil Wickremesinghe to set up a WHO-funded Benchmark lab to qualitatively expedite such queries.   By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: St. Thomas’ College, Matale celebrates 150 years today
author: Author not found
Content: St. Thomas’ College, Matale, the premier boys’ school in the Matale District is celebrating its 150th anniversary today (10 August 2023). The formal celebration ceremony will be held on Sunday, 13 August, at 10:00 a.m. at the school premises. President Ranil Wickremesinghe is the Chief Guest and (Dr.) Susil Premajayantha, Minister of Education will also be in attendance. Established in 1873 the inaugural class included 75 boys and 12 girls. In 1876, Rev. Fr. Aloysius J. M. Marrer divided the school into separate boys’ and girls’ schools. St. Thomas’ College became a government controlled institution in 1962. Currently, the school accommodates over 2,700 students, supported by more than 150 academic and non-academic staff members under Principal Dammika Hewawasam. Throughout the years, the College has consistently produced top-ranking students at the GCE A/L examination across various streams. St. Thomas’ College Matale is well known for its prowess in hockey, having clinched the all-island title on multiple occasions. Distinguished alumni currently serving in prominent positions, including Prime Minister’s Secretary Anura Dissanayake, Chief of Defence Staff, General Shavendra Silva and BASL President, Kaushalya Nawarathne will also participate in the main event on Sunday. Beyond the main Old Boys Association in Matale, St. Thomas’ College boasts of Old Boys Association branches in Kandy, Colombo, the UK, and Australia. The school invites all former Thomians to join in the main event. Further details can be obtained by contacting 066 2222523.

title: Courts have no Jurisdiction over Parliament – Speaker
author: Author not found
Content: Regarding the Petitions lodged against the approved Parliament resolution on Domestic Debt Restructuring, Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardene said yesterday (9) that no Court under Sri Lanka’s Constitution has the authority to issue orders or judgments against a resolution that has already garnered Parliamentary approval. This ruling was in response to a privilege concern raised by Minister Harin Fernando on the previous day (8). Minister Fernando sought a ruling from the Speaker to determine whether the petitions filed in court against the resolution for domestic debt restructuring were a breach of parliamentary privilege and the legislature itself. The Speaker said, “Article 4 (C) of Sri Lanka’s Constitution outlines that “the judicial power of the People shall be exercised by Parliament through courts, tribunals and institutions established by or recognised under the Constitution, or established by law. This holds true except for matters concerning the privileges, immunities, and powers of Parliament and its Members, where the judicial power of the People may be directly exercised by Parliament according to the law.” The Speaker said Article 148 of the Constitution grants Parliament full control over public finance. It specifies that no tax, rate, or levy can be imposed by any local or public authority without the authorisation of a law passed by Parliament. “I would like to first state that the Cabinet of Ministers unanimously endorsed the Domestic Debt Optimization plan proposed by the Ministry of Finance, Economic Stabilisation, and National Policies during a special Cabinet meeting on 28 June 2023. Subsequently, the resolution for implementing the Domestic Debt Optimisation to restore sovereign debt sustainability received approval from the Parliament’s Committee on Public Finance on 30 June 2023, with a majority vote by Committee Members.” “Since the subject matter of the mentioned resolution predominantly concerns public finance, the Resolution for implementing the Domestic Debt Optimisation to restore sovereign debt sustainability was ratified by Parliament on July 1, 2023, with a majority vote of 122 Members in favor and 62 against.” “As the resolution for implementing the Domestic Debt Optimisation to restore sovereign debt sustainability has been officially passed by Parliament on July 1, 2023, it falls outside the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court or any other court established under the 1978 Constitution of Sri Lanka. Thus, it cannot be contested, reviewed, or challenged.” “A ruling issued on 20 June 2001, by Speaker of Parliament Anura Bandaranaike unequivocally established that court interference with parliamentary proceedings is not permissible. The ruling stated that the Supreme Court lacks the jurisdiction to issue interim orders restraining the Speaker of Parliament with regard to actions authorised by Standing Order 78A. Furthermore, the interim order from the Supreme Court is not binding and holds no legal obligation to comply.” “Consequently, no court established under Sri Lanka’s Constitution has the authority to issue orders or judgments against a resolution that has already undergone due parliamentary processes and been approved by Parliament. Any such court order or judgment would constitute a violation of item 01 of Part B of the Parliament (Powers & Privileges) Act, No. 21 of 1953 (as amended).” By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: 25 accused further remanded till 10 August
author: Author not found
Content: Some 7,721 charges filed against 25 accused, including Nawfer Mowlavi, who have been implicated over the conspiracy to set off bombs, targeting Catholic Churches and star class hotels in Colombo and its suburbs, on 21 April (Easter Sunday) four years ago, were read before the Trial-at-Bar of the Colombo High Court, yesterday (9). The Department of Prisons produced the 25 accused before Court. Each of the accused, upon reading out the charges filed against them, pleaded not guilty . The Bench consisted of Judges Damith Thotawatta, Amal Ranaraja and Navaratne Marasinghe. The 25 accused were further remanded till 10 August, until such time the other charges filed against them are read out. The Attorney General indicted 25 accused before the High Court on 23,270 charges related to the said incident, while the 17th accused in the trial, had passed away while being imprisoned earlier. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Dilrukshi acquitted in voice tape case
author: Author not found
Content: The Public Service Commission (PSC) has decided to acquit former Director General of the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) Dilrukshi Dias Wickramasinghe from charges filed against her after she had been interdicted from duty due to the circulation of a controversial voice tape four years ago. The PSC has further pointed out that the conversation alleged to have taken place between Wickramasinghe and Chairman of Avant Garde Maritime Services Private Limited Nissanka Senadhipathi had been purportedly edited. A report compiled by the PSC has stated that they had taken this decision having perused submissions forwarded to it by the officials from the University of Moratuwa and the Government Analyst’s Department. The PSC commenced a probe into the incident after the contents of the voice tape went viral on social media in 2019. Thereafter, the former CIABOC DG was interdicted from the service on 24 September of that year. A top officer from the PSC added that Wickramasinghe, who is retired, would be entitled to her salary arrears and other requisite perks. At the time of the alleged incident, she was attached to the AG’s Department as the Deputy Solicitor General. By Mithun Jayawardena

title: PCs to be made corrupt-free – President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe said yesterday (9) the 13th Amendment to the Constitution must be implemented in a way that suits the nation’s growth and future. Delivering a special statement in Parliament, the President presented his suggestions and forthcoming action regarding the 13th Amendment and the delimitation of powers. After changing the laws regarding Provincial Councils and making new rules, if the Parliament agrees to change the Provincial Council Voting Act, this would include voting based on the District Proportional System, the President said. It would also let MPs run for positions in Provincial Councils. Additionally, there should be at least 25% women in these Councils. The President said following on how many women should be in these Councils, they will commence planning for Elections in these councils. He said the establishment of a committee, headed by the Prime Minister, will be pursued to re-evaluate the powers assigned to the central government, the functions assigned to Provincial Councils, and the shared responsibilities stipulated in the Constitution. The resulting amendments will be proposed, garnering the support of all parties in Parliament. Furthermore, he highlighted the intent to establish an advisory council to offer guidance to provincial governors until the Provincial Councils begin operations. Noting the role of Provincial Councils within the governance structure and political landscape of the country, the President emphasised the opportunity to effect a substantial transformation in constructing an effective, transparent, and corrupt-free Provincial Council system that commands public trust and addresses citizen concerns. The President acknowledged the challenges in reaching consensus, particularly with sensitive matters like police powers during the devolution of authority to Provincial Councils under the 13th Amendment. He underscored the importance of unity in executing these initiatives.

title: Excise Dept told to seek AG’s advice against Police officers
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Manjula Ratnayake informed the Department of Excise to seek instructions from the Attorney General on what action should be taken regarding the Police officers who allegedly obstructed the duty of a group of excise officers who were engaged in a drug raid in Bambalapitiya on 6 August. The Magistrate gave this instruction in consideration of a report filed by the Excise Department alleging that Police officers obstructed their duty. The Excise Department said they received information that drug trafficking activities were taking place near a hotel in Bambalapitiya.  A group of excise officials went to the location and when the suspects noticed the officials approaching, they attempted to escape using a luxury car. In response, the excise officers fired shots at the car to prevent the escape. After the shooting, Bambalapitiya Police arrested four excise officers and produced them in court. The excise officials were released on bail. It was revealed that one of the suspects involved in this smuggling was arrested and brought to court and remanded until 23 August. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: President scoffs at SJB over delay in debating NCM against Keheliya
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe yesterday (9) scoffed at the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) and queried how a date for Elections could be given when the SJB was not ready to debate the No-Confidence Motion (NCM) against Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella. Speaking in Parliament, the President said when the Government offered to take up the NCM this week, the Opposition did not agree. President: “You (the Opposition Leader) want Elections. How can I decide on Elections when you are not ready even to take up an NCM?” Opposition Leader: “Of course we want to debate the NCM. But it should be on our terms, not yours. You are trying to finish this as soon as possible. You have to do this properly.” The President: “There is a convention and according to that, when an NCM is submitted it should be taken up immediately. You know these things. We are ready to take up the debate soon. We are ready to have it tomorrow, the day after and on Saturday.” The SJB’s NCM against Rambukwella was handed over to the Speaker on 21 July. SJB General Secretary Ranjith Maddumabandara told the media that 45 MPs had signed the NCM. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Air Force Chief pays last respects to victims
author: Author not found
Content: Air Force Commander, Air Marshal Udeni Rajapaksa paid his final respects to the two Air Force officers who tragically lost their lives in the China Bay plane crash on 7 August. Wing Commander Tharindu Herath was laid to rest with full Air Force honours yesterday (9) at Borella Cemetery. Additionally, the funeral of Flying Officer Peshan Warnasooriya will take place today (10) with full Air Force honours at Diwulagahakotuwa Cemetery in Maharachchimulla, Alawwa. On 7 August, a PT-6 trainer aircraft attached to the No. 1 Flying Training Wing in China Bay, crashed shortly after takeoff, resulting in the unfortunate deaths of Herath and Warnasooriya. (NV)

title: Damage to train engine could run into billions – SL Railways
author: Author not found
Content: Due to the severity of a collision between a train and a container at the Wilwatta railway crossing last morning (9), the container had been thrown some 100 metres away from the scene of the accident while considerable damage had been caused to signal towers, and the gates at the railway crossing. Following the crash traffic flow on the Giriulla-Meerigama road had also been completely stalled and it had only been reopened for traffic after a four-hour delay. A top official from the Sri Lanka Railways Department (SLRD) said the damage caused to the train engine could run into billions of rupees. He said due to the massive damage, SLRD officials are compelled to tow the engine out of the track. He said once that is done, the damage to the engine could be assessed. The accident occurred when a container transporting a luxury vehicle had stalled for about 10 minutes near the Wilwatta railway crossing when a train heading from Polgahawela to Ratmalana had crashed into the container. Due to the accident, traffic flow on the mainline experienced long delays yesterday. Trains traveling to Colombo and those heading to the North were also inordinately delayed. However, SLRD sources confirmed that no loss of lives had been reported. Meerigama Police said the driver and the assistant of the luxury motorcar had jumped out of the vehicle for safety at the nick of time. BY Mithun Jayawardena

title: SC dismisses Petition on EPF, ETF
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court dismissed the Fundamental Rights (FR) Petition filed pertaining to the Employees’ Provident Fund (EPF) and Employees’ Trust Fund (ETF) related to the Domestic Debt Optimization process. The Petition was filed by Attorney-at-Law Sunil Watagala on behalf of the Inter-Company Employees’ Union, its President Wasantha Samarasinghe and six others. The petitioners sought an order from Court preventing the Government from waiving off the loans obtained from the EPF and ETF during the Domestic Debt Optimisation process. However, the Supreme Court today dismissed the petition without taking it up for hearing. The Supreme Court yesterday (9) rejected a petition that aimed to stop the Government from canceling loans acquired from the EPF and ETF funds during the process of restructuring domestic debt. The petition was filed by Attorney-at-Law Sunil Watagala on behalf of the Inter-Company Employees’ Union, along with its President Wasantha Samarasinghe and six others. They sought an order to prevent the Government from waiving off loans taken from the EPF and ETF during the Domestic Debt Optimisation process. The petitioners argued that a large portion of the money (93% of EPF deposits and 86% of ETF deposits) has been invested in government Treasury Bills and Central Bank bonds. They also claim that the Government’s decision to waive these loans taken from their EPF and ETF was unfair by the working community of around 20 million people. Therefore, the petitioners asked the Supreme Court to declare that the Government’s actions would infringe upon the fundamental rights of the working people, if the loans reduced these funds during domestic debt restructuring and requested an interim order to halt this action.

title: CTU mulls legal action against principal appointments
author: Author not found
Content: The Ceylon Teachers’ Union (CTU) plans to institute legal action against the move to appoint a new principal for Royal College, Colombo, without following due process, CTU General Secretary Joseph Stalin said yesterday (9). Speaking to Ceylon Today, Stalin pointed out that the selected candidate for the post of principal at Royal College did not attend the interview nor submitted any transfer applications. Stalin said the post of principal at Royal College in Colombo became vacant from yesterday (9), and there are allegations that a person with ties to former Education Minister Akila Viraj Kariyawasam is being considered for the post. CTU has decided to collaborate with other education trade unions to institute legal action against the move to appoint a principal who wasn’t even interviewed. Additionally, he alleged that appointments for new principals are planned without finalising the transfers of principals in five prominent schools in the country. These schools include Royal College, Colombo, D.S. Senanayake College, Colombo, Mahanama College, Colombo, Mahinda Rajapaksa College, Homagama, and Kuliyapitiya Central College. These principals were not included in the transfer list. He said interviews were conducted to select principals for 34 prominent schools, and this list has been forwarded to the Public Service Commission (PSC) for approval. However, the five principals mentioned in the initial list were absent from the PSC’s list. As a result, the initial list was rejected, and the PSC instructed to send the complete list. Even in the second list sent to the PSC, the above-mentioned schools were not mentioned. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: 56th ASEAN Day Celebrations at Indonesian Embassy, Colombo
author: Author not found
Content: The President of Sri Lanka, Ranil Wickremesinghe as the Chief Guest graced the occasion at the 56th ASEAN Day Celebrations held at the Indonesian Embassy in Colombo on 8 August. “The event was organised by the Heads of ASEAN Missions in Sri Lanka consisting of  Dewi Gustina Tobing, the Ambassador of Indonesia, U Han Thu, the Ambassador of Myanmar,  Badli Hisham, the High Commissioner of Malaysia, Poj Harnpol, the Ambassador of Thailand, and Ho Thi Thanh Truc, the Ambassador of Vietnam” said Heru Prayitno, Minister Counsellor of the Embassy of Indonesia. The Speaker of the Sri Lankan Parliament, Cabinet Ministers, State Ministers, Ambassadors/High Commissioners, Members of Parliament, the President’s Chief of Staff, the Chief of Sri Lanka Defence Staff, the Commander of the Sri Lanka Tri Forces, religious leaders, and other VIPs were also present. At her opening remarks, the Indonesian Ambassador, Dewi Gustina Tobing, on behalf of ASEAN Heads of Missions, enlightened the guests that commemorating the ASEAN Day commenced when fifty-six years ago, on 8 August 1967, five leaders – the Foreign Ministers of Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, and Thailand – sat down together in the main Hall of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs building in Bangkok, Thailand, and signed the document on the establishment of Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN). Since then, ASEAN has succeeded in building the Southeast Asian region as an economically, politically, and culturally integrated region. Ambassador Dewi further notified that Indonesia is the Chairman of ASEAN for 2023 and carried the theme “ASEAN Matters: Epicentrum of Growth”. With that theme, ASEAN countries would ensure that ASEAN remains and is increasingly strengthening its central role and being the centre of growth to make ASEAN significant and relevant to the ASEAN community and the world. ASEAN will continue to work closely with Sri Lanka. In the meantime, in his keynote remarks, President Ranil Wickremesinghe appraised the development and the central role of ASEAN and was keen to have a closer collaboration with ASEAN, given the strong ties between Sri Lanka and Southeast Asian countries. The President emphasised that collaborating more closely with ASEAN was one of his government’s policies whereby Sri Lanka could build more advanced political, economic, and cultural relations as well as expressed his intention for Sri Lanka to join the ASEAN-RCEP (Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership). The President also underscored that the Sri Lankan Government supported the concept of the ASEAN Outlook on Indo-Pacific and hoped there would be an increase in trade, investment, and tourists from ASEAN countries that benefit Sri Lanka’s economic development. The Annual ASEAN Day is celebrated in all Member States and at diplomatic missions, including the ASEAN Missions in Sri Lanka. Since its formation, ASEAN has succeeded in building the Southeast Asian region as an economically, politically, and culturally integrated region while upholding the principle of maintaining the centrality and proactive role of ASEAN in its relations with its external partners. It was also noted that Sri Lanka’s major exports to the region consisted of apparel, electrical machinery, natural pearls, and tea. Sri Lanka joined the ASEAN Regional Forum (ARF) in 2007 and was a signatory to the ASEAN’s Treaty of Amity and Cooperation in the same year. The Celebration of the 56th ASEAN Day consisted of two activities, namely the hoisting of the ASEAN Flag by three of the Indonesian Embassy’s personnel and followed by a Cocktail Reception at the Riptaloka Hall, whereby all guests tasted ASEAN countries’ traditional cuisine.

title: Embarking On ‘Green Roadtrip’ Seeking Environmental Justice
author: Author not found
Content: The inaugural session of the ‘Green Roadtrip’, a project to mobilise communities for environmental justice across the country was successfully held recently in Colombo. This series of events will be implemented by the Centre for Environmental Law and Policy of the University of Colombo, through the Support to Justice Sector Project (JURE), funded by the European Union and jointly implemented by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and UNICEF Sri Lanka, facilitated by the Ministry of Justice. The opening ceremony of the Green Roadtrip series was presided over by Snr. Prof. H.D. Karunaratne, Vice Chancellor, University of Colombo, along with Prof. (Dr.) Sampath Punchihewa, Dean, Faculty of Law, Prof. (Dr.) Kokila Konasinghe, Director, Centre for Environmental Law and Policy, and representatives from UNDP. Speaking at the occasion, Snr. Prof. H.D. Karunaratne remarked on the value and importance of this initiative at a juncture when environmental issues have become a global challenge. “JURE has provided the perfect platform for the Centre for Environmental Law and Policy of the Faculty of Law, University of Colombo to embark on this new initiative by promoting environmental awareness among the public authorities and youth communities,” he further added. The initial segment of this programme was for public officials from the provincial level and local government authorities representing the Western Province, covering national pollution control laws, environmental protection licence, public nuisance issues and environmental duties in legislation pertaining to local governments. Guest lectures from experts in the field such as Hemantha Vidanage, Snr. Adviser to the Centre for Environmental Justice and Dr. Rathnayaka, the Dep. Director of the Central Environmental Authority further enriched the programme. The sessions encouraged interaction and idea-sharing among the participants and concluded with awarding of certificates for all participants. The third day of the event targeted youth groups, with the participation of around 85 youth representing various universities, clubs and societies. The session topics selected for youth participants covered environmental justice and sustainable development and saw the lively participation and interaction of the youth groups. Speaking at this inaugural event in Colombo, Maheshi Herat, Technical Specialist (Civil and Criminal) of the JURE Project, UNDP stated, “Environmental degradation and its impact, can have harrowing implications on the well-being of people, including their right to life. JURE partnered with CELP to enable this countrywide Roadtrip to take place, which will create awareness on environmental justice and empower those who are in positions of authority to take the best course of action.” With the initiation of the Green Roadtrip in Colombo, the Centre for Environmental Law and Policy, University of Colombo is on the path to engage with government bodies and youth groups in all provinces around the country, discussing laws and legislation surrounding environmental law, the concept of environmental justice, environmental rights, sustainable development goals, the role of government in addressing environmental issues, sustainable energy and the green economy. Specially curated sessions will also be held to address area-specific environmental issues, during this Roadtrip.

title: A promising commencement of insightful discourse
author: Author not found
Content: The eagerly awaited Colombo Arbitration Week 2023 commenced on a high note, as legal professionals and enthusiasts of Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) gathered in the vibrant city of Colombo. The event’s inaugural session on Sunday saw the convergence of minds and ideas, marking the beginning of a week-long exploration into the world of Arbitration. The event’s curtain raiser was none other than Sulaiman Rameez, the Convenor of Colombo Arbitration Week. In his Welcome Address, Rameez set the tone for the upcoming discussions. He laid out the overarching goals of the Colombo Arbitration Week, deftly shedding light on the unique challenges and requirements that the local arbitration landscape presents. Notably, he emphasised the event’s commitment to enhancing the status of arbitration in Sri Lanka and positioning the nation as a global focal point for international dispute resolution. Following this introduction, the stage was graced by Malin Herwig, the UNDP Deputy Resident Representative. Her presence underscored the international recognition and support that Sri Lanka’s ‘Arbitration’ endeavours have garnered. Herwig delivered remarks that resonated with the audience, particularly highlighting the collaborative partnership between Colombo Arbitration Week 2023 and the Justice Reform (JURE) project. This partnership has undertaken the mission of spearheading the widespread adoption and promotion of Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) practices across the length and breadth of Sri Lanka. The evening’s programme unfolded to reveal two pivotal segments that enthralled the attendees. Dr. Romesh Weeramantry, an eminent figure in the realm of Legal and Arbitration circles, delivered an insightful Keynote Address. As a respected authority, Dr. Weeramantry masterfully delved into the steps that Sri Lanka must undertake to solidify its foothold on the Asian Arbitration landscape. With eloquence and precision, he dissected the current Arbitration terrain, deftly highlighting both effective strategies and imminent challenges. His address resonated as a clarion call, urging all stakeholders to rally together, united in purpose, to pave the way for a more robust Arbitration ecosystem within the nation. The event’s narrative then seamlessly transitioned into an engaging Panel Discussion, aptly titled “In Favour of Not Reinventing the Wheel or Chartering Our Own Path?” This session saw the convergence of luminaries who have left an indelible mark on the Arbitration landscape. Justice Janak De Silva, Judge of the Supreme Court of Sri Lanka, Justice Anselmo Reyes, former Judge of the High Court of Hong Kong, and Eric Ng, the Deputy Registrar of the Hong Kong International Arbitration Centre (HKIAC) covered all possible areas related to the question. During this captivating session, Justice Janak De Silva brought his extensive experience to the fore. He skillfully highlighted the existing gaps within Sri Lanka’s Legal and Arbitration framework, identified several strengths of the proposed Arbitration Act, and invited valuable perspectives from his fellow panellists. The esteemed members of the panel engaged in a riveting dialogue, underscoring the pivotal importance of embracing diversity, assimilating industry best practices, and charting a distinctive trajectory tailored to Sri Lanka’s unique context. A particularly resonant theme emerged during the discussion – the indispensable role of the younger generation in the realm of arbitration. The panellists unanimously stressed the significance of nurturing a culture of innovation and inclusivity, transcending the boundaries of seniority and experience. As the curtains drew on the first day of the Colombo Arbitration Week, a palpable sense of anticipation hung in the air. Participants departed with renewed zeal, eagerly looking forward to the days ahead. The remainder of the week promises an array of thought-provoking topics, expertly explored by luminaries within the field. Notably, an Award Writing Workshop, conducted by the Singapore International Arbitration Centre, is scheduled for 10 August. This will be followed by a landmark event – Sri Lanka’s inaugural Practitioners’ Assembly – slated for 12/13 August. As the sun sets on this promising inauguration, the stage is set for a week of inspired dialogue and profound insights, with Colombo Arbitration Week 2023 poised to catalyse fresh vistas of development in the realm of dispute resolution.

title: MoU between Illinois, Peradeniya Unis for exchange programme in education
author: Author not found
Content: The signing of a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) between the University of Illinois and the University of Peradeniya to establish a cooperative exchange programme in the field of education and research took place yesterday (9) under the chairmanship of Minister of Education Susil Premajayantha at the University Grants Commission (UGC) premises. On behalf of Sri Lanka, Vice-Chancellor of University of Peradeniya Prof. M. D.  Lamawansha signed the agreement and Peter Constable, Dean of the College of Veterinary Medicine of the University of Illinois signed for the US Government. Expanding and strengthening research and professional education cooperation between the two countries, special educational development is expected in the fields of veterinary medicine, animal food, animal medicine and veterinary surgery at the University of Peradeniya and to exchange relevant information and technical knowledge between the two countries. Sri Lankan scientist Siva Sivanathan, UGC Chairman Prof. Sampath Amaratunga and several other officials were present on this occasion.

title: Speaker certifies Anti- Corruption Bill
author: Author not found
Content: Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena on Tuesday (8) signed into law the Anti-Corruption Bill, which was passed in Parliament last month. Consequently, this legislation, which garnered unanimous approval among the 225-member Parliament, became effective from Tuesday (8). Originally presented to the House on 6 July, the Anti-Corruption Bill underwent amendments and was subsequently passed in Parliament on 19 July.

title: International Day of the World’s Indigenous Peoples
author: Author not found
Content: Violation of the rights of indigenous peoples has emerged as an ongoing concern. In response to this issue, indigenous communities are reminded of their entitlement to chart their own courses and implement decisions in ways that hold significance and align with their cultural values each year on 9 August. The International Day of the World’s Indigenous Peoples is observed to raise awareness and protect the rights of the world’s indigenous population. This event also recognises the achievements and contributions that indigenous people make to improve world issues such as environmental protection. This year’s International Day of the World’s Indigenous Peoples themed ‘Indigenous Youth as Agents of Change for Self-Determination,’ acknowledges their dedicated endeavours toward climate action, justice, and underscores the pivotal role of indigenous youth in shaping decisions. Dilena Pathragoda, Executive Director of the Centre for Environmental Justice (CEJ), said, “World Indigenous Day is commemorated annually on 9 August. In Sri Lanka, this took place in the Kotabakiniya, an Adivasi village located in Damana.” Particularly in Sri Lanka, the Indigenous People’s Day follows the Wariga Sabhawa (assembly) of indigenous people. During this event, indigenous individuals gather from distant areas like Henanigala, Rathugala, Pollebedda, and Wakarei, where the indigenous people reside. The Wariga Sabhawa convened, led by Uruwarige Wannila Aththo, and significant decisions were made by indigenous leaders. In 2022, the CEJ actively participated in this event and took the initiative to distribute a book called ‘Wedi Bhashawa’ (Indigenous Language) within their community. This book holds great significance for the indigenous people. Several crucial proposals were put forth during the Tribal Assembly on that day, Pathragoda said. “During the same event, discussions involving government entities such as the Department of Forest Conservation, Department of Wildlife Conservation, Local Government bodies, and Divisional Secretariats took place, focusing on the rights and challenges faced by indigenous communities. These discussions culminated in submitting a memorandum to the Government. While hopes were pinned on finding solutions within a year, the proposals presented last year remain unresolved.” Challenges related to climate change, food security, and environmental degradation must be addressed and deforestation stands out as a pressing threat to this region, Pathragoda said. “Notably, the ‘Galwala Yaya’ reserve in Pollebedda was threatened, prompting legal intervention to prevent over 1,500 acres of land from being used for maize cultivation. Although deforestation has ceased, the ‘Rambakan Oya,’ a water source that serves the area, has become contaminated, posing drinking water concerns. Several measures are imperative to safeguard the well-being and future of indigenous communities, necessitating substantial government intervention,” he pointed out.
