title: Old boy of Maliyadeva College enlarged on bail
author: Author not found
Content: An old boy of Maliyadeva College, Kurunegala, who is alleged to have assaulted the school’s disciplinary teacher during school hours on 4 August was suspended from all posts in the school’s Old Boys’ Association, the OBA announced. All teachers of the school have opted out of extracurricular activities in protest.  A feud had erupted between two groups of students, leading to a rugby player from the school setting upon the school’s teacher in charge of discipline. Three other students were hospitalised following the incident. The old boy charged with the assault was produced before the Kurunegala Chief Magistrate on 7 August and was enlarged on two sureties of Rs 200,000 each. By Ravindu Sooriyabandara – Kurunegala

title: SL’s first ‘French fries factory’ to open tomorrow
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s first potato strip (French fries) manufacturing plant is scheduled to open in Bandarawela, Kahattewela tomorrow (11). A senior spokesman for the Agriculture Ministry said the factory had been constructed on the Sri Sangharaja Temple premises in Kahattewela by the Smallholder Agribusiness Partnerships Programme (SAPP) of the Ministry of Agriculture and the Kahattewela Janatha Govi Samagama at a cost of over Rs 100 million. Potato strips or French fries are presently imported to Sri Lanka at a cost of about Rs 3.5 billion. With the high demand for ‘French fries,’ potato strips are prepared using locally grown potatoes. The factory purchases potatoes from 250 farmers while the daily production of potato strips is 1,000 kg. The island’s first model agricultural village, in Kahattewela was started by Minister Mahinda Amaraweera in 2018 while he was the Minister of Agriculture. However, due to various issues, the Factory was non-functional. But with the Minister being appointed as the Minister of Agriculture a second time the factory’s work was completed while production activities are scheduled to commence on 11 August. Minister Amaraweera said the aim was to produce things locally which would save Sri Lanka a large amount of foreign exchange.

title: Verité survey finds most believe ‘Aragalaya’a futile effort
author: Author not found
Content: Approximately 60 per cent of respondents of a recent survey conducted by Verité Research do not believe that the ‘Aragalaya’ fulfilled the wishes and aspirations of the people, while 11 per cent believe it did, 29 per cent held no opinion on the matter. The survey delved into various aspects of the Aragalaya. The survey, conducted in June 2023, also explored views on priorities for rebuilding the country. When asked to select from three options, 51 per cent of respondents emphasised the need to address corrupt and bad governance as a priority to rebuild the country, 34 per cent advocated to change the economic system and 15 per cent believed in giving precedence to stability over democratic space. During the time of the Aragalaya, which held a significant presence at Galle Face Green from 9 April, 2022, to 10 August 2022, pivotal events transpired, including the appointment of a new prime minister, the formation of a cabinet of ministers, and the resignation of President Gotabaya Rajapaksa. The survey, based on responses from 1,008 Sri Lankan adults, aimed to capture a nationally representative sentiment. The methodology and sample design ensured a maximum error margin of under ±3 per cent at a 95 per cent confidence interval.

title: 25-year-old youthgoes missing
author: Author not found
Content: Police request public assistance to find a 25-year-old youth who has been missing since October 2022.  Minuwangoda Police have launched an investigation following a complaint lodged by the parents. Kalinga Ramesh Chathuranga Perera has been missing since October 2022. He is approximately 5’5” tall and was last seen wearing a black long-sleeved shirt and a pair of blue striped shorts. Contact: Minuwangoda Police OIC:071 – 8591612 Minuwangoda Police Station:031 – 2295223 By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: State must act fastto obtain Insulin – Dr. Aluthge
author: Author not found
Content: The State should take immediate action, at least at a diplomatic level, to obtain stocks of insulin required by a large number of patients with diabetes, Secretary of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA) Dr. Haritha Aluthge said. Fielding questions during a media briefing on Tuesday (8) Dr. Aluthge said that insulin was an essential for some diabetic patients. “This is a matter of life and death where the required stocks should be obtained through at least government to government intervention via the diplomatic missions,” he urged.  Dr. Aluthge said the Health Minister should not merely pay lip service but should go beyond his words and put an end to emergency purchasing. He accused the Minister of having repeatedly stated that the Ministry would put a stop to emergency purchasing of medicinal drugs. “If the Minister wants to retain his credibility then he should go beyond his words and not just put an abrupt stop to emergency purchasing, but present the necessary agenda on how he proposes to do it, Dr. Aluthge said. The situation is the same with the fast depleting stocks of insulin available in State hospitals. They should not look for ways and means to award the tenders, to their bosom buddies, at a high cost.  Instead of leaving room for the large number of allegations of corruption related to the procurement of insulin, health authorities should intervene and take immediate action to procure necessary stocks as early as possible, he said. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: CEB will ensure uninterrupted power supply– Kanchana
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera said the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) will ensure an uninterrupted supply of Power islandwide, as there are no plans to schedule power cuts, despite the breakdown of Unit 2 of Norochcholai power plant and water scarcity in major reservoirs. During a press conference, at the President’s Media Centre (PMC) yesterday (8), he emphasised that the CEB will secure the necessary supplementary power required to maintain an uninterrupted 24-hour power supply. He addressed concerns about potential power cuts and urged citizens not to be misled by false information disseminated by certain political groups. Wijesekera mentioned that the Cabinet had approved the continuous provision of electricity to all areas of the country and endorsed utilising the maximum water capacity of the Samanalawewa Reservoir for electricity generation. He explained that the Electricity Board had already commenced releasing 3.5 million cubic metres of water from the reservoir’s maximum capacity since 3:00 a.m. on 8 August to generate electricity. He noted that between 11 – 15 August, the plans include releasing 2.5 million cubic metres of water to generate electricity. However, considering the existing water capacity, by 16 August, the electricity generation activities of the Samanalawewa reservoir will have to be temporarily suspended. The Cabinet has also granted approval to finalise the Polpitiya and Hambantota transmission line systems and procure electricity as needed. The Irrigation Department and the Water Management Committee hold the responsibility for releasing water required for power generation in other reservoirs. The Samanalawewa reservoir’s water capacity is efficiently managed for electricity generation under the CEB’s supervision. With adherence to the planned programme, the CEB aims to provide electricity without interruption until 15 September. Wijesekera acknowledged that due to the release of additional water from the Samanalawewa Reservoir, there’s a risk of power cuts in the Matara and Hambantota Districts of the Southern Province and partially in the Galle and Ratnapura Districts for a specified period. He emphasised on the essential purchase of electricity, given the insufficient water capacity in the Samanalawewa reservoir. To ensure continuous power supply, arrangements are being made to purchase electricity by 16 August. He stressed on the government’s proactive approach to address the immediate crisis and prevent further crises. Considering the available water capacity, all power plant systems are operational to supply electricity. Wijesekera clarified that the government has not taken any decision to implement power cuts and undue fear should not be generated among the public. Power cuts adversely impact tourism and industries. He highlighted that the plan for uninterrupted power supply was presented to the Cabinet after consultation with all parties. In addition to ensuring continuous electricity supply, the government has also resolved to allocate a specific amount of water for agricultural purposes. Recognising the ongoing drought situation and potential climate changes, Wijesekera expressed the government’s commitment to securing necessary electricity supply for the next two years and obtaining the required legal provisions. Wijesekera criticised factions with vested interests for attempting to politicise the matter during a drought crisis. He called for unity among all parties to collaborate with the government and officials in addressing the challenges faced by the people. Additionally, he informed that Unit 2 of the Norochcholai Coal Power Plant, generating 270 megawatts, suffered a breakdown due to a technical issue. Meanwhile, Unit 3 of the power plant has remained non-operational since 13 June for scheduled major overhaul maintenance work. As a result, only one unit of the power plant is currently operational, contributing 300 megawatts to the national grid. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Accountant dies in Kandana factory fire
author: Author not found
Content: A person lost his life in a fire that erupted around 8.00 a.m. in a detergent manufacturing company situated near Nendurupitiya in Kandana. The deceased was an Accountant by profession. Hospital and Police sources said that due to the smoke from the fire, 85 students from a nearby school were taken to Ragama Teaching Hospital for treatment. A group of students from St. Sebastian’s Girls’ College, located in close proximity to the factory, were admitted to the Ragama Teaching Hospital because they had inhaled a significant amount of smoke from the fire. The factory in question, named Global Care, employs 19 individuals. Hospital officials said that the condition of the schoolgirls was not severe. The Welisara Navy firefighting unit, along with the Negombo and Gampaha Municipal firefighting units, managed to extinguish the flames and prevent the fire from spreading further. The exact cause of the fire remains unknown. The fire resulted in the complete destruction of the factory. BY Prasanga Pavuluhewa – Ja Ela

title: Kanchana shifts blame to CEB
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara shifted the blame to the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB), regarding Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) member Namal Rajapaksa’s alleged unpaid electricity bill for services provided during his 2019 wedding. Speaking at a press conference, held at the President’s Media Centre (PMC) yesterday (8), Wijesekara stated that the CEB informed him that Rajapaksa hadn’t been issued a bill for those services. A report explaining the reasons behind the absence of an invoice for the past three years will be produced tomorrow (10). Wijesekara said, “It’s unlikely that anyone would pay for something without receiving a bill. The Minister has responded to the social media release by writing a letter on this matter. Subsequently, we’ve instructed the ministry and CEB to swiftly investigate why the bill wasn’t provided to the MP and ensure it reaches him. If any payments are due, the responsibility of delivering the bill lies with the CEB.” Former Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna (JVP) Provincial Council member Nalin Hewage last week revealed that he received a response from the CEB to his Right to Information (RTI) request. Accordingly, the CEB confirmed that an outstanding sum of Rs 2.6 million was due for the Weeraketiya residence, linked to security lights and generators, used during an event held between 12 and 15 September 2019. Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara shifted the blame to the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) in regard of Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) Namal Rajapaksa’s alleged unpaid electricity bill for the services obtained for his wedding in 2019. Addressing the press conference held at the President’s Media Centre (PMC) yesterday (8), Wijesekara said that the CEB informed him that Rajapaksa hasn’t received a bill for those services and the report as to why he hasn’t received an invoice for the past three years will be submitted on 10 August. “I don’t think anyone would pay for something if they haven’t received a bill. Minister has written a letter in this regard responding to the release that was in social media. Following, we have instructed the ministry and CEB to make an immediate inquiry on why the invoice has not been given to the MP and make sure it has been given to him. If there’s any payments to be made the CEB should be responsible on handing over the bill to anyone,” he added. Former Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna (JVP) Provincial Council member Nalin Hewage claimed earlier today that the CEB responded to his RTI request, stating that Namal Rajapksa has yet to settle the electricity bill from his 2019 wedding. The RTI document reveals an outstanding amount of Rs. 26,82,246.57 for the Weeraketiya house, related to security lights and generators used during an event held between September 12, 2019, and September 15, 2019. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Cabinet go ahead to amend EPF Act
author: Author not found
Content: The Cabinet of Ministers has given the green light to a proposal that aims to change the Employees’ Provident Fund (EPF) Act. The goal is to ensure that there’s a minimum annual interest rate of 9 per cent within the next four years. During a session on Monday (7), the Cabinet approved a resolution put forth by President Ranil Wickremesinghe, who also serves as the Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilisation and National Policies. This resolution directs the necessary action to amend the EPF Act No. 15 of 1958. The main point is to ensure that the minimum annual interest rate on the contributions, from 2023 to 2026, is set at least at nine per cent. This decision came after analysing the interest rates that EPF members received over the past five years.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Three-member probe committee appointed – Dy Speaker
author: Author not found
Content: Deputy Speaker Ajith Rajapakse revealed in Parliament yesterday (8) that a three-member committee has been appointed to conduct an internal investigation into the complaints raised by female employees, of the Housekeeping Department of Parliament. The Deputy Speaker was responding to a query from Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Rohini Kumari Wijerathna. Rajapakse said these complaints revolve around allegations of sexual abuse and harassment by senior officials. MP Wijerathna said that the affected female employees were coerced by the implicated senior officials to provide written assurances that no instances of abuse or assault had occurred. These actions, she mentioned, have cast doubts on the possibility of an impartial investigation. She called for stringent measures to be taken against those found responsible for these incidents. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: LG bodies amendment Bills inconsistent with Constitution
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court has determined that the Bills proposing amendments to the Pradeshiya Sabha Ordinance, Municipal Council Ordinance and Urban Council Ordinance, to reinstate local government members and re-convene the dissolved bodies are inconsistent with the Constitution, Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena informed Parliament yesterday (8). The Supreme Court has informed that these Bills should be passed by a special majority and a referendum, the Speaker said. The controversial amendments to the Pradeshiya Sabha, Municipal Council and Urban Council Ordinances, to reinstate local government members and re-convene dissolved bodies were presented to Parliament as a Private Members Bill by Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) MP Jayantha Ketagoda. The amendments were gazetted on 26 June. The Opposition and election monitoring organisations alleged that these Bill was anti-democratic. Meanwhile, the Attorney General in a letter addressed to the Secretary General of Parliament had informed her that the Bill was inconsistent with articles 3, 4, 12(1) and 14(1) of the Constitution and that it has to be enacted with a special majority and through a referendum. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Excise officers enlarged on bail
author: Author not found
Content: The Colombo Additional Magistrate yesterday (8) released on bail the four Excise officers, who were arrested by Bambalapitiya Police over shooting at a car on the previous day (7). Bail was set at two sureties of one million rupees each and the Magistrate also imposed a travel ban on the suspects. Although the Bambalapitiya Police requested that the suspects be remanded to a reserved prison, the Magistrate explained that since the Police did not provide enough evidence to the Court for remanding the Excise officers, they would be granted bail. Inquiring further, the Magistrate questioned whether Excise officers needed permission from the Police to conduct drug raids or use firearms to apprehend suspects involved in such activities. The Police clarified that Excise officers were not required to seek permission from the Police for such actions. The Magistrate also asked the Police if a statement had been obtained from the Excise Department regarding whether the Excise officers were directed to the location for the raid. The Police stated that they were instructed to obtain such a statement but hadn’t obtained it yet. Police informed the Court that on the previous day (7), the car used by the alleged drug dealers was found abandoned in the Wellawatta area. However, none of them had been arrested. The Police are investigating whether the shooting incident arose from a personal dispute and whether anyone in the car was wounded due to the shooting. According to the details submitted to the Court by the Police, the shooting incident occurred in the afternoon of 7 August in Marine Drive in Bambalapitiya. During the proceedings, a number of officials from the Excise Department were present in Court. The case was postponed to 22 August. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Cricket legend Tendulkar appeals to the affluent
author: Author not found
Content: Indian cricket legend and UNICEF South Asia Regional Goodwill Ambassador Sachin Tendulkar  appealed to those individuals who possess the means to make a difference and urged them to extend their care, support and resources to children who don’t have fair opportunities in their lives. Tendulkar, with several young people, who are a part of the UNICEF-supported Children’s Club network of the Department of Probation and Child Care Services participated in a ‘close cricket match’  yesterday (8). Prior to the ‘match,’ Tendulkar emphasised that it is important for every child in every country to have the opportunity to grow up in a state of happiness and good health. He also encouraged children to engage in sports, noting its potential to enhance focus and determination. He stressed that many children suffer from stunting. During his visit, Tendulkar also made a stop at a pre-school that benefits from UNICEF’s mid-day school meal programme. Here, he actively participated by serving nutrient-rich meals to the children. He expressed his deep appreciation for the heartwarming practice observed at the school, where he witnessed students, as they enjoyed their mid-day meal, their teacher walking around with a plate. The children voluntarily set aside a portion of their meal on this plate. Curious about the purpose, Tendulkar inquired, and the teacher explained  that this is for all the  birds outside and they know it’s their food time too. He said he had also the opportunity to spend time with their families in the tea plantation and he understood their challenges. Tendulkar visited the Sabaragamuwa Province where he interacted with children from various schools, played cricket and interacted with Indian Origin Tamils. He advocated the local therapeutic food, which is similar in operation in India, which is a ready to eat package made out of food that is available in the area, having all the local ingredients, making it a nutritious meal, which he believed is practiced here in Sri Lanka as well. Tendulkar started his engagements with UNICEF in 2015. He lauded the efforts of all government and non-government organisations towards bringing a positive change despite challenging environments. Since August 2022, UNICEF’s midday meal programme has been providing nutritious meals to 50,000 preschool children in nearly 1,400 schools across the country. The meal programme has also helped boost pre-school attendance.  “Children require a nutrient-rich diet and quality education to reach their full potential. By investing in their education and nutrition, we are not only investing in their future but also every country’s future,” said Tendulkar. “The children I spoke with are showing great tenacity, and their hope for a better future remains strong. We need to continue supporting them so they keep achieving their goals,” added Tendulkar. Since Tendulkar was appointed as the first UNICEF  Ambassador for South Asia in 2013, he has been playing a pivotal role in improving the lives of children in South Asia. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: All ethnic groups must be given equal rights
author: Author not found
Content: Ven. Walawahangunawewe Dhammarathana Thera, the Chief Incumbent of Mihintale Rajamaha Viharaya on Sunday (6) said all ethnic groups in Sri Lanka should be given equal rights without any discrimination. The Thera also extended this sentiment to the Malaiyaha (Upcountry Tamils of Indian origin) community, who were brought to the country, around 200 years ago, from India, to work in plantation industries through Mannar. He asserted that this community deserves equal rights, including access to housing and land. These remarks were made while welcoming a group of individuals who embarked on a padayathra from Talaimannar to Matale. During his address, the Thera highlighted the divisive tactics employed by politicians that have created disunity within society and condemned the existence of castes and religious differences, emphasising the inherent equality of everyone. He questioned the separation of schools along ethnic lines, suggesting that unity could disrupt the political agenda driven by these divisions. “Sinhala children should learn Tamil and Tamil and Muslim children should learn Sinhala, asserting that such unity would challenge the divisive strategies of politicians,” he said. All citizens, regardless of their identities, deserve equal rights, the Thera asserted. BY Shabeer Mohamed

title: Nine arrested for forcibly entering CBSL premises
author: Author not found
Content: Nine persons, including a woman, were arrested yesterday (8) for forcibly entering the Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) premises. This was following members of the Joint Association of Leasing and Debt Instalment Payers forcefully trying to enter the CBSL premise, after gathering in front of the CBSL to conduct a protest by sitting on the ground. Both, CBSL security personnel and the Police worked together to disperse the demonstraters, who declared their intention to launch an ongoing Satyagraha campaign on the premises. The nine protesters were arrested when the situation became heated. Nine members of the Lease and Instalment Payers Association have been taken into police custody who forcibly entered the premises of the Central Bank of Sri Lanka yesterday (8). Police said, a tense situation was created between the Police and the arrested while they were taken to custody. Meanwhile, there were a woman and eight men among the arrested. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: Prof. Ariyananda to deliver twentieth E.A. Wijesooriya oration
author: Author not found
Content: Mahinda College OBA, Colombo, is organising this annual event, in memory of the late Principal E.A. Wijesooriya, on 17 August at 5:00 p.m. at the Auditorium of the Meteorology Department, Colombo 7. This year, Prof. P.L. Ariyananda, former Dean, Medical Faculty of Ruhuna University, will deliver the oration on his experience ‘Seven Habits That Helped Me to Be an Effective Medical Dean’. Wijesooriya served as Principal at Mahinda College, Galle from 1932-1962 and was a prominent Educationist who nurtured a long list of distinguished students. The President and the OBA Committee expect Mahindians and well-wishers to be present on this occasion.

title: Top Indian investors meet Ports and Shipping Minister
author: Author not found
Content: A group of 12 leading Indian investors whose attention has been drawn to starting several projects in Sri Lanka’s shipping and aviation sector met Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva on 8 August for a discussion in this connection. At this discussion, the Indian investors stated that their group is focused on investing in the future development of the ports of Kankesanturai and Trincomalee. Commenting on this, the minister said with the commencement of passenger cruise services and luxury passenger ship services between Kankesanturai and India, the Port Authority has taken steps to provide infrastructure to Kankesanturai Port. Therefore, with the permission of the Indian Government, opportunities can be provided to investors who wish to start these transport services, the minister emphasised. The investors said they would like to invest in this passenger transport project with the permission of the Indian Government, and they will hold discussions with the relevant parties in the future. Regarding investment opportunities in Sri Lanka’s aviation sector, the minister said there are various investment opportunities related to aviation services within the Mattala Airport premises and for this purpose, the ministry will request proposals in the future. Indian investors paid close attention to this. Further, the two parties discussed starting direct flight services between the airports located in the main cities of India and the airports of Ratmalana, Jaffna and Batticaloa. Twelve representatives including Dr. Arvind Gupta, Ashok K. Kanth and Lt. Gen. R.K.Sawhney, Secretary of the Ministry K.D.S. Ruwanchandra and Chairman of the Port Authority Keith Barnard also participated in this discussion held at the Ministry of Ports,Shipping and Aviation. Following the discussion, the investors presented a special commemorative gift to the minister.

title: DP Education opens 44th, 45th branches of IT Campus
author: Author not found
Content: DP Education, the leading digital education provider in Sri Lanka, proudly inaugurated its 44th and 45th branches of the ‘DP Education IT Campus’ in grand ceremonies at Kundasale Mahamevnawa Buddhist Monastery and SapugodaIlamgoda Temple, Matara on 23 and 25 July, catering to over 2,850 students. This landmark project marks a significant step towards democratising knowledge, offering free access to coding, robotics, and AI courses for all Sri Lankans. The establishment of this state-of-the-art campus not only elevates digital literacy, critical thinking, and communication skills but also creates diverse job opportunities, fostering the growth of a robust digital economy in Sri Lanka. The DP Education IT Campus encompasses the renowned DP Education Coding School, as well as courses in collaboration with esteemed universities in Sri Lanka. DP Education in collaboration with the University of Moratuwa offers a comprehensive range of courses including Full-stack Development, Cloud Computing, Data Science, Quality Assurance, Cybersecurity, IoT, Data Structures and Algorithms, UI/UX Design, Mobile Application Development, and Project Management. Additionally, in partnership with the University of Kelaniya, DP Education introduces a specialised SAP Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) Course, while collaborating with the University of Ruhuna to offer an in-depth programme covering Data Science, Machine Learning, and AI. The prestigious opening ceremony of the ‘DP Education IT Campus’ at Mahamevnawa Buddhist Monastery was held under the patronage of Nalandawe Pawara Thera on 23 July and the ceremony at SapugodaIlamgoda Temple, Matara, was graced by the esteemed presence of Aggamaha Panditha Venerable Omare Kassapa Thera on 25 July. Both events were presided over by the visionary Founder and Chairman of DP Education, Dhammika Perera, representing the Dhammika and Priscilla Perera Foundation. During the events, Perera officially inaugurated the ‘DP Education IT Campus’ branches and ‘DP Education Digital Classrooms,’ while addressing the enthusiastic audiences gathered to witness this momentous occasion. Notably, all facilities, including computers with Internet access in the IT Campus and smart TVs in the Digital Classrooms, have been generously donated by the Dhammika and Priscilla Perera Foundation. The core objectives of the DP Education IT Campus are twofold: first, to bolster Sri Lanka’s digital economy by cultivating a skilled workforce with enhanced digital literacy, and second, to empower one million young Sri Lankan coders, with a focus on promoting half a million young Sri Lankan girl coders.

title: New Korean Envoy meets the Speaker
author: Author not found
Content: The new Ambassador of the Republic of Korea to Sri Lanka, Miyon Lee, paid a courtesy call on Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena in Parliament recently. During their cordial discussion they focused on several matters of mutual interests. The Ambassador emphasised on the assistance and the ongoing research and development affiliated to supporting the agricultural sector in Sri Lanka.Moreover, assistance provided through KOICA, Sri Lanka towards supporting Education, Transport, Water Management and Sanitation as well as Rural Development was also discussed. Acting Secretary General of Parliament Hansa Abeyrathne was also present.

author: Author not found

title: Army Seva Vanitha Ladies distribute relief packs
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Army Seva Vanitha Unit (ASVU), at the Army HQ, expanding its welfare role, once again donated 100 dry ration packs to selected soldiers working at the Army HQ, on Friday (4). The donation was made during a special ceremony, at the Army HQ, graced by Lieutenant General Vikum Liyanage RWP RSP ndu, Commander of the Army and Janaki Liyanage, President, ASVU, as distinguished guests. After routine formalities in the simple ceremony, Lieutenant General Vikum Liyanage together with Janaki Liyanage handed over three air-chilled Chiller Refrigerators to the Sri Lanka Army Service Corps – Seva Vanitha Branch (SLASC-SVB) for further promotion of the SLASC yoghurt production project. After the distribution of refrigerators, a cash cheque to the value of Rs 600,000 was awarded to a disabled War Hero of the Gajaba Regiment to complete his partially-built house.   In addition to that, the Commander of the Army, together with the ASVU President and Senior Members of ASVU, handed over the 100 dry ration relief packs to soldiers. Each ration parcel included rice, potatoes, onions and coconut milk packets. Major General M.G.W.W.W.M.C.B Wickramasinghe RWP RSP ndupsc, Director General General Staff (DGGS) of the Army, Brigadier I.H.M.R.K Herath USP ndcpsc, Director Media, Brigadier N Mahavithana KSV, Brigadier Coordinating of ASVU, Senior ASVU members, Senior Officers, Officers and Other Ranks also participated in the event.

title: Discussions to remove top Health officials soon?
author: Author not found
Content: Director General of Public Relations (DGPR), at the Presidential Secretariat, Thusitha Halloluwa has pledged to hold discussions with the President, as early as possible, in order to remove the Health Minister, the Health Secretary and several authorities of the Ministry and probe allegations of corruption levelled against them. President of the Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA), Chamal Sanjeewa said that during discussions held at the Presidential Secretariat yesterday (8), Halloluwa had pledged to take necessary action within a week and remove the top brass of the Health Ministry,  which includes the Health Minister. Dr. Sanjeewa made lengthy representations, to the DGPR and representatives of the Presidential Secretariat, regarding the collapse of the State and provincial health services owing to the present health service administration. The documents indicated that the State has incurred heavy losses, amounting to billions of dollars, during the past two years, due to the questionable procurement activities conducted by the Ministry. The DGPR of the Presidential Secretariat promised to discuss with the President the possibilities of taking disciplinary action against Health Secretary, the Chairman of the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA), the Chairman of the State Pharmaceutical Corporation (SPC), the Additional Secretaries responsible for pharmaceutical importation and all hospital directors, who allegedly signed the relevant documents for the procurement of medicinal drugs. The DGPR for the Presidential Secretariat promised the trade unions that he would hold discussions with the President regarding the changing of positions of many of the Ministry’s senior officials, including that of the current Director General of Health Services (DGHS), Dr. Asela Gunawardena, who has allowed the health system to go astray without a road plan and is directly responsible for the collapse of the health system since the time of the Covid- 19. The Office of the DGPR said it would form an Operational Centre from within the health service.  He also invited the trade unions to prepare a National Health Policy which could make arrangements for any minister, who  takes over the ministry, to follow a transparent manner regarding human and infrastructural resources, medicinal drug supply network and procurement process. Joint Convener of the National Movement of Health Professionals (NMHP),  Ravi Kumudesh  alleged that citizens bore a heavy burden at present, owing to questionable allocations of money to select companies due to very obvious and questionable procurement practices which results in greater damage to the national wealth. Convener of Civil Organisations and the National Movement Against Bribery and Waste, Jamuni Kamanta Roshan, warned that his outfit would start hunger strikes and protests in front of the Ministry of Health after next week, if the President failed to provide a positive solution within a week after holding the lives of the people to ransom for the 134 votes he received in parliament. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: SJB wants NCM against Keheliya prioritised
author: Author not found
Content: Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) has emphasised the urgency of discussing the No-Confidence Motion (NCM), they submitted against Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella, this week, deeming it a vital issue requiring immediate attention. SJB National Organiser and MP Tissa Attanayake conveyed their intention to urge Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena to include the motion in the Order Book for debate. Attanayake stressed that the ongoing irregularities and fraud within the health sector demand swift action and that a minister who cannot effectively address these concerns and safeguard people’s lives should not remain in such a position. He claimed that not only SJB MPs but also a majority of other MPs would support the motion, asserting that those who shield the Minister have disregarded their accountability to their constituents. The NCM against Rambukwella emerged amidst a series of crises and inadequacies within the State health sector. The motion, endorsed by 45 MPs, led by Opposition and SJB Leader Sajith Premadasa, carries the signatures of representatives from various Opposition parties and alliances, including the SJB, the Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB), the Tamil National People’s Front and the Freedom People’s Congress. BY Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Imthiaz’s ‘Sithamu’ launch tomorrow
author: Author not found
Content: The launch of the book by Parliamentarian Imthiaz Bakeer Markar, titled ‘Sithamu’  will take place on Thursday (10) at 4.00 p.m. at the Sri Lanka Foundation Institute, Independence Square, Colombo. “Sithamu” is a compelling compilation of columns written by Imthiaz Bakeer Markar, previously published in a prominent national weekly newspaper. The columns cover his profound thoughts on and aspirations for Sri Lanka, as well as social justice locally and globally. Bakeer Markar has published five previous books covering various subjects. Attendees of the book launch will have the opportunity to purchase the latest book ‘Sithamu’ at an exclusive discounted rate of 50%.

title: SLAF responds to Dayasiri’s allegation
author: Author not found
Content: Setting the record straight, concerning allegations levelled about the recent PT-6 aircraft crash, Sri Lanka Air Force (SLAF) yesterday (8) vouched that all aircraft, used for pilot training, had been manufactured after the year 2000. The SLAF, however, temporarily grounded all PT-6 aircraft in their fleet until the report by the special committee, appointed to investigate the crash of a training aircraft in China Bay, which resulted in the death of a pilot and an officer. The one that crashed on Monday (7) in China Bay was manufactured in 2018 and purchased by the SLAF in the same year, SLAF Director Media, Group Captain Dushan Wijesinghe said. He also said the lifespan of PT-6 is an average of 4,000 flying hours and the aircraft in question has only exhausted 850 flying hours. The SLAF was responding to yesterday’s (8) allegation, in Parliament, by MP Dayasiri Jayasekara, that SLAF was still using aircraft manufactured in 1958 for training purposes. Jayasekara told Parliament that the PT-6 aircraft, which are used for training purposes, were manufactured in 1958 and the engines were manufactured in 1961. When inquired SLAF Spokesperson, Group Captain Wijesinghe said in 2001, the SLAF purchased 10 PT-6 aircraft manufactured in 2000. “In addition to these 10 we purchased in 2001, our fleet of PT-6 aircraft consists of two manufactured in 2009 and purchased in the same year and another six manufactured and purchased in 2018. It’s not only we who use this Chinese-made PT-6 aircraft for training purposes. The manufacturer has so far sold over 3,000 aircraft,” SLAF Spokesperson added. PT-6 aircraft, provided by the same Chinese manufacturer, is used by the Air Forces of Bangladesh, North Korea, Tanzania, Albenia and several other countries in addition to Sri Lanka, he pointed out. Meanwhile, the PT-6 is used by commercial training (civil pilot training) in a number of countries including the USA, South Africa, Australia, New Zealand, Germany and Canada. By Gagani Weerakoon

title: Cabinet nod to release Samanala Wewa water
author: Author not found
Content: The Cabinet gave the nod for the release of essential water, from the Samanalawewa Reservoir, to support agricultural activities, while concurrently exploring alternate avenues to meet the nation’s electricity demands, State Minister of Power and Energy D.V. Chanaka said yesterday (7). Earlier, the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) refused to release water from the Samanalawewa to the paddy fields, warning that by releasing water the Southern Province would be deprived of 120 MW electricity generated from the Samanalawewa reservoir. That was despite the Satyagraha started by the farmers at Embilipitiya demanding water be released from the Samanalawewa to the Udawalawa Reservoir. Yesterday (7) marked the 15th day since the launching of Satyagraha. Chanaka told the media that the pertinent authorities have been duly informed to initiate the release of water specifically for agricultural purposes. This decision comes as a result of a meeting held yesterday (7), under the leadership of Minister of Power and Energy, Kanchana Wijesekara. The discussion revolved around the release of water necessary for agricultural tasks from the Samanalawewa Reservoir, as well as managing the consequences on power generation due to the prevailing unpredictable weather patterns. State Minister D.V. Chanaka, the Chairman and General Manager of the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB), officials from the CEB’s System Control Unit and representatives from the Irrigation Department participated in the meeting. Chanaka pointed out the hardships face by the people living in Hambantota and emphasised on the necessity of delivering the required water for cultivation purposes. Meanwhile, Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara disclosed that a crucial meeting was held at the President’s office on Sunday (6). This meeting brought together officials from the CEB and the Irrigation Department to discuss strategies aimed at maintaining an uninterrupted power supply, free from scheduled power cuts. Additionally, the matter of allocating the maximum possible amount of water for agricultural use was presented to the Cabinet of Ministers yesterday (7). Wijesekara said, on X social media platform (previously twitter), the completion of the Polpitiya-Hambantota transmission line, a project funded by the Asian Development Bank has been halted due a dispute between a landowner and the CEB, revolving around the government’s valuation of a 650-metre stretch of land crucial to the transmission line. “The ministry has set 11 August as the date for a discussion under the auspices of the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) to resolve this matter. Upon resolution of the dispute, the project could be completed within just four days. Compensation based on government valuation has already been disbursed to 2,500 individuals along a 150 km stretch, where the project has been successfully executed,” Wijesekara said. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Vavuniya Prison reopens today after measles scare
author: Author not found
Content: The Vavuniya Prison would reopen today (8) following a two-week quarantine period, owing to the detection of patients with measles.  Medical authorities yesterday (7) said that the situation had been brought under complete control while the prison was now clear of the disease.  They said that earlier the Medical Officer of Health (MOH) had taken action to vaccinate all prisoners above 21 years with the Measles Mumps and Rubella (MMR)  vaccine as soon as a prison officer who had been suffering from fever and measles like symptoms had tested positive for the infection. The MOH had taken immediate steps to vaccinate those prisoners who had not been administered with the MMR vaccine, while three prisoners had been isolated as and when they developed fever and measles like symptoms. Also detainees within the 15 to 20 age group had been checked, but not vaccinated. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Chinese tourist attacked
author: Author not found
Content: Nawalapitiya Police arrested two persons who attacked a Chinese tourist with a stick while the woman was on the Udarata Menike train from Colombo Fort to Badulla. The tourist was filming the scenery outside the train when she was attacked. Three individuals, standing on a rock by the railway track, close to the Inguruoya Railway Station, in Nawalapitiya, had used a stick in an attempt to knock the mobile phone out of the hands of a female Chinese Tourist, who was videoing the scenery. However, he had hit the tourist instead of the phone, injuring her.  Police have launched an operation to arrest the third suspect According to the Police, the arrested suspects are residents of the Iguruoya area in Nawalapitiya. They are in the age group of 22-24 years and have been released on bail by the Nawalapitiya Magistrate’s Court in connection with a drug charge. BY Neeta PathmaKumari – Norwood

title: Four Excise Dept officers arrested over shooting
author: Author not found
Content: Four Excise Department officers were arrested yesterday (7) in connection with an incident, in which they allegedly discharged their firearms at a vehicle near a petrol station, on the Marine Drive in Bambalapitiya. According to the Police, the Excise officers had allegedly acted on suspicion that the occupants of the targeted car were involved in drug trafficking. The incident took place yesterday (7) evening when a group of individuals arrived in a van and opened fire at a car situated near a filling station on Marine Drive, Bambalapitiya. The Bambalapitiya Police said that both the van and the targeted car subsequently departed from the scene. However, no casualties were reported as a result of the incident, the Police said. Further investigations are being conducted by Bambalapitiya Police.

title: Kanchana says no power tariff revision
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera, clarifying recent concerns regarding electricity charges, said there would be no immediate revision of electricity charges, despite speculations created by some media outlets. Posting on X social media site (previously Twitter) yesterday (7), Wijesekara underscored that the government’s established policy involves revising electricity prices twice a year, specifically in January and July. Meanwhile, Minister Wijesekera went on to highlight the proactive measures taken by the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) to ensure a consistent and unhindered power supply across the nation throughout the year. He emphasised that the present power plants are operating at their maximum capacity to meet the demands of power generation effectively. In the face of several challenges and initiatives, Wijesekera reaffirmed the government’s commitment to maintaining a stable electricity supply. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Extreme heat affecting 76% of children in S Asia– UNICEF
author: Author not found
Content: The United Nations issued a stark warning yesterday (7), revealing that an alarming three-quarters of children in South Asia are currently grappling with dangerously elevated temperatures, marking the highest proportion worldwide. As the consequences of climate change continue to unfold, the region is being significantly impacted. UNICEF, the United Nations children’s agency, disclosed that approximately 460 million children in South Asia, equivalent to 76 per cent of children in the region, are confronted with extreme heat conditions. This stark figure stands in contrast to a third of children globally who face similar challenges due to rising temperatures. Sanjay Wijesekera, UNICEF’s Regional Director for South Asia, emphasised the severity of the situation, stating, “With the world at global boiling, the data clearly show that the lives and well-being of millions of children across South Asia are increasingly threatened by heat waves and high temperatures.” The report particularly underscores the vulnerability of children in Afghanistan, Bangladesh, India, Maldives and Pakistan, who are deemed to be at an “extremely high risk” due to the effects of climate change. The criterion for such risk is experiencing 83 or more days per year with temperatures exceeding 35 degrees Celsius (95 degrees Fahrenheit). Children, due to their physiological development, struggle to swiftly adapt to temperature fluctuations and struggle to effectively dissipate excess heat from their bodies. Sanjay Wijesekera highlighted this vulnerability, stating, “Young children simply cannot handle the heat.” He emphasised that unless immediate action is taken, these children will continue to bear the brunt of more frequent and more severe heatwaves in the years to come. The impacts of global warming, largely driven by the burning of fossil fuels, have led to a 1.2-degree Celsius rise in global temperatures since the late 1800s. This increase has exacerbated heatwaves, making them longer, hotter, and more frequent, while also intensifying other weather extremes such as storms and floods. The gravity of the situation was underscored by the unprecedented heat experienced in July, which was recorded as the hottest month globally. This intense heat, magnified by global warming, affected tens of millions of individuals in parts of Europe, Asia, and North America. Scientists stress that the world must adapt to the existing heat and other repercussions caused by emissions. Urgent action is required to significantly reduce carbon pollution within this decade to avert even more dire consequences in the future.

title: FAO delivers Japan funded fertiliser to assist paddy farmers
author: Author not found
Content: The Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) delivered 8,360 MT of urea fertiliser, this week, to the Ministry of Agriculture, for distribution during the forthcoming Maha (2023/24) cropping season, FAO said in a statement yesterday (7). This has been made possible through generous funding from the Government of Japan, it added. The essential fertiliser will be distributed to over 228,000 smallholder paddy farmers across several districts in dry and intermediate zones of Sri Lanka, bolstering production and increasing the resilience of smallholder paddy farmers in the country, the FAO further said. The assistance targets smallholder paddy farmers cultivating lands up to one hectare in the Kurunegala, Jaffna, Killinochchi, Mullaitivu, Mannar, Vavuniya, Trincomalee, and Batticaloa Districts, it said. Under this emergency assistance programme, farmers cultivating up to 0.5 hectares of land will receive 25 kg of urea fertiliser free of charge, while those cultivating up to 1 hectare of land will receive 50 kg of urea, also provided at no cost, the FAO said.  Agriculture Minister Mahinda Amaraweera, in this connection, said, “The arrival of this urea fertiliser will support Sri Lanka’s steady recovery. By addressing the needs of our farmers, we are fostering the growth of a more resilient and prosperous agricultural sector. I thank the Government of Japan and the Japanese people for this valuable aid to the small holder paddy farmers of Sri Lanka.” (PA)

title: Iran urges Joint Economic Cooperation with SL
author: Author not found
Content: The Islamic Republic of Iran says they are ready to share their science and technology capabilities with friendly nations like Sri Lanka, despite facing cruel sanctions. In light of this, they also called for the joint commission of economic cooperation between Iran and Sri Lanka to become more active. During an official visit to Iran, at the invitation of the Iranian Foreign Minister Dr. Hossein Amir-Abdollahian, on 5August, Iranian President Dr. Ayatollah Ibrahim Raiesi met Sri Lankan Foreign Minister Ali Sabry at the Presidential Office on the following day. Iranian President Raiesi highlighted the remarkable progress that Iran has made in various fields, particularly in science and technology. He also emphasised the constructive and evolving relations between the two countries since the Islamic Revolution’s victory, recognising the untapped potential that could further enhance their bilateral ties. Dr. Raiesi underlined the need for stronger economic cooperation between Iran and Sri Lanka and pointed out that various countries, including Sri Lanka, possess immense potential for progress, which could have flourished even more if not for foreign colonial and self-interested interference. In response, Foreign Minister Sabry acknowledged Iran’s impressive achievements in science and technology despite facing sanctions, and he congratulated the President and the people of Iran. He also expressed his government’s keen interest in expanding cooperation with Iran in diverse economic, technological, and medical sectors. Following a joint press conference, held on 5 August, the Iranian Foreign Minister Dr. Amir-Abdollahian discussed a wide range of topics, including trade, tourism and international organisations. They addressed and worked through the challenges that have impacted relations between the two nations. President Raisi’s policy of prioritising Asia was also recognised, and both parties agreed that the capacities of the Asian continent have garnered global attention. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Justice Rajakaruna appointed Acting CoA President
author: Author not found
Content: Judge Sobitha Rajakaruna was sworn in as the Acting President of the Court of Appeal (CoA), before President Ranil Wickremesinghe, at the Presidential Secretariat yesterday morning (7). Additionally, High Court Judge M.C.B. Sanjeeva Moraes took oaths as a new Court of Appeal Judge in the presence of the President. The event was attended by the President’s Secretary Saman Ekanayake.

title: 241 Caregivers sent to Israel this year– Manusha
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment Manusha Nanayakkara announced that in 2023, a total of 241 Sri Lankan Caregivers have departed for employment in Israel. In a recent event held yesterday (7), Nanayakkara handed over air tickets to 22 newly recruited Caregivers bound for jobs in Israel. “This year, we have successfully dispatched 241 Sri Lankan workers to undertake Caregiver roles in Israel. This group comprises 33 male workers and 208 female workers,” Minister Nanayakkara revealed. He further outlined the distribution of departures throughout the year, with 13 workers sent in both January and February, 12 workers in March, 39 in April, 34 in May, approximately 40 in June, 51 in July, and an additional 39 in the first week of August alone. Nanayakkara acknowledged his prior discussions with the Population, Immigration, and Border Authority (PIBA) to expedite the process of deploying Sri Lankan workers for Caregiver positions in Israel, commencing from February 2023. He assured that the necessary measures are being taken from the Sri Lankan side to enhance the efficiency of the recruitment process. As a result of these efforts, the recruitment process for Caregiver positions in Israel has been notably expedited since April. To date, a total of 480 Sri Lankan workers have been successfully dispatched to take up Caregiver roles in Israel, contributing to both the workforce needs of Israel and the opportunities available for Sri Lankan workers, he said. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Two killed as SLAF training aircraft crashes
author: Author not found
Content: In a tragic turn of events, a PT-6 trainer aircraft, belonging to the No. 1 Flying Training Wing, at the SLAF Academy in China Bay, crashed last morning (7) killing the pilot and another officer on board. The incident took place within the Academy premises at 11.27a.m., shortly after the aircraft took off from China Bay airfield at around 11.25 a.m. Pilot, Wing Commander Tharindu Herath (fondly known as TK) and the Engineering officer, Flying Officer Peshan Warnasooriya, both hailing from Kurunegala, died in the crash. Following the incident, the Commander of the Air Force, Air Marshal Udeni Rajapaksa, appointed a board of investigation to conduct an immediate probe into the incident. He too visited the location to assess the situation. Wing Commander Tharindu Herath, an alumnus of Maliyadeva College, Kurunegala, joined the Sri Lanka Air Force on 12 January 2006 as an Officer Cadet in the General Duties Pilot Branch to the Intake 49.  In February 2012, Wing Commander Herath (who at the time was Flight Lieutenant) successfully executed a controlled ejection when the MIG 27 fighter Jet, belonging to the Sri Lanka Air Force No. 12 Jet Squadron he piloted, crashed in Dummalasooriya. That incident did not cause any damage to life. Flying Officer Peshan Warnasooriya, a past student of St. Anne’s College, Kurunegala, joined the Sri Lanka Air Force in 2017 as an Officer Cadet in the 35th Intake at Kotelawala Defence University (KDU), in the Aeronautical and General Engineering Branch.

title: South should not be wary of views of N-E politicians– Chandrakanthan
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Rural Road Development, Sivanesathurai Chandrakanthan yesterday (7) assured that citizens in the South need not be alarmed by the statements of extremist politicians in the region regarding the implementation of the 13th Amendment to the Constitution. Chandrakanthan emphasised that fostering mutual understanding among all parties involved is the most viable approach to address the concerns of the Tamil people.  Speaking at the President’s Media Centre (PMC) he lauded President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s proactive efforts towards positively and comprehensively advancing the implementation of the 13th Amendment, which seeks to provide a lasting resolution to the challenges faced by the Tamil community, despite varying opinions. Chandrakanthan urged the South not to be swayed by the views expressed by politicians from the North and East concerning the 13th amendment. He underscored the necessity of mutual understanding and trust among all stakeholders as the fundamental path to resolving the hurdles confronted by the Tamil community. Highlighting the historical context, the State Minister noted that the 13th amendment was initially proposed during the tenure of President J. R. Jayewardene when the current President, Wickremesinghe, served as a Cabinet Minister. Chandrakanthan expressed confidence in President Wickremesinghe’s impartiality, believing that he will propose an all-encompassing solution that garners consensus through the application of the aforementioned constitutional amendment. By Naalir Jamaldeen
