title: Agripreneurs’ Forum and IDEAS to support agri SMEs and startups
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Agripreneurs’ Forum (SLAF)  and I/D/E/A/S (Initiatives in Development of Entrepreneur Approaches and Strategies), a group of retired Sri Lankan professionals dedicated to giving back to the country, plan to launch the ‘Agcelerator’ programme. This collaborative initiative aims to support and empower innovative agri startups and SMEs through funding, investments, visibility and mentoring opportunities. The partnership between SLAF and I/D/E/A/S marks a milestone in Sri Lanka’s agricultural sector. With SLAF’s extensive industry knowledge and expertise, coupled with I/D/E/A/S’ strong track record of philanthropic endeavors, this collaboration sets the stage for transformative advancements in the agribusiness landscape. The ‘Agcelerator’ programme will provide a comprehensive platform for agri startups and SMEs to accelerate their growth and scale their ventures. Through a tailored approach, participants will receive financial support of up to Rs 500,000, strategic investments, increased visibility in the industry and invaluable guidance from experienced mentors. This holistic support system aims to nurture and shape the next generation of agripreneurs in Sri Lanka. “We are excited to join forces with I/D/E/A/S to launch the ‘Agcelerator’ programme,” said Chairman of SLAF, Rizvi Zaheed. “This collaboration brings together our shared vision of fostering innovation and entrepreneurship in the agribusiness sector. Through the programme, we aim to empower agri startups and SMEs, creating a thriving ecosystem that drives economic growth and sustainable development.” Treasurer, I/D/E/A/S, Lalit Godamunne said, “Our group is committed to supporting initiatives that have a lasting impact on Sri Lanka’s socio-economic landscape. The ‘Agcelerator’ programme aligns perfectly with our mission to foster innovation and empower entrepreneurs. We believe this collaboration will catalyse the growth of agri startups and SMEs, driving positive change in the agricultural sector.”

title: DWC Director pledges to stop jumbo Chandi’s translocation
author: Author not found
Content: Following a protest held by a group of environmentalists yesterday (7), Department of Wildlife Conservation (DWC) Director (Wildlife Health) Dr. Tharaka Prasad pledged to halt the translocation of blind elephant in Galgamuwa, ‘Chandi’ aka Ekadantha to Maduru Oya. Dr. Prasad has said that the DWC will perform a field visit with environmentalists and come to a decision. Meanwhile, the Centre for Environmental Justice (CEJ) Senior Adviser Hemantha Withanage and CEJ Executive Director Dilena Pathragoda, on the same day sent a Letter of Demand (LOD) to the Minister of Wildlife and the Director General of DWC demanding to halt the translocation of the elephant.  “Translocation of ‘Chandi’, a majestic one-tusk elephant, who has resided in the Galgamuwa area for over 50 years, is deeply concerning. Chandi’s home range has always been in Ehetuwewa, Galgamuwa and his connection to the land and its ecosystem is deeply ingrained. He is not aggressive towards people but sometimes raids crops and causes a minor amount of property damage. However, unlike most other elephants, he tends to come into populated areas during daytime and we understand that the DWC officers are often called upon to chase him away,” the CEJ in the LOD said. Chandi was captured for the first time in 2009, tied up, taken by truck to Somawathiya National Park and released. As you are also aware a GPS collar was put on Chandi at capture. After release in Somawathiya, Chandi left the park, went west towards Kantale, then turned south and crossing the Dambulla Trincomalee road at Habarana, proceeded to Galewela. He went through Galewela town, causing disturbances and a number of incidents. Then he tumed west again and got back to Galgamuwa after walking 243 km in 28 days. After he was back in his home range, he lived there for a number of years with minor issues. Then around 2015, he was captured again and taken to the Elephant Holding ground in Horowpothana. He was not collared this time. After a few months, he escaped from the holding ground and returned to Galgamuwa. He again lived there for a number of years as usual.” The LOD further stated, “in 2019 he was captured for the third time and taken to Horowpathana Holding ground for the second time. This time again he was collared with a GPS collar. He escaped from the holding ground for the second time and again came back to Galgamuwa. On his way he was involved in a number of conflict incidents and was also involved in fights with other male elephants around Horowpathana. Since then, he has been living in Galgamuwa with minor issues as usual. “However, the situation has drastically changed since Chandi’s previous relocations. He has now lost his sight in both eyes and has grown old, making him more vulnerable than ever. Translocating a blind and ailing elephant would expose him to severe stress, potentially leading to a painful and untimely demise in an unfamiliar environment.” The CEJ pointed out that Chandi’s translocation is very likely to cause increase and wider spread human-elephant conflict and cannot be justified in terms of human-elephant conflict mitigation. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Two killed as SLAF training aircraft crashes
author: Author not found
Content: In a tragic turn of events, a PT-6 trainer aircraft, belonging to the No. 1 Flying Training Wing, at the SLAF Academy in China Bay, crashed last morning (7) killing the pilot and another officer on board. The incident took place within the Academy premises at 11.27a.m., shortly after the aircraft took off from China Bay airfield at around 11.25 a.m. Pilot, Wing Commander Tharindu Herath (fondly known as TK) and the Engineering officer, Flying Officer Peshan Warnasooriya, both hailing from Kurunegala, died in the crash. Following the incident, the Commander of the Air Force, Air Marshal Udeni Rajapaksa, appointed a board of investigation to conduct an immediate probe into the incident. He too visited the location to assess the situation. Wing Commander Tharindu Herath, an alumnus of Maliyadeva College, Kurunegala, joined the Sri Lanka Air Force on 12 January 2006 as an Officer Cadet in the General Duties Pilot Branch to the Intake 49.  In February 2012, Wing Commander Herath (who at the time was Flight Lieutenant) successfully executed a controlled ejection when the MIG 27 fighter Jet, belonging to the Sri Lanka Air Force No. 12 Jet Squadron he piloted, crashed in Dummalasooriya. That incident did not cause any damage to life. Flying Officer Peshan Warnasooriya, a past student of St. Anne’s College, Kurunegala, joined the Sri Lanka Air Force in 2017 as an Officer Cadet in the 35th Intake at Kotelawala Defence University (KDU), in the Aeronautical and General Engineering Branch.

title: CTU President complains of threat from UNP activist
author: Author not found
Content: Ceylon Teachers’ Union (CTU) President S. Priyantha Fernando lodged a complaint with the Anuradhapura Police yesterday (7), alleging that an activist from the UNP Youth Organisation in Anuradhapura threatened him. Fernando alleges that an individual claimed that Nandika Viranjith Thambugala, who is also the Chairman of the Aura Lanka Group of Companies, is his uncle. The threat took place at the Anuradhapura weekly fair around 7:15 p.m. on the previous day (6). According to Fernando’s account, the interaction began with a casual conversation, where the person accused him of sabotaging a music festival organised by his uncle, Rajanganaya Yaya, at the 18th milepost. “He warned that they possessed the means to handle those who speak out against them, invoking the influence of the underworld. He said he knows that I was the one who opposed the music event and that they possess the tools to handle such big mouths,” Fernando alleged. Fernando said realising the potential danger, he chose to step back and distance himself from the situation, suspecting that the individual might be armed. Subsequently, “I discovered that the person who had threatened me hailed from the Ulukkulam area of Anuradhapura,” he said. Anuradhapura Police have initiated an investigation. BY Percy Kuruneru – Anuradhapura

title: Mineral Deposits In Sri Lanka Are For Sale
author: Author not found
Content: Debt-ridden Sri Lanka still has no clear local plan to build the economy rather than implementing an IMF package. However, the forest and mining deregulation, which former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa initiated, seems to be continuing under President Wickremesinghe. The former President initiated releasing 500,000 Ha of other State Forest, which we were able to reverse through a legal process. In recent weeks Forest Department top officials have visited several districts to identify lands coming under the purview of the Forest Department to release them for human settlements and cultivation. This is the result of a Cabinet decision taken in January 2023. It was reported that 26,000 Ha in Mullaitivu and 10,000 Ha in Moneragala have been identified for release. It was learned that more than 100,000 Ha will be released. This subject is even on the agenda of the all-party conference. Meanwhile mineral resources in Sri Lanka are facing a major threat as the GSMB is drafting necessary policy and regulatory changes to sell the valuable deposit to foreign companies. In this direction, the International Mines and Mineral Forum (IMMF -2023) is scheduled to be held on 20 and 21 October 2023, in Sri Lanka. This event is based on the new regulation gazetted under number 2313/37 in January 2023 and under 9(e) the mineral rights of the Republic have been changed by giving priority to the landowner to explore minerals. It says “(e) Notwithstanding the issuance of a valid exploration license to an applicant by the bureau, if an owner of a private land situated within the area of the land in respect of which the license has been issued, may make an application to minimum grid unit amount, regardless of the fact that the same grid has been previously granted to a third party under an exploration licence.” As we know, mining is a skilled industry. It requires relevant expertise to mine, segregate and value add. The above regulation can easily lead to a scam process and could encourage corruption during  obtaining  exploration licenses. This may lead to many social and environmental impacts. It looks like the GSMB is planning to ‘Kill the goose that lays the golden egg’ by rapid mining, but without value added to the mineral resources. We think this sudden decision to promote extensive mining at once with foreign investment, may lead to unsustainable consequences. Minister Chamara Sampath is leading this sale. In fact, he is planning to sell the Eppawela phosphate deposit, too. As an initial step, three trade licenses have been issued to the colleagues of a former GSMB chairman, who was appointed to the position while holding the license for the largest mechanical sand mining project in the Mahaweli River. This week TV channels reported that the Minister received legal opinion from the Attorney General that the Eppawela deposit can be sold with no legal barrier. The battle to save Eppawela Phosphate deposit was initiated in the early ‘90s and in 1999 The Environmental Foundation filed a Court case on behalf of seven petitioners from the area, including Ven. Mahamankadawala Piyarathana Thera. This case led to one of the most powerful environmental judgments in Sri Lanka delivered by Justice R. Amarasinghe, Justice Wadugodapitiya, and Justice Gunasekara. A proposal was made in 1992 to sell the phosphate deposit to a US company called Freeport Mcmoran and Japanese counterpart IMC Agrico with only five per cent shares for Lanka Phosphate Limited. The judgment in the case, Bulankulama v. Min. of Industrial Development (Eppawala case), S.C. Application No. 884/99 (F/R) issued, was based on many considerations including local phosphate requirement and environmental grounds. The judgment referred to the involvement of the National Science Foundation and stated, “based on a statement by  Prof. V.K. Samaranayake On the 23 July, 1999 a committee of twelve scientists, of the National Science Foundation, submitted a report under the title “The optimal use of Eppawela rock phosphate in Sri Lankan agriculture.” Having observed that the proposal of the US Mining company, “in the view of many of the Professional Associations in the country, eg the Institution of Engineers, Institute of Chemistry, National Academy of Sciences and most individual scientists and engineers, said this deal is highly disadvantageous to the country and with highly adverse environmental impacts,’’ the committee examined various proposals made and suggested options which in its view are more advantageous to the country. Although Minister Chamara Sampath is confident that they can sell the Eppawala deposit, the judgment prevents the respondent from entering into ANY contract relating to the Eppawela phosphate deposit up to the time. “(1) a comprehensive exploration and study relating to the (a) locations, (b) quantity, moving inferred reserves into the proven category, and (c) quality of apatite and other phosphate minerals in Sri Lanka is made by the third respondent, The Geological Survey and Mines Bureau, in consultation with the National Academy of Sciences of Sri Lanka and the National Science Foundation and the results of such exploration and study are published: and (2) any project proponent, whomsoever obtains the approval of the Central Environmental Authority, according to law, including the decisions of the superior Courts of record of Sri Lanka.” There is a misconception that a recent report produced by the GSMB fulfills the order. Unfortunately, the report only covers the northern section of the deposit, but I was told the southern section was not properly studied in this uncompleted study. During the Eppawela struggle it was found the agreement covered a 56 square km block of the mine and the total area including the buffer zone was 800 sq km, which also has some phosphate and other mineral deposits. A proper report needs to make a comprehensive study on the full area and make it available for the public at large. It also needs to be done in consultation with the National Academy of Sciences of Sri Lanka and the National Science Foundation. Meanwhile the second order requires the production of a proper Environmental Impact assessment under the National Environmental, an Act considering many of the facts and points mentioned in the case order.  While we know the EIA process in Sri Lanka is highly corrupt, they still need to respect the case order, in which the public can refer back to the Supreme Court. In my opinion the Eppawela case was brought to protect the phosphate deposit for the local needs as it is not a regenerative resource and to protect people and environment in the area. Judgment was delivered based on the principle of the public trusteeship doctrine which agrees that Natural resources in the country are owned by the people and the government is only the trustee. Only a comprehensive study can give proper opinion on the size of the deposit and the environmental and social consequences. The Industries Minister’s urgency to sell this deposit during his tenure will not bring justice to the people or the country. We should sustainably manage our mineral resources and do value adding to make the best use of such natural resources. Hemantha Withanage is Senior Advisor, Centre for Environmental Justice By Hemantha Withanage

title: Wajira lauds ‘Aswesuma’ programme
author: Author not found
Content: UNP Chairman Wajira Abeywardena, on 5 August, asserted that the UNP has always prioritised bridging the gap between the poor and the rich, with the ultimate goal of transforming the nation into a prosperous and cohesive entity. Abeywardena pointed out that the track record of every UNP-led government serves as clear evidence of their commitment to this principle. He expressed the party’s eagerness to gain the mandate from the people under the leadership of President Ranil Wickremesinghe in order to continue their efforts in building a better nation. The UNP Chairman emphasised the importance of unity and collaboration among all citizens to work towards the well-being of the country. He highlighted President Wickremesinghe’s numerous plans and mechanisms to drive the country’s development forward, expressing confidence that if implemented effectively, Sri Lanka will emerge as a developed nation capable of aiding countries facing severe economic challenges. The UNP’s first Working Committee meeting for the Matale District was held on 5 August at the Naula Cultural Centre in the Laggala Polling Division, under the chairmanship of Abeywardena and organised by Laggala Electoral Organiser Anuruddha Bandara. The event was attended by several UNP working committee members, including the Organiser of UNP for Matale District, Priyani Wijeratne. MP Abeywardena acknowledged the previous pattern of political exploitation in the country, where both the rich and the educated faced challenges, leading to setbacks in the plantation economy. He stressed the need to break away from such practices and move forward together to build a future where the interests of both the poor and the rich are aligned. The UNP Chairman expressed unwavering confidence that President Wickremesinghe’s vision and leadership would propel Sri Lanka to become a powerful nation in Asia. He praised the ‘Aswesuma’ welfare programme and emphasised the necessity of creating an environment where the younger generation can thrive while upholding their dignity and reputation. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date: The Embassy of Sri Lanka in Washington DC commemorated the  American national, the late Colonel Henry Steel Olcott, recalling the service he rendered to the Sri Lankan community through the revival of Buddhist philosophy in the island as well as assisting in its spread throughout the world.  This initiative was held at the Embassy on 2 August 2023, as part of the series of events organised by the Embassy, under the leadership of Ambassador Mahinda Samarasinghe, to celebrate the 75th Anniversary of diplomatic relations between Sri Lanka and the United States. A relative of the late Col. Olcott,  Douglas Olcott and the President of the Theosophical Society in America, headquartered in Illinois, Dr. Douglas Keene were present at the event. Ambassador Samarasinghe, in his welcoming remarks, extolled the contribution of the late Col. Olcott which had benefited Sri Lanka and its people in numerous ways by reason of his far-sighted and magnanimous vision and effort, including reviving general education for the people and propagating Buddhism as a philosophy, during British colonial rule. Principal Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Bureau of South and Central Asian Affairs and Deputy Assistant Secretary for Pakistan, US Department of State Elizabeth Horst also graced the event along with officials of the White House and Department of State. High Commissioner of Sri Lanka to Bangladesh Professor Sudharshan Seneviratne delivered a video-recorded keynote address emphasising the invaluable service of Col. Olcott that infused a new lease of life to Ceylon, then a colonised nation, establishing Buddhist Sunday schools and other educational institutions, youth organisations such as the Young Men’s Buddhist Association (YMBA), aiding in the design of the Buddhist flag and calling for social reforms including the promotion of women’s rights. A panel discussion followed, moderated by the President of Tapovanaye International Buddhist Center in California Ven. Tapovanaye Sutadhara. The panelists were President and Chief Prelate of the Buddhist Vihara Society in Washington DC Ven. Maharagama Dhammasiri, President and Chief Prelate of the Maryland Buddhist Vihara Ven. Katugastota Uparathana, a recently retired computer scientist researcher and engineer in Silicon Valley  were also present.  The panel focused on how Col. Olcott began his journey searching for the truth and how his inclusive and timely initiatives enlightened and enthused the Sri Lankan community, particularly the younger generation, during his time on the island.  During an interactive session, members of the audience posed questions and expressed their opinions relating to the life and work of the late Col. Olcott.  As a token of appreciation for the Embassy’s initiative, the President of the Theosophical Society in America presented a portrait of Col. Olcott to Ambassador Samarasinghe. (SRM) Popular

title: Journalist attacked by gang
author: Author not found
Content: Provincial journalist S.M.Z. Sitheeque was attacked and his tranquil cabana was vandalised by a group of thugs on 5 August. According to the journalist, the attack occurred after he cautioned them against using his hut for illicit activities. This incident took place in Irakkamam, Ampara. The injured journalist promptly reported the incident to the Irakkamam Police, who visited the scene and initiated an investigation. No arrests had been made at the time of going to press. Police investigation are ongoing.  Sitheeque said he had noticed a group of young individuals consuming alcohol and behaving inappropriately within his relaxation hut the previous day. He had advised them not to misuse his hut and encouraged them to utilise it for positive purposes. Regrettably, the youths disregarded his advice. On the following day, they returned to the hut and proceeded to vandalise its structures, destroying the furniture in the process. They also attacked him using their helmets. Fortunately, since the journalist was wearing a helmet at the time, he escaped head injuries. BY M.A.P. Deen – Ampara

title: ICT Lawyers Guild of Sri Lanka hosts first ever Int’l IC Law Conference
author: Author not found
Content: Specialist attorneys-at-law, academics, jurists, and researchers in Sri Lanka, engaged in Information and Communication Technology Law, have formed the Information Communication and Technology (ICT) Lawyers’ Guild of Sri Lanka. The Guild was the brainchild of Dr. Sunil D.B. Abeyaratne, Sri Lanka’s first-ever Information Communication and Technology (ICT) Law doctorate holder, who also serves as the President of the ICT Lawyers Guild of Sri Lanka. The main objectives of this guild are to enhance members’ understanding of recent developments in ICT laws and policies worldwide, to address practical issues related to computer and network-based offences, e-commerce law, intellectual property rights, data protection, admissibility of electronic evidence, and more in Sri Lanka. The guild also aims to nurture future scientific and technology lawyers to meet the country’s needs, to act in the public interest and to contribute to upholding the rule of law in the ICT field. To achieve these objectives and promote public awareness of ICT laws, policies, and ethics, the guild plans to conduct various awareness programmes for the general public. As a starting initiative and to establish a robust legal framework in Sri Lanka, the inaugural Annual Sessions of the Guild will focus on ‘AI and the Digital Economy’, was held on 7 August at Hotel Taj Samudra, Colombo. Given the government’s current emphasis on the digital economy as a developmental pathway for the country, two distinguished speakers in the field of ICT led the sessions. Professor Ian Walden, from the Centre for Commercial Law at Queen Mary University London, addressed Data Protection and Consumer Protection law, as well as E-Commerce. Additionally, Athul Harilal Menon, Head of Threat Intelligence Research at Uppsala Security (Singapore), provided insights into Electronic Fund Transferring, including blockchain and cryptocurrency law. The conference also featured addresses by notable figures such as Chief Justice of Sri Lanka Jayantha Jayasuriya, PC, Minister of Justice Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe, PC, Attorney General Sanjay Rajaratnam, PC, and President of the BASL, Kaushalya Navaratne. These speeches highlighted the importance of developing and fostering awareness of ICT law for the benefit of the country’s legal and IT professionals. This event stands as a significant milestone in this subject matter.

title: Rajitha blasts Health Ministry over Dr. Haq
author: Author not found
Content: With the Health Ministry allegedly taking action against Dr. Ruhul Haq, who served at the Colombo JMO’s office, only at the end of his suspension, former Health Minister, Dr. Rajitha Senaratne lambasted the Health Ministry for failing to take timely action in enforcing the Sri Lanka Medical Council (SLMC) suspension. Dr. Senaratne, when contacted yesterday (7), noted that it would be illegal and unethical for any medical practitioner to practise when his licence has been suspended. Any medical practitioner practising without the licence – even temporarily would be a quack, he noted. The SLMC registration was important for all doctors to practise.  Fielding questions he noted that the Health Ministry was very wrong to have allowed a Judicial Medical Officer (JMO), even if suspended for eight months, to practise without his registration to practice. He noted that the Ministry should have taken immediate action – as soon as the SLMC informed it of its decision to move into action. The former Minister said that the attempts to get the Public Service Commission (PSC) involved in the matter, while attempting to shift the responsibility to the PSC and the Colombo JMO’s office, without having taken the proper timely measures, was highly unacceptable. Attempts to contact the Health Secretary, the Director General Health Services (DGHS) and the Acting Deputy Director General (Medical Services-II) failed. However, the Health Ministry is alleged to have launched a Ministerial –level probe into Dr.Haq continuing to practice despite the imposition of an eight-month suspension beginning 20 December 2022. The Health Ministry also noted that the PSC had been notified of the suspension while it was awaiting a response from it before taking further disciplinary action. Meanwhile Dr. Haq had continued practising sans his SLMC registration whilst conducting two important post-mortems, including that of the deceased three year-old who had been receiving treatment at Lady Ridgeway Hospital, following kidney surgery. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: From Grade 1 upwards: Only one term test from 2024
author: Author not found
Content: Beginning 2024, there will be only one term test, throughout the year, for students in Grade 1 and above, Education Minister Susil Premajayantha announced. The decision was made with the well-being of students in mind, aiming to reduce the burden of heavy schoolbags on their physical health. As part of this initiative, the government will provide children with one textbook per school term. Minister Premajayantha emphasised that limiting the number of school term tests to one is a step towards achieving this goal. Instead of multiple term tests, assessments will be conducted at the end of each lesson or module. The marks obtained by students in these assessments will be computerised and added to the marks obtained at the year-end examination. Initially, 70 per cent of the total marks will be based on the final exam, while the remaining 30 per cent will be derived from the module assessments. Gradually, this percentage will be increased to a range of 50 per cent, allowing a more balanced evaluation of the students’ performance, the minister pointed out. In addition, the minister highlighted that once this system is in place, regular attendance in classes and completion of daily tasks will be mandatory for students. The aim is to reduce the need for students to attend external tuition classes, enabling them to focus on their studies within the school environment. Furthermore, Premajayantha said that parents will no longer feel compelled to spend money on unnecessary tuition classes due to the streamlined evaluation system. Instead, they can use these resources to meet the nutritional needs of their children. The minister emphasised that such reforms are essential for the successful implementation of free education, which remains the primary objective of the government.

title: Water bills via e-mail, SMS from Jan 2024
author: Author not found
Content: Starting from January 2024, the National Water Supply and Drainage Board (NWSDB) will exclusively deliver monthly water bills to consumers through email and SMS services, NWSDB Commercial Deputy General Manager, Piyal Pathmanatha announced. During a media briefing, Pathmanatha urged consumers to promptly register for the convenient SMS and E-bill services. He mentioned that since 1 October, the e-bill and SMS services have been successfully rolled out in Polonnaruwa, Trincomalee, Colombo South, and Kandy South. In addition to this, an on-the-spot tariff reduction e-bill service is scheduled to be introduced on 1 January 2024, for the convenience of consumers. The Deputy General Manager further said for those who do not have access to email or SMS facilities, special arrangements will be made to ensure they receive their water bills smoothly. However, Pathmanatha emphasised that in case consumers change their registered mobile numbers, they must re-register with the NWSDB via the hotline number 071939 9999 by sending an SMS.

title: Talaimannar pier to be re-constructed after 37 years
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping, and Aviation has planned to re-construct the Talaimannar Pier to facilitate passenger vessels from Rameswaram, India. The Pier was destroyed and had been abandoned during the conflict in the North. Accordingly, on the instructions of Minister of Ports, Shipping, and Aviation, Nimal Siripala de Silva, the Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA) has been tasked with the re-construction of the pier. The estimated cost of reconstruction is Rs 1.8 billion. Parallel to the re-construction of the pier, about 10 acres of State-owned land, bordering the port, will be acquired for port infrastructure development. Under these new developments, a modern passenger terminal and warehouse facilities will be constructed. It has also been decided to call for RFPs for these investments to be made under PPP. In the past, a passenger ferry service existed between Talaimannar and Danushukodi. However, the Dhanuskodi port was completely destroyed by cyclones. Currently, India has completed the development of the Rameswaram Port and the Indian Government has given the clearance to commence a passenger ferry service between Mannar and Rameswaram. To make the initial plans for the project and to carry out the necessary inspections, Minister Nimal Siripala de Silva made a special visit to the port on 4 August. After the inspection, the Minister also attended a special discussion to discuss and resolve issues pertaining to the project. Speaking at the event, the Minister said that the reconstructions will re-awaken the strong correlation between the two neighbouring nations. The Minister emphasised that the commencement of the ferry service between Talaimannar and Rameswaram will also facilitate Sri Lankan pilgrims to India by providing low-cost travel facilities. He also said that these measures will facilitate the exchange of goods between the two countries and will be a commendable opportunity to popularise the products of the people of northern Sri Lanka in India. Several officials, including the SLPA’s Chairman Keith Bernard, Vice Chairman Gayan Algewattege, and Sri Lanka Navy officials attended the meeting.

title: China announces full scholarships to 40 SL students
author: Author not found
Content: Chinese Embassy in Sri Lanka announced that the Government of China has granted full scholarships to 40 Sri Lankan students who have been accepted by more than 30 prestigious Chinese universities. These scholarships cover various academic disciplines, including science, engineering, agriculture, medicine, economics, and philosophy. Among the recipients, seven students were awarded scholarships for doctoral programmes, 24 for master’s degrees, and nine for undergraduate studies. The scholarship awarding ceremony took place at the Chinese Embassy’s premises in Sri Lanka on on 4 August. The provision of scholarships to Sri Lankan students by the Chinese Government dates back to 1975, a reflection of the strong friendship and cooperation between China and Sri Lanka. In total, approximately 80 students from Sri Lanka are currently benefiting from these full scholarships, supporting their pursuit of higher education. Chinese Ambassador to Sri Lanka, Qi Zhenhong, highlighted the positive impact of this educational exchange between the two nations. The Sri Lankan students studying in China and the increasing number of Chinese students coming to Sri Lanka for higher education are fostering the development of a profound friendship between the two countries, the Chinese Ambassador said. (PA)

title: Iran, SL agree on release of prisoners
author: Author not found
Content: Iran and Sri Lanka have agreed to take action regarding the release of prisoners, of the two countries, in a humane way in the near future, Iranian Foreign Minister Hossein Amir-Abdollahian said in a joint press release, with his Sri Lankan counterpart Ali Sabry, on 5 August. Asian countries should take advantage of dialogue and interaction in line with the interests of the nations, he said. “In today’s meeting, we discussed a wide range of bilateral, regional, and international issues, including economic cooperation, trade and tourism development, and increasing cooperation in regional and international organisations,” he said, adding, the two sides enjoy a common political will to expand cultural, tourism, scientific cooperation. “We discussed the latest status of the previously signed documents between the two countries and also discussed agreements for signing more documents in the future,” he said. The export of technical and engineering services, medical services and equipment, and new technologies in addition to cooperation in the fields of economy, tourism, and energy were among the issues of mutual interest between the Iranian and Sri Lankan diplomats. According to Amir-Abdollahian, the two sides also discussed the issue of Iranian and Sri Lankan prisoners. Based on the agreements, the two sides agreed to take action regarding the release of release prisoners in the two countries in a humane way in the near future. He also said that the two sides stressed strengthening cooperation in the fight against drug trafficking and human trafficking and other trafficking issues and trade ties. (Mehr News Agency)

title: Heroin trafficker nabbed in undercover operation
author: Author not found
Content: An individual involved in heroin trafficking was arrested in Ambalantota yesterday (6) when he mistakenly attempted to sell drugs to an undercover officer, from the Anti-Corruption Unit, of Tangalle Police Division. Prompted by a tip-off about heroin trafficking in Ambalantota and its vicinity, the Anti-Corruption Unit officials orchestrated an undercover operation. The operation involved several officials, including the OIC, who posed as civilians to blend in with the surroundings. The apprehended individual, who was located in Walawewatta, Ambalantota, unknowingly tried to sell heroin to the undercover OIC, leading to his immediate arrest. At the time of the arrest, authorities found approximately 1.3g of heroin in his possession. BY D.N. Jayasekara – Mattala

title: Mihintale electricity bill issue a ‘well scripted drama’ – Rangebandara
author: Author not found
Content: UNP General Secretary, Palitha Rangebandara claimed that the disconnecting of the Mihintale sacred site electricity supply and what happened later was a ‘well scripted drama’ that can be nominated for the State Drama Festival. Rangebandara, who labelled the whole incident as the ‘Mihintale light drama’ claimed as soon as the Chief Incumbent of the Minihtale Rajamaha Viharaya said electricity supply was disconnected, the subsequent scene was portrayed by ‘actor’ Sajith Premadasa, who immediately stepped forward and paid the bill. “In a good play, the audience should be intrigued by what happens in the next scenes. However, in the Mihintale Light Drama, Sajith Premadasa was humiliated by the public as they know what the truth is,” he alleged. The UNP General Secretary expressed concern for the innocent and economically disadvantaged visitors who come to Mihintale sacred site, contributing to pay the temple’s light bill. He sought transparency about how the money from ticket sales was utilised.

title: Beautification of Colombo according to Surbana Jurong plans – President
author: Author not found
Content: The beautification of Colombo will be carried out with the plans provided by Surbana Jurong, a Singaporean government-owned consultancy company and similar plans have been prepared for Trincomalee, President Ranil Wickremesinghe said. Surbana Jurong is actively involved in creating a tourist zone from Verugal Aru to Batticaloa and the Arugam Bay areas, contributing to the growth of the tourism industry, the President said. President Wickremesinghe revealed this at an international conference on Architecture, which was organised by the Royal Institute of British Architects (RIBA) Chapter in Sri Lanka, in collaboration with the American Institute of Architects (AIA) and the Italian Embassy of Sri Lanka, on the theme: ‘Architecture: A Lasting Impact’, held in the morning of 5 August at Cinnamon Grand, Colombo. President Wickremesinghe emphasised that Sri Lanka has demonstrated a strong commitment to addressing climate change goals. Going forward, Sri Lankan architects will play a pivotal role in this endeavour. “They will need to integrate climate change criteria into their designs, ensuring that the built environment aligns with sustainable and environmentally-responsible practices. Integrating sustainable and environmentally-conscious practices into our architectural designs will be instrumental in achieving our climate goals ahead of the set timeline. Also, together, we can build a resilient and environmentally-friendly future for Sri Lanka, contributing to global efforts to combat climate change and protect our planet for generations to come,” he said. The President further mentioned prominent examples of significant architectural achievements such as the grand Stupa, including Ruwanweliseya, Abhayagiri and Jetavanaramaya, as well as iconic structures like Sigiriya, which stands as a prime example of exceptional architecture recognised worldwide. These architectural marvels are further exemplified by the structures found in Polonnaruwa. Notably, even during a period of decline, architectural endeavours persevered, evidenced by the expansion of Sri Dalada Maligawa featuring its octagonal design and the construction of the Kandy Lake during the reign of the last king. President Wickremesinghe further stressed that throughout history, Sri Lanka has showcased its architectural prowess, evident in remarkable structures like the Trinity College Chapel, Kelaniya Rajamaha Viharaya, Lake House building, University of Peradenitya, Independence Square, and the Art Gallery, among others. The iconic Parliament building designed by Jeffrey Bawa has added to this rich architectural heritage, he added.

title: 15 MW of wind power integrated into Nat Grid in Mannar
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy, Kanchana Wijesekera, yesterday (6) announced that 15 Mega Watts of wind power were successfully integrated into the national grid in Mannar. The wind power plant, a joint effort by WindForce and Hiruras Power, features six wind turbines and was not only constructed by local engineers but was also commissioned ahead of the scheduled completion date. Situated in the wind-rich Mannar wind belt, this project is a pivotal milestone in Sri Lanka’s journey towards renewable energy, as stated by WindForce PLC. With WindForce holding a 100 per cent stake and a combined capacity of 15MW, this initiative solidifies their position as a leading player in the renewable energy sector, elevating their total installed capacity to an impressive 245.1 MW. The Hiruras Wind Power Project encompasses two phases: 10MW and 5MW. The first phase of 10MW was successfully commissioned on 12 June, followed by the second phase of 5MW, which was completed on 21 July, according to WindForce. The completion of the Hiruras Power (Pvt) Ltd Wind Power Project in Mannar stands as a remarkable achievement and a testament to the enormous potential of renewable energy in the region. WindForce emphasises that projects like Hiruras play a crucial role in paving the way for a sustainable and environmentally responsible future, particularly as the world transitions from fossil fuels to cleaner energy sources.

title: Devising specific policies or plans a challenge – Ahamed
author: Author not found
Content: It is challenging for us to devise specific policies or plans to tackle the prevailing El Nino weather condition, Minister of Environment Naseer Ahamed said yesterday (6). The minister was responding to a journalist’s inquiry regarding the ministry’s strategies to address the impacts of El Nino. He explained that formulating comprehensive plans was difficult due to the unpredictability of the weather phenomenon. However, Minister Ahamed reassured that the government is actively working to minimise the adverse effects of El Nino and is focused on educating the public about effective measures for ensuring food security. The emphasis lies on implementing nature-based solutions and adopting smart agricultural practices. Additionally, the ministry is engaging with funding agencies to secure early financial support for the implementation of these vital programmes, he said. Meanwhile, in recent interview with Ceylon Today, an expert on climatology and agro-climatology, agro-ecology and climate change Dr. Ranjith Punyawardena said that the present drought situation can be attributed to the El Niño impact, which has caused droughts in Sri Lanka this time and before, making it a recurring but not unusual event. By Sanjana Marzook

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Japan urges SL to be fair and equitable in debt restructuring process
author: Author not found
Content: Japanese Minister for Foreign Affairs, Yoshimasa Hayashi, during his visit to Sri Lanka on 29 July, expressed hope of further progress in the process of debt restructuring and emphasised the importance of a transparent, fair, and equitable debt restructuring process, involving all crediter countries, Japan’s Foreign Ministry stated. In response, President Wickremesinghe had assured that maximum care would be taken to ensure transparency and fairness in the debt restructuring process, the Japanese Foreign Ministry had stated.  Further, it was noted that both parties had a frank exchange of views on bilateral relations, regional affairs, including the situation in East Asia and economic cooperation. Minister Hayashi welcomed the increased diplomatic contacts between Japan and Sri Lanka since the 70th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations last year.  He noted Sri Lanka’s strategic location on the Indian Ocean sea lanes and its role as a key player in the realisation of a ‘free and open Indo-Pacific’ (FOIP).  The visiting Japanese Foreign Minister also had expressed his desire to actively cooperate with Sri Lanka as an important partner in realising the FOIP. During the meeting, Minister Hayashi also discussed the outcomes of the G7 Hiroshima Summit, highlighting the importance of maintaining and strengthening a free and open international order based on the rule of law. Regarding Sri Lanka’s efforts under its agreement with the IMF, Minister Hayashi appreciated the country’s anti-corruption measures and transparency in the policy-making process. He expressed hope for Sri Lanka’s swift return to development. On national reconciliation, he commended Sri Lanka’s efforts to amend the PTA and establish a Truth and Reconciliation Commission, with Japan expressing support for such endeavors. He and Minister Ali Saby had exchanged views on international issues, including nuclear disarmament and non-proliferation. Minister Hayashi expressed appreciation for the ratification of the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty (CTBT) by the Sri Lankan Government. Regarding the Advanced Liquid Processing System (ALPS) treated water issue, Minister Sabry conveyed Sri Lanka’s membership in the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) and expressed confidence in the IAEA process. Additionally, the two Ministers had discussed regional developments, including the situation in Ukraine and East Asia. They reaffirmed the importance of the efforts of the Black Sea Grain Initiative and condemned the termination of the Initiative by Russia, stating it was contrary to international efforts to address food insecurity. They emphasised the need for the international community to unite in strongly urging the Russian Federation to take appropriate action, the Japanese Foreign Minister had told their local media. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Mountain climbing, camping strictly prohibited
author: Author not found
Content: Nuwara Eliya District Secretary, Nandana Galabada, announced strict measures for those entering wildlife reserves in the Nuwara Eliya District. Mountain climbing within these reserves and camping is strictly prohibited from 4 August. This decision was prompted by the discovery of an unidentified woman’s body found under mysterious circumstances at the top of the Great Western Mountains in Talawakelle. This decision was made following a consensus reached among various stakeholders during a special discussion at the Nuwara Eliya District Secretariat. The discussion involved Wildlife Officers, Forest Conservation Department Officers, and Police Officers. According to Galabada, going forward, anyone planning to visit or explore any mountain in the Nuwara Eliya District must first obtain approval from the relevant agencies responsible for that specific mountain. Once the approval is obtained, it must be submitted to the nearest Police station to obtain further permission. Visitors are required to notify the Police when their tour is completed. Galabada warned that individuals not adhering to these instructions will face arrest by the respective government agencies responsible for the reserves or mountains. Stringent measures will be taken to enforce the law. At the initial stage, this system will be implemented through traditional means, but there are plans to streamline the process and allow people to obtain necessary permission through a phone application in the future, he said. By Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: Navy, Police arrest one with Rs 75M worth Kerala Cannabis
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Navy and Police apprehended a suspect with 228kg of Kerala cannabis, during a combined search operation conducted in Ponnalai, Jaffna on 5 August. The operations also led to the seizure of a lorry used to smuggle narcotic drugs. The special operation was mounted by SLNS Agbo in the Northern Naval Command with the assistance of Vaddukoddai Police in Ponnalai. In this search operation, the Naval and Police personnel had searched a suspicious lorry on the road and recovered the stock of Kerala cannabis in it. The seized eight sacks in the vehicle contained 105 packages of Kerala cannabis weighing about 228kg. The stock of Kerala cannabis, the lorry and a suspect were taken into custody. The gross street value of seized Kerala cannabis is believed to be over Rs 75 million. The suspect held in this operation is a resident of Bandarawela, aged 31. Meanwhile, the suspect along with the consignment of narcotic drugs and the lorry was handed over to the Vaddukoddai Police for legal action. (SM)

title: Hotel manager jailed
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Navaratne Marasinghe, on 3 August, sentenced a 64-year-old Hotel Manager to one-year’s Rigorous Imprisonment (RI) on his pleading guilty to the charge of forcing a 14- year-old girl, to engage in the sex trade. The Judge, as further part of the punishment imposed a Rs 25,000 fine on the accused and ordered him to pay compensation, to the tune of Rs 300,000, to the aggrieved party. Judge Marasinghe also added that the offence committed by the accused, being an elderly person, is serious and observed that forcing a minor to be engaged as a sex worker, cannot be condoned and that hence, he was imposing the said punishment on the accused. The Court stated that considering the fact, that the accused had pleaded guilty to the charge filed against him and also as he had consented to pay a sizeable compensation to the aggrieved party, it was imposing the said prison term on him. The Attorney General had indicted the accused Hotel Manager before the High Court, with having forced a minor, to engage in the sex trade, at a hotel situated in the Colombo suburbs, 14 years ago. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Namal urges for programme to assist drought hit
author: Author not found
Content: At a recent meeting of his party’s electoral organisation, Sri Lanka Podujana Premuna (SLPP) MP Namal Rajapaksa called upon President Ranil Wickremesinghe and his Cabinet to swiftly announce a comprehensive government programme aimed at providing relief to the communities adversely affected by the prolonged-dry spell and those in dire need of water for cultivation. “We only appointed this President. Therefore, we should question him and his Cabinet about the programme to give relief to these people. Farmers in the Eastern, Southern, North Central and North Western Provinces have been affected severely today due to drought,” he said. Rajapaksa also said the President attended the global climate summit and developed ties with the respective countries and therefore, it is better to look into the international assistance to face the current climate situation in the country. “We should explore what kind of help can be obtained from such countries at this hour,” he said Furthermore, he requested Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa and JVP leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake to stand up for joint efforts to address the issues rather than indulging in typical oppositional politics. “We are politically divided. Yet,we have to face natural challenges together. As such we need to work out a plan for water management, power generation and development of agro- productivity,” Rajapaksa said.

title: GSMB to regulate mineral transportation
author: Author not found
Content: The Minister of Environment, Naseer Ahamed, announced that the Geological Survey and Mines Bureau (GSMB) will now regulate mineral transportation by issuing transport licences containing the destination, vehicle number and route details. Speaking at a media briefing, held at the President’s Media Centre (PMC) yesterday (6), the minister highlighted that these licence details are computer-generated to prevent any alterations by the licence holder. To curb illegal mineral transportation, the ministry has introduced a blacklisting procedure through the GSMB’s database system for vehicles involved in such activities. Moreover, amendments have been made to the Mines and Mineral Act, introducing new provisions for the exploration licence procedure. In an effort to promote direct investments in Sri Lanka’s mineral resources without intermediaries, the ministry has also facilitated provisions for investors. Minister Ahamed emphasised the significance of the upcoming International Mineral Forum in October, which aims to open up the industry to those with technical and financial capabilities. He expressed his hope of genuine international companies participating in the forum and signing agreements worth at least Rs 600 million to one billion rupees. Highlighting the potential benefits, the minister explained that companies can collaborate with associated industries in mining, generating funds and reducing the import of goods. For instance, processing ore and titanium oxide in-country can produce iron bars, reducing the need for imports. With these regulatory measures and efforts to attract genuine international investors, the government aims to enhance transparency and efficiency in the mineral industry while maximising benefits for the country’s economy. By Sanjana Marzook

title: 81 Suspended due to substandard practices
author: Author not found
Content: A total of 81 institutions, offering NVQ certificate courses, have been suspended due to their substandard practices, the Sub Committee on Tertiary Education, appointed by the Committee on Public Enterprises (COPE), disclosed. As a result, it has been proposed to establish a proper mechanism to publish the names of these institutions through newspaper notices, along with the initiation of legal action to prohibit their operations. The sub-committee collaborated with representatives from various organisations, including the Ministry of Education, Tertiary and Vocational Education Commission, National Apprentice and Industrial Training Authority, Vocational Training Authority, and the Ceylon-German Technical Training Institute. One of the key concerns highlighted by the sub-committee is the identification of fake NVQ certificates. The COPE sub-committee highlighted the importance of taking legal action against individuals involved in the production and distribution of counterfeit certificates. While it is possible to identify fake certificates through the QR code system, the existing legal framework presents some limitations in pursuing legal action. To address this issue, the sub-committee has directed the relevant authorities to amend the existing Act to rectify these shortcomings and facilitate the appropriate action against those engaged in producing fake certificates. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: HC Orders Labour Ministry Secretary to Surrender
author: Author not found
Content: Panadura High Court Judge Saman Kumara yesterday (3) ordered R.P.A. Wimalaweera, the incumbent Secretary to the Ministry of Labour, who was a former Labour Commissioner General, to obey the law of the country and surrender himself to the Horana Magistrate’s Court, as someone who holds a responsible public post. The High Court Judge gave this order when Wimalaweera made a request for an order to cancel the arrest warrant issued by the Horana Magistrate, on 24 July, in connection with the death of five persons at a chemical waste station of a rubber factory in Horana. The deaths occurred when five individuals fell into a chemical waste tank at the factory. Wimalaweera is being accused of exerting influence on a former factory inspection engineer in the Kalutara District to fabricate false evidence related to the incident during his tenure as the Commissioner General of Labour. Considering these submissions, the Horana Magistrate’s Court issued an arrest warrant for Wimaraweera and ordered that the suspect be brought before the court within seven days. The execution of the warrant is to be carried out by the IGP, the Court had ordered. When Wimalaweera’s request was taken up by the Panadura High Court, the Judge said that the Horana Magistrate’s Court has issued the arrest warrant considering the submissions from all the angles and there was no need to cancel such a warrant. He stressed that when a lower Court gave an order, the elite and high ranking officials of Sri Lanka have made a habit of going to a higher Court to cancel those orders, given according to the law of the country.  The Judge said although 10 days have passed since the Horana Magistrate’s Court issued the arrest warrant, the Police have not arrested the Ministry Secretary. Former Commissioner of Labour Ashoka Peiris was arrested in connection with this incident and he has now been released on bail. Five people lost their lives after falling into a chemical waste disposal tank at the rubber factory in Horana on 19 April 2018. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Litro gas price revision today
author: Author not found
Content: Litro Gas Lanka Chairman Muditha Peiris yesterday (3) said the price of domestic Liquefied Petroleum (LP) gas would be revised today (4). He said the revised prices would be announced in the morning today. The decision to revise gas prices comes in response to the increase in the world market price of LP gas, which has risen by over USD 85 per MT, Peiris said.

title: Water Tariff increased
author: Author not found
Content: A significant increase in water tariffs was announced effective 1 August, as per the Extraordinary Gazette notification, published by Minister of Water Supply and State Infrastructure Development, Jeevan Thondaman. The decision comes as a measure to manage the growing demand for water and to ensure the sustainability of the country’s water resources. Under Section 84 of the National Water Supply and Drainage Board Law No. 02 of 1974, the revised water tariffs will apply to various sectors based on the number of units consumed. However, the Government has stated that there will be no increase in the water tariffs for Samurdhi beneficiaries and estate houses, aiming to safeguard vulnerable communities. The new tariff structure for domestic water usage will see substantial adjustments. Previously, the first 5 units were charged at Rs 20 per unit, but now they will be charged at Rs 60 per unit. The revised tariff for domestic use is as follows: Domestic Use: 0 to 5 units: Rs 60 per unit & monthly charge Rs  300 6 to 10 units: Rs 80 per unit & monthly charge Rs 300 11 to 15 units: Rs 100 per unit & monthly charge Rs 300. In addition to the water tariffs, the sewerage charges for consumers have also been revised, starting 1 August. This is the first water tariff revision since 1 September 2022.
