title: Mihintale Raja Maha Viharaya power disconnected
author: Author not found
Content: Electricity supply to the sacred Mihintale Raja Maha Viharaya was disconnected due to an outstanding electricity bill amounting to Rs 3.4 million, Chief Incumbent of the Viharaya Most Ven. Walawahangunawawe Dhammarathana Thera revealed yesterday (3). This was also confirmed by an official from the Anuradhapura District Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) Office. The Thera expressed his dismay over the power disconnection, stating that it has a significant impact on the age-old temple, which played a vital role in spreading Dhamma to the country since the time of Arahath Mahinda. He described the move as a severe blow to the Buddhasasana in the nation. Additionally, the Thera claimed that the disconnection was a result of his outspoken criticism of certain politicians in the government. According to him, this was an act of revenge aimed at the Buddhasasana by targeting the electricity supply of the Sacred Site. The Thera further raised concerns that the lack of power supply could jeopardise the re-development work of artifacts and historical sites within the temple premises, especially during nighttime, as there might be a risk of treasure hunters targeting the site. BY Percy Kuruneru – Anuradhapura

title: Hartal marks 1990 Kattankudy Mosque massacre
author: Author not found
Content: A Hartal was staged in Kattankudy yesterday (3) to mark the 33rd year since Kattankudy Mosque massacre in 1990. On 3 August 1990, the Kattankudy Mosque Massacre unfolded, resulting in the death of approximately 150 Muslim men and boys. On that day, around 30 armed LTTE terrorists raided four mosques in Kattankudy while over 300 people were prostrating in Isha Prayers. A special ‘dua’ (prayers) were held at Hussainiya Mosque and Meera Jumma Mosque in Kattankudy. Text and Pix by T.L. Jawfar Khan – Batticaloa

title: Businessman Onesh Subasinghe’s remains arrive in Colombo
author: Author not found
Content: The body of Sri Lankan businessman Onesh Subasinghe, who was murdered in a serviced apartment in Jakarta earlier this year, has been brought back to Sri Lanka after six months and handed over to his family members. Subasinghe’s body was brought to the Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA), Katunayake on Tuesday (1) and subsequently taken to the Negombo General Hospital for a post-mortem before being handed over to his family members. It was also revealed that Indonesian authorities too had conducted a post-mortem in Indonesia. Managing Director of OPEX holdings Subasinghe was found dead under suspicious circumstances in an apartment in Jakarta, Indonesia. The businessman was on a leisure trip in Jakarta along with his Brazilian wife, his four-year-old daughter and another Brazilian woman who was not identified as yet. Subasinghe was last in contact with his family in Colombo on 2 February and due to lack of contact thereafter, the family in Sri Lanka had contacted the apartment management and requested them to check up on Subasinghe. As the apartment management was unable to reach Subasinghe despite several attempts they had broken open the room door and found his body. BY T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: Main suspect in Vavuniya arson attack arrested
author: Author not found
Content: The main suspect, wanted in connection with the recent arson attack on a house in Thonikkal, Vavuniya during a birthday party, which resulted in two deaths and injuries to several persons, was arrested by the Police. According to Police, the suspect, a 36-year-old resident of the Kumankulama area in Vavuniya, was arrested on Wednesday evening (2) after thorough investigations conducted by the CID in collaboration with the Vavuniya Police. Earlier yesterday, five other suspects were remanded until 11 August, by Vavuniya Magistrate Waseem Ahamed. The tragic incident occurred on 23 July, when a group of individuals set the house on fire, resulting in the immediate death of a 21-year-old woman. Her husband, who suffered severe burn injuries, passed away on July 26 while receiving treatment at a private hospital in Jaffna. The fire also caused injuries to a 2-year-old boy, two 13-year-old girls, four females aged between 19 and 41, and a 42-year-old male, all residents of the Thonikkal.

title: Susil gets tough on pre-school registration
author: Author not found
Content: Pre-schools without proper training provided by the Education Ministry or without a pre-school diploma will not be allowed to operate, Education Minister Susil Premajayantha announced. During an event in Bomiriya, Kaduwela, the Minister highlighted the importance of a structured system for three and four-year-old children’s education. He stated that without a proper foundation at the pre-school level, school education will not be able to effectively shape their minds. As a result, the ministry cannot allow the establishment of pre-schools without the necessary training and qualifications. Premajayantha further emphasised the significance of early education, stating that education should begin at the pre-school level and not in the middle stages of schooling.Currently, there are approximately 40,000 pre-school teachers and about 19,000 pre-schools, he said. “As all pre-school students eventually enter Grade One classes in schools, the ministry will provide training to pre-school teachers to follow a curriculum based on activity-based learning. Upon completion of specific training hours, these teachers will receive a certificate. For those pre-school teachers willing to continue their profession, a diploma certificate will be awarded upon further training.” In light of these initiatives, it has been decided that pre-schools must possess the required pre-school training certificate or diploma before they can commence operations, the minister pointed out.

title: President Ranil skillfully splitting SLPP – Mano Ganesan
author: Author not found
Content: Leader of Tamil Progressive Alliance, MP Mano Ganesan, claimed that President Ranil Wickremesinghe is skillfully creating divisions within the Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) and he anticipates some “colourful events” in the coming months. Ganesan recently said, they will support the government that backs their policies despite showing allegiance to Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB). Addressing the press at the Jaffna Press Club on 2 August, he stated that they observed the SLPP gradually resurfacing after a period of seclusion last year during the peak of protests, and they were unable to engage with their constituents openly. “It seems they are now making public appearances and holding meetings, although some of these gatherings may not be entirely voluntary, but rather orchestrated. This might be causing annoyance among certain sections of the public. We are aware of the President’s track record in creating divisions among people, evident from his past actions. It appears he is employing the same strategy with the SLPP,” the MP said. He also said, there is an attempt to get the SJB to join the UNP, but all internal matters cannot be exposed to the public. Within the SLPP, there appears to be a faction aligning with President Wickremesinghe’s policies, he pointed out. Some young politicians from the SLPP are siding with the President. MPs like Namal Rajapaksa, who are known for promoting nationalism, had their members in national costumes in the Parliamentary Complex, but MP Ganesan pointed out that these politicians have undergone external transformations, such as adopting Western-style suits, possibly indicating their allegiance to the President’s ideology. He continued, “This regime, loyal to Ranil Wickremesinghe, is taking shape within the SLPP, with even Cabinet ministers like Susil Premajayantha and Prasanna Ranatunga along with several others now among the government’s advisers. The President seems to be diligently working towards his goals, and we must remain patient as many new events are likely to unfold in the coming months.” Regarding the 13th Amendment (13A), Ganesan commented on India’s stance, saying, “India has consistently reiterated the call for full implementation of the 13A and holding elections. There is no change in India’s position on this matter.” BY Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Vavuniya Prison to reopen next week
author: Author not found
Content: With only four persons, including a Prison guard and three prisoners affected with measles, the Vavuniya Prison would be reopened by around next week, health sources in the Vavuniya District said. Sources said yesterday (3), when contacted for comment, that the Medical Officer of Health (MOH) had taken immediate action to vaccinate all prisoners above 21 years with the Measles Mumps and Rubella Vaccine (MMR) vaccine as soon as a Prison officer who had been suffering from fever and measles like symptoms had tested positive for the infection. He had gone home on leave due to fever and later tested positive, they explained. The MOH had taken immediate steps to vaccinate those prisoners who had not been administered with the MMR vaccine, while three prisoners had been isolated as and when they developed fever and measles like symptoms. Those detainees within the 15 to 20 age group had been checked, but not vaccinated. Responding to questions, the health sources said, the two-dose MMR vaccine had only been introduced after Year 2000. The prison has about 500 inmates while there were those who had not been given the particular vaccine, they said.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Case against Gnanasara Thera put off to November
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Adithya Patabendige, yesterday (3) deferred to 10 November further hearing of the case, filed against Bodu Bala Sena (BBS) General Secretary Ven. Galagodaatte Gnanasara Thera, who has been charged with making remarks aimed at heightening racial tensions among different ethnic communities in the country. When the case was called, the accused Buddhist monk was present in Court, while a former News Director of a media institution and a photographer provided evidence on behalf of the Prosecution. The Counsel representing another witness in the trial, lawmaker Rishad Bathiudeen, informed Judge Patabendige, that his client was unable to be present to give evidence, due to him being indisposed and assured that he will appear in Court to testify, at the next hearing.Accordingly, the Court fixed further proceedings of the trial, to the said date. The Attorney General has indicted the Buddhist Monk concerned, before the High Court, for having made certain controversial remarks, aimed at heightening racial tensions amongst different ethnicities here, during a media briefing held on or before 30 November, 17 years ago. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Document chewing lawyer remanded
author: Author not found
Content: Kekirawa Chief Magistrate Senarath Bandara on Wednesday (2) rejected a bail request made by the lawyer, who was charged with the alleged tearing and chewing of two important documents, linked to a land case being heard at the Kekirawa Chief Magistrate’s Court, which had been taken out from Court safe. She was remanded until 9 August. Attorney-at-Law Tyrone Wijeratne, who appeared on behalf of the suspect, urged the Court to grant bail to his client under any suitable condition. The lawyer, a resident of Settupitiya in Kekirawa, had allegedly forcibly strived to remove two of the documents certified by the Government Analyst and when her attempt had been thwarted she had bitten part of the documents thus damaging them.   Remanding the suspect lawyer, the Chief Magistrate instructed the Kekirawa Police have her blood samples, obtained on 31 July by the Judicial Medical Officer (JMO), attached to the Anuradhapura Teaching Hospital, to be sent to the Government Analysts for DNA tests. Kekirawa Police prosecuting objected to the suspect being enlarged on bail as they stated that charges had already been filed against her based on Provisions of the Public Property Act. BY Upali Ananda – Anuradhapura

title: SJB facing slow death – Marasinghe
author: Author not found
Content: Former UNP MP Ashu Marasinghe claimed on Wednesday (2) that the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) is currently facing a ‘slow death’ while its Leader Sajith Premadasa is challenging a powerful government by demanding elections. Marasinghe criticised Premadasa for making imprudent statements alleging that the SJB was in a strong position to face any future elections, without understanding the Party’s actual position. Prof. Marasinghe also accused Premadasa of suggesting that the people were confused about their future due to the current government’s actions, while asserting that it is Premadasa who is uncertain about his political future and not the people. Marasinghe told the Media at Sirikotha that the country has not fallen into the anarchic situation that Premadasa anticipated, and was in a stable state. He further said that Sri Lanka currently holds foreign reserves of USD 3.7 billion, which is expected to increase in the near future. The Government is also working on resuming the light railway project in collaboration with Japanese authorities and is exploring the setting up of an investment zone by Thailand to initiate manufacturing processes in Sri Lanka. During President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s visit to Japan, he requested to include Sri Lanka in the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) Corporation, representing 30 per cent of the world’s economy. Presently, 15 countries, including Australia, New Zealand, Thailand, Vietnam, and Japan, are part of this group and Sri Lanka’s inclusion is expected to provide significant benefits, Marasinghe said. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Defence Adviser of British HC meets SLAF Chief
author: Author not found
Content: Defence Adviser of the British High Commission in Sri Lanka, Colonel Darren Woods called on the Commander of the Air Force, Air Marshal Udeni Rajapaksa at the Air Force Headquarters on Wednesday (2). After a discussion on matters pertaining to the enhancement of defence capabilities and exploring potential training opportunities, the Commander and the visiting Defence Adviser exchanged mementos as a gesture of the enduring partnership between the British High Commission and the Sri Lanka Air Force.

title: A person consumes 5g of micro plastic each week – Study
author: Author not found
Content: A research carried out by the Newcastle University in Australia has shown that a person consumes five grams of micro plastic per week, Nutritionist Roshan K. Dela Bandara lamented.   He said yesterday (3) that this amounted roughly to the size of a credit card. “If we consume micro plastics which amounts to the size of a credit card on a weekly basis then the monthly consumption would amount to 20g, the Nutritionist observed. Annually that would amount to 250g of plastic, Bandara said. “Although we have been only talking about micro plastic in relation to environment pollution research has shown that micro plastics have entered the food we consume, the water we drink and even the air that we breathe, Dela Bandara said. He noted that there was nothing extraordinary about this fact as from the cutting board used in the kitchen, to the lunch sheet used when wrapping food to the shopping bags which some people use to carry tea contains micro plastics.  Secretary, Sri Lanka Medical Association (SLMA) Dr. Sajith Edirisinghe, elaborated that studies had shown that main cause of getting micro plastic into our bodies was from nylon cloth and nylon fishing nets. “Most of the micro plastic enters our system through the air that we breathe. Our tissue is exposed to all the toxins and heavy metals that are absorbed by these micro plastics as a result. This causes genetic mutations which could lead to cancers and non-cancerous diseases.    Dr. Edirisinghe urged people not dispose plastic by roadside, do not burn it in the back yard, but hand them over to centres where they can be recycled.  He urged people also to refrain from burning plastic items, as it emits a number of poisonous chemicals and gases which are very harmful to the body. Young children whose lungs are not fully formed would fall ill regularly if exposed to such gasses and chemicals, he warned.   By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: BOC celebrates 84th Anniversary, nurturing Sri Lankan economy
author: Author not found
Content: The Bank of Ceylon, celebrated its 84th Anniversary at a ceremony held at the Bank’s Head Office in Colombo 1. The ceremony began with special religious sermons, invoking blessings on the staff and on all customers of the bank. The event was held under the patronage of the Bank’s Chairman, President’s Counsel Ronald C. Perera and the General Manager Russel Fonseka. Members of the bank’s Board of Directors, Corporate and Executive Management, Staff Members, Customers and Well-wishers were gathered at the Head Office to celebrate the event. Similarly the Bank’s branch network too, celebrated the anniversary along with their loyal customers and well-wishers. BOC’s founding is a major event in the country’s economic history in the modern era as it is a milestone in what today is called “Financial inclusion”. What may come as a surprise to leaders today is that the access we have today to modern banking services for the ordinary citizen or local business was not available then. The establishment of the Bank of Ceylon and its opening on the 1 August 1939 for business by British Governor Sir Andrew Caldecott led to an ordinary person or business being able open an account and use cheques in transacting. Today it is a thoroughly modern bank with technology forming the backbone of its operating infrastructure. The awards it continues to win and the accolades it continues to earn have become commonly repeated facts in various media. Its performance and figures are commonly known facts. A novel product focused on empowering customers through a flexible investment plan, ‘BOC Flexi Investor’ account was ceremoniously launched by the Chairman and the General Manager to commemorate the anniversary. This novel savings account comes with special features that enable the eligible account holder to have a goal-based investment plan to achieve financial goals in the way he/she desires. Flexibility to set own investment plan based on the goal, tenure and the affordable deposit with a wide range of investment options and attractive interest rates. It also gives the option to open multiple investment plans simultaneously and there will be no penalty for missed deposits. These novel concepts the bank introduces are aimed at assisting customers comprehensively being more responsive to their dynamic needs. Having served the country for 84 years as the leading banking institution rendering an impeccable service to its customers and community, the Bank of Ceylon has further sharpened its capabilities to ready to strive for many years to come.

title: Construction of ECT Operations building begins
author: Author not found
Content: Construction of the East Container Terminal (ECT) operations building of the Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA), commenced yesterday (3). Minister of Ports, Shipping, and Aviation, Nimal Siripala de Silva, speaking on the occasion, said “our aim is to increase the container handling capacity of the Port of Colombo from 8.5 million to 35 million.” The 1,300-metre terminal will be built at a cost of USD 580 million. The gantry cranes required for operations at the terminal have already been ordered. The construction of the four-storey main operations building at the terminal will cost Rs 1,300 million and is planned to be completed by February next year. The Minister stated, the current 8.5 million TEU handling capacity at the Port of Colombo (POC) will be increased to 35 million with the completion of ECT, Jaya Container Terminal V (JCT-V),  Western International Container Terminal (WICT), and the proposed North Port Projects. “It is my wish that the SLPA officials, employees, and trade union representatives should contribute and help carry out the construction work of the ECT according to a proper and accurate timeframe,” the Minister said. He added, the operations of the ECT should be carried out with semi-automation and with a minimum number of employees recruited for its operations. “These opportunities should be made available to the skilled youth of this country. They should have the potential to achieve maximum productivity through elevated efficiency in the operational process, especially by utilising the most advanced technologies for port and terminal operations. For this reason, everyone should well-identify the latest trends in the global commercial shipping industry, which runs in a very lucrative yet highly competitive business environment,” he added. Additional Secretary (Development) to the Ministry of Ports, Shipping, and Aviation Kumari Somarathna, SLPA’s Chairman –  Keith D. Bernard, Vice Chairman –  Gayan Algewattage, Managing Director –  Prabath J. Malavige, Additional Managing Directors, Directors, a number of Heads of Divisions, Executive Officers, Staffs, Employees, and Trade Union Representatives also attended the occasion.

title: Unleashing opportunities and enriching ICT ecosystem
author: Author not found
Content: The Regional Tech Summit 2023, a groundbreaking series of events aimed at enhancing the ICT sector across Sri Lanka, kicked off its journey with the successful Northern Chapter held in Jaffna this June. Organised by the Information and Communication Technology Agency of Sri Lanka (ICTA) in collaboration with the ‘USAID Catalyze’ Private Sector Development (PSD) Activity and the Northern Chamber of Information Technology (NCIT), the event provided a platform to share knowledge, initiate policy discussions, and empower regional skilled professionals to bridge employment gaps within the ICT industry. The Northern Chapter of the Regional Tech Summit 2023 featured a diverse range of activities tailored to enrich the ICT ecosystem in the Northern region. Participants were able to explore new opportunities, foster collaborations, and drive growth and innovation in the Jaffna IT-BPM industry. Over the course of two exciting days, there were training and knowledge sessions for IT MSME (Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises), networking opportunities with industry experts, meetings with local and multinational IT companies, and connections with bilateral and multilateral local/international associations. The Regional Tech Summit 2023 – Northern Chapter, was a beacon of inspiration, offering a diverse range of resources that ignited passion and propelled participants towards greatness. Industry experts delivered transformative IT MSME Training and Knowledge Sharing Sessions, equipping attendees with invaluable insights in areas such as International Market Access, UI/UX, Product Engineering, Contractual Law, Digital Media Management, IT Pricing, Procurement, and US-AID Support to IT Companies in Jaffna. These sessions were catalysts for innovation, empowering individuals to stay ahead in a rapidly evolving digital landscape. The event created an electric atmosphere of collaboration and connection. Networking Sessions provided a platform for participants to forge meaningful relationships with investors and industry leaders, opening doors to a future where partnerships and collaborations shape the destiny of their businesses. Meeting Sessions brought together local and multinational IT companies, as well as Expatriate Groups, fostering an environment where potential collaborations bloomed, and new partnerships took flight. These connections were the building blocks of a vibrant and expanding network that fueled further growth and development. The event not only fostered meaningful connections among individuals, but also connected them to a broader world of opportunities. Participants had the privilege of engaging with bilateral and multilateral local/international associations, broadening their horizons and gaining exposure to a wealth of resources and prospects. These connections transcended boundaries and unlocked new pathways, igniting the flames of creativity and possibility. Another equally important aspect highlighted during the Regional Tech Summit 2023 was access to finance. Exclusive banking facilities tailored for the ICT sector were showcased, followed by a panel discussion to converse about the industry’s constraints and possibilities, shedding light on enhanced avenues to secure financial support. The eminent panel was chaired by the Central Bank of Sri Lanka, adding further prominence to the event. The knowledge imparted at the event empowered businesses to leverage these resources, accelerating their growth and fostering a thriving ICT ecosystem. The event also celebrated the immense potential of individuals through the ICT Job and Certification Fair. This vibrant platform not only offered walking interviews and spot recruitment drives but also provided special discounts on ICT-related certifications. The workforce had the chance to embrace personal and professional growth, acquiring new skills and qualifications that would set them on the path to success. The Regional Tech Summit 2023 embodied the spirit of inspiration, igniting the passion within participants and propelling them towards greatness. It served as a reminder that the ICT sector holds boundless possibilities for innovation, collaboration, and personal growth. As the event concluded, it left an indelible mark on the hearts and minds of all who attended, reminding them that the future is bright and filled with endless opportunities waiting to be seized. Following the resounding success of the Northern Chapter, the Regional Tech Summit 2023 will continue its mission to enrich the ICT ecosystem by expanding to other regions. The next chapter of this transformative event will take place in Galle in August, promising another unforgettable experience where innovation, knowledge sharing, and networking converge. For more information about the Regional Tech Summit 2023, please email [email protected].

title: Abandoned gem pits a threat to people’s health and saftey
author: Author not found
Content: The health and safety of the people in the Bogawantalawa area have been seriously threatened by the presence of huge abandoned mining pits. Dr. Y. B. L. D. Basnayake, the MOH of Bogawantalawa, has written a letter to the Secretary of the Divisional Secretariat, Norwood and the National Gem and Jewellery Authority, urging them to take immediate steps to close these hazardous pits. In his letter to the National Gem and Jewellery Authority, Dr. Basnayake highlighted that in 2015, the authority granted permission for gem mining in the Chapelton Part of Kotiyagala Estate, under its jurisdiction, for a one-year period. However, despite the end of the gem mining activity, the large pits that were mined have not been properly closed. As a result, the local community’s health is now at risk due to these open pits. The situation is particularly concerning as the Castlereigh Reservoir predominantly flows into Keselgamu Oya and Bogawantalawa Theresia Estate, where the unsealed gem pits are located dangerously close to the school and Estate houses. Despite having issued written notices to the Plantation Management Authority and the National Gem and Jewellery Authority, for several years, no action has been taken to address the issue, as stated in the letter by Dr. Basnayake. Meanwhile, a plantation worker lost his life after falling into one of these large ditches filled with water, while cutting grass in the plantation recently. The proximity of these pits to the route used by residents to access Bogawantalawa town through Keselgamu Oya adds to the urgency of the situation. The plantation workers of Bogawanthalawa Theresia Estate are also urging the immediate closure of these hazardous pits to prevent further accidents and protect the well-being of the community. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: Indian industry delegation visits North
author: Author not found
Content: A delegation from the Confederation of Indian Industry (CII) and Vivekananda International Foundation (VIF) undertook a three-day visit to the Northern Province from 30 July to 1 August, aiming to explore investment opportunities in various sectors. During their visit, the delegation engaged in discussions related to conventional and renewable energy, logistics, IT, tourism, and agriculture with a focus on how Indian investment can contribute to Sri Lanka’s economy. The delegation met Governor of the Northern Province, P.S.M. Charles, who emphasised the importance of Indian investment in supporting Sri Lanka’s economic growth. Additionally, the delegation held meetings with local Chambers of Commerce, businessmen, and entrepreneurs to explore possibilities for joint ventures, investment, and business collaborations in the Northern Province. Throughout their stay, the delegation also visited sites to identify potential investment opportunities. Looking beyond the Northern Province, the delegation plans to visit other regions in the country to further enhance investment and foster stronger business ties between India and Sri Lanka. Consul General Raakesh Natraj said, this visit aligns with the vision of both nations’ leaders to promote seamless connectivity in all aspects between the two countries. The ultimate goal is to leverage these connections to achieve mutual economic growth and prosperity for both India and Sri Lanka. (SRM)

title: Two arrested in gemstone scam
author: Author not found
Content: Kurunegala Headquarters Police arrested two suspects who were involved in cheating women of their gold jewellery by offering them fake gems. The duo, aged 45 and 50, have been engaged in this fraudulent act for the past two years, mainly around the Teaching Hospital in Kurunegala. They target elderly women who visit the Kurunegala town and the Teaching Hospital. The suspects are residents of Badulla and frequently travel to Kurunegala. They approach the women and claim to have a gemstone for sale, stating they urgently need cash. If the women express inability to purchase the gem, the fraudsters propose exchanging the gemstone for the gold earrings and bangles they are wearing, Police said. Upon agreement, they exchange the stone for the women’s jewellry, telling them that the gemstone requires special protection. They then take back the gem, wrap it in a special package and then secretly replace it with a fake gem before returning it to the women, according to the Police. Numerous complaints were lodged with the Kurunegala Headquarters Police about such incidents. After a thorough investigation, Police apprehended the suspects. During the investigations it was found that the stolen jewellery had been sold to a jewellery shop in Colombo. Police said the total value of stolen jewellery from these women amounts to nearly Rs 3.1 million, equivalent to 21 gold sovereigns. BY Ravindu Sooriyabandara – Kurunegala

title: IRD in quandary over opening new tax files
author: Author not found
Content: Union representatives of the Inland Revenue Department (IRD) were recently called before the Parliament Ways and Means Committee where concerns pertaining to the Inland Revenue Department were discussed. This discussion was held on 31 July in Parliament. Although the Government has given a target to open new tax files, the issues that have arisen in implementing this were discussed at length. Pointing out that there is a huge delay in the initiation of new tax files using the RAMIS system currently in use by the Inland Revenue Department, union representatives pointed out that urgent action is needed to streamline this. The Committee said, in order to reap the full benefit of the RAMIS system, IRD should take responsibility for its implementation and a public-private partnership should be created to run it. It was also pointed out that the department has been instructed to join the integrated information system that will be created by merging 13 State Institutions. Tax files are to be opened for people above the age of 18 in connection with the census to be conducted by the Department of Population and Statistics and collect information using a mobile application and take steps to set up a proper data system.

title: Academic activities could grind to a halt – FUTA
author: Author not found
Content: President of the Federation of University Teachers Associations (FUTA) Prof. Barana Jayawardana says that due to the mass exodus of university lecturers the maintenance of day-to-day operations at Universities such as Rajarata, Ruhuna, Jaffna and Eastern have hit a snag. He stressed that due to a shortage of lecturers at these Universities, educational activities in faculties such as medicine, engineering, agriculture and social sciences could come to a halt sooner than later. Prof. Jayawardana said that during a six-month period from January to June this year, some 250 University lecturers had left the service to opt for other vocations or had left for overseas seeking greener pastures. He said among the reasons contributing to this crisis situation had been inadequate salaries paid to university lecturers, exorbitant taxes being imposed and the uncertainty surrounding the country’s immediate future. He explained that though 11,900 lecturers have to be in service in Universities, presently only 6,000 were on duty. He charged that instead of taking prompt measures to address the situation, the Ministers including the subject Minister are continuing to belittle the services rendered by lecturers. Prof. Jayawardana added that university lecturers put in at least a 20-hour service per week and he condemned the recent remarks made by Justice Minister Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe who had alleged that both University lecturers and school teachers render a similar service. BY Amith Madhuranga Gamage

title: Yasodara Prefects host blood donation camp
author: Author not found
Content: The Prefects’ Guild of Yasodara Vidyalaya, Colombo 8 will host a blood donation camp at the school’s main hall today (3) from 9:00 a.m. to 3:00 p.m. This event is open to people from all walks of life. The Prefects’ Guild for the academic year 2022-2023 invites the public to be a part of this noble cause. (DW)

title: TUs allowed to voice constructive criticism – Chandragupta
author: Author not found
Content: Health Ministry Secretary Janaka Sri Chandragupta accepted trade unions had the right to voice constructive criticism against corruption and malpractices taking place in the free health service. Chandragupta said this during a discussion with health trade unions. The unions were preparing for a strike today (3) in protest of the circular issued by Chandragupta restricting health professionals from providing statements to the media without prior approval from institution heads. Following the discussion, the trade unions decided to call off the strike. President of the Academy of Health Professionals (AHP), Ravi Kumudesh said the Secretary had refuted allegations accusing him of concealing the favour shown to trade unions in the Establishment Code and the Trade Unions Ordinance through his circular issued last week. However, during the meeting, Chandragupta said he would not violate the rights of trade union leaders and the heads of institutions of professional organisations. Kumudesh said the Health Ministry Secretary too had appealed to the trade unions to exercise caution when commenting about the State health service while trying to ensure its well-being. Following discussions, the health service trade unions have temporarily halted the strike scheduled for today (3) against the circular issued by the Health Secretary which prohibited the voicing of issues related to State health services to the media, the AHP President said, adding that there had been a written agreement between the trade unions and the Health Secretary, as reassurance in this regard. The trade unions have emphasised that there was no hidden agenda in their motives to expose the corruption and malpractices as they only wanted to protect the well-being of the Government health service and the rights of patients. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: HC Moragoda speaks at Indian Council of World Affairs
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s High Commissioner to India Milinda Moragoda attended a closed-door panel discussion organised by the Indian Council of World Affairs (ICWA), New Delhi on ‘Economic Recovery of Sri Lanka & Visit of the President of Sri Lanka Ranil Wickremesinghe to India’ as the lead speaker recently. In his opening remarks, the High Commissioner said the Sri Lankan President thanked the Indian Prime Minister and his government for the financial assistance rendered during the recent economic crisis which served as the lifeline to lay the critical initial steps towards economic stabilisation. He also said the future India-Sri Lanka cooperation would mainly focus on connectivity and investment which will be founded on a vibrant economic integration strategy. High Commissioner Moragoda elaborated on the significance of India-Sri Lanka relations and the special status it has reached in the recent past. Commenting on the recent visit of the President of Sri Lanka to New Delhi, the High Commissioner said the visit not only further strengthened existing bilateral relations, but laid a solid foundation towards a vibrant India-Sri Lanka economic partnership. Further, the High Commissioner also explained the broader contours mentioned in the joint vision statement along with the importance of MoUs that were signed and underlined the necessity of both countries working towards reaping mutual benefits founded on the key pillars of connectivity and integration, which are expected to be implemented through five key enablers stated in the India-Sri Lanka Economic Partnership Vision. Ambassador Ashok Kantha, former Indian High Commissioner to Sri Lanka, and Ambassador Mohan Kumar, Professor, and Dean of the Office of International Affairs and Global Initiatives, Jindal University also shared their views on the theme along with High Commissioner Moragoda. The ICWA was set up in 1943 by a group of intellectuals led by Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru and Dr. H.N. Kunzru. Its principal objective was to create an Indian perspective on international relations and act as a repository of knowledge and thinking on foreign policy issues. The ICWA is funded by the Ministry of External Affairs and enjoys full autonomy. Ambassador Vijay Thakur Singh, Director General – ICWA, former Indian diplomats, officials of the ICWA, and members of the leading New Delhi-based think tanks were also present at the event along with scholars and research personalities.

title: Unidentified body found in Talawakelle mountain
author: Author not found
Content: The body of a young woman was found in the upper part of the Great Western Mountain in Talawakelle in the evening of 1 August. However, the identity of the deceased is yet to be determined, Lindula Police said. Meanwhile, Nuwara Eliya District Secretary Nandana Galaboda instructed wildlife officers to deny entry to campers to the mountain. According to Police, a group of campers who found the body reported the incident. The body was found lying on the edge of a steep cliff at an approximate height of seven kilometres on the peak of the mountain. Accessing the location was challenging for the authorities as the body fell near a steep cliff close to a narrow road on the mountain. In another unfortunate incident, an Army Corporal who went to the mountain to bring the body fell sick and died as well. Police suspect that the victim was aged between 25 and 35 years. The Nuwara Eliya Magistrate yesterday (2) visited the scene and conducted an on-site investigation. The cause of death remains unknown yet. Police request the public with any information to inform them so that a thorough investigation could be carried out. However, Police suspect that the group or individual who was with her at the time of her death may have fled the scene. By Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood and Chandrasiri Mahagama – Nuwara Eliya

title: Magistrate orders Police to initiate comprehensive probe
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate, Rajindra Jayasuriya, ordered the Borella Police to initiate a comprehensive investigation into the controversial death of three-year-old Hamdi Faslim, without only referring to the post-mortem report. The child passed away at Lady Ridgeway Hospital (LRH) following a kidney surgery, raising concerns about the incident. The Magistrate emphasised the need to consider all the medical reports related to the child’s case before issuing any orders and told Police to inform the LRH Director to provide all those reports. The Magistrate also questioned how such an incident occurred, given that multiple medical tests were performed on the child prior to the surgery. These remarks were made during the Magisterial Inquest into the child’s death. During the inquiry, the child’s mother, Fathima Rizana Abdul Cader gave a testimony revealing that the doctor who performed the surgery had gone abroad after the operation. She further stated that the funeral of the child took place at the Muslim Cemetery in Maligawatte. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Bus driver arrested for threatening traffic cop
author: Author not found
Content: Welikada Police have arrested a bus driver following the circulation of a viral video, on social media, where he is seen threatening a traffic Police officer when he was charged with a traffic violation fine. The suspect is said to be operating a passenger transport service on the Hettiyawaththa-Karagampitiya route. The incident, captured in the video, occurred in Rajagiriya on Monday (31 July). The video attracted widespread attention and led to an investigation by the authorities. In the video, the suspect can be heard verbally threatening the traffic Police officer and warning him not to remain on the road after issuing the fine. Based on the viral video, Police initiated an inquiry and subsequently arrested the driver. (MD)

title: Second Coconut Triangle to be launched in North
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Plantation Industries and Minister of Industries Dr. Ramesh Pathirana stated that the Second Coconut Triangle to be launched in the Northern Province parallel to World Coconut Day. Pathirana stated that an income of USD 1,600 million is expected from exports of rubber and coconut in 2023. During a press conference at the President’s Media Centre (PMC), Dr. Pathirana said they expect USD 900 million from rubber and USD 700 million from coconut.  “The second Coconut Triangle would be launched in the Northern Province this year consisting of the areas of Jaffna, Mannar and Mullaitivu Districts in conjunction with World Coconut Day on 2 September. In the last two years, it was possible to get an income of Rs 1 billion from the export of rubber products. Due to the ability to purchase rubber for the manufacture of gloves during the last corona pandemic, it was possible to generate a sizable export income. But the demand for rubber goods is presently declining as a result of the global economic crisis. Therefore, it has been estimated that this year’s rubber-related export revenue will be around USD 900 million,” he added. He said the coconut export revenue has significantly increased in recent years. “The range of goods that can be found in our coconuts has led to an increase in demand. This year, it is anticipated that exports of coconut-related goods will bring in USD 700 million. It is anticipated that exports of goods related to coconuts would generate USD 2 billion in revenue during the next ten years. Thus, it is envisioned that Sri Lanka will develop a second coconut triangle. Local consumption accounts for two thirds of coconut production. One third is used for export. To increase export potential, this situation needs to be altered,’ he added. Pathirana said Jaffna, Mannar, and Mullaitivu Districts will be included in this second coconut triangle. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Teaching service to absorb 5,500 grads
author: Author not found
Content: Nearly 5,500 graduates will be recruited to the teaching service in the near future, Minister of Education Susil Premajayantha said. Premajayantha announced that Cabinet has approved the recruitment of 5,450 graduates to the teaching service. Speaking at a programme in Badulla aimed at educating school principals on enhancing the quality of education in Badulla District, the Minister emphasised that the recruitment will focus on main subject streams, including Science, Technology, English, and Foreign Languages. The recruitment will be carried out at the provincial level, and the Ministry of Education will later recruit teachers for national schools, he said. Speaking further, Premajayantha said a proposal to merge all National Institutes of Education (NIEs) and convert them into a single university has also been presented to Cabinet.

title: Health Secy, officials under microscope
author: Author not found
Content: Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA) and several civil organisations, lodging a complaint with the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) and the Inspector General of Police (IGP), called for legal action against the Health Secretary and several of its officials over the alleged procurement of lenses and incurring a loss of billions of rupees to the Government.  MCPA President, Chamal Sanjeeva yesterday (2) accused several officials, including the Health Ministry Secretary, of engaging in a procurement process which lacked transparency to procure nearly one million lenses in several stages at a cost of nearly Rs 1 billion without even giving the companies that submitted the lowest bids, during the relevant procurement process, the opportunity to even submit samples. The procedure was settled in a favourable manner for those who submitted one of the highest bids during the tender procedure. They urged the CIABOC and the IGP to initiate an investigation regarding the questionable procurement process and put a stop to it. Dr. Sanjeeva noted that the procurement process for lenses should be recommenced with transparency. Lodging the complaint, Dr. Sanjeeva called for the removal of the Health Secretary from his post, while initiating corruption charges against him. He accused him of making footnotes in favour of the pharmaceutical company which quoted a high price for the importation of lenses. “It is a shame that when we pointed out that a loss ofRs 500 million was incurred due to the purchase of questionable antibiotics, the Health Minister himself admitted that his Ministry had paid over Rs 1 million to buy the drugs. It is a clear fact that such frauds are committed by officials because they know very well that the law will not be enforced,” he said. Meanwhile, Convener of the National Campaign against Bribery, Corruption and Waste, Jaliya Kamantha Roshan, urged the CID to intervene and conduct a comprehensive investigation regarding the death of a child after kidney surgery at Lady Ridgway Children’s Hospital (LRH). He said it was regrettable that the Health Secretary and the Director General of Health Services were putting on a media show while medical negligence and corrupt medicinal drug deals were claiming the lives of patients. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: TUs allowed to voice constructive criticism – Chandragupta
author: Author not found
Content: Health Ministry Secretary Janaka Sri Chandragupta accepted trade unions had the right to voice constructive criticism against corruption and malpractices taking place in the free health service. Chandragupta said this during a discussion with health trade unions. The unions were preparing for a strike today (3) in protest of the circular issued by Chandragupta restricting health professionals from providing statements to the media without prior approval from institution heads. Following the discussion, the trade unions decided to call off the strike. President of the Academy of Health Professionals (AHP), Ravi Kumudesh said the Secretary had refuted allegations accusing him of concealing the favour shown to trade unions in the Establishment Code and the Trade Unions Ordinance through his circular issued last week. However, during the meeting, Chandragupta said he would not violate the rights of trade union leaders and the heads of institutions of professional organisations. Kumudesh said the Health Ministry Secretary too had appealed to the trade unions to exercise caution when commenting about the State health service while trying to ensure its well-being. Following discussions, the health service trade unions have temporarily halted the strike scheduled for today (3) against the circular issued by the Health Secretary which prohibited the voicing of issues related to State health services to the media, the AHP President said, adding that there had been a written agreement between the trade unions and the Health Secretary, as reassurance in this regard. The trade unions have emphasised that there was no hidden agenda in their motives to expose the corruption and malpractices as they only wanted to protect the well-being of the Government health service and the rights of patients. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: HC Moragoda speaks at Indian Council of World Affairs
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s High Commissioner to India Milinda Moragoda attended a closed-door panel discussion organised by the Indian Council of World Affairs (ICWA), New Delhi on ‘Economic Recovery of Sri Lanka & Visit of the President of Sri Lanka Ranil Wickremesinghe to India’ as the lead speaker recently. In his opening remarks, the High Commissioner said the Sri Lankan President thanked the Indian Prime Minister and his government for the financial assistance rendered during the recent economic crisis which served as the lifeline to lay the critical initial steps towards economic stabilisation. He also said the future India-Sri Lanka cooperation would mainly focus on connectivity and investment which will be founded on a vibrant economic integration strategy. High Commissioner Moragoda elaborated on the significance of India-Sri Lanka relations and the special status it has reached in the recent past. Commenting on the recent visit of the President of Sri Lanka to New Delhi, the High Commissioner said the visit not only further strengthened existing bilateral relations, but laid a solid foundation towards a vibrant India-Sri Lanka economic partnership. Further, the High Commissioner also explained the broader contours mentioned in the joint vision statement along with the importance of MoUs that were signed and underlined the necessity of both countries working towards reaping mutual benefits founded on the key pillars of connectivity and integration, which are expected to be implemented through five key enablers stated in the India-Sri Lanka Economic Partnership Vision. Ambassador Ashok Kantha, former Indian High Commissioner to Sri Lanka, and Ambassador Mohan Kumar, Professor, and Dean of the Office of International Affairs and Global Initiatives, Jindal University also shared their views on the theme along with High Commissioner Moragoda. The ICWA was set up in 1943 by a group of intellectuals led by Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru and Dr. H.N. Kunzru. Its principal objective was to create an Indian perspective on international relations and act as a repository of knowledge and thinking on foreign policy issues. The ICWA is funded by the Ministry of External Affairs and enjoys full autonomy. Ambassador Vijay Thakur Singh, Director General – ICWA, former Indian diplomats, officials of the ICWA, and members of the leading New Delhi-based think tanks were also present at the event along with scholars and research personalities.

title: Unidentified body found in Talawakelle mountain
author: Author not found
Content: The body of a young woman was found in the upper part of the Great Western Mountain in Talawakelle in the evening of 1 August. However, the identity of the deceased is yet to be determined, Lindula Police said. Meanwhile, Nuwara Eliya District Secretary Nandana Galaboda instructed wildlife officers to deny entry to campers to the mountain. According to Police, a group of campers who found the body reported the incident. The body was found lying on the edge of a steep cliff at an approximate height of seven kilometres on the peak of the mountain. Accessing the location was challenging for the authorities as the body fell near a steep cliff close to a narrow road on the mountain. In another unfortunate incident, an Army Corporal who went to the mountain to bring the body fell sick and died as well. Police suspect that the victim was aged between 25 and 35 years. The Nuwara Eliya Magistrate yesterday (2) visited the scene and conducted an on-site investigation. The cause of death remains unknown yet. Police request the public with any information to inform them so that a thorough investigation could be carried out. However, Police suspect that the group or individual who was with her at the time of her death may have fled the scene. By Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood and Chandrasiri Mahagama – Nuwara Eliya

title: Magistrate orders Police to initiate comprehensive probe
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate, Rajindra Jayasuriya, ordered the Borella Police to initiate a comprehensive investigation into the controversial death of three-year-old Hamdi Faslim, without only referring to the post-mortem report. The child passed away at Lady Ridgeway Hospital (LRH) following a kidney surgery, raising concerns about the incident. The Magistrate emphasised the need to consider all the medical reports related to the child’s case before issuing any orders and told Police to inform the LRH Director to provide all those reports. The Magistrate also questioned how such an incident occurred, given that multiple medical tests were performed on the child prior to the surgery. These remarks were made during the Magisterial Inquest into the child’s death. During the inquiry, the child’s mother, Fathima Rizana Abdul Cader gave a testimony revealing that the doctor who performed the surgery had gone abroad after the operation. She further stated that the funeral of the child took place at the Muslim Cemetery in Maligawatte. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: SL Embassy in Jakarta organises familiarisation tour
author: Author not found
Content: The Embassy of Sri Lanka in Jakarta, in collaboration with SriLankan Airlines, Jetwing Travels, and the Sri Lanka Tourism Promotion Bureau organised the first familiarisation tour after the Covid-19 pandemic to promote Sri Lanka as a preferred tourist destination for Indonesian Buddhists. The tour group, comprising 11 enthusiastic travellers, will embark on a journey to explore the cultural and spiritual wonders of Sri Lanka from 31 July to 9 August. Although a majority of Indonesians are Muslims, the Buddhist population is also quite significant. There are over 2 million Buddhists of Chinese origin in Indonesia and they play an active role in the business world. This initiative aims to deepen the cultural ties between the two nations while showcasing the rich heritage and serene landscapes that Sri Lanka has to offer. The familiarisation tour will take the participants to several iconic destinations, including the Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic, the breathtaking town of Ella, the picturesque coastal city of Negombo, the historic city of Galle, the cultural hub of Kandy, the enchanting Nuwara Eliya, and the awe-inspiring Dambulla Temple. One of the highlights of the group is the presence of Alicia Yudos, a prominent social media influencer, who will share her experiences and captivating moments throughout the journey, further promoting the beauty of Sri Lanka to a wider audience. Additionally, the group is honoured to include Wenny Lo, an honoured leader of the leading Buddhist Association in Indonesia, known as ‘WANDANI,’ whose participation signifies the strong bond between the Indonesian Buddhist community and Sri Lanka. It is noteworthy that the cost for this familiarisation tour has been solely borne by the travellers themselves, reflecting their genuine interest in exploring the wonders of Sri Lanka and promoting meaningful cultural exchanges between the two nations. Under the guidance of Ambassador of Sri Lanka to Indonesia and ASEAN Admiral (Retd) Professor Jayanath Colombage, Second Secretary (Commercial) Heshani Premathilaka and the team of the Embassy of Sri Lanka in Jakarta, Manager/Indonesia for SriLankan Airlines Amila Wijesekara and SriLankan Airlines team, Manager Jetwing Travels Chathura Fernando and Jetwing team, support in making this journey possible. Chairman/SLTPB H. Chalaka D. Gajabahu and Assistant Director Marketing/SLTPB Chami Lanka Gasnawage will also lend their support. As the group sets out on this adventure, the Embassy of Sri Lanka in Jakarta looks forward to welcoming more Indonesian Buddhists to experience the warmth and hospitality of Sri Lanka shortly.

title: Woman killed in SLTB bus collision
author: Author not found
Content: A road accident occurred on the Kurunegala road near the Warakapola, Thulhiriya Post Office, yesterday (2), when an SLTB bus from the Galgamuwa Depot collided with a fire truck, resulting in the death of a 51-year-old woman from Dompe. She was one of the 55 passengers on board the bus that was heading towards Colombo. According to Warakapola Police, the accident was caused by careless driving on the part of the bus driver, leading the bus to overturn and veer off the road. As a result of the collision, 12 passengers sustained injuries and were rushed to the Warakapola Hospital. Three individuals who were in critical condition were later transferred to the National Hospital Colombo for further treatment. The post-mortem of the victim took place at the Warakapola Hospital. By Damunupola Chaminda Jayalath

title: EP Governor meets Aussie Envoy
author: Author not found
Content: Eastern Province Governor Senthil Thondaman said on 1 August the Government of Australia pledged to assist in various ways to develop the Eastern Province and utilise all available resources. He was speaking following a meeting with the Australian High Commissioner in Sri Lanka, Paul Stefan, and Deputy High Commissioner Lalitha Gafoor at the Governor’s official residence in Batticaloa. High Commissioner Stefan pledged on behalf of the Australian Government to strengthen bilateral ties between the two countries. Governor Thondaman also expressed his belief that the province possesses abundant natural resources, and with proper utilisation, it could quickly become a developed region in the country. During the meeting, both the Governor and the Australian High Commissioner discussed several matters that need urgent attention. Thondaman said the High Commissioner promised to support the promotion of tourism in the Province and address issues related to the fisheries industry, which is crucial for the livelihood of many rural communities. Furthermore, they discussed the promotion of a green hydrogen economy and the use of mineral resources to achieve the development goals of the province. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Women MPs’ Caucus meets former New Zealand PMs
author: Author not found
Content: The Women Parliamentarians’ Caucus of Sri Lanka, who are on a study visit to New Zealand, met former Prime Ministers of New Zealand, Jacinda Ardern and Helen Clark, recently. Empowering women’s leadership in politics and promoting gender diversity were discussed at length with the Prime Ministers. Jacinda Ardern, who held the position of Prime Minister of New Zealand from 2017 to 2023, shared her experience of leading her country in the face of the economic and political crises as well as the Covid-19 pandemic during her tenure. The attention of women parliamentarians was drawn to matters such as the policies created to provide opportunities for women who gave up work to take care of children to enter the job market again, measures taken to create wage equality, paid parental leave in case of childbirth, reducing child poverty, etc. Also, Helen Clark, the first female Prime Minister of New Zealand, spoke about her political experience to the Caucus. She expressed her views on the measures taken during her tenure to empower women, including civil marriage reforms and encouraging women to save money for retirement. A cultural event was also organised representing the ‘Maori’ community in New Zealand to welcome the Sri Lankan Women Parliamentarians’ Caucus. Dr. Sudarshini Fernandopulle, Sitha Arambepola, Rohini Kumari Wijeratne, Pavithra Wanniarachchi, Geetha Samanmalee Kumarasinghe, Thalatha Athukorala, Kokila Gunawardena, Mudita Prishanthi, Rajika Wickramasinghe, Manjula Dissanayake, Dr. Harini Amarasuriya as well as Secretary-General of Parliament Kushani Rohanadeera, Assistant Director (Administration) Indira Dissanayake and Media Manager of Parliament Nimmi Hathiyaldeniya were present on this occasion. This study visit was organised by the National Democratic Institute (NDI) with the support of the United States Agency for International Development (USAID), to strengthen the measures taken by the Women Parliamentarians’ Caucus for the advancement of Sri Lankan women, including the empowerment of women’s leadership in the country’s politics and securing gender equality.

title: Local milk production rises again
author: Author not found
Content: Due to the shortage of animal feed and the economic crisis in the past two years, the dairy industry in this country had declined. But the local production of milk has increased again, the Government-owned main domestic dairy companies Milco, National Livestock Development Board (NLDB) and the private sector-owned Pelwatte Dairy Company emphasise. Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera discussed with the authorities of these dairy companies the present situation and future steps for Sri Lanka’s dairy industry. Accordingly, in the last six months, the National Livestock Development Board has increased the production of milk to 2,599,617 litres and the Milco Company to 19,152,766 litres of milk. The companies pointed out that this amount is a 30 per cent increase compared to last year. He also mentioned that the Pelwatte dairy factory run by Ariyaseela Wickramanayake has not been able to sell 500 mt of full cream milk powder produced with liquid milk in this country. He emphasised that at a time when the production of milk in the country has increased; the Government has allowed the import of milk powder from foreign countries, so it has become impossible to sell its products. As the production of liquid milk in the country is at a high level, the authorities of these companies requested the minister to stop the import of milk powder. However, the Minister instructed the officials of the Livestock Division of the Ministry of Agriculture to prepare a report for him as soon as possible regarding the increase in liquid milk production in the country. The Minister said the report will be submitted to Cabinet and further decisions will be taken regarding the import of milk powder. Meanwhile, due to the shortage of liquid milk in the last two years, Milco Company suspended the production of milk powder and Highland frozen milk, and this year they have started production again. Also, the National Livestock Development Board has again increased all its dairy products.

title: Australian-funded S4IG programme supports culinary training
author: Author not found
Content: The Australian-funded Skills for Inclusive Growth (S4IG) programme, delivered in collaboration with the Sri Lankan Ministry of Education, supports sustainable jobs and increased income in the hospitality and tourism sector through skills development. On Friday, Australia’s Deputy High Commissioner to Sri Lanka, Lalita Kapur, opened a newly-refurbished culinary training facility in Polonnaruwa, with Vocational Training Authority Chairman, Air Vice Marshal (Retired) Prasanna Ranasinghe. The Deputy High Commissioner said the facility will support young people wanting to pursue careers as chefs. “Australia’s support for tourism has been long-running, supporting quality, relevant and inclusive skills development in Sri Lanka,” Kapur said. The training facility aims to foster skills development and economic growth in the region by providing access to state-of-the-art equipment to train young professionals with a focus on supporting women and persons with a disability.
