title: Forest fires plague 15 DS divisions
author: Author not found
Content: Forest fires continue to plague 15 Divisional Secretariat Divisions in Badulla District, and there is a lack of essential facilities to control these fires, according to the Badulla District branch of the Disaster Management Centre (DMC). DMC Deputy Director E.M.L. Udaya Kumara highlighted the challenges faced in combatting these fires due to the lack of essential facilities and advanced technology. With the prevailing dry weather in the district, the deliberate lighting of fires in forest areas has become a significant concern. Reports indicate that multiple forest fires have been recorded across various areas within the 15 Divisional Secretariat Divisions of Badulla District. In some instances, nearly 10 fires have been reported in a single day. Efforts to control the fires involve assistance from the armed forces, divisional secretariats, and firefighting units. However, the lack of advanced technology hampers their effectiveness, increasing the risk of possible disasters in the future. Udaya Kumara also warned of the potential for severe landslides and rock falls, posing a serious threat to life and property if heavy rainfall occurs this year. By Nishantha Abeygunawardena – Badulla

title: Night experience vital to boost tourism – Gamage
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Tourism Diana Gamage referred to Colombo as a ‘dull city’ in Sri Lanka and urged for immediate measures to boost tourism y by implementing a night economy. She was talking about the quality of accommodation provided to tourists, such as Airbnb and homestays, during a media briefing at the President’s Media Centre (PMC)on Tuesday (1). “To revitalise the tourism industry, implementing a night economy was crucial. Tourists look for destinations that offer them and the freedom to enjoy life to the fullest. Closing tourist spots early, like at 10.00 p.m., would discourage tourists from visiting the country. To attract more tourists, it is essential to create vibrant and lively environment, rather than having ‘dull cities’ with limited nightlife experiences. To achieve this, it is necessary to extend the operating hours of tourist destinations, allowing visitors to have a more enjoyable experience. This might involve keeping certain places open late into the night, offering various entertainment options, and facilitating activities that appeal to tourists,” she pointed out. The Government has also taken steps to implement a system that assesses the quality of accommodation provided to tourists, such as Airbnb and homestays. Maintaining high-quality facilities and services can help Sri Lanka attract more tourists and enhance the overall tourism experience, she added. “With the implementation of these promotional programmes and initiatives, the State Ministry aims to strengthen Sri Lanka’s economy through a thriving and vibrant tourism industry. Emphasising a night economy, extending beach stays, and improving transportation connections will undoubtedly make Sri Lanka a more attractive and appealing destination for tourists from around the world. A thriving tourism sector can bring in substantial revenue, create job opportunities, and contribute significantly to the nation’s economic growth,” Gamage said. Gamage addressed the importance of direct flights with international airlines, particularly Chinese and Italian airlines, to enhance accessibility and convenience for tourists. Such partnerships can help attract more visitors and further contribute to the growth of Sri Lanka’s tourism sector. Further, she said a significant milestone is set to take place at the end of this year, as Sri Lanka plans to host the final competition of the World Travel Awards (WTA) in December. This event is expected to see the participation of 117 countries, further elevating Sri Lanka’s status as a global tourism destination. The President has been apprised of these developments, showing the Government’s commitment to showcasing Sri Lanka’s potential to the world, the State Minister said. BY Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Measles outbreak in Vavuniya Prison
author: Author not found
Content: Vavuniya Prison has been forced to close for two weeks due to a measles outbreak within the prison premises. As a precautionary measure, the entry of visitors has been suspended and temporary release of detainees for legal proceedings has also been halted. The cramped condition within the prison is believed to have contributed to the rapid spread of the disease. To combat the outbreak, health authorities, along with PHIs, have been proactive in providing vaccinations to prison officers and inmates. Vavuniya Prison currently has over 400 detainees while it is staffed by 85 officers. According to the media spokesman of the Department of Prisons, Chandana Ekanayake, it is anticipated that the prison will resume usual activities in a few days following the containment and management of the outbreak. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: UNP Working Committee meets today
author: Author not found
Content: A Working Committee meeting of the UNP headed by President Ranil Wickremesinghe is scheduled for today (2) at Sirikotha to take a final decision on holding the Party Convention. According to party sources, the meeting will commence at 4.00 p.m. All members of the Working Committee, including General Secretary Palitha Rangebandara, UNP Deputy Leader Ruwan Wijewardene, Chairman Wajira Abeywardena, Assistant Leader Akila Viraj Kariyawasam, National Organiser, Senior Presidential staff and Adviser to the President on National Security Sagala Ratnayake are expected to attend the meeting according to UNP sources. The meeting will cover important matters, such as the upcoming UNP convention scheduled for September this year and the proposed amendment to the UNP constitution. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: President to deliver special statement in Parliament on 13th Amendment
author: Author not found
Content: After lapsing two weeks of the All-Party Conference, President Ranil Wickremesinghe is scheduled to make a special statement in Parliament next week regarding the 13th Amendment to the Constitution. According to a statement issued by the UNP, the President’s statement will clarify that all powers, except Police powers, will be devolved to Provincial Councils as part of strengthening the 13th Amendment. Further, the President has assured that he will present all proposals related to reinforcing the 13th Amendment to Parliament for approval. However, the statement also acknowledges that the implementation of the 13th Amendment is facing obstacles due to differing opinions among Tamil political parties.

title: Coroner’s role to be streamlined
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet has approved Justice Minister Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe’s proposals to streamline the role of the Coroner and make it more efficient. Coroners are appointed in Sri Lanka on the ‘Korala’ basis, municipal division and hospital basis. The Government is of the view that the public is inconvenienced and find it difficult to get the services of Coroners due to the inability to identify the boundaries of the relevant jurisdictions, the Department of Government Information said in a statement. Further, the vacancies exist in some districts without a coroner being appointed for a long time is another reason that inconvenienced the public. To resolve these issues and provide a more efficient and regular service to the public, the Ministry of Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms has prepared a fixed manual, clearly stating the provisions including the qualifications, responsibilities and roles of Coroners. In accordance with the provisions in the manual, the ministry has planned to assign all currently appointed Coroners to Divisional Secretariats and identified hospitals, to appoint bilingual inspectors for bilingual Divisional Secretariats and to effect new recruitments to fill the remaining vacancies.

title: Namal blames ‘Aragalaya’ masterminds
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) MP Namal Rajapaksa shifted the blame for former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s decision to transit to 100 per cent organic fertiliser to the masterminds of the ‘Aragalaya’. During a recent SLPP meeting, Rajapaksa alleged that a ‘third party’ had initiated the ‘Aragalaya’ from the very beginning of Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s term in office. He also expressed concern over the unsatisfactory price at which the government is purchasing paddy from farmers, especially during the current drought. He emphasised the importance of compensating the farmers adequately for their hardships. “We are witnessing a drought that has severely affected paddy farmers. It is crucial for the government to prioritise compensating them for their losses. The government purchases their produce, but unfortunately, the prices offered to the farmers are far from satisfactory. In the upcoming SLPP parliamentary group meeting, we will address this matter with the government’s top officials,” he stressed. He further said the party’s commitment was to addressing the issues faced by farmers, mentioning their intervention to resolve matters related to the Aswesuma welfare benefit programme. Rajapaksa assured that they are closely monitoring the progress on this matter and will continue advocating for the welfare of the people. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: EOI for ‘e-passports’ suspended
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Public Security, Tiran Alles has decided to suspend the Expression of Interest (EOI) for the issuance of electronic passports, also known as ‘e-passports’, and instead call for tenders, the Ministry announced yesterday (1) The initial call for Expressions of Interest had encountered complaints from several applicants who faced technical difficulties. In response to the feedback and considering the current economic situation, Minister Alles presented a Cabinet paper which was approved. The Cabinet’s decision includes the appointment of a special technical evaluation committee to address the matter and initiate a new tender process for the issuance of ‘e-passports’. Consequently, Minister Alles decided to cancel the call for bids through the EOI mode and opted to call for tenders through the normal procurement process. A senior official from the Ministry said the target was to issue more than 700,000 e-passports annually, with an estimated cost of about USD 15 million. The official highlighted the significant expenditure required for the machines used in the passport issuance process, making the implementation of e-passports challenging due to the high costs involved. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Chicken prices to reduce by Rs 100 a kilo
author: Author not found
Content: Poultry producers have agreed to reduce the selling price of a kilogramme of chicken, by Rs 100. This decision comes in the wake of the Government’s decision to import chicken meat to control skyrocketing prices in the local market. A discussion was held at the Ministry of Agriculture with poultry producers yesterday (1) to safeguard the local poultry sector from a potential collapse which could occur if chicken imports flood the market. During the discussion producers attributed the recent increase in chicken prices to the Rs 75 import tax on maize, which is an essential feed component. They proposed that the import tax should be reduced to Rs 25, a measure that would help stabilise and reduce the cost of poultry production. In response to these considerations, poultry producers agreed to reduce the price of one kilogram of chicken by Rs 100, thereby easing the burden on consumers. Moreover, producers conveyed their commitment to continue finding ways and means to further reduce prices.

title: Diana questions Harin’s existence
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Tourism, Diana Gamage accused Tourism Minister Harin Fernando of not supporting initiatives undertaken by the Tourism Ministry to enhance country’s tourism sector. She emphasised that all the projects and programmes related to tourism have been accomplished with the support of the President. During a media briefing, at the Presidential Media Centre (PMD), yesterday (1), Gamage clarified that there is no personal animosity between them. She, however, expressed disappointment over the significant lack of support or active involvement from the Cabinet Minister of Tourism and Lands. ““I don’t even know whether the Cabinet Minister of Tourism still exists. We do not have any personal grudge yet, he hasn’t been much support ever,” she alleged. Gamage went on to share positive news about the tourism sector’s progress, stating that Sri Lanka has welcomed 763,000 tourists in the past seven months of the year generating approximately USD 800 million, in revenue. This is a remarkable growth rate of 205% compared to the previous year, she said. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Sinopec to initiate retail petroleum operations – Kanchana
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera yesterday (1) said the first fuel shipment from the Chinese company, Sinopec, was already being discharged and the arrival of the second shipment is expected today (2).  The Minister said this milestone is a significant step in introducing new retail suppliers to Sri Lanka’s petroleum market, which is projected to yield substantial economic benefits to the country. Following the finalising of agreements with fuel station dealers, Sinopec is now poised to initiate retail petroleum operations throughout the country. Their expansion plan aims to establish 150 fuel stations across the island. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: Diana pledges to cancel licences of tourism wrongdoers
author: Author not found
Content: Referring to the recent incident in which a Saudi couple who visited Sri Lanka was attacked at a hotel in Beruwala, State Minister of Tourism Diana Gamage assured that she would take necessary steps to cancel the licences of wrongdoers in the tourism industry. She expressed her concerns about recent incidents of misbehaviour towards tourists that were circulated on social media and said she has initiated investigations in order to take appropriate and severe measures. During a media briefing, at the Presidential Media Centre (PMC) yesterday (1), Gamage emphasised the role played by the State Ministry of Tourism in promoting and facilitating tourism. While private institutions and individuals are essential for the success of the tourism industry, she stressed while adding that even the actions of a single person can impact Sri Lanka’s reputation as a tourist destination. To maintain high standards and ensure a positive experience for tourists, Gamage highlighted the vital need for regulations in the tourism business. She acknowledged that regulating the industry is crucial to prevent negative incidents or inconveniences to tourists, as such occurrences can have far-reaching consequences on the entire tourism sector. Speaking further, Gamage emphasised the importance of a robust regulatory framework that safeguards the interests of both tourists and the tourism sector. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: CID takes over Vavuniya arson attack investigation
author: Author not found
Content: Investigation into the arson attack in Vavuniya, on 24 July, where a young couple was killed, has been handed over to the CID. The arson attack, during a birthday party, resulted in the death of the couple and caused injuries to several others. Vavuniya Police arrested five suspects, aged between 24 and 33, residing in Vavuniya. Three motorcycles suspected to have been used in the attack were also seized. Investigation so far, has revealed that the attack was motivated by a personal dispute, and the masked assailants had specifically targeted the house while the owner was celebrating his daughter’s birthday. The CID has obtained detention orders to interrogate the suspects.

title: Enhancing religious harmony among schoolchildren
author: Author not found
Content: A programme was held at Maris Stella College in Negombo under the patronage of Minister of Buddhasasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs Vidura Wickramanayake on 30 July. The main objective of this programme was to enhance the religious harmony among schoolchildren. More than 500 students, representing all four religions, participated in this event. The programme was a successfully completed with the aid of Ministry of Buddhasasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs, Department of Christian Religious Affairs, Seth Sarana and few other religious institutions. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: Police canine Agar brings robber to book
author: Author not found
Content: A thief who broke into a house in Kahalla, Katugastota and stole an antique armchair and a TV, was swiftly apprehended with the assistance of Police dog, Agar. When the house was unoccupied, the thief had removed the roofing sheets to gain entry. Upon receiving a complaint about the incident, Katugastota Police sought the assistance of the Sri Lanka Police K9 Division and brought in Agar to the scene. The clever dog was given a wooden box from the house to sniff and began tracking the thief’s scent. Agar led the Police to a house located around 200 metres away, where he started barking. Upon investigating the location, they found the stolen antique armchair. Subsequently, the Police questioned the owner of that house, leading to the discovery that the stolen TV had been sold to a neighbour for Rs 3000. Agar, the diligent police dog, has been instrumental in the capture of several criminals in Kandy, including a murder suspect, in recent times, highlighting the valuable contribution of Police canines in solving crimes, the Katugastota Police said. BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Successful Police ops result in reduced crime in SP – Minister Alles
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles said there has been a reduction in crime, especially in the Southern Province, due to successful operations conducted by the Police. Addressing the media during an event to honour two Police Officers and two civilians on 31 July, Minister Alles mentioned that several measures have been implemented to curb crime. However, he emphasised that the specific details of these measures cannot be disclosed to the public until the ongoing investigative operations are concluded. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: Impressive electoral performance for SLPP in upcoming Election – Johnston
author: Author not found
Content: MP Johnston Fernando, exudes confidence in the Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna’s (SLPP) ability to emerge victorious at any Election. He expressed confidence that former President Mahinda Rajapaksa would achieve a record number of preferential votes in the region, adding that at least 11 SLPP members were likely to be elected to Parliament from the Kurunegala District. Speaking at an SLPP meeting in Polgahawela, Fernando said the party has successfully reorganised itself in more than 70 percent of the electorates, dispelling doubts regarding their comeback after facing attacks the previous year. While addressing the media, Fernando said their party has defied expectations and regained their strength in over 70 per cent of the electorates, despite scepticism that their members would not be able to return to the field. Furthermore, Fernando projected an impressive electoral performance for SLPP in the upcoming elections, stating that they are poised to secure a majority of over 200,000 votes in the Kurunegala District. BY Dinithi Wijesundara

title: Bus plunges down10-foot cliff, 15 injured
author: Author not found
Content: A bus, belonging to the Nuwara Eliya Depot, was travelling from Colombo to Nuwara Eliya when it veered off the road and fell off a 10-foot precipice, resulting in 15 people being injured. The injured passengers were admitted to the Watawala hospital. The accident occurred yesterday (1) at approximately 4.30 a.m. in close proximity to the Watawala Sinhala Vidyalaya, on the Hatton main road. According to Police, the accident occurred as the bus driver tried to give way to another bus coming from the opposite direction. By Neeta Padma Kumari – Norwood

title: Farmers protest vegetable import decision
author: Author not found
Content: A group of Welimada farmers protested on Monday (31 July) against the government’s decision to import various types of vegetables, including potatoes. The protesters signed a petition to voice their opposition. The farmers marched to Vidurupola Bodhiya to express their grievances. They demanded that the government implement programmes to reduce the production costs of potatoes and vegetables. They also expressed concerns about the impact of importing vegetables from abroad, as it could flood the local market and make it difficult for them to sell their agricultural crops. The protesting farmers accused the government of neglecting the interests of the farming community and claimed that the decision to import vegetables would harm local agriculture. They called for an immediate reversal of the import decision and urged the government to develop a comprehensive programme to support and uplift local vegetable farmers. By Saman Nadungamuwa – Boralanda and Lushantha Rathnayake – Welimada

title: INS Khanjar departs
author: Author not found
Content: The Indian Naval Ship INS Khanjar, which arrived in Trincomalee on 29 July on a three-day formal visit, departed on Monday (31 July). The Sri Lanka Navy bade a customary farewell to the departing ship in accordance with Naval tradition at the Port of Trincomalee. On her departure, INS Khanjar conducted a successful Passage Exercise (PASSEX) with SLNS Sagara. In the PASSEX, Communication Training and Tactical Maneuvering Training exercises were conducted, and it concluded with the customary cheer ship salute. During the ship’s stay in the island, the crew members of INS Khanjar took part in several programmes including yoga and a beach cleaning drive, with a view to enhancing cooperation between two navies. In addition, a cross section of INS Khanjar crew witnessed a Visit Board Search & Seize – VBSS demonstration, at the Special Boat Squadron Headquarters and a cultural show presented by the Sri Lanka Navy at the Admiral Wasantha Karannagoda Auditorium, Naval and Maritime Academy. Meanwhile, personnel of the Sri Lanka Navy had the opportunity to visit INS Khanjar during its stay in Trincomalee. The crew members of the ship also took time off to visit some of the tourist attractions in the area. Visits like these will play a crucial role in fostering collaboration among naval forces. Additionally, these visits facilitate naval exercises and training activities, allowing the exchange of knowledge and information about their unique maritime environments. This exchange can be particularly beneficial in addressing shared maritime challenges.

title: Navy extinguish fire in Wattala
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Navy rushed a firefighting team to the Wattala area following a sudden fire which broke out in a house on Church Road last morning (1). The Navy rushed its firefighting team to the scene of fire when the Wattala Police requested assistance from the Operations Room of the Western Naval Command yesterday (1) morning, to extinguish the blaze and prevent the spread of the fire to nearby properties. The Navy rushed a firefighting team attached to SLNS Gemunu. Residents and Navy firefighters put out the fire preventing further devastation.

title: Kanthoori to mark 131st death anniversary of Sickander Voliullah
author: Author not found
Content: A commemorative event was held at Ambalathara Masjid-Nooraani, on 30 July, to mark the 131st death anniversary of Sheikh Kuthubuna Sheigu Sickander Voliullah, at the place where he was buried. The event included the hoisting of the flag, a recital of ‘Kathamul Quran,’ and Kanthoori which is a feast provided to the entire community, including villagers from the area and suburbs. A large gathering of Muslim devotees participated in the event. The District Secretary of Ampara, Chinthaka Abeywickrema and Professor M.M. Dheen Mohammed from the International University of Hammadin Khaleefain Qatar attended the event as the chief guest and guest of honour, respectively. District Secretary Chinthaka Abeywiickrema inaugurated the Kanthoori  and Professor Dheen Mohamed recited a special ‘Dua’. (Pix by M.A.P. Deen – Ampara)

title: Pakistan ASF arrest Doha-bound Sri Lankan with drugs
author: Author not found
Content: Pakistan’s Airport Security Force (ASF) arrested a Sri Lankan for attempting to smuggle 10kg of heroin to Qatar, Pakistan media reported. The arrest took place at the Islamabad International Airport during routine security checks before the passenger boarded a Doha-bound flight. During the regular luggage screening process, ASF staff became suspicious of a  bag and decided to inspect it further. The investigation revealed that the bag contained 10.294kg of heroin concealed inside. The Sri Lankan national who was in possession of the narcotics was taken into custody by the authorities. As of now, the identity of the drug smuggler has not been disclosed. Following the arrest, the individual has been handed over to Pakistan’s Anti-Narcotics Force (ANF) for further legal proceedings.

title: Aung San Suu Kyi jail term reduced after some pardons
author: Author not found
Content: Former Myanmar leader Aung San Suu Kyi has been pardoned in five of 19 charges brought against her by the military. The pardon, part of a seasonal amnesty, will reduce her 33-year jail sentence by six years.Former President Win Myint, who was ousted along with Suu Kyi, also received a reduced jail sentence after getting two of his charged pardoned. Periodic amnesties have been announced before, but this is the first time they have included Suu Kyi and Myint. The military junta has made other concessions in what appears to be an effort to revive stalled diplomacy efforts. Last week, Suu Kyi was moved from prison to house arrest in the capital Nay Pyi Taw. The 78-year-old Nobel laureate has been detained by the military since February 2021 following the coup that ousted her. The coup triggered civil war in the country, and has led to the deaths of thousands of people. The military junta has also been accused of unleashing disproportionate violence against those opposing its rule.

title: ‘ICE’ USE ON THE RISE
author: Author not found
Content: The initial results of a nationwide survey on Methamphetamine, commonly known as ‘ICE’ indicate that there are approximately 50,000 users of this drug in the country, according to Shakya Nanayakkara, Chairman of the National Dangerous Drugs Control Board (NDDCB). Addressing the media yesterday (31) Nanayakkara said that compared to the other drugs, ‘ICE’ has been widely spread in the country within last three years. Therefore, sharp attention should be drawn into that factor, he pointed out. However, Nanayakkara reassured that the use of ‘ice’ or Methamphetamine in schools is not as widespread as previously feared, based on the samples and findings gathered from the teachers involved in the survey. Nanayakkara also noted that towards the end of 2022, there was a notable increase in the number of individuals seeking admission to rehabilitation centres, indicating a concerning trend in drug abuse. Speaking further, Nanayakkara said no school student has been arrested for offences related to ICE during last six months. He said, however, tobacco consumption by school students had increased recently and it has been noticed that students take tobacco to the schools from their homes. BY Mithun Jayawardena

title: Public Security Ministry lauds exemplary cops, civilians
author: Author not found
Content: In recognition of the exemplary performance of Police officers and civilians, an awards ceremony was held yesterday (31 July) at the Ministry of Public Security, under the patronage of Minister Tiran Alles. During the event, Minister Alles praised the Police officers who carry out their duties with integrity and without accepting bribes, citing them as role models for the Sri Lanka Police. Two Sergeants of Doratiyawa Police Station, D.M.S.K. Dissanayake and L.A.I.G.H. Liyanaarachchi, were honoured for their refusal of a bribe amounting to Rs 100,000 from individuals attempting to transport 10 cows in a lorry from Dambulla to Kurunegala, which amounted to animal cruelty. Additionally, civilians H.A. Dileep Samankumara and R.A. Seelarathna were recognised for their assistance in apprehending a suspect who had robbed a woman’s gold necklace and promptly handing him over to the Divulapitiya Police. Minister Alles presented the two civilians with cash prizes and commendations, emphasising that the Sri Lanka Police relies on the support of the public in its mission to combat crime. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: Tax increase hampers Excise income
author: Author not found
Content: In the backdrop of reduction of excise income due to recent price hikes, the Committee on Ways and Means, that visited the Department of Excise, instructed the department officials to calculate the elasticity of demand for liquor before increasing prices. The officials of the Excise Department highlighted various factors, including the increase in taxes in the last budget, that have contributed to the decrease in excise income. Moreover, the committee emphasised the importance of conducting appropriate surveys and providing clear instructions to the Ministry of Finance when proposing tax adjustments on alcohol. In addition, the committee urged the department to take immediate action in developing a new application to identify liquor bottles with counterfeit foolproof stickers. Although these stickers were introduced to prevent the circulation of fake products, it has been brought to light that counterfeit stickers are still prevalent in the market. It was revealed that the Excise Department currently lacks the necessary mechanisms to recognise such counterfeit stickers. (MD)

title: SL, Japan agree to resume stalled projects
author: Author not found
Content: Both Sri Lanka and Japan have agreed to resume stalled projects sponsored by Japan, once Sri Lanka’s debt restructuring process is finalised, the President’s Media Division (PMD) announced yesterday (31). The PMD, in a statement, said Fujimaru Satoshi, Minister of State in the Cabinet Office of Japan and Yamamoto Kozo, former Minister of State for Regional Revitalisation and Regulatory Reform, called on President Ranil Wickremesinghe at the Presidential Secretariat yesterday (31). During the meeting, they discussed the stalled development projects in Sri Lanka, which were previously supported by the Japanese Government. The parties agreed to restart these projects once the credit optimisation process in Sri Lanka is completed. Additionally, they decided to involve officials from the Japanese Embassy in Sri Lanka in conducting an investigation related to these projects. The Japanese delegation, including Ambassador of Japan to Sri Lanka Mizukoshi Hideaki, President’s Senior Advisor on National Security and Chief of Staff Sagala Ratnayaka and President’s Senior Adviser on Economic Affairs Dr. R.H.S. Samaratunga, among others, attended this meeting.

title: Case against Gammanpila deferred to Nov
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Namal Balalle, yesterday (31) deferred further proceedings of the case against MP Udaya Gammanpila, to 8 November. The PHU Leader, has been charged before the High Court, by the Attorney General, with criminal misappropriation of a sum of Rs 21 million, having illegally sold the shares 19 years ago of a firm, owned by an Australian national Bryan Shaddick, via a fraudulently compiled Power of Attorney, containing the fake signature of the foreigner, from 26 September 1996 to 21 December 1997. When the case was called, Judge Balalle, noticed six witnesses for the Prosecution, to be present before him, at the next hearing. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Hit-and-run case against Patali deferred to November
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Namal Balalle, yesterday deferred further hearing of the hit-and- run case, against MP Patali Champika Ranawaka, to 23 November. The former Minister has been indicted before the High Court, by the Attorney General, with causing a grievous injury to youth Sandeep Sampath, at Rajagiriya seven years ago and for failing to report a traffic accident to Police, fleeing after causing an accident, providing misleading information to dupe the Judiciary, reckless driving and for flouting Provisions contained in Sections 149, 216, 224 and 161 (4) of the Motor Traffic Ordinance and for violating Provisions contained in Sections 329 of the Penal Code. When the case was taken up, the accused lawmaker was present in Court. Defence Counsel Amarasiri Paditharatne informed Judge Balalle, that his client had already filed an appeal before the Supreme Court (SC), related to a separate case, based on the same incident and noted that the SC, had issued an interim injunction on it. The Defence Counsel then added that his client had also filed an appeal, pertaining to the ongoing case, before the Apex Court. Taking the submissions into perusal, the Court fixed further proceedings of the trial, to the said date. Furthermore, the Attorney General has also indicted Dilum Thusitha Kumara, who had posed off as Ranawaka’s driver, during the said accident and former OIC of the Welikada Police, ASP Sudath Asmadala before the Court. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: School principal arrested over drunken assault
author: Author not found
Content: The principal of a popular school, in Mt. Lavinia, was arrested for assaulting a security officer. The victim, Kasun Dulanjana Nadira, a 28-year-old resident of Horana, Meewanapalana, is currently under treatment in the ICU of the National Hospital Colombo. He alleged that the principal was consuming alcohol in school premises when the assault incident took place. Police have recorded statements from five individuals, including the principal, regarding the assault. Additionally, the Mt. Lavinia Police have decided to search for any potential eyewitnesses and CCTV footage related to the incident.

title: Samurdhi payments to continue for ‘Aswesuma’ disqualified
author: Author not found
Content: The Cabinet has approved the proposal to continue providing Samurdhi welfare payments to nearly 394,000 Samurdhi recipients who were disqualified for the ‘Aswesuma’ welfare benefit programme, State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe announced. Currently, some 1.3 million families receiving Samurdhi benefits have applied for Aswesuma welfare benefits and out of these, 887,653 families have qualified. The Cabinet approved the relevant proposal submitted by the President. The process of reviewing appeals and objections against the beneficiaries’ list is ongoing, and new applications will be called for once these procedures are completed. According to Semasinghe, a total of 1.79 million families are eligible for Aswesuma welfare benefits, with 9,046,612 newly admitted to the welfare beneficiaries’ list. The aim is to provide Aswesuma welfare benefits to two million families and this goal will be reached after considering appeals and objections. The payments for the elderly, sick, and disabled individuals will continue as before. Elderly allowances can be obtained through post offices, while kidney patients and disability allowances will be delivered through regional secretariats. Beneficiaries living in elderly homes, children’s homes, disability centres, and clergy will receive their welfare benefits as usual. Around one million people have already provided their account details and the others on the beneficiaries’ list are urged to open relevant bank accounts as soon as possible to receive the payments. State banks will be open today (1 August) although it is a Poya Day to facilitate the opening of Aswesuma bank accounts, the State Minister said.

title: Tax increase hampers Excise income
author: Author not found
Content: In the backdrop of reduction of excise income due to recent price hikes, the Committee on Ways and Means, that visited the Department of Excise, instructed the department officials to calculate the elasticity of demand for liquor before increasing prices. The officials of the Excise Department highlighted various factors, including the increase in taxes in the last budget, that have contributed to the decrease in excise income. Moreover, the committee emphasised the importance of conducting appropriate surveys and providing clear instructions to the Ministry of Finance when proposing tax adjustments on alcohol. In addition, the committee urged the department to take immediate action in developing a new application to identify liquor bottles with counterfeit foolproof stickers. Although these stickers were introduced to prevent the circulation of fake products, it has been brought to light that counterfeit stickers are still prevalent in the market. It was revealed that the Excise Department currently lacks the necessary mechanisms to recognise such counterfeit stickers. (MD)

title: SL, Japan agree to resume stalled projects
author: Author not found
Content: Both Sri Lanka and Japan have agreed to resume stalled projects sponsored by Japan, once Sri Lanka’s debt restructuring process is finalised, the President’s Media Division (PMD) announced yesterday (31). The PMD, in a statement, said Fujimaru Satoshi, Minister of State in the Cabinet Office of Japan and Yamamoto Kozo, former Minister of State for Regional Revitalisation and Regulatory Reform, called on President Ranil Wickremesinghe at the Presidential Secretariat yesterday (31). During the meeting, they discussed the stalled development projects in Sri Lanka, which were previously supported by the Japanese Government. The parties agreed to restart these projects once the credit optimisation process in Sri Lanka is completed. Additionally, they decided to involve officials from the Japanese Embassy in Sri Lanka in conducting an investigation related to these projects. The Japanese delegation, including Ambassador of Japan to Sri Lanka Mizukoshi Hideaki, President’s Senior Advisor on National Security and Chief of Staff Sagala Ratnayaka and President’s Senior Adviser on Economic Affairs Dr. R.H.S. Samaratunga, among others, attended this meeting.

title: SJB to move a Motion to dissolve Parliament
author: Author not found
Content: The Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) said it will put forward a Motion, calling for the dissolution of Parliament. They added that other Parties, including the ruling Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) were invited to support it. Speaking to the media on 31 July, SJB MP S.M. Marikkar urged all parties to sign a resolution to dissolve Parliament paving the way for a general election. Marikkar said the SLPP, particularly former Minister Johnston Fernando, had expressed confidence of their victory in future elections. In response, the SJB challenges the SLPP to back the resolution and demonstrate their commitment to face a general election. He criticised the current state of Parliament, stating that, it no longer represents the will of the people. Therefore, the best course of action, Marikkar said, was to dissolve Parliament and allow the citizens to decide who should lead the country. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: LRH conducts probe into 3-year-old child’s death
author: Author not found
Content: Deputy Director General of the Lady Ridgeway Hospital for Children Dr. G. Wijesuriya said a preliminary probe had commenced into the death of the three-year-old patient following a kidney surgery. Dr. Wijesuriya yesterday (31) said the Health Ministry too would conduct a comprehensive probe at the end of the preliminary inquiry being conducted by the hospital. He said the three-year-old had undergone surgery in December 2022 and is alleged to have died due to an infection. According to media the deceased who had been a resident of Kotahena had been diagnosed with a failure of one of his kidneys (the left kidney) following tests carried out at the LRH, when he was nine-months-old. According to media reports the child’s right kidney had been healthy and functioning while his left kidney had been failing. The report by the surgeon who performed the operation had noted that the child’s left kidney had been surgically removed. Subsequent tests that followed, as the child had not been passing urine as usual, had revealed that an undiagnosed horseshoe kidney (a condition in which the kidneys are fused together) had been removed.  The child, sans functioning kidneys, had needed haemodialysis till such time that a suitable kidney could be transplanted. However, he succumbed to his illness following an infection before that. Meanwhile, Media Committee Member of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA), Dr. Chamil Wijesinghe urged health authorities to conduct an independent investigation into the death of the child as the entire medical procedure relating to the child’s medical condition had been taken collectively. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Group of 93 Japanese tourists visit Sri Lanka
author: Author not found
Content: A special group of 93 Japanese nationals, including 16 children, arrived in Sri Lanka on Saturday the 29 July 2023 on a 5-day tour of Sri Lanka. During their stay they will be touring Negombo, Sigiriya,and Kandy experiencing the traditional Ayurvedic treatments at Ayurvie Sigiriya by Thema Collection. The Japanese travellers were welcomed at the Bandaranaike International Airport by Dr. Ruwan Perera, Chairman Rowelmark Travels, Chandra Wickramasinghe Chairman and Managing Director of Travel Design by CDC (a subsidiary of Connaissance de Ceylan (Pvt) Ltd) along with other officials of both companies.

title: 56,000 dengue cases this year, 50% in WP – NDCU
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka has witnessed over 56,000 dengue cases so far this year, The National Dengue Control Unit (NDCU) revealed. Dr. Nalin Ariyaratne NDCU Director said, 50% of the dengue cases were recorded in the Western Province. Additionally, a significant number of cases have been reported in the Kandy, Kegalle, Kurunegala, and Puttalam Districts. Dr. Ariyaratne also pointed out that a considerable number of dengue cases have been identified in the Trincomalee and Batticaloa Districts. While there has been a notable decrease in the daily reported cases, Dr. Ariyaratne warned that the risk of dengue mosquito transmission remains and urges continued vigilance in dengue prevention efforts.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Installation of new office bearers
author: Author not found
Content: The installation ceremony of new office bearers of the Lions Club of Colombo Pride was held recently at the Mattegoda Camilla School. The chief guest at the ceremony was 2nd Vice District Governor Lion Priyantha Perera, MJF, MAF, who installed the officer bearers for the year. Past District Governor Lion Nimal Aluthge, MJF, MAF, JP also witnessed the occasion. The key members of the Clubarethe President-Lion Hasitha Dharmakeerthi, Secretary and LCIF Coordinator – Lion Sriyani Aluthge, MAF, Treasurer – Lion Mangala Pathirage, Vice President – Lion Harindu Aluthge, Membership Chairperson – Lion Kapila Rajapakshe, Service Chairperson – Lion Lakshika Dewathantriarachchi, Marketing Chairperson – Lion Gayan Dewathantriarachchi and Directors Lion Eshani Chandraratne, Lion Geetha Rajapakshe,Lion Chanchala de Silva, Lion Thusara Muramudali and Lion Asela Liyanage.

title: Making Waves For A Cleaner Coastline
author: Author not found
Content: In an inspiring display of environmental stewardship, AIESEC at the University of Sri Jayewardenepura conducted the OnBlue Beach Cleanup Project on 23 July, at the Mount Lavinia Beach Range. AIESEC which is the world’s largest youth-led organisation, engages in giving opportunities to the youth by facilitating them in cross-cultural internship and volunteering exchanges with the prime objective of developing young leaders. The initiative garnered widespread support from local authorities, businesses, and environmental activists, emphasising the community’s collective responsibility to safeguard the environment. With an impressive turnout of over 100 enthusiastic participants, the event proved to be a massive success. Armed with gloves and garbage bags, the eco-conscious volunteers tirelessly combed the shoreline, collecting plastic waste and other debris, leaving no stone unturned. The collective effort showcased the power of community engagement in tackling marine pollution, as participants united under the common goal of preserving our oceans. AIESEC’s initiative sets a shining example for future conservation projects. The Event Partners included American & Efird Lanka Pvt Ltd as the Banner Partner, Dilmah Conservation & Sustainability Research Centre as the Sustainability Partner, Ceylon Today Newspaper as the Media partner, and Eco 360 Pvt Ltd as the Eco Partner and our Industrial Partner, Ansell Lanka Pvt Ltd, for generously providing us resources for the Project. All  Contributions were crucial for the success of this Event.

title: Colombo Dockyard delivers first ever Cable Laying and Repair Vessel
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Dockyard PLC made history, on 28 July 2023, by delivering the first-ever Cable Laying and Repair Vessel (CLRV) to the European market from Sri Lanka. “Our client Orange Marine, a prominent French company, is a specialist in submarine telecommunications. They excel in every aspect of this field, including initial design, engineering, installation of intercontinental and regional links, as well as the maintenance of existing cables. Their fleet is widely recognised for its expertise and is considered one of the most experienced in the world, representing an impressive 15% of the global fleet in this sector,” Colombo Dockyard said. Colombo Dockyard delivered the first Cable Layer Vessel (CLV) to Japan in 2019. Now, with the delivery of ‘C/S Sophie Germain’, this becomes the second vessel of its category delivered by the shipyard. This remarkable accomplishment establishes Colombo Dockyard as a leading player in the international market, earning a reputation for successfully delivering two Cable Layer vessels within a short space of just five years. The ceremonial delivery of ‘C/S Sophie Germain’ took place at Dock No 4 south pier of CDPLC premises and was attended by owners, dignitaries from the Embassies of France and Japan in Sri Lanka, officials from government institutions including BOI,EDB,SLPA and Sri Lanka Navy, Merchant Shipping, State and private banks, Class surveyors, CDPLC top management, and employees. During the ceremony, Emmanuel Decugis, the Ship Newbuilding Project Director of Orange Marine, broke the traditional Sri Lankan milk pot to symbolise the delivery of the ship. He also received the ship model on behalf of Orange Marine. The event was further attended by representatives from Orange Marine, including superintendents and the ship’s crew, making it a significant moment for the company. Jean-François Pactet-French Ambassador to Sri Lanka, Mizukoshi Hideaki-Japan Ambassador to Sri Lanka, Murakami-First Secretary of Embassy of Japan in Sri Lanka, Jean Alexander Egea – Head of the Economic Department and Economic Adviser and Coordinating Attaché Imali Akarawita from Embassy of France in Sri Lanka represented the foreign missions. From CDPLC Hideaki Tanaka-Chairman, Thimira Godakumbura MD/CEO, Nozaki-Technical Adviser/ Alternate Director and a host of other Senior Management and Staff participated. ‘C/S Sophie Germain’ is a state-of-the-art, high-technology vessel, specifically designed and equipped for sub-sea cable laying and repair operations. The vessel was designed by Vard Design AS of Norway. The detailed design work was carried out in-house by Colombo Dockyard’s skilled design team. The vessel is 100m in length with a beam of 18.8m and a Depth of 7.15m and shall have a deadweight capacity of 1800 DWT. The vessel can achieve an impressive speed of 14.5 knots and has accommodation facilities for 76 persons. The vessel has three cable tanks to carry fiber optic and power cables. One of the three tanks is fitted with a Carousel system.  This vessel is built to Bureau Veritas (BV) classification society standards and regulatory requirements of the French Flag Authority. In his address at the occasion, CDPLC Chairman Hideaki Tanaka acknowledged the challenges faced due to the financial crisis in Sri Lanka, leading to the cancellation of significant projects and the risk of losing their standing in the international market. However, he expressed great satisfaction in the achievement of delivering ‘C/S Sophie Germain’, which serves as a powerful message to the international market. It demonstrates that Colombo Dockyard is coming back stronger and more resilient than ever, positioning itself as a tough and capable shipyard in the global arena. CDPLC, operating in joint collaboration with Onomichi Dockyard Company Limited of Japan, continuously shows its presence to the international market and contributes heavily to the National Export earnings from the Shipbuilding sector with much needed foreign currency for the Sri Lankan economy. This project will be instrumental in showcasing CDPLC’s reputation in the European Market with the brand ‘Built in Sri Lanka blending Sri Lankan technology with Japanese quality’.

title: Literature keeps a nation alive – Premier
author: Author not found
Content: The academic discourse at Temple Trees titled  ‘Sankathana Mandapaya’ is organised by the Prime Minister’s Office. This time around the programme focused on the literary achievements of Dr. Leel Gunasekara, a renowned senior administrative officer. The book titled ‘The Petition’, an English translation of  ‘Pethsama’ written in Sinhala authored by Dr.  Gunasekara was launched on this occasion. At the launch, Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena said; “Dr. Leel  Gunasekara   enriches  the never- ending river of Sri Lankan literature. Literature keeps a nation alive and  allows a nation to think anew.  I see it as a blessing that you have been gifted and able to accomplish these objectives over a long time”, the Premier said. “Pethsama is a work of art which consists of characters living in real society through the generation of time. The simplicity of genuine Sri Lankans can be understood in this book. It manifests the language of our country, lifestyle and how we have stood up bravely as a nation”, he further said.  Leel  Gunasekara is  a pioneer in the public service and education service as well. Once, Prime Minister Sirima Bandaranaike appointed him as the Inspector General of Police while he served as a Government Agent(GA). How ironical it is that Leel  Gunasekara who was a GA at that time  while appreciating the rustic nature of the village was also appointed as Inspector General of Police which has  a great responsibility. You would have been appointed to such a position because of your approach to the literary service as well as to the public service. Nowadays, the IGP is heavily criticised. Such criticisms were there even before and even after your appointment.  Under those circumstances you were steadfast in your love for literature and ensured that humanity rose above everything else. “When I was Foreign Minister, I heard about a report you prepared on the methods to be followed by low income earners of this country. It was stated in one chapter that strengthening the rural child with technical knowledge would help them when they left school. Even at this point of time imparting technical knowledge to children who drop out of school is not done in a proper manner in our country”, he said. Literary scholar Sunil Sarath Perera said, “Dr. Leel Gunasekara’s passion for History and his practical consciousness was extremely significant. I believe society itself gave him the opportunity to work as a writer for a long time. His experiences as a GA contributed greatly to the creation of these literary works. He enlivened the grievances of rustic life through his book ‘The Petition’. He displayed the authentic life of villagers who live in the rural areas of Nuwara  Kalaviya and Hathara Korale through his work of art.” The author said, “Today I am very happy to write an English novel for the first time and publish it under the patronage of the Prime Minister. I received the State Honorary Award in 1962 for ‘Pethsama’. Dr Gunapala Malalasekara, who watched Ediriweera Sarachchandra’s stage play ‘Maname’ said that Sarath’s work was excellent. It was at this point of time that I made up my mind that I too would produce a piece of work that would turn out to be excellent.  This book is a combination of ancient and modern literature that has inspired me.” Ven .Gatahaththe Sobitha Thera, Kirama Wimalajyothi Thera, MP Yadamini Gunawardena, Chairman of the Press Complaints Commission of Sri Lanka, Kumar Nadesan, retired senior civil officer Jolly Somasundaram, Head of Sarasavi publishers H. D. Premasiri and several scholars and artistes were present at the launch.

title: Motorists alerted to heavy traffic
author: Author not found
Content: Motorists using the Deniyaya – Akuressa main road in Matara have been alerted to possible heavy traffic congestion today (1 August) due to the annual Esala Perahera festival of Getabaru Devala in Kotapola, Matara. The final Randoli Perahera of the annual Esala Perahera festival, at the historic Getabaru Devala in Kotapola, Matara, will take place today (1). As a result, the Police have issued a special announcement to motorists in the area, informing them about the expected heavy traffic congestion from 1.00 p.m. to 10.00 p.m. Motorists are advised to consider using alternative routes during this period.

title: Dengue drivein Battaramulla
author: Author not found
Content: The Central Environment Authority (CEA), the Office of the Medical Officer of Health and Private Institutions of Health Medical Division  carried out a dengue prevention campaign in several areas of Battaramulla. The campaign covered government institutions, private establishments, homes and public places. The initiative will continue on a monthly basis, an official said. More than 20 private and public institutions comprising around 100 individuals, participated. Among them were representatives from the Battaramulla Health Division and Red Cross officials. Special attention was given to cleaning areas prone to mosquito breeding, and the public was informed about potential breeding grounds and ways to prevent dengue outbreaks.

title: Govt to introduce a business facilitation law
author: Author not found
Content: The Chairman of the Select Committee of Parliament, appointed to study the practical problems and difficulties, that have arisen, in relation to enhancing the rank in the Ease of Doing Business Index in Sri Lanka and make its proposals and recommendations, stated that President Ranil Wickremesinghe has provided guidance and support for the implementation of numerous programmes aimed at creating a conducive environment for investment in the country. MP Madhura Withanage revealed this during the Media Conference held at the Presidential Media Centre (PMC) on 30 July. He highlighted the government’s plan to introduce a business facilitation law aimed at removing barriers for investors. Additionally, Withanage emphasised that the bureaucratic hurdles in promoting investment and business should be addressed by adopting a public service management policy rather than traditional administration methods. He said that it is expected to bring a law to facilitate business in the country by removing the barriers for investors. Withanage expressed his concern about Sri Lanka’s current position at the 99th place in the business facilities improvement index, which is considered a significant global indicator. He pointed out that specific recommendations, issues arising from the relationship between the public and private sectors and outdated legal regulations are contributing factors to this situation. Acknowledging the support of President Wickremesinghe, Withanage stated that they have been granted full freedom to address these challenges and provide necessary solutions. He also mentioned the active involvement of a presidential task force dedicated to this matter. The Parliament’s recommendations will be promptly implemented by the task force, both in the short term and with a focus on medium and long-term solutions.

title: Love has no borders
author: Author not found
Content: In another cross-border story, a 25-year-old Sri Lankan woman had travelled to India to marry a man from Andhra Pradesh whom she met on Facebook six years ago. Arriving in India on a tourist visa, Vigneshwari tied the knot with Laxman, a 28-year-old resident of Andhra Pradesh. However, she has been informed that she must depart the country once her visa expires on 15 August, unless she seeks an extension of her stay, as reported by The Times of India. Chittoor District’s Superintendent of Police (SP), Y Rishanth Reddy, delivered a notice to the woman regarding this matter. Vigneshwari is reportedly planning to apply for Indian citizenship and has already applied for a one-year extension of her stay on Saturday, according to TOI. The couple got married at a temple on 20 July after Vigneshwari’s arrival in Andhra Pradesh on 8 July. The boy’s family blessed their union, and the Police have advised them to register their marriage officially. This story adds to a series of recent cross-border tales, such as that of Anju and Seema Ghulam Haider, who also ventured across borders to meet or marry men they encountered online. In the case of Haider, a Pakistani mother of four, she clandestinely entered India to live with Sachin Meena, a Hindu man she connected with while playing PUBG in 2019. Taking their relationship to the next level, the couple married at the Pashupatinath Temple in Nepal in March of the current year. Similarly, Seema travelled from Pakistan to Nepal, using the Karachi-Dubai route on a 15-day tourist visa on 10 May. From Kathmandu, she reached Pokhara, where she stayed for the night before crossing the Roopandehi-Khunwa (Khunwa) border district Siddharthnagar to enter India in the morning of 12 May. (One India)

title: Susil seeks Japan’ s help to enhance vocational education
author: Author not found
Content: Education Minister Susil Premajayantha and Japanese Minister of State Fujimaru Satoshi, former Minister of State Kozo Yamamoto and the Japanese Ambassador to Sri Lanka held discussions on enhancing vocational education in Sri Lanka. During the discussion yesterday (31 July), Premajayantha expressed his commitment to incorporating elements of the Japanese education system, specifically focusing on optimising professional training opportunities, into Sri Lanka’s educational landscape. He eagerly sought Japan’s support in this endeavour. In response, the Japanese ministers agreed to provide professional training opportunities for young workers in Sri Lanka through the Japan Tech Institute. Additionally, they pledged support for the formal training of teachers to be proficient in the Japanese language. This initiative aims to enrich language education and bridge cultural boundaries, fostering a deeper understanding between the two nations. Premajayantha further emphasised the need to create more educational and employment prospects for the students and workers in Sri Lanka. The focus on generating ample opportunities seeks to empower the Sri Lankan workforce with the skills to contribute meaningfully to the country’s growth and development. By Dinithi Wijesundara
