title: No coherent strategy to achieve President’s 2048 vision
author: Author not found
Content: Despite President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s vision to make Sri Lanka a developed country by 2048, the Ministry of Finance which comes under the President himself has no coherent strategy in place to achieve that goal, it was revealed at a recent Committee on Public Finance (COPF) meeting. COPF chaired by Dr. Harsha de Silva expressed strong dissatisfaction over the absence of summoned officials responsible for coming before the committee. The committee stressed that when discussing matters related to a particular Ministry, Heads of the Ministry who are accountable to Parliament should be present at the proceedings. This concern arose during the committee meeting held on Tuesday (25) in Parliament, where the Mid-Year Fiscal Position Report 2023, issued under Section 10 of the Fiscal Management (Responsibility) Act, No. 3 of 2003 was under consideration. The report, presented by the Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilization, and National Policies, highlighted that the budget’s primary balance had a surplus of 0.1%. Revenue collection witnessed a significant YoY increase of 41.9% to Rs 1,317 billion, primarily due to a substantial rise in VAT on goods and services. However, the expenditure for the first half of the year amounted to Rs 2,560 billion, representing a YoY increase of 40.5%. Notably, domestic interest expense experienced the most substantial increase, rising by 51.6% toRs 1,273 billion in the first half of the year. During the meeting, Committee members raised several questions concerning the fiscal position, economic performance, expenditure, and the performance of State-Owned Enterprises based on the presented statistics by the officials in attendance. Key concerns were expressed by the Committee about the 11.5 per cent contraction in the first quarter of 2023. The Committee inquired about the root causes of this contraction and the specific measures taken to address these issues to prevent further economic downturns. Additionally, the Committee questioned the Ministry’s sustainable plan to achieve growth in line with the President’s vision for 2048. However, it was disclosed that there was no coherent strategy in place. The Committee was dissatisfied with the officials’ responses to queries, finding them ineffective and lacking clarity. They also discussed the increase in taxes, differentiating between those driven by inflation and policy changes in taxes. The Committee emphasised the importance of presenting adequate data and statistics when appearing before them. They urged officials from the Ministry of Finance to be more responsible, have a proper vision, and establish a focused team to achieve the goal of a sustainable economy.

title: Medicine scarcity hits dental care
author: Author not found
Content: Signs have emerged of a possible standoff of Orthodontic treatment and dental conservation at State dentals and laboratories owing to the scarcity of chemicals, medicinal drugs and equipment. General Secretary of the Government Dental Surgeons’ Association (GDSA) Dr. Manjula Herath said since 2021 no chemicals or surgical equipment needed for dental surgeries had been received by the Medical Supplies Unit (MSU) of the Health Ministry. He stated that such surgeries had been carried out up to now requesting patients who come for surgeries to bring the necessary chemicals and equipment. He charged that though of a list of items numbering 2,500 needed to continue operations in laboratories and dentals, a list of ony 223 items had been submitted to health officials. However, to date they had not got them. Dr. Herath added that the perceived delay in getting items mentioned above had not been due to the economic upheaval and noted that officials had informed them that the delay was due to lack of sufficient officers to oversee the procurement process. He alleged another reason for the mess was the lack of coordination between the MSU of the Health Ministry, State Pharmaceutical Corporation (SPC), NMRA and the units tasked with carrying out emergency purchases. Meanwhile, the President Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA), Chamal Sanjeeva warned there was a danger in the closure of many dental clinics and normal dental care services provided in state hospitals due to the Health Ministry’s delays and its lax attitude towards an appeal made by the Dental Associations requesting  for the provision of essential chemicals, medicinal drugs and equipment on a priority basis. Dr. Sanjeeva said the delays in the procurement process and the procurement mechanism of the Health Ministry, the MSD, the NMRA and the SPC had given rise to such a situation. Dental services were given high priority in the country’s Rural and Community Health Services; the MCPA President said noting that Dental Surgeons were the ones who usually detected signs of possible oral cancer which was the most common cancer in Sri Lanka. He pointed out that it was the government’s duty to provide the necessary support to prevent the collapse of the dental service while the MCPA as a trade union pledged to throw its weight behind the GDSA in obtaining the necessary support from the state to carry out their services. Dr. Sanjeeva stated that the country’s health service was in serious collapse and the health system is in danger due to the increase in the price of medicines which are said to be inferior due to the shortage of medicines and the procurement process. BY Vineetha M. Gamage and Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: SL ratifies Nuclear Test Ban Treaty
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka ratified the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty (CTBT), becoming the 178th State to endorse the treaty, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced. The instrument of ratification of CTBT, the document by which a State expresses its consent to be bound by the treaty, was deposited with the UN Office of Legal Affairs (UNOLA) on Tuesday (25) at the UN Headquarters in New York. By depositing the CTBT instrument of ratification, Sri Lanka’s status as a signatory is elevated to a complete State Party to the Treaty. Drafted at the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva, and adopted by the General Assembly on 10 September 1996, the CTBT has been open for signature since 24 September 1996 at the United Nations, New York. Sri Lanka was among the first signatories of the CTBT in October 1996, just days after the Treaty opened for signature. Sri Lanka later entered into a Facility Agreement with the CTBTO in June 2000 which led to the establishment of an auxiliary seismological station in Pallekale, Kandy, as part of the International Monitoring System (IMS) to verify compliance with the CTBT. The Geological Survey and Mines Bureau (GSMB) is the national technical focal point of Sri Lanka for the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty Organization (CTBTO) based in Vienna, Austria. The CTBT bans all nuclear explosions everywhere, by everyone, and for all time. The Treaty is nearly universal, with 186 Signatory States and 178 ratifying states. However, the Treaty will only enter into force, once it is ratified by all 44 States listed in its Annex 2. Sri Lanka’s ratification at this juncture bears testimony to its long-standing commitment towards nuclear non-proliferation and its pursuit to achieve the principle objectives of the CTBT.

title: Welikada maid death verdict on 25 August
author: Author not found
Content: The Colombo Magistrate’s Court scheduled the verdict of the magisterial inquest into the death of a housemaid named R. Rajakumari, who died while in the custody of the Welikada Police, on 25 August. Rajakumari, a 41-year-old resident of Badulla was arrested on 11 May following a complaint made by her employer, Sudharma Nethicumara, who accused her of stealing gold jewellery. She passed away while in the custody of the Welikada Police, leading her relatives to raise suspicions and allege that she had been subjected to assault. During the recent Court session presided over by Colombo Additional Magistrate Harshana Kekunawala, evidence led by the Criminal Investigation Department’s Assistant Superintendent of Police (ASP) Meryl Ranjan Lamahewa, was concluded. In a previous court hearing, a witness named Mahendran Suresh testified that he had witnessed Rajakumari being assaulted by Welikada Police officers. He also revealed that two police officers had handcuffed him while he was at the Pettah bus stand and brought him to a house on Cotta Road in Borella, where the deceased woman was employed. According to Suresh’s account, both he and Rajakumari were handcuffed together, and she appeared to be in good health at that time. However, after they were taken to the Welikada Police station, two officers allegedly assaulted them, despite her employer’s pleas for a non-violent resolution. As a result of these allegations, disciplinary action was taken against seven officers from the Welikada Police, leading to the interdiction of a Sub-Inspector (SI), two Sergeants, and a Constable. Additionally, a Constable and two Women Constables were subsequently transferred. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Peripheral hospital system on the verge of collapse
author: Author not found
Content: Doctors warned that maintaining patient care services in the peripheral hospital system in the island would prove a serious challenge in the coming months with the increasing number of doctors leaving the country. Secretary of the Government Medical Officers Association (GMOA) Dr. Haritha Aluthge said according to data collected by the GMOA more than a thousand doctors have left the system since 2022 to date.  It has become a tough challenge to maintain patient care services in the peripheral hospital system. “If this trend continues, the day will not be far when services of not only the peripheral hospitals but the entire health service of the island will collapse,” he warned. It is no secret that the country’s medical specialists and senior doctors were leaving the country in the face of the current economic crisis, rising cost of living and socio-political instability. Dr. Aluthge said his union had continued to emphasise that a series of government policies should be implemented to encourage doctors to stay in the country – which, he observed “would be far better than illegal threats and the imposition of misplaced rules and regulations.”   By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: APC held at Presidential Secretariat
author: Author not found
Content: The All-Party Conference (APC) called to discuss the National Reconciliation Programme was held at the Presidential Secretariat yesterday (26). The Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP), Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB), and Illankai Tamil Arasu Kachchi (ITAK) participated in the APC. However, the Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) did not participate in the APC. After meeting Tamil political parties recently, the President invited all the parties for an APC. The President’s Media Division (PMD) said the primary aim was to apprise party leaders representing Parliament about both the National Reconciliation Programme and the North and East Development Plan. Ceylon Today learns that the parties could not reach a consensus with regard to enacting the 13th Amendment to the Constitution. It is reliably learnt that both Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa and Freedom People’s Congress leader MP Dullas Alahapperuma had requested to hold the long-delayed Provincial Council Elections before enacting the 13th Amendment. Meanwhile, the PMD said, the President pointed out the need for inclusive discussions on the 13th Constitutional Amendment during the All-Party Conference and emphasised that this matter affects the entire country and should be addressed with the participation of all political parties, and not limited to just Tamil MPs. The President also highlighted that seven out of the nine Provincial Councils are situated in regions where a majority of Sinhalese people reside and emphasised the need to address the existing shortcomings if the Provincial Council system is to be sustained in the future.

title: Manning market protest, six arrested
author: Author not found
Content: A tense situation erupted yesterday (26) at the new Manning Market in Peliyagoda when stall owners protested against the Urban Development Authority (UDA) recommending over 200 vacant stalls, which they named as ‘outsiders’. They demanded that the remaining stalls be given to those already doing business in the vicinity of the Manning Market and to those who have applied and live in and around Colombo. According to the Committee on Public Enterprises (COPE), which called for inquiries from the UDA to determine who should be given the vacant stalls recently, they recommended wholesale vendors near and far. Based on these recommendations, the UDA selected around 200 applicants to be offered the remaining stalls for rent as far as Dambulla, Nittambuwa, Meerigoda etc. However, the protesters argued that many vendors who were already on the old list submitted to the UDA were being ignored. They claimed that the newly allocated stalls were given to outsiders, and there were still many old vendors deserving of stalls. UDA officials, speaking to Ceylon Today, stated that all the old Manning Market vendors from Pettah have been given stalls, and there are over 200 stalls remaining to be allocated to other vendors. The protesters believed that political affiliations were behind the decision. Further, the UDA revealed that some of the new Manning Market vendors have allegedly rented their stalls to third parties, effectively controlling the market. During the protests, the vendors claimed that the UDA was being selective in giving stalls to outsiders and that they would not allow such practices, as they identified many old vendors who did not get stalls for themselves. Earlier, Minister of Urban Development and Housing Prasanna Ranatunga revealed that he has been informed about the Manning Trade Complex, Peliyagoda being misused by external parties for various unlawful activities. In response to this, he has advised the police to take strict measures to enforce the law against those involved in such misconduct. Amidst the commotion, police were deployed, resulting in the arrest of around six protesters on the same day (26). By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: DMT Werahera Branch to resume printing driving licences
author: Author not found
Content: Starting 1 September, the Department of Motor Traffic (DMT) Werahera Branch will resume printing driving licences, DMT Commissioner General Nishantha Anuruddha Weerasinghe announced yesterday (26). Previously, the printing of driving licences was undertaken by the Sri Lanka Army beginning 1 January 2021 using a specialised security system. The decision to hand over the printing process to the Army was made by Cabinet on 1 July 2020, as part of an initiative to enhance the efficiency of the public service. The driving licence printing department operated by the Sri Lanka Army was under an agreement for several years. However, with the transfer of responsibility back to the DMT, the agreement will be subject to review. In preparation for the transition, officers from the DMT are currently undergoing training to familiarise themselves with the affairs of the department. Once the training is complete, they will be assigned to handle the printing driving licences. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Japanese FM on visit from 28-29 July
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Foreign Affairs of Japan, Hayashi Yoshimasa will undertake an official visit to Sri Lanka from 28 to 29 July. During the visit, the Japanese Foreign Minister is scheduled to have official discussions with Minister of Foreign Affairs Ali Sabry at the Ministry and pay courtesy calls on President Ranil Wickremesinghe and Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced yesterday (26). Minister Yoshimasa will be accompanied by Senior Foreign Policy Coordinator Murakami Manabu, Director General Southeast and Southwest Asian Affairs Arima Yutaka, Director General International Cooperation Endo Kazuya, Deputy Press Secretary Okano Yukiko from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Japan and a 22 – member delegation consisting of officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan. The delegation will also visit a Japanese Official Development Assistance (ODA) site in Sri Lanka.

title: Harak Kata to be brought before Court
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Navaratne Marasinghe yesterday (26) instructed the Director of the CID to produce notorious drug trafficker Nadun Chinthaka alias ‘Harak Kata’ on 10 August. Harak Kata has been accused of issuing a death threat and intimidating a house owner with a weapon, after which a sum ofRs 20,000 in cash and a motor car had been robbed. CID informed the Court that the defendant is currently detained by them for interrogation. Harak Kata has been indicted before the High Court for having unlawfully entered the residence of Anura Perera situated at Mulleriyawa on 10 June eight years ago, in the company of deceased Harsha Yasas and making off with Rs 20,000 and a car. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Shortage of kidney drug, ploy for emergency purchase – GMOA Secretary
author: Author not found
Content: Following the warning given by the National Institute for Nephrology, Dialysis and Transplantation (NINDT) of a possible halt in kidney transplant surgeries due to the shortage of a medicinal drug, Secretary of the Government Medical Officers Association (GMOA), Dr. Haritha Aluthge warned that creating such shortages might possibly be another excuse to resort to emergency purchasing. Such situations were a result of the National Medicine Regulatory Authority (NMRA) registering the medicinal drug of one or maximum two suppliers creating a monopoly for the particular drug, addressing the media yesterday (26) Dr. Aluthge said. Later that particular supplier and another were intentionally excluded when calling for tenders. He explained that such tactics were followed mostly as a result of the Health Ministry’s delay in meeting its bills. A large amount of The Health Ministry’s arrears possibly running into millions for previous purchases would pile up while those suppliers would be kept waiting. “The pharmaceutical suppliers were also running a business venture. Therefore, the Health Ministry while delaying payments to those suppliers would import the medicinal drug from an unregistered supplier leaving doubts as to the quality of the drug”, he lamented.   BY Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Cassandra has made Sri Lanka proud
author: Author not found
Content: On a recent Sri Lanka visit was the first SL-born woman to be elected to Australia’s Federal Parliament, Canberra.   Cassandra Fernando (35) migrated with her parents to Australia at the age of 11 and grew up in Dandenong, Southeast of Melbourne, North Victoria.  There she worked at Woolworths in Dandenong Plaza for around 15 years, including as a pastry chef. She was educated at William Angliss Institute, Box Hill Institute. Representing workers in the retail and fast-food industries, Cassandra is currently the Labour MP for the Division of Holt since the 2022 federal election. Cassandra’s story would undoubtedly inspire and drive many young people both in Sri Lanka and elsewhere. Being a member of a country’s influential political party at such a young age is a challenging task for many of us.  Nevertheless, she has accomplished her goal and has become a shining example of Sri Lankans who have made their mark in world forums. Before entering politics, Cassandra volunteered to educate migrants and refugees from non-English speaking backgrounds as well as raised her voice to enhance the pay and conditions of workers, who worked diligently throughout the Covid-19 pandemic. She firmly believes everyone is entitled to a fair day’s wage. She also worked for the betterment of Sri Lankan migrants to ensure that families like hers are not held back or left behind. She says she upholds to this day, three values her parents taught her – hard work, commitment, and gratitude. It means that she has to be grateful to her community and to Australia and never miss an opportunity to repay the gratitude.

title: ‘Miss World Tourism 2023’ to promote SL tourism – Dr. Hettiarachchi
author: Author not found
Content: Dr. Sahida Hettiarachchi, International Directress of the Miss World Tourism pageant, said the main purpose of holding the ‘Miss World Tourism 2023’ pageant in Sri Lanka is to promote the tourism industry more formally. The photo shows beauty queens from 28 countries meeting Dr. Hettiarachchi. Pix By Sudath Malaweera

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date:  German national George Silan, 72, who has visited Sri Lanka a 100 times, was felicitated by the Ruhunu Tourist Bureau on Tuesday (25). His arrival in Sri Lanka on 1 July marked his 100th visit to the island. Silan speaks Sinhala fluently and said he was drawn to the country because of its many tourist attractions and places of historical importance. He however, said the greatest draw was the hospitality of its people and their welcoming and easy-going nature. Silan considers Sri Lanka virtually his second home and describes the country as like no other tourist destination. He said he has never got tired of visiting the Island and said he would continue to tour the length and breadth of the country till he is physically able to, and then call it a day. BY Kamal Wijehewa – Galle Popular

title: Education Minister meets Australian delegate
author: Author not found
Content: Education Minister Susil Premajayantha recently held a special meeting with Australia’s Shadow Minister for Multicultural Affairs, Community Safety, and Migrant Services, Jason Wood, at the Office of the Leader of the House of Parliament. During the meeting, the main agenda was to discuss ways to expand higher education opportunities for Sri Lankan students in Australia. Both Ministers highlighted the significance of enabling students to access quality education, promoting academic excellence, and fostering cultural exchange between the two countries. Minister Premajayantha also provided insights into the ongoing transformative education reform process in Sri Lanka. (DW)

title: Korea looks into new development projects – Korean Ambassador
author: Author not found
Content: Ambassador of Republic of Korea Miyon Lee said her country would work on a few new development projects in Sri Lanka in addition to early completion of  on-going projects. She said so when Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena requested her to take steps to resume some of the ongoing infrastructure development projects that were halted due to economic crisis and the issue of debt restructuring. She also pointed out that there are 25,000 Sri Lankans working in Korea and another 7,000 will be added this year. The Ambassador called on the Premier at Temple Trees on Tuesday (25) and said her country will consider the request made by the Prime Minister to assist projects on water treatment, sanitation, sewage disposal systems and dry zone agriculture. The Premier said Korea has the opportunity to invest in new sectors such as production of agricultural machinery, medicine and medical equipment and renewable energy and the fisheries sector. Ambassador Miyon Lee said she would also work on further enhancement of cultural and religious ties, educational exchanges and people-to-people relationship. The Premier requested her to look into the possibility of recruiting Sri Lankans under the seasonal agricultural workers scheme. The Ambassador assured that her Government would consider the request. (SRM)

title: Estate sector Aswesuma beneficiaries get welfare benefits
author: Author not found
Content: Many ‘Aswesuma’ beneficiaries in the Estate Sector were seen standing in long queues opposite State banks in Hatton town from the wee hours of 26 July. They had come to obtain their welfare benefits and to open new Bank accounts. The beneficiaries said they spent many days in queues at the Norwood Divisional Secretariat to claim the ‘Aswesuma’ welfare benefits. They were required to provide all documents to be eligible for the scheme. BY Neeta Pathmakumari – Norwood

title: Canada Govt redefining ‘Reconciliation’ in Sri Lanka for cheap Toronto political drama
author: Author not found
Content: In spite of the reconciliation mumbo-jumbo, what is being promoted is retributive justice for a National Army and restorative justice for an internationally banned terrorist movement. When foreign governments slap sanctions on those who ended decades of terror and envoys visit terrorist linked individuals, what is the message being conveyed? It therefore comes as no surprise when successive Canadian envoys are happy to be chit chatting with those linked to either terrorism or separatism and now cultural genocide with the vandalism taking place targeting Buddhist archaeological sites. Of course, cultural genocide is a topic close at heart to Canada, having been declared guilty of mass murders of Canadian indigenous natives in residential schools run by the Church. The truth and reconciliation promoted is to forgive Canada and the Church and for the indigenous folk to forget, while the indigenous natives continue to suffer discrimination and inequalities. Obviously the same remedy is being peddled in Sri Lanka. On 17 January 2005, Paul Martin the Prime Minister of Canada met the TNA and TRO at the Colombo Hilton. TNA requested the Canadian PM to channel funds through NGOs instead of through the GoSL.  Incidentally, the TRO was banned by US in 2007 for raising funds for LTTE. The TNA delegation included R. Sampanthan, Joseph Pararajasingham (killed in Dec 2005), Gajendrakumar Ponnambalam. K P Reggie (Exec Director of TRO). Paying courtesy calls on a controversial Northern PC Member Fast forward to July 2023, the Canadian High Commissioner Eric Walsh was seen paying courtesy calls on a controversial Northern PC Member T. Raviharan, involved in a series of mischief and propagating vandalism and violence upon Buddhist heritage archaeological sites in the North of Sri Lanka. He has been at the forefront of protests & unruly behaviour in Kurundi, Gurukanda Raja Maha Viharaya. When questioned about the sudden visit, the Canadian High Commission claims that Eric Walsh’s visit was to ‘meet people in different parts of the country, to better understand their priorities and perspectives”. The below breakdown of the Canadian High Commissioners visits should give a good idea or the people he has met and the “priorities” that Canada is giving prominence to. It is baffling why the Canadian High Commission would want to go to Jaffna twice and in particular to meet with T. Raviharan whose name has been repeatedly appearing for causing ethno-religious tensions. It is reliably informed that the envoy is arranging a Colombo-meet of these unscrupulous elements with obviously a well-funded plan to increase the tempo of attacks on the Buddhist archaeological sites as they foresee this as one of the biggest obstacles to advancing the 13th Amendment and cutting the North & East out of Colombo control. The reason to raise concern about the Canadian High Commissioner’s visits primarily centres on the decisions by the Canadian Government. It is true that outside of Sri Lanka, Canada and in particular Toronto holds the largest number of Tamils. What is also true is that these numbers are mostly asylum seekers or refugees as the numbers do not tally with the 2021 Canadian census. Be that as it may, these pro-LTTE elements are making considerable influence over Canadian Parliamentarians. Domestic politics and funding appear to be a key reason to promote a bogus genocide claim and slap sanctions when no legal court has declared anyone guilty of war crimes and even UNHRC has failed to provide evidence of even the 40,000 dead that kicked off a global tarnishing campaign. Incidentally, Serbia was accused of the same number of dead and eventually that figure ended up only 2,500 or less. The war crimes/genocide hype resulted in imprisoning the Serbian President who died in jail before he was eventually exonerated and those who accused have yet to even apologise for putting a President in prison for no valid reason. This is clearly the same outcome for Sri Lanka. Mourning terrorists It is shocking that to satisfy domestic politics, a national government like Canada is happy to mourn terrorists that died in the last phase of the conflict while agreeing to declare genocide remembrance week as well as subject Canadian children to learn about a genocide that never took place. Years down the line, Canada will end up a laughing stock. We await the day Canada finds out to their embarrassment that they had been commemorating dead LTTE terrorists, genocide was to mourn LTTE dead and a genocide sans names of the dead/dead bodies or even skeletons. To cover up this, Canada is ranting about Mannar graves when the site is on the other end of where the conflict took place. Take a map and look at where Mannar and Mullaivaikkal is located, please. Canadian Parliament in 2022 declaring 18 May as Tamil Genocide Remembrance Day (the GoSL should request Canada to produce genocide figures, the names of dead at least) July 1983 statements by even the Canadian PM Trudeau display ignorance of facts. Ontario Bill 104 in 2023 – Tamil Genocide Education Week. Are these foreign envoys here to build bridges or to break existing bridges and kickstart new turmoils? If envoys are in Sri Lanka to help make peace, what they are presently doing is nowhere near this objective. An analysis of who they meet, what they discuss is testament to what they are really up to veil by their statements that ooze out peace, reconciliation and whatnot. It is a pity that the Sri Lanka Foreign Minister and Ministry are not keeping a tab on the diplomatic movements, interferences into internal affairs and the funding that is being channelled to lay grounds for new mischief. Nothing in the Geneva protocols covers the type of interference and incursions being committed with impunity by a handful of Western and Indian diplomats in Sri Lanka. It is a shame that the objectives and goals of diplomacy is being clouded by these actions and behaviours. (This article originally appeared on https://www.shenaliwaduge.com/canada-govt-redefining-reconciliation-in-sri-lanka-for-cheap-toronto-political-drama/) BY SHENALI WADUGE

title: 22,000 Census Officers deployed for field work
author: Author not found
Content: The Department of Census and Statistics will start listing buildings in the second phase of the census, in September 2023, with the participation of 22,000 officers deployed to carry out field work, the Superintendent of the 2024 Population and Housing Census said. Director General of the Department of Census and Statistics, P.M.P. Anura Kumara, who will act as the Superintendent of Census, said his Department will handle technical activities of the listing stage. “The responsibility for administrative activities will be lie with the district and divisional administrations including the District Secretary. Accordingly, field work in the listing stage is being carried out with the participation of about 22,000 officers of the Department of Census and Statistics as well as the district and divisional administrations,” he added. The Department of Census and Statistics plans to list all buildings and census units during the latter part of 2023, and to conduct the fifteenth Census of population and Housing in 2024. The Superintendent said the census is an extensive and complex process, and  planning starts several years before the census is conducted. The United Nations published guidelines, principles, and concepts for conducting the census in each decade. “The census will be planned by adapting those guidelines to our country’s needs. In the census, the information should be collected, so that no person is omitted or counted twice. To achieve that objective, the census is conducted in four phases: mapping stage, listing stage, enumeration stage, and data dissemination stage,” he added. Preparation of maps, the first stage of the census, has now been completed and the entire country has been divided into smaller areas (enumeration areas) called Census Blocks. Accordingly, about 88,000 census blocks have been identified and mapped. The Department has developed a geo-database comprising accurate boundaries at the Grama Niladhari division level. “For the first time in Sri Lanka, tablet computers are being utilised to collect data instead of printed questionnaires. That method is called Computer Assisted Personal Interviewing (CAPI- Computer Assisted Personal Interviewing). Further, additional information will be collected this time to the information collected in the listing phase of the previous censuses. That is, all  buildings will be numbered and their Global Positioning System (GPS) readings will also be obtained. Information on disaster situations faced is also collected,” it was said. The Information and Communication Technology Division of the Department of Census and Statistics has developed software and data systems required for the census. By Gagani Weerakoon

title: US Envoy calls on SLAF Commander
author: Author not found
Content: The Ambassador of United States of America to Sri Lanka Julie J Chung called on the Commander of the Air Force, Air Marshal Udeni Rajapaksa on 24 July at Air Force Headquarters. A cordial discussion was held between the Commander and visiting Ambassador on matters of bilateral importance. Mementoes were exchanged to mark the occasion. The occasion was attended by Defence Attache, Lieutenant Colonel Anthony C. Nelson and Chief in the Office of Defence Cooperation, Lieutenant Commander Sean Jin.

title: Cambodian PM to resign after four decades
author: Author not found
Content: Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen, one of the world’s longest-serving leaders, has announced he will resign and hand over to his son in early August. The anticipated announcement came three days after his party again won all seats at an uncompetitive election. Hun Sen, 70, has become increasingly authoritarian after nearly four decades of rule in Cambodia. He first flagged a transition in 2021, but up to now no one knew exactly when it would take place. His eldest son, Hun Manet, until recently the Commander of the Royal Cambodian Army, has long been groomed for the role. In his announcement, Hun Sen said his son would be appointed Prime Minister on 10 August. “I would like to ask for understanding from the people as I announce that I will not continue as Prime Minister,” he said in a special broadcast on State television. He said he would be stepping down as staying in office could cause instability. However, he will retain leadership of the ruling Cambodian People’s Party – a position political analysts say still gives him ultimate control. Earlier on Wednesday, State media showed Hun Sen visiting the Cambodian monarch’s palace to announce the news of the dynastic succession. Hun Manet, 45, took a leading role in campaigning for the 23 July election this year – and was often spotted leading rallies next to his father, who has ruled the Southeast Asian nation of 16 million people since 1985. Sunday’s election was widely seen as a done deal, because the only credible Opposition party had been disqualified from the vote. There were 17 other parties on the ballot but they were all too small, new or aligned with the CPP to be considered a real alternative for voters. The US and the EU both released statements condemning the vote as neither free nor fair. Hun Sen’s elimination of political opponents is part of his wider crackdown on civil space in Cambodia in recent years. Having consistently crushed his opponents, in 2017 he used the courts to dissolve another popular opposition party, the CNRP, and jail or exile its leaders. (BBC)

title: Sirisena returns after IPC
author: Author not found
Content: Former President Maithripala Sirisena who was appointed as current president of the International Peace Conference (IPC) returned to Sri Lanka on 25 July. Sirisena also participated as an international observer to oversee the Cambodian election. Speaking about the election, he praised it for being conducted impartially, without corruption or terror. Furthermore, he highlighted that approximately 80 per cent of the countries belonging to the United Nations are part of this new peace conference. On his arrival, a group of supporters from the SLFP women’s wing and a group of SLFP electoral organisers gathered at the airport to welcome him. T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: One more death in birthday party attack
author: Author not found
Content: Another person who was injured in the attack by a group of people on a birthday party in Thonikkal of Vavuniya died last morning (26) at the District General Hospital Vavuniya. The deceased was a 25-year-old man named S. Suganthan. Nine others are being treated at the Vavuniya General Hospital and two of them are still in critical condition. The mob that attacked the house where the birthday party was held has not been arrested yet. Police said the incident was due to personal animosity. CCTV footage shows that about eight people had engaged in the attack, but no one has been identified because those engaged in the attack had their faces covered. However, the Vavuniya Police are conducting investigations into the incident. BY Rasadi Chathurangi Gamage – Vavuniya

title: State service should steer clear of politics – Anura Kumara
author: Author not found
Content: Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) Leader MP Anura Kumara Dissanayake said recruitment to the State service and giving promotions and transfers on personal connections should be dispensed with forthwith. He said the State service should not be turned into another branch of politicians of the ruling Party or coalition and said under an administration helmed by the NPP the State service will be devoid of political interference. Dissanayake charged that the State service has been at the mercy of politicians since Independence and the time had come for the State service to move away from  political patronage and be turned into a genuine public service instead. BY Anurada Herath

title: Fulfill tax obligations
author: Author not found
Content: Governor of the Northern Province P.S.M. Charles emphasized the importance of taxes in improving State services and contributing to the country’s growth. She urged the people not to avoid paying taxes and instead consider them a crucial component in the nation’s development. Speaking at an event ‘Building a United Country’ held at Saraswathi Hall, on Tuesday (25) Governor Charles highlighted the need for people to understand the purpose of taxes and how they serve the interests of the country. She also said those who have emigrated from Jaffna and were living abroad are aware of the tax systems in those countries. By observing how taxes play a significant role in the income of those countries, people can better comprehend their importance. The Governor expressed concern about tax evasion and stressed that it is the responsibility of citizens to fulfill their tax obligations. She emphasized that, given the various needs of the country, paying taxes is crucial for its progress. Governor Charles also pointed out that only a small number of taxpayers contribute to the country’s economy, considering the total population. Additionally, the Governor touched upon the income tax collected by the Government, mentioning that the proportion of individuals who actually pay income tax is relatively small compared to the overall population of the country. This may imply that there is a significant tax gap or tax evasion issue in the country. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Kidney transplants grind to a halt
author: Author not found
Content: Due to the scarcity of vital drug Basiliximab, which is required for kidney transplants, all surgeries in this regard which had been scheduled to be carried out at the National Institute for Nephrology, Dialysis, and Transplantation (NINDT) had come to a standstill, Ceylon Today reliably learns. It is said that before carrying out a kidney transplant the aforementioned drug has to be administered without failure to the patient concerned and via it the kidney that is transplanted is prevented from being rejected instantly. However, informed sources revealed a bottle containing the said drug costs around Rs 300,000 and it has been confirmed that the drug is unavailable in all hospitals which undertake kidney transplants. It is also stated that it is unavailable in private hospitals as well. According to sources, an alternative drug that is administered known as Antithymocyte is also unavailable in State hospitals but it is available in a few private hospitals. Antithymocyte has been priced at Rs 65,000 per bottle and it is administered to patients based on their weight. Hence, to administer the drug to certain patients a sum of Rs 400,000 has to be incurred. As the drug concerned is in short supply at the NINDT, they had requested the Medical Supply Unit to make available 12 vaccines of the drug urgently. They further informed that failure to grant the vaccines would force them to suspend surgeries forthwith. By yesterday (25), 10 patients had been on the waiting list for surgeries at the NINDT and sources revealed only two surgeries are conducted per week. By Vineetha M. Gamage

title: SJB to attend APC convened by President – Sajith
author: Author not found
Content: The Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) has decided to attend the All-Party Conference (APC) convened by President Ranil Wickremesinghe today (26). Speaking at an event in Bibile, Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa said the party decided to show its commitment to the welfare of the nation. However, he emphasised that they would withdraw from the discussions if they feel that the conference is merely a political manoeuvre without genuine intentions for national betterment. He said although they have been informed about the All-Party Conference, the official agenda is yet to be communicated. He also urged the ruling party members to reach a consensus on all relevant matters before the proposed meeting to ensure its effectiveness and productivity. “The only reason we decided to attend this meeting is that we want to give the message that the welfare of our people is our priority. But if we feel that the meeting is taking the wrong track, we will immediately withdraw. These meetings should not be political gimmicks,” he said.  By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Young Lankan honoured with NZ bravery award
author: Author not found
Content: A Sri Lankan Kiwi from South Otago has become the youngest-ever winner of a Mountbatten medal, after the heroic rescue of his younger brother from heavy surf. On 27 August last year, the then 13-year-old Kalya Kandegoda Gamage was paddling on the Water’s Edge at Chrystalls Beach with his 11-year-old brother Kithmi. It was then that a large wave swept his younger brother off of his feet, and two more large waves pulled him into the water. Kithmi, who was a confident swimmer, tried to get back to shore but when he couldn’t, he continued to tread water. However, battling the 3-metre swells he was becoming tired as he was pulled further from shore. Kalya said it took several jumps to get into the bitterly cold surf, and while he was not scared on the way to his brother, who was now 60 m from shore, he was scared when he reached him, and the pair had to return. He was concerned that he and his brother might not make it back to shore, but was relieved when they did so, cold and tired. Kalya said he was happy the siblings did not die that day. Both were now more careful around the sea after their experience. The citation from the Royal Life Saving Society noted a comment from a local Police officer that “no one survives in that stretch of water, it is notoriously dangerous.” “Undoubtedly, Kalya’s brave response saved his brother’s life that day.” While long-term Kalya wanted to start a business or become an engineer, he also wanted to improve on the swimming skills and lifesaving training he undertook in his home country of Sri Lanka. Those life-saving skills meant Kalya qualified – and won – the 2022 Mountbatten Medal, which was awarded to just one member of the Commonwealth, each year. The now 14-year-old became the youngest person ever to win the bravery award. Kalya was presented with the medal at a special school assembly at the Milton-based Tokomairiro High School, with his principal Declan Sheridan telling Stuff that: “The school is very proud of Kalya’s achievements.” (www.stuff.co.nz)

title: Expert Committee to restructure SL Railways
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardana, yesterday (25), revealed that Cabinet has advised the Secretary to the President to take the necessary steps to appoint an expert committee. The purpose of this committee will be to obtain recommendations for a comprehensive restructure and improvement of the Sri Lanka Railways service, Gunawardana said. During the weekly Cabinet media briefing, Gunawardana, who is the Minister of Transport and Highways, said the decision to restructure Sri Lanka Railways comes as a response to various issues that have arisen in the administration, financial management, and monitoring activities of the department. He pointed out the importance of maintaining a high standard of service while minimising these challenges. The Sri Lanka Railway Department, which is responsible for both passenger and goods transportation and holds an A-grade government department status, requires a more efficient and effective structure. Having obtained the consent of all relevant stakeholders involved with the Department, Cabinet has given its approval to the proposal put forth by the Minister of Transport and Highways. The proposal aims to assemble a committee consisting of subject matter experts who will devise appropriate recommendations for the department’s restructuring, he said.  By Mithun Jayawardena

title: Gazette on MRP for eggs withdrawn
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Trade Nalin Fernando said that the Gazette Notification, issued earlier this year, stipulating a Maximum Retail Price (MRP) for eggs, would be withdrawn at midnight yesterday (25). Fernando made this remark following his announcement that the stock of eggs imported from India will be made available in the local market starting on the same day. Accordingly, these imported eggs will be sold at all Lanka Sathosa outlets at a retail price of Rs 35 each. Additionally, egg cartons will be priced at Rs 40 per egg. The decision to import eggs earlier in the year was taken to address the acute shortage and high price of eggs in the local market. BY Methmalie Dissanayake
