title: Dengue cases top 55,000 – NDCU
author: Author not found
Content: The National Dengue Control Unit (NDCU) said the total number of dengue cases had topped 55,000 by yesterday (25) since January 2023 with 36 deaths. According to data issued by the NDCU, the total number of dengue cases in the country amounted to 55,049 with 36 deaths by yesterday (25). Of the total cases, 27,315 (49.6 per cent) were from the Western Province. The number of cases in the Gampaha District alone amount to 11,929 while the cases in Colombo District amounts to 11,833, data issued by the NDCU’s DenSys Surveillance System showed. From 1 July 2023 to date, a total of 5,729 dengue cases have been recorded. The Surveillance System of the Unit also showed that there were 8.9 per cent of dengue cases in the Central Province, 8.8 per cent in the North Western Province, while the Sabaragamuwa and Eastern Provinces had 8.1 per cent and 10.3 per cent of the dengue cases, respectively. At present, the island had 52 high-risk Medical Officer of Health (MoH) areas.   By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Police powers to be discussed at APC – Wigneswaran
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe, who will attend the All-Party Conference today (26), will primarily discuss the devolution of Police powers to all nine provinces of Sri Lanka with the Party Leaders, former Northern Province Chief Minister, MP C.V. Wigneswaran said. On 24 July, MP Wigneswaran and Dr. K. Wigneswaran, an engineer by profession met the President after the former had submitted his proposals regarding provincial councils and power-sharing, which has become a significant topic of discussion concerning the Tamils of Sri Lanka. MP Wigneswaran emphasised that since the 13th Amendment is already in the Constitution, there is no need for a two-thirds parliamentary majority. He clarified that the merging of the North and East provinces will not take place nor be discussed. However, he pointed out that the absence of a provincial police commission has to be reinstated before discussing the sharing of police powers. “These matters are expected to be discussed during the meeting today,” he added. Speaking to Ceylon Today, MP Wigneswaran mentioned that land powers, which has already been discussed and included in the Constitution, will be implemented, and the current focus is solely on the devolution of police powers. The TNA has rejected the President’s call to support the 13th Amendment without police powers, leading them to refuse participation in the meeting before President Wickremesinghe’s visit to India. The President has accepted the submission of the draft proposal from MP Wigneswaran. Additionally, he has agreed to meet the members of the advisory committee presented by MP Wigneswaran. This committee includes Dr. Wigneswaran, an engineer and former member of the merged North and East Provincial Council; Dr. Nirmala Chandrahasan, who holds degrees in law from the University of Cambridge and a Ph.D. from the University of Colombo; Pathmanathan, a retired public servant; and K. Sellathurai, former Eastern Province Land Commissioner. MP Wigneswaran asserted that the TNA demands the full and meaningful implementation of power devolution, whereas he believes that any aspects to be implemented should be carried out to reinstate the provincial council and other matters of the 13A that is constitutionalised. He said the President has already expressed intentions to return the powers of the provinces that were taken back by the Central Government to the Provincial Councils. “We cannot delay any progress related to the 13A. We will continue to discuss and see how we can progress in full implementation of it,” he added. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Customs seizes ‘Magic Mushrooms’ worth over Rs 70M
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Customs made a significant seizure in Seeduwa, intercepting the largest-ever stock of ‘Magic Mushrooms’ valued at over Rs 70 million, along with various other illegal narcotics. The contraband had been smuggled through a parcel courier service from the USA and the Netherlands. Acting on intelligence, officials from the Customs Narcotics Control Unit detained nine parcels that had recently arrived from the USA and the Netherlands, intended for different local recipients. Suspicions were raised when they found that the parcels were addressed to fake locations in Colombo, Maharagama, and Piliyandala. As a result, the decision was made to open and inspect the packages. On examination, the officials found a haul of illegal substances within the nine parcels. The seizure included 4 kg of a Cannabis variant known as Kush, 300 g of ‘Magic Mushrooms’ (Psilocybin mushrooms containing psilocybin, a psychoactive compound), 2,000 tablets of Ecstasy (MDMA), and some intoxicating chocolates. Customs Spokesman, Senior Director Sudaththa Silva said the confiscated items were promptly handed over to the Police Narcotics Bureau (PNB) for further investigation. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: TUs protest opposite Fort Railway Station
author: Author not found
Content: A demonstration was staged yesterday (25) by several trade unions opposite the Colombo Fort Railway Station. As a result, the Galle Face entry road was blocked for traffic starting from the Lotus Street junction. Earlier in the day, the Colombo Fort Magistrate had issued an order to prevent several trade unions from entering specific areas and roads within Colombo Fort. Protesters were barred from accessing locations such as the Presidential Secretariat, Presidential Residence, Finance Ministry, Central Bank of Sri Lanka, Olcott Mawatha, York Street, Bank Street, Lotus Road, and Chatham Street, in addition to being prohibited from causing any damage to public property, in accordance with the Court’s order.

title: Young Lankan honoured with NZ bravery award
author: Author not found
Content: A Sri Lankan Kiwi from South Otago has become the youngest-ever winner of a Mountbatten medal, after the heroic rescue of his younger brother from heavy surf. On 27 August last year, the then 13-year-old Kalya Kandegoda Gamage was paddling on the Water’s Edge at Chrystalls Beach with his 11-year-old brother Kithmi. It was then that a large wave swept his younger brother off of his feet, and two more large waves pulled him into the water. Kithmi, who was a confident swimmer, tried to get back to shore but when he couldn’t, he continued to tread water. However, battling the 3-metre swells he was becoming tired as he was pulled further from shore. Kalya said it took several jumps to get into the bitterly cold surf, and while he was not scared on the way to his brother, who was now 60 m from shore, he was scared when he reached him, and the pair had to return. He was concerned that he and his brother might not make it back to shore, but was relieved when they did so, cold and tired. Kalya said he was happy the siblings did not die that day. Both were now more careful around the sea after their experience. The citation from the Royal Life Saving Society noted a comment from a local Police officer that “no one survives in that stretch of water, it is notoriously dangerous.” “Undoubtedly, Kalya’s brave response saved his brother’s life that day.” While long-term Kalya wanted to start a business or become an engineer, he also wanted to improve on the swimming skills and lifesaving training he undertook in his home country of Sri Lanka. Those life-saving skills meant Kalya qualified – and won – the 2022 Mountbatten Medal, which was awarded to just one member of the Commonwealth, each year. The now 14-year-old became the youngest person ever to win the bravery award. Kalya was presented with the medal at a special school assembly at the Milton-based Tokomairiro High School, with his principal Declan Sheridan telling Stuff that: “The school is very proud of Kalya’s achievements.” (www.stuff.co.nz)

title: Expert Committee to restructure SL Railways
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardana, yesterday (25), revealed that Cabinet has advised the Secretary to the President to take the necessary steps to appoint an expert committee. The purpose of this committee will be to obtain recommendations for a comprehensive restructure and improvement of the Sri Lanka Railways service, Gunawardana said. During the weekly Cabinet media briefing, Gunawardana, who is the Minister of Transport and Highways, said the decision to restructure Sri Lanka Railways comes as a response to various issues that have arisen in the administration, financial management, and monitoring activities of the department. He pointed out the importance of maintaining a high standard of service while minimising these challenges. The Sri Lanka Railway Department, which is responsible for both passenger and goods transportation and holds an A-grade government department status, requires a more efficient and effective structure. Having obtained the consent of all relevant stakeholders involved with the Department, Cabinet has given its approval to the proposal put forth by the Minister of Transport and Highways. The proposal aims to assemble a committee consisting of subject matter experts who will devise appropriate recommendations for the department’s restructuring, he said.  By Mithun Jayawardena

title: SL High Commissioner meets Malaysian Chief of Defence Forces
author: Author not found
Content: High Commissioner of Sri Lanka, Air Chief Marshal (Retd) Sumangala Dias met Malaysian Chief of Defence Forces, General Tan Sri Haji Affendi bin Buang on 20 July, at the Malaysian Armed Forces Headquarters in Kuala Lumpur. During the meeting, the High Commissioner recalled the previous interactions both had in several military forums in Malaysia and overseas. Further, the High Commissioner highlighted the importance of Defence Cooperation, particularly in the area of training with Malaysia. He also offered some training courses in Sri Lanka that could be considered by the Malaysian Defence Forces.  At the request of the High Commissioner, the Chief of Defence Forces of Malaysia agreed to accommodate the ‘Overseas Study Tour’ by Defence Services Staff College students of Sri Lanka to Malaysia in September 2023. Further, the Malaysian Chief of Defence Forces agreed to provide free accommodation for the placement offered to Sri Lankan officers at the Malaysian Defence Services Staff College. Presently only course fee is exempted for Sri Lankan participants.  The Malaysian Chief of Defence Forces and the Sri Lankan High Commissioner exchanged plaques at the end of the meeting.

title: China a true friend of SL – Defence Secy
author: Author not found
Content: “When baseless allegations were raised on the international platform, China remained a true friend, standing shoulder-to-shoulder with us, and providing us with the necessary understanding and backing,” Defence Secretary General (Retd) Kamal Gunaratne said. He was speaking at a ceremony to celebrate the 96th Anniversary of the founding of the People’s Liberation Army of China, on Monday (24 July). Recalling the long-standing friendship between the two countries, Gen. Gunaratne said, “Our countries have shared strong diplomatic ties and have cooperated in various fields, particularly in defence and security.” Both Sri Lanka and China value peace and stability in the region and the world at large. He said, the Armed Forces of both nations play a vital role in upholding this commitment, ensuring the safety of our people, and contributing to regional and global security. Ambassador of China Qi Zhenhong received the Chief Guest of the occasion, Defence Secretary Gen. Gunaratne and Chithrani Gunaratne on their arrival at the Shangri-La Hotel, Colombo on 24 July evening. “The PLA’s remarkable journey from its inception to its current form as a modern and formidable force is a testament to China’s determination to safeguard its sovereignty and promote regional stability,” he added. He expressed gratitude to China for its solidarity and assistance during the conflict. “Their unwavering commitment to our nation’s well-being played a pivotal role in our journey towards peace and stability,” he further said. Ministers, Parliamentarians, Chief of Defence Staff, Tri-Forces Commanders, Chief of National Intelligence, former Military Commanders, Military Liaison Officer of the MOD, Chinese Defence Attaché Senior Col. Zhou Bo, members of the diplomatic community and senior Tri-Forces Officers were also present at the occasion.

title: Rain forces draw in Centennial WI-IND Test
author: Author not found
Content: Rain had to final say on Day 5 of the second Test in Port of Spain, without a single ball being bowled, as the game ended in a draw with India sealing a 1-0 win in the two-match Test series against the West Indies. The hosts, who were 76/2 at Stumps on Day 4, needed 289 to level the series. But persistent rain, which started overnight and continued into Monday (July 24), brought a damp end to the centennial Test between West Indies and India. Rain did relent for a while, and there were even glimpses of blue sky, as play was slated to begin at 1:15 pm local time, but it didn’t due to another spell of showers. Another revised start of 1:40 pm also did not materialise as it started raining again, and eventually it was curtains on the day’s play and the Test. India are currently ranked No.2 in the 2023-25 cycle of the World Test Championship, with four points from this drawn game taking their tally of points to 16, which has brought down their percentage of points to 66.66. West Indies register their first points on the board courtesy the drawn Test. Recapping the Test, the visitors were asked to bat first on Day 1 and Rohit Sharma and Yashasvi Jaiswal gave India a good platform as they raised their second successive century partnership. Rohit struck 80 while Jaiswal, having scored a century on debut, followed it up with a knock of 57, striking at over 75. West Indies hit back with quick wickets, leaving India in a spot at 182/4. Then followed Kohli’s 29th Test ton in his 500th international appearance as his 159-run partnership with Ravindra Jadeja (61) revived India. R Ashwin also delivered with the bat, scoring 56 to help the team post 438. Kraigg Brathwaite’s 75 off 235 led West Indies’ cautious reply as the visitors batted for 108 overs across Day 2 and Day 3 to be 229/5. But Mohammed Siraj’s maiden Test fifer opened up an avenue for India on Day 4 despite plenty of rain as the hosts were bowled out for 255. India then raced to 181/2 decl. in 24 overs, with Rohit registering his fastest fifty, and third in a row, while Ishan Kishan, promoted to No.4, brought up his maiden Test half-century. India made inroads in the fourth innings as West Indies went into Stumps on Day 4 at 76/2, which was also the final score as relentless rain forced a draw. India won the opening Test in Dominica by an innings and 141 runs to get their WTC campaign going, with Jaiswal’s 171 and Ashwin’s 12-wicket haul being the headline acts. The series now moves into the ODI mode with the first two ODIs in Barbados on July 27 and 29, while the third ODI will be played in Trinidad on August 1. This will be followed by a five-match T20I series from August 3 to 13. Brief scores: India 438 (Virat Kohli 121, Rohit Sharma 80; Jomel Warrican 3-89) & 181/2 decl. (Rohit Sharma 57, Ishan Kishan 52*; Shannon Gabriel 1-33) drew with West Indies 255 (Kraigg Brathwaite 75; Mohammed Siraj 5-60) & 76/2 (Kraigg Brathwaite 28; R Ashwin 2-33).

title: President, BIMSTEC Secy-General discuss regional cooperation
author: Author not found
Content: During a recent meeting between BIMSTEC Secretary-General, Tenzin Lekphell and Sri Lankan President Ranil Wickremesinghe, the two leaders discussed the crucial need for ongoing cooperation among member states and emphasised the significance of further developing the public health sector within the region, the President’s Media Division said yesterday (25). The Secretary-General commended Sri Lanka for its unwavering commitment to public health and urged the country to take a leading role in this field within the BIMSTEC region. BIMSTEC, which stands for the Bay of Bengal Initiative for Multi-Sectoral Technical and Economic Cooperation, consists of seven South and Southeast Asian nations, namely Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Myanmar, Nepal, Sri Lanka, and Thailand. The alliance’s primary goal is to foster collaboration in technical and economic realms among the countries situated along the Bay of Bengal, bridging the regions of South Asia and Southeast Asia. According to the PMD, President Wickremesinghe highlighted the importance of holding regular Ministerial level meetings among BIMSTEC members to ensure the organisation’s success and promote effective collaboration among member nations. Such interactions and consultations are crucial in shaping collective strategies and addressing shared challenges for regional development and cooperation. The meeting also saw the participation of Dinouk Colombage, the President’s Director of International Affairs, further underscoring Sri Lanka’s commitment to regional cooperation and engagement within BIMSTEC.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Ornamental fish breeding centre unutilised
author: Author not found
Content: Residents in Vijayabapura are expressing concerns about the state of an ornamental fish breeding centre that was set up two years ago in the Ibbanwewa Reserve, located within the Dimbulagala Divisional Secretariat Division. The project, initiated in 2021, was meant to benefit the community by boosting the local economy and generating income for the Government. However, the centre remains unused and in a state of disarray as it has not been officially handed over to the public. Despite a substantial investment of Rs 8 million for the construction of the ornamental fish breeding project, along with additional cash assistance ranging from Rs 100,000 to Rs 60,000 provided by the Government, the tanks and buildings intended for the project’s use are now falling into disrepair. The residents assert that not a single ornamental fish has been bred or placed in the tanks. On inquiry, Dimbulagala Divisional Secretary P.T.M. Irfan explained that the project encountered difficulties due to the Covid-19 pandemic that emerged shortly after its launch in 2021.  Consequently, the cost of construction and production escalated beyond the initial estimation of Rs 8 million. To expedite the project, Irfan personally contributed Rs 250,000, which he is yet to be reimbursed for. He emphasised that accusations of mismanagement are unfounded and asserted that once the remaining funds are received, the project will be completed as planned. Moreover, authorities are investigating whether the individuals who received financial aid, ranging from Rs 100,000 to Rs 60,000, for building net gear and tanks have utilised the funds for the intended purposes. If any misappropriation is uncovered, appropriate action will be taken to rectify the situation, he said. By Nimal Jayaratne – Manampitiya

title: Army hands over vehicles for UN duties
author: Author not found
Content: A ceremony was held yesterday (25) at Army Headquarters to distribute vehicles for United Nations duties. The Sri Lanka Army handed over two armoured personnel carriers (APCs) and four Police Crowd Control Vehicles (PCCVs) to benefit Police Special Task Force officers who are to be deployed to the UN force. These vehicles were manufactured by the Sri Lanka Army. The event was attended by Army Commander, Lieutenant General Vikum Liyanage and IGP C.D. Wickramaratne. The Sri Lanka Army said the market value of the vehicles is approximately Rs 200 million, but the estimated production cost in Sri Lanka was Rs 55 million. Despite this, the Sri Lanka Army managed to produce each vehicle at an impressive cost of approximately Rs 16 million. This significant cost-saving achievement demonstrates the capability and efficiency of the Sri Lanka Army in local manufacturing. (Pix by Nuwan Amarawansha) By Sanjana Marzook

title: Nine-and-a-half hour water cut in Pugoda
author: Author not found
Content: The National Water Supply and Drainage Board (NWSDB) announced a scheduled water supply suspension for 9 hours and 30 minutes in Pugoda today (26). The affected areas include Pugoda, Kirindiwela, Ranpokunugama Housing Complex, Wathupitiwala, Maimbula, Maduwegedara, Urapola, and Attanagalla. The water cut will be in effect from 8:30 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. The NWSDB has attributed this water cut to essential maintenance work being carried out in Ranpokunugama and Kirindiwela to improve the water supply in the region. Residents in the above areas are advised to make necessary arrangements to manage their water usage during the stipulated period. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: War heroes should be treated equally – Namal
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) MP Namal Rajapaksa has called for the same relief given to a convicted LTTE member to be extended to the soldiers. Rajapaksa said this with reference to the Presidential pardon granted to the LTTE member, who had been sentenced to 200 years in prison for his involvement in the Central Bank bombing that resulted in the death of 91 individuals and left 200 others injured. Speaking to the media, Rajapaksa said he, too, had been in remand prison in the past alongside some LTTE cadres. He said there is no harm in releasing imprisoned LTTE cadres and suggested that the same consideration should be given to war heroes who have been convicted on various charges. Rajapaksa said at this point, he believes the President should pardon these individuals as well, to close this chapter in Sri Lanka’s history. (DW)

title: Suspect arrested by Anuradhapura Police
author: Author not found
Content: Anuradhapura Police, on 24 July, arrested a suspect, on charges of attempting to stab a provincial correspondent of a private television channel, Thamseer Hamid within the premises of Teaching Hospital Anuradhapura. Police said the suspect is a resident of Thirikkulama in Anuradhapura District and he had been arrested by a team deployed on the instructions of North Central Province DIG Laksiri Wijesena. A spokesman from the Anuradhapura Police said the suspect will be produced before the Anuradhapura Chief Magistrate after recording a statement. The correspondent had lodged a complaint with the DIG of the Province in this connection.    By Percy Kuruneru – Anuradhapura

title: Concern expressed over damage caused to historic Stupa
author: Author not found
Content: Ven. Dewagala Deva Lankara Thera, the former Secretary of the Batticaloa Sasanaarakshaka Balamandala and Chief Incumbent of the Kalkudah Sri Seelalankara Pirivena, has expressed concern over the damage caused to the largest Stupa (Dagaba) constructed during the Anuradhapura period. The Stupa, situated at Mawadiwembu Division in the Chenkalady Divisional Secretariat of Eravurpattu, in the Batticaloa District, has suffered significant harm at the hands of grave diggers and treasure hunters. According to Ven. Dewagala Deva Lankara Thera, the Stupa, believed to have been built during the second or third Century BC, holds immense historical importance. The Ampara Office of the Archaeological Department had recognised it as a monument with historical value around six years ago. However, the Ven. Thera revealed that treasure hunters had desecrated the Stupa, removing invaluable items in the process. It was alleged that the treasure hunters claimed the location belonged to a Kovil. The monk has urged the officers from the Department of Archaeology to conduct a thorough investigation into the incident.  He seeks accountability from the treasure hunters responsible for the damages caused to the Stupa and calls for its restoration to its former glory. Preserving and protecting such historical sites is essential to maintain Sri Lanka’s rich cultural heritage. BY Nimal Jayaratne – Manampitiya

title: AMCHAM Celebrates 30 years of Operations in Sri Lanka
author: Author not found
Content: The scintillating and glamorous annual AmCham SL Ball made a grand comeback after a five-year hiatus, to celebrate the 30th Anniversary of AmCham Sri Lanka and the 75th Anniversary of USA/Sri Lanka bilateral relations. The AmCham Ball 2023, powered by Citi, was held recently at the Hilton Grand Ballroom and was a night of elegance and camaraderie that was undoubtedly a highlight of the Colombo Social Calendar. The event was attended by top corporates, and members of the diplomatic community as well as numerous social, civil and media personalities. Guest of Honour Julie J. Chung, Ambassador of the United States in Sri Lanka spoke at the occasion and stated, “This year marks the 30th year of AmCham’s operations in Sri Lanka and with just one look around this room you can see how successful the organisation has become …  (and) as we commemorate the 75th Anniversary of bilateral relations between the United States and Sri Lanka, and the 30th Anniversary of the AmCham, we should take pride in the positive impact that we have had on Sri Lanka, the economy, and its people.” Complimenting what Guest of Honour Julie J. Chung shared, Lakshan Madurasinghe, President of AmCham SL also stated that AmCham SL is not just an association; it is a dynamic forum that fosters trade, investment, and business relations between Sri Lanka and the United States. “As one of the most influential and prestigious international business chambers in the island, we are committed to providing our over 400 member companies – that we celebrate and recognise this evening, with a multi-dimensional resource network that equips you with the information, network, market access, tools, and knowledge needed to succeed in bilateral business endeavours,” he said. One of the highlights of the night which went hand in hand with the words of Ambassador Julie J. Chung was the felicitation of AmCham SL’s past presidents where presidents over the span of the last 30 years were recognised and appreciated for their impact and service both in person as well as posthumously. The elegant sit-down dinner was also followed by a silent auction to raise money for the AmCham SL Gives Back programme. The AmCham SL gives back programme is the CSR arm of AmCham SL which conducts annual community outreach activities. Last year supported by AmCham signature events such as yuletide greetings, AmCham SL and its members donated over Rs 6 million through various community outreach programmes. This night of refined elegance charmed guests with a mesmerising blend of curated culinary delights, engaging entertainment, and camaraderie of shared history. Entertainment powerhouses Natasha Ratnayake, Voiceprint, Redeemers, Flame and the highlight of the night, a guest spot by Bathiya and Santhush saw guests rocking the dance floor until the wee hours. The evening was made possible by the generous support of Title Sponsor Citi Bank and other sponsors namely South Beach Weligama, Sysco Labs, Haycarb, Kerry Logistics and LOLC Holdings among others. The American Chamber of Commerce in Sri Lanka (AmCham SL), is one of the most influential and prestigious business chambers in the island, recognised as the leading forum for the facilitation and development of trade, investment and business relations between Sri Lanka and the United States. AmCham SL is an Association whose stakeholders are its near 400 members, made up of top blue-chip organisations in the island and provides its members a multi-dimensional resource network that delivers information, tools and knowledge they need to succeed in bilateral business relations between the two Nations through information share, LQAs, Seminars, Workshops, B2G and B2B networking and exclusive connect & advisory services.

title: Court calls for Govt Analyst’s reports
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya, yesterday (25), noticed the Government Analyst to produce reports pertaining to four items, which had been sent to the Government Analyst’s Department, after being seized by the Police, to determine the cause of death of the late Director of Janashakthi Insurance PLC, Dinesh Schaffter. The Court issued this notice to the Government Analyst after considering a request made by the CID, with the latter stating that the reports connected to the items were necessary, for them to expedite their probe into the mysterious death of the businessman. The remains of Schaffter, which were exhumed based on a Court order, lie at the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital. Meanwhile, a five-member team of medical specialists and experts, appointed by the Court, to determine the cause of the demise of the businessman, is slated to submit their report shortly.  Schaffter’s death is yet to be deemed as a natural death or a suicide, while the CID continues to investigate the incident further. Thereafter, the Court deferred further proceedings of the case, to 8 August. By Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: SLAF assists to douse fire in Ella
author: Author not found
Content: In response to a request from the Disaster Management Centre in Colombo, the Sri Lanka Air Force swiftly deployed a Bell 212 helicopter to conduct Bambi Bucket Operations at the site where a sudden fire outbreak occurred on 23 July in Ella, Badulla District. A total of seven Bambi Bucket Operations were successfully executed by the SLAF to douse the fire. Additionally, the SLAF mobilised fire engines and skilled firefighters to provide crucial ground support for this operation.

title: 175 SLTB buses returned to service
author: Author not found
Content: A total of 175 buses owned by the Sri Lanka Transport Board (SLTB) have been successfully repaired and added to the service, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said yesterday (25). These buses had previously been taken out of service due to a shortage of spare parts resulting from the country’s import restrictions. Transport Minister Bandula Gunawardana presented the necessary documents and details of the project to President Ranil Wickremesinghe. This project was initiated at the depot level and funded through a Treasury allocation. The main objective of this project was to refurbish a total of 400 out of 852 buses that had been non-operational for over three years. As a result, 175 buses have been successfully restored to operational status at a total cost of nearly Rs 300 million. The PMD said 15 of the refurbished buses will be allocated to the ‘Sisu Seriya’ programme. The remaining buses will be allocated to respective depots to meet passenger transportation needs islandwide. The event to mark the restoration of these buses was attended by SLTB Chairman S.M.D.L.K. de Alwis, SLTB Chief Executive Officer Mahesh Kulathilaka, SLTB Deputy General Manager Panduka Swarnahansa, and SLTB Chief Mechanical Engineer Lakshman Pushpakumara.

title: Appellate Court refuses to extend Interim Order
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal, yesterday (25), decided not to grant a further extension to the Interim Order that had previously prevented the imposition of the newly-introduced Advance Personal Income Tax (APIT) on judges’ salaries. The unanimous decision was reached by a five-Judge Bench led by President of the Court of Appeal, Justice Nissanka Bandula Karunaratne. The Bench unanimously agreed to hear three petitions filed by the Sri Lanka Judicial Service Association, High Court Judges’ Association, and Labour Court Presidents’ Association. These petitions seek the dismissal of the decision to deduct the APIT Tax from the salaries of judges. The Court of Appeal has ordered the concerned parties to issue notices to the respondents mentioned in those petitions. Additionally, the Court has set a deadline for filing any objections related to the case, which should be done before 31 August. The next hearing for the petitions is scheduled for 22 September.

title: SC reserves JUDGEMENT on Royal Park convict’s pardon
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court yesterday (24) concluded its hearings and reserved judgement on the Fundamental Rights Petition, challenging the decision of former President Maithripala Sirisena, to grant a Presidential Pardon to Don Shramantha Jude Anthony Jayamaha, who was convicted in the Royal Park murder case. The three-Judge-bench comprising Justices S. Thurairaja, Yasantha Kodagoda, and Janak de Silva, heard the arguments presented by both, the petitioner and Respondent parties. Written submissions from the parties are to be filed by 25 August. The Fundamental Rights Petition was filed by the Women & Media Collective organization, contesting the legality of the Presidential pardon granted to Don Shramantha Jude Anthony Jayamaha by former President Sirisena. The respondents named in the Petition include the Attorney General, Don Shramantha Jude Anthony Jayamaha, Commissioner General of Prisons, Controller General of Immigration and Emigration, Inspector General of Police, Justice Minister and President of the Bar Association of Sri Lanka. In addition to challenging the Presidential pardon, the petitioners also seek guidelines to govern the granting of such pardons by the Head of State, as per Article 34(1) of the Constitution. Don Shramantha Jude Anthony Jayamaha was indicted by the Attorney General in the High Court with the murder of Yvonne Jonsson, who was 19 years old at the time, on or about 1 July 2005, under Sections 294 and 296 of the Penal Code. During the proceedings, President’s Counsel Sanjeeva Jayawardena, along with Counsel Rukshan Senadheera, represented the petitioner. President’s Counsel Faizer Mustapha appeared on behalf of former President Maithripala Sirisena, while President’s Counsel Saliya Peiris represented the Bar Association of Sri Lanka. Additional Solicitor General Nerin Pulle appeared for the Attorney General. The Supreme Court will announce its judgment on the matter at a later date.

title: Court orders exhuming of Crudia Zeylanica tree
author: Author not found
Content: The Gampaha Additional Magistrate yesterday (24) ordered exhuming of the buried root of the Crudia Zeylanica tree, which had been uprooted to make way for the construction of the Central Expressway, leading to a contentious situation. The order was issued by Gampaha Additional Magistrate Fathima Zahana, who also scheduled a recall of the case on 24 August. Ven. Udasgiriya Samitha Thera, the Chairman of the Organisation to Protect Archaeological Artefacts, had approached the Gampaha Magistrate’s Court with a request to exhume the uprooted endemic tree, believed to have been buried. Following the Thera’s request, the Additional Magistrate has instructed the forest officers to proceed with the exhumation of the tree’s root. The exhumed root will then be sent to an appropriate location for conservation, subject to identification by an official from the botanical gardens. Previously, on last Saturday (21), the Additional Magistrate had ordered immediate security measures to be implemented around the area where the tree was reportedly buried. Additionally, a statement was called for to ascertain the precise location where the tree had been interred.

title: SL lagging behind other S Asian nations
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka is lagging behind other South Asian countries, in bouncing back to pre-Covid standards of the child vaccination programme, data released by UNICEF and WHO show. According to data, only Sri Lanka and Nepal are yet to bounce back to pre-Covid vaccination standards while Pakistan is the highest to reach that level with 93 per cent achievement. UNICEF, in a press release, said immunisation services in South Asia reached 1.96 million more children in 2022 compared to the previous year, as countries stepped up efforts to address the historic backsliding in immunisation caused by the Covid-19 pandemic and save children’s lives.  According to data published yesterday by UNICEF and the World Health Organisation (WHO), in 2022, the coverage of the third dose of the Diphtheria, Pertussis and Tetanus vaccine (DTP3) increased by six percentage points, from 85 per cent in 2021 to 91 per cent in South Asia. The DTP vaccine is used as the global marker for immunisation coverage.  “South Asia’s progress to catch up with life-saving vaccinations is tremendous news for the children in the region who now have a better chance of being protected against deadly diseases such as measles, tetanus and more,” said UNICEF Deputy Regional Director for South Asia, Noala Skinner. “We owe this progress to the leadership of countries, the investment of donors and partners, tenacity of millions of vaccinaters and the commitment of parents to get their children vaccinated despite several challenges during and after the Covid-19 pandemic waves.” Among the eight South Asian countries, Bangladesh, Bhutan, Pakistan, India and the Maldives have fully recovered to their pre Covid-19 coverage levels. Sri Lanka and Nepal have made significant strides towards achieving complete recovery but are yet to fully catch-up.  Though progress has been made in Afghanistan, more efforts are needed to reach over 400,000 missing children with vaccination services. All countries, except Afghanistan and Pakistan, achieved vaccine coverage of above 90 per cent for DTP3, which is considered very high.  According to the data, in 2022, India, Sri Lanka, and Nepal had the highest percentage reductions in the number of children who weren’t vaccinated at all, with a decrease of 58 per cent, 50 per cent and 38 per cent respectively. In India, the number of children without any vaccines decreased from 2.7 million in 2021 to 1.13 million in 2022.  The percentage of children vaccinated with the new pneumococcal conjugate vaccines, which protect children against pneumonia, jumped 28 percentage points from 44 in 2021 to 72 per cent in 2022.  Vaccination for the first vaccine dose against measles – one of the most contagious vaccine preventable diseases – increased from 87 per cent in 2021 to 92 per cent in 2022. This was higher than the two percentage point increase globally.  As a result, an additional 1.94 million children were vaccinated against the deadly disease in South Asia in 2022.  However, the regional coverage for the first dose of measles vaccine is still lower than the target of 95 per cent needed to prevent measles outbreaks. According to the WHO surveillance data, in 2022 alone, there were 54,959 measles cases in South Asia, nearly triple the reported cases in 2021.

title: Bandula warns railway TUs
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Transport and Highways Bandula Gunawardene said if railway trade union reps were to resort to unfair strike action, inconveniencing commuters, he will be compelled to inform the Cabinet and take stringent action against such trade unions. He said certain railway trade unions had opted to go on a lightning strike when he had requested them to sort out their unresolved issues without harassing innocent commuters. Gunawardena added that if railway trade unions have issues to be sorted out then they should submit their concerns initially to the General Manager Railways after which they could forward them to the Secretary of the Ministry. He stressed that if either of the two aforementioned parties fail to resolve such issues then they could submit them to him as the subject Minister rather than opting to impede scores of train commuters. By Mithun Jayawardena

title: Govt to unveil new tourist plan
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe announced that the Government will be unveiling a new tourist plan called ‘Visit Sri Lanka’. It will be released in the coming months. He claimed the proposal is in the final stages of development and would be made public as soon as it is complete, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said. According to the President, culinary art in Sri Lanka will be given a priority in this plan. President Wickremesinghe made this statement while attending the Award Ceremony and a Gala dinner of the ‘Bocuse d’Or 2023’ competition held at the Waters Edge Grand Ballroom in the evening of 23 July, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said. The government aims to bring in five million tourists of whom 2.5 million will be high-end visitors, President Wickremesinghe said while emphasising that the industry is a significant economic driver. According to Indian estimates, Sri Lanka can host up to 10 million tourists, of whom most will be tourists from Asian and the Indian Ocean region, he continued. Transformation of the tourism industry is required to make Sri Lanka competitive in the global travel market place and the government has recognised the potential in promoting the country as a tropical nation with a diverse culinary style. Hence, attention will be given to develop culinary tourism in the country, the President said. The government is prepared to launch a Culinary School in collaboration with the private sector, the travel industry and the hotel industry, the President added, noting that there is a need to train more personnel in the hospitality field, particularly in culinary tourism. Attention will also be paid to aid private Culinary Schools in accomplishing this task, he added. The President expressed admiration for the late Merrill J. Fernando, a prominent business figure and founder of Sri Lanka’s renowned ‘Dilmah Tea’ brand. He praised Fernando’s valuable contributions to the country’s tourism industry, the PMD said.

title: Two-thirds majority, Referendum needed to reconvene LG bodies
author: Author not found
Content: The Attorney General yesterday (24) provided a statement to the Supreme Court, asserting that in order to reconvene the Local Government (LG) institutions, as proposed in MP Jayantha Ketagoda’s Private Member’s Bill, a two-thirds majority in Parliament and a Referendum would be required. The Attorney General further emphasised that certain clauses included in the private member’s Bill, which aims to amend the Municipal Ordinances on urban councils and municipal councils, are in violation of the Constitution. These matters were presented before the Supreme Court by the Additional Solicitor General, representing the Attorney General’s office, during the Court session on the 27 petitions that were filed. These petitions seek a declaration that the provisions contained in the relevant Bill are unconstitutional.

title: President presents SL’s ambitious development plans to Chinese delegate
author: Author not found
Content: Yuan Jiajun, a member of the CPC Central Committee Political Bureau and Secretary of the CPC Chongqing Municipal Committee, paid a courtesy call on President Ranil Wickremesinghe, on 22 July, at the Presidential Secretariat, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said. During the meeting, President Wickremesinghe presented Sri Lanka’s ambitious development plans, with a primary focus on enhancing connectivity with the rest of Asia. Emphasising the importance of regional cooperation, the President outlined how these plans would foster economic growth and facilitate increased trade and investment opportunities. Moreover, President Wickremesinghe briefed the Chinese delegation on the commendable progress being made in the country’s debt restructuring efforts. He expressed his confidence that upon successful completion of the restructure, several halted development projects would resume promptly, further bolstering the nation’s economic development. The Chinese delegation appreciated the President’s steadfast efforts to stabilise Sri Lanka’s economy amid challenging circumstances. They expressed optimism and confidence in the country’s future economic growth trajectory.

title: PHU to submit 22nd Amendment
author: Author not found
Content: Pivithuru Hela Urumaya (PHU) Leader MP Udaya Gammanpila said his Party will submit the 22nd Amendment to the Constitution to Parliament in order to remove ‘Police powers’ introduced by the 13th Amendment. He made these remarks while attending a press conference held at the PHU Headquarters yesterday (24). In order to win the next Presidential Election, the President has negotiated with the Tamil National Alliance (TNA) with regard to the full implementation of the 13th Amendment to the Constitution, Gammanpila alleged. “Recently, there was a meeting between the President and the Tamil parties. During that the President has agreed to implement the 13th Amendment to the Constitution sans Police powers. We learned that the Police powers too would be given gradually, later,” he claimed. To discuss and reach an agreement with regard to this, the President has called for all-party conference on Wednesday (26). We should remind everyone that the national security is placed in a danger in this backdrop. We should keep in our minds that whenever Ranil Wickremesinghe comes to the power, the national security is always in a danger, Gammanpila charged.  By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: President to Chair APC on Reconciliation
author: Author not found
Content: An All-Party Conference (APC, chaired by President Ranil Wickremesinghe, is set to take place at the Presidential Secretariat tomorrow (26), to inform leaders of Parties represented in Parliament about the National Reconciliation Programme, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said. According to the PMD, invitations have been extended to leaders of all Political Parties and Independent Groups with representation in Parliament. However, Ceylon Today reliably learns that both the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) and the Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) might boycott the meeting. It is reported that, several matters including enacting 13th Amendment to the Constitution would be taken for discussion.

title: Three-year-old girl sets Int’l record
author: Author not found
Content: A remarkable three-year-old girl from Kotagala, Hatton has achieved an extraordinary feat by setting an international record. She was able to identify the names of 40 world leaders from their photos in just 66 seconds. On 6 April, the young girl, named Senthil Kumar Bhavishana, made her appearance on the internet to set a world record in the International Book of Records, an international records book based in India. According to her father, Senthil Kumar, the talented girl looked at photos of various world leaders on a computer screen and accurately named each of them within one minute and six seconds. Her impressive achievement earned her a certificate and medal from the International Book of Records. Senthil Kumar further shared that he is a resident of Drayton Estate in Kotagala and works at the Kotagala post office, while his wife is a teacher. He expressed immense pride that this record was set by their eldest daughter. In recognition of this remarkable accomplishment by the three-year-old girl from Kotagala, members of the Kotagala traders’ association, including Vishwanath Pushpa, the president of the association, visited her house to pay tribute to her talent and achievement. BY Neeta Pathmakumari– Norwood

title: Fire breaks out at Hakgala Strict Nature Reserve
author: Author not found
Content: A fire broke out in the Hakgala Strict Nature Reserve in Nuwara Eliya, on Sunday (23), destroying an area of approximately 15 acres, The Hakgala Wildlife Range Office said. The officials suspect that the fire, which originated in the Hulankapolla of the Hakgala Strict Nature Reserve, was caused by the collapse of a high-voltage power line running through the reserve. Hakgala Strict Nature Reserve is one of the three highly protected forests in Sri Lanka. Located in the wet zone, it serves as a crucial ecological zone, hosting many unique species of animals and plants native to the country. The fire spread rapidly due to the dry and strong windy weather conditions in the Hulankapolla. The officers of Hakgala Wildlife Range Office and the employees of the Hakgala Botanical Garden collaborated to control and fully extinguish the fire by the evening of the same day. BY Chandrasiri Mahagama – NuwaraEliya

title: Hunters set forests ablaze
author: Author not found
Content: Farmers and environmentalists allege that several organised groups of animal hunters have been causing significant damage to the environment by setting fire to large areas of forests, including Divulapathana, Maha Oya and the surrounding forests of the Maduru Oya National Park in Polonnaruwa. On 23 July numerous forests were set ablaze, resulting in the complete destruction of nearly 50 acres of reserve land in the area, accoirding to farmers. Due to these fires, animals such as deer and rabbits, frequently visit the paddy fields in search of safety, as hunters continue to set fire to reserves and bushes. The hunters, coming from outlying regions, engage in destructive practices both during the day and at night. They set fire to reserves and forests, then use guns to shoot deer, and other wild animals. Subsequently, they take the meat of these animals to the hotels located in the outskirts of the area. Upon inquiry, officials from the Maduru Oya National Park’s Park Warden’s office confirmed that special operations have been initiated to apprehend these hunters. It has become common practice for various hunters to set fire to the bushes and hunt animals, particularly during the dry weather season in the vMaduru Oya National Park. BY Nimal Jayarathne – Manampitiya

title: Navy arrest 16 for illegal fishing
author: Author not found
Content: Special operations conducted by the Navy off Kadaikadu and Veththalakerni in Jaffna on 21 and 22 July , led to the arrest of 16 persons who were engaging in illegal fishing activities. During these operations, the Navy also held 11 dinghies and unauthorised fishing gear used for these illegal acts. The arrests were made by the Naval Detachments of Chundikulam, Chalei, Mamunai, Veththalakerni and Nagar Kovil belonging to the Naval Deployment Veththalakerni in the Northern Naval Command. The persons held in these operations were identified as residents of Mulliyan and Chilaw, aged from 24 to 47.

title: Viral disease hits tomato crops
author: Author not found
Content: Farmers in the Matale District are currently facing a significant risk of crop destruction, due to a viral disease that has struck tomato cultivation. Some of the symptoms of this viral disease affecting tomato plants include the growth of dry leaves and a reduction in flowers. One of the affected farmers, S. A. Ratnapala, a resident of Pattiwila in Galewela revealed that his entire eight acres of tomato cultivation have been severely impacted by this viral disease. Ratnapala also mentioned that using insecticides and fungicides has not been effective in combating the viral disease. Despite following the advice of agriculture officials and using various fungicides to control the disease, all attempts have failed. Another farmer named Suranga, from the Thattankotua, also reported that his tomato plantation has been affected by the same viral disease. Many farmers in the Matale District are facing significant challenges due to this virus attacking their tomato crops. As a result of the widespread infection, the prices of tomatoes in the market have surged to between Rs 300 and 400 per kilo. BY Thilak Pallegedera – Galewela
