title: Empty wallets, NICs found on roof of Municipal building
author: Author not found
Content: Dozens of empty wallets, a stack of national identity cards and several passports were discovered on the roof of a municipal building in Oroppuwatte, Galle. The find was made by municipal employees while they were removing a tree that had grown inside an abandoned water tank on the roof of the building. The employees promptly handed over the items to the Police. Upon investigation, the Police revealed that the thieves had been stealing wallets from the city, including from buses and houses. After taking the valuables, the thieves would discard the empty wallets on the roof of the municipality building. As of now, the Police are in the process of identifying the owners of the recovered identity cards and passports. Steps are being taken to inform and return the stolen belongings to their rightful owners. BY Farhan Nizamdeen – Galle and S. Diyagahage – Ahangama

title: Richmond College Galle Celebrates its 209th Anniversary
author: Author not found
Content: The Methodist missionaries, who set foot on the then known shores of  Ceylon, had done yeomen service to the education sector of our country during British colonial rule. According to the old records and chronicles of the mission, Richmond College is the oldest school, founded by the Wesleyan missionaries in Ceylon, as far back as 25 July 1814.  The signature book of ‘Forgotten History of Richmond College’ by the late Ananda Dias Jayasingha, after meticulous research, traced the history of Richmond College to 1814. Traditionally, the College celebrates its anniversaries on the 1 May each year since 1876.  However, it was established that the College was upgraded into a high school only on this particular day in 1876. This claim was endorsed by ProfessorK. D. Paranawithana, Professor G.V.P. Somarathna, Professor Michael Roberts and also the old Richmondite Professor P.V.J. Jayasekera. Therefore, Richmond College, Galle was officially founded on 25 July 1814.  This acclaimed book ‘Forgotten History of Richmond College’ written by the late Ananda Jayasingha has been endowed with the State literary award, the Southern Province Governor’s award, and the library authorisation of the Department of Education. Even the British High Commissioner in Colombo, in a special congratulatory message, on the occasion of the 208th anniversary, acknowledged the fact that Richmond College is the oldest Methodist School in Sri Lanka and has been in existence since 1814. According to the findings of this research, one of the pioneer members of the Wesleyan Mission, Rev Benjamin Cloff, who sailed the seas, first opened a school by the name of ‘Galle School’ in a mansion in Galle Fort called ‘Doornberg’ which belonged to the Dutch era. This school commissioned by the Wesleyan mission on 25 July 1814 was the forerunner to the present-day Richmond College. The evolution of the College to what it is today is a great piece of history that is worth delving into. Today, this monumental school, fashioned by British architecture, is majestically nestled on a beautiful hillock. Richmond College has so far produced two heads of State, namely Dr. Wijayananda Dahanayake, former premier, and Mahinda Rajapaksa, the Executive President of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka from 2005 to 2015. Richmond’s connection to the political echelons of the country has been deep-rooted. Even incumbent President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s paternal grandfather, the late C.L Wickremesinghe was a prominent Richmondite. He was the first Ceylonese Civil Servant towards the tail-end of the British regime and ascended to become a Government Agent and Commissioner of Lands in his illustrious career. A number of President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s family members attended Richmond College and the Scout Troop House, Lecture Theatre, and kindergarten of Richmond were the magnanimous contributions of his family lineage.  Besides, the founder of space law, Dr. Jasenthuliyana is a living legend produced by Richmond. In line with Richmond’s historic heritage, a thanks-giving service is scheduled to be conducted at the Methodist Church in the precinct of the College. This year, it will be conducted by the retired Methodist Bishop and old Richmondite Ven. Asiri Perera at1.00 p.m. on 25 July 2023.  As this church was declared an archeologically protected site through a Gazette Notification issued by the government, it signifies the historic value that the State has attached to it. The organisers extend an open invitation to all past Richmondites to participate in this epoch-making occasion. By Lasitha Mendis and Nalaka Jayasena

title: Bosevana lends a hand to the needy
author: Author not found
Content: Low-income families in Hakuruwela, Kotawaya, received dry ration packs at the Bosevana Buddhist Centre in Kotawaya recently. The Bosevana Buddhist Centre has provided assistance to hospitals, temples and various other organisations. This programme was launched under the patronage of the founder of Upeksha Buddhist Foundation and Upeksha Bosevana of Hakuruwela in Kotawaya, Angunukolapelessa Ven. Kotawaye Khemarama Thera with the support from philanthropists in Singapore. Ven Khemarama Thera said that a programme has been launched to repair the houses of low-income families in the area too.

title: SL Day in Ankara opens up multifaceted possibilities for mutual economic cooperation
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Embassy in Türkiye organised a ‘Sri Lanka Day’ event in Ankara together with the Türkiye – Sri Lanka Business Council on 20 June 2023. It was held at the Official Residence of the Ambassador to present opportunities for collaborations in trade, investment and tourism in Sri Lanka among the potential Turkish business community. The event was organised in three segments, namely: ‘Trade with Sri Lanka’, ‘Investing in Sri Lanka’ and ‘Sri Lanka Tourism’. Delivering the welcome address, Ambassador of Sri Lanka to Türkiye Hasanthi Urugodawatte Dissanayake stated that 2023 is a special year for the two countries; celebrating the 100th anniversary of founding of the Turkish Republic, Sri Lanka celebrating its 75th anniversary of independence as well as the two countries celebrating 75 years of diplomatic relations. She underscored that the activities commemorating these cornerstones contribute in promoting bilateral relations between Sri Lanka and Türkiye. The Ambassador also gave a brief introduction to Sri Lanka and highlighted the similarities in trade for over two millennia between Türkiye and Sri Lanka, with Türkiye being an important part of ancient trade routes connecting east and west over the land and while Sri Lanka was part of the sea trade route. She further noted that both countries have rich cultural influences due to being strategic locations on trade routes for a very long time. Therefore, it is no surprise that in 1864 the Ottoman Empire appointed a Honorary Consul in Sri Lanka. In his opening speech, Chairman of the Türkiye-Sri Lanka Business Council Mehmet Ali Uğur briefly explained about the activities of the Türkiye – Sri Lanka Business Council which started in 2014 and its contributions to the improvement of bilateral commercial relations between the two countries. He highlighted that Sri Lanka’s potential is not yet known adequately in Türkiye and thus the aim of the Business Council is to improve relations between the two countries with more awareness on opportunities that exist in the two countries, paving the way for enhancing economic cooperation of mutual benefit. He highlighted that Turkish business people should take a note of Sri Lanka’s strategic location and focus more on Sri Lanka and the region. The Head of Department of Asia and Pacific Countries, General Directorate of International Agreements and EU at the Ministry of Trade of Türkiye Çağatay Özden attended the event as the guest of honour. Özden emphasised how the bilateral relations and interactions have developed since the opening of the Embassies in Ankara and in Colombo and stated that there is a great potential to further strengthen trade relations. Minister (Commercial) at the Sri Lanka Embassy in Türkiye Thavishya Mullegamgoda delivered a presentation on Sri Lanka and the Sri Lankan product basket for export such as apparel, tea, spices, spa & herbal products, coconut & coir-based products, gems, food & beverages, fisheries products etc. The presentation also detailed potential collaborations for investments in tourism, agriculture production and energy sector among others. During an experience sharing session in doing business with Sri Lanka, General Manager of BETA Gıda Sanayive Ticaret A.Ş. in Türkiye Mehmet Ali Uğur shared his company’s successful experience dating back to the 1980’s. He praised the quality of Ceylon tea, tourism industry, and stressed the importance of the Colombo Port City project. He added that considering Sri Lanka’s close proximity to modern day Sea Lines of Communications (SLOCs), Colombo being one of the busiest ports in Asia, as well as the various trade agreements that Sri Lanka has with many countries, particularly in the South and South East Asia, a Turkish investor can have access to a much larger market than the 22 million market share in Sri Lanka. He added that he visions that Sri Lanka would be a thriving financial hub between Singapore and Dubai very soon. Advisory Board Member of Penthol Group of Companies based in Istanbul Aydin Ozu, Türkiye spoke of his experience in the energy sector, stating that Sri Lanka could be considered as a suitable country for investments in energy projects especially in the renewable energy sector. Chairman of Uluer Group of Companies in Türkiye and the General Manager of Sri Lanka Balloon Company Mahmut Sami Uluer, who is also Honorary Consul for Sri Lanka in Nevşehir, spoke of tourism in Sri Lanka. His company started a hot air balloon operation in Sri Lanka in 2016 and he highlighted the benefits of investing in Sri Lanka which included good air connectivity to the world and easy visa process. The Sri Lanka Day event was attended by business chambers, organisations, associations, potential Turkish importers, distributors, manufacturers, exporters, investors, travel companies, hotel chains etc. not only based in Ankara but also from other regions in Türkiye. Some of the Honorary. Consuls for Sri Lanka in Türkiye were also among distinguished guests. In her closing state,ment, First Secretary Priya Nagarajah thanked all participants who joined the event and everyone who contributed to make the event a success. During networking sessions, participants were served Sri Lankan cuisine and Sri Lankan tea.

title: Sri Lanka deeply appreciates French development assistance
author: Author not found
Content: “Sri Lanka deeply cherishes its long-standing ties of friendship and cooperation with France and  in recent times, we have seen a heightened level of engagement between Sri Lanka and France in political, economic and maritime realms,” said Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva. He made these statements at a ceremony held on 13 July 2023 to mark the French National Day, in Colombo.  Historical connections between Sri Lanka and France that date  back to the 17th century were  strengthened and consolidated with the establishment of formal diplomatic relations on 27 October 1948. This year, holds significance to both countries as they celebrate the 75th Anniversary of Sri Lanka – France diplomatic relations. “At present,  both our governments share an abiding commitment to transform this cooperation into a multifaceted partnership. Therefore, I take this opportunity to convey Sri Lanka’s deep appreciation to the French Government for playing a pivotal supporting role in our way forward for economic stabilisation, recovery and growth, and particularly in securing the Extended Fund Facility (EFF) from the IMF in its capacity as the Chair of the Paris Club,” the Minister said. He also emphasised that bilateral trade and investment between the two countries had much potential for expansion. France was the 10th export destination for Sri Lanka in 2022, with total exports recorded at USD 257 M. France is one of Sri Lanka’s  important tourism source markets and is also  the second largest provider of grant assistance to Sri Lanka that has become a major partner in Sri Lanka’s  development process. “I firmly believe that our economic relations will continue to strengthen in the years ahead and I hope more French companies would consider setting up their businesses in Sri Lanka to tap into the vast South Asian market and beyond. “Sri Lanka deeply appreciates French development assistance, received mainly through the AFD (Agence Française de Development) which supports infrastructure development, energy, water and sanitation projects, blue economy, disaster management and entrepreneurship in the country,” the Minister said. Speaking further, the Minister said:“Our bilateral maritime cooperation has continued to flourish over the recent years. The proposed establishment of a Regional Maritime Safety and Security School in Sri Lanka, France’s confirmed participation in the Galle Dialogue to be convened later this year are evidence of the current robust partnership that we share in the maritime sector. As France is a member country of the IORA (Indian Ocean Rim Association for Regional Cooperation), Sri Lanka wishes to engage more closely with France during Sri Lanka’s chairmanship of IORA from 2023 to 2025. I take this opportunity to reaffirm Sri Lanka’s commitment to build further on the friendship and cooperation between our two countries. I am confident that together with the efforts of Ambassador Jean Francois Pactet and his staff, we would succeed in strengthening our excellent bilateral relations and taking it to the next step forward.” French influence in Sri Lanka is reflected in art, music, architecture, literature, cinema, radio broadcasting and particularly in education.  The French missionaries’ contribution to the education system of Sri Lanka especially in the establishment of several leading Catholic schools in the country is noteworthy. The French language is sought after in High School and University curricular here, as well.  The Alliance Francaise which continuous its vibrant presence in Sri Lanka with branches in Kandy, Galle, Matara and Jaffna has for several decades contributed to the enhancement of the French culture in the country particularly with the younger generation. An additional dimension of Sri Lanka’s bilateral relations with France is the overseas community of Sri Lankan heritage now residing in France. This community while contributing productively to the French economy has been a strong element in strengthening people to people interactions. The number of students studying in French Universities also continue to rise. To mark the commemoration of  the 75th anniversary of Sri Lanka – France diplomatic relations in a fitting manner, a commemorative stamp along with the convening of inaugural bilateral political consultations will also be issued jointly.  A series of cultural engagements will also be held  to celebrate the abiding friendship between the  two nations.

title: Crime on the Rise
author: Author not found
Content: The number of grave crimes reported in the past two years has been rising, a Performance Report of the Police for 2022, presented to Parliament recently, showed. In this connection Police data showed that the number of grave crimes reported last year (2022) was 37,152, up 4.91 per cent (1,740) over the 35,412 reported in the previous year 2021. Further, the number of grave crimes reported in 2020 was a mere 31,098. Therefore, it may be seen, that grave crimes, 2021 over 2020 had increased by 13.87 per cent (4,314). Meanwhile, the top six grave crimes reported last year in descending order were burglary (8,645), possession of dangerous drugs/narcotics (8,268), theft of property worth more than Rs 50,000 (5,404), robbery (3,065), fraud, criminal breach of trust and criminal misuse worth more than Rs 500,000 (2,339) and rape (1,986). The number of burglaries reported in 2021 was 6,840, an increase of 26.39 per cent (1,805) in the following year 2022, year on year over 2021.  The number of burglaries reported in 2020 was 6,499, an increase of 5.25 per cent (341), 2021 over 2020. In related news, the number of drug cases reported in 2021 was 10,959, a decline of 24.56 per cent (2,691), 2022 over 2021.  The number of drug cases reported in 2020 was 6,811, an increase of 60.90 per cent (4,148), 2021 over 2020. In like developments, the number of thefts reported in 2021 was 4,801, an increase of 12.56 per cent (603), 2022 over 2021 and the number of thefts reported in 2020 was 4,073, up 17.87 per cent (728), 2021 over 2020. The number of robberies reported in 2021 was 2,277, an increase of 34.60 per cent (788), last year (2022) over 2021. Meanwhile, the number of robberies reported in 2020 was 2,148, an increase of 6.01 per cent (129), 2021 over 2020. In similar developments, the number of the above fraud and related GCs reported in 2021 was 2,207, up 5.98 per cent (132), 2022 over 2021. And the number of fraud and related GCs reported in 2020 was 2,891, a decline of 33.86 per cent (684), 2021 over 2020. The number of rape cases reported in 2021 was 1,977, an increase of 0.46 per cent (9), 2022 over 2021 and the number of rape cases reported in 2020 was 1,953, an increase of 1.23 per cent (24), 2021 over 2020. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Padayatra marks 200 years of Indian-origin Tamils in SL
author: Author not found
Content: The ‘Malaiyaha Ezhuchchi Payanam’ padayatra is all set to begin its journey from Talaimannar, commemorating 200 years since upcountry Tamils of Indian origin arrived in Sri Lanka. The event will start on 28 July 2023, commencing from Talaimannar and culminating in Matale on 12 August 2023, passing through Nalanda along the way. This Padayatra carries profound meaning as it pays homage to the historical ties between India and Sri Lanka, celebrating the rich cultural heritage and invaluable contributions of the upcountry Tamil community over the past two centuries within the country. The journey and events from Talaimannar to Matale are meticulously organised by the ‘Collective for ‘Maanbumigu Malaiyaha Makkal’, a collaboration comprising the National Christian Council of Sri Lanka and a diverse group of Civil Society Organisations and Individuals closely associated with the Malaiyaha community. Reverends S. Devadasan, M. Saminathan, along with Daniel Jesudasan and J. Suresh are the organisers of this event. The purpose of this Padayatra is to retrace the arduous journey of the initial groups of men and women who were brought to Sri Lanka to work in the plantations of the hill country. More than two centuries ago, thousands of South Indians arrived in Talaimannar and courageously embarked on foot to Matale, facing diseases, jungle clearance and encounters with wild animals. Tragically, a significant number, up to 40 per cent in some cases, perished along the way and were either buried or disposed of during this perilous trek. The organisers extend an invitation to all to join in this remarkable journey, a pilgrimage to reflect upon and connect with the first generation who undertook this challenging expedition 200 years ago. Beyond honoring the past, the ‘Malaiyaha Ezhuchchi Payanam’ also represents hope for the future, encapsulating the demand of the Malaiyaha Tamil community to be recognised as free and equal citizens of Sri Lanka. Since their arrival two centuries ago, the community has faced numerous struggles, continually appealing to successive Sri Lankan Governments for recognition and equal treatment as a distinct and integral people of Sri Lanka, on par with other main communities. This underscores the community’s unwavering pursuit of identity as a constituent people of independent Sri Lanka, deserving equal rights and recognition. The core objective of this Padayatra is to foster a deeper understanding among various communities, including Sinhalese, Sri Lankan Tamils, Muslims, and other fellow citizens, about the history, struggles, achievements, contributions, current socio-economic and political status, as well as the aspirations of the MalaiyahaTamil community. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Families of missing persons to stage hartal
author: Author not found
Content: The families of those who disappeared, in the North and East, have issued a call for a hartal on 28 July, across the Northern and Eastern regions, demanding for justice over the recently discovered ‘mass grave’ at Kokkuthoduvai in Kilinochchi, Northern Province. During yesterday’s (24) press conference, held at the Jaffna Press Club, the families of the disappeared took the decision to call for the hartal. The planned hartal includes a rally that will commence from Vattuwagal Bridge ending at the Mullaitivu District Secretariat. Organisers have also taken the necessary steps to ensure transportation arrangements for those participating in the rally. In a bid to garner broad support for their cause, the organisers have reached out to various segments of society, including civil society groups, traders, farmers, fishermen, university students, and political parties, urging them to extend their backing to the hartal. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: MRP for fuel soon
author: Author not found
Content: With the arrival of the first fuel shipment from China’s Sinopec Company in early August and agreements with two other international companies being signed to bring fuel to the country, the Ministry of Power and Energy will only set a Maximum Retail Price (MRP) in the future, giving room for these companies to decide fuel prices on their own, State Minister of Power and Energy D.V. Chanaka revealed yesterday (23). Addressing a media briefing at the President’s Media Centre (PMC), Chanaka said, “Until now, the fuel price formula existed only for Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC). Instead, steps will be taken to set a maximum retail price using the price formula, to be applicable to all companies through this new system. Thus, the Ministry will decide on the maximum retail price in the future. These companies will then be able to provide fuel at a price of their choice subject to the maximum price. This will create competition among fuel companies resulting in reduced fuel prices.” Also, discussions will be initiated with relevant parties to decide whether to increase the existing fuel quota to each vehicle category or completely abolish the QR Code system, he said. “Previously, there were no arrangements to maintain buffer reserves. So far, steps have been taken to maintain a reserve of 30,000 litres of fuel including petrol and diesel. We are in charge of additional USD 60 million in addition to the money needed for daily expenses. After studying the existing methods in the world, a new method was introduced in this country. Accordingly, we no longer pay any advance. Fuel tankers coming to Sri Lanka should be fully stocked in our warehouses. After that, the necessary purchases for the week are made with the dollars available in the CPC. There are several advantages here. Risk fees were completely eliminated. This new system has the potential to save USD 300 million per year,” the State Minister said. “We only paid late fees previously. But as of now for the first time, we have earned 13 million dollars in late fees from fuel companies in just the first half of this year. The first instalment of USD 3 million is being collected before 18 August. The remaining USD 10 million will be recovered from the suppliers”, he added. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Education Minister meets Australian delegate
author: Author not found
Content: Education Minister Susil Premajayantha recently held a meeting with Australia’s Shadow Minister for Multicultural Affairs, Community Safety and Migrant Services, Jason Wood, at the Office of the Leader of the House of Parliament.  They held an extensive discussion on increasing the Australian higher education opportunities offered to Sri Lanka, and Minister Premajayantha commented on the ongoing transformative education reform process in Sri Lanka.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: CSE – CEA workshopto strengthen EIA process
author: Author not found
Content: The Central Environmental Authority (CEA) and the Centre for Science and Environment (CSE), New Delhi, India conducted a workshop cum training programme to strengthen the Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) process in Sri Lanka.  The first workshop was conducted in Colombo from 17 – 18 July 2023 at the CEA Auditorium. The second was held in Kandy from 20 to 21 July 2023. According to the CEA and CSE, a though there were Laws under the National Environmental Act, implementing these laws was a challenge.   To implement the EIA for prescribed development projects, data collection, impact assessment study, the preparation of the EIA report, and implementation of the Environmental Management Plan (EMP) to facilitate compliance monitoring have to be executed in full spirit. When implementing, the EIA process the responsibility lies with stakeholders, the CEA, and the project proponent. There is also a need to improve the quality of the EIA report since decisions are made on recommendation of the EIA report.  Keeping this in mind, the CEA and the CSE conducted a workshop cum capacity building programme to enhance the knowledge of environmental regulators to ensure better implementation of EIA in Sri Lanka.  The two-day training programme showed regulators on how environmental impacts are identified and how to review EIA reports and preparation of EMP explaining some case studies from India were included in the programme.  In addition, there was a special lecture on the accreditation scheme for EIA consultants by Nivit Kumar Yadav, Director, CSE, India which is not practised in Sri Lanka. “Sri Lanka has strong environmental laws to implement the EIA process. However, there are some gaps which need to be addressed to achieve the standards of the best international practices.  Accordingly, proper data systems, good quality EIA reports, development of proper review systems, to evaluate EIA reports, enhancing the involvement of civil society, and compliance of approved projects through well-prepared EMPs were essential. Sri Lanka needs to improve transparency when it comes to environmental compliance which will push industries to take extra measures to comply with statutory norms” said Nivit Kumar Yadav. Supun S. Pathirage, Chairman, CEA, and P B Hemantha Jayasinghe, Director General, CEA expressed their  gratitude  to  the  CSE  in  holding  such  a  workshop  and pointed out the benefits of environment conservation work in Sri Lanka through strengthening the EIA process. The workshop was inaugurated with the participation of Supun S. Pathirage, Chairman, CEA, and P B Hemantha Jayasinghe, Director General, CEA, and the workshop was conducted by representing the Indian team, Nivit Kumar Yadav, Director of CSE and Dr. D D Basu, Advisor of CSE and Rajivu Aundhe, Director of AESPL [Aditya Environmental Services (Pvt) Ltd.] and Nilmini Attanayake, director of EIA unit of CEA participated in the workshop.

title: Litro, Laugfs to sell gas at same price – Trade Minister
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Trade Nalin Fernando said steps are being taken to implement a price formula to regulate the price of LP gas sold by both Laugfs and Litro Gas Lanka. He emphasised that there is a notable difference in the price of LP gas between the two companies, with Laugfs being relatively higher than Litro. After engaging in discussions with Laugfs officials, the LP gas supplier has committed to reaching an agreement regarding a price revision within the upcoming week. As part of the plan, a price formula will be introduced for the gas company to ensure transparency and fairness in pricing, the Minister said. Additionally, Fernando assured that all necessary measures will be taken to release imported egg stocks to the local market within the next few weeks, ensuring a stable and sufficient supply. Meanwhile, State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya, announced plans to increase the existing tax on imported coconut oil to safeguard the interests of local coconut oil manufacturers. This move aims to support and promote local production while also balancing the market dynamics for coconut oil, Siyambalapitiya added. (MD)

title: Indian Uni in Sri Lanka mulled
author: Author not found
Content: During the President’s visit to India, collaboration between Indian and Sri Lankan universities was bolstered, with the possibility of investing in establishing a prominent Indian university within Sri Lanka borders was discussed, Minister of Foreign Affairs Ali Sabry said. Speaking to the media on 22 July at the President’s Media Centre (PMC), Ali Sabry said President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s desire is to make the most of the development opportunities in the Indian Ocean region, which is the world’s largest emerging economic region. “Today, no country can advance by itself and every developed country in the world has made progress through regional partnerships, the Minister said, adding that the President’s programme is to fulfill the development expectations of Sri Lanka by developing Indo-Sri Lankan relations in a manner that benefits both parties and does not threaten them,” he said. Emphasising that the President nor the Government will do anything that threatens the country, the Minister said it was the Government’s aim to implement these activities with the full understanding and agreement of all parties. “We firmly believe that fostering a robust and enduring relationship with our close and long-standing partner, India, holds significant advantage for both Sri Lanka and the entire region. Acknowledging the prevailing consensus that approximately 2/3 of the world’s total growth will unfold in the Asia Pacific region over the next few decades, it is widely recognised that India and China will play pivotal roles in leading this growth. In the light of these realities, President Wickramasinghe said the need to capitalise on the vast development opportunities presented by the Indian Ocean region was immense. Drawing parallels with successful models in the European Union, Middle Eastern countries, China, and the North American region, we are determined to harness similar development dynamics.” The Minister said both President Wickremesinghe and Indian Premier Narendra Modi recognised the strategic importance of connecting ports to ensure Sri Lanka could leverage economic growth in Tamil Nadu, Andhra, and Telangana. Scholars are actively engaged in discussions to devise a framework to set up these port connections, leading to a consensus among leaders to present it to Parliament for a decision. Anticipating that renewable energy could meet 70 per cent of our country’s national electricity needs by 2030, we are keen to explore the market potential for exporting surplus energy. Deliberations on creating a conducive environment for the export of solar and wind power were extensive, culminating in a memorandum of understanding to facilitate collaborative efforts. Furthermore, opportunities for cooperation in green hydrogen and green ammonia through innovative technologies were explored, he said. Speaking further, Ali Sabry said, “In recognition of the significance of technical knowledge for the advancement of our agricultural sector, a memorandum of understanding was signed to acquire expertise in various fields, including animal husbandry and dairy production. Appreciating India’s substantial progress in digitisation, we sought technical assistance to accelerate our own digitisation efforts in Sri Lanka. Turning our attention to the plantation Tamil community of Indian origin residing in Sri Lanka for the past two centuries, India has expressed its commitment to implementing several programmes aimed at their progress, with a notable investment of INR 750 million. The prospect of establishing a university in the Nuwara Eliya area was also a subject of discussion, paving the way for future agreements.” The Minister said attention was paid to concerns of the fishing community, with a focus on gradually halting bottom trawlers in the North and seeking opportunities for Sri Lankan fishermen to operate beyond the Indian border. Constructive dialogue between the two parties remains the cornerstone for resolving these issues, he added. Both sides unanimously agreed on the imperative of maintaining the entire Indian Ocean region as a safe zone, acting collectively with the utmost commitment to safeguard mutual security, he further added.

title: Imported eggs at Rs 35 soon
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Trade Nalin Fernando announced yesterday (23) that imported eggs will soon be available for purchase at Rs 35 in all Lanka Sathosa outlets. The preparations to implement the plan are in progress and expected to be launched within the coming week. Minister Fernando said steps were being taken to ensure a steady supply of 100,000 eggs per day to meet the market demand. Sri Lanka decided to import eggs earlier in the year due to a significant shortage and the consequent surge in local egg prices.

title: A’pura Sacred Site development plan to be expedited
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe instructed officials to expedite the Anuradhapura Sacred Site Development Plan, giving priority to the Maha Viharaya Development Plan, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said. The President also said a Committee comprising experts from the National Physical Planning Department (NPPD), the Department of Archaeology and Universities will be appointed to implement the Maha Viharaya Development Plan. President Wickremesinghe said so while joining a discussion held on 22 July at the Bomalu Viharaya, Anuradhapura on the Maha Viharaya Development Plan and Anuradhapura Sacred Site Development Plan. The discussion was held under the Chairmanship of the Atamasthanadhipathi and Sanghanayaka of Nuwara Kalaviya most Venerable Pallegama Hemarathana Nayaka Thera. The President said it was regrettable thatalthough we are entitled to a proud civilisation and history, we  were not paying enough attention to this legacy while other countries continue to emphasise their historical civilisation. “A new law pertaining to Anuradhapura should be prepared to preserve the city’s historical legacy. Additionally, a Committee is anticipated to be set up to carry out this activity with officials. Despite the existence of Departments and Corporations, this work is not overseen by a single administrative officer. We should focus on that as well. If we start this project now, we can achieve some progress in the next 10 years, but it will take at least 25 years to complete it. When these operations begin, Sri Lanka will develop into an archaeological hub,” the President pointed out. The President questioned officials about the identification of the MahaViharaya complex boundaries and the status of excavation work. He also inquired about the number of archaeological officers employed in the excavation and the development of the Sacred Site, the composition, and the allocated provisions. The President stressed the need to implement the Development Plan by addressing flaws and that on-going efforts were left to be desired.

title: Court orders security be provided to site
author: Author not found
Content: The Gampaha Additional Magistrate ordered that security be provided to the area where the contentious Crudiazeylanica tree was uprooted and buried during the construction of the Central Expressway. Additionally, the Magistrate has mandated that a statement disclosing the precise location of the buried tree must be submitted to Court by today (24). Previously, the Gampaha Divisional Forest Office had submitted a ‘B’ Report to Court, confirming the uprooting and removal of the indigenous tree in question. Subsequently, on Friday (21), officials from the Gampaha Divisional Forest Office reappeared in Court, as mentioned in a motion filed with the Court. Cabinet Spokesman Minister Bandula Gunawardena has clarified that the decision to remove the Crudiazeylanica tree, situated in Daraluwa, Gampaha, was a policy choice taken by the government. He emphasised that he had specifically requested the removal in his capacity as the Minister of Transport. BY Tony K. Athukorala – Minuwangoda

title: School term schedule announced
author: Author not found
Content: The Education Ministry has released the schedule for the school holidays and school dates for the second and third terms of 2023. School holidays for the first phase of the second school term will be from 18 August to 27 August. The second phase of the second school term will commence on 28 August (Monday) and conclude on 27 October (Friday). Notably, the Grade Five scholarship examination is scheduled for 15 October (Sunday). Following this, the first phase of the third school term will begin on 30 October and extend until 24 November. Lastly, school holidays for the first phase of the third school term will be observed from 25 November until 31 December.

title: Sri Lanka Federation of University Women launch website
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Federation of University Women launched its website on Thursday, 10 July 2023, at its Headquarters in Colombo. In her welcome address, the SLFUW President, Colonel Dr. Udula Krishnaratne extended a warm welcome to the Chief Guest, Dr. Ramya Chamali Jirasinghe, and thanked her for gracing the occasion. She expressed her appreciation to those present  for their participation in the event. Dr. Jirasinghe is  the  Country Coordinator for Kindernothilfe Lanka and a former Deputy Director of the Fulbright Commission  Sri Lanka and also an award winning poet. Dr. Krishnaratne mentioned that it is interesting to note that, while the Fulbright Commission helped develop education  by providing Sri Lankans with opportunities for postgraduate studies in America, it was an American lady, Mrs. Clara Motwani, with a Masters Degree in Education, who helped develop school education in Sri Lanka,  and  also set up the SLFUW in 1941. Thus the SLFUW is 82 years but the years have only made it stronger, with a large and influential membership, both here/in Sri Lanka and abroad.

title: Kattankudy Educational Zone issues resolved – Thondaman
author: Author not found
Content: Eastern Province Governor Senthil Thondaman, on 22 July, announced the successful resolution of the issues prevailing in Kattankudy Educational Zone. Thondaman met former Governor, M.L.A.M. Hizbullah, at the Governor’s Secretariat in Trincomalee to address various issues prevalent in the province and find sustainable solutions. During their discussions, both governors focused on matters concerning the development of the Batticaloa District, particularly in terms of educational advancement. One of the topics brought up by the Governor was the appointment of M.M. Halawudeen, a Grade I member of the Sri Lanka Principal Service (SLPS), who was temporarily appointed as the Divisional Educational Officer of the Kattankudy Educational Zone until a qualified individual could be appointed. In a short period, A.G. Mohammed, a Grade III member of the Sri Lanka Educational Administrative Service (SLEAS) was appointed to the same post, and Halawudeen was transferred to a school situated nearly 58 km away from Kattankudy. Considering Halawudeen’s health condition, Hizbullah requested the Governor to explore the possibility of transferring him to a nearby school. Governor Thondaman responded positively to Hizbullah’s request and advised the Eastern Province Education Secretary to make the necessary arrangements for Halawudeen’s transfer to a nearby school as soon as possible. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Unstable salt price worries Kinniya producers
author: Author not found
Content: Salt manufacturers in Kinniya are voicing their concerns over the lack of a stable price for salt, leading to a decline in the number of people involved in production and leaving them in a helpless situation. They highlight that the price of a hammer of salt, which was previously sold at Rs 2,000-2,500 two to three years ago, has now plummeted to Rs 500-600, with no proper facilities for selling their produce after production. Covering an expansive area of nearly 100 acres within the Kinniya Divisional Secretariat, salt production sustains around 300 families in the region. However, salt manufacturers are facing a significant challenge during the rainy season, as fresh water mixes with salt, affecting the quality of the product. Despite the vital role these salt baths play in contributing to the economic development of the country, the relevant authorities have not taken the necessary steps to improve and develop the facilities, leaving the salt producers in dismay, they alleged. The declining prices and lack of support pose a serious threat to the livelihoods of those involved in salt production in Kinniya, the salt producers stressed. They called for attention and assistance from the authorities to address these pressing issues and ensure the sustainability of this traditional industry that has been a lifeline for their families and community. By W.M. Wickramasinghe – Kantale

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Small plantation owners halt raw tea leaf production
author: Author not found
Content: Small tea plantation owners in Hatton and Ratnapura claimed that presently they are facing significant challenges that have forced many of them to halt raw tea leaf production. According to them, last season, they were paid Rs 235 per kg for raw tea leaves. Unfortunately, the situation has worsened, and this month, they are receiving only Rs 110 per kg. This sharp decline in payment is attributed to several factors, including the decrease in the value of the dollar and the unrelenting costs of fertilisers, vitamins, and medicines used for tea trees. Despite the reduction in payments from merchants who buy the raw tea leaves, the expenses including labour allowances amount to approximately Rs 150 per kg, leaving them unable to cover the losses incurred by selling tea leaves at Rs 110 per kg, they alleged. Another critical issue raised by small tea plantation owners is the importation of ready-made tea from countries like India and Malaysia, which is then exported under the name of ‘Ceylon’ by large-scale businessmen. This practice has had a detrimental impact on the local tea industry, leading to further challenges for small tea estate owners. Moreover, the industry is grappling with the problem of large-scale smuggling, resulting in the production of waste tea that is processed using chemicals. This illicit activity is said to be prevalent in areas like Ambalangoda and Welamboda, exacerbating the crisis faced by small tea plantation owners, the tea plantation owners alleged. By Channa Addarage – Hatton

title: India pledges Rs 3B for betterment of IOT Community
author: Author not found
Content: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi agreed to grant three billion rupees for the betterment of Indian Origin Tamil (IOT) Community in Sri Lanka, Minister of Water Supply and Estate Infrastructure Development Jeevan Thondaman said. Addressing the media, after his return from India, Minister Thondaman stated that the said grant will be utilised for the transformation of the education and health sector in upcountry. Thondaman further said, “I was a part of the delegation to India, headed by President Ranil Wickremesinghe. In the bilateral meeting with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, implementation of the 13th Amendment to the Constitution, MoUs on energy and economic development, and development of Indian Origin Tamil Community in Sri Lanka were discussed. I also highlighted that providing infrastructure facilities alone will not empower the upcountry but providing quality education will provide sustainable transformation,” he added. “Hence the Government of India guaranteed to provide Rs 3,000 million and this will be utilised for the health and education sector in the upcountry.We have planned to host a State event to honour the IOTs who arrived to Sri Lanka 200 years ago who have greatly contributed to our economy. Special envoys will be participating representing India,” he said.

title: Chongqing Govt to help poverty alleviation and rice production in SL
author: Author not found
Content: A high level delegation from Chongqing CPC Municipal Committee Secretary Dr Yuan Jiajun, who is also a member of Communist Party of China (CPC) Central Committee Politbureau called on Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena at the Temple Trees on 22 July. The Prime Minister requested the delegation to share Chongqing’s experience of successfully alleviating poverty and ensuring food security by using hybrid rice and other food crops to increase production by several times. Dr Yuan Jiajun assured that China would extend fullest cooperation by encouraging large scale investments in industrial and agricultural spheres. He also agreed to provide experts on hybrid rice varieties and other food crops to Sri Lanka. “You have vast flat lands all over the country suitable for rice and other crops and we will extend assistance to increase harvest by several folds,” he said. The Prime Minister thanked China for the support given for agriculture, industry, education and other fields. Noting that Dr Yuan Jiajung is a top rocket scientist, the Prime Minister said the two countries could also cooperate in space science as Southern Sri Lanka has been identified as an area with lowest gravity in the world and the southern ocean is most suitable for landing of spacecraft. The Prime Minister said Sri Lanka looks forward to China’s support in restructuring its debt at the moment and further strengthening its economy in the near future. Ministers Nimal Siripala de Silva, Susil Premajayantha, Ali Sabry, Nalin Fernando, Ministers of State Anupa pasqual, Diana Gamage and Mohan Priyadarshana De Silva and MP Yadamini Gunawardena took part in the discussion. Ambassador of China Qi Zhenhong, Vice Minister Guo Yezhou, Vice Mayor of Chongqing Municipal Government Chen Mingbo, Secretary Luo Lin, CPC Director General of International Department Peng Xiubin and Chongqing Deputy Secretary General Guan Zhongxiao were present at the roundtable discussiona.

title: One killed, three children among nine injured in arson attack
author: Author not found
Content: In a tragic turn of events, a 21-year-old woman lost her life while nine others, including three children, sustained injuries when a group of unidentified men set fire to a house in Vavuniya, while a birthday party was in progress early yesterday (23). The injured have been admitted to the Vavuniya Hospital. Upon receiving an emergency call on the 119 hotline, the Vavuniya Police launched an immediate investigation into the incident. Responding swiftly, the Police, along with the Vavuniya Municipal Council Fire Department and local residents managed to extinguish the fire that had engulfed the house. Among the injured were a 2-year-old boy, two girls aged 7 and 13, four women between the ages of 19 and 41, and two men aged 36 and 42. (MD)

title: Mother, baby go missing in Hanguranketha
author: Author not found
Content: Police have received reports of another young woman and her daughter going missing in Hanguranketha. The 20-year-old mother and her 20-month-old daughter had boarded an SLTB bus and arrived at Rikillagaskada town in Hanguranketha last Thursday (20), which was the day they went missing. In response to the situation, Police interviewed the bus driver and conductor, both of whom confirmed that the two individuals were on the bus. Hanguranketha Police launched a full-scale investigation into the matter following a complaint by the missing woman’s mother.

title: Govt will set country right
author: Author not found
Content: Chief of Presidential Staff and Senior Adviser to the President on National Security Sagala Ratnayake said the Government is not going to play any politics but will set the country right. Many individuals like to see the country collapse as they will not have any political opportunities if it succeeds, he pointed out. “We are focused. We are not going to play any politics. We want to set the country right. We want to deliver. People in this country deserve it. The youth need a future. We can’t have all of them going overseas,” he added. “The youth employed abroad could contribute to the economy of the nation, but it cannot be the Government’s policy,” he said. To secure a future for the youth within the country, he stressed the need for a robust manufacturing industry, bolstered by education, a thriving tourism sector, and support for Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs). Ratnayake was speaking at an event organised by the Young Professionals Organization (YPO) in Colombo recently. Further, he highlighted that since welfare benefits are paid with tax money, the Government will ensure that they are given to those who truly deserve them. The Government only needs to implement the growth agenda and reforms properly while making sure to ward off evil for the country to have a better future, he added. Addressing misinformation surrounding the DDO programme, Ratnayake said some evil people claimed that the banks will collapse with the DDO (domestic debt optimisation), the Government was planning to seize all of the deposits, and the EPF capital would be taken over, but nothing of the sort happened; no bank collapsed, in fact, the banks have become stronger and the EPF is still available in totality. He further said the interest rate would not fall below the level that the EPF fund had been receiving up to now and that the Government would step in to ensure that the specified percentage was delivered if it did and this was the purpose of the DDO.

title: Tamils cannot be deceived – Rasamanickam
author: Author not found
Content: Illankai Tamil Arasu Kachchi (ITAK) Batticaloa District MP Shanakiyan Rasamanickam yesterday (23) claimed that the Tamil people cannot be deceived by superficial treats and are not willing to accept them. He said if President Ranil Wickremesinghe treats every community in Sri Lanka equally, he can resolve the pressing issues faced by the Tamil community, including their political rights and aspirations. While addressing a public event in Batticaloa, Rasamanickam stated that the political and fundamental rights issues of the Tamil people have been neglected and unresolved for several decades, casting doubt on the commitment of political leaders in the South to address these problems. Rasamanickam also lamented that despite efforts made over the years, finding a sustainable solution to the political issues faced by the Tamil community remains at a standstill. He criticised the political leaders in the South for misleading the public on this matter, asserting that Sri Lanka would not have faced such a tragic situation if power had been properly devolved to the Tamil people. During a meeting with Tamil political party leaders, President Wickremesinghe reportedly made various remarks regarding the problems faced by the Tamil people, according to Rasamanickam. He further asserted that the country belongs to no particular individual or ethnic group and everyone should have equal access to fundamental and political rights. Rasamanickam warned that if the President fails to treat everyone equally without racial or ethnic bias, he would likely be rejected by the people soon. Rasamanickam said no amount of amendments or resolutions would lead to economic advancement without addressing the burning problems of the Tamil community and finding a sustainable solution for their issues. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Two locally produced substandard ‘Asprins’ removed from hospitals
author: Author not found
Content: The Medical Supplies Division (MSD) of the Health Ministry has taken action to remove two categories of locally-manufactured ‘Aspirin’ from all State hospitals. This decision comes after the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA) conducted an investigation and subsequently issued a circular to all government hospitals, based on their recommendations. During the NMRA’s investigation, various samples of Aspirin were tested and the two identified categories were found to be substandard.  As a result, these specific categories have been withdrawn from use in hospitals. The Health Ministry reassured the public that despite the removal of these two substandard drugs, there is no shortage of Aspirin in hospitals and adequate supplies are available for patients. BY Vineetha M. Gamage

title: Use of two anaesthetic drugs suspended
author: Author not found
Content: Director General of Health Services (DGHS), Dr. Asela Gunawardena on Friday (21) suspended the use of two anaesthetic drugs. The decision came after a report from the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA). Speaking to the media in Anuradhapura, Dr. Gunawardena clarified that the withdrawn drugs have been replaced with different alternatives. He reassured the public that measures are being taken to distribute these replacements to all hospitals. Dr. Gunawardena emphasised that the process of replacing a drug in response to complications is a routine practice and should not cause concern among the public. Meanwhile, addressing the recent allegations regarding the import of substandard drugs, he firmly stated that such imports are not approved under any circumstances. He also underscored that Sri Lanka’s drug imports consistently adhere to the standards set by the State Pharmaceutical Corporation (SPC).

title: Indian Investment and security cooperation to be discussed – India
author: Author not found
Content: The Indian Ministry of Foreign Affairs stated that President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s visit will facilitate further discussions on closer economic cooperation between India and Sri Lanka. Additionally, they will address matters pertaining to security and development cooperation between the two nations, MFA India Spokesperson Arindam Bagchi emphasised. The President is scheduled to meet Prime Minister Narendra Modi at 11:00 a.m. today (21) at the Hyderabad House. During this meeting, they will exchange Memoranda of Understanding and hold a press meet as well, it was announced. Bagchi further noted that the relationship between Sri Lanka and India is multifaceted.  He also acknowledged India’s support to Sri Lanka during the financial crisis. Regarding the use of Indian currency in Sri Lanka, Bagchi clarified that Sri Lanka has already designated the Indian national currency for trading within its system. However, its utilisation depends on the Indian private sector and those involved in trade. India seeks to strengthen financial and economic ties and further details will be addressed during the official meetings today (21), the spokesperson said. President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s delegation arrived at New Delhi Airport yesterday (20) at approximately 5.30 p.m., where he was welcomed by Minister of State for External Affairs, V. Muraleedharan. Later in the evening, the Foreign Minister of India, Dr. S. Jaishankar, met President Wickremesinghe at the ITC Maurya Hotel. The main official engagement between India and Sri Lanka is scheduled for today (21), during which they will discuss Indian investments and continue the conversations initiated during their prior interactions. Before leaving India today (21), President Wickremesinghe is expected to meet President of India Droupadi Murmu, at 5.00 p.m. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Diana claims even MPs behind Onmaxdt pyramid scheme
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Tourism, Diana Gamage, in a strong speech in Parliament yesterday (20), alleged that there are even MPs behind the pyramid racket known as Onmaxdt. She added that after the institution was banned by the Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL), a sum of Rs. 29.2 million had been collected. Gamage claimed that some of her fellow MPs were involved in the racket. She alleged that the investigations into the pyramid scheme by the CID and the Attorney General’s Department were progressing slowly. She also disclosed that Rs 30 million had been frozen in Onmaxdt’s accounts, while Rs 300 million had already been transferred out of the country. Calling for swift action, she urged the authorities to expedite the investigation and uncover the mastermind behind the scheme. In response, Justice Minister Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe acknowledged the need for stronger measures to combat pyramid schemes. He suggested enacting new laws to deal with these fraudulent activities, highlighting that the Central Bank lacks the authority to regulate such schemes. Minister Rajapakshe explained that pyramid schemes originated in Singapore before moving to Malaysia after they were banned in Singapore. Eventually, they found their way to Sri Lanka after being banned in Malaysia. He emphasised that Parliament holds the power to draft and implement new laws to effectively address and take action against pyramid schemes. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Fuel quota increase next month
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara yesterday (20) announced that fuel quotas will be increased again next month, following an assessment. He shared this information via a Twitter message. The Minister tweeted that the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) conducted a comprehensive review of the fuel cargo plan and supply for the upcoming six months. During the review, various aspects were taken into consideration, including fuel import plans, refinery operations, proposals for refinery upgrades, quotas for the QR system, storage capacity, stock automation, agreements with fuel stations, and distribution strategies. Based on the evaluation, the decision was made to increase the fuel quotas in the coming month, likely to ensure adequate supply and meet the energy demands of the country, he said.(MD)

title: AG-led delegation in fruitful talks
author: Author not found
Content: A nine-member delegation from Sri Lanka, led by the Attorney General, engaged in fruitful discussions with lawyers representing the MV X-Press Pearl ship-owner’s interests and their insurers in Singapore on 18 and 19 July, the President’s Media Division (PMD) announced yesterday (20). The meeting was convened in response to a request made by the lawyers on behalf of their clients, following the claims action filed by the Government of Sri Lanka in Singapore back in April. During these discussions, both parties addressed several critical aspects related to the incident and its aftermath. The PMD said, a major focus of the talks was to evaluate the outstanding interim claims put forth by the Marine Environment Authority and the Ministry of Fisheries from the Government of Sri Lanka. In response to these concerns, the Sri Lankan delegation received assurance from the ship-owner interests and insurers that the assessment of these claims would be carried out promptly and efficiently. The Attorney General, representing the Government of Sri Lanka, emphasised the urgency of concluding the ongoing wreck decommissioning and debris recovery operations within Sri Lankan waters. The insurers of the ship-owner interests responded positively to this plea, indicating their cooperation in addressing this issue. According to the PMD, the ship-owner interests expressed their willingness to consider the claims made by the Sri Lankan Government concerning the damage caused to the marine environment. They also displayed openness to further discussions with the Government of Sri Lanka in the near future. The PMD claimed these discussions will have no impact on the ongoing legal proceedings initiated by the Government of Sri Lanka in Singapore, which are already underway.

title: Chandani becomes first woman Presidential Secy
author: Author not found
Content: In a ground-breaking move, Chandani Wijewardena has been appointed as the Acting Presidential Secretary, marking her first woman to assume this esteemed position. The appointment was a result of President’s Secretary, Saman Ekanayake, accompanying the President on an official visit to India. The momentous decision was announced yesterday (20) and will remain in effect until Ekanayake returns to the island. Chandani Wijewardena, an accomplished senior civil servant, is currently serving as a Senior Additional Secretary to the President. Her illustrious career spans back to 1994 when she joined the Sri Lanka Planning  Service. Over the course of 22 years, Wijewardena held various critical positions within the Treasury and ultimately rose to the position of Director General of the Planning Department. From 2015 to 2019, she served as the Secretary of the Ministry of Development Strategy and International Trade, contributing her insights and skills to the nation’s economic development. An Alumni of Galle Southland Girls’ College, she pursued her Master’s Degree at the Ruhuna University. Additionally, she holds a postgraduate degree in Regional Economic Development from The Hague University in the Netherlands, showcasing her commitment to continuous learning and professional growth. (GW)

title: CBSL Bill passed
author: Author not found
Content: The Central Bank of Sri Lanka Bill was passed in Parliament with amendments yesterday (20), without taking a vote. The Second Reading debate of the Bill was held yesterday (20) and Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) MP Vijitha Herath called for a division for the Second Reading. Accordingly, the Second Reading of the Bill was passed with a majority of 42 votes with 66 voting in favour and 24 voting against. Subsequently, amendments were added to the Bill during the Committee Stage and the Third Reading of the Bill was passed without a division. The controversial Bill is set to legalise output gap targeting (stimulus or printing money for growth) under a so-called flexible inflation targeting framework. The passing of a new Central Bank law is a requirement in the agreement with the International Monetary Fund (IMF).

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Examination dates released

Content: The Department of Examinations yesterday (20), announced the dates for the 2023 Grade Five Scholarship Examination and the GCE Advanced Level (A/L) examination. The Grade Five exam will be held on Sunday, 15 October. The A/L exam will begin on Monday, 27 November and will end on Thursday, 21 December.

title: Rohan Fernando ousted from SLT Chairmanship
author: Author not found
Content: Chairman of State-owned Sri Lanka Telecom (SLT) Rohan Fernando was sacked by its Board yesterday (20). Speaking to the media, Fernando said he was ousted as Chairman, by the SLT Board, by a majority of 6:4. There are 10 directors serving on the Board. His successor is Reyaz Mihular, an accountant by profession and who also serves in the SLT Board. Fernando was appointed by President Gotabaya Rajapaksa as SLT Chairman in January 2020. He said, that in a recent conversation with President Ranil Wickremesinghe he was offered to head another State institution but declined. According to Fernando, the Government has a 49.4 per cent stake in SLT, a Malaysian telecoms entity (not Dialog) 44.4 per cent and the public, the balance. He said, that the Government plans to privatise its stake in SLT to another foreign entity. SLT has staff strength of 7,500, Fernando said. He said, that he’s not against privatisation but is pro-national security. He was worried that national security would be endangered through the Government’s SLT privatisation plan. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Attendance requirement reduced to 40% for A/L candidates – Susil
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Education Susil Premajayantha announced in Parliament yesterday (20) the compulsory school attendance requirement for students applying to sit for the 2023 GCE Advanced Level (A/L) examination will be reduced to 40 per cent, down from the previous requirement of 80 per cent. Explaining the reasons behind this decision, he pointed out that the decision was taken in light of the circumstances prevailing in the country. The previous rule stated that a student needed to have completed 80 per cent of school attendance to be eligible for the A/L examination as a school applicant, as per the letter dated 17 July 2023. However, the Minister acknowledged the challenges posed by the Covid-19 pandemic, which affected school attendance in the years 2020 and 2021, along with the unrest that occurred in the country last year. Considering these exceptional circumstances, a new letter was issued to all provincial education secretaries and school principals, granting them the authority to make decisions at the school level regarding the school attendance of students expecting to appear for the A/L examination this year. Speaking further, Premajayantha stated that for the current year only students’ school attendance will be considered at a minimum level of 40 per cent, recognising the difficulties faced by students due to the extraordinary events that occurred in the past. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Police Environment Unit OIC in bribery net
author: Author not found
Content: The OIC of the Maradana Police Environment Unit was arrested by the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) for allegedly attempting to solicit a bribe of Rs 10,000. According to CIABOC Director of Investigations, SSP Nuwan Asanka, the SI was caught by Bribery Commission officers near the Kuliyapitiya Divisional Court while accepting the bribe. The arrest came after a complaint was filed by an individual from Dambadeniya. The suspect SI supposedly demanded the bribe in exchange for providing favourable evidence in a road accident compensation case pending at the Kuliyapitiya Court, benefiting the complainant. The arrested SI was due to be produced before the Kuliyapitiya Magistrate yesterday (20).
