BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Ali Sabry attends inaugural BIMSTEC Foreign Ministers’ Retreat
author: Author not found
Content: At the invitation of Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister of Thailand Don Pramudwinai, Foreign Minister Ali Sabry participated at the inaugural BIMSTEC Foreign Ministers’ Retreat on 17 July in Bangkok.  The Foreign Ministers of BIMSTEC Member States welcomed the initiative of Thailand to host a Retreat which facilitated an exchange of ideas in an informal setting. There was a broad agreement on the importance of creating crisis response mechanisms in BIMSTEC member States to coordinate different contingencies. Food security, public health, energy, and financial security, as well as trade and economic cooperation, were at the core of the discussions. Furthermore, the meeting also considered establishing digital payment systems, as well as strengthening cooperation in cyber security and prevention of transnational crimes. The Foreign Ministers agreed to hold a Retreat on a regular basis, preferably in the first quarter of each year. And a Ministerial Meeting on the sidelines of the United Nations General Assembly.  The BIMSTEC Foreign Ministers paid a joint courtesy call on the Prime Minister of Thailand Prayut Chan-o-cha after the conclusion of the Retreat. In his remarks at the Retreat, Minister Sabry highlighted the need for agreeing on a common vision and having an action plan with short, mid and long-term priorities to implement the areas for cooperation identified during the discussion. On the sidelines of the Retreat, Minister Sabry had bilateral meetings with Don Pramudwinai, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs of Thailand, Dr A.K. Abdul Momen, Minister of Foreign Affairs of Bangladesh, Dr Tanji Dorji, Minister of Foreign Affairs of Bhutan, Than Swe, Minister of Foreign Affairs of Myanmar, and Narayan Prakash Saud, Minister of Foreign Affairs of Nepal where he discussed matters of bilateral importance. On 18 July, Minister Sabry addressed an Investment Forum titled “Invest in Sri Lanka – Now is the Time” organised jointly by the Embassy of Sri Lanka to Thailand and Permanent Mission to UNESCAP and the Federation of Thai Industries. Welcoming Minister Sabry to the Federation of Thai Industries, its Chairman Kriengkrai Thiennukul assured that the Federation is ready to cooperate with Sri Lanka’s business sector and disclosed that arrangements are being made to send a business delegation to Sri Lanka in the near future. Minister Sabry invited Thai Entrepreneurs to make use of the strategic location of Sri Lanka as a gateway to enter the markets in South Asia, the Middle East and Africa and enlightened the membership of the Federation of Thai Industries on Sri Lanka’s emergence as a promising investment destination with immense potential for growth and prosperity and emphasised the need for collaborative efforts in building a prosperous future together. In an interview with the National Broadcasting Service of Thailand, Minister Sabry elaborated on the initiatives taken by the Government of Sri Lanka for the country’s economic recovery. Highlighting Thailand’s role as a regional player, Minister Sabry invited Thai entrepreneurs to invest in Sri Lanka and make use of the market access to India, Pakistan and Singapore through Free Trade Agreements. The Sri Lanka delegation included the Ambassador of Sri Lanka to Thailand and Permanent Representative to ESCAP C.A. Chaminda I Colonne, Director General of Economic Affairs (Multilateral) of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Samantha Pathirana, First Secretary A.W.S. Samanmali, and First Secretary (Commercial) Vireshika Bandara.

title: Hailing Six Decades of SL-Swiss relations
author: Author not found
Content: Toast proposed by Susil Premajayantha, Minister-in-Attendance at the reception to Mark the 732nd Anniversary of the Swiss Confederation (Swiss National Day) on 19 July, where Dominik Furgler, Ambassador of the Swiss Confederation to Sri Lanka, Cabinet Ministers, Deputy Ministers, and Members of Parliament, and other distinguished guests were in attendance.  The strong and enduring friendship between Sri Lanka and Switzerland has come a long way. Diplomatic relations between our two countries were established in 1956 and both countries have continued to enjoy over six decades of good relations based on a foundation of common values such as democracy and open economic policies. Our steadfast bilateral engagement is anchored in high-level exchanges, strong trade relations, people-to-people contacts and development cooperation. Sri Lanka welcomes the support extended by Switzerland as a member of the Paris Club in securing the Extended Fund Facility (EFF) from the IMF to Sri Lanka as well as the provision of assistance through UN agencies and the World Food Programme towards people impacted by the economic situation. Our trade ties are strong. Switzerland is among the top 20 destinations for Sri Lankan exports. We welcome the fact that the Swiss Generalised System of Preferences (GSP) facility allows many Sri Lankan products to be exported tariff-free to the Swiss market. There is immense potential for further expansion of trade between the two countries. Investments from Switzerland over the years have contributed well to Sri Lanka’s economic growth. Swiss companies are particularly active in Sri Lanka’s Agriculture, Food and Construction Sectors contributing to the development of the relevant industries, while generating employment opportunities for thousands of Sri Lankans. We hope to see more Swiss investments in sectors such as Tourism and Pharmaceutical manufacturing in the coming years. The Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation has been active in Sri Lanka since 2000, providing humanitarian aid, helping with reconstruction and uplifting the lives of thousands of Sri Lankans for years. We appreciate the fact that since 2010, Switzerland has been supporting the Safe Labour Migration Programme (SLMP) in Sri Lanka. It has cushioned the adverse impacts of labour migration while increasing the contribution made to sound policy priorities. The successful conclusion of the 2nd Expert Meeting on Migration Partnership between Sri Lanka and Switzerland last May in Colombo is a testament to the commitment of both our countries towards continued cooperation in migration matters.  Sri Lanka and Switzerland have also enjoyed a vibrant people-to-people exchange, with many Sri Lankans and people of Sri Lankan heritage living and working in Switzerland, and many Swiss tourists visiting Sri Lanka. We also appreciate the cultural exchange programmes conducted by the Swiss Embassy in Colombo such as showcasing Swiss Artists at the Fairway Galle Literary Festival and the contemporary Art Exhibition Colomboscope in cooperation with Pro Helvetia New Delhi. The organisation of film festivals in Sri Lanka, such as the European Film Festival, the Francophone Film Festival, Cinema on the Road, the Jaffna International Cinema Festival and the Colombo International Women’s Film Festival have expanded our outreach in cultural cooperation. Sri Lanka and Switzerland face common challenges in the 21st Century, such as Climate Change, Terrorism, and Food and Energy Security. The strong and steadily advancing partnership between our two countries gives us confidence in tackling these challenges together. We look forward to working with our Swiss friends to promote Sri Lanka-Switzerland bilateral ties to even greater heights. “I would be remiss in my duties today if I don’t say a few words about Ambassador Furgler who is about to conclude his tour of duty in Sri Lanka. “Ambassador Furgler, your services in Sri Lanka in the past three years is much appreciated not only because of your professionalism and Cordiality but also for the significant contributions made to broaden the vistas of our cooperation. We all enjoyed your hospitality and the kind relations that you and your wife Hayam established with Sri Lanka. We will miss you both. Thank you again and wishing you both the best for all your engagements and a wonderful retirement”.

title: FAO launches training of 300 Agriculture Extension Officers
author: Author not found
Content: The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), in collaboration with the Department of Agriculture and Mahaweli Authority in Sri Lanka (MASL), is taking crucial steps, supported by funding from the European Union (EU), to address the threat to Food Security caused by two consecutive seasons of poor harvests in 2021-2022. With a nearly 40% drop in paddy production in 2022, Sri Lanka’s rice ecosystem is vulnerable and requires immediate attention. To combat this issue, FAO has initiated an innovative project titled RiceUP, with funding of €4 million from the European Union (EU). As part of this project, FAO and its partners are conducting training programmes for Agriculture Extension Officers (AEOs) on Integrated Plant Nutrient Management (IPNM) in four districts: Ampara, Badulla, Hambantota, and Polonnaruwa. The training will equip them with the necessary skills and knowledge to guide paddy farmers on soil management and the optimal use of organic and chemical fertilisers to enhance crop yield, while reducing chemical dependency. The initial training session for Agriculture Extension Officers (AEOs) on IPNM practices was launched yesterday at the Rice Research and Development Institute in Batalagoda. This session marks the beginning of a series of five training programmes, aiming to train a total of 300 AEOs from the selected districts. The Training Manual developed collaboratively with international and national consultants, the Department of Agriculture, MASL, and the University of Peradeniya will serve as the cornerstone of these training sessions. IPNM is a sustainable land management practice that ensures soil quality, prevents degradation, and maximises crop productivity, while safeguarding the environment. FAO’s induction of IPNM, coupled with the provision of urea fertiliser to smallholder farmers in selected districts, is a response to the challenges faced by farmers in accessing essential fertilisers and maintaining food security. By adopting IPNM and accessing urea fertiliser, smallholder paddy farmers can reduce costs and improve productivity, leading to better profitability and resilience to future shocks. Through the implementation of sustainable farming practices, including the safe and efficient use of fertiliser and quality seed, RiceUP aims to enhance productivity, food security, and livelihoods in Sri Lanka’s paddy farming sector. Together with its partners, FAO remains dedicated to ensuring the long-term sustainability and resilience of Sri Lanka’s agriculture sector.

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date:  Not only Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella, but even his officials accused of corruption and giving false information to the public should be removed from the Health Ministry, the Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA) said. MCPA President, Chamal Sanjeeva, yesterday (20), accused an Additional Secretary of the Health Ministry, of lying regarding the number of medicinal drugs which had been removed from use during a media briefing. “Not just two drugs, but close to 500 types of substandard drugs and equipment have been removed from use since 2019, he said, noting that this was clearly stated on the website of the Medical Supplies Division (MSD) of the Ministry of Health. Health officials continue to give out false information to the public. Merely changing the Minister of Health would not suffice under such circumstances. It is clear that not only the Health Minister, but such officials too should be removed,” he said. Additional Secretary of the Health Ministry Dr. Saman Ratnayake, speaking to the media, said on Wednesday (19), that some of the Health Ministry’s warehouses had drugs that had failed quality control for years. There had been complications with eye drops that had been used at the National Eye Hospital and District General Hospital Nuwara Eliya post-eye surgery. That medicine contained bacteria. “We have stopped all other medicines temporarily. Until that investigation is over,” Dr. Ratnayake explained at the time. The MCPA President noted that when he had revealed there was malnourishment in the country last year, Minister Rambukwella had refuted such claims in Parliament stating that they were baseless. However, without any shame, he himself had to reverse his claims noting that at least one million of the country’s population were malnourished. Had the Minister carried out a proper follow-up based on the facts revealed by the MCPA in September last year, the nutritional situation in the country would have been more controlled by now, he lamented. Recollecting the facts given out by him regarding the situation of malnourishment prevailing in Sooriyawewa, Hambantota District, Dr. Sanjeeva said, at the time Rambukwella, making a statement in Parliament which had been written by the Director of Health Services for Hambantota District and the Health Secretary said there was no malnutrition in Hambantota nor in any other part of the country. Lashing out, he said the Minister of Health should be ashamed to continue lying and presenting false information to the public and the media hiding behind parliamentary privileges. “According to the Health Ministry, 300,000 children under the age of five and 700,000 women suffered from malnutrition. This situation could also be seen in the Western, Central, North-Western and Uva Provinces. The Health Ministry has to explain how it utilised nearly Rs 500 million allocated for the rural people from the last Budget when the funds could have been utilised to address such issues,” the MCPA President said. By Dilanthi Jayamanne Popular

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date:  Merrill J. Fernando, the founder and former CEO of one of Sri Lanka’s biggest tea brands, ‘Dilmah’ passed away yesterday (20). The leading businessman was 93 at the time of his demise. Born in 1930 in Negombo, Fernando received his primary education at Maris Stella College and his secondary education at St. Joseph’s College, Colombo. In 1954, when the island was still under the British colonials, Fernando started work as a tea assistant at AF Jones & Co. He was one of the first Ceylonese to learn tea tasting. Four years later, Fernando was elevated to the position of Managing Director. However, in 1962, he resigned from AF Jones & Co. and started Ceylon Tea Services Company. Later that year, he set up Merrill J. Fernando Company and exported bulk tea to Russia, USA, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, South Africa, Libya, Egypt and Saudi Arabia. In 1982, Fernando set up Ceylon Tea Services Ltd., floated as a public company at the request of the Government to support the up-and-coming Colombo Stock Exchange. Three years later, in 1985, Sri Lanka’s first value-added Ceylon tea brand ‘Dilmah’ was launched with Australia-based Mauri Foods. Dilmah Tasting and Packing Factory was awarded ISO 9002 Certification in 1994. Reaffirming his commitment to the company’s philosophy ‘Business is a Matter of Human Services’, Fernando in 2003 set up the MJF Charitable Foundation through which thousands of children, young women and men, impoverished adults, farmers, and war widows received help. The MJF Charitable Foundation undertook its first major relief effort, with the Small Entrepreneur Programme benefiting survivors of the 2004 tsunami disaster. The project has gone on to empower over 2,000 start-up businesses. In 2015, the famed teamaker was named an Honouree of the Oslo Business for Peace Award, chosen by a committee of Nobel laureates for ethical and sustainable business. A year later, he was named Global Businessman at the Sri Lankan of the Year Awards and was honoured with FIRST Award for Responsible Capitalism for improving the lives of underprivileged children and deprived communities. Staying true to his pledge made in 2014, Fernando also turned Dilmah into a carbon-neutral facility in 2017. The same year, he was recognised by Business Today in the ‘Passionate 2017’ list of Sri Lankans. In 2018, the Dilmah Tea founder was honoured by World Chefs with a Lifetime Achievement Award. He was also honoured by the International Chamber of Commerce in Sri Lanka as one of the three Most Admired Leaders and Dilmah as one of Sri Lanka’s Most Admired Companies. In 2019, Fernando was bestowed with the ‘Deshamanya’ title at the National Honours Ceremony presided over by former President Maithripala Sirisena. Later that year, he was capped as a Doctor of Science by Massey University in New Zealand. BY Adnan Ali Cassim Popular

title: Partheepan Jesuthasan Makes a Significant Impact on the Sri Lanka Tech Industry
author: Author not found
Content: Partheepan Jesuthasan, a prominent entrepreneur hailing from Batticaloa Eastern Province of Sri Lanka, has emerged as a driving force behind the transformation of the country’s tech industry. With a remarkable educational background and an unwavering entrepreneurial spirit, Partheepan has made remarkable strides in elevating the technological landscape of Sri Lanka. Born and raised in Batticaloa of Sri Lanka, Partheepan embarked on a remarkable journey of success, fuelled by their passion for technology. Armed with determination and a thirst for knowledge, Partheepan, pursued his education relentlessly. He earned a bachelor’s degree in marketing from theEastern University, where they honed their skills and gained a deep understanding of the industry.Fuelled by the ambition to make a difference, Partheepan ventured into the world of entrepreneurship. He founded Elephant Crew Pvt Ltd a trailblazing Mar Tech company (Marketing Technology) that has gained recognition for its innovative solutions and exceptional client service. Through his tireless efforts and visionary leadership, Partheepan has spearheaded a revolution in the Sri Lanka tech industry. Elephant Crew had the privilege of working with an impressive roster of clients, ranging from multinational corporations to local startups. By providing cutting-edge Marketing technological solutions tailored to meet the unique needs of each client, Partheepan has established long-lasting partnerships based on trust and mutual growth. His commitment to delivering exceptional quality has resulted in consistently exceeding client expectations. The impact of Partheepan’s contributions to the Sri Lanka tech industry is far-reaching. Not only have their innovative solutions transformed the way businesses operate, but they have also had a profound effect on various stakeholders. Through job creation, Partheepan has provided employment opportunities for talented individuals, helping to uplift communities and empower the local workforce. Moreover, the impact extends beyond individual companies and employees. Partheepan’s technological advancements have bolstered the overall economy of Sri Lanka by attracting foreign investments and driving economic growth. By positioning Sri Lanka as a hub for innovation and technological excellence, Partheepan has elevated the country’s reputation on the global stage. Partheepan continues to inspire and motivate aspiring entrepreneurs, especially those hailing from rural areas, to pursue their dreams relentlessly. Their remarkable journey stands as a testament to the potential that lies within every individual, regardless of their background or upbringing. As Partheepan forges ahead, the Sri Lanka tech industry can expect further advancements, game changing innovations, and transformative growth. Their relentless pursuit of excellence and unwavering commitment to making a difference ensure that Partheepan will remain at the forefront of revolutionising the tech landscape in Sri Lanka and beyond.

title: Hayleys Solar empowers Crystal Martin
author: Author not found
Content: In a powerful display of collective commitment to address climate change and promote sustainable practices, Hayleys Solar, the leading renewable energy arm of Hayleys Fentons and the country’s No.1 solar provider, joins forces with Crystal Martin Ceylon Group to embark on the second phase of a groundbreaking solar installation project. With a total project investment of USD 2.5 million and a combined capacity of 4.67 MW, this groundbreaking collaboration is an industry benchmark for leaders at the forefront of championing renewable energy solutions. Phase 01 of the project has already been completed, with an investment of USD 1 million and a capacity of 1.9 MW. The commencement of Phase 02, an extraordinary milestone, brings an investment of USD 1.5 million and a capacity of 2.7 MW. During Phase 02, Hayleys Solar will spearhead the supply and installation of cutting-edge solar power systems at Katunayake and Wathupitiwala. The Katunayake installation will showcase an estimated capacity of 1,585kW, employing over 2,880 state-of-the-art solar panels. Furthermore, the Wathupitiwala factory will be equipped with a solar system of over 2,090 panels and a capacity of 1,150kW. These cutting-edge solar installations will augment Crystal Martin’s power generation capacity by 4,672kW. Combined with the achievements of the first phase, the total annual CO2 footprint reduction at Crystal Martin will exceed 4,700 tonnes. Commenting on the project, Mark Muller, Country Manager of Crystal Martin Ceylon (Private) Limited said, “We are proud to partner with Hayleys Solar on this key project, which has streamlined operations across our manufacturing facilities. By fully embracing renewable energy, we are taking a significant step towards reducing our carbon footprint and becoming one of the pioneering companies in Sri Lanka to adopt sustainable energy initiatives. We are eagerly looking forward to continuing our efforts to contribute to a greener future.” Crystal Martin’s commitment to combat the climate crisis and support renewable energy is reflected in its ambitious sustainability goals. The completion of the second phase of the solar installation project reinforces Crystal Martin’s overall renewable energy efforts and sustainability objectives. Notably, the power generated by all these solar systems accounts for approximately 75% of Crystal Martin’s annual electricity requirement at the six factories, demonstrating the project’s substantial impact on their energy consumption and environmental footprint. The partnership between Hayleys Solar and Crystal Martin exemplifies the collective commitment of industry leaders to address climate change and promote sustainable business practices. Hasith Prematillake, Managing Director of Fentons Ltd highlighted the company’s commitment to meeting the country’s solar needs and supporting energy conservation efforts. He stated, “We are dedicated to contributing to the important cause of energy saving during these challenging times and facilitating businesses to transition to renewable energy in the near future.” Roshane Perera, Director & CEO of Hayleys Solar, expressed pride in being chosen as Crystal Martin Ceylon’s trusted partner for this significant renewable energy project. Highlighting Hayleys Solar’s expertise in large-scale solar initiatives and its position as Sri Lanka’s unrivalled market leader in renewable energy solutions, Perera stated, “We are honoured by Crystal Martin Sri Lanka’s decision to collaborate with us. With our exceptional capabilities and a skilled team of over 200 engineers, Hayleys Solar is fully equipped to lead the way in meeting the country’s solar demands and driving renewable energy solutions.”

title: Sri Lankan receives best hotel housekeeper award
author: Author not found
Content: A Sri Lankan, Jon Manohar, received the best hotel housekeeper UAE 2023 award at the MECHF Awards organised for the fifth time in Dubai, United Arab Emirates. Accordingly, he has been chosen from among all the hotels and resorts in the United Arab Emirates. Manohar, who has over 40 years of experience, is currently working at J5 HOTELS, Dubai as Cluster Director of Housekeeping, The fifth edition of the Middle East Cleaning, Hygiene and Facilities Awards brought many amazing journeys of housekeepers to light the amazing work of seasoned housekeepers. Winning the Best Hotel Housekeeper MECHF Trophy in the UAE is undoubtedly a significant achievement and a moment of pride for any hospitality professional. The MECHF Award is a symbol of recognition for outstanding contributions and achievements in the hospitality industry, and it is regarded as one of the most prestigious awards in the region and for the professional experience. The awards ceremony was held on 5 May 2023 at the Ritz Carlton, DIFC. The MECHF Awards is organised by Clean Middle East & Built Environment magazines – published by Media Fusion LLC. Media Fusion is a dynamic media company based out of Dubai, UAE. Clean Middle East and Media Fusion are proud to present the fifth edition of the MECHF Awards! For the past five years, the awards have brought recognition and glory to the stakeholders of the commercial cleaning and soft FM industries in the region. The MECHF Awards covers the entire chain of stakeholders in the industry – from the manufacturer to the distributor, the service provider and the end user. This combination not only makes MECHF Awards a unique entity, but it also continues to bring under the spotlight the broad spectrum that the cleaning and FM industries involve.

title: SLAF holds annual Islamic religious ceremony
author: Author not found
Content: The Annual Islamic Religious Ceremony of the SLAF was held at the Kollupitiya Jummah Mosque on 19 July 2023. Commander of the Sri Lanka Air Force, Air Marshal Udeni Rajapaksa, graced the event as the Chief Guest. The officiating Mowlavi invoked blessings and prayed to almighty Allah on behalf of the souls of all the brave men of the Sri Lanka Air Force who made the supreme sacrifice for the defence of the motherland. Further, blessings of almighty Allah were bestowed upon all ranks presently serving in the Air Force during the ceremony. Among the guests in attendance were the Chief of Staff of SLAF, Deputy Chief of Staff, Members of the Air Force Board of Management, Directors, Senior Officers, a cross section of other ranks and the beloved family members of the fallen war heroes.

title: Formulation of A New Policy to Resolve HEC – Pavithra
author: Author not found
Content: “A new Policy will be formulated to address the ongoing Human-Elephant Conflict (HEC)”, Minister of Wildlife and Forest Resources Conservation Pavithradevi Wanniarachchi stated. The Minister added that she hopes to address this issue with short, medium and long-term goals and objectives. She expressed these views today (19), during a Press Conference themed ‘Collective Path to a Stable Country’ held at the Presidential Media Centre (PMC). Elaborating further the Minister said: “Our Ministry has prioritised resolving HEC as soon as possible. Our aim is to provide related solutions through short, medium and long-term plans. So far, the Ministry has conducted several workshops to provide guidance and direction towards this end. “By incorporating the earlier measures and efforts to manage HEC, it has now become necessary to establish a permanent strategy for this. The Policy will then be turned into law after that. We are confident that by doing this, we will be able to permanently end HEC. “80% of the land in this country is owned by the State, while about 20% is owned by the public. The population of the country is growing day-by-day. Also, the habitats and paths of wild elephants are now occupied by people for various development activities. “Some believe that the ‘Elephant Fence’ is a solution to prevent wild elephants from invading villages. Given the current financial situation of the country, it will take some time to complete these activities. “It must be mentioned that immediately after learning that Agbo, the Elephant was injured, the Wildlife Department took prompt action to provide medical treatment. Even now, the elephant is under doctors’ due care and medical treatment. So far, there are no impediments with regard to finances and/or providing medicine for treatment and speedy recovery of the injured elephant. Therefore, no one should raise issues concerning the welfare of  Agbo. I wish to reiterate that the government is making every effort to safeguard the elephant’s life”.

title: Ali Sabry attends inaugural BIMSTEC Foreign Ministers’ Retreat
author: Author not found
Content: At the invitation of Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister of Thailand Don Pramudwinai, Foreign Minister Ali Sabry participated at the inaugural BIMSTEC Foreign Ministers’ Retreat on 17 July in Bangkok.  The Foreign Ministers of BIMSTEC Member States welcomed the initiative of Thailand to host a Retreat which facilitated an exchange of ideas in an informal setting. There was a broad agreement on the importance of creating crisis response mechanisms in BIMSTEC member States to coordinate different contingencies. Food security, public health, energy, and financial security, as well as trade and economic cooperation, were at the core of the discussions. Furthermore, the meeting also considered establishing digital payment systems, as well as strengthening cooperation in cyber security and prevention of transnational crimes. The Foreign Ministers agreed to hold a Retreat on a regular basis, preferably in the first quarter of each year. And a Ministerial Meeting on the sidelines of the United Nations General Assembly.  The BIMSTEC Foreign Ministers paid a joint courtesy call on the Prime Minister of Thailand Prayut Chan-o-cha after the conclusion of the Retreat. In his remarks at the Retreat, Minister Sabry highlighted the need for agreeing on a common vision and having an action plan with short, mid and long-term priorities to implement the areas for cooperation identified during the discussion. On the sidelines of the Retreat, Minister Sabry had bilateral meetings with Don Pramudwinai, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs of Thailand, Dr A.K. Abdul Momen, Minister of Foreign Affairs of Bangladesh, Dr Tanji Dorji, Minister of Foreign Affairs of Bhutan, Than Swe, Minister of Foreign Affairs of Myanmar, and Narayan Prakash Saud, Minister of Foreign Affairs of Nepal where he discussed matters of bilateral importance. On 18 July, Minister Sabry addressed an Investment Forum titled “Invest in Sri Lanka – Now is the Time” organised jointly by the Embassy of Sri Lanka to Thailand and Permanent Mission to UNESCAP and the Federation of Thai Industries. Welcoming Minister Sabry to the Federation of Thai Industries, its Chairman Kriengkrai Thiennukul assured that the Federation is ready to cooperate with Sri Lanka’s business sector and disclosed that arrangements are being made to send a business delegation to Sri Lanka in the near future. Minister Sabry invited Thai Entrepreneurs to make use of the strategic location of Sri Lanka as a gateway to enter the markets in South Asia, the Middle East and Africa and enlightened the membership of the Federation of Thai Industries on Sri Lanka’s emergence as a promising investment destination with immense potential for growth and prosperity and emphasised the need for collaborative efforts in building a prosperous future together. In an interview with the National Broadcasting Service of Thailand, Minister Sabry elaborated on the initiatives taken by the Government of Sri Lanka for the country’s economic recovery. Highlighting Thailand’s role as a regional player, Minister Sabry invited Thai entrepreneurs to invest in Sri Lanka and make use of the market access to India, Pakistan and Singapore through Free Trade Agreements. The Sri Lanka delegation included the Ambassador of Sri Lanka to Thailand and Permanent Representative to ESCAP C.A. Chaminda I Colonne, Director General of Economic Affairs (Multilateral) of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Samantha Pathirana, First Secretary A.W.S. Samanmali, and First Secretary (Commercial) Vireshika Bandara.

title: Hailing Six Decades of SL-Swiss relations
author: Author not found
Content: Toast proposed by Susil Premajayantha, Minister-in-Attendance at the reception to Mark the 732nd Anniversary of the Swiss Confederation (Swiss National Day) on 19 July, where Dominik Furgler, Ambassador of the Swiss Confederation to Sri Lanka, Cabinet Ministers, Deputy Ministers, and Members of Parliament, and other distinguished guests were in attendance.  The strong and enduring friendship between Sri Lanka and Switzerland has come a long way. Diplomatic relations between our two countries were established in 1956 and both countries have continued to enjoy over six decades of good relations based on a foundation of common values such as democracy and open economic policies. Our steadfast bilateral engagement is anchored in high-level exchanges, strong trade relations, people-to-people contacts and development cooperation. Sri Lanka welcomes the support extended by Switzerland as a member of the Paris Club in securing the Extended Fund Facility (EFF) from the IMF to Sri Lanka as well as the provision of assistance through UN agencies and the World Food Programme towards people impacted by the economic situation. Our trade ties are strong. Switzerland is among the top 20 destinations for Sri Lankan exports. We welcome the fact that the Swiss Generalised System of Preferences (GSP) facility allows many Sri Lankan products to be exported tariff-free to the Swiss market. There is immense potential for further expansion of trade between the two countries. Investments from Switzerland over the years have contributed well to Sri Lanka’s economic growth. Swiss companies are particularly active in Sri Lanka’s Agriculture, Food and Construction Sectors contributing to the development of the relevant industries, while generating employment opportunities for thousands of Sri Lankans. We hope to see more Swiss investments in sectors such as Tourism and Pharmaceutical manufacturing in the coming years. The Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation has been active in Sri Lanka since 2000, providing humanitarian aid, helping with reconstruction and uplifting the lives of thousands of Sri Lankans for years. We appreciate the fact that since 2010, Switzerland has been supporting the Safe Labour Migration Programme (SLMP) in Sri Lanka. It has cushioned the adverse impacts of labour migration while increasing the contribution made to sound policy priorities. The successful conclusion of the 2nd Expert Meeting on Migration Partnership between Sri Lanka and Switzerland last May in Colombo is a testament to the commitment of both our countries towards continued cooperation in migration matters.  Sri Lanka and Switzerland have also enjoyed a vibrant people-to-people exchange, with many Sri Lankans and people of Sri Lankan heritage living and working in Switzerland, and many Swiss tourists visiting Sri Lanka. We also appreciate the cultural exchange programmes conducted by the Swiss Embassy in Colombo such as showcasing Swiss Artists at the Fairway Galle Literary Festival and the contemporary Art Exhibition Colomboscope in cooperation with Pro Helvetia New Delhi. The organisation of film festivals in Sri Lanka, such as the European Film Festival, the Francophone Film Festival, Cinema on the Road, the Jaffna International Cinema Festival and the Colombo International Women’s Film Festival have expanded our outreach in cultural cooperation. Sri Lanka and Switzerland face common challenges in the 21st Century, such as Climate Change, Terrorism, and Food and Energy Security. The strong and steadily advancing partnership between our two countries gives us confidence in tackling these challenges together. We look forward to working with our Swiss friends to promote Sri Lanka-Switzerland bilateral ties to even greater heights. “I would be remiss in my duties today if I don’t say a few words about Ambassador Furgler who is about to conclude his tour of duty in Sri Lanka. “Ambassador Furgler, your services in Sri Lanka in the past three years is much appreciated not only because of your professionalism and Cordiality but also for the significant contributions made to broaden the vistas of our cooperation. We all enjoyed your hospitality and the kind relations that you and your wife Hayam established with Sri Lanka. We will miss you both. Thank you again and wishing you both the best for all your engagements and a wonderful retirement”.

title: FAO launches training of 300 Agriculture Extension Officers
author: Author not found
Content: The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), in collaboration with the Department of Agriculture and Mahaweli Authority in Sri Lanka (MASL), is taking crucial steps, supported by funding from the European Union (EU), to address the threat to Food Security caused by two consecutive seasons of poor harvests in 2021-2022. With a nearly 40% drop in paddy production in 2022, Sri Lanka’s rice ecosystem is vulnerable and requires immediate attention. To combat this issue, FAO has initiated an innovative project titled RiceUP, with funding of €4 million from the European Union (EU). As part of this project, FAO and its partners are conducting training programmes for Agriculture Extension Officers (AEOs) on Integrated Plant Nutrient Management (IPNM) in four districts: Ampara, Badulla, Hambantota, and Polonnaruwa. The training will equip them with the necessary skills and knowledge to guide paddy farmers on soil management and the optimal use of organic and chemical fertilisers to enhance crop yield, while reducing chemical dependency. The initial training session for Agriculture Extension Officers (AEOs) on IPNM practices was launched yesterday at the Rice Research and Development Institute in Batalagoda. This session marks the beginning of a series of five training programmes, aiming to train a total of 300 AEOs from the selected districts. The Training Manual developed collaboratively with international and national consultants, the Department of Agriculture, MASL, and the University of Peradeniya will serve as the cornerstone of these training sessions. IPNM is a sustainable land management practice that ensures soil quality, prevents degradation, and maximises crop productivity, while safeguarding the environment. FAO’s induction of IPNM, coupled with the provision of urea fertiliser to smallholder farmers in selected districts, is a response to the challenges faced by farmers in accessing essential fertilisers and maintaining food security. By adopting IPNM and accessing urea fertiliser, smallholder paddy farmers can reduce costs and improve productivity, leading to better profitability and resilience to future shocks. Through the implementation of sustainable farming practices, including the safe and efficient use of fertiliser and quality seed, RiceUP aims to enhance productivity, food security, and livelihoods in Sri Lanka’s paddy farming sector. Together with its partners, FAO remains dedicated to ensuring the long-term sustainability and resilience of Sri Lanka’s agriculture sector.

title: Broadcasters condemn SLC ‘banning’ some Journalists
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Broadcasters’ Guild (SLBG) has written to Sri Lanka Cricket (SLC) President Shammi Silva, raising concerns with regard to the controversy in which journalists from certain media stations have been allegedly ‘banned’ from attending the events organised by SLC , including press conferences and cricket matches. “As we understand it, this ban was purportedly implemented in response to certain news items reported or published by certain media stations. “Free Media is often considered as the fourth pillar of democracy, the other three being the executive, legislature and judiciary. Free Media plays an important role in maintaining checks and balances, which is an important requirement in a democratic society. In this respect, the role of a robust and independent media cannot be overstated.” The letter stated that SLBG believes this alleged ban sets a dangerous precedent. Barring critical voices is not conducive to a healthy dialogue and indirectly stifles the freedom of the media, it added. “We believe in the mutual respect and cooperation between the Sri Lanka Cricket and the media, as we both play vital roles in the development and promotion of cricket in our beloved nation. Let us continue this relationship with openness and mutual understanding,” the SLGB said.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Wanted killer shot dead
author: Author not found
Content: A 29-year-old, who was wanted in connection with a murder in Homagama, was killed during a shootout with the STF in Minuwangoda, Police said. According to Police, following a tip-off, an STF team from the Gonahena Camp launched an operation to arrest the suspect, who was in hiding, in Horanpella, Minuwangoda. However, he opened fire with T56 assault rifle when the STF officers tried to arrest him. The suspect, who was injured during the shootout was admitted to the Minuwangoda Hospital, where he succumbed to his injuries.

title: BOI approves USD 682M investments – Dilum
author: Author not found
Content: The target set by the Board of Investments (BOI) for Foreign Direct Investments (FDI) for 2023 is USD 1.5 billion and BOI FDI realised in the first quarter of 2023 amounted to USD 211 million, State Minister of Investment Promotion Dilum Amunugama said. The BOI has approved investments of USD 682 million from January to July, he added. Despite the ongoing economic crisis, the BOI has been able to attract Foreign Direct Investments of USD 1.75 billion exceeding the targeted amount of 1 billion US dollars for 2022, Amunugama added. He expressed these views during a press conference at the Presidential Media Centre (PMC) yesterday (20). Amunugama further said it is necessary to update and modify Sri Lanka’s existing legislative framework in order to make the country an investment-friendly destination. It is expected to introduce new investment laws by the end of 2023, without affecting other government entities and current legal frameworks. “Additionally, foreign investors do not receive their investment rights when they enter this country. As a solution, we must update our legislative framework to ensure that their investment rights are protected. A seven-member committee comprising Directors General of government institutions has already been appointed to look into the existing laws that restrict investments,” he said. He said,  “The government intends to execute a programme under the concept of ‘One Village – One Product’ to empower entrepreneurs who produce export-level products in selected regional secretariats, involving them in the export process, and scale it up at the District and National levels. A Central Export Centre will be established for them and measures will be taken to strengthen the connection between the rural exporters and the Sri Lanka Export Development Board.”

title: ‘Sambuddha Jayanthi Tripitaka’ to go online
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Buddha Sasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs Vidura Wickramanayake said, the ‘Sambuddha Jayanthi Tripitaka’ book series, recognised as a National Heritage, will be translated into English, published online, and subsequently printed. Wickramanayake said, this decision was made in response to a request from prominent Buddhist Monks during a meeting at the Ministry. The purpose is to facilitate the study of the Tripitaka by interested individuals, including lay clergy, both locally and internationally, aiming to promote Buddhism worldwide. To ensure successful implementation, the advice and approval of Mahanayake Theras will be sought, the Minister said. He added that three boards will be appointed — the Supreme Board, Supervisory Board, and Executive Board — and Cabinet approval will also be sought.

title: Another death due to antibiotic allergy
author: Author not found
Content: A patient, at the ICU of the Kegalle Teaching Hospital, died after he experienced an allergic reaction following an antibiotic being administered to him. Reportedly it was the same antibiotic used at the Peradeniya Hospital, resulting in the death of a 21-year-old girl recently. The patient was a 57-year-old resident of Kegalle. He was admitted to the hospital on 10 July for cirrhosis and developed the allergy on 17 July. He died the next day at the ICU. According to Director of the hospital Dr. Mihiri Priyangani the post-mortem reports revealed that the antibiotics in the patient’s system were the cause of his death. The Hospital Director said, Ministry of Health has been informed about the death. It was reported that antibiotics were administered to the patient 13 times previously. However, when the antibiotic was given for the 14th time, the diseased developed an allergy.

title: No theft of nuts, bolts from New Kelani Bridge– Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: Transport Minister Bandula Gunawardena refuted claims that nuts and bolts worth about Rs 280 million were stolen from the New Kelani Bridge. However, Gunawardena said in Parliament, yesterday (19), the total value of the stolen items including GI pipes, PVC pipes from the drainage system, parts of the air conditioning system in the communication room connected to the bridge, and coloured bulbs fixed along the bridge, was reported to be Rs 5.9 million. Further, he said thefts had also taken place on the Colombo-Katunayake Expressway (E03). Gunawardena said items such as copper wire, GI pipes, and lamp posts worth Rs 294.4 million were stolen, specifically highlighting the theft of copper wires from the electric cable system during the power crisis and the Covid-19 lockdown period between September 2021 and July 2023. The minister was responding to a question raised by MP Dayasiri Jayasekara on Tuesday (18) with regard to the reports about stolen nuts and bolts of the New Kelani Bridge. The Minister clarified that these nuts and bolts of the New Kelani Bridge cannot be easily removed as specialised tools are required for their removal, and only the relevant engineering companies possess these tools. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Renovated Popham Arboretum opens today
author: Author not found
Content: The newly renovated Popham Arboretum in Dambulla will be opened as an eco-tourism destination for nature lovers, today (20 July) at 3:00 p.m. by Minister of Environment Naseer Ahmed and Secretary to the Ministry of Environment Dr. Anil Jasinghe. NIFS-Popham Arboretum is situated about two-and-a-half kilometres away from Dambulla along the Kandalama road.  This unique site was owned by an Englishman, F.H. (Sam) Popham, who gifted it to the National Institute of Fundamental Studies (NIFS) in 1989 to carry out research and educational activities.

title: SC dismisses public interest litigation
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court dismissed a public interest litigation which challenged alleged violations of Fundamental Rights following an attack on Galle Face protesters on 9 May 2022. The Petition was filed by Phillip Dissanayake, the Executive Director of the Right to Life Human Rights Centre, and another individual. They claimed that the authorities had violated the Fundamental Rights of protesters on 9 May 2022. According to the petitioners, the Police had failed to take necessary action during the incidents at Galle Face Green, where protesters were attacked by a group of people, as well as subsequent violent incidents throughout the country. Justices S. Thurairaja, Yasantha Kodagoda, and Arjuna Obeyesekere, rejected the application after considering the preliminary objections raised by the Attorney General. Senior State Counsel Shaminda Wickrema, representing the respondents, raised several Preliminary Objections during the hearing. These objections included the petitioners not adhering to the required time limit, misrepresentation of vital facts, lack of substantiating facts for the allegations made, and the petitioners not approaching the Court with clean hands. The respondents named in the petition were the Minister of Public Security, the Chairman and members of the Police Commission, the IGP, and ten SDIGs, including Western Province SDIG Deshabandu Tennakoon. Senior Counsel Lakshan Dias represented the petitioners, while SSC Shaminda Wickrema, assisted by SC Jemiah Sourjah and Attorney-at-Law Haajer Azhar, appeared for the respondents.

title: Relatives of Muslim Covid-19 victims to go to Courts over cremations
author: Author not found
Content: Relatives of Muslim Covid-19 victims, whose bodies were cremated based on recommendations by the Committee of Experts, are preparing to take legal action against the committee members Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Rauff Hakeem revealed yesterday (19). Speaking in Parliament, Hakeem stressed that the committee members had advised the cremation of Covid-19 victims’ bodies, disregarding any scientific justification, despite other countries opting for different approaches. He accused the Committee of Experts of committing a hate crime against the Muslim community and announced that the affected relatives would initiate lawsuits against the committee members. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Path to recovery long, SL must stay the course
author: Author not found
Content: World Bank (WB) Country Director for Maldives, Nepal and Sri Lanka, Faris Hadad-Zervos called the development partners and others to work together to ensure that the Sri Lankan Government stays the course on difficult reforms and that the next two years will be critical for Sri Lanka’s economic recovery. Speaking on the topic during a Press Club event, titled ‘Towards Sri Lanka’s Recovery: Green, Resilient and Inclusive Development’ organised by the Sri Lanka Press Institute at the Hilton Colombo on 18 July, he pointed out that the dramatic increase in poverty and vulnerability has wiped-out decades-long human capital gains and pointed out that there is now a serious learning crisis in the country. For example, he said, only 14% of Grade Three students have acquired minimum competency in literacy and only 15% in numeracy.” These harrowing circumstances for the country and its people demand deep reforms to stabilise the economy and bold action to protect the poor and vulnerable. “Many more people are just one shock away from poverty and the World Bank has estimated that 5.7 per cent of the population lives less than 10% above the poverty line, and a further 5.6 per cent between 10 and 20 per cent above the poverty line due to Sri Lanka’s worst economic crisis in decades,” he underscored. There have been some signs of stability in the past few months compared to 2022 he added.  Inflation is trending downwards from 69.8% in September 2022 to 12% in June 2023, he stressed. Further, Market interest rates are also declining as the uncertainty over domestic debt restructuring wanes and the foreign exchange liquidity picture has also improved but yet, this is not the end of the road. The path to recovery is long and Sri Lanka must stay the course. He also said that the people of Sri Lanka have demonstrated incredible resilience in the face of these extraordinary challenges he pointed out adding that was demonstrated during acute shortages of necessities last year of food, medicines, and cooking gas. People supported each other and found innovative solutions to overcome difficulties. He also said in just one year, Sri Lanka has made good progress in addressing severe challenges facing the economy and the country is now in an economic recovery phase. Some difficult reforms have been implemented and economic recovery has started. Congratulating the Government on securing the International Monetary Fund (IMF) Extended Fund Facility, the parliamentary approval of the Domestic Debt Restructuring, and securing international financial support from the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank, he added that the government has committed to an ambitious reform agenda and implemented some difficult and necessary reforms, including tax reforms, cost-reflective utility pricing, a stronger social safety net, and debt restructuring to stabilise the economy. The key downside risk is a prolonged debt restructuring process, which would lead to greater uncertainty. Slow or uneven implementation of the reform agenda could further delay the recovery process and the return of confidence in the Sri Lankan economy. Hadad-Zervos expressed concerns about the scarring effects of Sri Lanka’s severe economic crisis on growth, income, and jobs. He warned that the problem could lead to a higher emigration rate among high-skilled individuals and result in families withdrawing children from school. Also, struggling companies might sell vital assets, reducing the country’s capacity to grow and generate jobs and income. To prevent the vulnerable from slipping deeper into poverty, social protection reforms need careful implementation. The World Bank is committed to supporting the government in its reform path, offering USD 700 million in financing support through the RESET DPO and the Social Protection project. The Country Partnership Framework (CPF) outlines a two-phased approach. In the initial 18-24 months, the focus will be on urgent macro-fiscal and structural reforms, protecting human capital, and supporting vulnerable populations. After this, with successful reform implementation and international financial support, the focus will shift to investments in longer-term development needs, promoting private sector job creation and building resilience to climate and external shocks. The WB official suggested five essential actions for Sri Lanka’s recovery, including shifting to a more productive and outward-looking economy by unlocking untapped export potential and attracting better investments. He also emphasized the need to transform economic governance, address competitiveness constraints, and improve the governance of State Owned Enterprises. Strengthening the social protection system, prioritizing investments in human capital, and enhancing access and quality of Tertiary and Vocational Education and Training (TVET) for skills development were also deemed critical for sustainable development and growth. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Sakvithi, wife ordered to pay Rs 1.6Bin in stalments
author: Author not found
Content: Sakvithi Ranasinghe, and his wife, Kumari Anuradhani who pleaded guilty to charges of committing a criminal breach of trust concerning Rs 1.6 billion in depositors’ funds with Sakvithi Housing and Construction (Pvt.) Ltd, were ordered to pay the money in instalments by Colombo High Court Judge Adithya Patabandige.  Under the agreed-upon plan, Sakvithi Ranasinghe and his wife will repay 60% of the total amount, amounting to Rs 1.6 billion, within a span of 20 months. The initial payment of Rs 5 million has already been made before the Colombo High Court, and the second instalment is scheduled to be paid on 24 August. High Court Judge Adithya Patabendige has convicted the two accused, and the final verdict will be passed once the repayment plan is successfully concluded. BY Hansi Nanayakkara
