title: Path to recovery long, SL must stay the course
author: Author not found
Content: World Bank (WB) Country Director for Maldives, Nepal and Sri Lanka, Faris Hadad-Zervos called the development partners and others to work together to ensure that the Sri Lankan Government stays the course on difficult reforms and that the next two years will be critical for Sri Lanka’s economic recovery. Speaking on the topic during a Press Club event, titled ‘Towards Sri Lanka’s Recovery: Green, Resilient and Inclusive Development’ organised by the Sri Lanka Press Institute at the Hilton Colombo on 18 July, he pointed out that the dramatic increase in poverty and vulnerability has wiped-out decades-long human capital gains and pointed out that there is now a serious learning crisis in the country. For example, he said, only 14% of Grade Three students have acquired minimum competency in literacy and only 15% in numeracy.” These harrowing circumstances for the country and its people demand deep reforms to stabilise the economy and bold action to protect the poor and vulnerable. “Many more people are just one shock away from poverty and the World Bank has estimated that 5.7 per cent of the population lives less than 10% above the poverty line, and a further 5.6 per cent between 10 and 20 per cent above the poverty line due to Sri Lanka’s worst economic crisis in decades,” he underscored. There have been some signs of stability in the past few months compared to 2022 he added.  Inflation is trending downwards from 69.8% in September 2022 to 12% in June 2023, he stressed. Further, Market interest rates are also declining as the uncertainty over domestic debt restructuring wanes and the foreign exchange liquidity picture has also improved but yet, this is not the end of the road. The path to recovery is long and Sri Lanka must stay the course. He also said that the people of Sri Lanka have demonstrated incredible resilience in the face of these extraordinary challenges he pointed out adding that was demonstrated during acute shortages of necessities last year of food, medicines, and cooking gas. People supported each other and found innovative solutions to overcome difficulties. He also said in just one year, Sri Lanka has made good progress in addressing severe challenges facing the economy and the country is now in an economic recovery phase. Some difficult reforms have been implemented and economic recovery has started. Congratulating the Government on securing the International Monetary Fund (IMF) Extended Fund Facility, the parliamentary approval of the Domestic Debt Restructuring, and securing international financial support from the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank, he added that the government has committed to an ambitious reform agenda and implemented some difficult and necessary reforms, including tax reforms, cost-reflective utility pricing, a stronger social safety net, and debt restructuring to stabilise the economy. The key downside risk is a prolonged debt restructuring process, which would lead to greater uncertainty. Slow or uneven implementation of the reform agenda could further delay the recovery process and the return of confidence in the Sri Lankan economy. Hadad-Zervos expressed concerns about the scarring effects of Sri Lanka’s severe economic crisis on growth, income, and jobs. He warned that the problem could lead to a higher emigration rate among high-skilled individuals and result in families withdrawing children from school. Also, struggling companies might sell vital assets, reducing the country’s capacity to grow and generate jobs and income. To prevent the vulnerable from slipping deeper into poverty, social protection reforms need careful implementation. The World Bank is committed to supporting the government in its reform path, offering USD 700 million in financing support through the RESET DPO and the Social Protection project. The Country Partnership Framework (CPF) outlines a two-phased approach. In the initial 18-24 months, the focus will be on urgent macro-fiscal and structural reforms, protecting human capital, and supporting vulnerable populations. After this, with successful reform implementation and international financial support, the focus will shift to investments in longer-term development needs, promoting private sector job creation and building resilience to climate and external shocks. The WB official suggested five essential actions for Sri Lanka’s recovery, including shifting to a more productive and outward-looking economy by unlocking untapped export potential and attracting better investments. He also emphasized the need to transform economic governance, address competitiveness constraints, and improve the governance of State Owned Enterprises. Strengthening the social protection system, prioritizing investments in human capital, and enhancing access and quality of Tertiary and Vocational Education and Training (TVET) for skills development were also deemed critical for sustainable development and growth. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Sakvithi, wife ordered to pay Rs 1.6Bin in stalments
author: Author not found
Content: Sakvithi Ranasinghe, and his wife, Kumari Anuradhani who pleaded guilty to charges of committing a criminal breach of trust concerning Rs 1.6 billion in depositors’ funds with Sakvithi Housing and Construction (Pvt.) Ltd, were ordered to pay the money in instalments by Colombo High Court Judge Adithya Patabandige.  Under the agreed-upon plan, Sakvithi Ranasinghe and his wife will repay 60% of the total amount, amounting to Rs 1.6 billion, within a span of 20 months. The initial payment of Rs 5 million has already been made before the Colombo High Court, and the second instalment is scheduled to be paid on 24 August. High Court Judge Adithya Patabendige has convicted the two accused, and the final verdict will be passed once the repayment plan is successfully concluded. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: NHSL Laboratory staff stages flash walkout
author: Author not found
Content: Laboratory services of the National Hospital Colombo staged a flash walkout, making five demands, of which the immediate removal of the incumbent Head of the Microbiology Unit to hand the position over to another Consultant Specialist and taking measures to urgently amend the faulty way in which additional allowances were being recommended were predominant.  President of the College of Medical Laboratory Science Sri Lanka (CMLSSL), Ravi Kumudesh, yesterday (19), said despite the agreement reached last week with the Director General of Health Services (DGHS) who pledged to take necessary measures to ensure the smooth flow of laboratory services at the NHSL, they continued to be hindered by unnecessary interference of those same officials even a week later. He said the trade union action which they had decided on had been temporarily shelved last week owing to the agreement which had been reached with the DGHS in the presence of the Deputy Director of National Hospital Colombo. Kumudesh said the chief demand had been the removal of the incumbent department head to appoint another Consultant Specialist to the post. However, it has been noted that the incumbent head, who is a Consultant Microbiologist was accused of holding onto the position by force for a lengthy period.   The protest which was staged in front of the office of the DDG-NHSL dispersed after he (the DDG-NHSL) agreed to discuss the implementation of the agreement that had been reached with the DGHS at noon today (20). By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Doctors slam Keheliya’s ‘funeral parlour’ comments
author: Author not found
Content: The Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA) condemned Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella for his comments regarding funeral parlours outside hospitals instead of thinking of saving every human life that could be saved. President of the MCPA, Dr. Chamal Sanjeeva, lambasting Minister Rambukwella yesterday (19), said his comments were an insult to all politicians in the country. According to the criteria of the World Health Organization (WHO), the responsibility of a country’s health system was to save every human life that could be saved. “Even during the most dangerous pandemic, great politicians in other countries declared that they would dedicate themselves to saving every human life they could save. They did not make such comments regarding the number of patients that died,” he said. It was announced in Parliament that the Health Ministry had spent half of its allocations from the 2023 Budget on emergency purchases of pharmaceuticals. The MCPA President noted that he had continuously pointed out during the past few months that high costs were incurred through emergency purchases of medicinal drugs. “It is clear now that the island’s Health Ministry is bankrupt as a result of spending such large amounts of money on emergency purchases,” he added. Dr. Sanjeeva lamented that the silent policy that was being observed by the President in view of the audit reports on the Health Ministry’s questionable corrupt expenditures on buying large quantities of antibiotics, surgical equipment, inhalers and insulin paying several times more than the stipulated price was unbelievable. The MCPA President warned that he would discuss with legal organisations what course of action needed to be taken against the human and economic killings that were taking place under the incumbent Health Minister and his officials. Further, he said all civil organisations would be rallied to create awareness amongst the national and international institutions, embassies and high commissions about the collapse of the State health system. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Launches Corporate Anthem
author: Author not found
Content: BMICH, Sri Lanka’s most recognisable and iconic landmark launched the Corporate Anthem at its 50th Anniversary which was celebrated recently. The Anthem was sung by the BMICH Staff Choir during the ceremony attended by President Ranil Wickremesinghe, Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena, Chairperson of the Bandaranaike National Memorial Foundation (BNMF), former President Chandrika Bandaranaike Kumaratunga and other dignitaries.  “We are honoured to launch the Corporate Anthem during the 50th Anniversary Celebrations and it was very special as the Anthem was vocalised by our very own Staff Choir,” said Sunil Dissanayake – Chief Executive, BMICH. Set in a sprawling site, 15 well-laid-out and spacious car parks that can accommodate 3,000 vehicles at a given time, and well-maintained landscaped gardens, BMICH is Sri Lanka’s largest and Asia’s very first purpose-built Convention Centre with ultra-modern facilities. BMICH is situated in one of the most prestigious locations in Colombo. BMICH won the South Asian Travel Award (SATA) Gold in 2016, Silver in 2017, and Gold again in 2018, 2019, 2020 and 2022 respectively. In 2016 BMICH also won the Quality ERA Geneva Gold Award and the Platinum Award in Paris in 2017.

title: 2nd Stage of Deegawapiya Stupa Restoration Begins
author: Author not found
Content: The 2nd  Stage of the Deegawapiya Stupa Restoration Project was launched by placing a symbolic brick by Gen. Kamal Gunaratne, the Initiator of the ‘Deegawapiya Aruna Trust’ and first Trustee, at the Deegawapiya premises, on 10 July. Gen. Gunaratne, the driving force behind the entire Project since its beginning, paid homage to the Chief Prelate of the Deegawapiya Raja Maha Viharaya Ven. Mahaoya Sobitha Thera on his arrival.  A brief discussion related to the progress of the restoration projects was also held during the session. The three-day preparation for the second stage saw various customary rituals associated with the sacred construction including an all-night Pirith chanting that culminated on Monday 10th, followed by alms giving to Maha Sangha, at the venue.   The visiting delegation reviewed peripheral constructions in the site while paying attention to the Shrine Hall and the Relic House which are being erected at a rapid pace.   The project is funded by the ‘Deegawapiya Aruna Trust Fund’ which is generously supported by philanthropists. Devotees who are eager to witness the former glory of Deegawapiya Stupa with the naked eye and to extend their generous supportive hands canobtain details through the Deegawapiya website www.deegawapiya.lk, [email protected] or, contact– 011 2430860-78. On completion of the programme at Deegawapiya, the delegation also delved into the progress of the ‘Neelagiri Maha Seya’ restoration project, which has reached up to 41 ft. high from the ground level, as of today. These Stupa restoration projects are in progress under the supervision of the Department of Archaeology and relevant State institutions while preserving the ancient value and former glory of the respective sacred sites. The Maha Sangha including the Asst. Coordinating Director, Pirivena Education in Eastern Province, Ven. Kirindiwela Sri Somarathana and Chief Incumbent, Pothubandana Raja Maha Viharaya Mahaoya Jinarathana Thera, Army Commander Lt. Gen. Vikum Liyanage, Air Force Commander Air Marshal Udeni Rajapaksa, Add’l DG Academics and Director, Architectural Conservation, Dept. of Archaeology Prasanna Ratnayake, Commander Security Forces HQ East Maj. Gen. Darshana Wijesekara, Military Liaison Officer, Ministry of Defence, Brig. Dammika Welagedara,  Regional and respective Project Officers, Architects, Archaeologists, Engineers and Police officers were also present during the visit.

title: Dep. HC of India pays farewell call on State Minister of Defence
author: Author not found
Content: Deputy High Commissioner of India, Vinod Kurian Jacob paid a farewell call on the State Minister of Defence, Premitha Bandara Tennakoon at the State Minister’s Office on Tuesday (18). The State Minister extended a warm welcome to the Indian Deputy HC and later had a cordial discussion with him. The Indian Diplomat conveyed his gratitude to the State Minister for his cooperation and assistance in maintaining the existing cordial bilateral military diplomacy. During the occasion, State Minister presented a memento to the outgoing Deputy HC  of India. Lt. Col. Puneet Sushil, Asst. Defence Adviser to the High Commission of India was also present at the occasion.

title: A Resounding Success Across SAARC
author: Author not found
Content: The Inaugural Annual Academic Conference of the Sri Lankan Society for Vascular Surgery, ‘SLSVS_23’, brought together the crème de la crème of Sri Lanka’s Vascular Surgical community. This highly anticipated event took place on 12 and 13 May 2023 at the elegant Balmoral, Kingsbury Hotel. Under the Presidency of Prof. Mandika Wijeyaratne, Professor of Surgery, University of Colombo, the Conference surpassed all expectations by providing a platform for esteemed scholars from Bangladesh, India, Nepal, Oman, Pakistan and Sri Lanka to exchange ideas, showcase their work, and foster collaborations in the field of vascular surgery. With the theme ‘Regaining Blood Flow’ – A SAARC Destination, the Conference not only pushed the boundaries of academic discourse and furthered the pursuit of knowledge in vascular surgery, but also built bonds between the vascular societies of the SAARC region. SLSVS_23 was a landmark occasion for many reasons. On one aspect the meeting was building friendships and fostering collaboration regionally and on the other, it was an event to honour and tribute to the greats of vascular surgery in Sri Lanka. The speciality of vascular surgery in Sri Lanka is growing from strength to strength, both in numbers and through its impact on the country and its healthcare service. The highlight of the Conference was the Inauguration Ceremony, graced by Chief Guest, Prof.  M. D. Lamawansa, Vice Chancellor, University of Peradeniya and current President, SAARC Surgical Care Society as well as the Guest of Honour, Dr Narendra Pinto, Past President, SAARC Surgical Care Society. In the words of Isaac Newton, “If we have seen further, it is only by sitting on the shoulders of giants”. The Inauguration Ceremony saw two such giants in Vascular Surgery being recognised for their outstanding contribution to the field of Vascular Surgery; Prof. Channa Ratnatunga, Emeritus Professor, University of Peradeniya and Prof. A.H. Sheriffdeen, Emeritus Professor, University of Colombo were awarded Lifetime Achievement Awards. The climax of the evening was the Inaugural A.H. Sheriffdeen Oration. Prof. Mandika Wijeyaratne, Professor of Surgery, Colombo and President of the Sri Lankan Society for Vascular Surgery, delivered the prestigious inaugural A. H. Sheriffdeen Oration, paying tribute to Prof. Sheriffdeen’s groundbreaking contributions and highlighting his impact on the development of vascular surgery in Sri Lanka over the years. Having been his protégé for over 30 years (and continuing), the oration served as a celebration of Prof. Sheriffdeen’s remarkable life, tireless efforts, and exemplary work ethic in advancing the field to what it is known for in the country today. Vascular surgery is a subspecialty of surgery that deals with blood vessels in the human body. The arteries transport the blood from the heart to the rest of the body and the veins bring back the distributed blood back to the heart. With Sri Lanka compounded by an ever-ageing population, an epidemic of diabetes mellitus, and an increase in tobacco use vascular diseases such as diabetic foot disease, critical leg ischemia leading to major lower limb amputation, stroke, aneurysms and varicose veins related issues are exponentially rising. ‘SLSVS_23’ – the meeting, led by Congress Chair Dr. Thushan Gooneratne, Consultant Vascular Surgeon, NHSL, was conducted over two days, focused on these issues and was a tremendous success. 25 foreign delegates took part in the meeting as resource persons from 8 different countries with 20 of them taking part in person. Together with fellow vascular surgeons of Sri Lanka, the start-studded list of renowned experts from the local and international faculty, shared their valuable knowledge and research findings, highlighting cutting-edge advancements in deep venous disease, aortic surgery, superficial venous disease, vascular trauma, vascular access, acute limb ischemia, and chronic limb-threatening ischemia. Their presence provided a global perspective and allowed enriched discussions much to the awe of the eager audience. Initially limited to only 60 participants, Registration had to be extended to over 100 participants owing to popular demand. The meeting saw them thoroughly engaging with fellow academics, exchanging ideas, and discussing the latest advancements in the field. An exceptional pre-congress workshop on endovenous laser ablation, a cutting-edge technique in the treatment of venous disease, was facilitated by Dr. Ravul Jindal (Bangalore, India), the President-Elect of the World Union of Phlebology, an esteemed expert in the field. This hands-on experience offered participants the opportunity to learn and refine their skills in this innovative procedure. Consultants and trainees who attended the workshop expressed their immense satisfaction with the hands-on skills and practical knowledge gained from the experience. History was created at SLSVS_23. The Conference marked the establishment of the first-ever, SAARC Society for Vascular Surgery, a momentous occasion that created an international platform for vascular surgeons across South Asia to collaborate, share knowledge, and advance the field. This Conference served as the inaugural event for the society, with the election of Prof. Mandika Wijeyaratne as the Inaugural President and Prof. Rezni Cassim as the Inaugural Secretary, setting the stage for future growth and achievements in the field of vascular surgery in Sri Lanka. In addition to the academic sessions, the conference hall showcased the latest advancements in vascular surgery through the participation of pharmaceutical and medical device companies. These exhibitors presented cutting-edge technologies, innovative devices and products, providing a conducive environment for networking and forging collaborations, with many participants expressing enthusiasm about potential joint ventures and research partnerships. As the Conference drew to a close, Country Awards were presented to Bangladesh, India, Nepal, and Pakistan in appreciation of their significant contributions to the Conference as well as towards the formation of the SAARC Society for Vascular Surgery. With a tremendous sense of success, the Conference came to an end, leaving a lasting impact on attendees. The gathering of remarkable minds in vascular surgery of the entire SAARC region under one roof, for the first time in history, united by the vision of promoting research, collaboration, and a yearning for future advancements, proved to be a truly inspiring weekend. Through its diverse range of topics, engaging sessions, and immersive cultural experiences, the SLSVS_23 fostered new connections, inspired innovative ideas, and contributed to the future of vascular surgery in the region and beyond. Prof. Mandika Wijeyaratne said at the inauguration “As a region, it is clear that we have our own intricacies and it’s an opportunity to look beyond simply our institution, or country and think regional.  To take upon issues that are common to all of us and to share resources in finding common solutions. Knowledge and resources can be shared; research in collaboration is the way forward”. Quite fittingly the theme of SLSVS_23 – “Regaining blood flow – A SAARC Destination” resonated with it. By Thushan Gooneratne

title: Before TRC, do follow-ups on established emblematic cases
author: Author not found
Content: The Batticaloa Peace Committee, Batticaloa Justice Walkers, and Family Members of the Disappeared said, before establishing the Truth and Reconciliation mechanisms, the Government must follow -up on the already-established findings related to a number of emblematic cases in Batticaloa, that were presented to the  Presidential Commissions and take concrete action on them. They also demanded to fast-track process to provide every affected family member with copies of key documents related to the incidents or losses they have experienced which includes copies of police reports, records from various public commissions, and complaint records submitted to the Human Rights Commission (HRC), among others. They said in cases where the original police complaint cannot be located in the police records, they propose recording new complaints linked to the original ones under this accelerated process. They also demanded, in the absence or death of the family members who originally had made complaints, recognise the right of the next of kin in that family who is continuing the struggle for truth and justice to claim these documents. The documents issued under the fast-track process must be guaranteed to have the same credibility for legal and administrative purposes as a police report made at the time of the event. He also noted that as the follow-up on the already-established findings related to a number of emblematic cases in Batticaloa, which were presented to Presidential Commissions on numerous occasions with clear and credible evidence, including eyewitness accounts. Thorough inquires and investigations must be conducted within one year, and results of these must be made public.  They also recalled that many families have already identified to numerous commissions which camps their loved ones were taken. A list of those who are responsible mast be published. This way, families can make specific demands with regards to the whereabouts of their loved ones, and for overall accountability for enforced disappearance. Also brought to light was that credible inquiries must be initiated into the role and culpability of all armed groups in abductions and enforced disappearances, including by groups such as PLOTE, EPDP, Karuna Faction and TMVP that worked alongside the government forces.  Meanwhile, multiple civil society groups have written to the Government and even submitted a copy of the letter of concern to Foreign Minister Ali Sabry, expressing the victim community’s lack of confidence in any local commission or tribunal, including the recent National Unity and Reconciliation Commission (NURC). These commissions have a history of obstructing truth-seeking and preventing the victims from attaining accountability. The groups have also highlighted that prominent officials and politicians consistently affirm their commitment to supporting war heroes and patriotic forces. The civil society said if the Government is interested in winning the public’s trust it should review the existing recommendations from previous commissions and develop a plan to implement them with a time frame. Another group has also written to the Government stating that the Truth and Reconciliation Commission by the Government should with the support of the International Community urged to fast-track a process of giving every affected family member copies of the key documents that relate to the incidents or losses they have experienced. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Man arrested with 4 kg stolen copper telephone wire
author: Author not found
Content: Kandy Police arrested a man involved in cutting and melting copper telephone wires to sell them within the Kandy city limits. Four kilogrammes of melted copper wire in the suspect’s possession was seized. The three-wheeler used by the suspect to transport the stolen copper was also seized by Police. Similar incidents have been reported in recent times, where telephone cables belonging to Sri Lanka Telecom in Kandy were cut and sold in various areas of Colombo. Police have stated that several more suspects are expected to be arrested in connection with these incidents. Previous Police investigations have uncovered that valuable copper wire worth millions of rupees was being cut on deserted roads in locations such as Aniwatta, Dodamwala, Thabodharamaya Road, Light House Road and Hanthana. By K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Hearing fixed for 14 November
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Damith Thotawatta, on Tuesday (18), dismissed initial objections raised by the Defence, pertaining to the vehicle misappropriation case, filed against former Minister and former head of the Development Lottery Board (DLB) Sarana Gunawardena, by the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC). The defendant’s lawyers said the case being filed against their client was contrary to the law. They further said, the prosecution had filed a slew of other cases as well against their client in High Court and observed that a similar case, filed against the defendant in the Colombo Chief Magistrate’s Court, had been withdrawn, at the CIABOC’s own volition. Considering the submissions, Judge Thotawatta rejected the initial objections raised by the Defence and fixed the hearing of evidence in the trial, to 14 November. The accused was present in Court when the case was taken up. The Bribery Commission indicted Gunawardena, before the HC on charges of misappropriation of State vehicles while serving as the Chairman of DLB and thereby causing a loss of revenue to the State. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: LRH doctors call off strike
author: Author not found
Content: Doctors of the Lady Ridgeway Hospital (LRH) for Children called off their strike at the Out Patients’ Department (OPD) yesterday (19) afternoon with a pledge from the Hospital Administration that it would take measures to fulfil two of their demands. One of the demands was transferring  three medical officers serving under the specialist doctor in ward 8B to another ward. Media Spokesman for the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA) Dr. Chamil Wijesinghe sad his outfit had demanded that the three Medical Officers who were serving under the said specialist be transferred to another ward in the Hospital and completing the inquiry against the said specialist doctor and acting on the recommendations of that inquiry. They warned however that should the Administration fail to take action in this regard the LRH OPD doctors would resume their strike at 12 noon today (20). Earlier in the day doctors of the LRH OPD struck work from 8.00 a.m. However, one or two doctors were on duty while Dr. Wijesinghe held that their strike action had been a success. He blamed the Director General Health Services (DGHS) and the Hospital Director who is also a Deputy Director General in the Health Ministry for their inability to resolve the situation and preventing a strike in the first place. Even the inquiry report is still pending even after the lapse of three weeks, he accused.   By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: KKS- Karaikkal ferry service on hold indefinitely
author: Author not found
Content: The Kankesanturai-Karaikkal (KKS-KKL) ferry services have been put on hold indefinitely and the ferry service from KKS is now diverted to the Port of Nagapattinam, a natural port located on the shores of the Bay of Bengal in Tamil Nadu, India, mainly due to absence of a comprehensive policy framework outlining safety measures and clear standards for the ferry service, including provisions for a place of refuge in case of distress. While Sri Lanka has given its approval for the operation of the KKS-KKL ferry, India, which has not operated ferry services for almost 40 years, needs to update its policies regarding quality passenger services, especially safety measures. The operator of the ferry service, Managing Director of IndSri Ferry Services Pvt Ltd, S. Niranjan Nandagopan, emphasised the importance of framing policies to ensure the safety and quality of the passenger service has come to light and as he was proceeding with obtaining approval from Indian officials he found more bottlenecks in getting clearances and approvals. Nandagopan, who is the cleared operator for IndSri, has already rented a passenger ship from Singapore, where he is domiciled. He pays a monthly rent of USD 50,000 for the ship, and he aims to commence the service between Nagapattinam and KKS by July 2023 failing which by the end of this year or January 2024. The policy framework is expected to be finalised soon, and Nandagopan told Ceylon Today that he is eagerly waiting for it to be in place. “One of the essential aspects that need to be included in the policy is a clause about a place of refuge, specifying the action to be taken if the ferry encounters distress at sea. Both the coastal guards of India and the Sri Lanka Navy need to agree on the responsibility of providing assistance in their respective waters. These measures came to light during the approval-seeking process,” he added. The governments of India and Sri Lanka announced the commencement of ferry services, targeted for the first week of July or no later than August 2023. The Union Ministry of Ports, Shipping, and Waterways of the Puducherry Port Department was also involved in the plans to launch a ferry service between KKL and KKS. However, the formulation of policies in several areas has delayed the process. Decisions about the ferry service, such as passenger capacity, vessel class, and craft speed, need to be carefully drafted within the policy framework. Nandagopan added that seeking permission and clearance faced several bottlenecks, and different parties involved in India had difficulties in approving the service due to uncertainties about roles and responsibilities. Now, the focus is on drafting a comprehensive policy framework that will enable the smooth operation of the ferry service. Further, Karaikkal Port, operated by Adani Group, primarily focuses on coal transport and industrial purposes. Due to concerns about passenger safety while leaving KKL, using that port has come to a halt. Finally, India has agreed to commence the ferry service between Nagapattinam Port and KKS, located in the North of Sri Lanka. Nagapattinam Port is about 25 km from KKL, situated in Tamil Nadu, while KKL is part of the Union Territory of Puducherry. Karaikkal Port Private Limited (KPPL) is a deep-water port developed on a Build, Operate, and Transfer format under Public-Private Partnership, awarded by the Government of Puducherry. Since its operations began, the port has handled various cargo, including coal, sugar, cement, fertilisers, project cargo, agro commodities, liquid cargo, and containers and to have a passenger service it was questionable, added Nandagopan. Meanwhile, the Indian High Commission to Colombo, on 17 July, noted that an India-Sri Lanka Joint Committee appointed under MoU on Passenger Transportation by Sea held a virtual meeting on 14 July where Rajesh Kumar Sinha, Additional Secretary, Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Waterways of the Government of India and K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, Secretary, Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation of the Government of Sri Lanka held discussions. The discussions focused on the resumption of ferry services between the two countries connecting mutually agreed points. Both sides agreed that the resumption of ferry services will boost regional trade and tourism and promote stronger people-to-people ties. The Joint Committee identified several areas for mutual cooperation for operationalisation of ferry services in the near future, and desired to take further steps based on mutual understanding. The Joint Committee was recently reconstituted by the Governments of India and Sri Lanka as per the provisions of the bilateral Memorandum of Understanding on Passenger Transportation by Sea, signed in 2011. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: President pledges 13A sans Police Powers
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe, yesterday (18), outlined the plans for devolution, stating that the 13th Amendment to the Constitution will be implemented with full powers except Police Powers. Accordingly, it will be implemented including specified functions in the Provincial Councils List, subject to agreement among Political Parties in Parliament. He was speaking during a meeting with Tamil MPs representing the North and East yesterday (18). During the meeting, attention was paid to the development of the Kanakesanturai Harbour, the Vavuniya, Palaly Airports and the potential establishment of a Ferry Service connecting the Northern Province with South India. Discussions primarily focused on the Water for the North Programme. The key areas of interest included projects related to water management, developing the Poonekery Tank, the River for Jaffna initiative to provide fresh water and increase the water capacity of the Iranamadu Tank, and renewal of small tanks. The President discussed the development of tourism in the North, specifically in Jaffna and Mannar, the promotion of coconut cultivation in Vanni, and the aim to establish Jaffna as a vibrant university town. Wickremesinghe told Tamil MPs from the North and East that the Anti-Corruption Law will undergo Committee Stage amendments in Parliament on 19 July and the Supreme Court’s proposed amendments will be considered. The Development Plan for the North aims to harness the renewable energy potential of the region, particularly through the production of green hydrogen and ammonia. This initiative seeks to attract investment and enhance the Port of Colombo. Additionally, the plan designates Pooneryn New Town as the central hub for the renewable energy economy, fostering concentrated growth in the sector.   By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: STF assistance to control situation – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Transport and Highways Bandula Gunawardana said in Parliament yesterday (18) that the assistance of the STF has been sought as there has been a rise in thefts of iron rods and bolts at Dematagoda, Ratmalana railway yards, and bridges. Due to the inability of railway security personnel and the Police to control the situation, the assistance of the STF will be sought to provide security to these areas, Gunawardana said. The Minister was responding to a question raised by MP Dayasiri Jayasekara regarding the removal of nuts and bolts from the New Kelani Bridge. He said the Police and Criminal Investigation Department (CID) are investigating these incidents. He expressed concern that these organised thefts pose a risk, as the stealing of iron rods from railway tracks could potentially lead to derailments and result in catastrophes. Further, he assured that a comprehensive report containing statistics on stolen items and their costs will be submitted in the near future. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Sajith confirms NCM against Keheliya
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa confirmed in Parliament that a No-Confidence Motion (NCM) will be moved against Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella. Accordingly, signatures for the NCM will be collected today (19). During a heated verbal exchange with Rambukwella, Premadasa announced that the Opposition will present the NCM against him in Parliament promptly. Premadasa alleged a severe shortage of medicines and medical supplies in Sri Lanka. He claimed that several deaths had been reported recently due to administering substandard medication at various hospitals. “People admitted for minor illnesses have died because they were given substandard medication. We urge the authorities to investigate these incidents and prevent further similar occurrences,” he said. Premadasa also called on the authorities to immediately withdraw the questionable medications and take strong action against those responsible for procuring them. He further questioned why Rambukwella remained silent despite repeated incidents of deaths caused by administering substandard medication. The Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) previously announced that an NCM would be moved against Minister Rambukwella due to the sudden deaths occurring in the country and the alleged importation of substandard medicine. Later, it was confirmed that the proposal was unanimously approved by all SJB MPs during its Parliamentary group meeting held on 17 July evening. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Cabinet nod for Prison Administration Bill
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet approved drafting a new Prison Administration Bill based on the preliminary bill prepared by the Law Reforms Committee. The committee was appointed by the former Justice Minister to address the inadequacies of the present Prisons Ordinance, which governs the prison system in Sri Lanka. The need for a new Bill arises from the recognition that the existing provisions of the Prisons Ordinance do not meet the present requirements and fail to comply with the international legal obligations and standards that Sri Lanka is obligated to uphold. In response, the Law Reforms Committee drafted a preliminary Bill proposing amendments to the existing Ordinance. Consequently, the Minister of Justice, Prison Affairs, and Constitutional Reforms presented a proposal to Cabinet, seeking approval to direct the Legal Draftsman to prepare a new Prison Administration Bill based on the preliminary Bill. Cabinet approved the preparation of the new Bill.

title: Civil Rights groups demand Keheliya’s resignation
author: Author not found
Content: With the number of medicinal drug-related incidents escalating, the Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA) and several other civil rights groups and trade unions have given an ultimatum to Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella to step down from his post within the next few days. MCPA President Chamal Sanjeewa, staging a Satyagraha (sit-down protest) outside the Health Ministry amidst heavy security provided to the Ministry premises, demanded that the Minister step down from his post failing which the civil organisations threatened to storm its premises. Accusing Rambukwella of seriously jeopardising the free health service in the island by bringing substandard drugs and giving unregistered drugs to patients, Sanjeewa warned that his outfit would rally all professional and civil organisations by next week and breach the walls of the Ministry if the Minister did not step down. “Former Minister of Health Channa Jayasumana ignored my warnings last year regarding mounting public dissatisfaction against former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa which resulted in the public uprising against him,” the MCPA President said.  “In the same way, even though the present Minister of Health is working for the survival of the free health service the poor administration and management of his officials who cannot even act according to the instructions, would lead to growing discomfort amongst people. If there is a conspiracy against the Government, as Minister Rambukwella himself says, he should consider himself responsible for it,” Dr. Sanjeewa said. He urged the President to pay heed to the warning and focus on solving the problem without distancing himself from the people. Convener of the National Movement Against Bribery and Corruption (NMBC), Jamuni Kamantha, lamented that the public had lost faith in the free health service. “Minister Rambukwella has been unable to resolve the crisis in the State health service while patients seeking treatment from the free health service have only lost their lives during his tenure as the Health Minister,” he said.  Civil Rights activist Ajantha Perera demanded the Minister quit his post as even the lives of infants and children’s lives were at stake owing to a decision taken by the Health Minister, Health Secretary and Director General of Health Services (DGHS) to use unregistered drugs. “The Minister does not have a moral right to occupy the post and the damage he has done to the health system should be compensated immediately and punished accordingly,” she said. Civil Aociety activist, Asela Sampath, urged people to rally together to take legal action against the Health Minister, the Health Secretary and the DGHS for the present crisis. He warned that simultaneous protests would be held outside the US Embassy, the World Health Organization (WHO) Office in Colombo, UNICEF and the Indian High Commission if the Minister failed to understand the message given through the Satyagraha and acted arbitrarily. Religious leaders, lawyers, trade unions and civil organisations participated in the sit-down protest.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: State officials promptly executed Cabinet decision – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Transport and Highways Bandula Gunawardana, yesterday (18), attributed the swift removal of the Crudia zeylanica tree in Daraluwa to the efficiency of State officials who promptly executed the Cabinet decision to remove it. He said this during yesterday’s parliamentary sittings in response to MP Wimal Weerawansa’s query as to how the tree was removed so quickly. Weerawansa raised a question regarding the quick removal of the ‘Sri Lanka Legume’ tree (Crudia zeylanica), which had obstructed the construction of the Central Expressway in Daraluwa, Veyangoda. Curious about the quick disappearance of the tree, Weerawansa directly asked the minister, “Minister, can you explain how you made the tree vanish so soon?” Gunawardana replied, “It is due to the efficiency of the State officials who carried out the Cabinet decision shortly after it was made.” By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date:  Ratnapura High Court Judge Lanka Jayaratne, on Monday (17), activated an order issued by former Ratnapura High Court Judge Anoma Jayawardena 15 years ago and sentenced nine accused who had been charged with torching of houses and properties of UNP activists in connection with the slaying of former lawmaker Nalanda Ellawala 26 years ago to terms of five and a half years to seven and a half years of Rigorous Imprisonment (RI). The case had been heard before the said Court since 1997 and during that period out of the nine accused, three had passed away. Following the verdict in the trial being delivered by the then Ratnapura High Court Judge Anoma Jayawardena, the report containing the verdict had been obtained by the former Secretary to the Justice Ministry under the Provisions of the Law Books Reviews Act. Subsequently, it was reported in the media that the said report was misplaced and the nine defendants then appealed against their verdict and were enlarged on bail. By K.A.S. Piyathileke – Kuruvita Popular

title: Tariff hike vital to address Water Board’s woes – Jeevan
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Water Supply and Estate Infrastructure Development Jeevan Thondaman announced the increase in water tariffs was a necessary step to address the substantial monthly losses of nearly Rs 2.8 billion and an annual loss of Rs 34 billion of the National Water Supply & Drainage Board (NWSDB). These losses have hindered the Board’s ability to cover operational expenses, service debts, and maintain the quality of water supply services, according to the Minister. Thondaman expressed these views during a media briefing held at the Presidential Media Centre (PMC) yesterday (18). He said the water tariff increase was a necessary step taken to address the critical challenges faced by the NWSDB and ensure clean drinking water for all Sri Lankans. “The increase was driven by several factors, including the surge in electricity tariffs, which significantly contribute to the cost of water production. Additionally, the burden of debt resulting from past capital expenditure to expand water infrastructure, combined with currency depreciation and interest rate hikes, as well as the exponential increase in the cost of raw materials required for water treatment, have added to the financial strain on the NWSDB,” he explained. Thondaman also confirmed that the NWSDB is committed to reviewing the water tariffs in the coming months and implementing a new tariff formula and policy in line with the Government’s commitments to its development partners. “I will take all necessary steps to reduce tariffs in the next revision while ensuring the financial viability of the NWSDB. We are actively exploring cost-saving measures within the NWSDB, such as reducing excess staff and adopting advanced technologies to optimise efficiency and streamline operations. Our goal is to provide efficient and effective water services to everyone while considering the economic challenges faced by our people,” he added. He revealed that there are over 12,000 employees under the NWSDB, with 75 per cent of them being unskilled workers. Thondaman plans to provide skill development opportunities to convert them into skilled workers and enhance their productivity. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Arrested for protesting on Court roof
author: Author not found
Content: A 37-year-old man, who held a protest on the roof of the Kurunegala Courts Complex yesterday (18), was arrested by Kurunegala Headquarters Police. The person claimed he resorted to this action due to the perceived injustice inflicted on him by the Melsiripura Police. He alleged the Melsiripura Police have filed a case against him over documents of a vehicle that is not owned by him. The officers at Kurunegala Headquarters Police utilised a crane from the Kurunegala Municipality Fire Department to safely remove the individual from the roof. By Ravindu Sooriyabandara – Kurunegala

title: LRH doctors threaten token strike
author: Author not found
Content: Noting that they were being pushed into unprecedented trade union action, doctors of the Lady Ridgeway Hospital (LRH) warned they would resort to a token strike in the hospital’s Outpatient Department (OPD) from 8:00 a.m. today (19) against a specialist doctor serving in ward 8B. Secretary of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA), Dr. Haritha Aluthge yesterday (18) said only emergency treatment would be provided at the OPD while all other routine OPD services would not be carried out. He said, “The solution to this issue is in the hands of the Director General of Health Services (DGHS) and we are ready to call off the strike even at the last minute.” However, while the DGHS has promised to resolve the issue even he seems to be intimidated by the Administration of LRH, Dr. Aluthge alleged. Accusing the specialist in Ward 8B of LRH of acting arbitrarily, harassment of ward staff and MBBS doctors serving in the ward, he said complaints to the Hospital’s Director and the Director General of Health Services (DGHS) were of no avail. They were not interested in resolving the issue and were only making empty pledges.  This is not the first time that such complaints have been made against the particular specialist. Dr. Aluthge alleged that such behaviour had been witnessed when the said specialist had served in areas like Karawanella, Avissawella, Negombo, and even when she worked at the LRH previously. “Her actions are such that even medical students do not go to her ward to train under her. Even the Post Graduate Institute of Medicine (PGIM) has stopped sending postgraduate trainees to her ward.” “But for the past two years the GMOA has been requesting a settlement to this issue,” while the DGHS has been making promise after promise, he lamented. He accused the LRH Director of even attempting to create a wrong impression by using a particular media organisation and a particular newspaper. He warned that the Hospital Administration should take the total blame for the strike. “He has failed to carry out the instructions of even the DGHS while the DGHS himself seems to be unable to act on his promise to resolve the matter,” the GMOA Secretary charged. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Not all patients make it out alive – Keheliya
author: Author not found
Content: Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella, yesterday (18), explained why funeral parlours are located near hospitals. Speaking in Parliament, Rambukwella said not all patients admitted to hospitals make it out alive and that is why funeral parlours are located near hospitals. Rambukwella, in response to a query made by Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, said the drug believed to be responsible for the recent death of a young woman at Peradeniya Teaching Hospital is still being used in hospitals islandwide. There are presently over 66,000 vials of this drug in stock nationwide, according to the Minister. The Minister informed Parliament that a total of 145,930 vials of the drug had been distributed to hospitals, with 79,260 vials already utilised. He provided specific figures for certain hospitals, stating that 19,200 vials were sent to Batticaloa Hospital, of which 16,800 had been used, and 12,800 out of 24,000 vials provided to Peradeniya Teaching Hospital had been used. Additionally, 1,800 vials out of 2,400 supplied to Avissawella Hospital and all 50 vials provided to Moratuwa Hospital had been used. The Minister clarified that this particular drug had been registered in Sri Lanka since 2013 and has been in use for 20 years. He also emphasised that the drug was imported by a reputable international company. Rambukwella dismissed allegations that the drug’s quality caused the death, attributing such claims to vested interests seeking to undermine the country’s free healthcare system. The Minister said the specific batch suspected to be linked to the fatality had been withheld for further investigation. Regarding the availability of other drugs, Rambukwella said all 14 life-saving drugs used in the country were sufficiently stocked until December of the present year. However, there is a shortage of 273 out of 850 essential drugs. He assured that 39 essential drugs would be received on the same day as the parliamentary session. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: CID to probe nine bank accounts of Pastor Jerome
author: Author not found
Content: The Colombo Fort Magistrate’s Court granted permission to the CID, yesterday (18), to examine nine bank accounts belonging to Pastor Jerome Fernando, his wife, the Glorious Church, and his company. During the Court proceedings, the CID informed the Court that their investigations have uncovered significant financial transactions, amounting to billions of rupees, through Pastor Jerome’s local bank accounts. This action is part of an ongoing investigation into Pastor Jerome’s speech against religious harmony in the country. The CID has already initiated investigations against Pastor Jerome for his offensive remarks toward other religions. He is accused of committing offenses under Section 291B of the Penal Code and Section 3 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR) Act No. 56 of 2007. It is alleged that on or around 18 May 2023, Jerome Fernando delivered a speech to a large audience where he made ‘derogatory’ statements about Buddhism, Hinduism, and Islam. The CID is also investigating Pastor Jerome Fernando under the Prevention of Money Laundering Act. On the direction of Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage, several private banks have been instructed to provide the CID with all transaction details related to the nine bank accounts for further investigation.

title: Indian ceo Forum meets Chairman of tata Sons in Colombo
author: Author not found
Content: The Board of the Indian CEO Forum-Sri Lanka (ICF) met the Chairman of Tata Sons, Natarajan Chandrasekaran who is on a visit to Sri Lanka. ICF had an interactive meeting with Chandrasekaran and highlighted the ‘positive environment’ opportunities for investments in Sri Lanka. The CEO team led by the Forum’s President, T.S. Prakash, stated that the member companies represent diverse industries and thanked the TATA Group for already having investments in many fields in Sri Lanka and also mentioned that Sri Lanka provides many opportunities for new investments. He said the objective of ICF is to promote economic growth in Sri Lanka through Indian investment, safeguard and strengthen existing economic cooperation, foster new economic ties between India and Sri Lanka, and provide an open forum for business leaders of Indian origin employed with Indian multinationals and Sri Lankan business organisations in Sri Lanka. Chandrasekaran said, “We need to identify the sectors which would help Sri Lanka, one of which is, of course, tourism which has a huge potential. We need to shortlist three other sectors in which India could successfully invest.” Chandrasekaran also mentioned that Sri Lanka is a beautiful country and is looking into understanding the opportunities for investments. Kishore Reddy, Vice President, ICF briefed Chandrasekaran on the ‘Shine Lanka’ initiative of the forum to promote trade and investments. Through this programme, ICF can assist and guide investments into Sri Lanka in various fields and initially will be concentrating on Tourism, IT, Education, Industries and Infrastructure. The Board members of ICF had a very interactive meeting with Chandrasekaran on the stability on the social and economic front with the efforts of the government post the crisis the country had gone through and also discussed the current economic situation, and various fields of investments that can assist Sri Lanka to further grow into a sustainable economy. The Indian CEO Forum – Sri Lanka (ICF), is a registered body with membership constituted by Indian investment in Sri Lanka, Indian heads of multinational companies (MNCs), and Sri Lankan companies. It currently has over 60 members contributing to providing gainful employment to thousands, providing best-in-class management, technical skills, and contributing substantially to Sri Lanka’s foreign exchange earnings. The members have made significant input and support to the Sri Lankan economy by way of bringing substantial investments into the country, export earnings, employment generation, and contribution of treasury through direct and indirect taxes, and building the brand of Sri Lanka to the outside world and making a significant contribution to the local economy. The team included President, ICF, TS Prakash (Umesh Modi Group), Vice President, Kishore Reddy, (Platinum Investments), Past President – Umesh Gautam, (Lanka Ashok Leyland PLC), Dipak Das, (Lanka IOC), Ashish Chandra, (Bharti Airtel), Sanjay Baid (Niru Group), Gaurav Mehta (Powertech), Monisha Abraham (CTC), Samrat Datta ( Taj Hotels)

title: Exploring Sri Lanka’s Path to Tackle Climate-Induced L&D
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Environment of Sri Lanka in partnership with SLYCAN Trust hosted a workshop on climate-induced Loss and Damage (L&D) at the Kingsbury Hotel in Colombo on 10 July. This event was aimed at identifying gaps and needs related to addressing climate-induced L&D in Sri Lanka while building on existing policy processes and programmes of action focused on climate-induced L&D as well as risk management, finance, and transfer to better contribute to national and global processes on addressing needs related to climate-induced L&D. Discussing the importance of identifying key gaps and needs to better address L&D in Sri Lanka, Dr. Anil Jasinghe said the necessity of addressing the issues connected to disaster risk management across the full spectrum rather than addressing standalone concerns, “As a country that is one of the worst affected by climate change, we need to act on climate justice and conduct disaster risk management across the full spectrum rather than focusing only on L&D as a standalone because then we would be limiting ourselves”. He commented that there was a gestation period involved for the work related to L&D, however, we will go ahead with the upcoming 28th meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC)-COP28 in November/December 2023 as it presents an important opportunity to engage in this process in line with Sri Lanka’s climate policies and the tripartite alliance for Sri Lanka’s participation in COP28. Addressing the gathering, Minister of Environment Naseer Ahamed commented on the importance of key stakeholders working together to achieve favourable outcomes related to climate action: “To effectively mitigate the L&D induced by climate change, the research and development aspect is important. To achieve long-term climate resilience,  it is important for Sri Lanka to engage in multi-actor partnerships to guide the way forward. This approach will enable the country to achieve sustainable development.” He said, this was particularly relevant in connection to global processes and climate negotiations under the UNFCCC, such as those related to the Loss and Damage Fund and the Santiago Network for Loss and Damage. Vositha Wijenayake – Executive Director of SLYCAN Trust – mentioned that L&D has become a key focus of climate discussions in the present day. She said, “Although many countries have been highlighting the importance of accounting for L&D induced by climate change since the climate conventions of 1992, the topic had not been seriously considered until recently.” She remarked on five focus areas related to L&D that had been developed in rollout plans since 2013, namely: slow onset events such as sea level and temperature increases, economic losses such as the destruction of our nature reserves, non-economic losses such as the erosion of our culture and heritage, comprehensive risk management and human mobility. Director of Climate Change Secretariat at the Ministry of Environment, Leel Randeni, closed the proceedings by highlighting that this workshop is the first event conducted on L&D under climate action in Sri Lanka and that mechanisms have been developed during the talks. He highlighted that the key elements of the workshop were the active participation of the key stakeholders gathered by filling out the questionnaires and templates and engaging in dialogue with each other.              SLYCAN Trust is an internationally recognised non-profit think tank working on climate change, sustainable development, ecosystem conservation, animal welfare, and social justice. Our work spans the national, regional, and global levels from policy analysis and evidence-based research to on-the-ground implementation.

title: Gampaha Conservation Officer ordered to make submissions
author: Author not found
Content: Gampaha Court No. 2 Magistrate Fathima Zahana, on Tuesday (18), ordered the Gampaha Wildlife Conservation Officer to be present in Court on 21 July to make submissions over the uprooting of a Crudia zeylanica tree situated in Daraluwa, Veyangoda, adjacent to the construction of the Central Expressway. The Gampaha Wildlife Conservation Office had previously informed the Court that the rare tree type had been illegally removed from its location. Counsel Lakdinu Weerasekera, appearing on the instructions of Ven. Udasgiriye Samitha Thera, urged the Court to take up the case yesterday. He said the tree in question had been listed in the Red Data Book as a species threatened with extinction globally. The Counsel said a Cabinet Minister had claimed that the removal of the tree in question had been made collectively by Cabinet. He added that the Gampaha Wildlife Conservation Officer, submitting a B Report to Court, had insisted that a probe had been launched by them already to identify those behind the uprooting of the tree. The Counsel, therefore, requested the Court to issue an order to arrest the suspects behind the removal of the tree as well as seize machines and equipment used for its uprooting as the incident is tantamount to a crime. Considering the submissions, the Court ordered the Duty Officer of the Gampaha Wildlife Conservation Office to produce submissions in this regard on the aforementioned date. By Tony Athukorala – Minuwangoda

title: Employees in favour of restructuring Postal Dept
author: Author not found
Content: Postal and Telecommunication officers have agreed to re-structure the Postal Department; however, they said they were not informed about any Bill or measures being taken for the initiation. During a recent press conference, State Minister of Mass Media Shantha Bandara announced that by the end of this year, a Bill will be presented to Parliament to re-structure the Postal Department. Additionally, a joint project, costing Rs 10 billion, has been planned, involving both the private and public sectors. It is emphasised that the modernization of the Postal Department should take place within the framework of state departments, with job security and improvements in service quality being key considerations. Postal and Telecommunication officers suggested that the Ministry of Mass Media engage in discussions with them, as they represent over 4000 members, to share the plans and progress before submitting the proposed Bill to Parliament. By Sanjana Marzook
