title: Navy Special Ops in Jaffna seas – 16 apprehended
author: Author not found
Content: Special operations conducted by the Navy off Kadaikadu, Nagar Kovil and Chundikulam in Jaffna on 16 and 17 July 2023, led to 16 persons engaging in illegal fishing activities being apprehended. During the operations, the Navy also held four dinghies, diving equipment and fishing gear used for the illegal acts. The Navy carries out regular operations in the coastal and sea areas around the island to prevent illegal fishing activities which threaten the sustainability of fish populations, undermine legitimate fishing industries, and damage marine ecosystems, the Navy said.  As an extension of these efforts, the Naval Detachments Veththalakerni, Mamunai and Chundikulam belonging to the Naval Deployment Veththalakerni in the Northern Naval Command made these apprehensions off Kadaikadu, Nagar Kovil and Chundikulam on 16 and 17 July. Accordingly, the Navy nabbed 16 individuals on charges of night diving without a valid licence using unauthorised nets and light coarse fishing equipment.  Four dinghies, diving equipment and unauthorised fishing gear used by the individuals were also seized. The suspects were identified as residents of China Bay, Trincomalee, Nagar Kovil, Vavuniya, Pudukuduirippu, Mullaitivu, Mannar and Pudumathalan areas, from 16 to 58 years of age. The suspects and their belongings were handed over to the  Fisheries and Aquatic Resources Department in Jaffna for onward legal action.

title: Citizens left high and dry
author: Author not found
Content: The Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) alleged that the Government was prioritising pleasing international organisations at the expense of the well-being of its citizens. Speaking at a media briefing on 16 July, JJB MP Dr. Harini Amarasuriya criticised the Ministry of Labour and Foreign Employment for introducing labour law reforms that she believes cater solely to the expectations of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank, neglecting the needs of the working class in the country. Amarasuriya argued that the new labour law reforms were drafted based on the illusionary concept of a “free economic individual” capable of directly negotiating with employers. She contended that those responsible for drafting these laws were operating under a neo-liberal illusion, mistakenly assuming the existence of free economic individuals in Sri Lanka akin to Western countries. According to Amarasuriya, the negative consequences of the new laws have been camouflaged by appealing terms such as “gender equality.” She suggested that the dangers associated with the implementation of this legal framework are concealed behind these decorative words borrowed from Western concepts. She further claimed that a selective choice of words has been employed to deceive the public. While acknowledging that the IMF and the World Bank have emphasised the importance of promoting female participation in the workforce due to Sri Lanka’s relatively lower female workforce compared to other countries, she criticised the approach taken to address this issue. Amarasuriya contended that these new labour laws serve as a tool for the Government to curtail people’s rights and appease external parties, particularly employers, thereby undermining the interests of employees. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: New Zealand to host Australia in Tests for first time since 2016
author: Author not found
Content: In a busy home summer schedule of 2023-24, New Zealand will host their Trans-Tasman rivals Australia in Tests for the first time since 2016. Basin Reserve in Wellington and Christchurch’s Hagley Oval will host the two games in February and March. New Zealand’s men’s team also welcome South Africa in the same month for two Tests – to be held at Bay Oval in Tauranga and Seddon Park in Hamilton. This will be New Zealand’s latest attempt to break their duck against a side who they have never beaten in the format at home or away. The men’s team’s home summer kicks off on 17 December with the ODI and T20I series against Bangladesh, which is then followed by five T20Is against Pakistan between 12 and 21 January, further ramping up their preparation for the T20 World Cup. While the Bangladesh fixtures will be played across four venues – Dunedin, Nelson, Napier and Tauranga – the Pakistan fixtures will be held in Auckland, Hamilton, Dunedin and Christchurch. New Zealand’s home summer consists of 32 international fixtures, starting off with Sophie Devine’s side taking on Pakistan in the first of the three T20Is in Dunedin on 3 December. This will be followed by as many ODIs until 18 December, that will be part of the ICC Women’s Championship. They will however not play another home game until 19 March, when they host England for five T20Is and three ODIs – in Dunedin, Nelson, Wellington and Hamilton. “It’s a hugely exciting time for cricket in New Zealand, both in terms of the great series and teams on offer this summer, and the ability for fans to either attend the matches first-hand or watch live on TV at no charge,” NZC Chief Executive David White said. While devising their schedule, New Zealand Cricket also decided to have no fewer than 10 double-headers – addressing the dual need of luring different audiences as well as enhancing the efficiency of the schedule in times of climate change awareness. “In terms of venues with lights, we’ve been able to schedule several back-to-back night matches and day matches to ensure good opportunities for both families and adult patrons, respectively, which we think is good for the game. It’s a strategy that also complements our need to prioritise energy efficiency – and to just do the right thing as a sports organisation, given the challenges we’re facing from climate change these days,” White said.  (Cricbuzz)

title: Felicitating the Veteran’s invaluable contribution to Arts and Culture on 28 July
author: Author not found
Content: Honouring six decades of invaluable service to the Sri Lankan cultural field by renowned journalist, poet, literary critic and author Tilakarathna Kuruwita Bandara, an event felicitating his services will be held on Friday, 28 July, at Sri Lanka Foundation Institute auditorium from 3:30 p.m. onwards. The event includes The Book launch of “Pathra Kala Kavu Silumina ‘Tilakarathna Kuruwita Bandara Abhisambhawana’” edited by Snr. Prof. Samantha Herath which includes scholarly articles written by reputed writers on Tilakarathna Kuruwita Bandara and his work. Dr. Sarath Amunugama will be the Chief Guest and Saman Athaudahetti and Snr. Prof. Samantha Herath will deliver the key lectures. Indika Upamali, Shalitha Abhayawickrama, Lakmini Udawaththa and Ravindra Alagiyawanna will give a rendition of songs written by Thilakarathna Kuruwita Bandara, with dancing choreographed by Dr. Ravibandu Vidyapathi.

title: Man arrested with 4 kg stolen copper telephone wire
author: Author not found
Content: Kandy Police arrested a man involved in cutting and melting copper telephone wires to sell them within the Kandy city limits. Four kilograms of melted copper wire in the suspect’s possession was seized. The three-wheeler used by the suspect to transport the stolen copper was also taken into Police custody. Similar incidents have been reported in recent times, where telephone cables belonging to Sri Lanka Telecom in Kandy were cut and sold in various areas of Colombo. Police have stated that several more suspects are expected to be apprehended in connection with these incidents. Previous Police investigations have uncovered that valuable copper wire worth millions of rupees were being cut on deserted roads in locations such as Aniwatta, Dodamwala, Thabodharamaya Road, Light House Road and Hanthana. The suspect was produced in Court yesterday (18). BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: ‘Rice imports will jeorpadise Yala harvest’
author: Author not found
Content: The National Organiser of the National Farmers’ Movement Karunathilake Herath said the Government has imported 900,000 MT of rice even though the Yala harvest is to be reaped soon, thus the imports will cause a huge loss to farmers. Karunathilake was speaking at a press conference held at the head office of the National Freedom Front (NFF) in Pitakotte yesterday (18). He said farmers will have to bid farewell to paddy cultivation because of this and they will hence face significant challenges in selling their harvest from Yala season. He also accused the Government of making rice farmers to give up cultivating paddy and handing over their fertile land to large-scale, multinational agricultural companies according to IMF conditions. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: Two suspects enlarged on bail on strict bail conditions
author: Author not found
Content: Kebethigollawa Chief Magistrate Kasun Dassanayake ordered two suspects who were remanded on charges of brutally assaulting a lawyer while the latter had been on his way home at Padaviya, to be enlarged under strict bail conditions. Due to the assault the lawyer who is attached to the said Chief Magistrate’s Court had sustained injuries. The suspects were thus ordered to be released on two sureties of Rs 200,000 each and were imposed fines of Rs 5,000 each. They were also warned against intimidating any of the witnesses to the trial and to report to the Padaviya Police on the last Sunday of the month. BY Upali Karunadasa – Anuradhapura

title: Employees in favour of restructuring Postal Dept
author: Author not found
Content: Postal and Telecommunication officers have agreed to re-structure the Postal Department; however, they said they were not informed about any Bill or measures being taken for the initiation. During a recent press conference, State Minister of Mass Media Shantha Bandara announced that by the end of this year, a Bill will be presented to Parliament to re-structure the Postal Department. Additionally, a joint project, costing Rs 10 billion, has been planned, involving both the private and public sectors. It is emphasised that the modernization of the Postal Department should take place within the framework of state departments, with job security and improvements in service quality being key considerations. Postal and Telecommunication officers suggested that the Ministry of Mass Media engage in discussions with them, as they represent over 4000 members, to share the plans and progress before submitting the proposed Bill to Parliament. By Sanjana Marzook

title: 20,000 arrested for distilling moonshine
author: Author not found
Content: The Excise Department has arrested over 20,000 people during islandwide raids carried out in the first half of this year. The Excise Department, in collaboration with the Police has intensified raids and search operations to combat the increasing illegal distillation and sale of moonshine, as well as to control other offences against the distribution and sale of alcohol-related products, said Kapila Kumarasinghe, Additional Commissioner General of Revenue Operations and Law Implementation at the Excise Department yesterday (17). These raids consisted of 16,722 conducted under the Excise Ordinance, 2,943 under the Poisons, Opium and Dangerous Drugs Ordinance, and Psychotropic Ordinance Act, and 452 under the Tobacco Tax Act and the National Authority Act on Alcoholic Products. Kumarasinghe said nearly 20,121 were arrested during the raids. Those arrested, along with the seized items, were produced in Court. These raids were carried out through 57 excise stations located across the country, he added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: SC dismisses protesters’ FR Petitions
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court dismissed three Fundamental Rights Petitions filed by protesters who claimed that their rights were violated during a demonstration near former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s private residence in Mirihana on 31 March 2022. The Petitions were submitted by three individuals who alleged that they were subjected to torture and illegal arrest during the Mirihana incident. This incident marked the initial protest of the Aragalaya movement, which subsequently led to numerous similar protests and eventually resulted in the removal of the then President Gotabaya Rajapaksa in July 2022. A two-judge Bench of the Supreme Court, comprising Justices Preethi Padman Surasena and Mahinda Samayawardana, refused to grant leave to proceed with the petitions after considering the preliminary objections raised by Senior State Counsel Shaminda Wickrema. The petitioners had named the Inspector General of Police (IGP), Commandant of the Special Task Force (STF), Officer in Charge (OIC) of Mirihana, Director of Riot Police, Commander of the Sri Lanka Army, and the Attorney General as respondents. They alleged that their fundamental rights were violated through their illegal arrest and torture. Senior State Counsel Shaminda Wickrema presented several preliminary objections, including misrepresentation, suppression of vital evidence, illegality committed by the petitioners, time constraints on the application, the petitioners’ involvement in an existing judicial process, and their failure to include necessary parties. He also informed Court that the Mirihana protest resulted in damages of over Rs 36 million to police vehicles and caused severe injuries to several police officers. Counsel Suren Fernando represented the petitioners, while SSC Shaminda Wickrema, along with SC Kanishka Rajakaruna, SC Thusara Warapitiya, and Attorneys-at-Law Haajer Azhar and Dilani Wijewardena, appeared for the respondents.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: 29,000 acres of land in Mullaitivu to be released
author: Author not found
Content: The Presidential Secretariat issued a notice instructing all parties to release 29,000 acres of land in the Mullaitivu District, which had been demarcated by the Department of Forest Conservation and hand it over to the public. During a discussion held at the Mullaitivu Government Agent’s office, Grama Niladhari officials and representatives of people’s organisations alleged that the Department of Forest Conservation, the Mahaweli Development Authority, and the Department of Archaeology had forcibly taken over 100,000 acres of land belonging to the people of Mullaitivu. Upon submitting a report on this matter to the Presidential Secretariat, representatives from Tamil political parties met the President. Following the discussion, orders were received to release the lands. The lands to be released are located in several areas including Pudukudiiruppu, Oddusuddan, Tunukai, Manthai East, and Weli Oya of the Mullaitivu District. The people of Mullaitivu have also submitted a petition to the Committee for formulating a National Policy on Land, established under the leadership of the President’s Secretary on the President’s orders. The petition states that in addition to the 29,000 acres of land that will be freed, farmers have also been prohibited from cultivating another 17,000 acres of land, which has been declared off-limits by forest conservation officers. BY Rasadi Chathurangi Gamage – Vavuniya

title: Sri Lankan Embassy in Rumania soon?
author: Author not found
Content: The Sectoral Oversight Committee on International Relations has recommended to open a Sri Lankan Embassy in Rumania and instructed the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to expedite the opening. The committee met recently under the chairmanship of SLPP MP Namal Rajapaksa in Parliament recently. During the meeting, the importance of opening an embassy in Rumania was discussed as many Sri Lankans were employed in Rumania at the moment. Further, SLPP MP Yadamini Gunawardena suggested that there is a high possibility of attracting more tourists if an embassy is opened in Madrid, Spain.  Following the suggestion, the committee instructed the Foreign Affairs Ministry to submit a report in this regard soon. Meanwhile, it was also decided that Sri Lankan foreign missions should set up programmes to attract more tourists. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Chandima to vote in favour of NCM against Keheliya
author: Author not found
Content: MP Chandima Weerakkody who recently joined the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) said if a No-Confidence Motion (NCM) is tabled in the House against Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella over the latter’s failure to address critical issues in the health sector he will be compelled to vote according to his conscience. The MP made this remark when ongoing discussions among the SJB Parliamentary group, to bring an NCM against Rambukwella was held. A meeting was held lasty (17) evening with regard to the matter, however, no consensus was reached at  the time of going to press. The MP claimed that he felt for the plight faced by scores of people in the country due to the lackadaisical attitude of the Minister and his officials. He said he felt remorse over the Minister’s predicament if an NCM is mooted against him in Parliament but said he was far more concerned about the plight faced by the masses rather than that of a solitary Cabinet Minister. BY T. Vithanawasam – Imaduwa

title: Mujibur wants to return to Parliament
author: Author not found
Content: Former SJB MP Mujibur Rahuman, who resigned from Parliament to run for Colombo Municipal Council Mayor in the aborted Local Government elections, has expressed his intention to find ways to regain his Parliamentary seat. Speaking to Ceylon Today, Rahuman said he is currently in talks with his lawyers to file a Fundamental Rights (FR) petition where the Elections Commission, Finance Minister, Secretary of the Ministry of Finance, and Attorney General would be named as respondents. Rahuman said he was withholding his decision to file a FR petition in the Supreme Court to reclaim his Parliament seat, as he is focusing on a petition filed by the SJB regarding a general election request. “I resigned from Parliament to contest for the post of Mayor of the Colombo Municipal Council. However, the Local Government (LG) Election has been postponed indefinitely. I resigned as an MP based on the announcement made by the Elections Commission regarding the LG Election and even paid the deposit as a candidate. Therefore, I believe I should be reinstated as a Member of Parliament,” he said. Rahuman further said State sector employees who decided to run in the Election have been granted their salaries, entitled privileges, and have been able to resume their previous positions. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Gammanpila urges Ministers who approved to be arrested
author: Author not found
Content: Pivithuru Hela Urumaya (PHU) Leader MP Udaya Gammanpila yesterday (17) said that every member of the Cabinet should be arrested for giving approval to rudely remove the Crudia zeylanica plant that was located in a small forest patch in the Gampaha District to facilitate the Colombo-Kandy expressway, as they have violated the Fauna and Flora Protection Ordinance. Addressing a media briefing, Gammanpila said, “It is true that several other plants of Crudia Zeylanica are in the country at the moment. However, the manner that was followed to chop the tree was totally unacceptable. Now the Government tries to justify this horrific act by claiming that 200 saplings would be planted. But this act can never be justified.” Gammanpila said the Cabinet cannot violate the country’s law in this manner. Removing this Crudia zeylanica plant was a violation of the Section 43 of the Fauna and Flora Protection Ordinance, under which the plant is deemed a protected species. So, now it is clear that the Cabinet has violated the law. Therefore, each and every Cabinet member should be arrested, he said. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Census should register ‘Upcountry Tamils of Indian Origin’ – Jeevan
author: Author not found
Content: Following the Government’s decision to conduct a census of population and housing in Sri Lanka for 2023 and 2024, General Secretary of Ceylon Workers’ Congress (CWC) Minister Jeevan Thondaman spoke of the importance of upcountry Tamils registering themselves as ‘Upcountry Tamils of Indian Origin’ during the census. He called for increased awareness among the public about this matter. He said, during the previous census, there were issues with misidentification, where many Indian origin Tamils were mistakenly counted as Sri Lankan Tamils. As a result, the number of hill country Tamils was inaccurately reduced to approximately 850,000. Thondaman pointed out that some census officials often assume that those living in plantations are Indian Tamils, while those in the cities were Sri Lankan Tamils. He also said some people wrongly identify themselves as Sri Lankan Tamils just based on language. To rectify these errors, he stressed the importance of accurately identifying the Indian origin Tamils during the upcoming census. He urged Tamil youth to take on the responsibility of spreading awareness about this matter among the community. He said the census was not a political matter but rather a crucial initiative for the benefit of the people. He called for a transformation in upcountry politics, discouraging the practice of idolizing politicians and instead focusing on the need for politicians to serve the people faithfully. This change, he asserted, is essential for the betterment of their community. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Protests against Health Sector apathy
author: Author not found
Content: Two protests were held opposite the Health Ministry and the National Hospital Colombo yesterday (17), demanding the authorities to resolve the crises in the State health sector and provide immediate solutions to the current public outrage with regard to the quality of medicinal drugs. The protests were organised by several civil society organisations and Trade Union Collective of Health Services. The Inter University Students’ Federation (IUSF) too joined the protest later. The Health Ministry is facing a severe backlash and public outrage due to allegations of irresponsibility. This had led to several unfortunate deaths in the country, the IUSF alleged. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: Where does your loyalty lie?
author: Author not found
Content: The Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) questioned whether the loyalty of the Director General of Health Services (DGHS) lies with the general public of the country or the Minister of Health. Former SJB MP Mujibur Rahuman, during a media briefing on Sunday (16) criticised the DGHS’ recent action with regard to a patient’s death at the Peradeniya Teaching Hospital last week. Rahuman alleged that DGHS is involved in covering up a health crisis. Rahuman directed his criticism towards the DGHS, questioning whether his loyalty lies with the patients of the country or with the subject Minister. He further raised suspicions about the DGHS’ ties to corrupt individuals who act as agents for multinational drug companies. He said the events surrounding the patient’s death, claiming that the antibiotic administered to her was initially discontinued but was later permitted to be used. He made a public statement during a visit to the hospital. However, just hours after this statement, two more patients’ experienced adverse reactions to the same drug, prompting the DGHS to once again order its discontinuation. The Former SJB MP questioned whether the Director was truly serving the people in need of protection. He expressed concern over the loss of innocent lives and alleged that there is a prioritisation of professional monopolies and the interests of multinational companies by the health service, while neglecting the well-being of patients. He further emphasised that the country has been facing crises across various sectors, particularly within the free health service, which he claimed has deteriorated over the past two and a half years. In addition to the DGHS, Rahuman accused Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella of appointing multiple committees with the intention of concealing the true state of the country’s health service. He alleged that these committees were established to cover up the on-going crisis. Rahuman referred to the controversy surrounding imported medicinal drugs in Sri Lanka and pointed out that despite the DGHS’ assurance of the safety of a controversial drug following an investigation has caused further complications among patients. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Agri Ministry wants retired SC Judge as Chair
author: Author not found
Content: The Secretary to the Ministry of Agriculture has informed the Ministry of Justice  to nominate a retired Supreme Court Judge as Chairman of the proposed committee to investigate alleged irregularities surrounding the controversial Chinese organic fertiliser ship, Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera said yesterday (17). In response to a question raised by journalists during a media briefing at the President’s Media Centre (PMC), Amaraweera said once the chairman is appointed, the rest of the committee will be appointed promptly. The Minister said the Auditor General’s report shows deception in the transaction relating to the rejected Chinese fertiliser ship. However, since it does not specify the individuals involved, the Minister proposed the appointment of a high-level committee to investigate the matter. Amaraweera said he has nothing to hide regarding this issue. He also said legal action will be taken against those identified by the high-level committee appointed to uncover the parties mentioned in the audit report. The Minister acknowledged that something went wrong in this transaction and, as there are criminals accountable for it, he will not attempt to conceal any information. He stressed that once the committee reveals the individuals involved, they will be prosecuted regardless of their position. Furthermore, he highlighted that the country has not imported rice since last year and will not permit any rice imports in order to support local farmers. The agriculture Act is being amended, and the Ministry intends to introduce new technologies to encourage the younger generation to engage in farming. The ministry also provides farmers with various welfare benefits, with plans to introduce more in the future. By Sanjana Marzook

title: Wimal’s bribery case fixed for 9 August
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Navaratne Marasinghe yesterday (17) fixed for 9 August, to hear the bribery case filed by the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) against former Minister Wimal Weerawansa. The National Freedom Front (NFF) Leader has been accused before the High Court of accruing a sum of over Rs 75 million, far exceeding his Ministerial income, from 1 January 2010 to 31 December 2014 and thereby flouting Provisions contained in Sections of the Bribery Act. Shavendra Fernando PC appearing for the defendant informed Judge Marasinghe, that his client had already filed an appeal, with regard to the dismissal of initial objections raised by his client, related to a case filed before a separate High Court and noted that it was to be called on, 19 July. Accordingly, Fernando PC requested Court to fix a date, after the appeal petition is taken up for hearing by the High Court. Taking the submissions into consideration, the Judge, fixed the hearing of the case to the aforementioned date. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Joint Committee to strengthen SL-India connectivity meets
author: Author not found
Content: India-Sri Lanka Joint Committee established under MOU on Passenger Transportation by Sea held a virtual meeting on 14 July 2023. The two sides were led respectively by Shri Rajesh Kumar Sinha, Additional Secretary, Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Waterways of the Government of India and K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, Secretary, Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation of the Government of Sri Lanka. The productive discussions focused on resumption of ferry services between the two countries connecting mutually agreed points. Both sides agreed that resumption of ferry services will boost regional trade and tourism and promote stronger people-to-people ties. The Joint Committee identified a number of areas for mutual cooperation for operationalisation of ferry services in the near future, and desired to take further steps based on mutual understanding. The Joint Committee was recently reconstituted by the Governments of India and Sri Lanka as per the provisions of the bilateral Memorandum of Understanding on Passenger Transportation by Sea, signed in 2011.

title: 512,000 hectares of paddy cultivated after 10- year lapse- Amaraweera
author: Author not found
Content: As a result of President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s  new fertiliser policy, 512,000 hectares of paddy were cultivated in the Yala season after a lapse of 10 years, Minister of Agriculture Mahinda  Amaraweera said. The Minister added that 80% of the nation’s agricultural production is expected to be produced locally by 2025 as part of the President’s strategy to modernise the agricultural industry. The use of contemporary technology in agriculture could improve production of fruits and vegetables intended for export and reduce the amount of food that is imported, Minister Amaraweera added. He was speaking at a media briefing held yesterday(17), at the President’s Media Centre (PMC) Amaraweera  said, “Within a year of taking office, the President promptly fixed farmer issues and tried to get them back to  farming. Without a doubt,   circumstances were dire when President Wickremesinghe assumed office and I took over the Ministry of Agriculture. Farmers protested on the roads demanding fertiliser. Youth belonging to farming families left the farms and moved to other areas. Some young people even left the country. The biggest issue in this case was guiding them back to the farmland. The public had no confidence in the Ministers. Farmers stayed away from meetings in this regard. If they are to return to the fields, they demand to be provided fertiliser. Although 275, 000 hectares were supposed to be cultivated during that Yala season, only 212, 000 hectares were cultivated. At that time, the President negotiated with the Indian Government and arranged to provide 6,500 metric tons of fertiliser under the Indian credit scheme. However, the Indian loan arrangement does not allow for the provision of fertiliser. The fertiliser was imported from Oman. Only after learning that a ship carrying fertiliser was approaching the Port did the farmers venture back to their fields. This allowed for the cultivation of 512,000 hectares. It is now the most cultivated hectares during the Yala season after ten years, he said. Amaraweera said a national policy framework is currently being prepared under the leadership of Professor Gamini Senanayake of the University of Ruhuna and added that this policy framework is expected to be complete by the end of August 2023.

title: Raising the Bar
author: Author not found
Content: Nestled amidst the heart of the Sri Lankan juditial system, Sri Lanka Law College is bringing back Hulftsdorp Debates after a hiatus of four years. The town that is home to a myriad of black cloaks and the birthplace of some of the most convincing speakers to have graced the stage or stood before a judge or jury, hosting a Championship to determine the best debaters is always a special occasion. The profession of law is one that very much values the skills of a good debater; critical thinking, a sharp wit, building on arguments, and public speaking are but a few of these abilities that are part and parcel of the profession in itself. The importance of the Hulftsdorp Debates is best highlighted in this context, in presenting the opportunity for university students all around the island to improve and showcase their debating prowess. The Hulftsdorp Debating Championship, also referred to as the “Hulftsdorp Debates”, is a British Parliamentary style debating tournament organised by the English Literary Association of Sri Lanka Law College. This year, the series of debates will be held on the 12 and 13 August, 2023. Seeing the steady improvement in the schools’ debating circuit, as well as the resurgence of schools outside of the Colombo suburbs has been very heartening. Hulftsdorp Debates will also be looking into building upon this solid foundation and giving students access to a healthy debating atmosphere after school, where they will be able to engage in competitive debates while also creating the opportunity to expose more students to this debating environment and mingle with like-minded contemporaries. Hailed by many prominent lawyers and debaters alike as a platform that will serve towards setting the foundation for students for an understanding of the overall legal system in Sri Lanka, the debates will also provide the students of Sri Lanka Law College access to a competitive debating environment so that they may improve on and showcase their debating abilities. Many eyes are upon those who will take part in this year’s Hulftsdorp Debates to determine the Champions of inter-university debating!

title: Five-member committee to probe health sector mishaps
author: Author not found
Content: Following public outrage over deaths and severe allergic reactions allegedly resulting from certain batches of medicinal drugs, Minister of Health Keheliya Rambukwella set up a five-member committee, led by Prof. Chandima Jeewandara from the University of Sri Jayewardenepura, to conduct a comprehensive investigation into issues concerning the health sector. According to the Ministry of Health this committee has been entrusted to examine the recent deaths that occurred in State hospitals after certain medications were administered. The committee consists of experts who have extensive knowledge and expertise in medicine, nursing, and allergies. The primary objective of the committee is to thoroughly investigate all the contentious incidents and deliver a detailed report to the Health Minister. Meanwhile, it was reported that a few more patients who had developed severe allergic reactions to controversial drugs have been allegedly admitted to the Intensive Care Units (ICU) at the Kandy, Peradeniya and Anuradhapura Hospitals. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Sri Lanka donates tea to cyclone-hit Myanmar
author: Author not found
Content: The Government of Sri Lanka with the support of the Sri Lanka Tea Board donated a consignment of “Ceylon Tea” to the Government of Myanmar on 15 July 2023 as humanitarian assistance to the victims of cyclone Mocha.  The consignment was officially handed over to the Director of Natural Disaster Management Centre of Myanmar Than Soe at the Yangon International Airport. The donation was coordinated by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs along with the Embassy of Sri Lanka in Yangon. The consignment was airlifted by the SriLankan Airlines from Colombo to Bangkok and Myanmar Airways International (MAI) from Bangkok to Yangon on complimentary basis.

title: PM Shehbaz has phone conversation with President, discuss economic situ
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif telephoned President Ranil Wickremesinghe on Monday and discussed matters relating to the current economic situation of both the countries. He thanked the President for supporting Pakistan with regard to the country’s agreement with the International Monetary Fund (IMF). “You have played role of a true friend and a well-wisher of Pakistan, and I thank you on behalf of the people of my country,” the prime minister told the President. He paid tribute to Sri Lanka for its role in promoting regional peace and development. He also hoped that both Pakistan and Sri Lanka would come out of the economic crisis very soon. President Ranil Wickremesinghe congratulated Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif for reaching the staff level agreement with the IMF. He also thanked the Premier for expressing his good wishes for his country. President Wickremesinghe  appreciated the struggle and efforts made by the Pakistani Premier during the difficult economic situation in Pakistan. President Wickremesinghe urged the IMF to help Pakistan saving it from default as Sri Lanka had to face a tough situation after falling into default.

title: Widening the scope of vocational training vital – Susil
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Education Susil Premajayantha said the global demand is for skilled workers, and there is a huge recognition for those who obtain diplomas from institutions like ‘German Tech,’ which are highly sought after by developed countries. Addressing the diploma awarding ceremony of the Ceylon-German Technical Training Institute (German Tech) at the BMICH, Premajayantha pointed out that there is a timely need to take a rapid approach to updating school syllabi and widening the scope of vocational training. “To achieve that goal, steps are being taken to provide fibre optic connections, electricity, and other infrastructure facilities to 1,000 schools,” he assured. Speaking further, the Minister said not only should school syllabi be transformed, but university syllabi should also focus on vocational training. The ministry will take necessary action in this regard he said. “We also expect to provide the opportunity for students who have finished their O/L examination to take a vocational training course in their own schools in the near future. This will expand their knowledge of professionalism, and they can obtain certification even if they do not wish to pursue A/L studies,” Premajayantha pointed out.

title: Jazeera Airways to increase flights to several destinations
author: Author not found
Content: To meet the growing demand for summer travel, Jazeera Airways will increase the number of flights to several destinations including Colombo, an Airline spokesman said. The other destinations are of Sarajevo, Tbilisi and Baku, he added and said all these destinations offer great tourist attractions for a quick getaway or a relaxing holiday. Jazeera will operate daily flights to Sarajevo, six flights a week to Colombo and five flights a week to Tbilisi and Baku. Travellers will also enjoy special return fares to Sarajevo, Colombo, Tbilisi and Baku. Jazeera Airways flies to 66 cities across the Middle East, Europe, Central and North Asia as well as Africa.  (Albawaba)

title: Winner all the way
author: Author not found
Content: A musical and dancing competition titled ‘B2s Got Talent’, organised by Leo District 306 B2, was recently held at the Apegama auditorium, Battaramulla. Baddhakachchayana Rajapaksa, daughter of veteran media personality and former Media Secretary to the Fisheries Ministry Narendra Rajapakse, secured first place in the dancing competition. She received the winning medal from Ragesh Yogeshwaran, President of Leo District 306 B2.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Sama International Choral Festival from 24 to 30 July
author: Author not found
Content: The Sama Choral Festival is aimed at promoting peace, and interfaith harmony, and removing misconceptions confronted by many. The world is aware of the numerous challenges and conflicts we are constantly facing, and it is with this in mind that we believe it essential to work together to foster understanding and create peaceful coexistence among people of different backgrounds. We are determined to utilize the power of music, a universal language to rise above limitations and bring people closer together. Religion in all communities is based on peace, and compassion, and holds great potential to contribute to noble objectives. By showcasing the rich musical heritage and spiritual traditions of all faiths we can dispel misunderstandings and promote a deeper appreciation for the values and teachings it upholds.  The involvement and support invested in our work will have a profound impact on the collective effort to build bridges of understanding and goodwill. By participating, you can help foster an environment where people from different faiths and backgrounds can come together, learn from one another, and celebrate the diversity that enriches our societies.  The Festival aims to create a space where artistes and performers can showcase their talent and their contributions will not only promote culturally rich exchanges but will also serve to challenge stereotypes and misconceptions due to ignorance. By joining hands with other artistes, musicians, and performers can collectively raise their voices to spread the message of peace and harmony.

title: Ceylon Chamber raises concerns over healthcare sector
author: Author not found
Content: The Ceylon Chamber of Commerce has expressed its concerns over recent developments in the healthcare sector, particularly the quality of pharmaceutical products procured for the public healthcare system. In a press release, the Chamber highlighted the persistent shortage of essential medicines, which has been exacerbated by the ongoing economic crisis and the lack of a robust and transparent procurement system. The Chamber recommended that immediate action be taken to ensure and enhance the public procurement of medicines in a transparent manner, following established guidelines and requiring registration with the regulator. They emphasised the crucial role of the National Medicines Regulatory Authority in ensuring the procurement of high-quality medicines, including essential medicines obtained through emergency processes. The chamber called for a stronger, more transparent and independent role for the authority. In addition, the Chamber suggested that the pricing of medicines should adopt a market pricing formula, similar to the approach taken for other commodities such as fuel and gas, which were previously subject to price controls. Implementing a pricing formula, developed by relevant experts, will ensure sustainability in the quality of medicines procured. The Chamber acknowledged the recent directive issued by the President to streamline the procurement system. They, along with affiliated associations and professional bodies such as the Sri Lanka Medical Association, are ready to support policymakers in improving and uplifting the current state of the healthcare system, ultimately benefiting the people of the country, the press release said. The Chamber called for prompt and decisive action to address challenges faced in the healthcare procurement sector, emphasising the importance of transparency, quality assurance, and sustainability in providing essential medicines to the public healthcare system.

title: Family dispute leads to death of one, 3 injured
author: Author not found
Content: A family dispute that escalated  led to a clash between two groups, resulting in several being injured and hospitalised. The clash broke out initially at a hospital, and later continued at the Kalawana Base Hospital, where one person was killed and three others were injured. Kalawana Police reported that a man was stabbed and killed in the hospital’s fourth ward. The incident took place at midnight on Sunday (16). The deceased was identified as Dhamwala Liyanage Ranil Pradip Kumara, a 42-year-old from Delgoda, Kalawana. According to Police investigations, the deceased and his two friends were consuming alcohol. It was during this time that the suspect, accompanied by his father, encountered the group and an altercation ensued. The deceased initiated the attack on the suspect and his father. Another dispute related to the same incident took place near a shop in the Delgoda Colony, where the two groups clashed again while on their way to the Kalawana Base Hospital for medical treatment. During this clash the suspect, his father, and a friend of the deceased sustained injuries. The injured parties arrived at the Kalawana Base Hospital in the 1990 Suwaseriya ambulance service and a private vehicle. However, the situation escalated once again when a group of individuals accompanying the injured parties caused further conflict at the hospital. The suspect’s brother-in-law, who was involved in the murder, was also attacked within the hospital premises. Investigation findings indicate that the suspect, in response to the stabbing of his sister by the deceased, grabbed a knife and pursued the deceased. The deceased sought refuge in the fourth ward of Kalawana Hospital and locked the door, but the suspect forcibly broke in and stabbed the victim. The suspect has fled the area, and Kalawana police are currently conducting investigations to apprehend him. The suspect’s father, sister, and friend have been injured and taken to the hospital, with two of them being admitted to the Ratnapura Teaching Hospital. The Kalawana Police, under the direction of its OIC H.M. Herath, is leading the investigations. Officers from the Ratnapura Police are also involved in the investigation, and the inspection is being conducted by OIC Mayadunna. The Magisterial Inquest was conducted on the afternoon of Sunday (17). BY L. Niroshan – Kahawatte

title: K-Pop World Festival held in Colombo
author: Author not found
Content: K-Pop World Festival, a cultural celebration of Korean K-pop in Sri Lanka, took place recently at the BMICH. The event was hosted by the Korean Embassy in Sri Lanka, and the chief guest was Minister of Cultural Affairs Vidura Wickramanayke. Over 1,200 K-pop fans in Sri Lanka participated.  The event was also attended by Miyon Lee, Korean ambassador to Sri Lanka.

title: USAID launches plastic recycling centres
author: Author not found
Content: The Kaduwela Municipal Council opened the first of four plastic recycling centres at Dedigamuwa as a pilot project to improve standards in plastic waste collection and apply environment, health, and safety best practices. The plastic recycling centres, supported under United States Agency for International Development (USAID) Clean Cities Blue Ocean activity will sort, clean, and bale or crush large quantities of plastic in the municipal areas for commercial recycling. The plastic recycling centre is a significant step towards strengthening the role of informal waste collectors through a plastic recycling model developed to increase the recycling rate , said Douglas Sonnek, the Deputy Chief of Mission of the U.S. Embassy in Colombo. “During the US-Sri Lanka 75-year partnership, we have supported such interventions, contributing towards the transformation of discarded plastics into valuable resources, as well as education and researching, and the engagement of local communities in the waste management process”, he said. USAID support provided essential machinery and equipment, including a crusher and baler machine, to the recycling centre among other equipment, such as a scale, trolley, and jumbo collection bags. The workers also received safety equipment such as first aid kits, personal protective equipment, and fire extinguishers. “Collecting and recycling waste is a service to the environment as well as to people to reduce the damage caused by improper waste disposal to the environment. I am very glad that I can contribute to this service with the support of USAID CCBO and Janathakshan”, said Krishantha Vidanagama, Managing Director, Green Step Private Limited. This model piloted in the Kaduwela Municipal area will be replicated in Galle in the coming months to promote sustainable waste management, foster the integration of informal waste collectors into a formal system, and create a cleaner and more environmentally-friendly country. “Investment in recycling gives double dividends. On one hand, it improves the economy of the country by saving the expenditure on plastic material importation while creating employment opportunities for marginalized communities. On the other hand, it reduces the negative impacts on the sensitive ecosystems by diverting the plastic waste which will otherwise be added to the environment for recycling”, said Anil Jasinghe, Secretary of the Ministry of Environment.

title: Did former Polls Commissioners violate MPs’ privileges?
author: Author not found
Content: Plans are afoot to move a motion requesting a Parliamentary Special Committee be appointed to ascertain whether the privileges of MPs have been violated by the activities of the former members of the Election Commission and to make suitable recommendations. Ruling Party sources said a decision will be taken by the Committee on Parliamentary Business chaired by Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena this morning (17). The proposal submitted by 14 MPs including MP Sampath Athukorala has been included in the supplements of the Order Book as an indefinite motion. The Motion has been moved under the pretext that the Election Commission consisting of N.G. Punchihewa (Chairman), S.B. Divaratne, M.M. Mohammad, K.P.P. Pathirana and P.S.M. Charles was appointed on 3 December 2020, it is stated in the proposal that the Election Commission is accountable to Parliament as per the provisions of Article 104 B (3) of the Constitution. It also states that according to Article 30 (4) of the 21st Amendment the members of the Commission have completed their tenure and are exercising and performing their powers and functions as interim members. Since the Election Commission has announced that nominations were called for the Local Government Election on 18 January 2023, it has been announced that two members of the Commission have decided to fix this poll on 9 March 2023 and have obtained the consent of the other three members, it is further stated. It is also included in the resolution that the Secretary of the Ministry of Finance, Economic Stabilisation and National Policies has filed an affidavit to the Court stating that it will be challenging to find funds to hold such an election in March 2023. The proposal also states that there is a question as to whether the Commission is satisfied that all the pre-conditions to hold such an election have been met. On 25 January 2023, P.S.M. Charles submitted her resignation letter to the President and the Commission has failed to report to Parliament, which is responsible for public finances, about the problems that have arisen with regard to the Local Government Elections. If the privileges of the MPs and Parliament have been violated, it should be investigated and appropriate recommendations should be made in this regard, the motion further stated. It is learnt that this proposal will be submitted to Parliament on Tuesday (18) and preparations are underway to appoint the Parliamentary Special Committee on the same day. By J.T. de Silva

title: Mt. Lavinia-KKS luxury train service from 1 Aug
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Railways is to operate an air-conditioned luxury train between Mount Lavinia and Kankesanturai from 1 August. The train will depart around 10:00 p.m. from Mount Lavinia and a ticket to KKS will cost Rs 4,000, the Railway Department said. Deputy General Manager of Railways N.J. Idipolage said this luxury train service will be launched in addition to the six trains which operate daily from Colombo Fort to Kankesanturai every week. (MJ)

title: President to meet TNA MPs ahead of India visit
author: Author not found
Content: Ahead of his visit to New Delhi, President Ranil Wickremesinghe has planned another round of discussions with Parliamentarians representing the Tamil National Alliance (TNA). According to political sources, this meeting is scheduled to be convened on Tuesday (18) evening at the Parliament Complex. Commenting on the planned meeting, a TNA spokesperson said it is expected to discuss several salient issues concerning the Tamil community including land disputes in the North, the distribution of power, and Provincial Council Elections. Several rounds of discussions have already taken place between the President and TNA. The latter recalled the assurance by the President to provide a final solution before 31 July to these issues. The TNA MPs had earlier directed a letter to Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, requesting to urge the Sri Lankan Government to provide expeditious solutions to their issues. (GW)

title: CEB bill for Dalada Perahera is norm – Official
author: Author not found
Content: The Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) sending an estimated bill prior to the annual Dalada Perahera is a norm, an official of the Dalada Maligawa responding to concerns raised by various parties, including Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa said. The official said previously the CEB footed a large share of the estimated cost and this time a discussion will be held to ascertain how to settle the bill without putting the whole burden on the State institution. A letter in this regard was sent to Sri Dalada Maligawa Diyawadana Nilame Pradeep Nilanga Dela on 13 July by CEB Chief Engineer (Kandy City) A.H.M.H.S. Abeyrathne. The CEB has thus informed the Sri Dalada Maligawa (The Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic) to deposit over Rs 13.2 million to provide a continuous electricity supply for the Esala Perahara. According to the letter, Rs 13,299,010.99 was assigned for the electricity charges of the Sri Dalada Maligawa (Rs 3,412,479.29), Sri Natha Dewalaya (Rs 1,122,145.69), Sri Vishnu Dewalaya (Rs 1,368,385,69), Sri Kataragama Dewalaya (Rs 1,102,705.69), and Sri Paththini Dewalaya (Rs 1,102,705.69). The cost for the perahera street lights is Rs 4,441,373,85 and the cost for other expenses like electricity generators is Rs 479,215.10. (GW)
