title: Nearly 30,000 apply for online passports
author: Author not found
Content: Nearly 30,000 persons have applied for passports within 30 days through the recently introduced decentralised system at 51 Divisional Secretariats. Public Security Minister Tiran Alles said a total of 29,578 persons have applied online to obtain passports since the launch of the service at 51 Divisional Secretariats last month. He said out of those, 5,294 persons have submitted applications for one-day service and 24,285 for the normal service. Online applications for passports commenced at 51 Divisional Secretariats on 15 June to enable applicants to obtain passports from their hometowns without having to visit Colombo. The Minister said the Immigration and Emigration Department has received 29,579 applications within 30 days since the launch of the service. He pointed out that it is necessary to visit any of the 51 designated Divisional Secretariat offices for registration and the relevant payments can be made online or by visiting a branch of the Bank of Ceylon. He said the long queues in front of the Battaramulla Immigration and Emigration Department office have also ended following the launch of this system. (GW)

title: Paddy farmers to get free TSP fertiliser
author: Author not found
Content: The Agriculture Ministry is to provide another variety of chemical fertiliser free of charge to paddy farmers for the next Maha season. Agriculture Minister Mahinda Amaraweera said in the coming Maha season of 2023 and 2024, one more type of chemical fertiliser will be provided free of charge to farmers who cultivate paddy. This year, the Government took steps to provide free TSP (Triple Super Phosphate) to the farmers free of charge after three cropping seasons, to all those who cultivated paddy during the last Maha season, regardless of whether or not they cultivated paddy this Yala season. Accordingly, vouchers were issued for the amount of Rs 20,000 for a hectare and Rs 40,000 for two hectares. Meanwhile, the Government has also decided to deposit cash into the bank accounts of all the farmers instead of vouchers to buy fertilisers in the next season. Accordingly, farmers will be able to purchase either chemical or organic fertilisers from the private sector or the Ceylon Fertilizer Company at their discretion. (GW)

title: SJB slams sending electricity bill to Dalada Maligawa
author: Author not found
Content: The Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB), yesterday (16), expressed their strong disdain, unhappiness and protest against putting an unbearable burden on places of worship without looking for alternatives. Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa alleged that the Government has resorted to an unprecedented practice of forwarding an electricity bill for the historical procession of the Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic which is the pinnacle of Buddhist reverence and has, thus, exposed its rude and unscrupulous policy and this vile act is a disgrace to the Dharma of the fully enlightened Lord Buddha, to the entire Buddhist society and the whole country in general. “In particular, I consider this as a serious insult to the global community that pays attention to the historical procession of the Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic,” he said. The Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) has informed the Nilames of four main devalayas and organisers of the Kandy Esala Perahera to deposit a sum of Rs 13 million to ensure an uninterrupted power supply for the festival. This year’s Kandy Esala Perahera festival will commence on 17 August with the traditional ‘Kap’ planting ceremony at the four Maha Devalayas. The Opposition Leader further said: “I recall that we were immensely shocked by hearing it and express our unconditional disdain to the Government that took this arbitrary decision. It should be remembered at this moment that the Government has allocated money without hesitation especially for activities like the Republic Parade, and we have a strong disgust about the degree of attention paid by the Government to the procession of the Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic, which is famous both locally as well as internationally. The Government had, even previously, targeted several temples issuing them with an unbearable electricity bill and this is something that brings immense displeasure. Rulers should understand that any country has a unique culture and religious value systems and the Government should reveal the root cause of its antagonism against religious and cultural matters. The Government should make it mandatory to resort to subsidised electricity bills for temples and religious shrines and for that, it is possible to get the contribution of the Cultural Fund. We express our strong disdain, unhappiness and protest against putting an unbearable burden on religious shrines without looking for alternatives.” By Gagani Weerakoon

title: Ban on five proscribed organisations lifted
author: Author not found
Content: Considering the prevailing “peaceful” condition in the country, the Government has decided to lift the ban on five organisations out of 11 organisations which were banned following the Easter Sunday terrorist attacks on 21 April 2019 under “strict conditions”. Accordingly, the ban on these organisations (previously identified as Islamist groups) will be lifted subject to strict conditions: Jamiyathul Ansaari Sunnathul Mohomadiya (JASM), Sri Lanka Thawheed Jamma’ath (SLTJ), All Ceylon Thawheed Jamma’ath (ACTJ), Ceylon Thawheed Jamma’ath (CTJ) and United Thawheed Jamma’ath (UTJ). Former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa issued a Gazette Notification in April 2021 banning these five organisations along with six others under the Prevention of Terrorism Act. The ban on the five organisations is being lifted in line with recommendations by a committee comprising experts from expert investigative and intelligence agencies after a probe spanning more than a year, and also following talks between representatives of these groups and Government authorities. Nevertheless, the expert committee has recommended that even after the ban is lifted, authorities should keep a close watch on the activities of these organisations, their funding and education programmes. If there is any kind of threat to the national security from these organisations in the future, the committee has recommended re-imposing the ban. (GW)

title: New Postal Act to Parliament this year – Bandara
author: Author not found
Content: A new Postal Act will be presented to Parliament within this year to expedite the modernisation process of the Postal Department, State Minister of Mass Media Shantha Bandara said. The modernisation process is planned to be carried out as a joint public-private sector partnership at a cost of Rs 10 billion and the Postal Department will not be privatised at any cost, Bandara said. He was speaking during a media briefing held at the Presidential Media Centre (PMC) yesterday (16). It is expected to convert the Postal Department into a profit-making institution within the next two years, through the digitisation of the Department, the Minister pointed out. Further, the Minister said by the end of 2023, the loss of the Postal Department will be reduced byRs 4,000 million. “When President Ranil Wickremesinghe assigned me this Ministry he entrusted me with the challenge of converting the Postal Department into a profit-generating institution. The Postal Service’s income in 2022 wasRs 7,000 million while the expenditure was Rs 14,000 million. I discussed with the relevant officials and took steps to reduce the gap between the income and the expenditure of the Postal Department from Rs 7,000 million to Rs 4,000 million. It is planned to resolve the gap between income and expenditure by 2024. In 2025, our goal is to create a Postal Department that no longer depends on the Treasury,” State Minister Bandara said. “The Postal Department, which is one of the oldest Departments in this country, still has an Ordinance brought during the time of the Queen. It has been amended only once so far. We have identified the Post Office Ordinance as a major obstacle to the modernisation process of the Postal Department and other relevant activities. Therefore, steps are being taken to amend it urgently and 80 per cent of the work has been completed,” the State Minister said. “We hope to create new revenue generation channels through digitisation of the postal service. Presently, Rs 4,000 million, Rs 668 million andRs 200 million has been earned annually by the sale of stamps, postage of stamps and the Cash on Delivery (COD) service, respectively. Also, in the future, it is planned to increase revenue by popularising the COD method. During the modernisation of the postal service, 1,000 three-wheelers will be deployed islandwide replacing the traditional bicycles that were used in the field for a long time. We also hope to provide an official uniform. By doing so, our ultimate goal is to create a strong postal service in the country,” State Minister Bandara added. (GW)

title: Govt trying to abolish workers’ rights – NPP
author: Author not found
Content: The National People’s Power led by the JVP accused the Government of attempting to abolish the rights of the working people through proposed labour laws in a move to fulfil IMF conditions. NPP MP Vijitha Herath, speaking at a media briefing yesterday (16), said the Government has proposed to abolish 13 Acts, through these new laws, that so far have ensured the rights of the working people. Herath also alleged the new labour laws propose to abolish the 8-hour work day and introduce a 12-hour work day instead, and added that it could be extended to 16 hours on the consent of the employee. “The 8-hour work week is a right achieved after a global struggle sacrificing so many lives. Abolishing it is a huge blow to the working people,” he said. The MP said 13 Acts including the Shop and Office Employees Act, Wages Boards Ordinance, etc. have been proposed to be abolished in the new laws and added that these Acts had ensured the rights of working women and the labour force. “The Shop and Office Employees Act ensured the rights of working women, especially when working at night. The employer is bound to provide transport to women if they work after 8:00 p.m. and the consent of the female employee is needed to employ them for night duties,” he said. He urged the Government to withdraw the proposed Bill and ensure the rights of the working people. “The duty of the Government is to ensure the rights of the working people during an economic crisis like this. However, the Government has burdened the people through the Domestic Debt Restructuring, the ‘Aswesuma’ welfare scheme and now through new labour laws,” he added. By Gagani Weerakoon

title: FETÖ elements eliminated from SL
author: Author not found
Content: Following joint efforts in the fight against terrorism, Türkiye says FETÖ elements have been eliminated from Sri Lanka. The elements of FETÖ (Fethullahist Terrorist Organization) – the group behind the foiled 2016 coup bid – have been eliminated from Sri Lanka after successful joint efforts by the two nations against terrorism. Local intelligence services, based on information provided by Turkiye, alerted relevant authorities of the alleged functioning of FETÖ well ahead of the 2019 Easter Sunday bomb attacks. Addressing the Democracy and National Unity Day Commemoration Ceremony in Colombo on Saturday (15), Ambassador Demet Şekercioğlu said Türkiye continues to engage with the Sri Lankan authorities with enhanced intelligence sharing to build a strong, vigilant and comprehensive response to terrorism. On 15 July 2016, the Government of Türkiye President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan defeated an attempted coup d’état by FETÖ members, which claimed the lives of 251 citizens and left thousands of others injured. The day is commemorated as the Democracy and National Unity Day in Türkiye. The Ambassador said the tragic events that unfolded on 15 July 2016 were not merely acts of terror, but a blatant affront to the founding principles that define the Republic of Türkiye and its people – the principles of democracy, freedom, and the rule of law. She said the malicious acts witnessed on 15 July 2016 were not the result of an overnight attempt, but the climax of many years of meticulous planning and covert operations by the FETÖ led by Fethullah Gülen. Meanwhile, the Türkiye Foreign Minister thanked the country’s Asian partners for their support in the fight against FETO. (GW)

title: CEB bill for Dalada Perahera is norm – Official
author: Author not found
Content: The Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) sending an estimated bill prior to the annual Dalada Perahera is a norm, an official of the Dalada Maligawa responding to concerns raised by various parties, including Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa said. The official said previously the CEB footed a large share of the estimated cost and this time a discussion will be held to ascertain how to settle the bill without putting the whole burden on the State institution. A letter in this regard was sent to Sri Dalada Maligawa Diyawadana Nilame Pradeep Nilanga Dela on 13 July by CEB Chief Engineer (Kandy City) A.H.M.H.S. Abeyrathne. The CEB has thus informed the Sri Dalada Maligawa (The Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic) to deposit over Rs 13.2 million to provide a continuous electricity supply for the Esala Perahara. According to the letter, Rs 13,299,010.99 was assigned for the electricity charges of the Sri Dalada Maligawa (Rs 3,412,479.29), Sri Natha Dewalaya (Rs 1,122,145.69), Sri Vishnu Dewalaya (Rs 1,368,385,69), Sri Kataragama Dewalaya (Rs 1,102,705.69), and Sri Paththini Dewalaya (Rs 1,102,705.69). The cost for the perahera street lights is Rs 4,441,373,85 and the cost for other expenses like electricity generators is Rs 479,215.10. (GW)

title: Sri Lanka launches ‘Zapmail’
author: Author not found
Content: The world’s first collaborative email service, ‘Zapmail’ has been launched and is now available to the public, aiming to provide the best communication experience at your own pace. Zapmail is the world’s first collaborative email service designed and developed by Sri Lanka to address inefficiencies in team communication by simplifying and streamlining communication, saving teams time and increasing productivity. Commenting on the launch, the Co-Founders of Zapmail; Sean Samarasinghe, Mark Sachintha, Shay Anthony, Devmin Abeyasena and Meredith Ivor say that; “Traditional email services are not designed for team collaboration, resulting in disorganised conversations, difficulty finding relevant information, and time wasted. Thereby, we concentrated on developing a solution that enables teams to communicate in real time no matter where they are. Within our company, we saw the difficulties that teams had in effectively collaborating via traditional email services. We saw the need for a solution that combines the advantages of email communication with an effective way to collaborate. After extensive research and product improvements with teams from around the world, we are excited to launch ‘Zapmail’, a collaborative email service that integrates conversational emails, zero spam inbox, organised threads, and collaborative spaces for teams.” Zapmail’s developers move forward in search of solutions for the team to be able to collaborate in a professional setting while representing the brand of the organisation. Businesses, universities, organisations, and any other formal setting can now form a more cohesive digital environment to achieve their goals. Furthermore, because Zapmail is cloud-based, it is accessible from any device, allowing teams to continue their conversations from anywhere in the world. “We are just getting started, and our goal is to make business communication simple and effective for everyone by increasing productivity in organisations all over the world,” added the Co-Founders. Customers of Zapmail, whether large, small, or medium-sized enterprises, businesses, universities, or professionals, will reap several benefits from the tool. Communication within the team will be simplified, organised, and streamlined, resulting in increased productivity and efficiency as information can be transmitted effortlessly. Teams can use Zapmail to switch between chat-like conversations and organised email threads, all within the same platform.

title: SL-Australia bilateral consultations in Colombo
author: Author not found
Content: The 4th round of foreign office bilateral consultations, second strategic maritime dialogue and third joint trade and investment committee meeting between Sri Lanka and Australia took place on 12 July 2023 at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Colombo. These meetings were co-chaired by First Assistant Secretary of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade of Australia Gary Cowan, Additional Secretary (Bilateral East) Yasoja Gunasekera and Additional Secretary (Economic Affairs) Shanika Dissanayake of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Secretary of the Ministry of Trade, Commerce and Food Security A.M.P.M.B. Atapattu. During the discussions, new avenues for increased institutional cooperation in the defence, agriculture, cyber security and education sectors were identified. Both sides agreed to work together to strengthen regional cooperation, including through the Indian Ocean Rim Association (IORA). Discussions also took place on strengthening trade and investment ties.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Gift of life from the Brandix Group
author: Author not found
Content: Brandix was felicitated once again as Sri Lanka’s largest corporate blood donor by the National Blood Transfusion Service (NBTS), for the 11th consecutive year. Last year, Brandix staff from all over Sri Lanka donated over 5,700 pints of blood – the gift of life – to the NBTS, bringing its total contribution up to 42,041 pints since 2011. One in every 100 blood donors in Sri Lanka is part of the Brandix family. During an event at the NBTS in Colombo, Brandix was recognized as the Largest Corporate Blood Donor, and Organiser of the Largest Mobile Campaign. The Brandix facility in Batticaloa was felicitated for Best Mobile Donation Campaign Organiser and Highest Contributor in the Eastern Province. The facility in Avissawella won Best Mobile Donation Campaign Organiser in the region. Director of the NBTS, Dr. Lakshman Edirisinghe, said: “Contributions from Brandix and its employees have enriched the lives of thousands of Sri Lankans over the years, and of those engaged within the health sector. In addition to the support rendered to the NBTS to maintain a regular supply of blood, the company helped establish a Blood Bank at the Negombo District General Hospital and collaborates extensively with the Ministry of Health to ensure effective operations at hospitals around the country. This includes the provision of clean drinking water and sanitation. The NBTS and Sri Lanka’s health services sector is privileged to partner with Brandix to advance healthcare all over the island.” Nalin De Mel from the Brandix Essentials facility in Koggala has made the highest individual contribution of blood with 49 pints to date. From Batticaloa, 800 Brandix employees donated blood last year, with 498 from Polonnaruwa, 367 from Girithale, 343 from Wathupitiwala and 310 from Welisara amongst others. “At Brandix, we are committed to the wellbeing of all our family, and that commitment extends beyond our walls to the communities in which we serve. The ‘blood drive’ is an integral part of our pledge to enhance Sri Lankan lives, and we are deeply grateful for the opportunity and assistance offered by the NBTS and the Ministry of Health towards our mission,” added Malika Samaraweera, Group Head of CSR, Brandix.

title: Foreign Minister leads SL Delegation to ASEAN Regional Forum
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Foreign Affairs M.U.M. Ali Sabry led the Sri Lanka delegation to the 30th ASEAN Regional Forum (ARF) Ministerial Meeting held on 14 July 2023 in Jakarta, Indonesia. The ARF is an Asia-Pacific region centric security dialogue mechanism inaugurated in 1994 in Thailand which seeks to promote regional development and prosperity through open and inclusive dialogue while recognising challenges to regional peace, security and prosperity. The ARF has 27-member States and Sri Lanka has been a member of the ARF since 2007. Addressing the forum, Foreign Minister Sabry highlighted the important areas of cooperation for Sri Lanka, including maritime security, disaster management, defence-related confidence building measures and preventive diplomacy, and for sustaining the growing economic dynamism and prosperity of the region. He also welcomed the steady advancement in the areas of cooperation in the ARF and unreservedly supported the process. The Foreign Minister said that Sri Lanka intends to become a member of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) which is the world’s largest free trade area that came into effect on 1 January 2022. Australia, Brunei, Cambodia, China, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Laos, Malaysia, Myanmar, New Zealand, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam are the 15 founding members of the RCEP. The RCEP became open for new members from 1 July 2023 and Sri Lanka has submitted the Letter of Intent to the ASEAN Secretariat on 28 June 2023 to join the RCEP. The Minister held a series of bilateral meetings on the sidelines of the ARF with the Ministers of Foreign Affairs of Australia, Indonesia, Lao PDR, Mongolia, New Zealand, the Philippines, Russia, Timor Leste, Vietnam and the UK to discuss areas of mutual interest. During his stay in Jakarta, he also held discussions with the Indonesian Minister of Finance, the National Agency for Combating Terrorism (BNPT) of Indonesia and the Sri Lankan business community in Indonesia. The Sri Lanka delegation included the Ambassador of Sri Lanka to Indonesia Jayanath Colombage and Director General of the Southeast and Central Asia Division of the Foreign Ministry Waruna Wilpatha.

title: IATA urges SL to develop aviation blueprint
author: Author not found
Content: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) strongly encouraged Sri Lanka to expand its aviation industry. Specifically, the organisation requested that Sri Lanka develop a blueprint to generate both economic growth and prosperity driven by commercial aviation. The announcement was made by Philip Goh, IATA’s Regional Vice President for Asia-Pacific, at Aviation Day Sri Lanka, an event hosted by the organisation in partnership with the Civil Aviation Authority of Sri Lanka (CAASL). In his remarks, Goh indicated facilitating growth, safety, and sustainability as three key areas for the South Asian nation to consider. Aviation maintains a critical role in 15 of the 17 UN Sustainable Development Goals. Everything from trade and tourism to the creation of jobs and the alleviation of poverty relies on a thriving commercial aviation industry. “Sri Lanka’s aviation blueprint needs to facilitate the sustainable growth of the industry and having an updated airport masterplan is the first step. I urge the Government to engage in a consultative approach involving airlines to ensure that industry input is factored in,” Goh said. Goh urged Sri Lanka to digitise processes for passenger and cargo facilitation. “Many of the country’s passenger and cargo processes continue to be paper-based. As traffic grows, digitalisation will be key to address capacity constraints, increase efficiency and improve the travel experience. IATA’s One ID and One Record initiatives can help support this,” said Goh. Goh also highlighted the need to keep costs low, in particular jet fuel. Airlines pay more for jet fuel in Sri Lanka than at other major airports in Asia. He recognised much has been done in recent months to lower the cost of jet fuel, and encouraged the Government to review and consider placing limits or capping the amount that CEYPETCO can mark up for supplying fuel at the airport. “It is important for Sri Lanka’s aviation sector to grow sustainably in a safe manner, and IATA is doing our part to support the country’s efforts. Utilising the International Airlines Training Fund, IATA will support the aviation industry in Sri Lanka by conducting safety related training in August for CAASL and SriLankan Airlines,” said Goh. Goh encouraged the Government to explore how the IATA Operational Safety Audit (IOSA) and IATA Safety Audit for Ground Operations (ISAGO) can be used to contribute to greater aviation safety in Sri Lanka. “I am delighted that net zero carbon from aviation by 2050 is one of the stated policy goals of Sri Lanka’s sustainable aviation environment policy, including the need to ensure the availability of sustainable aviation fuels (SAF) in the country,” said Goh. SAF is expected to abate more than 60 per cent of aviation carbon emissions by 2050. Goh called on the Government to adopt a comprehensive consultation process involving airlines and other aviation stakeholders as the Government develops sustainability policies.

title: Two critically injured in Jaffna multiple vehicle collision
author: Author not found
Content: Two persons were critically injured in an accident yesterday (16) morning involving an SLTB bus, a car and a motorcycle along the Palali Road near the Kondavil Junction in Jaffna, according to Police. Police said the injured are presently receiving treatment at Teaching Hospital Jaffna. The car that collided with the bus on its way to Kilinochchi had subsequently collided with a motorcycle that was travelling in the opposite direction, causing critical injuries to the motorcyclist. Palali Police are conducting investigations. Statements will be recorded from the victims. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Health Ministry to blame for public health crisis
author: Author not found
Content: ITAK Batticaloa District MP Shanakiyan Rasamanickam, yesterday (16), alleged that the Health Ministry should be held responsible for the tragic loss of life within a short span due to medical negligence and medicinal drug issues. MP Rasamanickam said he also suspected the malpractices taking place at the Health Ministry could be the cause for the emergence of such a tragedy. A large number of officials appointed for the Dengue eradication programme in Batticaloa have not been made permanent and this should be looked into expeditiously, he said. He said if the Peradeniya Teaching Hospital was in dire straits, one can just imagine the state of the other divisional hospitals. “Hundreds of persons are dying, but employees attached to the Dengue eradication programme are working tirelessly to protect people,” the ITAK MP said. “These employees were appointed when President Ranil Wickremesinghe was the Premier and he needs to provide a sustainable solution, though they had been marginalised during the ‘Pohottuwa’ Governments,” MP Rasamanickam added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Moonshine production plant raided in Welipitiya
author: Author not found
Content: The Kalutara District Anti-Vice Squad raided an illicit liquor manufacturing plant in Welipitiya. The racket was carried out misusing a permit issued for toddy collection. The main racketeer supplied illicit liquor to Aluthgama, Benthara and surrounding areas. The raid was conducted based on a tip-off received by Kalutara Anti-Vice Squad OIC Nuwan Koralage. The plant was concealed with a cinder block wall. Police seized nearly 27,000 litres of goda used in the production of alcohol, large barrels, water pumps, ammonia, and other equipment used in the racket. Two persons in charge of the plant were arrested and will be produced before the Kalutara Magistrate. State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya recently said illicit liquor production poses a threat to the country’s excise tax revenue. He also said this puts the national economy in jeopardy. By Sanjana Marzook

title: BASL acting in partisan manner
author: Author not found
Content: The Buddhist Lawyers’ Association of Sri Lanka strongly condemned the partisan and selective approach displayed by the Bar Association of Sri Lanka (BASL) whilst agreeing with the sentiments expressed by the BASL to uphold the rule of law and to safeguard the independence of the judiciary. The Sri Lanka Buddhist Lawyers’ Association said they condemn BASL for being silent on parliamentarian M.A. Sumanthiran’s statement criticising the judiciary and expressed its disappointment on the selective nature of the BASL’s stance, wherein it appears to be inconsistent in the application of its principles. The Sri Lanka Buddhist Lawyers’ Association said: First and foremost, it is essential to remind the BASL that it serves as the voice of the legal profession, and thus it has a responsibility to promote unity and fairness within the administration of justice. However, the said statement seems to align itself with sectarian views rather than focusing on the principles of justice and the rule of law. We note with disgust that the BASL was prompt in issuing a statement with regard to a speech made by parliamentarian Dr. Sarath Weerasekara, calling it a barren attack on the judiciary, when he was expressing his views of denial of freedom of religion at the several Bhikkus of the Kurundi Vihara. It is also surprising that the BASL was completely silent and did not think it fit to issue a similar statement condemning the blistering attack on the judiciary by parliamentarian M.A. Sumanthiran, who also happens to be a member of the BASL. During the debate on the 22nd Amendment to the Constitution Bill in Parliament, parliamentarian Sumanthiran had stated: “It is not only the Parliament that swings like a pendulum; it is (also) the Supreme Court judges of this country, so change that Supreme Court also. Ask them to go home if they can’t read and understand their own determination in the 19th Amendment, with the very same words, within a few years, they said no, this requires a referendum  How can that be? They are supposed to be learned?” This is a scathing attack by parliamentarian Sumanthiran on the Apex Court, and the Supreme Court judges of this country. However, quite shockingly the BASL remained silent, it underlined.                          (SM)

title: Dry rations distributed at Sri Vijayarama Maha Viharaya
author: Author not found
Content: Donations of dry rations to the underprivileged by Buddhist temples in China under the Faxian Charity Project are being held islandwide. One such programme was held at Akkaraipattu Sri Vijayarama Maha Viharaya under the patronage of its Chief Incumbent, Venerable Dewagoda Soratha Thera. Under the guidance of General Officer Commanding 24 Infantry Brigade, Major General W. Chandrasiri and the coordination of Commander 241 Infantry Brigade, Colonel L.S.D.N. Pathirathna, 100 dry ration packs were distributed among low-income families in Akkaraipattu on Saturday (15). The ration packs, each worth Rs 5,100, were donated by Chinese Buddhist temples as a gesture of goodwill. Social activists Nishantha Witharana and Udaya Karunarathna, were the main facilitators of the donation programme and they arranged the dry ration packs in coordination with Chinese Buddhist temples. The ration packs were distributed among needy students of Akkaraipattu Dharmarathana Sinhala Maha Vidyalaya and Damruwan Preschool at Akkaraipattu Sri Vijayarama Buddhist Temple. The beneficiaries greatly appreciated the initiative of the Sri Lanka Army and the goodwill of Chinese Buddhists, as it was a great relief to them during the crippling economic crisis. By M.A.P. Deen – Ampara

title: Both sides aim to further cooperation
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena said the opening of a resident Diplomatic Mission of New Zealand in Colombo demonstrates that both sides recognise the importance of furthering cooperation in practical and meaningful ways. Speaking at the opening of the New Zealand High Commission in Sri Lanka – being commemorated on Friday, 14 July on the occasion of Matariki or Māori New Year, he said this step will assist in forging stronger links between the two countries across all spheres, focusing primarily on advancing economic, trade, and investment partnerships. Pointing out that Sri Lanka and New Zealand are the oldest democracies in Asia and the Pacific and both countries are enjoying universal franchise since 1931, the Prime Minister thanked New Zealand for assisting to set up a Dental College in Maharagama in 1951 and the National Milk Board in 1956. The first few batches of nurses were trained in New Zealand. The IOH has produced nearly 1,000 qualified nurses (967) and 345 of them are presently in service. The IOH has conducted school dental clinics in 443 schools islandwide, he said. The Prime Minister urged New Zealand to further collaborate to upgrade the IOH by providing dental expertise and educational affiliations with New Zealand Dental Universities. High Commissioner Michael Appleton said the opening of the resident mission is a chance for the two countries to take their close relations to the next level. “Our Matariki holiday is about unity, renewal, celebration, hope, and a new beginning. It provides New Zealanders a chance to pause, reflect and look optimistically to the future,” Appleton said in his speech at the event. “In the spirit of Matariki, I would like to wish Sri Lankans, and indeed the Sri Lanka-New Zealand relationship, unity, hope and a new beginning.” The event also featured Ngati Koraha, a Māori kapahaka group with performances reflective of the culture of New Zealand’s indigenous people. Appleton said New Zealand, as a long-standing friend, had sought to assist Sri Lanka in its time of need. “At the height of the crisis last year, we provided humanitarian assistance targeting malnourished children and struggling farmers,” he said. “More recently, we have been focused on providing niche technical assistance in policy areas where we have expertise and where Sri Lankan authorities are seeking to make reform, such as on public financial management, governance, and diversity in political representation.” Appleton added that just as Sri Lanka and Sri Lankans had sought to adapt to the economic crisis, so had New Zealand tried to tailor its approach. “As Sri Lanka seeks to write a new chapter in its history, the New Zealand-Sri Lanka relationship is also adapting, renewing, and moving in different directions. In coming years, as Sri Lanka seeks to adapt, improve and reform in response to the crisis, New Zealand will be here in Colombo – a steady, friendly partner, looking for new ways to cooperate that benefit our two peoples, whether in commerce, education, tourism, sport, security, foreign policy or via our respective diasporas.” Ministers, MPs, diplomats and senior officials attended the event.

title: CEJ issues LoDs to GSMB, State institutions
author: Author not found
Content: The Centre for Environmental Justice (CEJ) has taken measures to issue Letters of Demand (LoD) to the Geological Survey and Mines Bureau (GSMB) and several other State institutions and Ministries for allegedly permitting private entities to export phosphate illegally with the involvement of the relevant minister, ministry secretary without following due tender procedure and disregarding previous Supreme Court rulings. CEJ Legal Officer Attorney-at-Law Thusini C. Jayasekara, on behalf of CEJ’s Senior Adviser Hemantha Withanage and Executive Director Dilena Pathragoda sent LoDs to the Inspector General of Police (IGP), Minister of Industries, Minister of Environment, Commissioner, Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption, Chairman of GSMB, Director General of GSMB and the Secretary of the Ministry of Environment. Following are excerpts: I am instructed to state that considering the facts, there is a binding judgment delivered by the Supreme Court of Sri Lanka regarding the Eppawala phosphate resources in the Supreme Court judgment, known as Bulankulama and Others v. Secretary, Ministry of Industrial Development and others [2000]. According to the aforementioned judgment, the planned undertaking for phosphate mining and mineral extraction at Eppawala falls under the category of a Prescribed Project (pg. 306 of the Judgement) as stated in Part I (6) of Gazette Extraordinary No. 772/22 dated 24 June 1993, in accordance with Section 23Z of the National Environmental Act, No. 47 of 1980, as amended (NEA 1980). The Court also acknowledged the collective rights of the citizens, as well as the principles of the precautionary principle, rational planning, the polluter pays principle, and inter-generational equity through the judgment. I am instructed to state that you, your institution along with the other officials and the politicians have violated the above-mentioned binding rules promulgated by the Supreme Court of this country. In addition to that, I have been further instructed to state that you all have violated the existing statutes and Gazette Notifications with regard to the mining of phosphate and exporting such minerals. I have been further instructed to state that you all have violated the existing tender procedure in awarding the contract for the extraction of the minerals as well as the legal provisions related to purchasing and exportation. I have been further instructed by my clients to state that the existing tender procedure inter alia state as follows: The Procurement process should ensure: (a) maximising economy, timeliness and quality in Procurement resulting in least cost together with the high quality; (b) adhering to prescribed standards, specifications, rules, regulations and good governance; (c) providing fair, equal and maximum opportunity for eligible interested parties to participate in Procurement; (d) expeditious execution of Works and delivery of Goods and Services; (e) compliance with local laws and regulations and international obligations; (f) ensuring transparency and consistency in the evaluation and selection procedure; and (g) retaining confidentiality of information provided by bidders. However, I’m instructed to state that none of the above procurement objectives and procedures have been followed by you and, by the above-mentioned institutions, officials and politicians. I am further instructed to draw your attention to the following extract found in the SC/ FRA/ 147/2017: In the aforementioned judgement, His Lordship Justice Amerasinghe expressing his view in Pamkayu (M) SND BHD (Appearing By Its Attorney, Hemachandra) and Another Vs. Liyanaarachchi, Secretary, Ministry of Transport and Highways and Another (2001) 1 SLR 118 at page 125, states that, “The award of a tender must be based on compliance with the terms and conditions of the tender documents on the date and at the time specified for the closing of the tender. An offer that does not comply with the terms, conditions and specifications at that date and time must be rejected in the same way as a late offer.” In a similar vein, it was held in Noble Resources International (supra, at pages 155 and 161) that “[I]t is essential to the maintenance of the rule of law that every organ of the State must act within the limits of its power …When specific provisions are laid down in the Government Procurement Guidelines- 2006 and in the Bid Documents, the rule of law will imply that the requirements of those provisions are not violated.” As held in SmithKline Beecham (supra) at page 29, when referring to inequality before ‘law’ and equal protection of the ‘law’, the ‘law’ mentioned therein is “not confined to the enactments of Parliament, and includes the regulations, rules, directions, instructions, guidelines and schemes that are designed to guide public authorities.” Therefore, the Government Procurement Guidelines of 2006 on Goods and Works, which in its Preface itself assures that the purpose of its enactment is to, “enhance the transparency of Government procurement process to minimise delays and to obtain financially the most advantageous and qualitatively the best services and supplies for the nation” should be upheld when awarding bidders on public tenders (Emphasis added). You and the officials and the politicians above mentioned have also violated the provisions of the Bribery and Corruption Act and have also committed an offence punishable under the provisions of the above Act and, have also violated the provisions of the Mines and Minerals Act, provisions of the Penal Code and the provisions of the Constitution of the Republic of Sri Lanka In the said circumstances, I am instructed to demand from you and the demand is hereby made of you to suspend the exportation of phosphate forthwith until the proper legal investigation is conducted by the relevant authorities including the judiciary in this regard. In the event of your failure to take action as herein demanded, I am instructed to take such further action(s) against you to punish you and or to imprison you and for the recovery of damages caused by you to the country and to its future generations, without any further reference to you. By Gagani Weerakoon

title: Ganiya Banister pleads guilty; gets two-year suspended RI
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court (CHC) Judge Namal Balalle, on Friday (14), imposed a two-year rigorous imprisonment on accused Swiss Embassy official Ganiya Banister Francis, who pleaded guilty to the charge of furnishing fake information to destabilise the former Government and ordered it to be suspended for a period of five years. When the case was taken up, the accused was present in Court and on her pleading guilty to the charge filed against her the aforementioned punishment was imposed on her. Judge Balalle also ordered the accused to pay compensation of Rs 2 million and a fine of Rs 5,000 and ordered the passport of the accused which had been impounded by the Court, to be released back to her. The Court instructed its Registrar, to convey its decision in this regard, to the Controller General of the Department of Immigration and Emigration. When the case was taken up, the prosecution submitted its amended indictments against the accused, after being advised to do so, during the previous Pre-Trial Conference (PTC) of the case, by the Court. Thereafter, the accused Swiss Embassy official pleaded guilty to the charges filed against her and the Court thus imposed the said penalties on her. DSG Janaka Bandara prosecuted on behalf of the AG, while Kalinga Indatissa PC, represented the accused. The Second Officer of the Swiss Embassy in Colombo had lodged a written complaint with the then Acting IGP, on 27 November four years ago, that its official Ganiya Banister Francis, who is a resident of Maligawatta, had been abducted by a five-member gang in the Cinnamon Gardens area, three days earlier. The written complaint to the Acting IGP had further alleged, that Francis on being abducted by the gang, had been sexually abused, after which she had been detained and questioned, regarding providing visa facilities to Ex-CID sleuth Nishantha Silva and then released. The CID, had then commenced a probe into the alleged incident, based on advice from the Acting IGP and it had also been mentioned in the complaint, that the Embassy official, had been abducted, while she had been proceeding to her child’s school. The Colombo Chief Magistrate, at the time, ordered her passport to be impounded, over her failure to provide a statement on the incident to the CID, during the course of the latter’s probe into it. However, the Embassy staffer was then noticed to provide a statement to the CID, before 9 December 2019. The CID thereafter named Ganiya Francis, as a suspect in the case, on 16 December of that year, as per instructions from the then AG and subsequently the CID arrested her and produced her in Court. The suspect, who was then remanded, was enlarged on bail by the Colombo Chief Magistrate’s Court on 30 December 2019. Lastly, the AG proceeded to indict her before the HC, two years ago on charges of furnishing bogus information, with the sinister intention of destabilising, the then regime.              By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: No talks held on digital services tax
author: Author not found
Content: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) claimed it has not discussed any plans for a digital services tax with Sri Lankan authorities in the current programme. An IMF spokesperson further clarified that it has not provided any recommendation on whether or not Sri Lanka should sign on to the OECD/G20 Inclusive Framework agreement for international corporate taxation. The OECD (Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development)/G20 inclusive framework on BEPS (Base Erosion and Profit Shifting) over 135 countries and jurisdictions are collaborating on the implementation of 15 measures to tackle tax avoidance, improve the coherence of international tax rules and ensure a more transparent tax environment. The IMF statement came in response to some recent media reports and queries regarding its advice for digital service tax in Sri Lanka. Revenue mobilisation is a key pillar of the IMF Programme with Sri Lanka, the spokesperson said further, adding that as part of the upcoming first review of the Extended Fund Facility (EFF) programme scheduled in September, the global lender plans to discuss with the authorities how best to mobilise additional revenue. This could include considering the benefits and challenges of introducing a digital service tax. The IMF said it would work with the authorities to put in place reforms that are in the best interest of Sri Lanka and its people.

title: 14-hour water cut in Colombo and suburbs
author: Author not found
Content: The National Water Supply and Drainage Board (NWSDB) will impose a 14-hour water cut tomorrow (15) from 8:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. in Colombo 1 to 4 and Colombo 7 to 14. NWSDB made this announcement as renovation work is to be carried out on the power line that supplies electricity to the Maligakanda and Eli reservoirs. The Board also announced possible inconveniences to consumers in these areas while instructing them to dial the hotline 1939 for further information. Meanwhile, NWSDB will impose an eight-and-a-half-hour water cut on 16 July beginning from 8:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. in every area coming under the Biyagama Water Treatment Plant of NWSDB, Indika Prashanthi Vithana said yesterday (13). She said the Board has made this urgent announcement as sudden renovation work is to be carried out at the Sapugaskanda Power Station on this day. Accordingly, water cuts will be imposed in Peliyagoda, Wattala, Ja-Ela, Katunayake and Seeduwa Municipality areas and Kelaniya, Biyagama, Mahara, Dompe, Minuwangoda and Katana Pradeshiya Sabha limits, according to Vithana. The people living in the aforesaid areas and other government and private sector entities and business establishments have been asked to make arrangements to keep enough water stored for the day’s use, Vithana added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: 2024 Grade 1 applications called
author: Author not found
Content: The instructions relating to the admission of students to Grade One for the year 2024 in government schools were released by the Education Ministry. “A specimen application form was published on the website www.moe.gov.lk,” it said. The Ministry said parents or legal guardians, who wished to enrol their children into Grade One of Government schools in 2024, should submit their applications prepared as per the specimen form and instructions and send them to the relevant Heads of Schools by registered post to reach them before 18 August 2023. The Ministry said all qualifications must be fulfilled and valid up to 30 June 2023.

title: Sri Lanka participates at EXPO Turismo Goiás 2023 in Brazil
author: Author not found
Content: The Embassy of Sri Lanka in Brazil in collaboration with the Sri Lanka Tourism Promotion Bureau (SLTPB) participated at the EXPO Turismo Goiás 2023 held at the Convention Centre in Goiânia from 7 to 8 July 2023. Addressing the opening ceremony, the Ambassador of Sri Lanka to Brazil, Sumith Dassanayake, informed the well-attended audience of Brazilian travel traders on the diversity of the tourism industry in Sri Lanka and invited them to enter into partnership arrangements with their Sri Lankan counterparts to receive mutual benefits. During the technical sessions held on 8 July, First Secretary (Commercial) of the Embassy, Chathurika Perera made a presentation highlighting tourist attractions and other related details pertaining to Sri Lanka Tourism. The Embassy officials met with the officials of the Brazilian Hotel Industry Association (ABIH-GO), Brazilian Association of Travel Agencies (Abav) and Tourism & Hospitality Union in the State of Goiás (Sindtur-GO) during the event and discussed on the possibility of future cooperation between respective organisations of the two countries. The Sri Lanka pavilion decorated with scenic pictures, banners of Sri Lanka and showcased different flavours of Ceylon Tea, Cinnamon and other traditional items, etc;. The pavilion attracted wider attention of both printed and electronic media. ‘TV Alego’ one of the prominent TV channels in the State of Goiás made a live coverage on the Sri Lanka booth. A number of You Tubers and other broadcasters also gave live coverage on the Sri Lanka pavilion on their media platforms. The Embassy also arranged to screen video clips on Sri Lanka Tourism, at regular intervals at the entrance of the convention centre. Over 2,500 visitors visited the Sri Lankan pavilion were presented on ‘Sri Lanka’ and provided the opportunity to taste Ceylon Tea.

title: Health Minister should resign – Wimal
author: Author not found
Content: Chairman of the Uttara Lanka Sabhagaya, MP Wimal Weerawansa said the Minister of Health, who has allowed a medicinal drug shortage to take place while paving the way for the purchase of substandard drugs sans a proper tender procedure, should tender his resignation forthwith. He charged that the subject Minister should also be held accountable for earning commissions via underhand deals ahead of so-called emergency purchases while driving scores of innocent patients to the mortuary. The MP made these allegations addressinga media briefing convened by the Supreme Lanka Coalition (SLC) in Colombo yesterday (13). Among others who spoke at the media briefing were SLC General Secretary Dr. G. Weerasinghe, Patron of the SLC MP Ven. Athuraliye Ratana Thera and Deputy Secretary of the SLC MP Gevindu Cumaratunga. Speaking further, MP Weerawansa said, “It is clear to everyone that the present regime without taking any concrete measures to resolve the country’s economic crisis are continuing their merry way, while placing the lives of the people in jeopardy. On one side, there is an acute shortage of vital drugs in hospitals. On the other, there are serious issues concerning the quality of the drugs which are available in hospitals. The serious nature of this issue could be gauged from the fact that a young woman who had been admitted to hospital for a heart ailment had passed away due to substandard drugs which had been administered to her. The Health Ministry sans conducting requisite tests to determine the quality of drugs and antibiotics had bought such items as emergency purchases. They had bought most of these drugs from India. Due to this situation, scores of patients are being turned into lab rats. It could be argued that presently heading to the hospital is akin to being sent to the mortuary for the people of this country. If this situation is not resolved urgently, those who seek relief from the free medical service will be forced to look elsewhere as it will only be confined to mere words. Countries mired in an economic crisis do not opt for emergency purchases. Such countries have to formulate a proper tender process and then opt for suitable buyers. But, these people are allowing a drug scarcity to take place intentionally so they can opt for emergency purchases as there are commissions which could be obtained under the table. This has now turned into a crisis and now patients have started to die in their numbers. Thus, it has to be questioned whether there are such despicable politicians and State officers in any other country. It is also evident that the Health Minister continues to function in his post as if everything is hunky dory in the country’s health sector. They take prompt Cabinet decisions to fell or even uproot priceless trees such as Crudia zeylanica, but keep mum on removing either Cabinet Ministers or State Officers who are responsible for the deaths of innocent patients. This course of events has to be overturned sooner than later. The Health Ministry must cancel forthwith all so-called emergency purchases. They need to draft a plan to purchase vital drugs in advance. This system of allowing the Ministers and State officers to play with the innocent lives of patients has to end right now. That is why we demand that both the subject Minister and the Health Secretary must tender their respective resignations immediately. But, it seems they have no such intention and therefore this situation has to be described as terrible and unfortunate. But, we as the SLC are ready to do our best to rid this country of these despicable political characters and give fresh leadership and we implore our people to join forces with us in that onerous task.”

title: NWSDB provides new connections to Katana residents
author: Author not found
Content: The National Water Supply and Drainage Board (NWSDB) is implementing the Dorin-Dorata Ran Diyavara project islandwide to provide special concessions to the user community and provide new water supply connections quickly. Under this scheme, the event of providing new water connections in Katana was held on 7.7.2023 at Pallegama Community Centre. Sanjeeva Wijekoon, Vice President of the NWSDB, Ananda Harishchandra, former Western Provincial Council Member, Hemantha, Govinna, Pradeshiya Sabha member, Piyal Padmanath, Deputy General Manager (Commercial), Assistant General Manager (Billing), Manager, Commercial Officer and Officer-in-Charge participated in the event. Bank of Ceylon also participated in this programme for the purpose of accepting new water connection estimates and providing instalment facilities under zero interest basis.

title: SJB will pursue amendments to EPF Act – Harsha
author: Author not found
Content: The Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) Economic Council said it will continue to pursue bringing in amendments to the 1958 Employees’ Provident Fund Act, to ensure the active membership of 2.6 million beneficiaries will receive a minimum rate of return at a fixed rate, or representative of market rates or reflective of inflation. Addressing the SJB Blueprint media briefing, MP Harsha de Silva said these amendments will be presented by the Economic Council of SJB and that the amendment proposals will guide the members to determine a certain minimum return or to pay an interest return equal to the interest income received for other investments or to pay a capital interest. “To protect the benefits due to the members of the EPF, Colombo District Samagi Jana Balawegaya will bring amendments to the Employees’ Provident Fund Act introduced by T.B. Ilangaratne in 1958. At present, there are 19.6 million accounts in this fund. Of these, about 2.6 million beneficiaries are active. The benefits they receive should be permanent for the next 15 years. That’s why we hope to submit these amendments,” de Silva said. De Silva noted that there have been accusations that in the recent domestic debt optimisation, the burden has been placed unilaterally on the EPF and that this violates the principles of fairness. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Sirisena should set an example to all citizens– Fr. Fernando
author: Author not found
Content: With former President Maithripala Sirisena requesting an extension period to settle the remaining sum of Rs 85 million as compensation to the victims of the Easter Sunday attacks, Director for National Catholic Mass Communication (NCMC), Fr. Jude Krishantha Fernando, lashing out, said he (the former President) should set an example to the citizens of Sri Lanka by abiding by the Court order. Fr. Fernando yesterday (13) pointed out that the compensation was not for those who had died in the violent attacks but for those victims who had survived with severe injuries for which they were still undergoing treatment. In some families, it was the breadwinner that died in the blasts leaving behind fatherless families with no support. Children of those families need support for their education. Therefore, it is an insult to these victims that those responsible for their misery were delaying and showing such reluctance to fulfil the Supreme Court ruling.  The Supreme Court held that the respondents had failed to prevent the Easter Sunday attacks in 2019 despite having received prior intelligence and had violated fundamental rights preserved under Article 12(1) and 14(1)(e) of the Constitution as a result. “The NCMC Media Director alleged that seven people holding responsible positions had violated the human rights of the victims and their families. They should not disobey that law but should at least now work towards uplifting the lives of those people who suffered. Or else they would only show that they were using their positions to violate the human rights of those victims further,” he said. He also warned that such a move would only serve to establish the opinion that the United Nations Human Rights Council has of Sri Lankans and its hierarchy. Fr. Fernando said there had been a large gathering of international media at the Vatican at the time the Easter Sunday victims visited it and that they too would be of the same opinion. They too would note that higher officials and even the former President of Sri Lanka were continuing to violate the human rights of victims. Only a part of the compensation money has been paid to the victims of the 2019 Easter Sunday attacks. While former President Sirisena has paid only Rs 15 million, he requested the Supreme Court for an extension to pay the outstanding amount of Rs 85 million through a series of ten equal instalments until 2033 Also, the National Intelligence Chief, Sisira Mendis has paid Rs 5 million and former IGP Pujith Jayasundara paid Rs 1.75 million. The former Defence Secretary has paid only Rs 1 million while the former SIS Director has paid Rs 4.1 million.   By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Six arrested with Valampuri worth Rs 56M
author: Author not found
Content: The Ja-Ela Police arrested six suspects with a Valampuri (conch shell) in their possession, which they planned to sell for Rs 56,000,000. Police also seized a cab and two motorcycles. The arrests were made based on a tip-off. The Valampuri is 14 inches in length, left-sided and brown in colour with white and yellow spots. The suspects include four men aged 30, 32, 48 and 59 and two women aged 26 and 58. They are residents of Kirindiwela, Nittambuwa, Angoda and Maligakanda. Ja-Ela Police are conducting investigations. By Sanjana Marzook
