title: Elon Musk announces new AI start-up
author: Author not found
Content: Tesla boss Elon Musk has announced the formation of an artificial intelligence startup. The new company is called xAI, and includes several engineers that have worked at companies like OpenAI and Google. Musk has previously stated he believes developments in AI should be paused and that the sector needs regulation. He said the start-up was created to “understand reality”. It is unclear how much funding the entity has, what its specific objectives are or what kind artificial intelligence the company wants to focus on. The company’s website says the goal of xAI is to “understand the true nature of the universe.” The new firm will host a Twitter Spaces chat on Friday, which may reveal further details about its aims. Elon Musk was the one of the original backers of OpenAI, which went on to create the popular large language model ChatGPT, which has – often controversially – become popular for uses such as assisting students with writing homework. However, the billionaire’s relationship with the company has soured. He has criticised ChatGPT for having a liberal bias. “What we need is TruthGPT”, Musk tweeted in February. He also disagrees with how ChatGPT has been run – and its close relationship with Microsoft. “It does seem weird that something can be a nonprofit, open source and somehow transform itself into a for-profit, closed source,” Musk said in a CNBC interview. In March, Musk signed an open letter calling for a pause to “Giant AI Experiments”, which to date has around 33,000 signatures. In an interview with the BBC in April Musk said he had been worrying about AI safety for over a decade. “I think there should be a regulatory body established for overseeing AI to make sure that it does not present a danger to the public”, he said. Musk has also pitted himself against AI companies due to the data they use to train chatbots – the software that learns how humans interacts by scraping masses of data from various sources to fuel its knowledge and interaction styles. The billionaire believes vast amounts of Twitter’s data is scraped from the platform, and that the company should be adequately compensated. Musk purchased the microblogging platform in a deal worth billions, before making sweeping changes which led to many leaving the platform in protest, including the producer of shows such as Grey’s Anatomy and Bridgerton, Shonda Rhimes, as well as model Gigi Hadid and comedian and actor Stephen Fry. (BBC)

title: Reviving Gandhara Civilisation and Buddhist Heritage in Pakistan
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister’s Task Force on Gandhara Tourism; the Institute of Strategic Studies Islamabad (ISS); and Directorate of Archaeology and Museums, Government of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa convened the Gandhara Symposium titled “Cultural Diplomacy: Reviving Gandhara Civilisation and Buddhist Heritage in Pakistan” in Islamabad. The Inaugural Session, held on 11 July 2023, was attended by President of Pakistan, Dr. Arif Alvi, as a Chief Guest, where he addressed the audience. Dr. Ramesh Kumar Vankwani, Minister of State, Chairman of the Prime Minister Task Force on Gandhara Tourism, was the Guest of Honour. In his address, the President of Pakistan lauded the initiative and reminded the audience that the Gandhara Civilisation held immense importance for the Pakistani nation, representing a powerful dimension of our rich cultural heritage. The President emphasised that in today’s world, where hatred is on the rise and increasing polarisation is fuelling conflicts, it’s time to rediscover the role of cultural diplomacy to promote dialogue among civilisations. He stressed that cultural diplomacy holds enormous potential to strengthen global ties. The journey to revive the glorious Gandhara Civilisation and Buddhist Heritage in Pakistan is thus vital in this regard. The President believed Gandhara was a learning centre that attracted intellectual discourse, and its cosmopolitan nature and cultural fusion fostered an environment of tolerance and harmony. He accentuated that reinventing humankind towards peace and harmony is the biggest challenge today. To address this, the President recommended that the message of peace from religions is the most important one that the world needs today. The movement to end violence in the world is perhaps the most important today. It can emanate in the form of a message of peace from Buddha. Dr. Ramesh Kumar Vankwani stressed that the revival of the Gandhara civilisation is a dream that necessities the encouragement of all stakeholders. This Symposium symbolises a commitment to the revival of Gandhara civilisation and Pakistan’s rich Buddhist Heritage. He stated that the soft power of cultures needs to be capitalised on. In this regard, collaboration within the country among all stakeholders as well as cooperation from other countries is vital. Gandhara tourism, he quoted, has the potential to draw five lack people to Pakistan that can bring about USD 1.5 billion in revenue in its first year, followed by USD 3 billion and USD 6 billion per year. He also spoke about his plan to promote tourism in Pakistan by giving new breath to the great legacy of Gandhara. This will also help in improving the prosperous and peaceful image of Pakistan. Session I of the Gandhara Symposium was on the theme ‘Pathways to Peace: Exploring Pakistan’s Rich Buddhist Legacy.’ The speakers were religious scholars and faith leaders from Malaysia, Thailand, South Korea, Nepal, Sri Lanka and China. The speakers agreed that Gandhara was a major centre for Buddhist learning and education and recommended preserving the Buddhist Gandhara Heritage in Pakistan. Session II discussed ‘Gandhara Civilisation: Celebrating Pakistan’s Buddhist Heritage.’ The panel of the second session’s presenters comprised experts, faith leaders and religious scholars who emphasized that Buddhist Gandhara Heritage is paramount to Pakistan. Pakistan is blessed with rich culture and is a hub of civilisation. The Punjab and Sindh have landmark historical sites with excellent archaeological research and spiritual tourism opportunities. Pakistan’s Buddhist legacy offers a pathway to peace, harmony and tranquillity. The best way to preserve cultural heritage is to share it with the world and allow them to be part of this world. The panellists suggested that the Buddhist Heritage has economic potential and educational attraction. They recommended promoting Gandhara Heritage to the world and creating economic opportunities for Pakistan. The speakers stressed that we must try to dispel the misconceptions about Pakistan and build trust among Buddhist people so, that Buddhists can come to Pakistan from around the world. Session III of the Gandhara Symposium delved into ways of ‘Promoting Tourism: Creating an Enabling Environment.’ Experts from Pakistan’s tourism industry and think tanks were invited as speakers. The panellists agreed that efforts need to be put in to develop the tourist industry of Pakistan that presents a positive image of the country. They suggested that special attention should be given to various tourism-related sectors such as visa regimes, film and media, hospitality, culinary, museums, tours and tourist centres to promote the potential of Gandhara tourism in Pakistan. Lastly, an illustrious panel of religious experts, academics, curators, faith leaders and other stakeholders gathered for a Roundtable on ‘Gandhara Civilisation: Opportunities and Challenges.’ Pakistan is a safe place for tourism, and this conference conveys this message aptly. Pakistan is going to start Gandhara Tourism, and it is ready to collaborate with other countries to enhance B2B and P2P contacts. The roundtable concluded that the lack of security structure, awareness and marketing, funds for preservation and restoration, unsupervised hotels, underdeveloped roads, tourist safety, and lack of modern tourism infrastructure were a few of the mentioned challenges.

title: SLAF holds annual Christian Commemorative Service
author: Author not found
Content: The Annual Air Force Christian Commemorative Service, where the Air Force remembers and appreciates those who laid down their lives in the name of service and nation, was held at St. Mary’s Church, Bambalapitiya, recently, under the auspices of the Commander of the Air Force, Air Marshal Udeni Rajapaksa. Chief of Staff of SLAF, Air Vice Marshal Sampath Wickremaratne, Members of the Air Force Board of Management, a cross section of Officers with their families, Other Ranks, civilian staff and family members of those who have sacrificed their lives in action for preserving the sovereignty of the nation, participated in the Service. The ceremony commenced with bagpipers leading the Officiating Clergy to the Alter. Christian Clergy representing all major sects of the Christian faith participated at the service, invoking divine blessings on the Commander of the Air Force and all members so, that they may continue to protect and defend the skies above Sri Lanka. Air Commodore Gihan Senaviratne delivered the welcome address. Wing Commander Ruwan Goonewardene read the prayer of dedication, while Squadron Leader Shakya Wickremasinghe conducted the First Reading in Sinhala and Warrant Officer Rajkumara M conducted the Second Reading in Tamil.  A distinctive feature of the service was the Blessing of the Flags, where Flags representing the Air Force Academy, all Bases and Stations of the SLAF were marched up to the Alter and blessings were invoked on them and the establishments that they represented by His Lordship Most Rev. Dr. Maxwell Silva. A scroll containing the names of all who have laid down their lives in the line of duty was also offered and consecrated.

title: Healthcare staff not to blame – Nurses Union
author: Author not found
Content: Medical and healthcare staff in hospitals expressed deep concern regarding the spate of patient deaths that have occurred following the administering of injections, accusing the Health Ministry of attempting to shoulder the blame on them despite the fault lying elsewhere. Education Secretary of the All Ceylon Nurse’s Union (ACNU), Prabath Palipane lamented yesterday (13) that the Ministry had blamed the ward staff and the doctor who prescribed the drug and the nurse who administered it in a drug-related incident which claimed the life of a 23-year-old woman at the Colombo North Teaching Hospital early this month. “It is not the hospital staff who import these medicinal drugs but the Health Ministry and the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA),” he said. “All these years there had been only one or two pharmaceutical companies purchasing certain medicines but now there seemed to be a change of the company almost every month. Additionally, there should be facilities for testing the medicines which are imported. But even the facilities for testing are poor. Instead of getting their act together, the Health Ministry has squarely placed the blame on the ward staff,” Palipane lamented. Meanwhile, the Health Ministry withheld batches of two anaesthetic drugs which caused the deaths of three patients. Additional Secretary of the Health Ministry, Saman Ratnayake said on Wednesday (12) that batches, DP 2100, DP2202 and DP 2203 of the Bupivacaine injection had been withheld by the NMRA.        By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Sri Lanka participates at EXPO Turismo Goiás 2023 in Brazil
author: Author not found
Content: The Embassy of Sri Lanka in Brazil in collaboration with the Sri Lanka Tourism Promotion Bureau (SLTPB) participated at the EXPO Turismo Goiás 2023 held at the Convention Centre in Goiânia from 7 to 8 July 2023. Addressing the opening ceremony, the Ambassador of Sri Lanka to Brazil, Sumith Dassanayake, informed the well-attended audience of Brazilian travel traders on the diversity of the tourism industry in Sri Lanka and invited them to enter into partnership arrangements with their Sri Lankan counterparts to receive mutual benefits. During the technical sessions held on 8 July, First Secretary (Commercial) of the Embassy, Chathurika Perera made a presentation highlighting tourist attractions and other related details pertaining to Sri Lanka Tourism. The Embassy officials met with the officials of the Brazilian Hotel Industry Association (ABIH-GO), Brazilian Association of Travel Agencies (Abav) and Tourism & Hospitality Union in the State of Goiás (Sindtur-GO) during the event and discussed on the possibility of future cooperation between respective organisations of the two countries. The Sri Lanka pavilion decorated with scenic pictures, banners of Sri Lanka and showcased different flavours of Ceylon Tea, Cinnamon and other traditional items, etc;. The pavilion attracted wider attention of both printed and electronic media. ‘TV Alego’ one of the prominent TV channels in the State of Goiás made a live coverage on the Sri Lanka booth. A number of You Tubers and other broadcasters also gave live coverage on the Sri Lanka pavilion on their media platforms. The Embassy also arranged to screen video clips on Sri Lanka Tourism, at regular intervals at the entrance of the convention centre. Over 2,500 visitors visited the Sri Lankan pavilion were presented on ‘Sri Lanka’ and provided the opportunity to taste Ceylon Tea.

title: Health Minister should resign – Wimal
author: Author not found
Content: Chairman of the Uttara Lanka Sabhagaya, MP Wimal Weerawansa said the Minister of Health, who has allowed a medicinal drug shortage to take place while paving the way for the purchase of substandard drugs sans a proper tender procedure, should tender his resignation forthwith. He charged that the subject Minister should also be held accountable for earning commissions via underhand deals ahead of so-called emergency purchases while driving scores of innocent patients to the mortuary. The MP made these allegations addressinga media briefing convened by the Supreme Lanka Coalition (SLC) in Colombo yesterday (13). Among others who spoke at the media briefing were SLC General Secretary Dr. G. Weerasinghe, Patron of the SLC MP Ven. Athuraliye Ratana Thera and Deputy Secretary of the SLC MP Gevindu Cumaratunga. Speaking further, MP Weerawansa said, “It is clear to everyone that the present regime without taking any concrete measures to resolve the country’s economic crisis are continuing their merry way, while placing the lives of the people in jeopardy. On one side, there is an acute shortage of vital drugs in hospitals. On the other, there are serious issues concerning the quality of the drugs which are available in hospitals. The serious nature of this issue could be gauged from the fact that a young woman who had been admitted to hospital for a heart ailment had passed away due to substandard drugs which had been administered to her. The Health Ministry sans conducting requisite tests to determine the quality of drugs and antibiotics had bought such items as emergency purchases. They had bought most of these drugs from India. Due to this situation, scores of patients are being turned into lab rats. It could be argued that presently heading to the hospital is akin to being sent to the mortuary for the people of this country. If this situation is not resolved urgently, those who seek relief from the free medical service will be forced to look elsewhere as it will only be confined to mere words. Countries mired in an economic crisis do not opt for emergency purchases. Such countries have to formulate a proper tender process and then opt for suitable buyers. But, these people are allowing a drug scarcity to take place intentionally so they can opt for emergency purchases as there are commissions which could be obtained under the table. This has now turned into a crisis and now patients have started to die in their numbers. Thus, it has to be questioned whether there are such despicable politicians and State officers in any other country. It is also evident that the Health Minister continues to function in his post as if everything is hunky dory in the country’s health sector. They take prompt Cabinet decisions to fell or even uproot priceless trees such as Crudia zeylanica, but keep mum on removing either Cabinet Ministers or State Officers who are responsible for the deaths of innocent patients. This course of events has to be overturned sooner than later. The Health Ministry must cancel forthwith all so-called emergency purchases. They need to draft a plan to purchase vital drugs in advance. This system of allowing the Ministers and State officers to play with the innocent lives of patients has to end right now. That is why we demand that both the subject Minister and the Health Secretary must tender their respective resignations immediately. But, it seems they have no such intention and therefore this situation has to be described as terrible and unfortunate. But, we as the SLC are ready to do our best to rid this country of these despicable political characters and give fresh leadership and we implore our people to join forces with us in that onerous task.”

title: NWSDB provides new connections to Katana residents
author: Author not found
Content: The National Water Supply and Drainage Board (NWSDB) is implementing the Dorin-Dorata Ran Diyavara project islandwide to provide special concessions to the user community and provide new water supply connections quickly. Under this scheme, the event of providing new water connections in Katana was held on 7.7.2023 at Pallegama Community Centre. Sanjeeva Wijekoon, Vice President of the NWSDB, Ananda Harishchandra, former Western Provincial Council Member, Hemantha, Govinna, Pradeshiya Sabha member, Piyal Padmanath, Deputy General Manager (Commercial), Assistant General Manager (Billing), Manager, Commercial Officer and Officer-in-Charge participated in the event. Bank of Ceylon also participated in this programme for the purpose of accepting new water connection estimates and providing instalment facilities under zero interest basis.

title: SJB will pursue amendments to EPF Act – Harsha
author: Author not found
Content: The Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) Economic Council said it will continue to pursue bringing in amendments to the 1958 Employees’ Provident Fund Act, to ensure the active membership of 2.6 million beneficiaries will receive a minimum rate of return at a fixed rate, or representative of market rates or reflective of inflation. Addressing the SJB Blueprint media briefing, MP Harsha de Silva said these amendments will be presented by the Economic Council of SJB and that the amendment proposals will guide the members to determine a certain minimum return or to pay an interest return equal to the interest income received for other investments or to pay a capital interest. “To protect the benefits due to the members of the EPF, Colombo District Samagi Jana Balawegaya will bring amendments to the Employees’ Provident Fund Act introduced by T.B. Ilangaratne in 1958. At present, there are 19.6 million accounts in this fund. Of these, about 2.6 million beneficiaries are active. The benefits they receive should be permanent for the next 15 years. That’s why we hope to submit these amendments,” de Silva said. De Silva noted that there have been accusations that in the recent domestic debt optimisation, the burden has been placed unilaterally on the EPF and that this violates the principles of fairness. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Sri Lanka Embassy organises promotional event in Kuwait
author: Author not found
Content: The Embassy of Sri Lanka in Kuwait participated in a promotional event on the sidelines of the Asia Cooperation Dialogue (ACD) Day Reception on 10 July 2023 at Crowne Plaza Hotel. Over 25 member States and other diplomatic missions based in Kuwait participated in the event. Assistant Foreign Minister for Asian Affairs Ambassador Sameeh Essa Johar Hayat graced the event as the Chief Guest.  The visitors to the event included members of the diplomatic corps, UN agencies, political leaders, business leaders, trade chambers, prominent members of Kuwaiti Society, expats and the mainstream media.  The Sri Lanka Embassy showcased the many strengths of Sri Lanka including Ceylon Tea, spices, apparels, handicrafts, culture, tourism and the national carrier SriLankan Airlines. The Embassy’s “Tea tasting” station was the centre of attention where the proper way of brewing of Ceylon Tea was demonstrated under the guidance of Sri Lanka Tea Board. Ceylon Tea of multiple varieties were served to hundreds of visitors. Promotional videos showcasing Sri Lanka’s art, culture, and tourism attractions were shown throughout the event. The Radhika Dance Troupe entertained the audience at the cultural show that followed the ACD reception. Promotional materials in Arabic and English along with tea packs and gift items from the Sri Lanka Tourism Promotion Bureau and the Sri Lanka Tea Board were distributed among the visitors.

title: Villagers of Kanagar Gramam to be resettled soon
author: Author not found
Content: The villagers of Kanagar Gramam in the Pottuvil DS Division who fled their homes and were living in temporary shelters and/or in their relative’s houses owing to the three-decade-long civil war are to be resettled soon on their own soil after about 35 years on the action taken by the Governor of Eastern Province Senthil Thondaman. Several efforts taken by these villagers to get back to their respective places soon after the restoration of peace had failed. The frustrated villagers were also agitating for their lands and had staged several protests, erecting effigies, observing fast unto death etc to no avail. On the advice of the President, Governor Senthil who understood their plight visited Kanagar Gramam recently along with the MP, much to the relief of the villagers. By M.A.P.Deen – Ampara

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Case against Rajitha deferred to 22 September
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court (CHC) Judge Navaratne Marasinghe, yesterday (13), deferred further hearing of the case filed against former Minister of Fisheries Dr. Rajitha Senaratne and two other accused, to 22 September. The SJB MP and two others, namely former Chairman of the Fisheries Corporation Upali Liyanage and its former MD Neil Munasinghe, have been accused before the HC, by the Bribery Commission, of causing a loss of profit to the State, over the illegal leasing out of the Modera Fisheries Harbour, to a private firm, from 1 August to 1 November, nine years ago. When the case was taken up, the three accused were present in Court. PC Sampath Mendis, appearing for the Defence, informed the Court, that the prosecution had only submitted two copies of the audit report compiled by the Auditor General (AG), in this regard and alleged that the remaining copies of the full report had still not been handed over to the Defence. Judge Marasinghe then instructed CIABOC officers to submit copies of the full audit report to the Defence.   By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Police probing fake IELTS certificate racket
author: Author not found
Content: A resident of Mirihana has lodged a Police complaint on 4 July that he was cheated out of Rs 500,000, for what he learnt was a forged IELTS certificate. Headquarters Chief Inspector of Mirihana, H.T.M. Thushara, said the victim, W.H. Irosh Jayanath, was in a hurry to get an IELTS certificate to apply for jobs in Australia. According to the complaint, as there was a certain waiting period to obtain such certificate from British Council, he had been introduced to a person, who had identified himself as a lecturer, for his purpose. With his support, the victim had sat for the IELTS exam on 3 March. Thereafter, he was given the IELTS certificate on 17 March. Further, for the above service he was charged Rs 500,000 and received the IELTS certificate. It was emailed to a person named Alexendra, a job agent in Australia, who replied that it was a forged certificate,” he added. Thushara said the complainant sought the return of Rs 500,000 to the victim and further investigations are underway. (NV)

title: Suspect gets six-year suspended prison term
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Amal Ranaraja, yesterday (13), imposed a six-year suspended prison term, on an accused, after the latter pleaded guilty to a charge of fleecing an individual of a sum of Rs 180,000, under the pretence of providing him a job at the State Printing Corporation. The Judge suspended the six-year prison term for a period of five years and instructed the accused, to pay the entire amount fleeced from the plaintiff, back to him as compensation. The Court also ordered the accused, to pay a fine of Rs 15,000, for three charges filed against him. The accused was identified as Samuel Siyupalan. The Attorney General had indicted the accused before the HC, over the said offence committed five years ago.     By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Further hearing deferred to 14 December
author: Author not found
Content: First witness Amila Priyantha, responding to cross-examination by the Defence, in the abduction case filed against Ex-MP Hirunika Premachandra, before Colombo High Court (CHC) Judge Amal Ranaraja, stated that he has no intention of lying before the Court and that it was true, that the former lawmaker’s henchmen had been ordered to abduct him. He accepted that Premachandra had helped him in the past, but insisted that he has no intention of whitewashing the incident over it. Ahead of the cross-examination, Defence Counsel Eraj Fernando charged that the first witness had provided bogus evidence in Court, with the sole motive of tarnishing his client’s public image. The first witness maintained that submissions produced before Court, by him, were true and genuine and observed that it had not been his aim, to either tarnish anyone’s public image or sling mud at someone politically. The witness was of the view, that due to the severe mental anguish experienced by him over the incident and due to the sufferings he had undergone during the past few years, some of the details related to it, were hard to recall presently. The Defence Counsel stated that the alleged incident had taken place, without his client’s knowledge and stressed that hence it was unfair to level baseless and fabricated charges against her. The witness added that he had no intention of gaining any political mileage over the incident and that it was his sincere aim, to highlight the injustice meted out to him, at the hands of the accused former MP. Thereafter, the HC Judge ordered further hearing of the evidence, to be deferred to 14 December, when the 18th witness to the trial, a Chief Inspector attached to the CCD, is slated to testify. The AG has indicted Premachandra and seven of her aides, before the HC on the charge of forced abduction and intimidation of a youth, who had been employed at a textile shop in Colombo 9, on 21 December eight years ago. However, the seven aides of the accused pleaded guilty to the charges filed against them, on 24 November 2017 and they were imposed with two years RI, which were suspended for 12 years by the HC. The HC then ordered the charges filed against the former lawmaker, to be maintained, as she refused to plead guilty, to the charges filed against her.  By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Ali Sabry off to Jakarta to attend ARF
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Foreign Affairs M.U.M. Ali Sabry will travel to Jakarta, Indonesia to take part in the forthcoming 30th ASEAN Regional Forum (ARF) Ministerial Meeting on 14 July. The ARF is an Asia-Pacific region-centric security dialogue mechanism inaugurated in 1994 in Thailand which seeks to promote regional development and prosperity collectively through open and inclusive dialogue benefiting all stakeholders while recognising the challenges to regional peace, security and prosperity. The ARF has 27 member States and Sri Lanka has been a member of the ARF since 2007. This year’s Forum is hosted by Indonesia, the current Chair of ASEAN under the theme “ASEAN Matters: Epicentrum of Growth” to celebrate the 30th anniversary of the  ARF and exchange views on confidence-building measures and cultivating preventive diplomacy in addressing the pressing regional issues and global challenges.   Foreign Minister Ali Sabry is expected to meet several counterparts on the sidelines of the 30th ARF for bilateral discussions during his stay in Jakarta.

title: Procurement process commences for SL-UDI
author: Author not found
Content: The procurement process of the Indo-Sri Lanka joint project for the Sri Lanka Unique Digital Identity Project (SL-UDI) has commenced, State Minister of Technology Kanaka Herath announced yesterday (13). The project commenced with the signing of an MoU between Sri Lanka and India on 28 March 2022 and an Indo-Sri Lanka Joint Project Monitoring Committee (JPMC) for the SL-UDI project was introduced. The Government of India is overseeing the software development for the SL-UDI and has contributed INR 300 million to this cause. As a result, major automated biometric systems and other software systems will be installed with the Information and Communication Technology Agency of Sri Lanka’s full supervision and consultation (ICTA). The technological knowledge needed in preparing a Digital ID will be provided by ICTA and PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) Lanka. The second stage of the project will involve collaboration with the Department for Registration of Persons to collate a database of citizen information, including biometric data. The aim is to begin collecting this data by 2024. As part of this project, even newborns will be assigned an index number, and by the age of 15, individuals will receive their National Identity Card. With the launch of the SL-UDI project, every citizen in the country will get a unique number. The project aims to collect biographic and biometric information, including facial, iris, and fingerprint data, which will be stored in a centralised system for the purpose of issuing identity cards as per the standards set by the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO). In the first phase, the project will be launched by the ICTA under the supervision of the Technology Ministry. With the implementation of the project, more effective and efficient delivery of government services, poverty reduction and welfare programmes; financial inclusion through better access to banking and other products/services, and minimisation of corruption, will be ensured.  By Sanjana Marzook

title: Navy Thwarts Gold Smuggling Racket
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Navy foiled a smuggling racket via sea in the wee hours on Wednesday (12), seizing about 8kg and 450g of gold, during a special operation mounted in the Wannimundalama lagoon area, Kalpitiya. The operation led to the apprehension of two suspects and a dinghy used for this illegal act. The Navy carries out regular search operations and patrols in the coastal and sea areas around the island, with a view to preventing a series of nefarious activities. As an extension of these efforts, SLNS Vijaya in the Northwestern Naval Command conducted this special operation in the Wannimundalama lagoon yesterday. Upon detection of a suspicious dinghy speeding off from the lagoon towards the Kalpitiya sea area, the Navy intercepted the dinghy and searched it on suspicion. During the search, about 8kg and 450g of gold, suspected to be smuggled, were recovered in four packages which were concealed in the dinghy. Also, two suspects in connection to the incident and a dinghy used for the act were detained by the Navy. The suspects aged 37 and 42 respectively are residents of Mandalakuda in Kalpitiya. The accused along with gold and the dinghy are being handed over to Customs Preventive Office, Katunayake for legal proceedings.

title: Crisis and the Way Forward
author: Author not found
Content: It has been 80 years since the founding of the Marxist-Leninist Communist Party of Sri Lanka. Although some of the party’s founding motivations have yet to be realised, the Communist Party has managed to bring several victories to the people of Sri Lanka. From full independence to the establishment of the welfare sector of the economy, the Communist Party has made enormous contributions to the motherland. The Communist Party’s 80th Anniversary coincides with Sri Lanka’s economic crisis. Before any party predicted or attempted to remedy the situation, the Sri Lankan Communist Party published a Book titled “What needs to be done and what should be prioritised” in 2019, which was given to then-presidential candidate and later Sri Lankan President Gotabaya Rajapaksa. However, due to the lack of attention to policy-driven politics that pervades Sri Lankan political culture, this proposal was rejected. That government’s fate was a result of its aimless politics. Despite the fact that Sri Lankan political culture is based on superficial rhetoric, the Communist Party proposed a short-term policy proposal based on an empirical analysis of the crisis. This was published and submitted to the appropriate authorities at the time. The short-term policy proposal of the Communist Party addresses various aspects of the crisis, including debt restructuring, welfare renovation, financial innovation, food security, and various fiscal adjustments. Since its inception, the Communist Party has understood the Sri Lankan problem in terms of capital dynamics and the labour relations that result from them (so-called class contradiction). The first “idirimaga (Way Forward)” clearly mentions the existing stage of capital development and class contradictions. Sri Lanka, like all former imperial colonies, is confronted with the problem of dispositioned modes of production. In contrast to advanced economies, colonial countries were occupied by an external force at some point in their history and rearranged their mode of production to meet the needs of the coloniser rather than the country’s national interest. When a country achieves constitutional independence, its modes of production must also achieve independence and align with its national interests. For a variety of reasons, this is a long-term project. Despite the fact that dispositioned modes of production have significant economic externalities for the country’s development, they also contribute to the existing economy. In the sector, there are already stakeholders. These industries employ a sizable number of people. As a result, such industries cannot be ignored. Instead, to industrialise and increase productivity, we must propose an industrial plan for such sectors of the economy. Industrialisation will not only strengthen labour-capital relations, but it will also decouple these sectors of the economy from their colonial roots. Apart from Marshall Plan countries, only a few colonial countries are rapidly modernising, with Marxist-Leninist-ruled China and Vietnam being the best examples. The majority of postcolonial countries that had previously dispositioned production modes were compelled to undergo emerging neoliberal economic reforms. Neoliberalism is a global bourgeois reaction to the stagnant productivity of the global economy. This includes decreasing government intervention in the economy, privatising State-owned assets, and reducing welfare. As a result of neoliberal reforms, postcolonial economies (except Vietnam and China) were forced to undergo a condition known as premature deindustrialisation. In the case of Sri Lanka, neoliberal reforms were imposed on the country’s economy in 1977. Neoliberal reforms not only deindustrialised the economy but also exacerbated Sri Lanka’s colonial legacies. Neoliberal reforms inherited a chronic ‘balance of payment’ problem as a result of the economy’s lower relative productivity in comparison to the rest of the world. Rather than addressing the root cause of the crisis, governments after 1977 focused on debt absorption to address the ‘balance of payment’ problem. The national debt then ballooned to the point of default in 2022. Industrialisation, progressive segments of society should recognise, is the path to national liberation from its colonial capital relationship. Industrialisation not only improves our citizens’ quality of life but also prepares the country to defend its sovereignty. The majority of countries around the world defend their sovereignty by industrialising. As a result, the Communist Party proposes a policy path for Sri Lanka called Idirimagen Idiriyata, which provides an overview of the country’s sectors as well as a path forward.  Our policy approach to Sri Lanka is technically driven, pragmatic, and fundamentally based on our motherland’s best interests. Our 80-year legacy demonstrates that the Communist Party of Sri Lanka is one of the country’s few parties that has always fought for the country’s best interests. The policy proposal of the Sri Lankan Communist Party envisions a socially harmonious, technologically advanced, and environmentally sustainable path for our motherland. Times may change. But the spirit is eternal. The Communist Party of Sri Lanka’s, Education Dept

title: Sagala in discussion with officials of Indian High Commission
author: Author not found
Content: The survey to explore the possibilities of laying a pipeline to transport the petroleum products from India to Sri Lanka is currently underway, Chief of Staff and Senior Adviser to the President on National Security Sagala Ratnayake said. Ratnayake expressed confidence that once the proposed plan was implemented the time being spent to transport fuel to Sri Lanka from abroad can be reduced to a significant level. A discussion with regard to this matter was held between Ratnayake and a group of officials at the High Commission of India in Colombo at the Presidential Secretariat on 12 July to discuss the pros and cons of this proposed plan. Ratnayake said the focus of this programme is to bring fuel expeditiously and address ongoing fuel issues in Sri Lanka and it is noteworthy that Chief Secretary to the Indian High Commissioner Irina Thakur led the delegation. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Top Chinese investors on exploratory visit to Sri Lanka
author: Author not found
Content: A large group of Chinese entrepreneurs called on Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena at Temple Trees yesterday (13) to discuss possible investments in many spheres. The Prime Minister said there is vast potential for investments in many fields including tourism and hospitality industry, gem and jewellery, agriculture, medicine, food processing, renewable energy and entertainment industry. Chairman of Daguowen Culture Co., Ltd., Zhang Qihua said he is dealing with international cultural exchange, global sustainable development promotion and Sri Lanka has potential to attract more than million tourists from China. He said he would work closely with Chandra Wickremasinghe, Chairman of Connaissance De Ceylon to jointly promote Chinese tourists to Sri Lanka. Jin Mei Yang – Chairwoman of Zhejiang Outstanding Women’s Chamber of Commerce expressed willingness to assist women empowerment programmes in Sri Lanka. Xie Yueyu – Chairwoman of Wuxin Group, a medical research group working on collaboration between human liver cells and gemstones for human health said she was interested in setting up a branch in Sri Lanka to assist cancer cure. The delegation included Zhang Xiaomei – General Manager of Lanzhou General Machine Manufacturing Co., Ltd. , Mr. Li Zhengguo, Chairman of Shandong Jujinlong Group (Hydrogen energy industrial park for new energy technology), Zhou Wenlong – Chairman of Shenzhen Zhongdian Core Technology Co., Ltd., Li Min – Executive Assistant at Shenzhen Zhongdian Core Technology Co., Ltd., Guo Tingting – Chairman of Anthony Walter Piano and Executive President of Wuxin Public Welfare Foundation (International artistic and cultural cooperation) and Xiao Ling – General Manager of Wuxin Group (Public emergency Chinese medicine assistance and collaboration with Chinese hospitals).

Neoliberalism is a global bourgeois reaction to the stagnant productivity of the global economy. This includes decreasing government intervention in the economy, privatising State-owned assets, and reducing welfare. As a result of neoliberal reforms, postcolonial economies (except Vietnam and China) were forced to undergo a condition known as premature deindustrialisation. In the case of Sri Lanka, neoliberal reforms were imposed on the country’s economy in 1977. Neoliberal reforms not only deindustrialised the economy but also exacerbated Sri Lanka’s colonial legacies. Neoliberal reforms inherited a chronic ‘balance of payment’ problem as a result of the economy’s lower relative productivity in comparison to the rest of the world. Rather than addressing the root cause of the crisis, governments after 1977 focused on debt absorption to address the ‘balance of payment’ problem. The national debt then ballooned to the point of default in 2022. Industrialisation, progressive segments of society should recognise, is the path to national liberation from its colonial capital relationship. Industrialisation not only improves our citizens’ quality of life but also prepares the country to defend its sovereignty. The majority of countries around the world defend their sovereignty by industrialising. As a result, the Communist Party proposes a policy path for Sri Lanka called Idirimagen Idiriyata, which provides an overview of the country’s sectors as well as a path forward.  Our policy approach to Sri Lanka is technically driven, pragmatic, and fundamentally based on our motherland’s best interests. Our 80-year legacy demonstrates that the Communist Party of Sri Lanka is one of the country’s few parties that has always fought for the country’s best interests. The policy proposal of the Sri Lankan Communist Party envisions a socially harmonious, technologically advanced, and environmentally sustainable path for our motherland. Times may change. But the spirit is eternal. The Communist Party of Sri Lanka’s, Education Dept

title: Sagala in discussion with officials of Indian High Commission
author: Author not found
Content: The survey to explore the possibilities of laying a pipeline to transport the petroleum products from India to Sri Lanka is currently underway, Chief of Staff and Senior Adviser to the President on National Security Sagala Ratnayake said. Ratnayake expressed confidence that once the proposed plan was implemented the time being spent to transport fuel to Sri Lanka from abroad can be reduced to a significant level. A discussion with regard to this matter was held between Ratnayake and a group of officials at the High Commission of India in Colombo at the Presidential Secretariat on 12 July to discuss the pros and cons of this proposed plan. Ratnayake said the focus of this programme is to bring fuel expeditiously and address ongoing fuel issues in Sri Lanka and it is noteworthy that Chief Secretary to the Indian High Commissioner Irina Thakur led the delegation. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Top Chinese investors on exploratory visit to Sri Lanka
author: Author not found
Content: A large group of Chinese entrepreneurs called on Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena at Temple Trees yesterday (13) to discuss possible investments in many spheres. The Prime Minister said there is vast potential for investments in many fields including tourism and hospitality industry, gem and jewellery, agriculture, medicine, food processing, renewable energy and entertainment industry. Chairman of Daguowen Culture Co., Ltd., Zhang Qihua said he is dealing with international cultural exchange, global sustainable development promotion and Sri Lanka has potential to attract more than million tourists from China. He said he would work closely with Chandra Wickremasinghe, Chairman of Connaissance De Ceylon to jointly promote Chinese tourists to Sri Lanka. Jin Mei Yang – Chairwoman of Zhejiang Outstanding Women’s Chamber of Commerce expressed willingness to assist women empowerment programmes in Sri Lanka. Xie Yueyu – Chairwoman of Wuxin Group, a medical research group working on collaboration between human liver cells and gemstones for human health said she was interested in setting up a branch in Sri Lanka to assist cancer cure. The delegation included Zhang Xiaomei – General Manager of Lanzhou General Machine Manufacturing Co., Ltd. , Mr. Li Zhengguo, Chairman of Shandong Jujinlong Group (Hydrogen energy industrial park for new energy technology), Zhou Wenlong – Chairman of Shenzhen Zhongdian Core Technology Co., Ltd., Li Min – Executive Assistant at Shenzhen Zhongdian Core Technology Co., Ltd., Guo Tingting – Chairman of Anthony Walter Piano and Executive President of Wuxin Public Welfare Foundation (International artistic and cultural cooperation) and Xiao Ling – General Manager of Wuxin Group (Public emergency Chinese medicine assistance and collaboration with Chinese hospitals).

title: Only 31,000 pay taxes to State – SOC
author: Author not found
Content: Although there are 500,000 personal income tax files, only 31,000 are paying taxes to the country, it was disclosed at the Sectoral Oversight Committee on National Economic and Physical Plans chaired by MP Mahindananda Aluthgamage that met recently in Parliament. Aluthgamage also pointed out that there are 105,000 registered limited companies in the country, but 82 per cent of the tax revenue is received from only 382 companies. Elaborating on the failure of the Inland Revenue Department to collect the tax revenue, the Committee also discussed about the collection of Rs 904 billion in arrears which is due to the Inland Revenue Department. Aluthgamage also emphasised that it is important to maintain the inflation, the reserves of the country and the Government’s income in an optimal condition by December by the time of the second review of the International Monetary Fund, given that the said factors must be considered when granting loans. Therefore, it was agreed that the Committee will hold regular discussions with Sri Lanka Customs, Excise Department and Inland Revenue Department to provide necessary facilities to increase State revenue. Aluthgamage said he would also provide his utmost support to fill the existing employee vacancies in the Inland Revenue Department. The Inland Revenue Commissioner General, speaking at the occasion, said he appreciated the support received from the Sectoral Oversight Committee on National Economic and Physical Plans to make the work of his department efficient. The Commissioner stated that the tax revenue target given by the Government for the year 2023 of Rs 1.6 trillion was expected to be earned by 40 per cent in the first 6 months and 60 per cent in the remaining 6 months, and the target for the first 6 months has already been met. In addition, he said work is underway to generate expected tax revenue in the remaining 6 months. The Committee also insisted on the need to establish a systematic mechanism to regulate the collection of tax revenue. Members as well as officials pointed out that because the data provided for the registration of companies in this country is not genuine, they face problems in tax collection. The Committee also discussed at length the need to set up a digital data system linking the Sri Lanka Customs Department, the Excise Department and the Inland Revenue Department as soon as possible, as well as the need to re-register the private tax file in the country. Members of the Committee Wimalaweera Dissanayake, Eran Wickramaratne, Sudath Manjula, Gunathilaka Rajapaksha, Dhammika Perera, Udayana Kirindigoda, Karunadasa Kodithuwakku, Madhura Withanage, and Mohomad Muzammil were present at the Committee meeting. By Gagani Weerakoon

title: IGP’s second service extension unlawful – Gammanpila
author: Author not found
Content: Leader of the Pivithuru Hela Urumaya Udaya Gammanpila says the country had been devoid of an IGP for 108 days since 26 March. He alleged that granting a second service extension to outgoing IGP C.D. Wickramaratne is unlawful and stressed that it could create a dangerous precedent as well. He was speaking at a media briefing held at the PHU Office yesterday (12). Speaking further, he said, “The media here reported that the outgoing IGP had been handed a service extension with the consent of both the President and the Minister of Public Security. However, that service extension is illegal on two fronts. As per Article 41 (1) of the Constitution, the President has no powers vested in his post to make appointments unless those that had been approved by the CC. This Provision in the Constitution states that it also is valid even for an Acting Officer who is appointed for a 14-day period. The President went ahead and ratified a three-month service extension to Wickramaratne on 28 March sans the consent of the CC. He only received the approval on 1 April. Hence, it is crystal clear as per Provisions of Article 41 (1) of the Constitution that the President has no powers to appoint an IGP ahead of the nominee being green lighted by the CC. Even now, the President has given a three-month extension to the retiring IGP sans the ratification of the CC. Therefore, as per the law, this service extension has to be described as unlawful and if challenged in Court it could be deemed as null and void.  That in other words further underscores the fact that this country is still without a legally binding IGP. As per the laws drafted under the Public Judicial Officers (Retirement) Ordinance though the retirement age had been fixed at 60 any officer could be granted a service extension if the requisite official is of the view that his or her services are required for that particular firm’s growth and profits.  However, it must not be forgotten that this service extension can only be given to one who is still in active service. But, Wickramaratne went into his retirement on 28 March and there are no Provisions in the law to grant service extensions to those who had retired. It is due to this reason that the President appointed Wickramaratne anew to his post on 28 March.  But, there are no provisions in the law to appoint those who had exceeded the retirement age. That is why we say that before the law the appointment given to the outgoing IGP is unlawful. Therefore, it could be argued that since 28 March this country has been without an IGP. The one who is functioning in his current post is illegal. Hence, the question has to be asked as to how Police Officers would be able to perform their duty while their head is operating unlawfully.”

title: Rs 206B allocated for ‘Aswesuma’– Semasinghe
author: Author not found
Content: While noting approximately 1.2 million (1,287,747) families presently receiving Samurdhi benefits have applied for ‘Aswesuma’ welfare benefits, State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe said the Government expects to spend Rs 206 billion annually on the ‘Aswesuma’ programme. He also said the Government spent Rs 144 billion on welfare benefits last year and as per the agreements with the IMF and World Bank, Sri Lanka had agreed to spend a minimum of Rs 187 billion annually on welfare benefits. It has taken about 20 years to put in place a systematic and transparent method to identify the underprivileged and those in need of welfare benefits, the State Minister added. “Out of the 982,770 appeals received thus far, 650,000 appeals have been received from individuals whose names are already in the published list,” he said. Meanwhile, the first payment will be made within this month for all beneficiaries selected and who have not received objections or appeals, the State Minister said. Commencing from 1 August, those who could not apply for ‘Aswesuma” this year or failed to submit appeals will have another chance to do so, he added. He expressed these views yesterday (12) during a media briefing themed ‘Collective Path to a Stable Country’ held at the Presidential Media Centre (PMC). State Minister Semasinghe further said, “The time period given to all applicants whose names were not included in the list of ‘Aswesuma’ beneficiaries to file appeals ended on 10 July. Accordingly, 982,770 appeals and 62,368 objections have been received thus far. Arrangements have been made to commence investigations pertaining to these appeals and objections received by the Divisional Secretaries under the supervision of District Secretaries. Out of the 982,770 appeals that have been received thus far, significantly 650,000 appeals have been received by the individuals whose names are already in the published list demanding to upgrade their names from the category they are already in, to a category with more benefits. Only after investigating these appeals will a final decision be made regarding which categories the benefits should be distributed under. They will either stay in the category they have been chosen for or have their category modified. In addition to this, only about 350,000 appeals have been received from those who have not been selected. A total of 1,287,747 families already receiving ‘Samurdhi’ benefits have applied for ‘Aswesuma’. Out of them, 70 per cent (887,653) family units have been identified to be eligible to receive ‘Aswesuma’. As per the directions of President Ranil Wickremesinghe, it has been decided to execute the current list of beneficiaries receiving differently-abled, elderly, and kidney support allowances without subjecting to any change until a new system is implemented within a time period of 3-6 months. We are working to make the first payment within this month for all candidates elected and who have not received objections or appeals. We believed we would get more than 800,000 appeals. Accordingly, the appeals we have received thus far are within our estimated amount. Accordingly, these appeals and objections will be promptly investigated and if the investigations reveal that he/ she/ family unit, is eligible to receive ‘Aswesuma’, their  ‘Aswesuma’ allowance due in July, will be added to the August allowance and paid to that family. ‘Aswesuma’ hopes not to cut off any benefits received by low-income groups or individuals receiving any form of welfare benefits but to enter all who are eligible into the welfare system without losing anyone.” By Sanjana Marzook

title: Legal delays need to be swiftly resolved – President
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s judicial system boasts a rich history of over 200 years, making it home to the oldest legal system in Asia, but the issue of delays in legal proceedings has become a significant problem, President Ranil Wickremesinghe said, while insisting on the need for swift resolutions to address this matter, as a nation cannot progress if there are delays in the administration of justice. “The challenges posed by legal delays are not limited to the public; even investors encounter various problems. While I won’t delve into this at length, we presented several solutions during the Bar Association meeting held in Nuwara Eliya. To tackle this issue, a comprehensive discussion has taken place among various stakeholders, including the Chief Justice, relevant Government Ministers, Judges representing the Chief Justice, President of the Court of Appeal, High Courts, and District Magistrate Courts, as well as Members of Parliament from the ruling party and the Opposition, representatives from the Attorney General’s Department, and the Bar Association,” the President said while declaring open the new Court Complex built in Ratnapura. This collaborative effort instils hope, recognising that this is a long-term problem that cannot be resolved by one group blaming another, he added. President Wickremesinghe also pointed out that the country’s current laws must undergo reform as some laws have remained unchanged for as long as the Courts themselves. “The Police Ordinance, for example, has remained unaltered for 175 years. Our Justice Minister is particularly focused on addressing this issue. In the past, new laws were enacted every six months, but now we are witnessing frequent introductions of new legislation,” he noted. The President also said it is anticipated that, by the end of this year, Parliament will need to convene for three weeks instead of the usual two to pass these laws. Meanwhile, speaking at the event, Justice Minister Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe said the Ministry of Justice has already presented over 30 new bills to combat corruption within the country. This serves as a reminder that we remain committed to establishing a future where adherence to the law is paramount, he added.

title: No Cabinet Minister is above the law – CEJ
author: Author not found
Content: While condemning the arbitrary statement by Minister Bandula Gunawardana who insisted he was fully aware of the ‘removal’ of the contentious Crudia zeylanica tree (Pandu Karanda) and that the act was carried out following Cabinet approval, the Centre for Environmental Justice (CEJ) emphasised that no Minister is above the law of the land. “Cabinet Minister Bandula Gunawardana, in a special statement released to the media, has mentioned that the contentious ‘Crudia zeylanica’ tree was uprooted following a special Cabinet decision. As per Section 42 of the Fauna and Flora Protection Ordinance No. 2 of 1937 as amended by Act, No. 22 of 2009, no person shall in any area remove, uproot or destroy or cause any damage or injury to any plant which is for the time being included in Schedule V and is growing on the property of any other person or is growing in any public place,” CEJ noted. “Therefore, the entire Cabinet who supported and approved his (Gunawardana’s) proposal has committed a legal offence which can be subjected to an imprisonment of 2 to 5 years and a fine of Rs 10,000 to Rs 20,000,” CEJ Chairman, Dr. Ravindranath Dabare pointed out. CEJ also highlighted that at a time when a social conversation is going on about the danger of people taking the law into their own hands, it is sad to see Cabinet Ministers engaging in ultra vires activities in violating people’s environmental human rights. Regardless of the nature or orientation of social discourses regarding the plant Crudia zeylanica, illegal interventions pose a formidable threat to the preservation of the rule of law. The CEJ strongly condemns this act and emphasises that no minister or Cabinet has the authority to override the law, he added. (GW)

title: PAFFREL challenges Ketagoda’s Private Member’s Bill
author: Author not found
Content: The People’s Action for Free and Fair Elections (PAFFREL) filed a petition before the Supreme Court yesterday (12), challenging the Private Member’s Bill presented to Parliament by SLPP MP Jayantha Ketagoda seeking to amend the Municipal Councils Ordinance. The petition was put forward by PAFFREL Executive Director Rohana Hettiarachchi, seeking a Court Order declaring that certain provisions in the said Private Member’s Bill are unconstitutional. The petitioner says the MP, through his Bill, seeks to amend the Provincial Councils Ordinance to empower the Minister of Public Administration, Home Affairs, Provincial Councils and Local Government to re-convene the dissolved local government bodies without holding elections. Further, the petitioner took issue with MP Ketagoda’s bid to empower the subject minister to extend the tenure of the re-convened local government (LG) bodies. Hettiarachchi pointed out that pursuant to legal provisions, the local government elections should be held every four years, however, authorising the subject minister to extend the tenure of LG bodies violates the people’s right to vote.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Navy brings ashore fisherman with burn injuries
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Navy provided crucial assistance in bringing ashore a fisherman who sustained burn injuries following a collision at sea, in a daring operation on 13 June. The incident occurred approximately 431 nautical miles off the southwestern coast of Galle. The ill-fated multiday fishing trawler, named ‘Sachintha Putha’, bearing registration number IMUL-A-0460 CHW, embarked on its fishing voyage from Negombo Harbour on 22 June, carrying a crew of five. However, fate took an unexpected turn when the trawler collided with a foreign vessel on the high seas southwest of Sri Lanka. The reports suggest that the collision resulted in a harrowing attack by the foreign vessel, leading to severe burn injuries for one of the fishermen aboard the local trawler. The exact circumstances surrounding the incident are presently under investigation. Promptly alerted to the situation, the Department of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources swiftly contacted the Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre (MRCC) located at the Navy Headquarters in Colombo. Recognising the gravity of the situation, the Sri Lanka Navy mobilised its resources to rescue the injured fisherman from the distressed multiday fishing trawler. Undeterred by the vast distance, the Sri Lanka Navy’s skilled personnel braved the challenging conditions to reach the vessel located approximately 431 nautical miles from the coast. Their professionalism and dedication ensured the safe evacuation of the injured fisherman, who required urgent medical attention. Following the successful rescue operation, the Sri Lanka Navy facilitated the fisherman’s immediate transfer to a suitable medical facility on land. Medical professionals are now providing the necessary care and treatment to aid his recovery. As the investigation unfolds, authorities are working diligently to ascertain the details surrounding the collision and the motives behind the foreign vessel’s attack. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: Stripping, assaulting women despicable – Geetha
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Women and Child Affairs Geetha Kumarasinghe assured that prompt legal action will be taken against those who stripped and videoed two women after they were found with a monk. Speaking to the media yesterday (12), Kumarasinghe condemned the assault of the two women. “The disciplinary issues of the monk can be dealt with separately. But, how the women were stripped naked and assaulted was despicable. No person has the right to do that,” she said.  Kumarasinghe noted that she is disgusted by the way the 22-year-old woman and the other woman were treated.  “What are these predators expecting by assaulting them? Maybe, these women do this for a living, according to her work she is not supposed to probe whether the person she is accompanying is a Bhikkhu or a priest as they do it to survive,” she added. Kumarasinghe noted that society doesn’t feed women or provide them with shelter, and therefore, nobody has the right to strip and assault them.  By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: President committed to addressing reconciliation – Ekanayake
author: Author not found
Content: Presidential Secretary Saman Ekanayake emphasised that President Ranil Wickremesinghe is committed to addressing the task of reconciliation in Sri Lanka, rather than passing it on to future generations. Ekanayake pointed out that there is an urgent need to resolve the issues related to the reconciliation process, and that if this effort is successful, there will be no need for the country to go to the UN Human Rights Council in Geneva for another year. He said this at a civil society awareness discussion on the Truth and Reconciliation Mechanism held on Tuesday (11) at the Presidential Secretariat under the chairmanship of Foreign Minister Ali Sabry. The Foreign Minister explained the objectives of the Truth and Reconciliation Mechanism, and the role of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission was discussed at length. Ekanayake, who sought the views and suggestions of the members of the civil society organisations who were present on the achievement of the objectives of the commission’s establishment, also stated that he expects everyone’s support to make the reconciliation process a success. He emphasised that the agreement and support of all citizens is needed to move forward as a country. (SRM)

title: GMOA proposes unique salary structure for doctors
author: Author not found
Content: With over 700 medical practitioners leaving the State health service to migrate to foreign countries last year, doctors have proposed solutions to the issue especially by calling for a provision of a unique salary structure for medical practitioners based on their performance and market value. Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA) Media Spokesman, Dr. Chamil Wijesinghe yesterday (12) said with the dilemma regarding the National Wage Policy which had been violated one too many times, his outfit had seen this as the best possible solution to put a plug on Sri Lankan medical practitioners leaving the island in search of greener pastures. He noted that the Rs 30 or Rs 50 that a medical practitioner in the Outpatient Department (OPD) receives for seeing a patient was very much less than what an OPD doctor was paid in a private sector hospital. He lamented that State health service authorities had grossly failed to provide a proper value for the employment of all categories of doctors including interns considering their market value. The situation could be amended by introducing a special salary structure for doctors based on performance and market value while revising the pay packet of interns accordingly. GMOA Secretary, Dr. Haritha Aluthge noted that his union had continued to emphasise the importance of proper management of human resources in the field to manage the State health system in the best way possible. The provision of quality healthcare islandwide had largely contributed towards the recognition of the island’s free health service even internationally. Dr. Aluthge said implementing the eight-step solution proposed by his outfit would prevent the impending collapse that was going to happen in the health system in the near future. The eight-pronged solution to the looming crisis in the State health service includes the announcement of a work plan to increase the residential facilities of doctors within a given time frame, mainly targeting the difficult peripheral hospitals. He noted that the union had identified the non-payment of proper attention to increase the transportation facilities of the doctors who are dedicated to all island service to be a bone of contention for medical practitioners. To resolve this issue prompt measures should be taken to revise the Disturbance Availability and Transport (DAT) allowance in accordance with the present-day criteria and update the related allowance once in three years. Also, including ‘medical officers’ in Circular 22/99 of the Ministry of Public Administration for the provision of official transport facilities provided to senior-grade public services. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: PAFFREL challenges Ketagoda’s Private Member’s Bill
author: Author not found

Further, the petitioner took issue with MP Ketagoda’s bid to empower the subject minister to extend the tenure of the re-convened local government (LG) bodies. title: Special majority needed to reconvene LG bodies – AG
author: Author not found
Content: Chief Opposition Whip Lakshman Kiriella yesterday (12) urged the Government to state whether it is planning to hold a referendum or not as the Attorney General has informed that the controversial Private Members Bill to re-convene local government bodies requires a special majority or a referendum. The AG, in a letter addressed to the Secretary-General of Parliament, had informed he is of the opinion that clause 2 of the legislation is inconsistent with Articles 3, 4, 12(1) and 14(1) of the Constitution and that it has to be enacted with a special majority and through a referendum. “Further, a dissolved local authority may be re-convened for an indefinite period of time without any nexus to the crisis referred to in the proposed provision. Therefore, the proposed amendment would have the effect of extending the terms of local authorities and delaying elections, and members of local authorities who have exceeded their term limit as elected representatives of the people could continue in office for an indefinite period of time without a democratically obtained mandate. Hence, the franchise of people, as well as their fundamental rights to vote and stand for elections would be affected. In this context, your attention is drawn to the special determination of the Supreme Court in SC (SD) Nos 20-32/2017 to the 20th Amendment to the Constitution Bill,” the AG said in his letter. The amendments to the Pradeshiya Sabha Ordinance, Municipal Council Ordinance and Urban Council Ordinance to reinstate local government members and re-convene dissolved bodies were presented to Parliament about a fortnight ago. (GW)

title: Japan hands over DTTB tech report to SL
author: Author not found
Content: Japanese Ambassador Mizukoshi Hideaki handed over the technical standards prepared by Japan on the Digital Terrestrial Television Broadcasting (DTTB) Project in Sri Lanka to Minister of Mass Media Bandula Gunawardana yesterday (12). Japan has been continuously supporting the DTTB Project in Sri Lanka since 2014 with Japanese Official Development Assistance (ODA) financing. The launch of the DTTB Project in Sri Lanka was held in 2021.  Japan said, the DTTB Project will offer two major benefits to Sri Lanka providing High-Definition television broadcasts free of charge that will strengthen the telecommunications infrastructure that serves as the foundation for the digitalisation of social and economic activities through the effective use of the radio waves. Ambassador Hideaki stressed how significant this project is in terms of implementing the ‘Digital Economy’ that the Government of Sri Lanka has been focusing on as one of its top priorities, as well as exploring bilateral cooperation in this field. It is sincerely hoped that this milestone project will be successfully completed soon to help achieve the sustainable development of Sri Lanka as well as to further develop bilateral relations between Japan and Sri Lanka, the Japanese Ambassador said. Japan announced it would support DTTB several years ago and finally a technical report has been prepared to boost the project. In Analog TV broadcasting, Japan supported the setting up of the Sri Lanka Rupavahini Corporation (SLRC) which started its TV broadcasting in 1982, and since then, Japan has been continuously providing technical cooperation to SLRC. Japan said, now it is time for Sri Lanka to move to the digitalisation of TV broadcasting through the DTTB Project. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: COPE highlights irregularities in coconut industry
author: Author not found
Content: The Committee on Public Enterprises (COPE) which met recently disclosed many administrative concerns and irregularities in the Coconut Development Authority, Coconut Cultivation Board and Coconut Research Institute. The Committee expressed strong displeasure that the online system introduced to stop the monopoly mafia in coconut auctions and to create transparency remains inactive. COPE also gave instructions to discuss with all three institutions and prepare a common programme for the control of diseases that can affect coconut cultivation. The last application of fertiliser to the crops in the lands belonging to the Coconut Cultivation Board was in 2016, COPE revealed and was also concerned that 78 per cent of the coconut oil consumption in the country is met by imported oil. The three main institutions related to coconut cultivation and industry of the country which are the Coconut Development Authority, Coconut Cultivation Board and Coconut Research Institute were called before COPE at the meeting held recently chaired by Prof. Ranjith Bandara. The progress of the implementation of the recommendations given to the said institutions during the COPE meeting held on 21 January 2021 was also reviewed. Developing a common programme Considering it as an emergency, a special committee was appointed to control the whitefly disease affecting the coconut plantation and the need to prepare a common programme was discussed with the three institutions to control the diseases that could affect the coconut plantation. As the Coconut Development Authority has not been involved in the ‘National Disaster Management Operational Unit’ which has been established so far, the need to involve the institution was also emphasised for this operation. Officials stated that there is a risk of diseases like this due to the non-application of fertiliser at the right time for coconut cultivation. It was also revealed that the last application of fertiliser to the crops in the lands belonging to the Coconut Cultivation Board was in 2016. The displeasure of the Committee was expressed regarding the non-application of fertiliser to government-owned coconut plantations The Secretary to the Ministry of Plantation Industries was recommended to inform within two weeks action to be taken by involving all three institutions. Accordingly, the COPE Chair said, he will inform Parliament, the Treasury and the President’s Secretary about the provision of necessary resources in this regard. Instructions to re-implement online system Although computer software has been prepared for online bidding for the coconut auction, attention was drawn to the fact that it is presently inactive. It was revealed that this system will enable the auction to be conducted more transparently and this system was introduced to prevent the monopoly of a few people in the coconut auction in Sri Lanka.
