title: SLLDC to renovate canals, anicuts, bridges
author: Author not found
Content: Following advice received from Minister of Urban Development and Housing Prasanna Ranatunga, the Sri Lanka Land Development Corporation (SLLDC) has launched a project aimed at renovating all canals, rivers, anicuts and bridges in the Colombo District with the concerted intention of controlling floods in the metropolis and its suburbs. As part of this planned project among the canals and rivers due to be renovated are Thalawathugoda River, Diyawanna Oya, Nagahamulla River, Kimbulawala River and the river situated at Palamthuna Bridge in Pelawatta. Sources from the Ministry of Urban Development and Housing stated that most of the aforementioned rivers and canals had been replete with polluted items and the stench emanating from it had become unbearable for residents. They said to prevent floods in the future, the Ministry, based on instructions from the subject Minister, had decided to renovate the canals, rivers and bridges in the coming months. Ministry sources added that following a survey conducted jointly by the Department of Irrigation and the Sri Lanka Land Reclamation and Development Corporation it had come to light that improper drainage systems in place could pave the way for future floods in Colombo and its suburbs. Hence, the Minister stressed the importance of renovating the existing canals, rivers and bridges in Colombo to avert major flooding as well as beautify the metropolis for both local and foreign tourists.

title: Sangili Kanadarawa Maha Vidyalaya closed indefinitely
author: Author not found
Content: Due to the failure of wildlife officials to provide a lasting solution to wasp attacks on students studying at the Sangili Kanadarawa Maha Vidyalaya, Rambewa in Medawachchiya for months, the school faces an indefinite closure once more. The school had been closed on 4 July due to the presence of five large wasp nests on the third storey of the building as well as atop a tamarind tree situated in the school compound. The school authorities stated that they had decided to close the school indefinitely due to fear of wasp attacks on students following strong gale force winds and wasps being targeted by hawks and pigeons. Though the principal D.M.K.K. Dissanayake had made a written request to officials from the Wildlife Department to take prompt action to remove the wasp nests from the school premises, the appeal had fallen on deaf ears, forcing her to close the school till further notice. By Thisara Samal

title: NARA researching drop in fish breeding – Devananda
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda said the National Aquatic Resources Research and Development Agency (NARA) is conducting research to identify the cause for the decrease in fish breeding in the territorial waters of Sri Lanka. Minister Devananda said this when a delegation from the JVP chaired by former Hambantota District MP Nihal Galappaththi and Chief Secretary of Fisheries Federation led by JVP Ratna Gamage met him at the Fisheries Ministry on 10 July. During the meeting, the delegation led by Galappaththi explained to Minister Devananda about 18 factors that have impacted the fisheries industry while stressing the need to resolve these issues as soon as possible while bringing to the attention of Devananda that they are aware of the economic crisis and the dollar shortage in the country. They also emphasised Minister Devananda of the need to control the increasing fish price and to maintain price stability, so that it remains affordable to ordinary citizens. In response to their plea, Minister Devananda said NARA has been engaging in research activities in this connection and agreed that fish breeding has dropped significantly. Devananda said research is also being conducted to ban the use of buoys in fish breeding sites, adding that he has sought funds from Cabinet to implement this project, but he wasn’t able to obtain funds due to the prevailing economic crisis. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Nepal first South Asian nation to allow same-sex marriage
author: Author not found
Content: Nepal’s Top Court has ordered the legal registration of same-sex marriages, a first step towards marriage equality for LGBTQ+ people in conservative South Asia. Supreme Court Judge Til Prasad Shrestha ruled marriages of same-sex and non-traditional couples must be registered as “temporary” until lawmakers come up with a new legal framework to uphold such unions permanently. In an interim ruling on 28 June, the Judge ordered Nepal’s Government to set up a separate register of marriages for same-sex couples, whose lawyers say will have the same rights as heterosexual partners. The Court also asked opponents of its landmark order to file their objections within two weeks. The ruling makes Nepal the first country to recognise same-sex marriages in South Asia, where Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka and the Maldives have all opposed same-sex civil unions. In the rest of Asia, only Taiwan has legalised same-sex marriage. The ruling followed a petition submitted by LGBTQ+ activists last month to enforce existing rulings, dating back to 2007, that instructed the Government to amend Nepalese legislation to recognise same-sex marriage for the sake of equal rights. Successive governments have so far failed to change the law. One of the petitioners, Pinky Gurung, a trans woman who heads Nepal’s Blue Diamond Society Gay Rights Group, called the latest verdict historic. “I think it shows that there are people accepting us gradually,” she said. A 2011 census estimated that 1,500 people identified as lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, intersex or other diverse sexual or gender identities in Nepal, but activists have claimed the queer community actually consists of 2.5 million Nepalese in the country of 30 million. Maya Gurung, a trans woman who married her partner Surendra Pandey six years ago in a Hindu ceremony that was not officially certified by authorities, said the legal battle wasn’t over. “Now we can finally feel our marriage will be legally secure,” the activist said, adding that she would now seek privileges granted to all married couples. Western diplomats also hailed the ruling, which came during the global Pride month that celebrates LGBTQ+ people and their battle to overcome prejudice. “As we conclude Pride month, we are reminded that the freedom to marry means very little without the freedom to marry the person you love,” said US Ambassador Dean Thompson. “Nepal continues to demonstrate regional leadership in promoting the rights of LBGTIQA+ communities,” said Australian Ambassador Felicity Volk in a separate tweet. But the verdict also angered conservative Nepalese politicians. “Same-sex marriage is against natural law, social norms and culture,” tweeted Kamal Thapa, a former Deputy Prime Minister and an influential politician in overwhelmingly Hindu Nepal. “If same-sex marriage is legalised it will lead to family confusion and social distortion,” he claimed. Sujan Panta, a lawyer who advocates for LGBTQ+ rights, warned that many people “in positions of power” held similar beliefs. “A majority of them still find same-sex marriage to be unnatural, but with this Court order, Nepal took its first step toward legalising same-sex marriage,” he said. In May, the Supreme Court ruled in favour of a same-sex couple who married legally in Germany but struggled to get their union recognised in Nepal. Judges called it a constitutional breach and ordered the Government to act. Nepal has tried to stamp out social discrimination ever since a decade-long Maoist rebellion ended in 2006 and the 239-year-old Hindu monarchy was dismantled two years later. Citizens who identify neither as male nor female are permitted to use a third gender on their passports and other official documents, in line with guidelines against discrimination spelled out in Nepal’s new Constitution approved in 2015. More and more public parades and unofficial weddings are being held in Nepal, though LGBTQ+ people report that discrimination and harassment, including violence, remain commonplace. (RFI)

title: 16 killed, 98 injured within 24 hours
author: Author not found
Content: Nearly 16 lives were lost and 98 injured within 24 hours due to fatal accidents, Police Spokesman SSP Nihal Thalduwa said while adding that it is indeed a tragic loss of life when road accidents result in deaths. He stressed the importance of responsible driving and insisted that it is the driver’s responsibility to ensure safety on the roads. “This responsibility becomes even more crucial for drivers in the public transport sector, as they are entrusted with the lives of many passengers,” he added. SSP Thalduwa said reckless driving should never be excused, as it poses a significant risk to the driver, passengers, and other road users. “By disregarding traffic rules and driving without due care, reckless drivers not only jeopardize their own lives but also put innocent lives at stake. These preventable accidents can lead to premature deaths, causing immense grief and loss for the victims’ families and loved ones. It is essential to appreciate and acknowledge the responsible drivers who prioritize the safety of themselves and others. These individuals play a vital role in fostering a culture of safe driving and reducing accidents. Their efforts contribute to creating a safer environment on the roads, and they deserve recognition for their responsible behaviour. To avoid premature deaths on roads, it is crucial for all drivers to prioritize safety, adhere to traffic regulations, and remain vigilant while driving. By doing so, we can work towards minimizing accidents, saving lives, and creating a safer transportation system for everyone,” he added. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: Need for joint contributions to thwart manufacture of artificial drugs
author: Author not found
Content: An International Summit on Proliferation of Artificial Drugs was held on 7 July via Zoom technology by the US State Department helmed by Secretary of State Antony Blinken. It was attended by subject Ministers and State officials from several countries such as the US, UK, Israel, Germany, Italy, Argentina, Belgium, Canada, Australia, South Africa and Korea while Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles had represented Sri Lanka. The aim of the International Summit was to stress the need for all countries to make joint contributions to thwart the manufacture and distribution of artificial drugs. The Summit also emphasised that globally, countries could be categorised as those that have the ability to produce artificial drugs and those that don’t. It observed that countries which have the ability to manufacture artificial drugs should be dissuaded at all costs from continuing with such measures and prevent such activities from taking place in countries which do not have the scope to produce. Exchanging views between countries and sharing technological knowhow to combat the spread of illegal drugs globally was also discussed while Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles assured of Sri Lanka’s fullest support to undertake such tasks.

title: CMLSSL threatens trade union action
author: Author not found
Content: The College of Medical Laboratory Science Sri Lanka (CMLSSL) warned they would resort to trade union measures on Thursday (13) if immediate action was not taken to resolve their issues, in particular the alleged antagonism and arbitrary actions of the consultant microbiologist of the National Hospital. President of the CMLSSL, Ravi Kumudesh, in a letter to the Health Secretary warned that they would be compelled to resort to a ‘walk out’ on Thursday (13) and more stringent trade union action on 19 July 2023 if the Ministry did not put a halt to the antagonistic actions of the Consultant microbiologist who was allegedly sending petitions with false accusations against the Medical Laboratory Scientists. He warned, “Action should be taken to undo some of the unjust actions taken by her such as acting outside the circulars with regard to their overtime payments while cutting down on the allowances of Medical laboratory scientists without informing them.”  He demanded a halt to the tampering and obstructing of the official duties of the Superintendent Medical Laboratory Scientist Officers. Kumudesh accused the said Consultant Microbiologist of forcibly holding on the authority that was traditionally given on exchange to the Pathology Specialist who was then referred to as the Department Head. This was an annual process, he explained noting however that the particular Microbiology consultant had been clinging on to the post for the past six years. The CMLSSL President Accused the particular Consultant of handing over the ‘General Inventory’ of the laboratory to other external parties while alleging that she even labelled the staff of the laboratory as corrupt crooks  and thereby maintained arbitrary control by misleading the higher administration. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Fisheries Minister to update TN on fishers poaching in SL waters
author: Author not found
Content: At the outset of President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s visit to India scheduled for 21 July, during which Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda is also expected to accompany him, the Fisheries Minister on Sunday (9) stated that Tamil Nadu fishermen and not the Sri Lankan Navy who were responsible for violations in the Sri Lankan sea area for illegal poaching and urged Tamil politicians from the North and East to step forward and clarify the situation to Tamil Nadu leaders and people regarding the harm caused by Indian fishermen’s encroachment in Sri Lankan waters. The Minister urged fellow members of Parliament from the North and East to fulfil their moral duty and clarify the situation to resolve the issues faced by fishermen. He also called upon the Indian government to promptly take constructive measures to control the violations committed by Tamil Nadu fishermen. The conflict between Indian fishermen and Sri Lankan fishermen, particularly in the Northern Province, has led to escalating tensions. Despite several rounds of talks, no resolution has been achieved. This issue will be discussed during President Wickremesinghe’s visit to New Delhi. On Sunday (9) the Navy arrested 15 Tamil Nadu fishermen and confiscated two fishing trawlers as they illegally entered Sri Lankan waters for fishing activities. Minister Devananda, after paying attention to the news published in Tamil Nadu media regarding this incident, refuted the claims that the Sri Lankan Navy was involved in violations. He stated that Indian fishermen crossing the border were being apprehended due to the insistence of Sri Lankan Tamil fishermen. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Indian Foreign Secy Vinay Kwatra in Colombo
author: Author not found
Content: Indian Foreign Secretary Vinay Kwatra arrived yesterday (10) on a brief work visit to discuss arrangements for President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s 21 July visit to New Delhi, where he is expected to meet Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi. Foreign Secretary Kwatra’s recent visit was on June 23, 2022, during Sri Lanka’s crisis situation. The President will travel to India on July 21 with several cabinet ministers, according to the Hindu and discuss the political and economic situation in the country.  (SRM)

title: Aswesuma appeals being processed– WBB Chairman
author: Author not found
Content: The Welfare Benefits Board (WBB) said, by yesterday, nearly 957,000 appeals and 37,000 objections had been received by it, related to shortcomings in the ‘Aswesuma’ Welfare Benefit Scheme. WBB Chairman B. Wijeyaratne said appeals and objections had been received from 20 June to 10 July. He added that they were submitted to the Appeals Boards at Divisional Secretariats and that following the data being processed by the relevant District Secretary, suitable families will be selected to receive the welfare benefits. By Amith Gamage

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Aswesuma appeals being processed– WBB Chairman
author: Author not found
Content: The Welfare Benefits Board (WBB) said, by yesterday, nearly 957,000 appeals and 37,000 objections had been received by it, related to shortcomings in the ‘Aswesuma’ Welfare Benefit Scheme. WBB Chairman B. Wijeyaratne said appeals and objections had been received from 20 June to 10 July. He added that they were submitted to the Appeals Boards at Divisional Secretariats and that following the data being processed by the relevant District Secretary, suitable families will be selected to receive the welfare benefits. By Amith Gamage

title: Opposition pulls out of PSC to probe bankruptcy
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa announced that the Samagi Janabala Sandanaya and all Opposition Parties affiliated with it have decided to withdraw from the Select Committee to Investigate Causes for Financial Bankruptcy. Premadasa while speaking to the Opposition Executive Committee, yesterday (10) said the Opposition will create a new Independent Select Committee. “The purpose of the Parliament Select Committee which is to find the reasons for the bankruptcy of the country and work together to recover the country, hasn’t been served, therefore there is no point in continuing to be in it. The appointment of Podujana Peramuna Secretary General, Sagala Kariyawasam as Chairman of the PSC will convert the committee into a talk shop and the Basil Rajapaksa-led group will be saved through this,” alleged Premadasa. Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena announced that a Select Committee of Parliament to Investigate Causes for Financial Bankruptcy was appointed to investigate the causes of the financial bankruptcy declared by the Government on 6 July in Parliament. Accordingly, the Speaker appointed MPs under the Chair of Sagala Kariyawasam, to serve on the Select Committee and to report to Parliament and submit its proposals and recommendations in this regard. BY Nabiya Vaffoor

title: State should promptly stem flow of doctors overseas – Consultant
author: Author not found
Content: While highlighting that the State spends over Rs 18 million on training a specialist doctor, Consultant Dr. Chrishantha Abeysena stressed the onus is on the Government to implement a system to prevent scores of specialist doctors from leaving the country for greener pastures. He said the State spends in excess of Rs 6 million to train a qualified doctor. Dr. Abeysena warned that if the Government fails to put in a prompt mechanism to prevent doctors from seeking better prospects abroad, the number of patients dying for want of specialists in this country could spike in the not too distant future. By Anurada Herath

title: 2023 A/L exam in December
author: Author not found
Content: The GCE Advanced Level examination 2023 will be held in December, Education Minister Dr. Susil Premajayantha announced yesterday while adding that the suspended Suraksha insurance scheme will also be resumed in 2024. The Minister said the education system will undergo a transformation and essential measures will be taken to produce students ready for the twenty-first century. According to the Education Minister, human resources will be managed to meet the need and education will be reformatted in keeping with international standards maintaining high-quality education. Minister Premajayantha was speaking at a yesterday (10) at a press conference titled ‘Collective Path to a Stable Country’ held at the Presidential Media Centre. The Minister said the ‘Suraksha Sisu Rakshanaya’ insurance scheme introduced for school children which was suspended due to the financial crisis will resume in 2024. Education Minister further said, “In developed countries, the Ministry of was a separate entity from the Central Government and a Provincial Minister is in charge of the Ministry of Education. The educational rights of children in countries such as India, Canada and Japan have been safeguarded as a result of this educational pattern”. “The Ministry of Education is under the Central Government. All schools in our country, with the exception of 399, are governed by the Provincial Ministries of education. The initiative to establish 1,000 national schools was launched in 2001. When the 13th Constitutional Amendment was initiated there were 17 national schools in this country. However, as a result of political initiatives or the requests of individual Education Ministers, there was a dramatic rise in the number of national schools. However, one cannot say that it led to high-quality education. There was a time when 28 national schools were created overnight.  But right now, the education sector has to be transformed. Instead of the exam-centred education system, students should be aligned in a student-centred education pattern”, he further said and added “There was a significant setback in education as a result of Covid-19 and the recent economic downturn. Additionally, socio economic issues made it impossible to run the schools effectively due to fuel and gas concerns. Federation of University Teachers’ Associations (FUTA) and Teacher trade unions did not attend to evaluate the answer sheet of the Advanced Level examination. The evaluation of the A-Level exam questions has been completed, and that matter is now resolved. I think the exam results could be released in the middle of the next month. The A-Level exams for this year are scheduled to take place in December, according to the Ministry of Education. The Ministry of Education has taken steps to hold all the examinations in the prescribed year”. “The programme to reform education is currently being implemented. Plans are afoot to commence  teaching activities in the English medium in association with the British Council. For this purpose, 13,800 teachers have been trained so far. The updating of textbooks for the  English medium has also commenced. “The addition of Artificial Intelligence and Information Technology to the curriculum is proposed for  Grade 6-9 and Grade 10-13. We are attempting to secure Information Technology assistance for this from companies like Microsoft. About fifty principal vacancies exist. While conducting a competitive examination for the recruitment, a trade union went to Court and got an injunction. For the recruitment of teacher administration services, there are roughly 22,000 openings. Government employees who applied for the position have also gone to Court to explain why they are unable to take the competitive exam. The recruitment process has thus far been delayed as a result. Due to 100 people’s human rights being brought up in Court, 4.2 million students’ human rights have already been violated. As a result, we think Courts will make a ruling on this issue quickly. We are working to continue the ‘13 plus’ education programme presented by the President when he was Prime Minister. A select committee has been set up to expand the education sector and the necessary proposals are currently being prepared. Accordingly, the programme to expand education will be prepared jointly with Non-Governmental Organisations in the future. Arrangements are being made to provide loan facilities to Non-Government Universities as well as to create an environment where they can contribute to the economy. It is intended to establish a training University in Kotagala to train students who choose to go to a plantation in order to safeguard the educational rights of children of estate workers. By substantially bolstering the regulating programme of private and international schools, we are committed to ensuring children’s right to education. With regard to all of these issues, we are working to bring about a change in education from next year,” he further said.

title: LIOC contributes Rs 200M to President’s Fund
author: Author not found
Content: Lanka IOC PLC (LIOC), being a responsible corporate citizen, has been making regular donations mainly focusing on education, healthcare, environment and community development under CSR activities of the Company. LIOC has been regularly discharging its corporate social responsibility to the Community by making contributions and donations for the needy through various CSR Projects. LIOC has donated medicine and medical equipment to hospitals, distribution of dry rations to the needy and weaker sections of society, donating sanitary equipment and other material to Schools in addition to providing necessary material for e-learning in schools. During a recent visit of Chairman, LIOC Sujoy Choudhury from India to Sri Lanka, the management of LIOC made a contribution of Rs 200 million to the President’s Fund which was handed over to President Ranil Wickremesinghe in the presence of Dipak Das, Managing Director LIOC. The proceeds will be used for Medical Assistance, Education and Scholarship programmes, welfare activities, religious activities, sports and the Arts and cultural activities.

title: Jaffna resident sets new record for pulling truck with beard
author: Author not found
Content: A 59-year-old resident of Thenmarachchi, Jaffna, S. Thiruchelvam, set a world record by pulling a vehicle weighing 1,550 kg over a distance of 400 metres with his beard in 7 minutes and 48 seconds. The event was organised by the Cholan World Record Book Company, and entrepreneur A. Krupakaran was the Chief Guest. Social worker Kalanithi Akilan Muthukumarasamy and Rajeepan from City Cherry English College were present as special guests. MGR fan club President M. Vijayakanth and former Pradeshiya Sabha member D. Thangavelu were also among the attendees. Cholan World Record Book Company Sri Lanka Branch President Jude Nimalan also attended the event. By T. Pratheepan – Jaffna

title: Nursing university mulled
author: Author not found
Content: While 3,315 nursing students were to be given appointment letters for training in nursing schools, Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella said an agreement had been reached to commence a nursing university in Sri Lanka. A senior Spokesman for the Health Minister quoting Minister Rambukwella yesterday (10) said the Minister had indicated that an agreement had been reached regarding the submission of a Cabinet Paper in this regard. Minister Rabukwella explained that the agreement had been reached to start a nursing university about a month ago by submitting a Cabinet Paper. He noted that it was important to do a diploma and get a degree. “As the Minister of Foreign Employment, I looked into possibilities of initiating a programme to send nurses to countries like Canada and America,” he said noting that the basic request those countries had been for a nursing degree. In a bid to boost the human resources of the state health service in the island, the Health Ministry award appointment letters for training of 3315 nursing students of the 2020 student nurses batch. The Spokesman said the period of 2018/2019 was a period of political and economic pressure in this country with the Covid epidemic and a complex situation where certain decisions could not be made. Quoting the Health Minister who was addressing the gathering at a ceremony held yesterday (10) said that “ the 2018/2019 recruitment program for nursing students started the 2018/2019 A-Level results, 3315 out of 5657 have been selected for nursing training. The recruitment of the two batches commenced despite the economic pressure and the political issues of the time. “The students themselves were facing a dilemma and their parents called me and informed of the problem of facing these children,” he explained. The spokesman said that the Ministry had been able to probe these issues and find solutions.  First, was by resolving the problem related to the’ Z score’ within a very short period of two weeks. The examination department was able to solve the problem. “These children did not demonstrate or carryout protest marches but put pressure on us with intelligence. Otherwise we would not have felt the force and the need to act should they have taken to the streets,” he observed. The Minister of Health also pointed out that plans were being made to recruit 2497 students who had completed three years of training as nurses. According to the 2018/2019 high school results, 3315 students qualified for nursing training this year, and a group of nursing students from Colombo district were officially appointed for training at the Health Ministry. Simultaneously with these appointments, the Health Ministry had made arrangements to provide appointments for nursing students in 15 nursing schools across the island. Accordingly  nursing schools in Ampara received 200, Anuradhapura 162, Badulla 227, Batticaloa 165, Colombo 225, Galle 321, Hambantota 200, Jaffna 96, Kalutara 219, Kandana 299, Kandy 350, Kurunegala 395, Matara, 175 Ratnapura, and 106 Vavuniya nursing students. Currently, about 3700 students are undergoing nurse training in nursing schools, while the Health Ministry has  issued a gazette notification to select student nurses from the 2019/2020 G.C.E. Advance Level results. (DJ)

title: Australian Border Force Commander meets Navy Commander
author: Author not found
Content: A delegation from the Australian Border Force led by the Commander Joint Agency Task Force Operation Sovereign Borders of the Royal Australian Navy (RAN), Rear Admiral Justin Jones called on Commander of the Navy, Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera at Navy Headquarters in Colombo yesterday (10). They exchanged views on matters of bilateral importance, focusing on efforts by the Sri Lanka Navy and Australian Border Force to stop people smuggling by boat to Australia as well as public awareness programmes being held in this regard. The discussions drew to a close with an exchange of mementoes as a gesture of goodwill and cooperation. In the joint media release issued by the Australian Border Force, Sri Lanka Navy and Sri Lanka Police, Commander of the Navy said people were still being lured to part with their hard earned savings and falsely believe that an illegal maritime journey will work. That was why educating communities on both the pitfalls as well as the legal pathway is vital to stemming the flow, he further added. The Defence Adviser at the High Commission of Australia in Colombo, Captain Ian Cain, Deputy Chief of Staff of the Navy and Director General Operations, Rear Admiral Pradeep Rathnayake and a group of senior officers from the Navy Headquarters were also present on this occasion.

title: Air Force Commander visits Dalada Maligawa
author: Author not found
Content: In keeping with tradition, the Commander of the Air Force, Air Marshal Udeni Rajapaksa, visited the Dalada Maligawa in Kandy and paid homage to the Sacred Tooth Relic recently The Commander called on Venerable Mahanayake Theras of the Malwathu and Asgiriya Chapters at their respective temples and received their blessings during the day. Following the call on sessions, the Commander and his family visited the Sri Dalada Maligawa Museum. The occasion was attended by the Chief Custodian of Sri Dalada Maligawa, Pradeep Nilanga Dela, the Chairperson SLAF Seva Vanitha Unit, Enoka Rajapaksa, the Commander’s family members and other representatives from the Air Force.

title: Pakistan Envoy launches community well project
author: Author not found
Content: High Commissioner of Pakistan Major General (R) Umar Farooq Burki HI inaugurated 102 individual and community water wells in Addalachenai during his visit to the Eastern Province. The drinking water well project is a first of its kind initiated by the Pakistan High Commission in Sri Lanka on behalf of the Pakistani government. The project will benefit more than 150 families in the area. These wells are a part of a project which targets different parts of the island, specially areas where the water table is low and is difficult for the local deprived community to get fresh water for drinking, irrigation and other routine matters. The project was initiated in the Northern Province, where community wells situated at 15 different locations were gifted to the people of Mannar in November last year. During the visit, the High Commissioner also distributed school bags and sports items among children of different ages. The Pakistan envoy’s tour of the Eastern Province was multi-faceted and the response from the local community was overwhelming. He was warmly welcomed wherever he visited and the High Commission activities were greatly highly appreciated by everyone, The Pakistani government will continue many more goodwill activities which will benefit the people of Sri Lanka regardless of gender, age or ethnicity, a spokesman said. During his speech at the inaugural ceremony, the High Commissioner reiterated the resolve of the Pakistani government to continue to help , local communities of in every possible way in the spirit of bilateral relations and friendship that exists between the two countries.
