title: Premier lauds Army Corporal for saving lives
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunewardena commended the soldier who prevented the Kandy- Mahiyangana bus accident and was able to save many lives. The Premier praised Corporal B.R.K.L Karunaratne of the Sri Lanka Infantry who intervened and prevented a major bus accident that could have resulted in the bus falling off a cliff in Kandy while on its way to Mahiyangana. The soldier’s quick reflex action prevented the accident and  thus saved  lives of more than 50 passengers on the bus. When the bus was travelling via Ududumbara on 26 May 2023, when the driver was thrown out of the driving seat and the bus was moving without the driver for about fifty metres. The Corporal who was traveling in the bus took immediate action and halted the bus which was running without a driver towards a huge cliff with great effort and prevented a major accident from ocuring.

title: Sri Lanka needs devil’s advocates, not armchair national security experts
author: By Major (retd) Hemantha Dayaratne USP
Content: Sri Lanka’s national security thinking is yet to evolve. Armchair national security experts dominate in national security architecture. Needs devil’s advocates for course correction to restore some balance.         Events unfolded in the recent past in national security and have raised a fundamental question. Has Sri Lanka had credible national security experts to advise politicians in power to make right national security decisions to prevent debacles? This is worth exploring for many reasons.        Reportedly, one expert’s advice to former president Gotabaya Rajapaksa on organic farming was about to destroy country’s food security, an essential component in national security. On another occasion, state national security experts to the same head of the state had no objection when he declared open an ‘Agitation Site’ for public to protest at Galle Face, Colombo. Having seriously mistaken with democracy and its enshrined freedom of expression, the ‘vital ground’ to consolidate in disguise and launch an attack to the president, his office and residence was so arranged thanks to ‘expert advice’ or rather a lacuna of advice. Machiavelli famously said, ‘Rivers and men can be controlled but, not trusted’. No expert was there to realise that sooner or later it would be a ‘deliberate ambush site’ or rather a ‘Forming Up Place’ (FUP) for angry mobs to ideally position the head of the state in a Killing Zone. The ambush sprang as planned meticulously. The violent mob smartly and swiftly formed the ‘assault line’ and attacked both targets. See how conventional battlefield terminologies and tactics applicable to counter revolutionary warfare situations, though nowhere is it mentioned as possible the mixing of the two theatres of war and predicting the consequences. Transferring executive power in the event of political fallout to a successor could have been peaceful and safe with no anarchy if the State had real national security experts to advise politicians in power. National security blunders list The ‘national security blunders list’ does not end there. Former president Maithripala Sirisena too made an unforgivable blunder thanks to armchair national security experts. For him there were no threats to the nation after the demise of the LTTE. Armchair national security experts dared not contradict the President’s utopian idea and thus, led to ignore precise intelligence warnings they had received from India. Those debacles are just a few to realise that Sri Lanka has only a bunch of armchair national security experts at public expense in weakly organised entities in the name of national security and strategy. The new President Ranil Wickremesinghe should be aware of this harsh reality.   It is striking to mention about a country that triumphantly ended a 30 year-long very difficult armed conflict a decade ago, is now left with non-professional security experts in the State. In fact, the professional security experts  were made to fade away long ago for a reason. Because they were ‘devil’s advocates’ amongst amiable, incompetent and gullible armchair national security experts who began to dominate in state national security thinking, teaching, academic and policy making institutions in successive governments in the aftermath of war with no expert ability on national security or strategy. Sri Lanka has thus reached a destination where the ‘devil’s advocates’ contribution is mandatory for course correction and to restore some balance in the national security domain. The devil’s advocates are those who pretend, in a discussion or argument, to go against an idea or plan that has a lot of support in the hope of uncovering flaws or mistakes. Therefore, the devil’s advocates’ assessments naturally will contradict the established view. However, it will be  important as they encourage doubt among decision-makers as unilateral or collective thinking by the previous two governments has seriously failed on many occasions as explained. Some countries as a remedy to such anomalous practice ‘the tenth man rule’ which has its origins in the devil’s advocacy. It suggests that, if nine people in a group of ten agree on an issue, the tenth member must take a contradictory viewpoint and assume the other nine are wrong. Politicians chase fame, power and popularity and so, find it difficult to make right national security choices by themselves. Then they look for experts around them and there, it is only the armchair national security experts are available with not an iota of practical knowledge or experience on national security. Strategies they have learned from books are impressive but often not practical in the local context. More to add, strategy if repeated is not a strategy. Therefore, they are cherry picking; only to go with the popular argument or view that they desire or their superior wishes to have in them. Their research publications are full of red herrings, distracting from real national security issues in the country. No alternative thinking, just book reading outcomes. So, they have been only good at ‘national security autopsies’. Further, if carefully considered, it is notable that these armchair national security experts are simply satisfying big power interests over state national security interests knowingly or unknowingly. Then, who can perform the role of the devil’s advocate? It can surely be veterans and former foreign service officers. Sri Lanka’s foreign service has been historically-highly politicised. However, there are a few retired professionals remaining. They have proved their mettle in advancing public diplomacy, politics, peace, economics and security in the past in the best interest of the State. Academically qualified soldiers Veterans are professionally and academically qualified soldiers or officers who have served in real battlefields, realised the multi-faceted nature of war, peace and conflict, and were honourably discharged under certain circumstances. Most Sri Lankan Armed Forces veterans who battled in the war are now retired but, they can still play important roles in Sri Lanka’s national security accredited to their education, experience and knowledge as experts. Their experience and knowledge on conflict can be incorporated effectively into national security teaching, thinking and policy making in the country.  A few hand-picked men from the above two professional categories, being the devil’s advocate could improve strategic national security decision-making if certain conditions are met. Such conditions include avoid becoming an overly negative ‘carping critic’, meaning delivering deliberately unreasonable criticism, have a deep and sincere commitment to questioning the basic assumptions of the majority, objectively. Had some kind of the ‘devil’s advocate’ on national security and strategy purposefully doubted the two previous Presidents’ and their armchair national security experts’ opinion, both the devastating Easter attacks and the Galle face fiasco could have been easily managed without endangering the country and the people. Unfortunately, the ‘devil’s advocates’ usually find it hard to survive among armchair national security experts owing to the harsh reality that politicians are more comfortable with the latter than the former. Whatever the national security decision that ruling politicians take, it is unlikely to matter to them as none seems answerable to national security blunders at the end, in this fragile state. This is another reason for politicians’ apathy to the ‘devil’s advocates’.  Sagala Ratnayake has been appointed as  Senior National Security Advisor (NSA). This new State appointment is timely and important, but the appointee does not stem from any national security background. In this context, serving military officers’ capacity to play the ‘devil’s advocate’ role is limited for obvious reasons of military discipline and their expressed loyalty to the Government in power. In such a setting, the NSA must have ‘devil’s advocates’ in his office to better advise the President and the Government to satisfy national security interests of the nation. National security is too dangerous to be left only in the hands of armchair national security experts.    (The writer, formerly an infantry officer in the Sri Lanka Army, Fellow Institute for Defence Studies and Analysis, New Delhi and founding Research Officer and Lecturer, Department of Strategic Studies, KDU and international media officer to President’s media division. He can be reached by email [email protected] )

title: Credit Optimisation Bill proved Opposition predictions wrong
author: Author not found
Content: Adviser to the President on Parliamentary Affairs, Prof. Ashu Marasinghe said yesterday (10) the Government has nearly USD 83 billion to be settled in debts which comprises USD 42 billion in local debt and USD 41billion in foreign loans. Prof. Marasinghe said,  “Today Sri Lanka has been able to process foreign loans as well as local loans as the local Credit Optimisation Bill to create sovereign debt sustainability was passed with a majority in Parliament”. During a media briefing at Sirikotha, Prof. Marasinghe said countries and financial agencies which gave loans to Sri Lanka, have agreed to write off a total sum of USD 17 billion and to extend the period of settling dues to 15 years and that passing the Bill was the reason. He said the request of international creditors was if USD 17 billion ought to be reduced from what Sri Lanka has obtained, domestic credit must be restructured in some way adding that accordingly, Sri Lanka has been able to extend the repayment of domestic loans of US$ 2 billion to 15 years.  “The bankrupt Opposition continues to make absurd allegations and was misinterpreting it as a move to destroy the Employees’ Provident Fund and Employees’ Trust Fund. They also predicted that the Bank system was drifting into a dangerous state, a situation that has never happened ever before in the financial history of Sri Lanka. “They said the share market would collapse as a result. Due to the continuous government holidays it was able to carry out this process very independently and freely,” said Prof. Marasinghe. On certain occasions, if depositors had withdrawn their money from Banks believing these rumours, there was a possibility of the banking system of this country collapsing, Prof Marasinghe further said. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Protests against Mahaweli H Zone land transfer
author: Author not found
Content: A protest was held at the Thambuttegama town yesterday demanding the cancellation of the secret distribution of commercial State lands in the Mahaweli H Zone in Thambuttegama town in the Anuradhapura District via the Mahaweli Authority among political henchmen. The protest was held opposite the Management Office of the Mahaweli H Zone in Thambuttegama town. A protest was also held opposing the incident on 7 July where protesters stated that they had been forced to stage another demonstration as officials had failed to rectify the situation. The protesters subsequently dispersed peacefully after being guaranteed of a discussion with the Mahaweli DG in the coming weeks. Text and Pic by Thisara Samal – Anuradhapura

title: Strengthening ties between Iran, Sri Lanka
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Buddha Sasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs, Vidura Wickremanayake said several programmes will be initiated to further strengthen cultural, religious, scientific and industrial ties between Iran and Sri Lanka. The Minister made this remark following talks with the Cultural Adviser of the Iranian Cultural Centre,  Dr. Moazami Goodarzi at the Iranian Cultural Centre in Colombo recently. Wickremanayake added that he had discussed with the Iranian official  exchanging knowhow between Tehran and Colombo with regard to Archaeology, Education and Technology.

title: First T-Bond auction after four months
author: Author not found
Content: Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) will hold its first Treasury (T) Bond auction after a lapse of four months on Thursday (13), data on CBSL’s website  yesterday ( Monday 10 July)) showed. This auction is for the issuance of Rs 100 billion T-Bonds comprising Rs 50 billion each of 2028 and 2030 maturities.  Prior to the coming Thursday’s T-Bond auction, the  last time CBSL held a T-Bond auction was on 13 March 2023 for the issuance of  Rs 180 billion T-Bonds comprising Rs 70 billion and Rs 110 billion 2024 and 2027 maturities. That auction was fully subscribed with the weighted average yields (WAYs) fetched being 29.99 per cent and 28.11 per cent, respectively. After the 13 March 2023 auction, CBSL stopped issuing T-Bonds till is domestic debt restructuring (DDR) matter was sorted out which took place on 1 July, with Parliament passing the necessary laws on that day. Issuing of T-Bonds is a key way that the Government of Sri Lanka (GoSL) meets its long term (over one year) borrowing needs. Under normal circumstances, investing in T-Bonds are risk free, because in the event GoSL is unable to repay such debt, CBSL is normally mandated to print demand-pull inflationary money and repay such creditors. Money printing is the sole mandate of CBSL. CBSL is also the steward of GoSL debt. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: IPE returns to Sri Lanka this week
author: Author not found
Content: Australia’s flagship regional engagement activity, the Indo-Pacific Endeavour (IPE), returns to Sri Lanka this week to conduct bilateral diving training between the Royal Australian Navy (RAN) and the Sri Lanka Navy, as well as to host a Maritime Security Law Forum. IPE supports the Australian Government’s focus to deepen diplomatic and defence partnerships across Southeast Asia and the Northeast Indian Ocean, and reinforces Australia’s commitment to a peaceful, secure and prosperous region.  IPE 2023 will conduct activities with Bangladesh, Brunei, Cambodia, India, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, the Maldives, the Philippines, Singapore, Sri Lanka, Timor-Leste, Thailand and Vietnam. “We are excited to return to Sri Lanka and train alongside the Sri Lankan Navy, Air Force, Coast Guard and Police. The diving training and law forum will enhance interoperability and increase shared maritime domain awareness between our respective forces. We engage regularly on a wide range of issues, including on economic, security, and development priorities, as well as human rights and reconciliation. The activities that are part of IPE 2023 will build friendships and understanding. “This will ultimately make it easier for us to work together in support of regional security, stability and prosperity,” Air Commodore Tony McCormack, Commander IPE23 said. Royal Australian Navy ships, Australian Army detachments and Royal Australian Air Force aircraft will also support exercises and engagement activities, sharing information and providing training opportunities throughout IPE 2023. Other agencies will also contribute to a range of activities, reflecting  the Australian government’s commitment to regional stability and security.

title: No truth in video footage circulating on YouTube
author: Author not found
Content: UNP Chairman MP Wajira Abeywardena claimed yesterday (10) an impartial inquiry must be launched into  baseless allegations  where his name has been dragged with regard to the release of gold articles from the Customs at the BIA. MP Abeywardena also claimed false news was circulating on YouTube a few days ago  damaging his reputation saying that he pressured the Director General of Customs to release the gold jewellery a housemaid had brought for her personal use. There was no truth in the video footage circulating on YouTube and had been created contrary to the truth and purely a move being to tarnish his image, Abeywardena said. He said he has asked the authorities to institute legal action in this connection while his Media Secretary will file a case in this regard with the CID urging them to commence inquiries as soon as possible. Abeywardena lamented that certain political leaders were engaging in a propaganda giving unwanted publicity to this issue. He condemned the baseless allegation and said he was instituting legal action against the smear campaign. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: CEB-powered hydroelectricity meets over 50 per cent electricity needs
author: Author not found
Content: Renewable energy (RE) led by cheap and clean Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) powered hydroelectricity met over 50 per cent of Sri Lanka’s (SL’s)  electricity needs for seven consecutive days to Sunday (9) after a lapse of more than  seven months, CEB  data showed.  Prior to Sunday, the last time RE met over 50 per cent of Sri Lanka’s electricity needs for at least seven consecutive days was from 31 July 2022 to 24 November 2022, where, RE met over 50 per cent of Sri Lanka’s electricity needs for 117 consecutive days, available CEB data showed. Sunday was also only the tenth day for the year (2023) thus far that RE has met over 50 per cent of Sri Lanka’s electricity needs, with the balance nine days, thus far for the year to Sunday that RE has met over 50 per cent of the island’s electricity needs being 8 January, 14 May, 4 June, 3 July, 4 July 5 July, 6 July, 7 July and 8 July, respectively.  On all other days of the year thus, over 50 per cent of Sri Lanka’s electricity needs were met by the pollutive, expensive and fossil fuels (FFs) led by imported coal and diesel. CEB further said that on Sunday Sri Lanka consumed a total of 36.73 Giga Watt hours (GWh) of electricity with RE meeting 18.26 GWh (51.24 per cent) of those needs and the balance 17.91 GWh (48.76 per cent) having been met by  FFs. Meanwhile, Sunday’s total electricity split was  coal meeting 10.94 GWh or 29.78 per cent of Sri Lanka total electricity needs;  CEB hydroelectricity  providing 10.84 GWh (29.51 per cent) of the country’s total electricity consumption; other forms of RE including private sector (PS) biomass, wind-comprising both CEB and PS wind, mini hydroelectricity and solar together: 7.98 GWh (21.73 per cent),  CEB thermal oil 3.69 GWh (10.05 per cent)  and PS or independent power producers’ (IPP’) thermal oil which includes  diesel, also an FF, 3.28 GWh (8.93 per cent) respectively. According to the recently released Central Bank of Sri Lanka 2022 Annual Report, the most cost effective form of electricity generation to the CEB last year was CEB hydroelectricity costing Rs 1.80 a unit of electricity or per one kilo Watt hour (KWh) per unit, followed by non conventional RE such as PS mini hydroelectricity, etc., Rs 14.98, coal (Rs 27.32), CEB fuel oil (Rs 67.69) and PS fuel oil (Rs 69.65) and respectively. CBSL’s 2022 Annual Report further said that CEB’s average electricity tariff last year was Rs 21.25 a unit. Meanwhile, CBSL in their tariff calculations have not taken into account the 66 per cent electricity tariff increase imposed by the Government in February of this year (2023). By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Coastal areas to woo tourists identified
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Urban Development and Housing, Prasanna Ranatunga instructed the Department of Coast Conservation and Coastal Resources Management (DCCCRM) to implement a programme to identify places of attraction in the coastal areas to woo tourists to the country.  The Minister had further advised officials to seek the support of the State and private institutions to  develop such spots and secure suitable investors for such projects. Ranatunga made these observations during a discussion at his Ministry yesterday. DCCCRM officials stated that they had identified 24 spots that would attract tourists in the coastal belt to be developed, and added that measures will be taken to expedite the process.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Applications called for Additional District Secy posts in six Districts
author: Author not found
Content: The State Ministry of Home Affairs has called for applications from Grade One officers of the Sri Lanka Administrative Service to fill vacancies in Additional District Secretary posts in six Districts in the country. The vacancies were in Colombo, Nuwara Eliya, Puttalam, Moneragala, Jaffna and Mannar Districts. State Ministry sources added that applications will be accepted till 21 July and were for 12-months. By Amith Gamage

title: SLTB long – distance services go digital
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Transport Board (SLTB) launched its digital long-distance bus timetable accessible through a mobile and web-based application in a bid to make it easy for passengers track the services. The sltb.eseat.lk was launched by Minister Bandula Gunawardana following a media briefing at the Government Information Department. Launching the application, the Minister said this was Sri Lanka’s largest online bus/coach reservation platform ever, which will transform the way millions of Sri Lankans travel and reserve seats to travel across the country. Through the application, people will be able to reserve seats via its online bus ticket booking services, he said. “Reservations can be done through the website 24X7 via hotline 1315. 400 long-distance buses, including 2,500 routes, were added to the system. The arrival and departure of the buses will be displayed through the application,” the Minister said. This application was launched in line with the programme of digitalising government institutions, he said.

title: ‘Very important’ revelation in near future – Aluthgamage
author: Author not found
Content: Bank accounts of those who have been identified as ‘leaders of the Aragalaya’ including Rajangane Saddharathana Thera and Inter-University Bhikku Federation (IUBF) Convener Galwewa Siridhamma Thera, are under the scrutiny of the CID at present to find out whether they have received foreign money during the Aragalaya period last year, Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) MP Mahindananda Aluthgamage said yesterday (9). Aluthgamage held a media briefing at the President’s Media Centre (PMC) on the first anniversary of Aragalaya, where he claimed that a “very important” revelation regarding how these “leaders” obtained foreign money would be made in the near future. “A young man is being held on suspicion of giving leadership to burn down President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s residence. It has been established that his account also received funds from abroad. Additionally, some leading activists of the Aragalaya are currently having their accounts investigated. In a few days we will bring to light how they received the money,” he stressed. The SLPP MP, speaking about Rajangane Saddharathana Thera, who has been remanded under the ICCPR Act, alleged the latter had received about Rs 400 million from Guatemala. “Guatemala is a country that is heavily involved in international drug trafficking. We shouldn’t overlook the fact that the previous President worked hard to combat drug trafficking in this situation. The facts I am saying are the facts revealed during CID investigations,” he claimed. Speaking further, Aluthgamage said files have been opened to provide compensation to the MPs whose houses were set alight during violence on 9 May 2022 and the aftermath. One MP has been given Rs 800,000 as compensation, he added. “One of the most innocent people’s representatives in Parliament, SLPP Polonnaruwa District MP Amarakeerthi Athukorala was brutally killed by a mob of protestors. 47 houses belonging to MPs, Ministers, and State Ministers were set on fire. Houses of local political leaders and supporters were burnt and destroyed,” he stressed. By Amith Madhuranga Gamage

title: Bus topples into precipice, 26 injured
author: Author not found
Content: At least 26 individuals were injured in a bus accident at Dunukedeniya, Pundalu Oya last evening (9). The bus, which was carrying a group of estate workers, veered off the road and toppled down a 30-foot precipice. The incident occurred at approximately 4.30 p.m. yesterday (9), resulting in injuries to the 26 women who were passengers on the bus. They were rushed to the Kotmale Divisional Hospital. Some of the injured women, who sustained critical injuries, were transferred to the Nawalapitiya District General Hospital for further care. Pundalu Oya Police said the accident was caused by a technical failure in the bus. BY Neeta PathmaKumari – Norwood

title: University, Police launch joint probe
author: Author not found
Content: The University of Peradeniya and the Peradeniya Police have launched a joint investigation into an attempted suicide of a student, after being questioned by the CID recently.  The second-year student from the Faculty of Allied Health Sciences was questioned by the CID over an alleged ragging incident in the university. Investigations into the allegations were handed over to the CID. Following this, a team of CID Officers visited the University of Peradeniya, amidst the protests of the students’ unions. The student who attempted suicide is presently receiving treatment at the Teaching Hospital Peradeniya. His condition is stable. The victim told the Police that he was assaulted by CID Officers and that they confiscated his mobile phone, threatening to cancel his studentship, causing fear and distress to him. (If you need mental health assistance, dial 1926; the NIMH hotline) By K.L. Samaraweera – Kandy

title: President to discuss fishermen’s issues with PM Modi – Douglas
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe is expected to have extensive discussions with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi regarding Indian fishermen poaching in Sri Lankan territorial waters, off the Northern and Eastern coasts, Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda said yesterday (9). Devananda said diplomatic and friendly measures are being taken to put an end to the plundering of Sri Lanka’s aquatic resources by Indian trawlers through illegal poaching. The Fisheries Minister expressed deep concern over the immeasurable damage caused to the local economy and the fishing gear owned by Sri Lankan fishermen due to the activities of Indian trawlers. He stressed the urgent need to address this issue effectively. Devananda also called upon the representatives of the Tamil community in the Northern and Eastern Provinces to meet Tamil Nadu Chief Minister M. K. Stalin. The purpose of the meeting would be to clarify that this issue directly affects the Tamil-speaking communities in Sri Lanka and to dispel any misconceptions regarding the Sri Lankan Navy and military hindering Tamil Nadu fishermen in their profession. Devananda expressed his willingness to lead the delegation if the representatives from the Northern and Eastern provinces are ready to visit India. The Fisheries Minister highlighted that despite his efforts to address this long-standing issue, a resolution has not yet been reached. He emphasised that the Sri Lankan Navy has intensified patrol operations along the international maritime border to apprehend poachers and their vessels. Devananda added that allegations contrary to the truth have been made against the Sri Lankan Navy in this regard. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Navy arrests 12 in Jaffna, Mannar
author: Author not found
Content: The Navy arrested 12 individuals in Jaffna and Mannar who were involved in illegal fishing on 7 and 8 July. These operations resulted in the seizure of 1,870 illegally harvested sea cucumbers, unauthorised fishing gear, and four dinghies. The Navy regularly conducts operations to combat illegal fishing activities in coastal and sea areas islandwide. As part of these efforts, the Naval Deployment Veththalakerni in the Northern Naval Command conducted special operations on 7 July night, arresting nine individuals engaged in light-coarse fishing off Chalei and Chundikulam. Unauthorised fishing gear and three dinghies were also seized during the operation. Further, on 8 July evening, SLNS Buwaneka in the North Central Naval Command arrested three individuals for fishing without valid passes off Illuppaikadavai. In addition to the arrests, the Navy confiscated 1,870 illegally harvested sea cucumbers and a dinghy used for the illegal activity. The arrested individuals, aged 23-58, were from various locations including Dharmapuram, Vallipuram, Chilaw, Mailavapuram, Kallaru, Thalayadi, and Walaipadu. The Navy handed over the suspects, their belongings, and the illegally harvested sea cucumbers to the Department of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources, Jaffna, and Mannar Assistant Directorate of Fisheries for further legal action. (SM)

title: Sajith calls for peaceful people’s struggle
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, who extended his congratulations to the citizens on the first anniversary of ‘Aragalaya’ on 9 July, emphasised the need for a peaceful people’s struggle to rebuild the country that has collapsed. In a statement, Premadasa said, “The people rose against a corrupt and inept regime that led the country to bankruptcy last year. “The climax of that struggle was on 9 July. It was a truly remarkable people’s movement, and I would like to congratulate all the citizens who participated in that struggle.” The Opposition Leader highlighted that the people peacefully protested against the former government, armed only with placards and slogans against the corrupt regime. However, their collective voices were so powerful that the then President had to resign, he added. “Nevertheless, the victory achieved through that struggle is now under threat as the ‘Rajapaksa gang’ has snatched it away from the people. Therefore, we urgently need another peaceful struggle to rescue the country,” the Opposition Leader said. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: IGP C.D. Wickramaratne given three-month extension
author: Author not found
Content: C.D. Wickramaratne has been given a three-month extension as the IGP with effect from yesterday (9) by President Ranil Wickremesinghe, following the recommendation of Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles, the Ministry of Public Security announced. This is the second service extension given to the IGP. Wickramaratne’s tenure ended on 26 March, following which he received a three-month extension by way of a Extraordinary Gazette Notification issued by President’s Secretary Saman Ekanayake. Accordingly, the position of IGP has been left vacant since the end of Wickramaratne’s tenure on 26 June. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Truly independent Bribery Commission expected – Jayamanna
author: Author not found
Content: Sarath Jayamanna, former Director General of the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) claimed that a new Anti-Corruption Bill will establish a ‘truly independent Bribery Commission.’ He said this during an interview conducted by the President’s Media Division (PMD). He emphasised the people’s determination to resist any attempts to suppress this commission, calling on the public to encourage Government leaders and officials to embrace the change and move away from empty slogans. Jayamanna highlighted that bribery and corruption are not unique to Sri Lanka but affect economies worldwide. He stressed that leaders genuinely committed to their country’s development and its people are actively working to combat corruption. Citing examples from countries such as Singapore, Hong Kong, Bhutan, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Scandinavian nations, he urged Sri Lanka to adopt their successful approaches in eradicating bribery and corruption. He acknowledged that eliminating bribery and corruption overnight is unrealistic but emphasised the significance of the new Anti-Corruption Act. He noted that despite Sri Lanka signing a charter against bribery and corruption in 2004, effective implementation has been lacking. The proposed Act marks a crucial step forward in addressing the perception that the Government and private sectors are plagued by bribery and corruption. The former DG also highlighted the need for expertise beyond policing in investigating complex crimes like bribery and corruption. He recommended recruiting individuals with knowledge in mathematics, engineering science, forensic auditing, and forensic accounting to work in this field. Countries like Hong Kong and Bhutan have successfully employed officials recruited similarly to civil administrators for such investigations. “Under the new legislation, the commission will have the authority to hire expert investigators directly, avoiding the bureaucracy of seeking funding from the Ministry of Finance or the Treasury. Funding will be provided from the Treasury through the Parliament, enabling the commission to address conflicts of interest and fulfil its obligations to the private sector. Additionally, the Act mandates the electronic submission of assets and liabilities of government executive officers to the Bribery Commission for the first time in history. Provisions have been established to investigate and penalise past offenses, ensuring a smooth transition from the old laws. The selection of commissioners will be done by the Constituent Assembly, and the President’s appointment of the Director General will require consultation with the Commission,” Jayamanna said.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Sajith calls for peaceful people’s struggle
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, who extended his congratulations to the citizens on the first anniversary of ‘Aragalaya’ on 9 July, emphasised the need for a peaceful people’s struggle to rebuild the country that has collapsed. In a statement, Premadasa said, “The people rose against a corrupt and inept regime that led the country to bankruptcy last year. “The climax of that struggle was on 9 July. It was a truly remarkable people’s movement, and I would like to congratulate all the citizens who participated in that struggle.” The Opposition Leader highlighted that the people peacefully protested against the former government, armed only with placards and slogans against the corrupt regime. However, their collective voices were so powerful that the then President had to resign, he added. “Nevertheless, the victory achieved through that struggle is now under threat as the ‘Rajapaksa gang’ has snatched it away from the people. Therefore, we urgently need another peaceful struggle to rescue the country,” the Opposition Leader said. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: IGP C.D. Wickramaratne given three-month extension
author: Author not found
Content: C.D. Wickramaratne has been given a three-month extension as the IGP with effect from yesterday (9) by President Ranil Wickremesinghe, following the recommendation of Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles, the Ministry of Public Security announced. This is the second service extension given to the IGP. Wickramaratne’s tenure ended on 26 March, following which he received a three-month extension by way of a Extraordinary Gazette Notification issued by President’s Secretary Saman Ekanayake. Accordingly, the position of IGP has been left vacant since the end of Wickramaratne’s tenure on 26 June. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Truly independent Bribery Commission expected – Jayamanna
author: Author not found
Content: Sarath Jayamanna, former Director General of the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) claimed that a new Anti-Corruption Bill will establish a ‘truly independent Bribery Commission.’ He said this during an interview conducted by the President’s Media Division (PMD). He emphasised the people’s determination to resist any attempts to suppress this commission, calling on the public to encourage Government leaders and officials to embrace the change and move away from empty slogans. Jayamanna highlighted that bribery and corruption are not unique to Sri Lanka but affect economies worldwide. He stressed that leaders genuinely committed to their country’s development and its people are actively working to combat corruption. Citing examples from countries such as Singapore, Hong Kong, Bhutan, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Scandinavian nations, he urged Sri Lanka to adopt their successful approaches in eradicating bribery and corruption. He acknowledged that eliminating bribery and corruption overnight is unrealistic but emphasised the significance of the new Anti-Corruption Act. He noted that despite Sri Lanka signing a charter against bribery and corruption in 2004, effective implementation has been lacking. The proposed Act marks a crucial step forward in addressing the perception that the Government and private sectors are plagued by bribery and corruption. The former DG also highlighted the need for expertise beyond policing in investigating complex crimes like bribery and corruption. He recommended recruiting individuals with knowledge in mathematics, engineering science, forensic auditing, and forensic accounting to work in this field. Countries like Hong Kong and Bhutan have successfully employed officials recruited similarly to civil administrators for such investigations. “Under the new legislation, the commission will have the authority to hire expert investigators directly, avoiding the bureaucracy of seeking funding from the Ministry of Finance or the Treasury. Funding will be provided from the Treasury through the Parliament, enabling the commission to address conflicts of interest and fulfil its obligations to the private sector. Additionally, the Act mandates the electronic submission of assets and liabilities of government executive officers to the Bribery Commission for the first time in history. Provisions have been established to investigate and penalise past offenses, ensuring a smooth transition from the old laws. The selection of commissioners will be done by the Constituent Assembly, and the President’s appointment of the Director General will require consultation with the Commission,” Jayamanna said.

title: Prof Sethunga appointed NIE DG
author: Author not found
Content: Professor Prasad Sethunga has been appointed as the new Director General of the National Institute of Education (NIE). The appointment was made by the Minister of Education, Dr. Susil Premajayantha, who handed over the appointment letter to Prof. Sethunga at the Ministry of Education premises on 9 July. Following the appointment, Prof. Sethunga officially assumed his duties at the National Institute of Education. He is a respected scholar who actively works in the field of education, particularly in areas such as teacher education, teachers’ professional development, interactive education, and school-based teacher development programmes in Sri Lanka. Prior to this appointment, he held the position of Senior Professor in the Education Faculty at the University of Peradeniya.

title: SL experiencing economic boom
author: Author not found
Content: Chief of Staff of the President, Sagala Ratnayake, claimed on 8 July that the country’s economy is experiencing significant growth under the leadership of President Ranil Wickremesinghe. Ratnayake emphasised the President’s efforts to revive the bankrupt economy and initiate a well-planned development programme to transform the country into a developed nation in the near future. He expressed confidence that many pressing issues the country is facing can be resolved by the end of the year, urging the public not to panic about the future. He mentioned that the country is steadily returning to normalcy, addressing issues one by one while implementing welfare programmes to benefit people at the grassroots level. Sri Lanka has received positive attention from various countries, including developed nations and friendly nations, who are extending a helping hand to overcome the ongoing economic crisis that has affected the lives of ordinary people and the overall economy, he said. Ratnayake stressed the need to strengthen the country’s economy by generating more income or increasing taxes. Ratnayake also commended President Wickremesinghe’s efforts in stabilising skyrocketing inflation, considering it a significant achievement both locally and internationally. He emphasised the importance of rebuilding Sri Lanka’s reputation among foreign investors and devising new mechanisms to attract more investment. He said without foreign investment and support, the country’s development would always be questionable. Further, Ratnayake mentioned the abundant natural resources in the region that can promote the tourism industry. He called for unity and to set aside personal disputes and political agendas to create a new Sri Lanka. Meanwhile, Adviser to the President on International Affairs, Dinouk Colombage, added that the UNP is transforming into a victorious force islandwide, including the Southern region, and expressed confidence in securing more seats in future elections. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Cricket carpets set alight at McHeyzer Ground
author: Author not found
Content: Unidentified individuals set fire to cricket carpets at McHeyzer Ground in Trincomalee on 8 July night, Police said.Police have launched investigations to arrest the suspects. A team from the Trincomalee Police visited the scene and gathered evidence, following a complaint. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Diana urges removal of ‘viral’ audio clip
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Tourism Diana Gamage has written a letter to the head of the Police Cyber Crimes Division, urging the removal of a widely circulated audio clip of her conversation with an individual on social media platforms. Gamage stressed that she has been repeatedly subjected to nuisance calls and text messages from a certain individual. Her security officers have already requested this person to cease their activities and leave her alone. Unfortunately, the caller has also directed abusive language. In light of these circumstances, the State Minister has appealed to the Head of the Cyber Crimes Division to take necessary action to remove the audio clip from social media platforms.

title: NAM Ministers meet in Azerbaijan
author: Author not found
Content: Addressing the Ministerial Meeting of the Coordinating Bureau of the Non-Aligned Movement (NAM) held from 5-6 July 2023 in Baku, Azerbaijan, State Minister of Foreign Affairs Tharaka Balasuriya joined other NAM Ministers in the call for substantial reform of NAM for its continuation as an effective multilateral forum to address contemporary challenges. Sri Lanka is a co-sponsor of the Bandung Conference of 1955 which serves as the foundation of the Non-Aligned Movement and a founding member of the NAM. Today, NAM has evolved as an important partner in the current geopolitical developments with 120 Member States. State Minister Balasuriya held bilateral meetings with Deputy Foreign Minister of Azerbaijan Elnur Mammadov, Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs of Vietnam Do Hung Viet, and Foreign Minister of Nepal Narayan Prakash Saud on the sidelines of the meeting. He was accompanied by Deputy Permanent Representative of Sri Lanka to the United Nations in Geneva, Dayani Mendis who also represented Sri Lanka at the Senior Officials Meeting which preceded the Ministerial Meeting.

title: Tourism will contribute significantly to FX earnings – President
author: Author not found
Content: During the ‘Transcending Borders – Transforming Lives’ programme organised by the Indian Tourism Federation at BMICH on 6 July, President Ranil Wickremesinghe expressed his belief that the tourism industry would contribute significantly to the country’s foreign exchange earnings in the coming decade. The President highlighted that comprehensive plans had already been formulated to enhance Sri Lanka’s appeal as a tourist destination and stressed that promoting tourism could lead to an increase in per capita income. President Wickremesinghe also emphasised the importance of collaborative efforts among all the BIMSTEC countries to develop the BIMSTEC region into a thriving tourism hub, transcending national borders. Addressing the event, Indian High Commissioner to Sri Lanka, Gopal Bagle, announced the expansion of flights between Chennai and Jaffna, which now operates only four times a week, to begin operations on a daily basis starting from 16 July. He further mentioned ongoing efforts to resume the long-discontinued ferry service between the two nations, which had remained inactive for several decades. With a strong turnout, 500 members of the Indian Tourism Federation participated in this highly anticipated event. The promotion of Sri Lanka’s tourism industry has been a focal point of discussions throughout the conference. Additionally, 50 Indian journalists joined the gathering to cover the proceedings, highlighting the significance of this occasion. Coinciding with the conference, the Sri Lanka Association of Inbound Tour Operators (SLAITO) and its member associations have meticulously organised a post-summit tour encompassing popular tourist destinations such as Bentota, Galle, and Kandy. This initiative aims to showcase the beauty and diversity of Sri Lanka’s attractions to the attendees. The Travel Agents Association of India (TAAI) Colombo Summit has garnered support from four major airlines, namely SriLankan Airlines, Air India, IndiGo, and Vistara. These partnerships will facilitate seamless travel arrangements for the participants and further enhance the success of the summit. Dignitaries and key figures attending the event included Nimal Siripala de Silva, Minister of Ports and Maritime Affairs, Harin Fernando, Minister of Tourism and Lands, and Jyoti Mayal, President of TAAI, among others.

title: Old Anandians felicitate SLAF Chief
author: Author not found
Content: Old Anandians’ Professional Forum (OAPF) and Old Anandians’ Sports Club (OASC), in adherence to its tradition of acknowledging individuals who have attained the highest levels of recognition and accomplishment in society, paid the utmost honour to an alumnus and the newly appointed 19th Commander of the Air Force, Air Marshal Udeni Rajapaksa. The distinguished gathering took place at Hilton Colombo on last Wednesday (5) under the guidance of Ananda College alumnus, the President of the OAPF and OASC, as well as the incumbent Secretary to the Ministry of Defence, General Kamal Guneratne. The felicitation ceremony featured an impressive assembly, including the present Principal of Ananda College, Lal Dissanayake, members from the Ananda College Old Boys Association, Old Anandians’ Professional Forum and Old Anandians’ Sports Club. A senior member of the Old Anandians’ Professional Forum, Mahinda de Lanerolle, launched the event with a welcome note. Subsequently, General Kamal Guneratne, delivered a speech signifying the Ananda College’s history of producing exemplary individuals who serve the country in esteemed positions. General Guneratne expressed immense pride and inspiration in the achievements of Air Marshal Udeni Rajapaksa, highlighting his excellence in sports, academics and extracurricular activities during his time at the school. Following the speech, Air Marshal Rajapaksa, the Chief Guest, addressed the distinguished gathering. Prior to his address, an Introductory Note about the Chief Guest was delivered by a classmate of the Commander, Dr. Ishantha Siribaddana and a batch mate from the 6th Intake of Kotelawala Defence Academy, Major Mahinda Adikari (Retd). Air Marshal Rajapaksa humbly acknowledged that his achievements were a result of the solid foundation he received during his secondary education at his beloved Ananda College. With pride, he expressed profound gratitude to his alma mater, addressing the Alumni members and emphasising that the strong educational foundation he received paved the way for his appointment as the Commander of the Air Force. The Commander also warmheartedly remembered and appreciated all the teachers who served during his time for secondary education at Ananda College. As a gesture of recognition, a special memento was presented to Air Marshal Rajapaksa by Ananda College alumnus, the President of the OAPF and OASC, as well as the incumbent Secretary to the Ministry of Defence, General Kamal Guneratne. The ceremony concluded with the Vote of Thanks, delivered by  Sitendra Seneviratne, the Former President of the Old Anandians’ Sports Club.

title: Utilise natural resources to develop N and E – Rasamanickam
author: Author not found
Content: Ilankai Tamil Arasu Kachchi (ITAK) MP Shanakiyan Rasamanickam claimed that the North and East possess abundant natural resources that could be utilised to drive development in both regions. Rasamanickam expressed confidence that if these resources were properly utilised, the North and East could quickly become developed regions. He also highlighted that the lack of power has hindered the development of these provinces. However, he expressed optimism that President Ranil Wickremesinghe, who is concerned about every citizen, will soon recommend sustainable solutions for the fundamental rights and development-related issues of the Tamil people. He said this during a media interaction following a workshop organised by the T20 Organisation in Meghalaya, India. The workshop aimed to foster understanding among stakeholders regarding climate and social changes, potential environmental impacts, and the achievement of sustainable development by addressing various challenges. During the discussions, it was stressed that climate change and other environmental issues would significantly impact future generations. MP Rasamanickam emphasised the importance of involving youth in facing and overcoming these challenges. Rasamanickam said Meghalaya, established in the early 1970s, has successfully transformed itself into a developed region by harnessing its resources. He said the North and East could achieve sustainable and steady development within a short period if they were granted the necessary power through proper devolution. Further, Rasamanickam emphasised that although the provinces possess sufficient resources to drive development, the main obstacle lies in the lack of rights and power to implement their development plans as desired. He specifically mentioned the issue of illegal sand mining occurring in both provinces. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Explosives found in abandoned toilet
author: Author not found
Content: Explosives were found inside an abandoned toilet on private land in Kuppilan, Mullaitivu District. The owner, while cleaning the garden for cultivation, unexpectedly found the explosives and immediately informed the Mullaitivu Police on 9 July. On receiving the information, the Mullaitivu Police promptly arrived at the scene. They marked off the specific pit and its surrounding areas, suspecting the presence of additional explosives. To ensure safe disposal, the Police sought approval from the Mullaitivu District Court. Police said they believe that the pit may contain hand grenades and Rocket-Propelled Grenades (RPGs). By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Event testifies to India – SL economic ties
author: Author not found
Content: Deputy High Commissioner of India, Vinod K. Jacob, addressing the inauguration ceremony of the Construction, Power and Energy Expo 2023 in Colombo on 7 July, said the occasion testifies to the robust economic and commercial links between India and Sri Lanka. Following is the full speech: “I am particularly encouraged by the enthusiastic participation of Indian companies in this Expo, which by the latest count amounts to nearly 50. This testifies to the robust economic and commercial links between India and Sri Lanka. The past three years have demonstrated the close links between the people of India and Sri Lanka. In line with the Neighbourhood First Policy of the Government of India, the Indian High Commission has steadfastly supported the economic and social ministries of Sri Lanka as they navigated the challenges of the Covid pandemic, the economic crisis and the political upheavals during this period. India’s financial and humanitarian support worth USD 4 billion is far in excess of the total anticipated Extended Fund Facility of the IMF. We were the first creditor nation in January this year to convey the financing assurances needed to kick-start the IMF process. India will continue to play a constructive role as a Co-Chair of the Creditors Committee along with Japan and the Paris Club. The successful visit of External Affairs Minister Dr. S. Jaishankar to Sri Lanka in January this year opened up avenues for further cooperation through investment in infrastructure, manufacturing and promoting connectivity. India was Sri Lanka’s largest trading partner in 2022. Sri Lanka’s exports to India have also grown. The use of Rupees for trade settlement is further helping Sri Lanka’s economy. These are concrete steps to help Sri Lanka’s economic recovery and growth. I am glad to note that India was once again the largest source of tourists for Sri Lanka last year with over 100,000 tourists and is continuing to top the chart so to say this year as well. Around one in every five to six tourists in Sri Lanka is an Indian. The resumption of Chennai-Jaffna flights is yet another step in bringing the people of the two countries closer. Ferry services between the two countries will bolster this further. Connectivity is a force multiplier in this context. This will complement the flagship development cooperation partnership which has given such useful public goods like the Suwa Seriya 1990 Ambulance Service, the Indian Housing Project, the reconstruction of schools and construction of hospitals and other socioeconomic projects. Recent developments in India-Sri Lanka ties have strengthened our friendship and all-round cooperation. At the same time, the two countries also remain vigilant to address common challenges, especially in the maritime security domain. I hope the participants in the Expo will keep this background in mind and strive to further deepen the India-Sri Lanka friendship which is currently at its highest point in the past 75 years. We have reached this stage because the people, the business circles and the Government of India have resolved to strongly stand by Sri Lanka at the current juncture.”

title: Variety bargain sale to fund charity work
author: Author not found
Content: The Passion for Compassion Society will hold a variety bargain sale to help fund their upcoming charity projects for underprivileged children and the elderly. The sale will include many stalls offering a variety of goods ranging from clothing, linen to kitchen, tableware and food. Nearly new items will also be on sale at deeply discounted prices! When: 12 July from 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Where: St. Paul’s Milagiriya Parish Hall, Bambalapitiya. The Passion for Compassion Society is a group of volunteer social workers with a mission to assist underprivileged children with education and the helpless elderly of Sri Lanka with quality of life. The proceeds from this variety bargain sale will fund many of the planned projects the society has for this year and will help this group of tireless volunteers to continue their noble work and service to society.

title: SL, Australia to hold foreign office bilateral consultations
author: Author not found
Content: The Fourth Round of Foreign Office Bilateral Consultations, Second Strategic Maritime Dialogue and Third Joint Trade and Investment Committee Meeting between Sri Lanka and Australia will be held on 11 and 12 July at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Colombo. These meetings will be co-chaired by First Assistant Secretary of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade of Australia Gary Cowan, Additional Secretary (Bilateral East) Yasoja Gunasekera, and Additional Secretary (Economic Affairs) Shanika Dissanayake of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and Secretary of the Ministry of Trade, Commerce and Food Security A.M.P.M.B. Atapattu. The meetings are expected to assess the status of bilateral relations covering ongoing cooperation and areas of shared interest including politics, trade and investment, defence, tourism, agriculture, education, health and in the field of sports. The previous sessions of the above three bilateral mechanisms were held in September 2019.

title: India a trustworthy friend – Speaker
author: Author not found
Content: Expressing his gratitude to “a trustworthy friend” India for saving Sri Lanka and preventing a “bloodbath” during its unprecedented economic crisis last year, Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena said not a single nation has extended that kind of assistance to Colombo as done by New Delhi. Sri Lanka was hit by a catastrophic financial crisis in 2022, the worst since its independence from Britain in 1948, due to a severe paucity of foreign exchange reserves. As the country struggled, locked in the throes of the crisis, India extended multi-pronged assistance of about USD 4 billion to it last year, through multiple credit lines and currency support, in line with India’s ‘Neighbourhood First’ policy. In his address at the gala dinner reception hosted for delegates of the Indian Travel Congress on Friday, Abeywardena said India “saved us” during the financial crisis, otherwise, there would have been “another bloodbath for all of us”. At the evening reception, he thanked India for the help extended to the cash-strapped nation and recalled the civilisational ties and similarities between the two countries and their cultures. “Sri Lanka and India are very, very closely interconnected countries, culturally, nationally, and policy-wise, and above all, India has been a very close associate and trustworthy friend of Sri Lanka,” Abeywardena said, adding that when “we were in trouble”, India always helped out. “And, even this time, today, I heard that India is willing to extend our restructuring of loans for 12 years. Never expected, and never in history, not a single country has extended that kind of assistance,” he said. He recalled the helping hand lent by India during the period of trouble last year that devastated the Sri Lankan economy, pushing it into a debt crisis. “I must tell you, during the trouble that we had last year, you (India) saved us, India saved us otherwise, there would have been another bloodbath for all of us. So, that is how India came to help us,” Abeywardena said. He said this in the presence of Indian High Commissioner to Sri Lanka, Gopal Baglay, Tourism and Lands Minister Harin Fernando, and other senior officials of the Sri Lankan Government. “Your ambassador here, (is a) very close friend of ours. We love and respect him,” the Speaker said, referring to Baglay. Later, in an interaction with PTI on the sidelines of the reception, Abeywardena said, “India has always come to the aid of Sri Lanka” in times of crises, and laid emphasis on the financial assistance given by New Delhi last year when the island nation was mired in the economic turmoil. “That helped us survive for six months in the midst of the crisis,” he said. “We thank India for the kind gesture, and I also say, thank you, Prime Minister of India (Narendra Modi),” he told PTI. Noting the similarity between the Indian surname Singh and the Sri Lankan surname Singhe, Abeywardena said, “It shows we are genetically connected to India”. “That way, India is not a new country to us. It’s part of the ethos of our country, part of our life, part of our heart,” he said, adding, “We are here to receive you, respect you, join with you.” “Together, we (Sri Lanka) can join with you (India), without any difficulty or hesitation, with great trust,” the Speaker said. In his address, Tourism and Lands Minister Fernando pitched Sri Lanka – Pearl of the Indian Ocean – as a unique destination for India and the rest of the world, saying, “One island nation offers so many different tourist experiences, without travelling far from one location to another.” Meanwhile, several sessions were held on Saturday as part of the three-day 67th Convention of the TAAI (Travel Agents Association of India) which began on 6 July. The four-day convention of the TAAI, which was set up in 1951, is being held with the support of the Sri Lanka Tourism Promotion Bureau (SLTPB) and the Sri Lankan Association of Inbound Tour Operators (SLAITO). (PTI)

title: Govt to promote liquid milk production – Herath
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Livestock Development D.B. Herath said people are interested in the production and consumption of liquid milk, and by supporting the liquid milk business it has been feasible to boost the dairy farmers’ economics and satisfy the country’s need for protein. The Minister also mentioned that the Government has implemented a specific programme to promote liquid milk production in the country. He expressed these views during a media briefing themed ‘Collective Path to a Stable Country’ held at the Presidential Media Centre (PMC) on Friday (7). “In the past, the Ministry of Agriculture had to face many problems. In the face of that crisis, the President started a strong programme to meet the food needs of the people of the country. The Ministry of Agriculture faced numerous issues in the past. The President launched a robust effort to meet the food needs of the people of the country in response to that disaster. Our goal in the livestock sector is to primarily supply the nation’s protein and dairy needs. Medical guidelines state that one individual requires 100 ml of milk every day. As a result, the nation should produce 750 million ml of milk per day,” he said. In 2021, we could not achieve those goals. We could produce only 712 million litres of milk. We had to import the rest from foreign countries. The Government has spent Rs 58 billion for that. This is a serious challenge for us economically, he added. The minister said to date, Customs concessions have been provided to import animal feed and medicine. The possibility to import mother cows has also been made available. We plan to reduce costs by doing this. “We anticipate charging the consumer a fair price for these products. Restarting industry-related enterprises that have failed is one of our key objectives. Making the nation milk self-sufficient is our goal. Despite the difficulty, we have commenced the required programme for that. We currently have only 16,000 cows in this programme. Additionally, there are 400,000 buffaloes. Currently, the Central and North-West Provinces make significant contributions to milk production. The majority of animals are raised solely for meat in the Eastern and Southern Provinces. Also, we are currently implementing a programme to provide the knowledge related to the subject to other farmers in that field, including the small-scale farmers who represent the livestock sector, thereby increasing the production capacity.”

title: Pakistani HC visits Ampara District
author: Author not found
Content: High Commissioner of Pakistan in Sri Lanka, Major General (Retd) Umar Farook Furkhi, visited the towns of Ampara District in response to an invitation from the Young Men’s Muslim Association (YMMA) and former Deputy Mayor of Kalmunai Municipal Council, Rahmath Munsoor. During his visit on 8 July, the High Commissioner participated in various welfare programmes that were well-attended by local residents. One of the highlights of the visit was the commissioning of several drinking water schemes. These projects were implemented with funding assistance from the High Commissioner, reflecting Pakistan’s commitment to supporting the well-being of the local community. In addition, the High Commissioner also distributed school equipment, sports equipment, and dry rations to individuals living below the poverty line. In the accompanying photo, High Commissioner Umar Farook Furkhi can be seen handing over a packet of sports equipment to a child, with Rahmath Munsoor looking on. The visit emphasised the strong ties of friendship and cooperation between Pakistan and the Ampara District, as well as the commitment to addressing the welfare needs of the local population.

title: Midwives want alternative nutrition package to replace Thriposha
author: Author not found
Content: The Government Midwifery Service Association has requested the government to initiate an alternative food package programme for children aged between six months and three years. This programme would be in place until the Sri Lanka Thriposha Limited is able to resume production of Thriposha, a nutritious supplementary food.  Devika Kodithuwakku, the Chairperson of the Association, emphasised the importance of Thriposha for pregnant women, lactating mothers, and undernourished children to improve their nutritional status in the country. “For about a year, there has been a halt in providing Thriposha to children, aged between six months and three years. The government should implement a programme that includes other nutritious foods, such as eggs, sprats and a variety of grains rich in nutrition. This will help support the growth of the children until Thriposha production is restored,” Kodithuwakku emphasised. She further explained that pregnant and breast-feeding mothers could incorporate the provided products into the daily meals of their children, which would help maintain their nutrition levels. BY Nabiya Vaffoor

title: SYU organiser calls for end to racism
author: Author not found
Content: National Organiser of the Socialist Youth Union (SYU) Eranga Gunasekara, has called for an end to racism and the unity of the nation. During a media briefing held on 7 June, Gunasekara emphasised the importance of defeating racism and promoting a sense of brotherhood among all citizens. Gunasekara highlighted the significance of July as a month marked by various historical events in Sri Lanka, including the tragic Black July incident, which occurred 40 years ago. He condemned the manipulation of racism by political leaders for their own narrow interests, resulting in divisions and destruction within the country. Addressing the current situation, Gunasekara expressed concern over certain groups attempting to sow chaos and create divisions within society, particularly during a time when the public is seeking unity. He criticised the ‘Ranil-Rajapaksa government’ for failing to address economic issues, leading to increased taxes, a rising cost of living, mounting debt, and shortages of essential supplies such as medicine and food. Gunasekara called for a change in governance to solve these problems and protect the well-being of the people. In light of these challenges, Gunasekara urged the public to stand together and defeat the conspiracy of division. He called for the establishment of a people-centric government that prioritises the rights and happiness of all citizens, fostering a harmonious and prosperous nation. Gunasekara’s message resonated with the need to build a united and beautiful country where every individual can enjoy their rights and live in peace. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.
