title: Group working to create a crisis in the country – Premitha
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of State for Defence, Premitha Bandara Tennakoon claimed yesterday (6) that intelligence services have uncovered that a group is working to create a crisis in the country and that they have received special training on how to confront the Army and the Police. Addressing a media briefing at the President’s Media Centre (PMC), the State Minister claimed that intelligence reports have specified that various groups supporting the programme aimed at undermining the country will initiate a wave of strikes. He alleged, “Members of these groups received special training on how to confront the Army and the Police during a protest held at a prominent hotel near the Hunnas Giri waterfall in the Elkaduwa area last week.” According to the Minister, the intelligence report indicates that practical and theoretical training was conducted to teach protesters on how to respond to the Army and Police during demonstrations, including handling tear gas and water cannon. He alleged that these groups are attempting to prevent the country from returning to normalcy after experiencing a major crisis. He assured that Intelligence units are continuously monitoring the activities of these groups. Despite claims that the intelligence sector has weakened and posed problems to the country’s national security, the Minister asserted that the intelligence sector remains solid. He also addressed the accusations faced by the intelligence services, in relation to the Easter Sunday terror attacks in 2019, claiming that despite receiving intelligence information about the attack, no action was taken. Meanwhile, Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella too, during a media briefing at the PMC last Sunday (2), alleged that reports have been received indicating the reformation of an organised group in the country. “Their objective is to contrive a plan to destabilise all sectors of the country through strikes in September. The first step in destabilising the country and reigniting a major crisis is to target the sensitive healthcare sector,” Rambukwella alleged. By Mithun Jayawardena and Sanjana Marzook

title: Laugfs reduces gas price
author: Author not found
Content: Following in the footsteps of Litro Gas Lanka, Laugfs Gas PLC yesterday (6), announced a significant reduction in the prices of its domestic gas. Accordingly, effective from today, Laugfs Gas has lowered the price of its 12.5 kg LPG cylinder by Rs 300, bringing it down to Rs 3,690. Additionally, the price of the 5 kg cylinder has been reduced by Rs 120 and is now available at Rs 1,476. Laugfs Gas Company stated that the decision to reduce prices was aimed at directly passing on the benefits of global market price drops to consumers. To obtain comprehensive information about the revised prices and district-wise pricing of gas cylinders, the general public can contact the Laugfs Gas hotline ‘1345’. In a similar move, Litro Gas Lanka had also substantially reduced the prices of its domestic gas cylinders this week. The revised prices announced by Litro Gas Lanka are 12.5 kg cylinder is Rs 2,982 (reduced by Rs204),  5 kg cylinder Rs 1,198 (reduced by Rs 83) and 2.3 kg cylinder is Rs 561 (reduced by Rs 37).

title: CBSL to take action against banks failing to reduce interest rates
author: Author not found
Content: The Central bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) yesterday (6) said actions will be taken against banks if they fail to pass down the benefits to their clientele, in line with the announced reduction in policy interest rates. The Monetary Board of the CBSL, at a meeting held on 5 July, decided to reduce the SDFR and the Standing Lending Facility Rate SLFR of the CBSL by 200 basis points to 11 per cent and 12 per cent, respectively. CBSL Governor Dr. Nandalal Weerasinghe said banks will be given a time to adjust the new interest rates according to their requirements. However, if they fail to do so, actions will be taken against such banks, he added. CBSL, in a statement said further relaxing the Facility Standing Deposit Rate (SDFR) and the Standing Lending Facility Rate (SLFR) the Monetary Board said that the banking sector is expected to pass down the benefits to the public immediately and that action would be taken if the progress was sluggish. CBSL said, that the Monetary Board arrived at this decision following a careful analysis of the current and expected developments, including the faster-than-envisaged disinflation process and benign inflation expectations in the domestic economy, with the aim of enabling the economy to reach its potential and stabilising inflation at mid-single digit levels in the medium term, while easing pressures in the financial markets. The Monetary Board expects that, with this reduction of policy interest rates by 200 bps, and the reduction of policy interest rates by 250 bps in early June 2023, along with the significant reduction of risk premia on government securities witnessed recently, the market interest rates, particularly lending rates, will adjust downwards adequately and swiftly. According to CBSL, the successive reduction in the policy interest rates will provide the impetus for market interest rates to adjust downwards in line with the faster moderation of inflation, so that monetary conditions remain accommodative. “The Monetary Board expects the banking and financial sector to pass on the benefits of the reduction of policy interest rates thus far and the reduction of interest rate risk premia to businesses and individuals without delay. “However, if the pass-through of such developments is deemed to be inadequate and sluggish, the Central Bank will consider taking appropriate administrative measures to ensure the timely and adequate pass-through of accommodative monetary policy,” CBSL said. (MA)

title: AHP concerned over death at Eye Hospital
author: Author not found
Content: Following a death of a patient who had undergone surgery at the National Eye Hospital, Colombo, suspicions have been raised whether the death resulted from some complications that occurred due to the anaesthetic drug given to her, before the surgery, the Association of Health Professionals (AHP) alleged. AHP President Ravi Kumudesh, who spoke to the media yesterday (6), alleged it should be probed whether the death was caused due to brand ‘Propofol’ an intravenous anaesthetic, which had been the particular brand which had allegedly led to the death of a child at the Sirimavo Bandaranaike Specialised Children’s Hospital, Peradeniya. However, the Health Ministry had taken urgent measures to clear the drug and negate the claims, Kumudesh stressed. The AHP President said, H.G. Himali Priyadarshini Weerasinghe, a 35-year-old mother of two, from Kosgoda Boralukatiya South, died following eye surgery at the National Eye Hospital, Colombo (NEH). The deceased had previously undergone surgical intervention to insert a lens in her eye at the NEH, Colombo, but due to an allergic reaction in the eye, which had been operated, she had been admitted to the hospital on the same day for a second surgery, which had been carried out on Wednesday (5). However, Himali had died following the surgery without even regaining conscious, he said.  Kumudesh noted that the relatives of the dead woman’s family suspected that she died due to the anaesthetic drug that had been administered to her. Despite being repeatedly told that the particular brand of Anaesthetic had caused the death of the child at Sirimavo Bandaranaike Children’s Hospital in Peradeniya, the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA) held a press conference and dismissed the claims publicly denying the allegations. The Health Minister even stated in the Parliament that the death was not a result of the particular brand of anaesthesia drug, he said. “We strongly believe that had the health authorities been sensitive and not haughtily waived off the complaints the second death could have been prevented,” he lamented. Furthermore, Kumudesh said the AHP would meet with the Bar Association of Sri Lanka (BASL) and inquire into possibilities of resolving the injustice of the current medicinal drug issue through public welfare litigation. Kumudesh said his outfit had arranged to forward all the related articles through email. “Since we do not have a thorough knowledge of the law, we hope to meet with the BASL and look into possibilities of seeking justice with regard to the poor quality drugs which had led to death and blindness in patients,” Kumudesh said.  He said his outfit had informed the , parallel to the request made to the President and the Minister of Health on 2 July, regarding the incident at Sirimavo Bandaranaike Children’s Hospital, Peradeniya. He urged the public, to seek assistance from the Sri Lanka Medical Council, the Director General Health Services or inform the nearest Police station whenever they had doubts, in order to work actively for an improved State health service. “There is no necessity to get alarmed by reports regarding the death of patients following surgery and treatment. The AHP has been repeatedly been calling for the immediate establishment of a specific committee or team to set up a specific mechanism to investigate harm caused by medicinal drugs and medical professional practices, to prevent the recurrence of this situation, Kumudesh said.  It is the responsibility of the Health Minister, his Ministry and the government to at least form a special committee for that purpose.  The health service has become a serious danger to the public as a result of it paving the way for the importation of low quality medicines, he added. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Probe into Mullaitivu ‘mass grave’ begins
author: Author not found
Content: The Mullaitivu Magistrate and the Police conducted a visit to the suspected mass grave site in the Kokkuthoduvai village, Mullaitivu yesterday (6). This visit marked the resumption of an investigation into the human skeletons discovered on 29 June 2023, during the digging of the ground to install a pipeline for a drinking water project. The area was tightly secured, preventing access to the public, as the Magistrate conducted an inquiry into the mass grave. When news of the detection of human skeletons broke on 29 June, villagers quickly gathered at the site. The excavation work was immediately halted and the matter was reported to the Magistrate’s Court by the Police. The Mullaitivu Magistrate yesterday (6), in the presence of a Judicial Medical Officer (JOM), Police, lawyers, officials from the forensic department, water supply board, department of archaeology, telecom, and the Ceylon Electricity Board, visited the area. The main road in the Mullaitivu-Jaffna Route was closed off for excavation, as the site was located by the Main Road. Several NGOs have recently raised concerns that approximately 20 identified mass graves have been left unattended. (Pix: BBC Tamil) By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: India’s largest travel agents group holds its 67th Convention in Colombo
author: Author not found
Content: The 67th Convention of the Travel Agents Association of India (TAAI), which began yesterday (6) in Colombo, will continue till Sunday (9). Over 600 visitors and experts from the tourism industry, primarily from India, are participating in the event.  TAAI convention is being held in Sri Lanka after an 18-year hiatus. The theme of the convention, ‘Transcending Borders’, aims to explore the evolving landscape of the tourism industry and emphasise the embrace of new adventures and destinations. The convention was inaugurated yesterday (6), at the Bandaranaike Memorial International Conference Hall, by President Ranil Wickremesinghe and Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawadanena. TAAI, the largest and oldest tourism agency in India, will showcase the theme of ‘Futuristic Focus on Transcending Borders’. The focus will be on highlighting Sri Lanka as a safe, convenient, and welcoming destination for Indian tourists. This collaboration is made possible by the Sri Lanka Tourism Promotion Bureau, the Sri Lanka Association of Inbound Tour Operators, and SriLankan Airlines. Indian High Commissioner to Sri Lanka, Gopal Bagley will deliver a welcome address to emphasise the significance of this prestigious event, fostering networking and knowledge sharing among participants from various countries. Notable industry experts attending the event are: Consulting CEO, FAITH Ashish Gupta, CEO Indigo Pieter Elbers, Country Director – India, IATA Amitabh Khosla, Co-Founder & Chief Commercial Officer, Akasa Air Praveen Iyer, Chief Commercial Officer, Amadeus India Rajeev Bhatia; Head of Global Sales, Indigo Vinay Malhotra, CEO, SriLankan Airlines Richard Nuttall, CEO and Director, CAPA India Kapil Kaul, Founder and CEO, Asego Insurance Founder & CEO – AsegoDev Karvat;  Managing Director, Snow Leopard Adventures Ajeet Bajaj,  G.B. Srithar, Regional Director, India, Middle East & South Asia, Singapore Tourism Board; Senior Vice President, JM Baxi & Co Commander Nevil Malao, COO – Passport, eVisa, Identity & Citizen Services, VFS Global Noel Swain, CEO – InterGlobe Technology Quotient Sandeep Dwivedi and many more. Dimuthu Thennakone, Head of International Sales and Distribution at SriLankan Airlines, expressed the airline’s goal to strengthen relations with India, focusing on leisure and MICE (Meetings, Incentives, Conferences, and Exhibitions) tourists. SriLankan Airlines plans to expand its flight operations to several other cities in India and is delighted to collaborate with the TAAI Association in further developing tourism activities between the two countries, he added. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Second Reading of Anti-Corruption Bill passed without vote
author: Author not found
Content: The Second Reading of the Anti-Corruption Bill was passed in Parliament yesterday (6), without holding a vote. The Committee Stage of the Bill was postponed until 19 July. Leader of the House, Susil Premajayantha, initially proposed the postponement of the vote on the Bill. This decision faced criticism from the Opposition and even Justice Minister Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe, questioned the rationale behind it. Rajapakshe said: “I have invested significant effort into preparing the Bill with amendments and I haven’t put in this much work just to have other legislation enacted. I fail to understand why the enactment of the Anti-Corruption Bill should be postponed.” Speaking before Rajapakshe, Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, Chief Opposition Whip Lakshman Kiriella, MPs Chandima Weerakkody, Dr. Rajitha Senaratne and Weerasumana Weerasinghe too, queried as to why the Committee Stage of the Bill was postponed. In response, Premajayantha assured that the Government does not have any intention to postpone the enactment of the Bill indefinitely. He proposed passing the second reading yesterday (6) and finalising the amendments on 19 July. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Nigerian given death sentence
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Namal Balalle yesterday (6) sentenced a Nigerian national to death, after convicting him on twin charges of possession and peddling of 250gm of cocaine. The Judge stated that he was handing down the death sentence on the accused, as the prosecution had proved its charges beyond all reasonable doubt. The Senior State Counsel, who prosecuted on behalf of the Attorney General, urged Judge Balalle to impose the maximum possible punishment on the accused, so as to deter others from turning Sri Lanka, into a safe haven for narcotic smuggling. He added that such a stringent punishment could give a clear message to illegal drug peddlers, that it is difficult to turn Sri Lanka into a paradise for illegal drug peddling and that those found guilty of such offences, will not be let off lightly. The convict had been nabbed in possession of the aforesaid quantity of cocaine by a Police Narcotic Bureau (PNB) team, led by Chief Inspector Tharaka Praboda, at a car park situated in Rajagiriya, on 27 May seven years ago. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Will Govt take action against Gota?– Sajith
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa yesterday (6) queried whether the Government would take action against former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa over the importation of inferior organic fertiliser. During parliamentary sittings, Premadasa raised his concerns to the Minister of Agriculture, highlighting that USD 6.9 million was spent on organic fertilisers imported from China, which amounts to Rs 1.38 billion. He stressed that the government has been unable to recover this sum, as compensation for the distribution of substandard fertilisers in that deal. Referring to an audit report, Premadasa said, the responsible individuals within the State and Cabinet Minister of Agriculture were negligent in their duties, resulting in the failure to retrieve the money. He said, the government must take immediate action or table the Auditor General’s report, which has reportedly concluded the investigation into the ‘Nano Nitrogen Fertiliser fraud’ as well. Premadasa also addressed concerns regarding the purchase of paddy, citing discrepancies in prices across different areas. He said, although the President had promised a guaranteed price of Rs 100 per kilo of paddy, the reality is different. Premadasa questioned the Minister of Agriculture about the measures that would be taken in the current season to address the issue. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: HC rejects Tharindu’s Petition
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Sujeewa Nissanka, yesterday rejected a petition submitted by journalist Tharindu Jayawardhana, who prayed the Court to invalidate an order issued to the CID, by the Colombo Fort Magistrate’s Court, to probe an alleged Contempt of Court charge, against him and a few others. The Judge said that the Petition concerned, had been submitted to him by a third party and explained that the Petitioner, has not been named as a suspect, in the on-going probe. Judge Nissanka also added that as per the law, the Magistrate’s Court has the authority to issue directives to the CID or the Police, to investigate whatever complaint that is lodged with it. Hence, he noted that as the Petitioner has neither been named as a suspect nor even been arrested in connection with the incident and as there was no legality to the Petition, he was dismissing it then and there. Jayawardhana filed the petition following the order of Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage, to the CID, probe whether Jayawardhana and several others had committed the offence of Contempt of Court during a press conference held after the arrest of comedian Nathasha Edirisooriya. Through the petition, Jayawardhana said, a Magistrate’s Court has no power to investigate Contempt of Court cases. Also, he said the said press conference was held in Maradana Police Division, which belongs to the Maligakanda Judicial Zone, hence the Colombo Fort Magistrate’s Court does not have the power to investigate the case. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Natasha gets bail
author: Author not found
Content: Nathasha Edirisooriya, who was arrested over her controversial remarks made during a stand-up comedy show about the childhood of Prince Siddhartha, was granted bail by the Colombo Fort Magistrate yesterday (6) on the charges filed under the Penal Code and the Computer Crimes Act. Allegations were filed under the Sections 120, 291(a) and (b) and the Section 6 of the Computer Crimes Act. On Wednesday (5), the Colombo High Court granted her bail for the allegations filed under the Section 3 of ICCPR Act. She had been remanded for 40 days. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Indian national remanded over killing
author: Author not found
Content: An Indian national, who was produced before the Colombo Fort Magistrate yesterday (6), over the death of another Indian national, was remanded until 14 July. According to the Police, the incident occurred at a restaurant located in Galle Face, Colombo, where an Indian national, who serves as the restaurant manager, has allegedly committed murder by attacking the head chef with a knife. The incident took place within the premises of the restaurant in the night of Wednesday (5). Further investigation by the Police has revealed that the victim, Ajay Kumar, was also an Indian national and held the position of head chef at the restaurant. The incident occurred following an argument between the suspect and the 29-year-old victim, which eventually escalated into a physical altercation.

title: House heats up over appointment of Sagara as Chair
author: Author not found
Content: A heated debate erupted in Parliament yesterday (6) over the appointment of SLPP MP Sagara Kariyawasam to chair the Parliamentary Select Committee (PSC) to probe the reasons for the economic crisis in Sri Lanka. Following Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena’s announcement about the appointment of the PSC, Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa along with Chief Opposition Whip Lakshman Kiriella, demanded that the chairmanship of the Select Committee be granted to the Opposition. MPs Pavithra Wanniarachchi, Prof. Ranjith Bandara, Eran Wickramaratne, Vijitha Herath, Major Pradeep Undugoda, Shanakiyan Rasamanickam, D.V. Chanaka, Mahindananda Aluthgmage, Jayantha Ketagoda, Harshana Rajakaruna, Sanjeewa Edirimanne, and Nalaka Bandara Kottegoda were announced as the PSC members. Premadasa and Kiriella alleged that the country’s insolvency was a direct result of the massive tax concessions, valued at Rs 700 billion, granted by the current government. Consequently, they deemed it inappropriate to appoint a member of the ruling party as the committee chair and requested the appointment of an Opposition MP instead. In response, Minister Bandula Gunawardena pointed out that several previous governments were also responsible for the economic crisis. He highlighted a legislation enacted years ago stipulating that the budget deficit should be reduced to five per cent of GDP and public debt should amount to 65 per cent of the GDP by 2006. “None of the governments in power during that period had fulfilled these requirements. Therefore, the current SLPP government should not bear sole responsibility for the economic crisis,” he said. Minister Ali Sabry further defended the ruling party, claiming that the previous Good-Governance Government, in 2015, mismanaged the economy and significantly decreased the economic growth, which stood at seven per cent. He emphasised that the SLPP government cannot be solely blamed for the crisis. Opposition MPs Weerasumana Weerasinghe and Mohomad Muzammil, who interjected, asserted that the composition of the Select Committee should reflect the new composition of the House Minister Kanchana Wijesekara said, when the PSC to probe the Easter Sunday terror attacks in 2019 was formed, the then government members, who are now in Opposition held posts in that PSC BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Existing laws enough to act against econ criminals
author: Author not found
Content: Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake yesterday (6) said, the existing laws are sufficient to take action against economic criminals and the failure to bring these criminals to justice was due to the prevailing culture of bad politics in the country, rather than flaws in the law itself. Speaking in Parliament, Dissanayake stated that laws such as the Public Property Act, Prevention of Money Laundering Act, Bribery or Corruption Act, and the Criminal Procedure Act provide ample provisions to prosecute individuals involved in economic crimes. The judicial system primarily targets ordinary citizens engaged in minor offenses, while those involved in serious offenses often escape punishment due to their political influence, he stressed. He pointed out an example where someone was apprehended for stealing coconuts, while a Police constable and a Grama Niladhari who accepted bribes were held accountable. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: First Peruvian photography and film festival in SL
author: Author not found
Content: On 30 June, the Honorary Consulate of Peru in Sri Lanka, in collaboration with Alliance Française of Kandy, proudly inaugurated a photography exhibition featuring the renowned Lines and Geoglyphs of Nazca and Palpa, one of the most well-known UNESCO World Heritage Sites in Peru.  On the same day, the First Peruvian Film Festival in Sri Lanka commenced, presenting six captivating films from 1 to 8 July. The inaugural ceremony was graced by the presence of the Ambassador of Peru to Sri Lanka, Javier Paulinich, Satya Rodrigo, Director General of the Latin America and Caribbean Division of the Sri Lankan Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Tikiri Kobbekaduwa, former Governor of the Sabaragamuwa Province, Sabry Abuthahir, President of the Executive Committee of Alliance Française of Kandy, and Romani de Silva, Honorary Consul of Peru in Sri Lanka. “The Nazca Lines have left an indelible mark on world culture, stirring the curiosity and imagination of archaeologists, historians, and art enthusiasts alike. These magnificent ancient works, depicting various geometric shapes, animals, and stylised figures, are believed to have been created between 500 BCE and 500 CE. Among the countless individuals who have dedicated themselves to understanding and preserving the Nazca Lines, Maria Reiche stands as a luminary figure. This German-Peruvian mathematician devoted her life to studying and safeguarding these enigmatic lines, unravelling their mysteries and ensuring their conservation for future generations,” said Ambassador Paulinich. Following the inauguration, the film festival kicked off with the screening of the movie Don’t Call Me Spinster, directed by Ana María Alva Helfer. Throughout the week, the festival will also feature films such as Deliciosa Fruta Seca by Ana Caridad Sánchez, Margarita by Frank Pérez-Garland, and Las Mejores Familias by Javier Fuentes León. Additionally, documentary films Peru’s City of Ghosts and Cities in the Clouds, produced by Paul M.M. Cooper, will be showcased. The Peruvian Photography Exhibition and Film Festival provide a unique opportunity for Sri Lankan audiences to immerse themselves in the vibrant cultural heritage of Peru. It celebrates the strong cultural ties between our two nations and showcases the rich diversity of Peruvian art and cinema.

title: Ibrahim further remanded
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Navaratne Marasinghe yesterday (6), fixed the Pre-Trial Conference of the case against millionaire businessman Mohamed Ibrahim and two other accused, to 22 September. Ibrahim is the father of 2019 Easter Sunday suicide cadres Insaf Ahmed and Ilhamm Ahmed, who blew themselves up at Shangri-La and Cinnamon Grand Hotels. When the case was taken up, Judge Marasinghe dismissed the bail application submitted to him, by the remanded third accused and remanded him till the next hearing. Three accused have been charged before the High Court, by the Attorney General, with failure to forewarn the Police over the impending suicide blasts, after they had been in possession of such information and over their failure to prevent the resultant loss of lives and for having flouted Provisions contained in Sections of the PTA and the Penal Code. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: BOC rolls out Fourth ‘Gammana’ Programme in Meegasthenna Village
author: Author not found
Content: Bank of Ceylon, Bankers to the Nation, recently commenced the fourth ‘BOC Gammana’ programme successfully in Meegasthenna village located in Dehiowita, Sabaragamuwa Province. The programme was implemented by the Consumer and Development Banking Division and the initiative aims to enhance financial literacy and livelihoods of the population residing in underprivileged rural outskirts of the country. Accordingly, BOC has structured a range of special programmes to reach these target groups and a number of programmes have already been implemented successfully. As a leading State-owned bank, BOC strongly believes that assistance in uplifting of living conditions of the rural population is a corporate social responsibility and accordingly, the Bank launched the ‘BOC Gammana’ programme as a landmark rural development initiative. The launch of the fourth BOC Gammana programme was held with the participation of Sabaragamuwa Provincial Deputy Chief Secretary Parakrama Piyasena, BOC’s Chairman Ronald C. Perera, General Manager Russel Fonseka, Deputy General Manager-Branch Operations Priyal De Silva other officials from the bank and residents of the area. In conjunction with the ‘BOC Gammana’ programme, BOC developed communal facilities and infrastructure of Meegasthenna village belonging to Yatiyanthota and Dehiowita Divisional Secretariats including repairing of a dilapidated road, rehabilitation of a dam that was damaged by landslides, renovation of the preschool and donating sports equipment and renovation of the Buddhist monastery in the area. Simultaneously, several key programmes such as enabling access to microfinancing facilities through BOC Mithuru Groups and distribution of plants for home gardens were also underway.  With the support of the bank, a fund has also been set up to finance the proposed building for the Meegasthenna College consisting of two classrooms for Advanced Level students. Moreover, the rural library along with BOC Ran Kekulu Sansadya was opened on the same day and in support of the school handball team, new jerseys were handed over. A blood donation campaign was also organised along with these activities during these days. In addition to supporting the rural agricultural sector, the main aim of the BOC ‘Gammana programme’ is to enhance financial literacy among the rural population, while expanding and popularising digital banking services even to the outskirts of cities. The ‘BOC Gammana’ programme was the first instance that a Sri Lankan Bank pioneered a national project of this nature. During the implementation of the programme, there has been a keen interest among the people in the programme with their active participation to make it a success. The bank takes humble pride in being able to inspire the villagers of Meegasthenna to work towards their future.

title: President felicitates four farmers, agricultural scientist
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe awarded gifts to the four farmers who recorded the highest paddy yield in the country in the 2022/23 Maha season and to the agricultural scientist who introduced the At 362 paddy variety to Sri Lanka that led to the highest paddy yield. The gifts were presented during the ‘Amaraviru Abhiman 32’ programme held at Magam Ruhunupura International Conference Hall to commemorate the 32nd year of the political career of Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera. Accordingly, in the last Maha season, four farmers from Ridiyagama, Ambalantota recorded the highest paddy yield per hectare. K.P.D.E. Jayasekara, Mala Paranamana, G. Abeysinghe and Janaka Nuwan Dissanayake were presented with gifts by the President. These four farmers harvested 10-11 metric tonnes of paddy per hectare. At present, the yield per hectare is 3 – 4.5 metric tonnes. This is the highest yield per hectare in Sri Lankan history. The Department of Agriculture has confirmed that all these farmers cultivated the At 362 variety of rice and used chemical fertilisers, organic fertilisers, as well as ash and straw for cultivation. Research Officer G.A. Jinadasa, who introduced the At 362 rice variety to Sri Lanka, was also felicitated by the President. Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena was also in attendance.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Existing laws enough to act against econ criminals
author: Author not found
Content: Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake yesterday (6) said, the existing laws are sufficient to take action against economic criminals and the failure to bring these criminals to justice was due to the prevailing culture of bad politics in the country, rather than flaws in the law itself. Speaking in Parliament, Dissanayake stated that laws such as the Public Property Act, Prevention of Money Laundering Act, Bribery or Corruption Act, and the Criminal Procedure Act provide ample provisions to prosecute individuals involved in economic crimes. The judicial system primarily targets ordinary citizens engaged in minor offenses, while those involved in serious offenses often escape punishment due to their political influence, he stressed. He pointed out an example where someone was apprehended for stealing coconuts, while a Police constable and a Grama Niladhari who accepted bribes were held accountable. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: First Peruvian photography and film festival in SL
author: Author not found
Content: On 30 June, the Honorary Consulate of Peru in Sri Lanka, in collaboration with Alliance Française of Kandy, proudly inaugurated a photography exhibition featuring the renowned Lines and Geoglyphs of Nazca and Palpa, one of the most well-known UNESCO World Heritage Sites in Peru.  On the same day, the First Peruvian Film Festival in Sri Lanka commenced, presenting six captivating films from 1 to 8 July. The inaugural ceremony was graced by the presence of the Ambassador of Peru to Sri Lanka, Javier Paulinich, Satya Rodrigo, Director General of the Latin America and Caribbean Division of the Sri Lankan Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Tikiri Kobbekaduwa, former Governor of the Sabaragamuwa Province, Sabry Abuthahir, President of the Executive Committee of Alliance Française of Kandy, and Romani de Silva, Honorary Consul of Peru in Sri Lanka. “The Nazca Lines have left an indelible mark on world culture, stirring the curiosity and imagination of archaeologists, historians, and art enthusiasts alike. These magnificent ancient works, depicting various geometric shapes, animals, and stylised figures, are believed to have been created between 500 BCE and 500 CE. Among the countless individuals who have dedicated themselves to understanding and preserving the Nazca Lines, Maria Reiche stands as a luminary figure. This German-Peruvian mathematician devoted her life to studying and safeguarding these enigmatic lines, unravelling their mysteries and ensuring their conservation for future generations,” said Ambassador Paulinich. Following the inauguration, the film festival kicked off with the screening of the movie Don’t Call Me Spinster, directed by Ana María Alva Helfer. Throughout the week, the festival will also feature films such as Deliciosa Fruta Seca by Ana Caridad Sánchez, Margarita by Frank Pérez-Garland, and Las Mejores Familias by Javier Fuentes León. Additionally, documentary films Peru’s City of Ghosts and Cities in the Clouds, produced by Paul M.M. Cooper, will be showcased. The Peruvian Photography Exhibition and Film Festival provide a unique opportunity for Sri Lankan audiences to immerse themselves in the vibrant cultural heritage of Peru. It celebrates the strong cultural ties between our two nations and showcases the rich diversity of Peruvian art and cinema.

title: TISL condemns Ketagoda’s Bill seeking reconvening of dissolved LG Bodies
author: Author not found
Content: Transparency International Sri Lanka (TISL) yesterday (6) condemned the private member’s Bill, presented to Parliament by SLPP MP Jayantha Ketagoda, to re-convene the dissolved Local Government (LG) bodies without holding elections. TISL, in a statement, alleged that the Bill is ‘anti-democratic’ and added that it believes that this move would be a heavy blow to the people’s sovereignty enshrined in the Constitution. “Local Government Members are the grass-roots level public representatives. Regular elections are essential for the people’s mandate to be reflected in the Local Government bodies. In addition, this Amendment sets a bad precedent as it creates a risk of abusing the legal framework to prevent holding timely elections, including national elections. This can lead to the people losing faith in the entire democratic system in the country, with negative implications to the rule of law as well. Therefore, TISL emphasises that any attempt to pass this Amendment must be roundly defeated. TISL calls on all citizens to stand up for their voting rights, by opposing this move,” the TISL stressed.

title: President’s DDR decisions safeguarded entire population – Wajira
author: Author not found
Content: UNP Chairman MP Wajira Abeywardena asserted on Tuesday (4) that President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s decisions regarding Domestic Debt Restructuring (DDR) have safeguarded the business community and the entire population of the country. President Wickremesinghe held constructive discussions with various donor groups in Paris, France and Great Britain, seeking their support to rescue the country from its financial crisis and achieve sustainable development goals. Addressing the media at Sirikotha, Abeywardena mentioned that many individuals have started to repay their debts as a result. Abeywardena expressed confidence that by the end of September, Sri Lanka can significantly address its financial challenges and uplift the people’s well-being. Furthermore, the World Bank has announced its readiness to provide a total of USD 700 million as part of its on-going assistance programme to Sri Lanka. According to Abeywardena, these positive outcomes have been made possible through the consultation and financial restructuring carried out with the assistance of renowned agencies like Lazard, aiming to make Sri Lanka a strong country. He highlighted that parliamentary approval was obtained, considering the future of over 22 million people in the country. Abeywardena stated that making deposits in banks can save approximately Rs 57 million, and restructuring the domestic debt can contribute 50% of income to the treasury while advancing the local economy. He also emphasised that President Wickremesinghe has taken necessary steps to protect depositors of private banks. MP Abeywardena expressed concern about the Opposition and certain factions’ attitude during the government’s efforts to secure parliamentary approval. Furthermore, he mentioned that Sri Lanka has improved its standing in the global corruption index, now ranked 101 out of 180 countries, demonstrating the country’s gradual progress towards becoming corruption-free. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Sirisena woos Jaffna politicians
author: Author not found
Content: Former President Maithripla Sirisena, during his recent visit to the Jaffna District, held talks with a few representatives of the Tamil political parties, including Leader of Illankai Tamil Arasu Kachchi (ITAK) Mavai Senathirajah. During these talks, the former Leader had sought the backing of Tamil political parties for the Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP) ahead of future elections. However, most of the political parties in the North had not directly informed Sirisena of their willingness to back the SLFP at future Polls. But, Senathirajah had conveyed to the former President that they will only support a party from the South that strives to implement a permanent political solution to North-East. BY Rasadi Chathurangi Gamage – Vavuniya

title: Separate area for breastfeeding at Jaffna bus stand
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda announced that a dedicated area has been designated for breastfeeding women at the Jaffna Bus Stand. This arrangement aims to provide convenience to the large number of passengers who are nursing mothers. Given the high volume of daily passengers at the bus stand, the existing facilities are comparatively limited. Devananda emphasised that positive steps will be taken to enhance the facilities for all passengers at the bus stand. Devananda has instructed the relevant officials to promptly address this matter and develop additional facilities. “As part of the proposed development plans for the Jaffna Bus Stand, a special area, exclusively for breastfeeding women, has been reserved. Other development plans will commence in the near future,” said Devananda. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Child abuse, rape account for 33% cases before MCs
author: Author not found
Content: In a startling revelation in Parliament yesterday (5), Minister of Justice Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe said a shocking 33 per cent of all cases, currently before the Magistrate’s Courts (MCs) in Sri Lanka, are related to child abuse and rape cases, serving as an immense source of national shame. According to the Minister, out of a total of 29,723 cases, a distressing 5,550 pertain to child abuse, while an alarming 4,312 are rape cases. The Minister stressed, “As Sri Lankans, we must confront this disheartening reality head-on and express genuine remorse for our collective failure. These abhorrent statistics not only tarnish our reputation, but also expose the disturbing aspects of our societal culture. Urgent and decisive action is imperative to combat these despicable acts.” Acknowledging the gravity of the situation, the Minister highlighted the implementation of stringent laws aimed at safeguarding the welfare of children. Over the past ten months, Parliament has enacted an impressive total of 25 laws in this regard. “Nevertheless, with cases of murder, attempted murder and dangerous drugs accounting for 6,661 of the overall caseload, constituting 22 per cent, it is evident that our challenges extend beyond child abuse and rape,” he added. “Furthermore, a staggering 55 per cent of the total cases, currently before the Magistrate’s Courts, involve child abuses, rape, murder, attempted murder, or dangerous drugs. These numbers paint a distressing picture of the widespread injustices plaguing our society,” he said. The Minister also drew attention to the immense backlog of cases within Sri Lanka’s judicial system, with a staggering 1,127,265 cases pending. It is deeply concerning that there are only 399 judges available, ranging from the Supreme Court to the Magistrate’s Courts, to address this overwhelming caseload, he pointed out. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Opposition groups engaged in fearmongering – Rangebandara
author: Author not found
Content: UNP General Secretary Palitha Rangebandara accused Opposition groups and trade union representatives of making false statements and baseless allegations without any ethical considerations. During a media briefing at Sirikotha, Rangebandara mentioned that when efforts were made to provide permanent land deeds to individuals after demarcation, some individuals misinterpreted it as an attempt to divide the country into separate North and South zones. He criticised these elements for creating a fictitious narrative, suggesting that visas would be required to travel between the South and North of the country. Rangebandara further stated that false propaganda was carried out against the Millennium Challenge Corporation (MCC) agreement, which led the people to work against the Government and ultimately topple it without understanding the truth and the benefits Sri Lanka could have gained from it. As a result, many people continue to live without land ownership. He also highlighted that similar propaganda was being spread against seeking assistance from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to rescue the country from its financial crisis. He alleged that certain factions criticised every effort made to improve the country’s economy with international support, only to change their stance when the international community started viewing Sri Lanka positively. He expressed concern that the Government’s actions are being criticised and allegations are being made, particularly targeting ordinary citizens. Rangebandara mentioned the protests against the ‘Aswesuma’ welfare programme, claiming that they misguide ordinary people who are unaware of the programmes truth and the benefits it offers. He added that President Ranil Wickremesinghe has advised District Secretaries nationwide to be cautious when selecting beneficiary families for the welfare programme, ensuring that all suitable families are included without marginalisation. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Literacy rate of Grade 3 students drops to 14%
author: Author not found
Content: An alarming decline in literacy rates among Grade 3 students is observed owing to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic, Minister of Education Susil Premajayantha said in Parliament yesterday (5). According to the Minister, a recent survey showed that the literacy rate among Grade 3 children had dropped to a worrisome14 per cent. He pointed out that the disruption caused by the pandemic was the primary reason behind this decline in educational standards. In addition, the minister highlighted a significant decrease in numeracy skills among children. Further, he raised concerns about the education system in the country, stating that approximately 4,000 schools were presently operating without principals. The minister shared that he had received a call from the Education Director of the Southern Province, who informed him about protests occurring in schools due to shortages of teachers and principals. Some individuals have filed petitions challenging the appointments, and these cases are still pending. Until the cases are resolved, the minister explained, they are unable to appoint principals and teachers. Interestingly, he mentioned that some Members of Parliament who are lawyers are representing the petitioners. In response to Premajayantha’s claim, MP Dayasiri Jayasekara said MPs have the right to represent anyone in their capacity as legal professionals. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Nathasha granted bail by High Court
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Adithya Patabendige, yesterday (5) enlarged on cash bail in Rs 100,000 stand-up comedian Nathasha Edirisooriya, who was arrested and remanded over her remarks during a stand-up comedy show in April. This was after a petition, filed on her behalf, was taken up before the Judge, last afternoon. Judge Patabendige, elaborating on his decision to grant bail to the accused, stated that the latter had informed Court that she was willing to seek public forgiveness from any group or section of society, over her remarks, if it had hurt them. The Judge said the accused had also conveyed to Court, that she was feeling highly remorseful over her remarks and that as the Attorney General, had also not expressed any objection to her being enlarged on bail, it was being granted. Accordingly, the Judge instructed the Court Registrar, to convey his decision on granting bail to the accused, to the relevant Magistrate’s Court. Judge Patabendige further stressed that it was rather questionable, whether the remarks attributed to have been made by the stand-up comedian, would have caused public riots here. He pointed out that the society too had been unaware of the incident, till the remarks made by the accused had been posted online and on various social media platforms. He observed that sufficient submissions had not been produced in Court, to suggest that Edirisooriya’s comments could have prompted violent incidents in the country. The Judge added that under such circumstances, the arrest of the accused has to be considered under Provisions contained in the Penal Code. He opined that it has also to be considered, whether just because any powerful individual in society lodges a complaint, a suspect could be apprehended willy-nilly, as per Provisions of the ICCPR. President’s Counsel Anuja Premaratne appeared on behalf of the accused comedian, while Senior Deputy Solicitor General (SDSG) Dileepa Peiris represented the Attorney General. However, when Edirisooriya, was produced before the Colombo Fort Magistrate’s Court earlier yesterday (5), she was ordered to be further remanded until 12 July. Edirisooriya had landed herself in hot water, over certain remarks she had made, comparing the childhood of Prince Siddhartha with the modern children, during her segment at a recent stand-up comedy show in Colombo. She was arrested by the CID on 28 May at the Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA) in Katunayake, while trying to fly out of the country. After being remanded for over a month by the Colombo Fort Magistrate’s Court, the suspect filed a bail application before the Colombo High Court and bail was granted yesterday. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Four remanded over staged shooting
author: Author not found
Content: The Colombo Additional Magistrate yesterday (5) remanded, till 19 July, four suspects, including a Director of a well-known company in Sri Lanka, who have been charged with firing several shots, with a T-56 rifle, at the entrance door of a house. The four suspects were identified as D. Gihan Rajapaksa, a Director of four firms coming under the purview of his Company, R.M. Cyril Ratnayake, a former SL Army soldier and a resident of Kirindiwela, K.P. Janaka Jayathileke, a resident of Nittambuwa and a private security officer assigned to the Director of the firm and Sashi Liyanage, a resident of Kirindiwela. As per an order issued by the Court, the four suspects had been detained for questioning by the Borella Police and upon them being produced in Court, they were remanded. Borella Police prosecuting told the Court, that the first suspect in the case, Gihan Rajapaksa had lodged a complaint, stating that an unidentified group had fired at the front door of his house on 26 June. They stated that following a detailed probe conducted into the incident, it had come to light that the second suspect in the case, the former soldier had fired at the front door of the house, according to a well laid out plan by the first suspect and that the other two suspects had aided and abetted it. Police said that the investigation had also shed light, on the fact that there had been a long- standing family feud related to the Company and that the first suspect, had hatched a plan to suggest that the firing on the house, had been the sinister work of other family members. They added that the first suspect had lodged a bogus complaint with the Police, claiming that the incident was the work of disgruntled family members. Police said they were also probing to determine, whether the suspects had been involved in any other crimes elsewhere and whether the firearm used for the firing, had been utilised for other crimes here. They urged the Court to remand the foursome, as the probe into the incident, has not been concluded. After considering the submissions produced by the prosecution and lawyers for the suspects, the Court ordered the suspects, to be remanded till the aforesaid date. By Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Speaker, Sajith lock horns
author: Author not found
Content: Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena yesterday (5) informed Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa that while the latter has the authority to summon State officials and seek clarifications on any matter at any time, he is not allowed to attend Committee Meetings and question officials. A heated verbal confrontation between the Speaker and the Opposition Leader sparked at the beginning of yesterday’s Parliamentary Sittings when the latter requested the Speaker to make his stance known on the Opposition Leader attending a meeting of the Committee on Public Finance (COPF) on 30 June. The Speaker deemed Premadasa’s presence at the COPF meeting inappropriate. In defence of his actions, Premadasa explained that he attended the COPF meeting to question relevant State officials about the impact of domestic debt restructuring on the Employees’ Provident Fund (EPF) and Employees’ Trust Fund (ETF). He expressed his frustration at not having the opportunity to question the officials directly and stated that he would summon all government officials from now on. Premadasa warned that if they failed to appear, it would be a violation of his privileges, holding the Speaker responsible for any such violations. Chief Opposition Whip, Lakshman Kiriella, claimed that the Opposition Leader attended the COPF meeting on a request from President Ranil Wickremesinghe to support the domestic debt restructuring process. Kiriella accused the Speaker of having a personal issue with the President, alleging that this was the reason behind his attempts to sabotage the President’s efforts. The Speaker denied these claims, asserting that he had no issue with the President. At this point, arguments escalated as some accused the Speaker of abruptly ending the debate on domestic debt restructuring. However, the Speaker clarified that he had sought the approval of the House to extend the session until the vote on the resolution, scheduled for 1 July, was completed. At this juncture, Chief Government Whip, Prasanna Ranatunga, pointed out that even six members of the ruling party had missed the opportunity to speak during the debate on the domestic debt restructuring programme. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Fried rice, kottu prices slashed by 10%
author: Author not found
Content: The All Island Canteen Owners’ Association (AICOA) has announced a 10 per cent reduction in the prices of fried rice and kottu, effective yesterday (5). During a media briefing, the association’s Chairman Asela Sampath said the price of a Rs 700 packet of kottu would decrease by Rs 70, while the price of a Rs 1,000 kottu would be reduced by Rs 100. This price adjustment follows Litro Gas Lanka’s announcement of its fourth consecutive price reduction this year. Previously priced at Rs 3,186, the 12.5 kg domestic gas cylinder now costs Rs. 2,982. The prices of the 5 kg and 2.3 kg cylinders have been reduced to Rs 1,198 and Rs 561, respectively. Meanwhile, Sampath strongly condemned the recent incident involving singer Saman de Silva, who was allegedly involved in a fight with restaurant staff. Sampath called on AICOA members to respond firmly if customers refuse to pay their bills. He emphasised that free meals should not be given to anyone, as restaurant and canteen owners work hard to prepare their food. He further criticised certain State officers, Police Officers, public health officers, consumer affairs officers, and politicians who often receive complimentary meals. He urged restaurant and canteen owners to impose the maximum penalty on individuals who fail to settle their bills after consuming meals. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Medicine shortage to end soon – Keheliya
author: Author not found
Content: Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella assured yesterday (5) that the problems faced by certain hospitals concerning the scarcity of pharmaceuticals and dialysis equipment for kidney patients will soon be addressed. Speaking in Parliament, the Minister acknowledged that these issues had arisen due to obstacles in the procurement process, including Court Orders causing further hindrances in some cases. In response to a question raised by MP Dayasiri Jayasekara, who highlighted the serious challenges faced by hospitals such as Kuliyapitiya and Galgamuwa due to shortages in dialysis equipment, the Minister concurred that kidney patients were indeed suffering and losing their lives as a result. He attributed the problem to an administrative matter within the Health Ministry, specifically pointing out difficulties in obtaining the necessary equipment through tender procedures. The Minister acknowledged the validity of the MP’s concerns and pledged prompt action to resolve the situation. “The issue will be addressed expeditiously as there is an inherent procedural problem in the procurement process,” he assured. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Reconvening dissolved LG bodies undemocratic – Sajith
author: Author not found
Content: The Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) cried foul in Parliament yesterday (5) over the recent Gazette Notification published on 26 June, regarding the reconvening of dissolved local government bodies. According to the Gazette, all dissolved Pradeshiya Sabhas, Urban Councils, and Municipal Councils can be reconvened by the Minister responsible for Local Government and Provincial Councils. The duration of reconvening would be determined at the discretion of the subject Minister, disregarding the previous 12-month extension due to the inability to hold elections for these bodies. The Municipal Councils Ordinance, Pradeshiya Sabha Act, and Urban Council Ordinance will be amended accordingly to facilitate the reconvening of these local bodies. Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa stressed that the reconvening of dissolved bodies was undemocratic. “This decision is made in response to the request of ‘kaputa’ and his ghost, and we will challenge it in Court,” Premadasa said. SJB MP Dr. Harsha de Silva, joining the Opposition Leader, questioned how Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena accepted the said gazette notification, claiming the move violated the Constitution. Intervening, MP Jayantha Ketagoda stressed the motives of the SJB are questionable. “I can’t understand what these people are saying. When it was called for the reconvening of the previous Parliament, which was dissolved in 2020 to address the prevailing Covid-19 pandemic, these people objected. What are they saying now? They know nothing about the context,” he said. Responding to the questions raised by the SJB, he said the Opposition is welcome to pursue legal action against the gazette. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Met Dept issues strong winds advisory
author: Author not found
Content: The Department of Meteorology issued a strong winds advisory, effective for 24 hours beginning 1:30 p.m. yesterday (5).  The department warned that during this period, strong winds of approximately 50-60 kmph can be anticipated intermittently in various regions. The western slopes of the Central hills, as well as the Northern, North-Western, and North-Central Provinces and the Hambantota and Trincomalee Districts, are expected to experience these strong winds due to the active South-West monsoon conditions. In the general weather forecast for today (6), the department stated that the prevailing heavy showers in the South-Western part of the island are likely to decrease from today (6). However, there will still be occasional showers in the Western, Sabaragamuwa, and Central Provinces, as well as in the Galle and Matara Districts. The North-Western Province may experience several episodes of showers as well. The Department of Meteorology added that strong winds of about 45-50 kmph can be expected at times in the western slopes of the central hills, the Northern and North-Central Provinces, and in the Puttalam, Hambantota, and Trincomalee Districts.

title: Muthu Raja won’t return to SL
author: Author not found
Content: It is out of question that Sak Surin (Muthu Raja), now the most famous elephant in Thailand, will return to Sri Lanka, as he is now under the patronage of the Thai King, Thailand’s Natural Resources and Environment Minister Varawut Silpa-archa said yesterday (5). Sak Surin, who arrived in Thailand on Sunday, quickly became familiar with his new environment, despite the fact that he had lived in Sri Lanka for 22 years. Commenting on a call from a senior monk in Sri Lanka for Bangkok to return the elephant once he fully recovers, Varawut said the matter is not even open for discussion. “Sak Surin is now under the patronage of the King, so that is out of the question,” Varawut said. Sak Surin is currently in quarantine for 30 days, at the elephant conservation centre in the Hang Chat District of Lampang Province. The elephant seems to be in a good mood, shaking his head and enjoying his food. After the quarantine period, vets will conduct more thorough checks on him. Initial examinations show that SakSurin is suffering from a cataract in the right eye, it cannot bend its front left leg, he has infected wounds on his hips and has problems with his nails and the soles of all four feet. Varawut also mentioned two other Thai elephants donated to Sri Lanka, Sri Narong and Pratupa, which remain there. He said it seems that Sri Lanka is capable of taking care of them and they are apparently in good health, although one of has suffered minor injuries. Some universities in Sri Lanka have contacted the Thai Ministry of Foreign Affairs to offer to take care of the Thai elephants, claiming they have the capabilities to do so.(Thai PBS)

title: Draft Bill to Labour Advisory Council today
author: Author not found
Content: The Labour and Foreign Employment Ministry yesterday (5) announced its submission of a Draft Bill for a modernised labour law system to the Labour Advisory Council today (6). This step comes after considering the valuable suggestions received during public consultation sessions, aiming to create a labour law framework that aligns with the demands of the contemporary employment landscape. Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment Manusha Nanayakkara will present this draft bill to the Labour Advisory Council. Before its public release, the minister had ensured that the draft bill for the establishment of an integrated labour law system would be shared with the Council, and he has delivered on that commitment. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Probe into deaths of four newborns at K’nochchi Hospital
author: Author not found
Content: An investigation has been launched into the deaths of four new-born babies within a week at the District General Hospital, Kilinochchi. The investigation was launched in response to a complaint filed by a family member of one of the deceased infants. Ceylon Today learns that the investigation would look into the possibility of medical staff negligence as well. BY Rasadi Chathurangi Gamage–Vavuniya

title: Opposition groups engaged in fearmongering – Rangebandara
author: Author not found
Content: UNP General Secretary Palitha Rangebandara accused Opposition groups and trade union representatives of making false statements and baseless allegations without any ethical considerations. During a media briefing at Sirikotha, Rangebandara mentioned that when efforts were made to provide permanent land deeds to individuals after demarcation, some individuals misinterpreted it as an attempt to divide the country into separate North and South zones. He criticised these elements for creating a fictitious narrative, suggesting that visas would be required to travel between the South and North of the country. Rangebandara further stated that false propaganda was carried out against the Millennium Challenge Corporation (MCC) agreement, which led the people to work against the Government and ultimately topple it without understanding the truth and the benefits Sri Lanka could have gained from it. As a result, many people continue to live without land ownership. He also highlighted that similar propaganda was being spread against seeking assistance from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to rescue the country from its financial crisis. He alleged that certain factions criticised every effort made to improve the country’s economy with international support, only to change their stance when the international community started viewing Sri Lanka positively. He expressed concern that the Government’s actions are being criticised and allegations are being made, particularly targeting ordinary citizens. Rangebandara mentioned the protests against the ‘Aswesuma’ welfare programme, claiming that they misguide ordinary people who are unaware of the programmes truth and the benefits it offers. He added that President Ranil Wickremesinghe has advised District Secretaries nationwide to be cautious when selecting beneficiary families for the welfare programme, ensuring that all suitable families are included without marginalisation. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Medicine shortage to end soon – Keheliya
author: Author not found
Content: Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella assured yesterday (5) that the problems faced by certain hospitals concerning the scarcity of pharmaceuticals and dialysis equipment for kidney patients will soon be addressed. Speaking in Parliament, the Minister acknowledged that these issues had arisen due to obstacles in the procurement process, including Court Orders causing further hindrances in some cases. In response to a question raised by MP Dayasiri Jayasekara, who highlighted the serious challenges faced by hospitals such as Kuliyapitiya and Galgamuwa due to shortages in dialysis equipment, the Minister concurred that kidney patients were indeed suffering and losing their lives as a result. He attributed the problem to an administrative matter within the Health Ministry, specifically pointing out difficulties in obtaining the necessary equipment through tender procedures. The Minister acknowledged the validity of the MP’s concerns and pledged prompt action to resolve the situation. “The issue will be addressed expeditiously as there is an inherent procedural problem in the procurement process,” he assured. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Ports Minister seeks Belgium’s help
author: Author not found
Content: A discussion between His Excellency the Ambassador of the Kingdom of Belgium to Sri Lanka Didier Vanderhasselt and Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva, took place yesterday (5) morning at the Ministry office. At the discussions, the Belgian Ambassador expressed consent to provide modern European technology required to develop Sri Lanka’s ports. In a formal appeal, the Minister requested Belgium’s support in the development of the Ports of Trincomalee and Galle, while also extending lucrative opportunities for Belgian investors to actively participate in these undertakings. Belgium plays a key role as a member in the International Maritime Organisation. Within Europe, the Antwerp Port of Belgium holds a significant position, ranking second only to the Rotterdam port in Europe. The Ambassador emphasized that the port’s annual throughput operations surpass 13.5 million TEUs. He also expressed consent to provide assistance to utilise European technology used by Belgium’s Antwerp Port for the operations at the Port of Colombo. The discussions also included possibilities to train local youth at the Belgium yacht boat yard in southern Sri Lanka aiming at employment and also to establish a yacht marina at the Port of Galle. Expressing further views the Minister said that discussions were taking place to plan on strengthening maritime development activities between Sri Lanka and Belgium and expressed gratitude to the Belgium Ambassador for all support and assistance extended to make such efforts a success. Consul of Belgium in Sri Lanka Koenraad Pringiers and Private Secretary to the Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Akila Gayan Kaushalya also attended the discussion.

title: St Anne’s Church Beruwala marks 125 years
author: Author not found
Content: The celebration marking the 125th anniversary of St. Anne’s Church in Polkotuwa, Beruwala  was held on Tuesday (3). Archbishop of Colombo, Malcolm Cardinal Ranjith participated in the event. Members of the China Fort Mosque Society, Alhaj Shihab (Joint Secretary of the mosque society), Alhaj Zawahir (Joint Treasurer of the mosque society), and Alhaj Ihsanudeen (mosque society member), participated as special invitees. During this event, a memorial plaque was presented to Cardinal Ranjith by the China Fort Mosque Society. (Photo credit: B.M. Mukthar – Beruwala)

title: Cooperation with SL instrumentalised through MoUs – Trinidad and Tobago Envoy
author: Author not found
Content: New High Commissioner of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago Dr. Roger Gopaul said recently signed Memoranda of Understanding with Sri Lanka would result in instrumentalising bilateral cooperation in several fields. When he called on Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena at the Temple Trees on 3 July, he said such formalising of ties would increase cooperation in many spheres such as trade, education, employment, tourism and investment. The High Commissioner, based in New Delhi, presented credentials to President Ranil Wickremesinghe on 30 June in Kandy. The Prime Minister discussed with the new High Commissioner about possibility of exchange of expertise in new areas such as gem and jewellery, sugar cane and other agricultural products. The Financial Intelligence Unit (FIU) of Trinidad and Tobago has signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with the Financial Intelligence Unit of Sri Lanka. The agreement allows the two countries to exchange information securely and enhance networking and co-operation with foreign FIUs in the fight against money launderers, financiers of terrorism and other criminal organisations.

title: The learning crisis and the way forward
author: Author not found
Content: Addressing the International Donor Agencies Workshop, held yesterday (5), Education Minister Susil Premajayantha spoke at length on the learning crisis and the way forward for Sri Lanka’s primary education sector. Following is the full speech. I like to thank the UNICEF Sri Lanka for taking initiative to organise this workshop of international donor agencies to discuss the way forward in primary education in Sri Lanka. As in many other countries, the Covid-9 period resulted in many serious problems in our school system, mainly the primary education section. This workshop will examine the issues involved and what priorities must be considered in charting the way forward. Children, who represent 30 per cent of Sri Lanka’s total population, are disproportionately impacted by humanitarian crises and require special care and attention. Children face the risk of separation from their families, or may not be able to access critical services such as health, nutrition, water, sanitation, education and protection. In areas with existing vulnerabilities such as poverty, young people are even more vulnerable to chronic malnutrition, food insecurity, child labour, trafficking and exploitation, and they may drop out of school at increased rates. Furthermore children and young people are now part of a generation that will have to deal with increasingly adverse, climate change-related events. UNICEF coordinates, strengthens and execute response plans in the face of such crises through early warning mechanisms, emergency operations and development planning in coordination with the Government of Sri Lanka and key ministries. While Sri Lanka has made significant progress in primary education, there are still some gaps and challenges that need to be addressed. Here are some key gaps in the primary education sector of Sri Lanka: Quality of Education: Despite high enrollment rates, ensuring quality education remains a challenge. There is a need to focus on improving teaching methodologies, instructional materials, and teacher training to enhance the overall quality of education in primary schools. Learning Outcomes: There is a need to closely monitor and address gaps in learning outcomes. While enrollment rates are high, ensuring that students acquire the necessary knowledge and skills at the primary level is crucial. Efforts should be made to improve learning outcomes, especially in areas such as literacy, numeracy, critical thinking, and problem-solving skills. Regional Disparities: There are regional disparities in access to quality education, with some areas, particularly in rural and remote regions, having limited educational resources and infrastructure. Addressing these disparities and ensuring equitable access to quality education across all regions of Sri Lanka is essential. Infrastructure and Facilities: Some primary schools in Sri Lanka face challenges related to inadequate infrastructure, lack of proper sanitation facilities, and insufficient learning resources. Investing in improving school infrastructure and providing necessary facilities can contribute to creating a conducive learning environment for students. Teacher Shortage and Quality: Ensuring an adequate number of qualified and motivated teachers is crucial for the success of primary education. Sri Lanka has faced challenges related to teacher shortages, particularly in rural areas. Recruitment, retention, and professional development of teachers are important areas that need attention to enhance the quality of education. Inclusive Education: Addressing the needs of students with disabilities and promoting inclusive education is another important area for improvement. Providing support services, specialised training for teachers, and accessible learning materials can help ensure that all children, including those with disabilities, have equal opportunities to access quality education. Parental Engagement: Enhancing parental engagement in primary education is essential for improving student outcomes. Encouraging parents’ active involvement in their children’s education, promoting parent-teacher collaboration, and providing resources and guidance to parents can positively impact student learning and overall educational outcomes. Early Childhood Education: Expanding access to quality early childhood education is crucial for setting a strong foundation for primary education. Focusing on the early years can help improve school readiness and better prepare children for primary education. Addressing these gaps requires concerted efforts from policymakers, educators, parents, and the community. It involves investing in infrastructure, improving teacher quality, curriculum development, and implementing effective monitoring and evaluation systems to ensure progress and bridge the gaps in the primary education sector of Sri Lanka. I am very pleased that you have taken a keen interest in understanding these issues and showing commitment to finding solutions to them. I am looking forward to working with you all. Thank You.
