title: Patients suffer due to the closure of Dickoya Base Hospital dental unit
author: Author not found
Content: The dental unit at the Dickoya Base Hospital has been closed for two months, causing severe inconvenience to the patients in the area. Patients claim that the dental unit at Dickoya Base Hospital was well-maintained. However, due to its closure over the past two months, they have had to pay a large sum of money to receive the same treatment in the private sector. They also claim that they are experiencing a lot of pain without receiving treatment because they do not have enough money to afford private dental clinics. The patients mentioned that the dental unit at Dickoya Base Hospital was the only dental facility available for patients in Bogawantalawa, Maskeliya, and Hatton. When inquired from Nissanka Wijewardena, the Director of Nuwara Eliya Regional Health Services, about the closure of the dental unit at the Dickoya Base Hospital, he said two doctors who worked in the dental unit had gone overseas. As a result, a dentist working at the Avissawella Primary Hospital was appointed to the Dickoya Base Hospital. However, that dentist has been transferred to the medical unit and the Director of Avissawella Base Hospital has not yet released the doctor. BY Neeta PathmaKumari – Norwood

title: Sinopec’s first fuel shipment expected end July – Kanchana
author: Author not found
Content: The first fuel shipment of China’s Sinopec, which signed a contract to enter the Sri Lankan fuel market, will arrive in the country at the end of this month, Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera said yesterday (4). The Minister, speaking to the media at the President’s Media Centre (PMC), said after the arrival of their ship in Sri Lanka, fuel distribution will be initially carried out under the CEYPETCO brand, until they set up their own fuel stations. “After the arrival of their ship in Sri Lanka, fuel distribution will be initially carried out under the name of CEYPETCO. However, future distribution will take place under their own company name,” Wijesekera said. Wijesekera revealed that the Ministry of Finance has imposed a tax of Rs 50 per litre of fuel supplied by the new companies and that revenue would be utilised to pay off the debts of Indian and Iranian fuel suppliers. The President’s Media Division (PMD) on 22 May announced that Sinopec signed a contract with Sri Lanka to enter the local fuel market. According to the contract which entitles them to a 20-year licence, the Chinese company will be granted permission to operate 150 fuel stations. The company will also be able to invest in 50 new fuel stations and it can start operations within 45 days of licence issuance, the PMD said. Meanwhile, in March, Cabinet approved Australia’s United Petroleum and US firm RM Parks in collaboration with Shell to enter the local fuel market. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Cannabis cultivation pilot project launch next month – Diana
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Tourism, Diana Gamage, announced that the pilot project for cannabis cultivation, within the Board of Investment (BOI) Zone in Katunayake, will be launched next month. She revealed that 11 investors have expressed interest in participating in the project. During a media briefing yesterday (4), Gamage claimed that this initiative has the potential to generate revenue of Rs 4 to 5 billion within the next two to three years. Gamage confidently said that the experts’ committee, appointed to study the matter, has given the green light for the project, in its report. She said, “We have received the go-ahead for the pilot project. There are approximately 11 investors who are keen on participating in the project. They will be responsible for growing the cannabis and manufacturing products derived from it, which will contribute to the country’s income.” Gamage asserted that she would not allow it to fail like previous ventures that were marred by conflicts among officials. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Banks will lose more than Rs 95B due to DDR – Gammanpila
author: Author not found
Content: Local banks will suffer a significant loss of over Rs 95 billion, due to Domestic Debt Restructuring (DDR), despite the Government’s claims to the contrary, Pivithuru Hela Urumaya (PHU) Leader MP Udaya Gammanpila said. During a media briefing yesterday (4), Gammanpila said their scrutiny of the Cabinet Memorandum on domestic debt optimisation, along with the Central Bank’s (CBSL) presentation to the Cabinet, revealed that the Government’s claims were false. According to the Cabinet Memorandum dated 28 June 2023, presented by the Minister of Finance, the outstanding value of Sri Lanka Development Bonds (SLDBs) is USD 886 million or Rs 272 billion. The CBSL presentation indicated a capital reduction, also known as a haircut, of 30 per cent on SLDBs, amounting to Rs 81.6 billion. Gammanpila highlighted that domestic banks hold 85 per cent of the SLDBs, resulting in a loss of Rs 69 billion due to the haircut. Additionally, a 30 per cent haircut is applicable to Foreign Currency Banking Unit (FCBU) loans, which amount to USD 323 million or Rs 92 billion. This translates to a loss of Rs 28 billion. Therefore, the alleged total loss from both SLDBs and FCBU loans amounts to Rs 97 billion, he claimed. Furthermore, Gammanpila stressed that there will be an approximate 35 per cent reduction in interest rates as part of the DDR. Although they have not calculated the specific loss associated with this interest rate reduction, he believes it will have an adverse impact on commercial banks’ liquidity and profitability during the DDR process, Gammanpila added. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: SJB rejects President’s olive branch
author: Author not found
Content: The Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) yesterday (4) rejected President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s invitation to collaborate with his administration, and instead demanded the immediate dissolution of Parliament. During a media briefing, SJB MP Nalin Bandara stressed that dissolving Parliament and facilitating an election would be a favour to both the party and the country, allowing them to govern with a newly-elected SJB government. Bandara said, “The entire country agrees that the present 225 members in Parliament lack a mandate. We also view this as a violation of the mandate. Wickremesinghe needs the SJB to remain as President. He is a shrewd politician. He is only offering us assistance to achieve his own objectives.” Bandara further demanded that President Wickremesinghe terminate what he referred to as his “deal” with the ruling Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna and dissolve Parliament. President Wickremesinghe on Monday (3) reiterated his previous invitation to the SJB, led by Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, urging them to prioritise the national interest over politics and join efforts to resolve public issues. Wickremesinghe suggested that the SJB could remain in the Opposition and support his Administration’s recovery and reform agenda through the parliamentary committee system. He also expressed disappointment with the SJB for what he implied was a politically motivated attack on Sri Lanka’s domestic debt restructuring plan. In response to the President’s statement, Bandara stressed, “If you genuinely want to assist us, dissolve Parliament immediately. That would be a favour to us and the country. Then you can continue to govern with a new team for a while longer.” He also mentioned that the SJB would consider Wickremesinghe’s offer to “help him” once Parliament has been dissolved, noting that the President has had the legal authority to dissolve Parliament since March 2023. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Medical community demands SPC Chair’s removal
author: Author not found
Content: The Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA), lodging a complaint with the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) called for the removal of the Chairman of the State Pharmaceutical Corporation (SPC), for allegedly participating in procurement procedures, to import medicinal drugs from blacklisted companies at a higher price. MCPA President Dr. Chamal Sanjeewa yesterday (4) said the SPC should pay attention to all these matters and remove its Chairman while initiating an investigation against him. He called for an investigation against the Chairman of the SPC for continuing to hold the position even after being found guilty by the Committee on Public Enterprises (COPE). Dr. Sanjeewa claimed that the State health service has been the subject of discussion following the appointment of a person, who the Public Accounts Committee held unfit to hold such an esteemed post in the public service, after the incumbent President came to power. The Civil Activists accused the incumbent Health Minister and Health Secretary of being responsible for the greatest collapse of the health system in the history of Sri Lanka, while calling for their immediate removal followed by the system’s urgent   reorganisation. The MCPA in collaboration with other the civil organisations, including the National Anti-Corruption Movement (NACM) lodged the complaint. Leader of the NACM Jamuni Kamanta lamented that it was most unfortunate that the political machinery of the country was maintaining a very lax attitude regarding the misuse of the taxpayers’ money through continuous corruption and irregularities in the government and semi government services. If emergency drug purchasingis required, it should be done in a transparent manner, subject to the recommendations of the expert committee and not based on the needs of the Health Minister or the Secretary’s Additional Secretaries, he lashed out noting that this continuous emergency purchasing of medicinal drugs by the Health Ministry was a colossal problem. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: CEB, CPC restructuring to go ahead
author: Author not found
Content: Although the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) and the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) are on the path towards financial stabilisation, the plans to restructure both entities will not be halted, Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera said yesterday (4). Addressing a media briefing at the President’s Media Centre (PMC), the Minister said, granting salary increments and bonuses to the employees of these two entities has been suspended as it is not possible to provide such perks at the loss-making entities. “As a result, a 25 per cent salary increase every three years for the 24,000 employees of the CEB has been discontinued. Salary increments are allocated exclusively to employees who are actively working and demonstrate productivity. It is a common practice worldwide to provide salary increments selectively rather than uniformly across an organisation. Similarly, bonuses distributed in April and December are contingent upon the entities’ profitability and are awarded solely to employees who contribute effectively,” he said. “The CPC has successfully repaid all loans owed to the Bank of Ceylon and the People’s Bank, resulting in its strengthened financial position. Despite this, the restructuring process of the CPC will continue as planned. The revised draft for the restructuring of the CEB has been forwarded to the Legal Draftsman, and once received from there it will be submitted to the Attorney General and subsequently presented to the Cabinet for further recommendations.” Meanwhile, Wijesekera said he would submit a Cabinet paper next week to cancel the tenders given to the investors who have not implemented Renewable Energy projects according to the conditions mentioned in the tenders. He said some investors who have been granted the tenders are now saying they cannot implement the projects according to the present costs. It has also been found that some of the companies that were awarded tenders have sold them to other entities. Thus, the tender call for 500 megawatts of renewable energy is expected to be cancelled in the upcoming Cabinet meeting, and a fresh tender call will be issued, he said. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Jaffna residents facing malaria risk
author: Author not found
Content: Jaffna residents are at an increased risk of contracting malaria, according to the Malaria and Epidemic Unit of the Jaffna Teaching Hospital. Two new cases of Malaria have recently been discovered in Jaffna, in addition to the previously reported five cases. The Jaffna Hospital states that the previous cases of Malaria were caused by the Anopheles Palciparum, while the current cases are attributed to the Anopheles Stephensi. Although the World Health Organisation (WHO) has issued a certificate stating that Malaria has been eradicated from Sri Lanka, the Malaria and Epidemic Unit of the Jaffna Teaching Hospital emphasises that the threat of Malaria in Sri Lanka has not been completely eliminated. This is due to Sri Lankans travelling to countries in Africa and other regions where malaria is still prevalent. BY Rasadhi Chathurangi Gamage – Vavuniya

title: Strong winds damage 31 houses
author: Author not found
Content: Strong winds experienced in the Ratnapura, Nuwara-Eliya and Kandy Districts yesterday (4) damaged 31 houses, impacting 32 families comprising 133 people, the Disaster Management Centre (DMC) said. The DMC added that in the three days to yesterday, heavy, rains, landslides and strong winds experienced in the Ratnapura, Nuwara-Eliya, Kandy and Trincomalee Districts damaged a total of 41 houses, affecting a total of 44 families comprising 188 people. Seemingly, paradoxically, it was hardly a month ago, dry weather conditions caused a water shortage that impacted 2,746 families comprising 8,979 people living in the Trincomalee and Ratnapura Districts, the DMC added. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Rajagiriya Filling Station sealed
author: Author not found
Content: The licence granted to the Rajagiriya Filling Station, Sri Jayewardenepura Kotte has been suspended over its failure to maintain necessary stocks during the recent fuel price revision, Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera said. Speaking at a media briefing at the President’s Media Centre (PMC) yesterday (4), the Minister revealed that complaints have been received regarding 120 filling stations that did not comply with stock maintenance requirements during fuel price revisions. He said legal action will be instituted against those fuel stations as well. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Tourist arrivals increase by 51.90% to 624,874
author: Author not found
Content: Tourist arrivals in the first six months of the year (2023) increased by 51.90 per cent (213,497) year-on-year (YoY) to 624,874, Sri Lanka Tourism Development Authority (SLTDA) statistics from yesterday (4) showed. The figure in the first six months of last year (2022) was 411,377. However, when compared with Sri Lanka’s best year for tourism thus far, 2018, tourist arrivals in the first six months of the year have fallen by 46.35 per cent (539,773). Tourist arrivals in the first six months of 2018 numbered 1,164,647. Meanwhile, tourist arrivals last month (June 2023) alone increased by 205.5 per cent (67,532) to 100,388. However, compared with June 2018, tourism numbers have fallen by 31.63 per cent (46,440). The comparative June 2018 tourist arrival figure was 146,828 and total tourist arrivals in June 2022 numbered 32,856. However, tourism earnings in the first five months of this year were short by USD 1.1 billion compared to the first five months of 2018 which year thus far was the best year for tourism, official data further showed. Further, according to latest SLTDA figures, tourism earnings at USD 827.8 million in the first five months of this year is equivalent to 72.85 per cent of total tourism earnings last year which was USD 1,136.3 million and arrivals at 624,874 in the first six months of this year is equivalent to 86.79 per cent of total arrivals last year which was 719,978. However, the best year for tourism thus far was in 2018 when Sri Lanka enjoyed a total of 2.33 million arrivals raking in USD 4.38 billion in earnings for the country. In the first six months of 2018 Sri Lanka entertained a total of 1,164,647 visitors whilst raking in a total of USD 2,159.9 million (USD 2.16 billion) by way of tourism earnings during that period. Meanwhile, tourism earnings of USD 827.8 million in the first five months of this year according to the latest available data is short of USD 1,059.8 million (USD 1.1 billion) compared to the tourism earnings of USD 1,887.6 million made in the same period last year. Tourism earnings of USD 827.8 million made in the first five months of this year is equivalent to only 43.85 per cent of total tourism earnings made in the same period in 2018. Tourism was Sri Lanka’s fifth largest FX earner last year, behind garments, remittances, IT and IT-enabled services exports and tea in that descending order, respectively, according to the latest Central Bank of Sri Lanka and Export Development Board data. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: GMOF alleges Keheliya bribed officials, TU leaders
author: Author not found
Content: The Government Medical Officers’ Forum (GMOF) accused Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella of allegedly bribing the officials and certain trade union leaders to conceal the truth regarding the low quality medicinal drugs that were being purchased. GMOF President, Dr. Rukshan Bellana yesterday (4) said, “We know that the medicines that are purchased allegedly do not meet the standards and that there have been incidences of deaths that have been caused as a result. But there is a question as to whether the Health Minister wants to conceal this truth by giving various bribes to his officials and trade unionists. Besides violating policy decisions taken during the 2023 Budget to extend the retirement age of Consultants and other medical practitioners, there are notable incidents that show the Minister’s efforts to bribe Health Ministry officials and trade unionists.” Certain health officials including the Director General of Health Services who has travelled abroad six times was given permission to travel overseas for the seventh time even though trade unions and other professional categories brought this to Minister Rambukwella’s attention.  “There are major objections against high-level health officials travelling overseas regularly even when the trips are offered to other categories in the State health services, the most recent being the DGHS’s tour to Geneva. When it should have been a Community Physician and public health officers who accompanied him on the tour the opportunity was given to the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA). It is because of these public health officers and community specialists that Sri Lanka could boast of her quality of health,” he said. Dr. Bellana alleged that the most competent person for the position had been overlooked while awarding the CEO post of the NMRA. “The present CEO who is another political appointee allegedly uses the Health Minister’s name while soliciting bribes. He is referred to as Mr. 10% in the Health service,” the GMOF President alleged.  “Minister Rambukwella exempted a trade union leader amongst members of the minor employees from carrying out his duties for the 14th consecutive year so that he could allegedly engage in trade union work in a bid to keep them happy while overlooking the corruption that was taking place,” Dr. Bellana charged, noting that according to experts even Maithripala Sirisena, who was a predecessor of Minister Rambukwella did not degrade the State health service to this extent. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Banks will lose more than Rs 95B due to DDR – Gammanpila
author: Author not found
Content: Local banks will suffer a significant loss of over Rs 95 billion, due to Domestic Debt Restructuring (DDR), despite the Government’s claims to the contrary, Pivithuru Hela Urumaya (PHU) Leader MP Udaya Gammanpila said. During a media briefing yesterday (4), Gammanpila said their scrutiny of the Cabinet Memorandum on domestic debt optimisation, along with the Central Bank’s (CBSL) presentation to the Cabinet, revealed that the Government’s claims were false. According to the Cabinet Memorandum dated 28 June 2023, presented by the Minister of Finance, the outstanding value of Sri Lanka Development Bonds (SLDBs) is USD 886 million or Rs 272 billion. The CBSL presentation indicated a capital reduction, also known as a haircut, of 30 per cent on SLDBs, amounting to Rs 81.6 billion. Gammanpila highlighted that domestic banks hold 85 per cent of the SLDBs, resulting in a loss of Rs 69 billion due to the haircut. Additionally, a 30 per cent haircut is applicable to Foreign Currency Banking Unit (FCBU) loans, which amount to USD 323 million or Rs 92 billion. This translates to a loss of Rs 28 billion. Therefore, the alleged total loss from both SLDBs and FCBU loans amounts to Rs 97 billion, he claimed. Furthermore, Gammanpila stressed that there will be an approximate 35 per cent reduction in interest rates as part of the DDR. Although they have not calculated the specific loss associated with this interest rate reduction, he believes it will have an adverse impact on commercial banks’ liquidity and profitability during the DDR process, Gammanpila added. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: SJB rejects President’s olive branch
author: Author not found
Content: The Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) yesterday (4) rejected President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s invitation to collaborate with his administration, and instead demanded the immediate dissolution of Parliament. During a media briefing, SJB MP Nalin Bandara stressed that dissolving Parliament and facilitating an election would be a favour to both the party and the country, allowing them to govern with a newly-elected SJB government. Bandara said, “The entire country agrees that the present 225 members in Parliament lack a mandate. We also view this as a violation of the mandate. Wickremesinghe needs the SJB to remain as President. He is a shrewd politician. He is only offering us assistance to achieve his own objectives.” Bandara further demanded that President Wickremesinghe terminate what he referred to as his “deal” with the ruling Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna and dissolve Parliament. President Wickremesinghe on Monday (3) reiterated his previous invitation to the SJB, led by Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, urging them to prioritise the national interest over politics and join efforts to resolve public issues. Wickremesinghe suggested that the SJB could remain in the Opposition and support his Administration’s recovery and reform agenda through the parliamentary committee system. He also expressed disappointment with the SJB for what he implied was a politically motivated attack on Sri Lanka’s domestic debt restructuring plan. In response to the President’s statement, Bandara stressed, “If you genuinely want to assist us, dissolve Parliament immediately. That would be a favour to us and the country. Then you can continue to govern with a new team for a while longer.” He also mentioned that the SJB would consider Wickremesinghe’s offer to “help him” once Parliament has been dissolved, noting that the President has had the legal authority to dissolve Parliament since March 2023. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Nabbed dumping garbage in reserve area
author: Author not found
Content: In a recent incident, residents of the Wewelhinna village, in Badulla, caught a group of individuals involved in the transportation and disposal of garbage to a reserve area. The incident took place on 2 July. According to reports, the villagers have been noticing a recurring issue of garbage being dumped in this particular reserve, which is a crucial water catchment area. Being vigilant on the matter, the villagers were able to catch the culprits red-handed during their illegal activities. Upon intervention, the villagers handed over both the suspects and the lorry used for transporting the garbage, to the Police. Subsequently, the Police have arrested the lorry driver, who has now been released on bail. The lorry remains in Police custody, and a case will be filed against the driver. The Badulla Police have initiated further investigations into the incident. BY Jayalath Dissanayake – Badulla

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Navy arrests suspect with 1,947 kg Kendu leaves
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Navy arrested a suspect  with 1,947kg of smuggled Kendu leaves, during a special operation conducted in Karative beach area in Puttalam on Sunday (2) morning. The Navy often conducts patrols and search operations in coastal and sea areas surrounding the island, to ward off the influx of contraband through sea routes. As a result of these efforts, SLNS Vijaya belonging to the North-Western Naval Command made this arrest, during a special operation conducted in Karative beach area this morning. Accordingly, the suspect who had smuggled 65 packages of Kendu leaves weighing 1,947kg was nabbed at the beach by the Navy.   The suspect held in this operation is a resident of Karative, Puttalam, aged 50. The accused along with Kendu leaves was handed over to the Kalpitiya Police for onward legal action.

title: Jaffna District records 1, 843 dengue cases from 1 January
author: Author not found
Content: A total of 1,843 individuals had been diagnosed with dengue in the Jaffna District since 1 January this year, Deputy Director General of Northern Province Health Services, Dr.T. Sathyamoorthy revealed. He emphasised that this number reflects the cases reported within the past six months, with only one reported death. However, that victim was not a resident of Jaffna District, but was from the Southern Province.  During a press conference held yesterday (4),   he pointed out the breakdown of dengue cases by district was: 1,491 in Jaffna, 65 in Kilinochchi, 77 in Mannar, 106 in Vavuniya, and 104 in Mullaitivu. Notably, the Nallur and Karaveddy areas of Jaffna City are particularly at risk of the spread of dengue. Dr. Sathyamoorthy also highlighted the high prevalence of dengue in the Gampaha District. To combat the spread of the disease, it is crucial to eliminate the mosquitoes that transmit dengue as these mosquitoes breed in various locations and contribute to the spread of the disease. Given the significant impact of dengue in the Jaffna District, the public’s cooperation in maintaining a clean environment is essential to prevent dengue infections.  He requested the public for their full support to avoid dengue pandemic. “Keep the environment clean and give full cooperation,” he said. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan and Naalir Jamaldeen

title: List of Welfare eligible released
author: Author not found
Content: The Welfare Benefits Board (WBB) released the list of individuals eligible for welfare benefits, specifically targeting the disabled, elderly, and sick individuals yesterday (4). The relevant list has been displayed at select Divisional Secretariats and Grama Niladhari offices in various parts of the island. Starting from today (5) the list will be made available at all respective offices across the country. Furthermore, the approved lists from both the Social Empowerment and Welfare Ministry and the Health Ministry have been incorporated into the ‘Aswesuma’ welfare benefit scheme without any modifications.  Additionally, the usual allowances for differently-able individuals, the elderly, and kidney patients will continue to be provided.

title: China ‘not comfortable’– Ali Sabry
author: Author not found
Content: The Government yesterday (3) said the Chinese are “not comfortable” getting on to the common platform, where other creditors, such as the Paris Club, India and Japan are, on debt restructuring for Sri Lanka. Instead, China is engaging in bilateral negotiations with the Sri Lankan Government, ‘separately’. “They will not come on board on the common platform but will corporate bilaterally. We are confident China will support the restructuring of the debt in that manner,” Foreign Minister Ali Sbary said yesterday (3). At the press conference held by Minister Sabry, at the President’s Media Centre (PMC), he emphasised that both governments are actively involved in negotiations, bilaterally and on the common platform, where China was present and knows all the parameters of these negotiations with other creditors as well. China’s bilateral is three folds, which are with the Chinese Government, the second is of the Exim Bank and the third is the Chinese Development Bank. He added that the good thing is that China knows the parameters of the discussions held with other creditors, as they are present at all the discussions and it would be comparable treatment on the bilateral basis at the end of the day. He said “China has its own reason why it does not want to be on the common platform. That is fine with us as long as they come to us and give the same relief what we want,” he pointed out. Sabry stressed that he met top Chinese investors and the president of the Exim Bank and the China Development Bank. He also told the media that the CHEC Developers of the Port City expressed their keen interest in investing of USD 1.2billion in a project at the Port City and Sinopec has agreed to invest in an oil refinery project in Hambantota. President Ranil Wickremesinghe earlier said that the CHEC wanted to construct an International Financial centre at the Port City.  When asked about China, the largest creditor, not joining the common platform with other creditors, the minister explained that China is currently engaged in continuous discussions with Sri Lanka. These discussions are taking place through two separate lines of communication. One line involves negotiations within the common platform, while the other is a bilateral approach. The minister emphasised that Sri Lanka wants to avoid becoming entangled in China’s multilateral dealings, as there are fundamental differences in their approach. The main concern for Sri Lanka is focused solely on restructuring its debt and finding a mutually beneficial solution. He assured that China would not receive separate treatment in the debt restructuring process. According to the deal made with the IMF in March, all countries were expected to provide assurance and cooperate with the debt restructuring efforts initiated by the IMF. The President of Sri Lanka personally wrote to all countries, emphasising that they would be treated equally and comparably, without any difference in the treatment received. He further stated that the process is transparent, ensuring fairness and accountability. These considerations form the basis for the preparation of the debt sustainability analysis, he said, adding that it is within this context that the assessments have been made. He said countries that have undergone debt restructuring programmes have experienced a subsequent default after making 60 per cent of their payments. Sri Lanka’s goal is to ensure that any defaults, which occurred last year, are ultimately eliminated. By prioritising timely repayment, the aim is to prevent any further defaults in the future. In response to concerns about potential rupee depreciation when  debt repayments begin, he emphasised that the government’s reforms are aimed at achieving steadfast and sustainable progress. “By attracting investments, promoting tourism, and increasing remittance through exports, they believe they can effectively manage the debt crisis. The focus is on implementing measures that will stimulate economic growth and create a favourable environment for both domestic and foreign investments, thus mitigating the risk of currency depreciation.” The Foreign Minister also noted that Sri Lanka’s export has decreased from 31 per cent to 14.5 per cent and the government is to establish a one stop shop for investors. “Then we think of digitisation of the country. Then we got to focus on renewable energy to reduce the expenditure on oil purchasing.  If we can promote tourism and bring more investors to port city we can gain from those income,” he said. “We are planning on export oriented manufacturing economy we are focusing on and working on a roadmap,” he added. The debt analysis takes into account various factors, including projected outflows and inflows over the next 10 years, revenue estimates and payment obligations, according to Minister Sabry. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Interest-free student loan application process starts today
author: Author not found
Content: The application process for the Interest-free Loan Scheme, for students who want to pursue higher education after the GCE Advanced Level  commences today (4) and will continue until 7 August, State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said. Addressing the media, Siyambalapitiya said this interest-free loan scheme is specifically designed for 5,000 students. In case of any competition for eligibility, the free-student loan scheme may take into consideration the Z-score. Students who have taken the GCE Advanced Level examination in 2019, 2020, and 2021 are eligible to apply for this loan, intended for their higher education at private universities, he said. The State Minister also said that the government will cover the interest on the loan for the 5,000 students enrolled in job-oriented courses. By Sanjana Marzook

title: Litro 12.5kg cylinder of gas to cost under Rs 3000
author: Author not found
Content: Litro Gas Lanka, in an official statement yesterday (3), said a reduction in the price of  a 12.5 kg cylinder of domestic gas will come into effect from midnight today (4). The Chairman of Litro Gas Lanka confirmed that the price of the 12.5 kg domestic cylinder will now be under Rs 3,000 after the implementation of this price reduction. This marks the fourth consecutive price reduction initiated by Litro Gas Lanka. Notably, in June, Litro Gas had previously announced a reduction of over Rs 300 for a 12.5 kg gas cylinder. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Tilvin says President acts arbitrarily
author: Author not found
Content: JVP General Secretary Tilvin Silva accused President Ranil Wickremesinghe of acting arbitrarily and postponing the elections, allowing politicians to make decisions that should be made by the people. Silva, addressing the media, also criticised the Gazette that enables the subject minister to recall dissolved Local Government entities and extend the current tenure. The Minister of Local Government has been granted the authority to recall disbanded local government bodies through a gazette notification, he said. “According to the gazette notification, issued on 27 June if the extended term of local government bodies exceeds the stipulated period, the responsible minister has the power to reconvene them for an additional period. As a result, it becomes possible to reconvene the dissolved local government bodies. If these bodies have already announced an election but are unable to proceed due to a crisis situation in the country, this gazette notification allows for the recall of the local government bodies. The Minister has been granted the power to convene them. “This amendment has been introduced as section 2 (c) in the Municipal Council Act of 1987,” Silva said. Referring to this gazette, Silva accused Wickremesinghe of attempting to consolidate power, disregard the Constitution and engage in dictatorial practices, adding that it is important to defeat these attempts and hold those responsible accountable. “This kind of political greed and practice should not exist in our country or be allowed to consolidate power. Ranil Wickremesinghe is trying to set aside the Constitution, intimidate officials and assume a dictatorial role. Sri Lanka has violated IMF conditions 13 times. We have the responsibility to defeat their attempts to maintain their previous power through cunning tactics,” he stressed. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: Bills brought in haste are ineffective – Sajith
author: Author not found
Content: Saying that traditional and indigenous medicine practices in Sri Lanka should be protected, Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, referring to the newly published Ayurvedic (Amendment) Bill, was of the view that hastily introduced Bills are ineffective. The Bill, which has sparked controversy among the traditional and indigenous medicine practitioners, was gazetted on 12 June. Premadasa who met a group of traditional medical practitioners at the Opposition Leader’s office in Colombo yesterday (3), discussed various issues related to Ayurvedic, traditional and indigenous medicine. Premadasa emphasised the importance of preserving both indigenous and traditional medicine fields. He criticised the current government for potentially jeopardising the traditional medicine sector in the country through the new Bill. While acknowledging the need for a legal framework for the Ayurvedic medicine sector, Premadasa argued that such a framework should be developed in accordance with the principles of Ayurvedic medicine and traditional medicine, catering to the needs of both fields. Premadasa further suggested that instead of hastily introducing such Bills, it would be more beneficial for the parties involved, including the Minister of Health, to engage in formal discussions and gain a comprehensive understanding of the situation. BY Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Dengue takes 31 lives this year
author: Author not found
Content: Dengue has claimed 31 lives so far this year, the National Dengue Control Unit (NDCU) said adding that by the beginning of July, the total number of cases recorded Island wide was nearly 50,000. Accordingly, the total dengue cases since January is 49,759.  The NDCU said that a total 439 cases had been recorded from Saturday (1) till yesterday (3) morning. Statistics issued by the ‘Densys Surveillance’ showed that a total 24,837 (49.9%) patients were from the Western Province, while the Central, Northern and Sabaragamuwa Provinces have a total 4,065 (8.1%), 4,564 (9.1%) and 3,876 (7.7%) dengue cases from the beginning of the year till date. Meanwhile, health authorities have declared 61 MOH Divisions across the country as high-risk areas for dengue. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Former PUCSL Chair says he was finally proved right about CEB data
author: Author not found
Content: Former chairman of the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) Janaka Ratnayake said it has been proven that he was correct when he pointed out that the CEB data was wrong, as today the CEB has admitted to it and finally revised the power tariff. Ratnayake stressed that the reduction of the current electricity tariffs proves that the increase in electricity tariffs in February 2023 was based on wrong data as he had pointed out. Ratnayake recalled that some of the data presented by the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB), for tariff revisions, were incorrect and a proper investigation will prove it. “Last February, the Ceylon Electricity Board proposed to increase the tariffs by 66 per cent. But at that time, the actual cost data revealed that a 30 per cent tariff increase was sufficient. Therefore, I opposed the 66 per cent tariff revision. We should have limited the rate increase to 30 per cent at that time, in order to protect five million electricity consumers as well as minimise the negative impact on the economy. But due to political pressure, three members of the Commission approved the proposal presented by the CEB as it was. He added that now, they themselves have admitted that the CEB data is wrong, which is why the CEB has decided to reduce the electricity tariffs by 14 per cent instead of the proposed reduction of three per cent. “Because I was against the increase in fees, a vote was held in the parliament and I was removed from my position.” He said he is happy to give up the post of chairman to someone else as everyone has accepted his argument. “I commend the new chairman and members of the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka. Because the steps I took then, to protect the independence of the Commission, are being continued today by them. The Commission should be appreciated on the steps taken to protect the rights of all electricity consumers.”Rathnayake also pointed out that energy poverty has increased due to the increase in unfair tariffs implemented in February. “Nearly 0.5 million electricity consumers have reduced their electricity consumption to zero. When they get an unaffordable electricity bill, their response was to reduce consumption. Special attention should be paid to this customer group. Justice has been done to some extent in this year’s tariff revision. The annual amount of electricity generated by hydropower is nearly 5000 gigawatt hours. A unit costs less than five rupees. Nearly five million low consumption domestic consumers consume less than 2000 gigawatt hours of electricity annually. The annual electricity consumption of 45,000 religious places is about 90 gigawatt hours. So, all these people can be supplied with electricity at a very low price. Also, a reasonable fee can be given to small and medium enterprises as well.” Rathnayake further emphasised that he is committed to protecting the rights of not only electricity consumers but also all consumers who are suffering due to various injustices. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: President invites Opposition to join Government
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe invited the Opposition, led by Sajith Premadasa, to join the Government to address the country’s challenges, instead of making misleading arguments. President Wickremesinghe extended this invitation at the Amarawiru Abhiman 32’ ceremony, which honoured Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera on his 32- year political career. He pointed out that the opposition’s allegations, regarding the restructuring of local debt, have been proven false. The President encouraged the Opposition to participate in the next presidential election and contribute to rebuilding the country by fulfilling their responsibilities to the people. He also expressed his willingness to assign additional duties to the Opposition in consultation with the Speaker, if necessary. During the event, the President received a special commemorative edition of ‘Amaraviru Abhiman 32’ and presented commemorative gifts to farmers, agriculture supporters, and students who achieved academic success in the Hambantota District. “In continuation, as Prime Minister of President Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s government, I announced our intention to move forward with the participation of all members. In 2022, President Gotabaya Rajapaksa invited all Parliamentary party leaders to the President’s Office. Unfortunately, the Samagi Jana Balawegaya(SJB) and Janata Vimukthi Peramuna(JVP) boycotted the meeting. During that time, I, along with R. Sampanthan and MaithripalaSirisena, discussed how to resolve this issue. Despite our efforts to bring everyone together, after the incident on 9 May 2022, the SJB did not join us, even though they were offered the opportunity to participate without assuming the post of Prime Minister. Consequently, our government was formed, and we began our duties. I was appointed President, Dinesh Gunawardena became the Prime Minister and Mahinda Amaraweera was entrusted with the responsibility of the Agriculture Minister. Despite the challenges faced by the agriculture sector, Amaraweera’s leadership has allowed us to make significant progress,” he said.

title: Musician compensates complainants
author: Author not found
Content: The employees of a restaurant in Panadura, who were reportedly assaulted by singer Saman de Silva on 1 June, have been compensated with Rs 25,000, after agreeing to withdraw the complaint, Panadura South Police said yesterday (3). The Police said that after receiving the money, the complainants informed the Police that there was no need to investigate the complaint further. After that both parties were warned and sent away. It was reported that the singer had gone to the particular restaurant with a set of friends to eat, but had assaulted the cashier and a waiter due to a conflict which arose while settling the bill. They had also damaged two chairs. Saman de Silva, who commented on the incident, said this was not an incident as reported by the media and the two parties had reached an agreement after he gave the complainants Rs.25,000. BY Sumith Ranawaka – Pothupitiya

title: Police find dead elephant
author: Author not found
Content: Mahakalugolla Police on 2 July discovered the carcass of a wild elephant in a meadow at Newgala, which is in the jurisdiction of the Mahakalugolla Police Division. This male elephant measures approximately 7 ½ feet in height and is estimated to be between 20 and 25 years old. Upon receiving a notification of the elephant’s death, the Damana Wildlife Office dispatched a team of officials, to the scene. A post-mortem examination was scheduled to take place yesterday (3) to determine the cause of death. Following the post-mortem examination, the Damana Wildlife Office will be able to ascertain the cause of death. Mahakalugolla Police are conducting investigations. BY Nandun Gunathilake – Bibile

title: Protest against rogue finance company
author: Author not found
Content: A group of people held a protest in front of a private financial institute on Sunday (2), alleging that the institute had defrauded persons who invested nearly Rs 270 million and the owner of the finance company had closed the business and left the area with the money. Protesters alleged that around five hundred persons from Galenbindunuwewa had entrusted their hard-earned money to this institution. However, the company failed to fulfil its agreements to repay the deposited money and interest. Depositors claimed that the owner had shut down the finance institution approximately eight months ago and cheated customers by vanishing with their funds. They warned that if no responsible institution made contact and addressed the issue to help reimburse their money by 18 July they would stage a strong protest in front of the Galenbindunuwewa Divisional Secretariat. BY Chinthaka Chrishantha Balasooriya – Galenbindunuwewa

title: Five drown within 48 hours
author: Author not found
Content: Within the past 48 hours, up to 8.00 a.m. yesterday (4), five fatal drowning incidents had been reported from different locations in Sri Lanka. On Saturday (1) evening, a 21-year-old woman went missing and was presumed drowned while bathing in the Attanagalle Oya in Nittambuwa. According to the Police, she was with a group of relatives visiting a relative’s house when the incident occurred. A search operation is underway to locate the missing woman. In another incident, a 42-year-old resident of Negombo lost his life while bathing in the Deduru Oya, in Chillaw on Sunday (2) evening. He was reported missing after drowning while participating in a leisure trip with a group. The Police and Navy conducted a search operation, leading to the discovery of his body. Two individuals, aged 21 and 66 years, drowned while bathing in the Eththalaya Sea in Aalankuda, Norochcholai on Sunday (2) evening. They were part of a group, including relatives, who were on a leisure trip to the area. The bodies of these two individuals were taken to the Puttalam Hospital. Additionally, a 29-year-old youth drowned while bathing in the Pasikuda Sea in Kalkuda, Batticaloa on Saturday (1). The Police said that the youth, who was part of a leisure trip group, had been swimming beyond the designated safety area in the sea. The deceased’s body was taken to the Valachchenai Hospital. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: DMT CG proposes concessional revenue licences for old vehicles
author: Author not found
Content: Commissioner General (CG) of the Department of Motor Traffic (DMT), Nishantha Anuruddha Weerasinghe, has announced a proposal to provide concessional revenue licences for old vehicles that have been parked and unused for an extended period, without obtaining the necessary licence. According to Weerasinghe, a significant number of vehicles have remained unused due to the hefty fines associated with re-registration. As a result, the proposal aims to offer relief to vehicle owners seeking to renew their registrations. The Commissioner General also mentioned that the proposal will be submitted to the Cabinet for approval.

title: Wildlife guards demand arrest of attackers
author: Author not found
Content: The All-Island Wildlife Guard Officers’ Union has issued a warning to the authorities, stating that if the Police fail to apprehend the main culprits responsible for attacking wildlife officers at the Udawalawa National Park during a recent operation, they will initiate trade union action without further notice. In a letter dated 2 July, addressed to the Director General of the Wildlife Conservation Department, General Secretary of the All-Island Wildlife Guard Officers’ Union, M.R.D. Wijeratna, outlined the necessary course of action. The letter also mentioned that during the said operation conducted by wildlife officers at Udawalawa National Park, in the area of Habaraluwewa, Sevanagala on 30 June, two tranquiliser guns, two rifle barrels, a quantity of buffalo meat, a buffalo head, confiscated goods and gunpowder belonging to the criminals was seized. The trade union stressed the importance of arresting the suspects involved in the incident, irrespective of their rank and bringing them to justice, over assaulting investigating officers at Sevanagala. By Sisira Peelladeniya – Pallebedda

title: CMLSSL warn of collective decision before September
author: Author not found
Content: The College of Medical Laboratory Science of Sri Lanka (CMLSSL) warned that they would be pushed into a collective decision with the remaining services in the State health sector, even before September, depending when the Health Minister decides to submit the Cabinet paper regarding the retirement age of consultants and other medical practitioners. “Even before submitting the Cabinet memorandum, the Health Minister seems to know that there would be strike in September 2023, one which even we have not contemplated,” CMLSSL President Ravi Kumudesh said yesterday (3). Kumudesh lambasted Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwellafor pushing the health service into further quandary.  “The Health Ministry does not hold itself responsible for the Health Ministry while the government too does not hold itself responsible for the Health Ministry. When this is the situation it is apparent that there would be no one to take responsibility for patients, which is why the health service unions have not struck work despite having ample reasons to do so till now,” said. He warned that the remaining health service trade unions would take up the cudgel if the Health Ministry took action only to extend the date of retirement of only the medical practitioners, while forcing the others into retirement by the age of 60.  “Already the medical practitioners are engaged in work not related to the medical profession. Therefore the CMLSSL and other health professional categories would not tolerate the Health Minister’s efforts to violate the government’s policy of retirement to extend the date of retirement only for consultants and other medical practitioners,” Kumudesh said. Either the Minister take measures to include all State health service employees in the Cabinet paper or allow it to remain as it is, he added.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Substandard Eye Drops Blacklisted – Keheliya
author: Author not found
Content: Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella yesterday (2) said the Indian company, from which the eye drops that caused loss of vision following eye surgery at Nuwara Eliya District General Hospital were imported, has been blacklisted. Speaking at a media briefing, Rambukwella said the patients who developed complications will be granted compensation as well. The Minister said after the reports of complications, the remaining batch of eye drop stock was returned and the company was blacklisted. According to the minister, the conditions of two patients are still critical and the other eight persons have recovered. Ten patients who underwent cataract surgery at the District General Hospital, Nuwara Eliya a few months ago had experienced vision impairments owing to a ‘Prednisolone’ eye drop used post-surgery. It is alleged that the particular drug had been purchased from India using the money received under the Indian Credit Line. Systematic investigations on this had been conducted by Eye surgeons and the Health Ministry following prescribed methods, to find out whether there was a germ in medicine that was used post-surgery. He said the same germ had been reported in patients who had developed vision problems at the National Eye Hospital Colombo. After the incident came to light, President Ranil Wickremesinghe also ordered a probe. By Mithun Jayawardena

title: Litro announces price drop
author: Author not found
Content: Litro Gas Lanka, one of the leading suppliers of domestic Liquefied Petroleum (LP) gas in the country, will once again revise the prices of its domestic LP gas cylinders on 4 July. There will be a decrease in the prices of LP gas cylinders this time as well. This upcoming adjustment will mark the fourth consecutive price reduction of LP gas in recent times. In the previous price revision, the cost of a 12.5 kg cylinder was reduced by Rs 452 to Rs 3,186, while the 5 kg cylinder saw a reduction of Rs 181 to Rs 1,281, and the 2.3 kg cylinder decreased by Rs 83 to Rs 598. Laugfs Gas Company also hinted at a possible future price revision; however, no official announcement has been made regarding this matter so far.  (MD)

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: 5th CCC of Army leaves for UN Peacekeeping in Mali
author: Author not found
Content: One more contingent of well-trained and meticulously-prepared Army personnel from the 5th Combat Convoy Company (CCC), designed to serve in the United Nations (UN) Multidimensional Integrated Stabilisation Mission in Mali (MINUSMA), left for Mali on Saturday (1) evening as the first segment of 170 troops, out of the full contingent of 243 set to leave in stages. Major General G.R.R.P. Jayawardana RWP RSP ndu, Colonel of the Regiment, Sri Lanka Sinha Regiment (SLSR) and Quarter Master General (QMG) at the Army HQ was at the BIA departure terminal to see them off. Extending best wishes to the Mali-bound first group of 20 Officers and 150 Other Ranks, Major Genera Jayawardana and Senior Officers shared a few thoughts with Colonel W.W.N.P. Wickramarachchi of the Sri Lanka Sinha Regiment, Commanding Officer of the contingent, Major A.D. Bandaranayake of the Sri Lanka Armoured Corps, Second-in-Command of the CCC and other members of the contingent. The 5th CCC comprises Officers and Other Ranks of the Sri Lanka Sinha Regiment (SLSR), Sri Lanka Armoured Corps (SLAC), Sri Lanka Engineers (SLE), Sri Lanka Signal Corps (SLSC), Mechanised Infantry Regiment (MIR), Corps of Engineer Services (CES), Sri Lanka Army Service Corps (SLASC), Sri Lanka Army Medical Corps (SLAMC), Sri Lanka Army Ordnance Corps (SLAOC), Sri Lanka Electrical and Mechanical Engineers (SLEME), Sri Lanka Corps of Military Police (SLCMP), Sri Lanka Army General Service Corps (SLAGSC) and Sri Lanka National Guard (SLNG). The majority of the contingent is made up of SLSR troops. Adding memories, the group thereafter posed for a photograph with Senior Officers, present at the airport. The remainder of the contingent will leave for Mali on 29 August.  Brigadier K.L.S.S. Liyanagama RWP RSP, Director, Directorate of Movement, Brigadier C.S. Thibbotuge, SLSR Centre Commandant, Senior Officers, Other Ranks and family members of the contingent were at the airport to bid goodbye to them. Earlier, a Guard of Honour parade, held at the SLSR Regimental HQ grounds, saluted the Army Commander, Lieutenant General Vikum Liyanage RWP RSP ndu.

title: Prison Guard’s attackers had inside help
author: Author not found
Content: Startling revelations have emerged from the investigations into the recent assault on a prison guard, at the Magazine New Remand Prison in Colombo. It has been found that the attackers received assistance from another prison officer. The Police Homicide and Organised Crimes Division has disclosed that the assault was captured on video and sent to a notorious underworld gang member known as ‘Handaya’,  who is currently residing abroad. In a significant development, two individuals, including a Captain of the Sri Lanka Army, were apprehended in Nuwara Eliya.  The authorities discovered a cache of weapons in their possession, including a T-56 firearm, two Browning pistols and 167 rounds of ammunition. Interrogations of the suspects revealed that the attack had been orchestrated at the behest of the underworld figure ‘Handaya’. Furthermore, the assailants obtained details about the targeted guard’s private residence from another prisons officer. Subsequently, on 30 June, three additional individuals, believed to be involved in the incident, along with the van used in the attack, were taken into Police custody. The investigation is ongoing, with law enforcement agencies working diligently to unravel the complexities surrounding the case. The incident occurred on 12 May when Sankha Kusal Marasinghe, a prison guard, at the Magazine New Remand Prison, was ambushed by three unidentified assailants at his private residence in Minuwangoda. The perpetrators forcibly entered the guard’s home, compelling him to kneel on the floor before subjecting him to a vicious assault, accompanied by menacing threats to his life. According to the guard’s statement to the Police, the attackers attempted to restrain him using zip-ties but resorted to brandishing a firearm, placing it against his head as a dire warning against interfering with heroin trafficking operations within the prison. The assailants, aware of the potential consequences, cautioned the guard against reporting the incident to the authorities, promising dire consequences if he failed to comply. Shockingly, one of the attackers recorded the entire assault on video. Following the traumatic ordeal, the prison guard filed a complaint with the Minuwangoda Police, after which he was admitted to the Minuwangoda Hospital. Subsequently, he was transferred to the Gampaha Hospital. Marasinghe had gained recognition for his successful raids within the prison, receiving an award for seizing the highest number of contraband items in the Magazine New Remand Prison during the 2018/2019 period. Authorities suspect that his relentless efforts to curb illicit activities behind bars may have served as the motive for the attack.

title: Inland Revenue Act to be modified to align with DDO strategy
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya announced that the Inland Revenue Act and the Appropriation Act will be modified to align with the Domestic Debt Optimisation (DDO) strategy. He made this statement during a media briefing in Ruwanwella, discussing the next steps following the parliamentary approval of the DDR strategy, the previous evening. Siyambalapitiya emphasised that the decisions reached by the Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) on the DDO strategy will be published in newspapers and through other media outlets. Additionally, an invitation will be extended to all retirement funds, involved in the programme, for discussions and consideration of their alternative views, if any. The State Minister highlighted the need for amendments to the Inland Revenue Act and the Appropriation Act to accommodate the DDO strategy. He also mentioned that the President has been granted powers to safeguard the interests of the people, particularly in protecting the funds of pensioners. The DDO was passed in Parliament with amendments on 1 July, with 122 votes in favour and 62 against, securing a majority of 60 votes. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: ‘Muthu Raja’ touches down in Thailand
author: Author not found
Content: The ailing tusker ‘Muthu Raja’ was airlifted to Thailand on a special charter flight which left BIA last morning (2). The jumbo is expected to receive treatment from Thai veterinary surgeons in Chiang Mai. The elephant arrived in Thailand just after 2:00 p.m. (0800 GMT). “He arrived in Chiang Mai perfectly,” Thai Environment Minister Varawut Silpa-archa said at the airport. “He travelled five hours and nothing is wrong, his condition is normal,” he added. Thai officials said the repatriation of the 4,000 kg mammal cost USD 700,000. The Ilyushin IL-76 cargo aircraft carrying Muthu Raja took off around 7:40 a.m., the Airport Duty Manager said. The elephant will be quarantined at a nature reserve on arrival in Chiang Mai. Veterinarians had prepared to airlift the Asian elephant from Sri Lanka back to its home country of Thailand over the weekend after it spent more than two decades at a Buddhist temple. The Thai Royal Family gifted the elephant to the Sri Lankan Government in 2001, which in turn gifted it to the Kande Viharaya Temple where it was named ‘Muthu Raja’ and given honoured roles in religious processions. However, the animal rights group Rally for Animal Rights and Environment (RARE), claimed it was being mistreated, and that it had a stiff leg from a long-neglected injury. It lobbied last year for the intervention of Thai officials, who asked Kande Viharaya Temple officials to allow the jumbo’s return to Thailand for medical treatment. The temple agreed to transfer the elephant last November to the National Zoological Garden – Dehiwala, where it received treatment and was prepared for the journey to Thailand. According to reports, two big abscesses on the elephant had mostly healed. However, the zoo has not been able to fully treat the animal’s leg due to a lack of facilities. Visit Arsaithamkul, Chief Vet of the Zoological Park Organization of Thailand said the treatment in Chiang Mai could include hydrotherapy, laser treatment and acupuncture. At the zoo, Muthu Raja’s morning routine had included veterinarian check-ups, bathing in a small pond and practising getting into the air freight container. The container is cushioned and has windows for feeding, which will include a diet of bananas, pumpkin and sugar cane. Zoo officials had hoisted the 9-foot, 4-ton creature in trial lifts to test the container’s strength. Muthu Raja, also known back in its birthplace as Sak Surin, will be sedated if needed, and two vets will monitor him during the journey, reliable sources said.  Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena told Parliament last month that he expressed his regret to the Thai Premier over the treatment of the elephant during his trip to Thailand in May. By Adnan Ali Cassim

title: Street library in ruins
author: Author not found
Content: A street library, gifted by Pakistan to Sri Lanka, as a symbol of cultural exchange and literacy promotion, has fallen into disrepair. The street library, designed to encourage a sense of community and foster a love for reading, now stands as a dilapidated structure, with visibly damaged walls and a collection of worn-out books. The street library was opened in January 2022, opposite Royal College, Colombo in the parking lot of the race course.  The concept of the street library revolves around the idea of ‘take a book, leave a book’, allowing visitors to borrow books and contribute by donating their own. However, without proper upkeep, the library has lost its appeal and has become inaccessible for readers. BY Shabeer Mohamed

title: 81 Persons hospitalised following wasp attacks
author: Author not found
Content: At least 81 persons have been admitted to Teaching Hospital Kandy and Bogawantalawa Hospital following wasp attacks on Saturday (1 July). A wasp attack during a trekking excursion in the Hanthana Mountain Range has resulted in the hospitalisation of at least 42 university students. The incident was reported to the Police on Saturday afternoon (1 July). Among those injured, 15 are female students, while 27 are male students. Prompt action was taken by the Police and Army personnel, who immediately arranged for their admission to the Kandy Teaching Hospital using the 1990 ‘Suwa Seriya’ ambulance service, alongside assistance from residents. The remaining students were safely transported back to their destination using the same buses they had arrived in, according to Police. The group of students involved in the mountain climb consisted of 276 students from the Sri Lanka Technological Campus (SLTC) in Meepe and 64 students from the University of Sri Jayewardenepura. Kandy Police are conducting investigations. Meanwhile, a group of 40 estate workers in Bogawantalawa also came under a wasp attack and were rushed to hospital. (MD) By K.L. Suraweera – Kandy, Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood and C.D.H. Hewage – Watawala

title: Thalangama Police investigate ‘casting scam’
author: Author not found
Content: Thalangama Police have launched investigations into reports of a group engaging in fraudulent activities by luring young women with promises of acting opportunities in exchange for money. The group’s troubling approach involves confiscating the victims’ mobile phones and utilising TikTok to send messages. Authorities have launched investigations to arrest the culprits using bank account numbers and mobile phone records.  The perpetrators will be brought to book for their deceitful actions against women, Police said. By Sanjana Marzook

title: Dutch King apologises for colonial past
author: Author not found
Content: Dutch King Willem-Alexander has formally apologised for the Netherlands’ involvement in slavery, saying he felt “personally and intensely” affected. The king was speaking at a ceremony on Saturday marking the 160th anniversary of the legal abolition of slavery in the Netherlands, including its former colonies in the Caribbean. “I’m standing here in front of you as your king and as part of the Government. Today I am apologising myself,” Willem-Alexander said. “On this day we remember the Dutch history of slavery, I ask forgiveness for this crime against humanity.” He said racism in Dutch society remains a problem and not everyone would support his apology. The slave trade brought vast riches to his ancestors. The Dutch funded the so-called Golden Age of their empire and culture in the 16th and 17th centuries by shipping about 600,000 Africans as part of the slave trade, mostly to South America and the Caribbean. In December, Prime Minister Mark Rutte apologised on behalf of the Dutch State.  The monarch acknowledged the apology saying “a start has been made” but also there was “still a long way to go.” Descendants of slaves had called for the king to use Saturday’s ceremony at the Oosterpark in Amsterdam to apologise. In his speech broadcast live on national television, Willem-Alexander asked for “forgiveness” saying while nothing had been done about the past for a long time, “at some point, one feels the moral duty to act.” “The chains have truly been broken,” Willem-Alexander said to cheers and applause from thousands of onlookers at the national slavery monument. Slavery was formally abolished in Suriname and other Dutch-held lands on 1 July 1863, but the practice only really ended in 1873 after a 10-year transition period. A Dutch study released in June found the royal family earned 545 million euros (USD 595 million) in today’s terms between 1675 and 1770 from the colonies, where slavery was widespread. The current king’s distant ancestors, Willem III, Willem IV and Willem V, were among the biggest earners from what the report called the Dutch state’s “deliberate, structural and long-term involvement” in slavery. Since the Black Lives Matter Movement emerged in the United States, the Netherlands has embarked on an often difficult debate about its colonial and slave-trading past that turned it into one of the world’s richest countries. In 2022, King Willem-Alexander announced he was ditching the Royal Golden Coach that traditionally transported him on state occasions because it had images of slavery on its sides. One side panel had a picture called Tribute of the Colonies depicting kneeling black people handing over produce such as cocoa and sugarcane to their white masters. While some European leaders have apologised for their country’s colonial past, others have refused to take that step. In January, French President Emmanuel Macron stated he will not “ask forgiveness” from Algeria for French colonisation, but hoped to continue working towards reconciliation. “It’s not up to me to ask forgiveness, that’s not what this is about, that word would break all of our ties,” he said in an interview. British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak also rejected calls to apologise and offer reparatory justice for victims of the British slave trade and imperialism, saying the attempt to “unpick our history” was not something the Government would “focus its energy on.” (Al Jazeera)

title: PSC appointed to tackle drug menace
author: Author not found
Content: In a bid to address the rapidly spreading drug problem in the country, Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana announced the establishment of a Parliamentary Select Committee. The committee, chaired by Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles is tasked with identifying effective mechanisms to immediately control and eradicate the drug menace. Their findings and recommendations will be submitted to Parliament for consideration. The appointed members of the Select Committee include prominent parliamentarians who bring a wealth of expertise and diverse perspectives to the table. The committee comprises MPs Sisira Jayakody, Dr. Seetha Arambepola, Buddhika Pathirana, Dr. Gayashan Nawananda, Thushara Indunil Amarasena, Dr. Upul Galappaththi, Major Sudarshana Denipitiya, Asanka Navarathna, Upul Mahendra Rajapaksha, Thavaraja Kalai Arasan, and Manjula Dissanayake. The primary objective of the Select Committee is to thoroughly examine the existing drug control policies and programmes while proposing effective measures to tackle the escalating drug problem. With the drug menace posing a grave threat to the nation’s well-being and security, this committee aims to devise strategies that will curtail drug-related activities and safeguard communities from its adverse effects.

title: Sri Lanka as a destination promoted in Austria and Europe
author: Author not found
Content: The Embassy and Permanent Mission of Sri Lanka, together with the Sri Lanka Tourism Promotion Bureau (SLTPB) launched two commemorative landmark publications namely ‘Sri Lanka: Resilient Heritage’ authored by Ambassador Dato Dr. Ananda Kumarasiri, and, ‘From Europa to Taprobana’  authored by  Dr. Zameer Careem, at the Embassy on 26 June 2023. The two publications were undertaken in conjunction with the commemoration of the 75th Anniversary of Sri Lanka’s Independence.  In delivering the opening remarks, Ambassador and Permanent Representative Majintha Jayesinghe expressed his appreciation to both authors. He underlined that these books notably capture the underlining essence of Sri Lanka’s resilience as a nation by tracing its rich history, civilisation and culture. He went on to state that it offers insights into an array of remarkable achievements and unique features of Sri Lanka that has earned the reputation of the island for ages as being ‘a land like no other’. Ambassador Jayesinghe expressed aspirations that both these books will present an insightful account of the rich heritage of Sri Lanka’s relations with Austria as well as with the rest of Europe. He hoped that the two commemorative publications would encourage future generations to look at the shared history and relations with pride and motivate them to further enhance this unique friendship and goodwill to higher vistas of achievements.  In his speech, Ambassador Alexander Ehrlich-Adam of the Federal Ministry of European and International Affairs of Austria said the launching of these two publications marks a remarkable milestone in the special relations between Sri Lanka and Austria.  Most Venerable Dr. Wijayarajapura Seelawansa Thera of the Dhammazentrum Nyanaponika Vienna, in his brief remarks, recalled the historic relations between the two countries. Venerable Thero expressed hope that these publications will further strengthen the close bonds of friendship.  The author of the book, ‘Sri Lanka: Resilient Heritage’, Ambassador Dato Dr. Ananda Kumarasiri, traced Sri Lanka’s rich historic relations with Austria and Europe. He expressed confidence that this book would serve as a strong foundation for further enhancing both bilateral and multilateral relations in all fields of endeavour.  Author of the book ‘From Europa to Taprobana’, Dr Zameer Careem, stated that his book encapsulates the history of Sri Lanka’s special relations with Austria and Central and South East Europe. He expressed confidence that this historical foundation will assist to further expand and strengthen relations in the years ahead.  The commemorative event was attended by a large gathering including officials of the Federal Ministry of European and International Affairs of Austria, Diplomatic Corp., Honorary Consuls of Sri Lanka in Austria and accredited countries, travel agents and tour operators, travel writers and bloggers, academic, representatives of universities and museums, Sri Lankan expatriate community, print and electronic media.  As customarily practised Sri Lankan traditional food and world renowned Ceylon tea were served.

title: New Korean Envoy presents credentials
author: Author not found
Content: The Government of the Republic of Korea with the concurrence of the Government of Sri Lanka has appointed Lee Miyon as Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary of the Republic of Korea to Sri Lanka based in Colombo. She presented her credentials to President Ranil Wickremesinghe on 30 June at the President’s House, Kandy.
