He hoped that the two commemorative publications would encourage future generations to look at the shared history and relations with pride and motivate them to further enhance this unique friendship and goodwill to higher vistas of achievements.  In his speech, Ambassador Alexander Ehrlich-Adam of the Federal Ministry of European and International Affairs of Austria said the launching of these two publications marks a remarkable milestone in the special relations between Sri Lanka and Austria.  Most Venerable Dr. Wijayarajapura Seelawansa Thera of the Dhammazentrum Nyanaponika Vienna, in his brief remarks, recalled the historic relations between the two countries. Venerable Thero expressed hope that these publications will further strengthen the close bonds of friendship.  The author of the book, ‘Sri Lanka: Resilient Heritage’, Ambassador Dato Dr. Ananda Kumarasiri, traced Sri Lanka’s rich historic relations with Austria and Europe. He expressed confidence that this book would serve as a strong foundation for further enhancing both bilateral and multilateral relations in all fields of endeavour.  Author of the book ‘From Europa to Taprobana’, Dr Zameer Careem, stated that his book encapsulates the history of Sri Lanka’s special relations with Austria and Central and South East Europe. He expressed confidence that this historical foundation will assist to further expand and strengthen relations in the years ahead.  The commemorative event was attended by a large gathering including officials of the Federal Ministry of European and International Affairs of Austria, Diplomatic Corp., Honorary Consuls of Sri Lanka in Austria and accredited countries, travel agents and tour operators, travel writers and bloggers, academic, representatives of universities and museums, Sri Lankan expatriate community, print and electronic media.  As customarily practised Sri Lankan traditional food and world renowned Ceylon tea were served.

title: Education Minister attends 40th COL board meeting
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Education Susil Premajayantha participated in the 40th meeting of the Board of Governors of the Commonwealth of Learning (COL), held in Vancouver, Canada on 28 and 29 June. The Commonwealth of Learning is an international organisation headquartered in Canada, and it has been founded by the Commonwealth Heads of State to encourage the development and sharing of open learning and distance education resources and technologies. Premajayantha is the Asian regional representative of the COL Board of Governors and was elected to that post in April this year. The Minister was also able to direct the attention of the COL to improve access to quality education in Sri Lanka. This visit was fully sponsored by the Commonwealth Of Learning.

title: 9 of 11 minor offenders likely to re-offend
author: Author not found
Content: Owing to the loopholes in the present policies and programmes with regard to youth offenders, at least 9 out of 11 minor offenders are likely to re-offend, it was revealed at the Sectoral Oversight Committee on Reconciliation and National Unity. This was revealed by the Watareka Training School for Youthful Offenders and Department of Community Based Corrections under the Ministry of Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms when they appeared before the committee in Parliament recently. The Watareka Training School accommodates young offenders aged 16-22 who have been sentenced by the Magistrate’s Courts under the Criminal Code for committing offenses. Rather than serving a prison sentence, these individuals are required to complete a compulsory waiting period of three years. After this waiting period, they have the opportunity to apply for a government job in the external environment, as explained by Senior Assistant Secretary of the Watareka Training School for Youthful Offenders, A.V. Vajira Damayanthi. Institutional data reveals a decreasing trend in the number of young convicts being imprisoned from 2013 to 2022. However, it was found that many of the children entering this correctional institution come from broken families, leading to custody issues after the waiting period. The Ministry of Education provides schooling at the Watareka Training School, where attendance is compulsory. Despite this, the pass rates in the General Examination have been consistently low. For instance, in 2014, out of the 16 children who sat for the Ordinary Level examination, only one child passed. The situation did not improve significantly, as only one child passed in 2021. Officials emphasised the challenge of effectively providing vocational education to these children due to the compulsory nature of school education. They acknowledged the need for policy changes in this regard, and the Committee agreed to discuss these issues with relevant institutions and policymakers. The Committee raised concerns about the likelihood of young offenders becoming re-offenders, to which officials pointed out that 9 out of 11 children were likely to re-offend. The committee then shifted its focus to providing necessary facilities to enhance language proficiency among these children and exploring methods to connect them with foreign job opportunities through the Foreign Employment Bureau. Additionally, the Committee highlighted the potential role of community-based correctional departments in alleviating prison overcrowding, emphasising the importance of paying attention to this aspect. They also discussed the alarming fact that about 50 per cent of individuals who should be placed under community-based corrections end up being imprisoned by magistrates. The Committee emphasised the need to address this concerning situation by informing magistrates and encouraging them to take appropriate steps. Officials stressed the importance of providing vocational education to youth offenders, enabling them to secure employment and generate income during the remaining two years after the one-year training period. This approach would not only equip them with economic skills on leaving the institution after the three-year residency period but also reduce the temptation to re-offend, according to the officials’ recommendations. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: GSMB probing after-quakes
author: Author not found
Content: The Geological Survey and Mines (GSMB) Bureau said it is looking into the after-quakes which occurred following the quake reported on Saturday (1) afternoon in the seas off South-East Sri Lanka. The GSMB reported that there had been a magnitude 5.8 earthquake in the seas off South-East of Sri Lanka on Saturday (1) afternoon. The tremor, which occurred deep below the sea, was located approximately 1,260 km away from Colombo. It is reported that the people in Colombo, Battaramulla, Akuressa and Galle felt the quake. However, the Bureau said there were no adverse effects from the tremor on Sri Lanka.  BY Amith Maduranga Gamage

title: Govt plans to complete DDO by next month
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka plans to complete the domestic debt optimisation (DDO) programme by next month (July) in order to reduce gross financing needs (GFN) to less than 13 per cent of GDP between 2027 and 2032 (currently, it was around 35.6 per cent of GDP), Governor of the Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) Dr. Nandalal Weerasinghe said yesterday. “We plan to launch the DDO programme on Tuesday (4 July) and finalise it within the next month,” he stated at a special press briefing held at the President’s Media Centre in Colombo. Speaking at the briefing, Finance Ministry Secretary K.M. Mahinda Siriwardana emphasised that ongoing fiscal adjustment and external debt restructuring alone are insufficient to meet the IMF-led debt sustainability targets. Sri Lanka received a USD 2.9 billion IMF bailout in March to reduce debt and achieve IMF’s goal of 95 per cent debt to GDP by 2032. He emphasised that restructuring foreign debt alone won’t reduce the GFN to 13 per cent. Secretary Siriwardana suggested that DDO could be feasible without impacting the banking sector, as an additional burden could threaten financial stability. Therefore, the Sri Lankan Government has excluded the banking and financial sector from the DDO process to ensure the safety of deposits of over 57.2 million (with multiple) depositors. The banking sector has already borne significant burdens from fiscal adjustment and economic crisis, with a total tax burden increasing from 39 per cent to 48 per cent. Nonperforming loans have also increased, necessitating high provisioning and capital enhancement. Foreign currency debt restructuring will also impact the banking sector and they have already made 35 per cent provision for their ISB investments. However, over 60 per cent of the domestic debt of the Government is held by the non-commercial banking sector. He also mentioned that the process of restructuring domestic and foreign debt will be considered separately and a 30 per cent haircut from private external creditors is also proposed. Japan, France and India support a common platform for Sri Lanka’s debt restructuring through coordinated negotiation. Debt restructuring discussions aim to reach agreement on perimeter and parameters for bilateral and commercial foreign debt before the upcoming (September) IMF-EFF review. Creditors emphasise the importance of burden sharing for debt treatment, involving both foreign and domestic creditors. Sri Lanka’s debt service reduction during 2022-27 should close external financing gaps of USD 16.9 billion. According to the CBSL, this DDO process will apply to all CBSL Treasury Bill holdings and Provisional Advances to Government, Sri Lanka development Bonds (SLDB) and Foreign Currency Banking Unit (FCBU) assets held by domestic banks and Treasury Bond investments in Superannuation Funds such as EPF and ETF, held until 4 July 2023. According to Dr. Nandalal Weerasinghe Superannuation funds would be encouraged to participate to the DDO operation, on the back of higher annual income tax of 30 per cent to be applied to non-participating funds. Therefore, the Government of Sri Lanka plans to restructure its Employment Provident Fund (EPF) by reissuing new bonds for existing bonds, paying 12 per cent until 2025 and nine per cent thereafter. “Current member balances will remain unaffected, and the Government will top up returns below nine per cent. There are discussions about changing the EPF law to guarantee a nine per cent return. The offer to exchange new funds will be made to other provident funds, such as the Employees Trust Fund (ETF),” the Governor said. This DDO process will convert CBSL holdings of Treasury Bills to longer term Treasury Bonds, subject to the approval of the appropriate legislation. This will help to reduce overall financial requirements. The result of this adjustment will be depleted and negative capital on the CBSL’s balance sheet. “Recapitalisation may be required to mitigate the adverse impact of negative equity on CBSL’s credibility and independence,” the Governor stated. The Government also provides holders of SLDBs and FCBUs with two options for DDO participation. The main alternative is to exchange outstanding SLDBs/FCBUs for new USD instruments that are equivalent to foreign creditors, while the second option is to exchange outstanding SLDBs/FCBUs for new Sri Lankan rupee instruments. Sri Lanka’s local currency market debt accounts for a sizeble portion of the country’s public debt, accounting for 42 per cent of overall public debt and more than 50 per cent of GDP. Total local market debt, as of the end of 2022, is estimated to be roughly Rs 12.8 trillion or USD 34.5 trillion, which includes Rs 4.1 trillion in T-Bills and Rs 8.7 trillion in T-Bonds. Sri Lanka’s Government debt has reached an unsustainable level due to challenges in debt servicing, low revenue mobilisation, and limited foreign inflows and market access due to default credit ratings. Access to concessional funding was also limited due to the country’s transition to the middle-income status in the early 2000s. The Government sought assistance from the IMF for an EFF arrangement to restore debt sustainability. The release of the second tranche of EFF would require significant progress on debt restructuring, with Lazard Frères SAS and Clifford Chance LLP contracted to support the process. The Government has already embarked on a fiscal consolidation path, aiming for a sustainable surplus in primary balance. However, further tightening of fiscal stance could be economically and socially costly, as it burdens businesses and households and negatively impacts economic activity. By Ishara Gamage

title: 20 Malaria cases detected in six months
author: Author not found
Content: A total of 20 cases of malaria have been detected in the country during the past six months, the Anti-Malaria Campaign (AMC) said. The AMC revealed yesterday (29) that they included three foreign nationals, while the remaining cases were locals who had been travelling in malaria endemic countries like Guinea, Tanzania, Sierra Leon, Sudan and Uganda. The AMC said, while preventive medication was available, to be taken beforehand, for those who travelled to those countries, locals returning from malaria endemic countries should either visit the AMC head office or the closest hospital or undergo a blood test for the mosquito borne disease. Consultant Community Physician Dr. Shilanthi Seneviratne warned that with the malaria vector Anopheles still present in the country there was a high risk of disease spread if timely action was not taken to diagnose it. The campaign has also set up a 24-hour hotline 071 2841 767 and 011 7626 626 for any issues regarding the disease.    BY Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: New members appointedto EC, HRCSL
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe has appointed new members to the Election Commission (EC) and the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL). Accordingly, Justice L.T.B. Dehideniya, a retired Supreme Court Judge, was appointed as Chairman of the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka. R.M.A.L. Rathnayake, a former Additional Commissioner of Elections, has been appointed as the Chairman of the Election Commission. Other members of the Election Commission are M.A. Pathmasiri Chandrawansha Perera and Ameer Mohommed Faiz. The newly appointed members of the Human Rights Commission, as directed by the President, include Nimalasena Gardier Pundihewa, Thaiyamuttu Thanaraj, Prof. Fathima Farzana Hanifa, and Dr. Gehan Dinuk Gunatillake.

title: CEB claims to have settled solar power debts
author: Author not found
Content: The Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) announced that they have settled approximately Rs 4 billion accumulated arrears due to rooftop solar customers.  Accordingly, all due arrears up to April 2023 have now been settled, CEB said in a statement. During 2022, CEB was unable to settle the payments for rooftop solar customers in total due to severe financial difficulties faced by CEB, mainly due to non-availability of a cost reflective tariff.  However, with the implementation of cost reflective tariff, on 15 February 2023, CEB managed to commence settlement of monthly bills from internal cash generation and accumulated arrears by raising loans from financial institutions despite the fact that settlement of previous debt is not included in the tariff. “CEB is happy that now we managed to settle all due arrears up to April 2023,” the CEB said. Electricity customers had installed about 700 MW of rooftop solar energy systems which is sizeable compared with day peak of the country which is only 2700 MW including Rooftop solar. Roof solar has contributed immensely to increase renewable energy share of the country, the CEB said.

title: AHP calls for audit of Health Ministry projects
author: Author not found
Content: The Association of Health Professionals (AHP) called for an immediate audit to be conducted on the effectiveness of the projects implemented by the Health Ministry. AHP President Ravi Kumudesh yesterday (29) said that these were to establish data systems wasting public funds due to their non-functional state. Kumudesh alleged that billions of rupees had been thrown away, by the Health Ministry to set up data systems, which had only been wasted due to the lack of proper technology. Kumudesh, lashing out, said, the Medical Supplies Division (MSD) alone had removed a data system which it had set up spending millions of rupees, to set up new data system which was worth more that Rs 100 million. “Unfortunately the data systems set up during the last five years in the Health Ministry were currently non operational,” he accused. While hospitals spent billions of rupees on data systems, and infrastructure, equipment and technical devices were being destroyed due to non-use, the Health Ministry was setting up data systems which were not being put to use of or were non-operational, the AHP President accused. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Laugfs refutes gas shortage rumours
author: Author not found
Content: Laugfs Gas PLC refuted rumours of a gas shortage in the country, assuring the public that there is an ample supply available. Nalinda Kurukulasooriya, CEO of Laugfs Gas, addressed the issue and confirmed that all terminals currently have a stock of LP gas that can meet the demand for an entire month. Regarding the potential reduction of LP gas prices, Kurukulasooriya mentioned that a price revision will occur as scheduled, and the benefits of this revision will be passed on to the consumers. However, final decision on the price revision will depend on factors such as the exchange rate between the Sri Lankan Rupee and the USD, as well as the availability of LP gas, he added. Meanwhile, Litro Gas Lanka recently announced that there will be another reduction in the prices of domestic LP gas. This upcoming price revision, scheduled for early July, marks the fourth consecutive reduction in prices in recent times.

title: Amaraweera says even European countries want SL’s Toque monkeys
author: Author not found
Content: Although legal action has been instituted by some environmentalist groups, against exporting toque monkeys to China, a private company in China is still offering to take the monkeys, Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera claimed. The Minister revealed this in response to questions posed by a group of journalists. He also said other than the Chinese company, several zoos in European countries have requested for toque monkeys from Sri Lanka. Journalists questioned the minister about the continuation of the programme to export the toque monkeys, amidst legal challenges. “Currently, some environmental organisations and animal welfare associations have taken legal action regarding the programme. We do not export these animals. The Ministry of Agriculture does not have the legal capacity for that. That is why we appointed a committee to find out whether the proposal presented by a Chinese private company can be fulfilled. But now legal action has been taken against it. Even so, there is no change in the position of the relevant Chinese company seeking the toque monkeys,” he said. “We requested, on many occasions to submit comments and suggestions from all parties, regarding the prevention of wild animal damage to crops. Some suggestions have been implemented so far and have failed. For example, they suggested various tactics to repel animals. Extermination is not a successful strategy to prevent wildlife damage. Even if they flee from one place, they wreak havoc in another,” Amaraweera added. “Also, some said, every farmer should set aside half-an-acre of cultivated land for wild animals. But we don’t know if the farmers will like it. And even if half an acre is allotted, this is our own share. There is no way for the animals to think that we are not going to other parts. Some other organisations said to hang saris around the plantation. We have to think how many saris one farmer will have to buy to hang around three to four acres. And some others said to hang tins around the farm and around the trees. No constructive and practical proposals were presented except such non-practical nonsensical proposals,” he asserted. Speaking further, Amaraweera said, some others ‘advised’ to do sterile surgeries like vasectomy and tubectomy. “These animal welfare associations do not know that like all these sterilised animals, the sutures break and they die in extreme suffering. They only want foreign dollars. All they do is show the animals of our country and earn foreign currency to live.” The minister alleged that those who oppose the plan do not know the hardships farmers are going through in the country due to crop damage caused by wild animals. “So, I have to tell you, don’t ask us about preventing crop damage caused by wild animals. Ask the gentlemen and ladies of these animal welfare associations who depend on the dollars they receive from animals in cold rooms in Colombo, he stressed. “Some claimed that these animals were taken to eat their brains. Various lies were told. But now, somehow, the best arrangement to prevent animal damage was disrupted. Now the solutions for the measures to be taken in relation to crop damage should be asked from the animal welfare associations that have been disrupted. If this arrangement had been implemented, our toque monkeys would not have died. They had the opportunity to live with the love and kindness of thousands of people in foreign zoos. Farmers are now asking for guns to protect crops. What happens then? The end is the death of these animals.”

title: Separate list of allowance payments to be made public
author: Author not found
Content: A separate list pertaining to the payment of allowances, for various assistance programmes running alongside the Aswesuma relief benefit programme, will be made accessible to the public next week, the President’s Media Division (PMD) said. These include 456,806 for elderly allowances, 19,496 for kidney patients’ allowances, 46,857 disability allowances and 523,159 public assistance programme allowances. The disclosure of this information will provide clarity and transparency regarding the distribution of benefits across multiple social support initiatives. The PMD said, in a statement, that with an overwhelming response, the Divisional Secretariats across the island have received a staggering 3.7 million applications for the Aswesuma Social Security Benefit Programme. Out of the selected applicants, a list comprising two million names has been released to the public, designating them as eligible beneficiaries, pending appeals and objections, the PMD said. “Following a comprehensive survey, a total of 3.3 million applications have been carefully selected, marking a significant milestone in the programme’s implementation. Out of the selected applicants, a list comprising two million names has been released to the public, designating them as eligible beneficiaries, pending appeals and objections. The selection process was diligently overseen by a three-member committee at the Divisional Secretariat level, with final approval granted by the District Secretary. This meticulous approach ensured that deserving candidates were rightfully chosen to benefit from the programme.” For individuals who believe they qualify for the Aswesuma welfare , but do not find their names on the published list, a window of opportunity has been provided to file appeals until 10 July, the statement said. “Furthermore, if any details of individuals who should not receive social welfare benefits are identified in the public list, a mechanism for anonymous complaints has also been established. Appeals and objections can be submitted in writing to the Divisional Secretariats, which have been duly informed of the process. President Ranil Wickremesinghe has underscored the importance of fairness and inclusivity in implementing this programme, ensuring that no one is unjustly treated or left behind. Directives have been issued to all Divisional Secretariats to adhere to the government’s decisions, further emphasising the commitment to uphold transparency and equity. Lastly, an annual opportunity is extended to individuals who were unable to register for the Aswesuma Social Welfare Benefit Programme, as well as those who wish to join the programme anew. This initiative ensures that individuals have a chance to avail themselves of the programme’s benefits and support, contributing to their overall welfare and well-being,” the PMD said.

title: Devananda confident President will solve Tamils’ issues
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda claimed the President is deeply concerned and committed to resolving the longstanding political and other fundamental issues faced by the Tamil community. Devananda expressed confidence and hope that President Wickremesinghe would be dedicated to implementing the 13th Amendment to the Constitution. The Minister held a meeting with representatives of active civil organisations involved in politics in the Northern Province, specifically in Jaffna. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss the current political situation and determine further actions in consultation with them. During the meeting, the necessity of implementing the 13th Amendment was emphasised. It was argued that if the elected members of the Northern Provincial Council had effectively utilised their power, there would have been potential for introducing a federal system in the Northern Province. However, due to various factors, the situation took an adverse turn. Additionally, Minister Devananda was informed that the LTTE and the politicians in the province, who closely collaborated with the previous Good Governance Government, were responsible for exacerbating the tragic situation faced by the Tamil community as a whole. Devananda emphasised the urgency of addressing this issue and highlighted that the President has taken proactive measures to rebuild unity and harmony, which have been undermined by the growing influence of divisive political forces in the country. The Minister said he firmly believes that implementing the 13th Amendment is the only solution to resolve the longstanding ethnic crisis. He expressed his regret that the LTTE and certain political organisations have failed to accept this solution for the past 30 years. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: LPBOA decides against fare revision
author: Author not found
Content: The Lanka Private Bus Owners’ Association (LPBOA) announced yesterday (29) that they have decided against implementing an annual bus fare revision for the current year. Addressing the media, LPBOA Chairman Gemunu Wijerathne said they have chosen to maintain the existing bus fare without introducing any changes and the decision has been communicated to the National Transport Commission (NTC). Wijerathne said, typically, the annual bus fare revision takes place on 1 June, considering factors such as inflation rate, diesel prices, maintenance costs, and the prices of tires and spare parts, among others. “The NTC informed us about a seven per cent increase in bus fares as per their calculations for the annual revision. However, as an association, we conveyed to the NTC that we find the seven per cent increment unacceptable at this time,” he said. (MD)

title: Vijeyakala in ICU after road mishap
author: Author not found
Content: Former State Minister Vijeyakala Maheshvaran is currently warded in the ICU of the Chilaw General Hospital, after being involved in a road accident near Mangalaeliya in Mundalama on the Colombo-Puttalam road. Following the accident, she was initially taken to the Mundalama District Hospital and later transferred to the Chilaw General Hospital. According to Police, the van she was travelling in veered off the road and overturned, injuring her, the driver and another. Both the driver and the other passenger were admitted to the hospital. Preliminary investigations have indicated that the driver fell asleep behind the wheel, Police added. BY Prasad Purnamal

title: Romania supports GSP plus duty extension for Sri Lanka
author: Author not found
Content: Romanian Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Traian Hristea thanked Sri Lanka for deciding to open an Embassy in Bucharest shortly. He said this when he call on Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena at the Temple Trees on June 25 to discuss bilateral ties, economic cooperation, investments and employment issues. The Prime Minister thanked the government of Romania providing employment to a large number of Sri Lankans in recent years. Romania is the most favourable and preferred employment destination for Sri Lankans since 2016 and already, the Sri Lankan workforce in the apparel, construction, hospitality and agriculture sectors is assessed to be more than 32,000. The State Secretary Hristea said there will be additional employment opportunities for Sri Lankans as Romania is currently implementing several large scale infrastructure and other development projects. The Prime Minister urged Romania to consider investments in education, agriculture, railways, IT and tourism sectors. He explained the measures taken by Sri Lanka to solve the issues related to the current economic crisis and stressed the need for continuous support of European Union. Romanian Minister assured that his country would support Sri Lanka’s request for continuation of GSP plus duty concessions for Sri Lankan exports. Romanian Minister was accompanied by Dr. Victor Chiujdea, Charge d’affaires of the Embassy of Romania in Colombo, Mrs. Diana Tase, Director of the Asia Pacific Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Romania and Bogdan Aldea Counsellor MFA. MP Yadamini Gunawardena, Additional Secretary Mahinda Gunaratne, Dr Jayantha Jayamanna and Sugeeswara Senadhira also were present on this occasion.

title: Temp driving licence validity extended
author: Author not found
Content: In response to the shortage of printing cards and to address the accumulation of temporary driving licences, the Department of Motor Traffic (DMT) has announced an extension of the validity period for selected temporary driving licences. According to the DMT, all temporary driving licences, issued between 3 March 2022, and 30 June 2023, will now have their validity extended by two years. This extension applies to each licence from its original date of expiry. This decision aims to alleviate the backlog of temporary driving licences caused by the shortage of printing cards.

title: Don’t skip a beat
author: Author not found
Content: The Rotary Clubs of Colombo Metropolitan and Colombo West of District 3220 in partnership with leading healthcare providers including Lanka Hospitals Sri Lanka recently surpassed the milestone of facilitating 80 heart surgeries for children from impoverished families. This initiative which was launched in 2019 has benefited children with congenital heart disease from all over Sri Lanka, typically from low-income households. Congenital heart disease is a challenging condition affecting children from birth, necessitating timely intervention and specialised care. Currently, in Sri Lanka, there are hundreds of children on the waiting list at Lady Ridgeway Hospital to receive congenital heart surgeries. Recognising the urgency of this issue, the Rotary Club of Colombo Metropolitan and the Rotary Club of Colombo West initiated comprehensive programmes to address the healthcare gaps and provide life-saving support to affected children across Sri Lanka. Through strategic collaborations and fundraising with its main sponsor Linde Foundation which committed USD 100,000, International Partner Gift of Life International, Hospital Partner Lanka Hospital and local medical professionals, the Rotary Club of Colombo Metropolitan has facilitated 50 life-changing medical interventions for children born with congenital heart disease in 2023. Their efforts have led to successful surgeries, ensured access to vital medications, and provided post-operative care, enabling these children to live healthy and fulfilling lives. Lanka Hospital which, provides the surgeries at cost is celebrating and marking its 100th congenital heart surgery in partnership with Rotary. Congratulating the Rotary Clubs on the success of their noble initiative, Dep. CEO/Director – Medical Services of Lanka Hospitals Dr. Lasantha Karunasekera said: “Lanka Hospitals Group, driven by a relentless pursuit of excellence in healthcare, takes pride in serving the Sri Lankan community with world-class medical services. We are committed to our socially responsible initiatives, as witnessed by our recent endeavours. At the start of this year, Lanka Hospitals facilitated 100 free cardiac surgeries for the underprivileged, and more recently, we assisted in 120 cataract surgeries. These endeavours mark just the beginning of our unwavering dedication to enhancing the lives of those in need.” Rotary Club of Colombo West, in partnership with renowned cardiac centres such as Amrita Hospital, Cochin, India and Rotary Club of Cochin West, have focused on establishing a Rotary Global Grant valued at USD 200,000. The grant allows 65 complex child surgeries to be conducted overseas at Amrita Hospital. The partnership provides training for five local doctors and thirty nurses on complex heart surgeries. On Sunday, 18 June, visiting doctors from Amrita Hospital conducted a specialised Foetal Echocardiography workshop for over 60 local doctors and radiographers at Lanka Hospitals. Their multi-faceted approach has resulted in numerous sponsored surgeries and substantial improvements in the quality of care available to children affected by congenital heart disease. The collaborative success of the Rotary Club Colombo Metropolitan and the Rotary Club of Colombo West demonstrates the power of community, compassion, and collective action. Together, they have brought hope and transformed the lives of countless children in Sri Lanka. To support their objective of creating hope for every child please contact the Rotary Club of Colombo Metropolitan and Rotary Club of Colombo West via [email protected] as they continue to make a lasting difference in healing children’s hearts affected by congenital heart disease in Sri Lanka. Together, we can create a world where every child has access to life-saving healthcare and a chance at a brighter future.

title: Clinic held to treat dogs, cats
author: Author not found
Content: A two-day continuous clinic for domestic and stray animals took place at the Anuradhapura veterinary office on 24 and 25 June. Organised by the Anuradhapura Municipal Council, the clinic offered various services free of charge, including sterilisation for dogs and cats, rabies vaccinations, treatment for diseases and other surgeries. Veterinarian Pradeep Nandadasa reported that the animal clinic operated non-stop from 6 a.m. on 24 June. During the clinic, a total of 200 sterilisation surgeries, over 300 hydrocephalus injections and treatment for 120 animals with conditions like rashes were carried out. The clinic was staffed by five veterinarians and 15 support staff members. BY Sumedha Karunarathna – Mihintale

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. title: Romania supports GSP plus duty extension for Sri Lanka
author: Author not found
Content: Romanian Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Traian Hristea thanked Sri Lanka for deciding to open an Embassy in Bucharest shortly. He said this when he call on Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena at the Temple Trees on June 25 to discuss bilateral ties, economic cooperation, investments and employment issues. The Prime Minister thanked the government of Romania providing employment to a large number of Sri Lankans in recent years. Romania is the most favourable and preferred employment destination for Sri Lankans since 2016 and already, the Sri Lankan workforce in the apparel, construction, hospitality and agriculture sectors is assessed to be more than 32,000. The State Secretary Hristea said there will be additional employment opportunities for Sri Lankans as Romania is currently implementing several large scale infrastructure and other development projects. The Prime Minister urged Romania to consider investments in education, agriculture, railways, IT and tourism sectors. He explained the measures taken by Sri Lanka to solve the issues related to the current economic crisis and stressed the need for continuous support of European Union. Romanian Minister assured that his country would support Sri Lanka’s request for continuation of GSP plus duty concessions for Sri Lankan exports. Romanian Minister was accompanied by Dr. Victor Chiujdea, Charge d’affaires of the Embassy of Romania in Colombo, Mrs. Diana Tase, Director of the Asia Pacific Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Romania and Bogdan Aldea Counsellor MFA. MP Yadamini Gunawardena, Additional Secretary Mahinda Gunaratne, Dr Jayantha Jayamanna and Sugeeswara Senadhira also were present on this occasion.

title: Temp driving licence validity extended
author: Author not found
Content: In response to the shortage of printing cards and to address the accumulation of temporary driving licences, the Department of Motor Traffic (DMT) has announced an extension of the validity period for selected temporary driving licences. According to the DMT, all temporary driving licences, issued between 3 March 2022, and 30 June 2023, will now have their validity extended by two years. This extension applies to each licence from its original date of expiry. This decision aims to alleviate the backlog of temporary driving licences caused by the shortage of printing cards.

title: Don’t skip a beat
author: Author not found
Content: The Rotary Clubs of Colombo Metropolitan and Colombo West of District 3220 in partnership with leading healthcare providers including Lanka Hospitals Sri Lanka recently surpassed the milestone of facilitating 80 heart surgeries for children from impoverished families. This initiative which was launched in 2019 has benefited children with congenital heart disease from all over Sri Lanka, typically from low-income households. Congenital heart disease is a challenging condition affecting children from birth, necessitating timely intervention and specialised care. Currently, in Sri Lanka, there are hundreds of children on the waiting list at Lady Ridgeway Hospital to receive congenital heart surgeries. Recognising the urgency of this issue, the Rotary Club of Colombo Metropolitan and the Rotary Club of Colombo West initiated comprehensive programmes to address the healthcare gaps and provide life-saving support to affected children across Sri Lanka. Through strategic collaborations and fundraising with its main sponsor Linde Foundation which committed USD 100,000, International Partner Gift of Life International, Hospital Partner Lanka Hospital and local medical professionals, the Rotary Club of Colombo Metropolitan has facilitated 50 life-changing medical interventions for children born with congenital heart disease in 2023. Their efforts have led to successful surgeries, ensured access to vital medications, and provided post-operative care, enabling these children to live healthy and fulfilling lives. Lanka Hospital which, provides the surgeries at cost is celebrating and marking its 100th congenital heart surgery in partnership with Rotary. Congratulating the Rotary Clubs on the success of their noble initiative, Dep. CEO/Director – Medical Services of Lanka Hospitals Dr. Lasantha Karunasekera said: “Lanka Hospitals Group, driven by a relentless pursuit of excellence in healthcare, takes pride in serving the Sri Lankan community with world-class medical services. We are committed to our socially responsible initiatives, as witnessed by our recent endeavours. At the start of this year, Lanka Hospitals facilitated 100 free cardiac surgeries for the underprivileged, and more recently, we assisted in 120 cataract surgeries. These endeavours mark just the beginning of our unwavering dedication to enhancing the lives of those in need.” Rotary Club of Colombo West, in partnership with renowned cardiac centres such as Amrita Hospital, Cochin, India and Rotary Club of Cochin West, have focused on establishing a Rotary Global Grant valued at USD 200,000. The grant allows 65 complex child surgeries to be conducted overseas at Amrita Hospital. The partnership provides training for five local doctors and thirty nurses on complex heart surgeries. On Sunday, 18 June, visiting doctors from Amrita Hospital conducted a specialised Foetal Echocardiography workshop for over 60 local doctors and radiographers at Lanka Hospitals. Their multi-faceted approach has resulted in numerous sponsored surgeries and substantial improvements in the quality of care available to children affected by congenital heart disease. The collaborative success of the Rotary Club Colombo Metropolitan and the Rotary Club of Colombo West demonstrates the power of community, compassion, and collective action. Together, they have brought hope and transformed the lives of countless children in Sri Lanka. To support their objective of creating hope for every child please contact the Rotary Club of Colombo Metropolitan and Rotary Club of Colombo West via [email protected] as they continue to make a lasting difference in healing children’s hearts affected by congenital heart disease in Sri Lanka. Together, we can create a world where every child has access to life-saving healthcare and a chance at a brighter future.

author: Author not found
Content: A two-day continuous clinic for domestic and stray animals took place at the Anuradhapura veterinary office on 24 and 25 June. Organised by the Anuradhapura Municipal Council, the clinic offered various services free of charge, including sterilisation for dogs and cats, rabies vaccinations, treatment for diseases and other surgeries. During the clinic, a total of 200 sterilisation surgeries, over 300 hydrocephalus injections and treatment for 120 animals with conditions like rashes were carried out. The clinic was staffed by five veterinarians and 15 support staff members. In addition to this programme, a separate initiative was undertaken to provide treatment and rabies vaccinations for stray animals over a period of three days, from 21 to 23 June. BY Sumedha Karunarathna – Mihintale

title: Medicines and staff needed for Wanela Hospital
author: Author not found
Content: M.R.B.G. Lokubanda, President of the Wanela Elders Society, urge the Minister of Health and the Government to immediately provide the necessary medical and staffing facilities, for inpatient treatment, to the only rural hospital in Wanela, Kantale where nearly twenty thousand farmers live. People have to travel a distance of 27 km to reach the Kantale Base Hospital for treatment and it is further said, due to the problem of wild elephants at night, there is a danger to life and there are cases of deaths reported while taking the sick patients to the hospitals. “Despite informing all Government and political leaders several times about this discrepancy through letters, meetings and verbally informing facts to consider the matter, it is sad that it has not been implemented so far. However, we received some positive response from the Governor Senthil Thondaman about this,” he stressed. BY W.M. Wickramasinghe – Kantale

title: No water to quench their thirst
author: Author not found
Content: Residents of Dimbulagala, Aralaganwila and Dehiattakandiya alleged that they have been suffering for years for want of safe drinking facilities. They stressed that currently they are tending to their needs via water seeping through canals, while others have been compelled to pay Rs 500 per trishaw to get to Aralaganwila Town to secure safe drinking water in cans. They said ,over 100 families in each of the aforementioned areas are presently facing this predicament and they urge authorities to provide them relief in this regard. BY Nimal Jayaratne – Manampitiya

title: Over 1,500 GPs have left the service – Nalinda
author: Author not found
Content: JVP Politburo member Dr. Nalinda Jayatissa said according to a report received by them, there were approximately 18,600 general practitioners in the country, but a significant number, ranging from 1,500 to 1,700, have left. He said the report highlighted that there should ideally be 103 cardiologists, but currently, only 57 are practising. Furthermore, eight of the remaining cardiologists are set to retire by December. This situation poses a threat of closing nearly 50 Peripheral Hospitals across the country. Dr. Jayatissa further presented data from the report, stating, “By 2028, the country should have 418 physiotherapists, but the current count is only 240, and 22 of them are scheduled to retire by December. Initially, there were 247 surgeons, but now there are only 145. Furthermore, 23 of them are expected to retire in December. Similarly, there were 302 paediatricians, but only 146 remain, and 28 of them will retire by the end of December. Additionally, 24 Gynaecologists and obstetricians have already left the country. Previously, there were 284 Anaesthesiologists, but the number has dwindled to 129, and 18 of them will retire by the end of this year.” He also expressed concern about the impact of paediatricians leaving the country, which resulted in the closure of the professor unit affiliated with the Rajarata Faculty of Medicine, operated by the Anuradhapura Teaching Hospital. Currently, a specialist doctor has been temporarily assigned to the Thambuttegama Hospital. The shortage of cardiologists is also alarming, as the country falls short of the required 103, with only 57 in practice. Additionally, eight of the remaining cardiologists will retire by December. The report also indicated that there should ideally be 129 dermatologists, but only 66 are currently available, and eight of them are set to retire in December. This shortage of healthcare professionals is evident across various fields, and the trend of professionals leaving the country continues. Consequently, several wards in Peripheral Hospitals are unable to operate effectively. He emphasised the gravity of the situation, saying, “Out of the approximately 18,600 general doctors, a significant number, ranging from 1,500 to 1,700, have already left the country. The closure of 50 Peripheral Hospitals looms as a real threat. There is a limit to how long this situation can persist with the available doctors. Even if there are specialists remaining, their efforts will be futile without an adequate number of general doctors to provide support. Some hospitals are now limited to performing only emergency surgeries.” BY Anuradha Herath

title: SL resolved most of its problems with India’s support – Wijeyadasa
author: Author not found
Content: Justice Minister Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe has praised the Indian Government led by Prime Minister Narendra Modi for helping Sri Lanka during the economic and political crisis. He also said the Sri Lankan Government will soon set up the Truth and Reconciliation Commission to bring long-standing peace to the island nation with consensus from all communities. The Minister further said the Sri Lankan Government is holding continuous interactions with the Tamil Diaspora and people and leaders living in different parts of the world. “We resolved most of our problems with the support we got from the Indian Government led by PM Modi. We are hopeful to bring normalcy back to Sri Lanka,” Rajapakshe, who handles the Justice Department, told PTI on Saturday on the sidelines of the Peace Conference in Nagpur city of Maharashtra. Sri Lanka was hit by an unprecedented financial crisis in 2022 that also sparked political turmoil in the island nation which led to the ouster of the all-powerful Rajapaksa family. The crisis led to the formation of a government led by Ranil Wickremesinghe which was tasked with stabilising the economy and restoring the financial health of the economy. Rajapakshe said Sri Lanka witnessed 30 years of war and disastrous things in which 60,000 lives were lost. “I took many initiatives to help the people affected by the war. We have commenced the process in 2016 and launched the offices for missing people, reparation of peace, and reconciliation of peace,” Rajapakshe added. He was replying to a query on complaints from ethnic communities and religious minorities in Sri Lanka about alleged injustice and discrimination and the role of the Sri Lankan justice system. “The Sri Lankan Government will set up the Truth and Reconciliation Commission and we are trying to ensure long-standing peace in consensus with all communities. “We have resolved many issues. There were several litigations and so many prisoners. However, now all these issues have become minimal. Sri Lanka is addressing all the issues from every angle,” Rajapakshe said. He said the Sri Lankan Government held dialogues and interactions with the Tamil community to reach some understanding to resolve the issues. “We are holding continuous interactions with the Tamil Diaspora, people and leaders living in different parts of the world. Now, all have supported establishing peace. They also categorically say that everybody in Sri Lanka has suffered. It is not confined to a particular community in Sri Lanka,” the minister said. He said the Government is of the view that these problems mustn’t be passed to the next generations. “We should ensure that in our country all Sri Lankans whether they are Muslims, Tamils, or Sinhalese live in peace with the Sri Lankan identity. We are hopeful to accomplish this,” he said. Rajapakshe also spoke about how Sri Lanka is addressing the economic crises in the aftermath of the coronavirus pandemic. “The country’s economy was in dire straits and inflation was around 97 per cent (when the new government took over). We were going through a very difficult period. We didn’t even have 2 million when we took over. We told this truth to the people,” he said. Our target was to bring inflation to a single digit in a year and ensure people get essential foods, coal and gas and increase foreign reserve up to USD 5 billion, he added. “We have brought down the inflation to 21 per cent. People do not face power cuts and coal shortages. Essential goods are available adequately. Our foreign reserves stand at 3.5 billion and we hope to increase it to USD 5 billion,” Rajapakshe added. He said the Government has stabilised the political and economic situation in the country. Queried on allegations that the ex-Sri Lankan President tampered with Police records to stall investigations into the alleged discovery of mass graves in an area where he was a military officer during the Marxist rebellion in 1989, Rajapakshe said, “There is no possibility of tampering with the records as he (Rajapaksa) is not in power”. “There had been some allegations in the last few days, and certainly, authorities will continue with the investigation. If guilty are found the normal laws of the country will take course,” he added. Rajapakshe also spoke about introducing a new bill to be passed in Sri Lankan Parliament next month to address the corruption in the public sector. (PTI)

title: Cabinet nod for domestic debt restructuring
author: Author not found
Content: The Cabinet of Ministers, at a special Cabinet meeting held last afternoon, approved the proposed restructuring of the domestic debt. Meanwhile, with House being convened on Saturday, to discuss crucial fiscal matters, including domestic debt restructuring, the Committee on Public Finance (COPF) yesterday summoned officials of the Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL), the Ministry of Finance and the Auditor General’s Department for the first session of discussions on the proposed domestic debt restructuring process. COPF Chairman Dr. Harsha de Silva, in a tweet, stated that the commercial banks, the Employees’ Provident Fund (EPF) and other relevant institutions have been summoned for the second session today (29). He added that they will meet on Friday (30) once again to resolve outstanding issues. Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena issued a Gazette Extraordinary, convening Parliament on Saturday (1 July). Subsequently, Secretary General of Parliament Kushani Rohanadeera has, in writing, informed all Members of Parliament that the Parliament will convene at 9:30 a.m. on 1 July 2023. During this special parliamentary session, the proposal for domestic debt restructuring will be presented for adoption. President Ranil Wickremesinghe met the ruling Party MPs following the special Cabinet meeting. Meanwhile, political sources claimed ruling Party MPs have been notified to remain in Colombo by cancelling all other visits outside Colombo, including overseas travel, since the debt restructuring proposal is to be presented in the House. The President earlier said that the debt restructuring programme will be presented to the Cabinet on Wednesday, and that it will be presented to Parliament and before the Committee on Public Finance (COPF) tomorrow (30). By Gagani Weerakoon

title: 19th SLAF Commander to assume duties tomorrow
author: Author not found
Content: Chief of Staff of the Sri Lanka Air Force (SLAF), Air Vice Marshal Udeni Rajapaksa will assume duties as the 19th Commander of the SLAF tomorrow (30) on being elevated to the three-star rank of Air Marshal. He will also go down in history as the first Anandian to become an SLAF Commander. The incumbent Commander Air Marshal Sudarshana Pathirana recently announced his retirement from the post on 30 June as his six-month extension comes to an end. Air Vice Marshal Udeni Priyadarshana Rajapaksa, a distinguished military officer, received his primary education at Parakrama Vidyalaya, Bandarawatta and Bandaranayake College, Gampaha. Continuing his academic journey, he pursued his secondary education at Ananda College, Colombo. Displaying a strong commitment to serving his country, he joined the Kotelawala Defence Academy in Ratmalana as an Officer Cadet on 6 October 1988, as part of the 6th Officer Cadet Intake and earned a Bachelor of Science degree in Electrical Engineering. Air Vice Marshal Rajapaksa underwent Basic Combat Training and Graduate Studies at the Kotelawala Defence Academy. Thereafter, he completed Basic Flying Training at No. 1 Flying Training Wing, Sri Lanka Air Force Base Anuradhapura, where he excelled and was recognised as the Best Flight Cadet in the 33rd Flight Cadet course. Following the achievement, he advanced to No. 2 Squadron, Sri Lanka Air Force Base Ratmalana, for Advanced Flying Training. On 5 October 1990, he was commissioned as a Pilot Officer in the General Duties Pilot Branch. Air Vice Marshal Rajapaksa has expertise as a pilot in a remarkable range of aircraft, including the Pucará as a Fighter Pilot and Cessna 150, Harbin Y-12, Avro 748, SIAI-Marchetti SF.260, Beechcraft, Antonov An-32 and Lockheed C-130 Hercules as a Transport Pilot. By Gagani Weerakoon

title: ‘Aswesuma’ doesn’t cater to everyone in need
author: Author not found
Content: The Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) expressed concerns that the ‘Aswesuma’ programme does not cater to a sufficient number of beneficiaries. During a media briefing held yesterday (28), SJB MP Eran Wickramaratne said the think-tank LIRNEasia has claimed that the poverty rate in Sri Lanka was 14 per cent in 2019 and has now increased to 32 per cent. Wickramaratne pointed out that 47 per cent of the population has reduced the amount of food consumed at home, and not only that, but one-third of the meal size has also decreased. He added, “If any savings were made to provide for children, 50 per cent of those savings have been used, and 32 per cent of those who fulfil their daily needs have no assets or homes and are in debt.” Further, he mentioned the welfare programme ‘Aswesuma,’ is intended to benefit 200,000 individuals. “There are around 400,000 people in the interim section, around 400,000 people at risk, around 800,000 poor individuals, and around 400,000 extremely poor individuals. This is based on an analysis of 22 indicators and information from the World Bank,” he explained. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: 40-year-old suspect arrested
author: Author not found
Content: A 40-year-old individual was arrested by the Piliyandala Police on Tuesday (27) evening for attacking a 19-year-old female with a sharp weapon, resulting in critical head injuries. According to Police, the incident took place in Arawwala, Piliyandala when the victim was returning home from work in the evening. Police said the incident was captured on a CCTV camera installed at a nearby building. Preliminary investigations showed the suspect is a drug addict and the attack on the victim was a result of a dispute between her father and the suspect. The victim was admitted to Homagama Base Hospital and transferred to National Hospital Colombo for further treatment. The suspect was arrested by Police while hiding on a telephone tower in the area. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Public advised to lodge Police complaints
author: Author not found
Content: Deputy General Manager of the Railway Department, V.S. Polwattage, has urged the public to inform the department or lodge complaints with nearby Police stations regarding individuals involved in the theft of railway track accessories, such as nails. Polwattage said these thefts have resulted in numerous train derailments in the past. “An incident occurred recently where a train departing from Fort Railway Station derailed near Baseline Railway Station, causing the engine and three compartments to jump the rails. As a result, train services on this route have been suspended until the necessary repairs are completed,” he said.  Polwattage said those who engage in theft underestimate the seriousness of their actions. Therefore, it is essential for the public to exercise caution and report any suspicious activities to the authorities, including the Police, he said. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Registrar of Births, Deaths mobile service a success
author: Author not found
Content: The mobile service of the Registrar of Births and Deaths, at Akkaraipattu Divisional Secretariat, successfully issued over 200 certificates yesterday (28). The event, themed ‘New Village, New Country’, took place at the Divisional Secretariat and was conducted under the guidance of Additional Registrar General M.M.H. Saman Kumara. The officers from the Akkaraipattu Divisional Registrar (ADR), led by Additional District Registrar M.M. Shamil Moulana, provided the mobile service.

title: Liquor producers given 14 days to settle tax dues
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya, yesterday (28), said certain liquor manufacturers in the country have been instructed to settle their tax dues within a period of 14 days. Addressing the media at the President’s Media Centre (PMC), Siyambalapitiya said the Government owed approximately Rs 6.16 billion in taxes and overdue payments from distilleries. The State Minister said the tax payments are expected to be recovered from 10 liquor manufacturing companies. As a result, the companies were summoned on Tuesday (27) and instructed to settle their outstanding payments within 14 days. Appropriate action will be taken against those companies if they fail to comply with the payment deadline, he stressed. Furthermore, the State Minister revealed that a set of unique recommendations, including the establishment of a special Court, will soon be forwarded to the President for his approval in order to address legal issues related to tax collection. (MD)

title: COPE calls for new Sathosa business model
author: Author not found
Content: Parliament watchdog, the Committee on Public Enterprises (COPE) said instead of importing and selling goods, Lanka Sathosa could increase its customer base and profits if it buys good from Pettah. Lanka Sathosa Ltd was called before COPE recently under the chairmanship of Member of Parliament (Prof.) Ranjith Bandara to investigate primary facts related to the 2019 and 2020 Auditor General’s reports and present performance. In response, Lanka Sathosa officials explained the loss was due to the delay in receiving money and the goods were imported based on the policy decisions of the Government. The COPE Chair emphasised the need to prepare a business model suitable for Sathosa. The Auditor General also pointed out the internal administrative weaknesses as well as the need to establish this institution under a business model that can make decisions independently without external interference. The Committee also emphasised the need to attract more customers to Lanka Sathosa stores. Attention was drawn towards the fact that a concrete plan for 2021-24 was in place but it was not approved by the Ministry. Therefore, the Committee Chair informed the officials to prepare a comprehensive plan up until 2028 and report on its activities within 2 months. The COPE Chair further instructed to prepare an action plan. It was discussed that although there are 21 internal audit staff, only 3 audits have been submitted for 2021 and none for 2022. Moreover, attention was drawn to the auditor’s difficulty in obtaining information regarding the company’s accounts. Accordingly, the Auditor General also informed that the Internal Audit Department should be notified in this regard through an internal circular. It was disclosed that during 2014-2015, there was a loss of Rs 6 billion due to rice imports through Lanka Sathosa. It was also discussed that the imported rice has been sold for animal feed due to expiry. A report has been prepared by the Auditor General regarding this incident and thus it was decided by the Committee to discuss this matter in the future. The Chair also said the loss of Lanka Sathosa in 2022 is close to Rs 600 million. It was also discussed that the total loss by 31 December 2021 is close to Rs 15 billion. Moreover, there are 1,123 vacancies in the institution and the Auditor General pointed out the need for a re-evaluation before filling those employee vacancies.

title: Termites attack Panadura Base Hospital ICU
author: Author not found
Content: The Panadura Base Hospital administration is currently facing a dilemma following what began as a termite infestation, in its Intensive Care Unit (ICU), informed hospital sources said yesterday (28). According to the sources, the High Dependency Unit (HDU) of the Hospital had been converted into a temporary ICU when termites were found in the Unit last month. Pest control measures were taken while the ICU had been temporarily closed for two weeks owing to the chemical used. Hospital authorities had taken the decision to extend the period of closure and complete renovations in the ICU. The ICU was in need of urgent renovations and repair due to age. Fielding queries, the sources said that all possible measures had been taken to prevent patients from being inconvenienced.  The HDU was converted into the Hospitals temporary ICU and ventilators were installed. They assured that if the necessity arose at least two more beds could be set up.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: SJB strongly opposes local debt restructuring– Harsha
author: Author not found
Content: The Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) has made it clear that they vehemently oppose the proposed local debt restructuring, Dr. Harsha de Silva said yesterday (28). Speaking at a media briefing yesterday, Dr. de Silva said the SJB does not agree with the idea of restructuring local debt. He highlighted the lack of clarity regarding the specific proposals put forth by the Government. He emphasised that if the proposal includes a 20 per cent reduction in any form, the SJB’s opposition remains firm. While the exact details of the Government’s proposal are yet to be seen, it is expected to be presented to Cabinet and the Committee on Public Finance in the coming days. “The impact of this deduction on individuals who have deposited money in banks will play a crucial role in determining the SJB’s response. If the Central Bank (CBSL) offers fixed deposits for five years, and the Government suggests extending them for another five years while only paying additional interest for that period, the SJB is entirely against such a proposition,” he asserted. Speaking further, he said when people deposit their hard-earned money in banks, those funds are lent to entrepreneurs and industrialists by the banks. If the government delays repaying the loans taken from the bank within five years and depositors demand the return of their money, the bank should have the capacity to fulfil these requests, he pointed out. “As per the Central Bank’s regulations, any liquidity requirements faced by banks should be addressed by the Central Bank itself,” he said. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Pregnant teacher harassed by Education officials
author: Author not found
Content: In a disturbing incident at Mattakotuwa Primary School, in Chilaw, a pregnant teacher has been subjected to harassment and undue scrutiny, for reporting to the work wearing a maternal dress, the Ceylon Teachers’ Union (CTU) alleged. The CTU said the Zonal Director of Education posted a complaint against the pregnant teacher, instructing her not to wear the dress again. Furthermore, a Deputy Director of Education from the Chilaw zone allegedly scolded the teacher over the phone during working hours, claiming that her photo was circulating on social media. The teacher reportedly fainted as a result of the distress caused by this incident. In a subsequent development, the Regional Director of Education visited Kakkapalliya Siri Sujatha College, where the teacher was working part-time and posted a similar complaint, urging people to come to school dressed in saree. Additionally, a preliminary investigation was initiated against the teacher regarding her adherence to the Ministry of Education’s circular letter on clothing during pregnancy. Speaking about the disturbing incident, CTU General Secretary Joseph Stalin criticised the Zonal Director of Education, saying their actions displayed a lack of understanding of the relevant circulars pertaining to the attire of public officials and pregnant teachers. Stalin emphasised that the only active circular relevant to public officials’ attire is Circular 08/89, which specifically addresses staff officers and is not applicable to teachers. Stalin further condemned the zonal education director for committing several serious duty errors, including keeping log notes against the teacher, violating circulars, disobeying orders from superiors and improperly exerting authority over others. He pointed out that the preliminary investigation carried out against the teacher, by the Regional Director of Education, is illegal, as the disciplinary authority for public officials lies with the Secretary of the Public Service Commission. The CTU has demanded the immediate withdrawal of the investigation and warned of legal action if the matter is not resolved promptly. The organisation stresses the need for education officers to exercise their authority responsibly and exhibit a thorough understanding of the applicable circulars to avoid such incidents in the future. According to the CTU, the Madampe Police, that were involved in handling the complaint filed by the teacher’s husband, have reportedly provided legal guidance to the relevant education officials and urged them to adhere to the circulars intelligently. The Police instructed the officials to withdraw the complaint against the teacher and refrain from interfering with her choice of attire considering her pregnancy. The CTU commended the intervention of the Police regarding the matter. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.
