title: Nas Daily to collaborate with Sri Lanka Tourism
author: Author not found
Content: Nuseir Yassin, the popular Palestinian-Israeli creator of viral video sensation ‘Nas Daily’, plans to create three videos to promote Sri Lanka for tourism and investment. In 2020, Yassin created Nas Academy, a school for video creators and Nas Studios, a video production studio. Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando said Cabinet approval has been received to create social media content with Nas Daily, under Finance Ministry supervision. Yassin will create three videos for Sri Lanka on the themes, ‘Why invest in Sri Lanka?’, ‘The craziest train ride in Sri Lanka’ and ‘Waterfalls in Sri Lanka’. Yassin previously featured Sri Lanka in his 1,000, one-minute video series. Some of the notable titles about the country include ‘This is Made of Poop?’ (explaining how locals turn elephant dung into paper), ‘My Biggest Money Mistake’ (on the economic growth of the country), and ‘The Key Board Warrior’ (about the inspiring story of the late Irfan Hafiz, an author who suffered from Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy). In 2020, Nas Daily released another video on Sri Lanka titled ‘The Most Generous Country During Covid.’ By Adnan Ali Cassim

title: TID permitted to probe Ven’ ble Siridhamma Thera’s bank accounts
author: Author not found
Content: The Colombo Chief Magistrate’s Court granted permission to the Terrorism Investigation Division (TID), yesterday (28), to investigate 19 bank accounts belonging to Ven. Galwewa Siridhamma Thera, who is out on bail after being arrested under the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA). The TID had requested the Court’s permission to investigate the bank accounts. Former Inter University Students’ Federation (IUSF) Convener Wasantha Mudalige was the first accused in this case. The Court released him citing lack of evidence. Mudalige and Ven. Siridhamma Thera had been detained, under the PTA, for 90-days last year and were later remanded by the Court. Ven. Thera was granted bail on 23 November 2022. BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Health Ministry’s affidavit comes under fire
author: Author not found
Content: Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella and a section of his officials came under severe censure, for having created a bigger quandary for the State health service, by filing an affidavit in the Court of Appeal saying that the Health Ministry had no objections to extending the age of retirement of medical officers, specified in the Gazette Notification, bearing No.2310/07 dated 12 December 2022, up to 63 years. Health sources in the Ministry yesterday (28) alleged that instead of defending the budgetary decision and the collective responsibility which he bore as a Minister by upholding the Cabinet decision, taken with regard to the retirement age, Minister Rambukwella has made a move to keep certain officials of the Health Ministry and medical practitioners happy so as to subdue issues pertaining to medicinal drugs which emerged recently. It is apparent that the Cabinet would be left to unravel the problems which would come up as a result. The age of retirement was limited to 60 years on a 2022 budgetary proposal taken in Parliament. Therefore it may seem as though the Court would have no right to reverse a decision taken through the Constitution. All State employees are faced with that decision where their retirement age has been limited to 60 years with no exceptions, they noted. Health Secretary A. Janaka Sri Chandragupta submitted an affidavit in the Court of Appeal on Tuesday (27) declaring that his Ministry had no objections to extending the age of retirement of medical officers, specified in the Gazette Notification, bearing No. 2310/07 dated 12 December 2022, up to 63 years “subject to obtaining approval from the Cabinet of Ministers and other relevant authorities pursuant to submitting a Cabinet Memorandum in that regard.” The medical practitioners included in last December’s Gazette Notice include grade medical officers, specialists, Medical Administrators, dental surgeons,  and  registered medical officers. The budgetary decision last year declared that the age of retirement of all State employees would be brought down from 65 years to 60 years of age.   Sources warned that this would only create further unrest in the State health service as other service categories such as nurses and professions supplementary to medicine and paramedical services would also demand the same. President of the Government Medical Officers Forum (GMOF), Dr. Rukshan Bellana alleged that at a time when the government was going through an economic crisis and was depending on the International Monetary Fund (IMF), which wanted it tone down its workforce burden, the Health Minister and his officials were attempting to make a joke of decision taken by the Parliament and Cabinet. Dr. Bellana noted that if there was a shortage of consultants for sub specialities there were possibilities of extending their services on contract basis rather than extending the age of retirement of all medical practitioners and thereby increasing the burden on the government.     By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Women Para jumpers a first in SLN history
author: Author not found
Content: For the first time in the history of the Sri Lanka Navy, the first group of women Para jumpers, comprising two officers and three sailors, successfully completed their basic parachute course at the Sri Lanka Air Force Parachute Training School, Ampara on 21 June. Going by an idea mooted by the Commander of the Navy, Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera, this particular group of women grabbed the opportunity to follow the first ever basic parachute course, marking a historic milestone for gender equality and women’s prowess in the Sri Lanka Navy. With a view of competing in the Defence Services Free Fall Parachute (Skydiving) Tournament with a Sri Lanka Navy team of women Para jumpers, a group of wome officers and sailors were attached to Sri Lanka Air Force Parachute Training School, for their basic parachute course. Having qualified from a special mental and physical fitness test in this regard, the officers – Lieutenant Iresha Madushani and Lieutenant Prasadi Nadeeshani and sailors –Able Physical Training Instructor Ayesha Wijayarathna, Ordinary Seaman Maheesha Ranasinghe and Ordinary Seaman Kaushi Thisera successfully completed the basic parachute course. The course was held from 24 April to 21 June at the Sri Lanka Air Force Parachute Training School, Ampara. The Basic Parachute Course No. 52 at Sri Lanka Air Force Parachute Training School was followed by 43 personnel (both men and women) from the Army, Navy, Air Force and Police Special Task Force. On successful completion of theoretical classroom sessions and ground training, they mastered essential skills such as aircraft exit procedures from An-32 of the Sri Lanka Air Force, form 800 – 1,000 high in the sky to the premises of Air Force Parachute Training School, Ampara. The five successful jumps they made also included a night parachute jump and a tactical equipment jump. Following successfully completed their basic parachute course, this group of women Para jumpers, of the Sri Lanka Navy, are expected to participate in the Skydiving Course scheduled to commence at the Air Force Parachute Training School, Ampara on 2 July. Highlighting the growing recognition of women’s capabilities in  traditionally male-dominated fields, they will be attached to the Parachute Pool of the Sri Lanka Navy and participate in joint operations, training exercises and parachute displays in due course. (SM)

title: Rs 208B allocated for welfare programmes – Ratnapriya
author: Author not found
Content: A total of Rs 208 billion has been set aside to provide Samurdhi relief and towards other welfare programmes being implemented targeting the poor and those who live below the poverty line, Director General of Trade Unions to the President Saman Ratnapriya said yesterday (28). He said Sri Lanka was drifting into anarchy and facing its worst economic crisis last year. The poverty gap was widening and over 500,000 persons had lost their jobs. It is the worst crisis Sri Lanka has faced since receiving independence from the British 75 years ago, Ratnapriya said. He said rescuing them from this tragic situation was the prime focus of the ‘Aswesuma’ welfare programme. Speaking to the media at Sirikotha, Ratnapriya said everyone knows that there are many shortcomings in the Samurdhi relief programme and added that a total of 17 million people received Samurdhi subsidy on average and unfortunately those who were not entitled to this programme were also among them. It has come to light that there are people among the beneficiaries who lend money on interest on a six-month or one-year basis, Ratnapriya said. This problem has been unresolved for a long time. It had been emphasised in 2002 to formulate a new effective programme by conducting a census, but no Government did so, Ratnapriya charged.  There are nearly 51,000 persons who have kidney complications, those suffering from various ailments and there were plans to give this aid to 2 million people. The World Bank had recommended increasing benefits for those at the grassroots level as the present relief assistance is not sufficient to combat the increasing needs, Ratnapriya added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: USD 17B foreign debt to be restructured in five years
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe has announced that the Government of Sri Lanka has set a goal to restructure a significant portion of its foreign debt, amounting to USD 17 billion, within a period of five years. The President’s Media Division (PMD), in a statement said, this restructuring plan is part of a larger effort to address the country’s total foreign debt of USD 41.5 billion. The President made these remarks during the inauguration ceremony of the new building of the Gampaha District Secretariat. The President emphasised that it is also necessary to restructure Sri Lanka’s local debt. However, he assured that this restructuring process would not have any negative impact on the stability of the country’s banking system, which includes both state-owned and private banks under the supervision of the Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL). President Wickremesinghe reassured that the restructuring of local debt would not affect deposits held in the banking system and there would be no impact on the interest paid on bank deposits. He further stated that the restructuring would not impact the member balances of superannuation funds, such as the Employee’s Provident Fund (EPF) and the Employees’ Trust Fund (ETF). The rate of return on these funds that has been paid in the past will also remain unaffected by the debt restructuring.

title: SL to train over 50,000 seafarers in coming years
author: Author not found
Content: Minister Nimal Siripala de Silva expressed Sri Lanka’s strong commitment to becoming a prominent hub for seafarer training and employment, with a target of increasing the number of trained seafarers to over 50,000 in the coming years. He said this during his speech at the Seafarer 2050 Conference, held on 26 June, at the Conrad Hotel in Manila. The conference, themed ‘Shaping the Future of Shipping,’ brought together government ministers, regulators, financiers, NGOs, ship owners, industry CEOs, and technology and infrastructure providers. During his address, Minister de Silva emphasised ten key areas that Sri Lanka is focusing on to ensure its preparedness for the challenges of 2050. These areas include strengthening maritime education and training, fostering collaboration with the industry, embracing technology advancements, developing soft skills and cultural competence, implementing mental health support and social security measures, prioritising safety and emergency response capabilities, promoting environmental awareness, investing in research and development, ensuring regulatory compliance, and fostering continuous professional development through international collaboration.  The opening session of the conference featured an inauguration by Emanuele Grimaldi, Chairman of the International Chamber of Shipping, followed by a speech from President Ferdinand R. Marcos Jr. of the Philippines. President Marcos stressed the importance of the shipping industry integrating new developments, particularly technological advancements, into their fleets. He also emphasised the need to invest in a highly qualified and well-trained workforce. During the keynote session, a video address from the Minister of Ports, Shipping, and Aviation of Sri Lanka highlighted the country’s vision for the future of shipping and underscored the crucial role of seafarers. The conference programme included policy discussions on the economic value of seafarers to the national economy, lessons learnt from other sectors, the significance of retraining and reskilling seafarers for a just transition, and policy recommendations to support the fair transformation of the shipping sector. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Police fire warning shots to disperse mob
author: Author not found
Content: Police fired 38 rounds of warning shots following a tense situation in front of the Hanguranketha Police Station on Monday (26) night. More than 200 people protested over the failure to arrest a group of suspects in connection with the murder of a resident in Diyathilakapura, Hanguranketha. The Police fired warning shots when the group tried to forcibly enter the Police station. According to Police Spokesman SSP Nihal Thalduwa, the Hanguranketha Police arrested one suspect for a brutal assault on 21 June, in which a father and his 23-year-old son were critically injured over a land dispute. The son succumbed to his injuries on 26 June, four days after being admitted to the Kandy National Hospital. The suspect was produced in Court and remanded. However, area residents who were enraged over the failure to arrest the other suspects gathered in front of the Police station on 26 June. On 27 June, the Police made another eight arrests in connection with the murder. The suspects, aged 19 to 63, surrendered to the Kandy Police earlier in the day. They are residents of Mathurata, Rikillagaskadawala, and Udawaththakumbura. By Keerthi Mendis

title: SL greatly values China’s continuous support – PM
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena said Sri Lanka greatly values China’s continuous support to the country. He said this when Chinese Ambassador to Sri Lanka Qi Zhenhong met him at Temple Trees on Monday (26) to discuss bilateral relations. The Prime Minister said Sri Lanka looks forward to direct investments from China as well as investments in agriculture, renewable energy, IT, education and water supply sectors to provide long-term solutions to economic issues. The areas covered during the discussion included issues relating to new investment projects, furthering trade with China, Colombo Port City, Hambantota Port, poverty alleviation programmes, education, agriculture, cultural exchanges, high-level exchanges and assistance to the underprivileged. The Prime Minister made a special request to support the Sri Lankan rice-growing rural population to increase production by introducing high-yielding rice varieties developed in Yunnan Province in China. Ambassador Qi Zhenhong said he was pleased to see the resilience of Sri Lanka to overcome difficulties and assured China’s continuous support to Sri Lanka’s efforts to meet the present efforts at debt restructuring and meet economic challenges. He said he planned to visit schools in remote areas of Badulla and Buttala to distribute educational needs. The Prime Minister thanked Zhenhong for the assistance provided by China to alleviate the present economic crisis in Sri Lanka and made a special mention of the Chinese stand in support of Sri Lanka’s sovereignty at the international forums including the UNHRC. The discussion was initiated with a satisfactory reference to the historical bilateral relations between the two countries. On the importance of further strengthening longstanding cultural ties, the Chinese Ambassador said the Chinese Buddhist Associations will continue to help temples and set up internationally important Theravada Buddhist Centre in Sri Lanka. The Prime Minster agreed to set up a Coordinating Committee to expeditiously implement these proposals. Prime Minister’s Secretary Anura Dissanayake was also present at this meeting.

title: Air China to resume Colombo flights on 3 July
author: Author not found
Content: Air China will resume flights to Sri Lanka on 3 July, aviation officials said. As a Covid control measure, China prevented its citizens from travelling overseas and reopened for tourism in early February. The airline will operate three weekly flights between Chengdu and Colombo. Meanwhile, Sri Lanka Tourism Development Authority (SLTDA) Director General Priyantha Fernando said SLTDA is forecasting revenue of USD 2 billion from tourism in 2023. Additionally, it is expected that the number of Chinese tourists visiting Sri Lanka will continue to rise in the coming months. He added that Sri Lanka has already welcomed 13,771 Chinese tourists this year. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Good Governance Govt not to blame– Akila Viraj
author: Author not found
Content: UNP Assistant Leader Akila Viraj Kariyawasam has refuted claims that the failure of the tab computer programme for schoolchildren was the fault of the Good Governance Government led by the United National Front (UNF). Kariyawasam was the Minister of Education during the Good Governance Government. Speaking at a media briefing held at Sirikotha, Kariyawasam expressed his disappointment with the circulation of news stories that falsely accuse the previous government with regard to this matter. He said extensive efforts had been made to finalise arrangements to provide tab computers to students under the Good Governance Government, on the instructions of President Ranil Wickremesinghe. Unfortunately, due to the change in government in 2019, this programme couldn’t be implemented. Kariyawasam said the plan was initially to distribute tab computers to G.C.E. A/L students and later expand it to include students up to Grade 6. The required number of teachers had been trained, and an efficient content plan had been prepared. However, after the new government came to power, they implemented a different programme that contradicted the previous plans and recommendations, disregarding the Cabinet decision made during the Good Governance Government. According to Kariyawasam, tab computers and laptops were distributed to security forces, departments, and teachers at the College of Education, neglecting the targeted group of schoolchildren. This resulted in a significant waste of funds without any tangible benefits or outcomes. Kariyawasam told the public not to blame the Good Governance Government for the failure of the programme. The project had received approval through 14 Cabinet papers, but unfortunately, it could not be implemented following the change in government. He emphasised that the Good Governance Government cannot be held responsible as they had initiated the programme and expressed concern that it did not achieve its intended objectives.  By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Speaker endorses Parliamentary Budget Office Bill
author: Author not found
Content: Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana signed the Parliamentary Budget Office Bill yesterday (27) which was debated and passed in Parliament last week. The Budget Office was set up to assist Parliament, which has the power to control public finances, to fulfil its responsibilities on public finance with an independent, non-biased economic and financial analysis and vision on income and expenditure. Further, the Speaker endorsed the certificate to the recently passed Civil Procedure Code (Amendment) Bill. Accordingly, the two Bills will come into force as the Parliamentary Budget Office Act No. 6 of 2023 and the Code of Civil Procedure (Amendment) Act No. 7 of 2023. Secretary-General of Parliament Kushani Rohanadeera and Director of Legislative Services and Director of Communications (Acting) Janakantha Silva were also present at this occasion.

title: Tour Operators against minimum room rates for City Hotels
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Association of Inbound Tour Operators (SLAITO) has strongly rejected the Sri Lanka Tourism Development Authority (SLTDA) directive that sets minimum room rates for city hotels in Colombo. SLAITO claims that they were not consulted prior to the SLTDA taking this decision and that the minimum rates are not competitive. However, the SLTDA has stated that it was the two major associations, namely The Hotels Association of Sri Lanka (THASL) and the Colombo City Hotels Association (CCHA), who requested the introduction of minimum rates for Colombo city hotels. After three months of discussions, these associations could not reach a conclusion. In response, the SLTDA requested them to submit a written request, following which the SLTDA proposed a minimum rate of USD 130 per room for city hotels. This minimum rate and the directive suggest that everyone should promote rooms priced above USD 130, considering that five-star hotels currently sell rooms at rates exceeding this threshold. As room rates are determined by market demands, this directive has been sent to all tourism associations and a copy has also been forwarded to the presidential secretariat. SLAITO argues that the directive on minimum room rates does not align with their markets and will place Sri Lanka at a disadvantage compared to other countries. They contend that Sri Lanka’s competitive markets will suffer while competitors gain an advantage. Presently, there are over 7,000 rooms in city hotels in Colombo, and these establishments are already competing with hotels in New Delhi. SLAITO emphasises that the new rate directive will not benefit Sri Lanka. They have expressed their concerns to the Minister of Tourism, Harin Fernando, who has also acknowledged the lack of clear guidance regarding the room rates. Currently, room rates in city hotels range between USD 65 and 80. However, the directive proposes an increase to USD 130. SLAITO believes that before implementing such prescribed rates, it is crucial to generate demand and interest in Sri Lanka. They argue that adopting these rates will render Sri Lanka uncompetitive and result in a loss of clients, even when compared to hotels in New Delhi, with which they are currently competitive. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Protest seeking President’s intervention over ownership of temple
author: Author not found
Content: A group of villagers held a protest in the Nedunkerni town on Sunday (25) demanding that the President intervenes to confirm the ownership of two temples: the Kurudumale Temple in Mullaithivu and the Lingeswara Hindu Temple in Nedunkerni, Vavuniya. During the protest, the villagers voiced their concerns regarding the division of land believed to belong to the Kurundumale Temple urging the President to order the use of boundary stones to demarcate the boundaries accurately. They also emphasised the need for the President to confirm the ownership of the Vedukkunari, Nedunkerni and Lingeswara Hindu Temples. The protesters expressed their discontent over the placement of Buddha statues and the construction of Buddhist stupas near the Hindu temples in the northern region. They claimed that these actions have hindered Hindu devotees from conducting their religious activities and alleged that the Department of Archaeology has forcefully acquired a significant amount of land belonging to the people of the north. The protest was aimed to draw the President’s attention to these issues and seek his intervention in resolving the ownership disputes and preserving the religious sanctity of the temples mentioned. BY Rasadi Chathurangi Gamage – Vavuniya

title: Indo – SL Joint Project underway– Herath
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Technology Kanaka Herath stated that the Indo-Sri Lanka Joint Project for the Sri Lanka Unique Digital Identity Project (SL-UDI) is underway and that biographic and biometric information, facial, iris and fingerprint will be collected and entered into a central system to issue identification cards. The State Minister said this at the first meeting of the Ministerial Consultative Committee on Technology of the Fourth Session of the Ninth Parliament held recently. Further, digitalising information under one identification number in all documents starting from the birth certificate was discussed at length. The officials present stated that though the proposal to do so has already been adopted and is in progress, the mechanism of execution has caused it to stall. The Committee suggested that rather than trying to digitise past documents which causes delays and backlogs, to skip the past generations and begin fresh from one batch which will allow it to move forward. MPs Imran Maharoof, Samanpriya Herath, Weerasumana Weerasinghe, Ashoka Priyantha, and Gunathilaka Rajapaksha were present at the Committee meeting.

title: CEB rolls out next phase of e-Billing
author: Author not found
Content: The Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) has announced the launch of the next phase of their e-Billing system, which will come into effect on 1 July. Through this initiative, it is expected to save approximately 100 million sheets of paper annually. Customers residing in the Dehiwala, Kelaniya, and Sri Jayewardenepura areas will exclusively receive their electricity bills in a digital format, delivered either through SMS or email, the CEB said in a statement. “This change marks a departure from the conventional practice of issuing printed paper bills. By transitioning to electronic billing, the CEB aims to streamline operations and offer a more eco-friendly solution. CEB encourages all its customers nationwide to register promptly for this convenient service, as the issuance of printed paper bills will gradually be phased out in the coming months. To register via SMS, customers need to type REG followed by a space and their A/C Number, and send it to 1987. Alternatively, they can visit the official website http://ebill.ceb.lk and follow the provided instructions to register online,” the statement said.

title: School needs gifted to children’s home
author: Author not found
Content: Under the guidance of General Officer Commanding 24 Infantry Division, Major General Vipula Chandrasiri, and the coordination of Commander 241 Infantry Brigade, Colonel L.S.D.N. Pathirathna, school equipment, consisting of bags, shoes, exercise books, and stationery, was distributed to 40 students residing in the Akkaraipattu Swami Vipulananda Children’s Home. This was made possible due to the efforts taken by the Commander 241 Infantry Brigade in organising overseas donors and local philanthropists, who are also members of the ‘Lions Club of Raigampurawaraya 306 A-2’. Lion Alikan (Osaka Lanka), Lion S. Sivadasa (Siva Distributors), Lion Dr. A.A.E Nuwan Madushanka, Lion Priyanthi de Silva (Australia), Lion Shiron Gunawardana (UK), Ponnerselvam (Switzerland), and medical professionals of Base Hospital Akkaraipattu extended financial assistance to support this event.  The distribution ceremony, chaired by the founder President of the Vipulanada Children’s Home, T. Kailayapillai, was graced by the Divisional Secretary of Alayadivembu, Major General W. Chandrasiri, Commander 241 Infantry Brigade, Colonel L.S.D.N. Pathirathna, Lt. Colonel Thilak Kumarasiri, and religious dignitaries. BY M.A.P. Deen – Ampara

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Human Resources Development Plan for BIMSTEC presented to PM
author: Author not found
Content: The Human Resources Development (HRD) Plan, for the Bay of Bengal Initiative, for Multi-Sectoral Technical and Economic Cooperation (BIMSTEC) region, was presented to Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena at a meeting held on 26 June 2023, at Temple Trees. The National Human Resources Development Council (NHRDC) made this presentation. At the gathering, Dr. Chandra Embuldeniya, the appointed Team Leader for developing the HRD plan, delivered a comprehensive presentation outlining the strategic vision for advancing human capital development in the BIMSTEC member countries. Under the purview of the Ministry of Public Administration, Home Affairs, Provincial Councils and Local Government, the NHRDC has been entrusted with spearheading human resources development efforts in Sri Lanka. chaired by Thusitha P. Wanigasinghe, the Council comprises members from various government ministries, educational institutions and key commissions. During the meeting, Dr. Chandra Embuldeniya provided a comprehensive overview of the strategic initiatives to foster human resources growth within the BIMSTEC region. The BIMSTEC member countries comprise Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Myanmar, Nepal, and Thailand. The HRD plan encompasses various sectors, including education and vocational training, to enhance the region’s workforce’s skills, capabilities and employability. The Council’s presentation was well-received by the Prime Minister, who commended the collective efforts and emphasised the significance of collaborative initiatives in human resources development. Acknowledging the pivotal role of a skilled and empowered workforce in driving economic growth and regional cooperation, the Prime Minister expressed his support for the HRD plan and highlighted the importance of swift implementation to maximise its impact.

title: COYLE holds discussions on progressive labour reforms
author: Author not found
Content: The Chamber of Young Lankan Entrepreneurs (COYLE) held a crucial meeting at the Labour Department with the Minister of Labour, Manusha Nanayakkara, the Commissioner General of Labour, B.K. Prabath Chandrakeerthi, Adviser cum Private Secretary to the Minister, Shan Yahampath and other Ministry officials to address the need for important labour reforms. The primary focus of the meeting was to advocate for progressive labour regulations that will help to ensure a safe and conducive working environment for employees, complemented by a well-designed safety net post-employment. The meeting concluded on a very positive note with the department officials and COYLE in agreement to cooperate to venture into further possibilities of reviewing reforms to help develop a larger economy in Sri Lanka thereby creating a large pool of jobs. The post-pandemic situation as well as the economic crisis faced by Sri Lanka has resulted in the much-observed ‘brain drain’ that is occurring. COYLE believes this can only be prevented in the future years by ensuring that our economy has a significant increase in the number of private sector institutions capable of delivering sufficient wages to its workforce. The public sector has been burdened and rendered inefficient due to the large redundant workforce that has been brought onto its payroll by politically motivated decisions made by all governments during the past decades. This crisis should be the final catalyst for shifting the thought mechanism of burdening the public sector with short-term decision-making for political mileage to develop the private sector to amass a larger job pool and more career-building opportunities as all developed countries. COYLE shall be working closely with the ministry with the view of progressive reforms that remove the conflictive culture that presently exists between the Labour Department and the employer to put forth mechanisms that provide a fair safety net for employees whilst ensuring a more progressive legislation that will not deter investors away from Sri Lanka.

title: Cabinet approves Vidura’s proposal
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet approved a proposal submitted by Minister of Buddhasasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs Vidura Wickramanayake to appoint a committee to look into alleged insults against religious teachings and propose necessary legal provisions. The proposal entails the appointment of a committee comprising representatives from the major religions, namely Buddhism, Islam, Hinduism, Catholicism, and Christianity. The committee will also include individuals with expertise in the legal field, media, and civil society activism. Their task will be to thoroughly study the matter and provide recommendations. The committee’s objective is to examine the issue comprehensively and propose suitable measures to protect religious freedom and prevent any form of disrespect towards religious teachings or preaching. By bringing together religious leaders, legal experts, media professionals, and civil society activists, the committee aims to provide a well-rounded perspective and ensure that the proposed legal provisions align with the diverse needs and sensitivities of society.

title: ‘Mahavamsa’ added to UNESCO Memory of the World
author: Author not found
Content: The UNESCO Memory of the World (MoW) International Register for 2023 has recently included The Great Chronicle of Sri Lanka, known as the ‘Mahavamsa,’ as one of its 64 new items of documentary heritage. Spanning from the 6th Century BCE to 1815 CE, the ‘Mahavamsa’ provides a comprehensive historical account of Sri Lanka. It holds the distinction of being one of the world’s longest-unbroken historical narratives and stands as the pioneering work of its kind in South Asia. By presenting Sri Lanka’s history in chronological order, it established a mature historiographical tradition in the region. Archaeological research conducted in Sri Lanka and India has substantiated the authenticity of the information presented in the document. As a valuable historical source in South Asia, the ‘Mahavamsa’ offers crucial insights into significant events such as the life of the Buddha, Emperor Asoka, and the rise of Buddhism as a global religion. Further, the ‘Mahavamsa’ played a vital role in the dissemination of Buddhism in Southeast Asia and greatly contributed to shaping the historical identity of Emperor Asoka in India. The widespread existence of numerous manuscripts of the ‘Mahavamsa’ in various countries, as well as its transliteration and translation into several Southeast Asian and European languages, attests to its immense historical, cultural, literary, linguistic, and scholarly value. Inclusion in the Memory of the World Register signifies that the ‘Mahavamsa’ has been recommended by the International Advisory Committee and endorsed by the Director-General of UNESCO. It fulfils the selection criteria by demonstrating its global significance and outstanding universal value as a piece of documentary heritage.

title: Nawaloka Hospital achieves milestone in cardiac care
author: Author not found
Content: Pioneering the cardiac unit since 1994, Nawaloka Hospital, the leading healthcare institution, is proud to announce the successful completion of 15,000 heart surgeries, marking a significant milestone in the hospital’s history and affirming its position as a pioneer in cardiac care. To solidify the remarkable achievement of 15,000 successful heart surgeries, Nawaloka Hospitals celebrated an internal ceremony at the premises on 20 June. Nawaloka Holdings Chairman Dr. Jayantha Dharmadasa, Deputy Chairman Anisha Dharmadasa, DGM Prof. Lal Chandrasena and Directress Givanthi Dharmadasa and over 50 thoracic surgeon consultants and cardiologist consultants from past to present who have made a significant contribution to the unit were present at the ceremony. Nawaloka Hospitals has a distinguished record in cardiac care, boasting a rich history of pioneering achievements within the private sector of Sri Lanka. Over several decades, Nawaloka has accomplished numerous noteworthy milestones. These include conducting the country’s first Coronary Artery Bypass Graft (CABG) procedure on 15 August 1994, introducing the first Radial Artery Grafting in 1999, and successfully performing the inaugural Re-do CABG and Off-Pump Total Arterial Revascularisation in the same year. In 2000, the hospital achieved the first-ever Open Endarterectomy with Vein Patch. Not stopping there, Nawaloka further made advancements with breakthrough procedures such as the pioneering MIDCAB and Multi Vessel MIDCAB surgeries, as well as the first Pulmonary Arteriovenous Fistula treatment in the right lung and the inaugural Keyhole ASD surgery. In 2022, they made history once more by performing the first Hybrid Bypass within the private sector. Additionally, Nawaloka collaborated with the Madras Medical Mission to offer open heart surgeries free of charge to 18 underprivileged children through the Children’s Heart Project, an initiative promoted by Dr. P.N. Thenabadu. Notably, they also achieved the significant milestone of successfully operating on a premature baby while still in the incubator, performing the first-ever ligation of a persistent ductus arteriosus. Within 30 years of operation, Nawaloka Hospital’s relentless pursuit of excellence in cardiac care has been made possible by its continuous investment in cutting-edge technology and infrastructure. The hospital boasts state-of-the-art operation theatres, advanced diagnostic facilities, and dedicated intensive care units, ensuring the best possible outcomes for patients undergoing heart surgeries. As a result, with unwavering commitment and the latest technological advancements, Nawaloka has successfully performed a diverse range of heart surgeries, including complex procedures such as bypass surgeries, valve replacements, and minimally invasive interventions. In addition, Nawaloka Hospitals has also successfully performed over 66,000 angiograms and angioplasties which is a record for any private hospital in Sri Lanka. At present, Nawaloka Hospitals has two dedicated cardiac angiography units, six echocardiography machines, an 11-bed CICU, three-bed HDU, two dedicated cardiac OTs with a dedicated anaesthesia room, two heart-lung machines/heater coolers, four balloon pumps, 10 Consultation chambers for cardiac requirement and ACT Machines. Additionally, Nawaloka Hospitals also has two Cath Labs which has enabled many in and outstation cardiologists to use lab properties at any time, based on their convenience. Geared with the latest technology and affordable healthcare solutions of international standards and driven by a passionate, professional team of only the best consultants and nurses, Nawaloka Hospitals is fully committed to the principal vision of building a healthier, stronger Sri Lanka. For more information, contact the cardiac unit on 0776724517.

title: SL Embassy in Washington, D.C. hosts ‘Wharton Club of DC’ event
author: Author not found
Content: The Embassy of Sri Lanka in the United States, in collaboration with the Wharton Club of DC, hosted a vibrant evening reception on 23 June at the Embassy premises in Washington, D.C., promoting trade and investment opportunities in Sri Lanka among a large number of entrepreneurs and senior professionals of the Club. Ambassador Mahinda Samarasinghe, in his speech, highlighted that Sri Lanka was the first ever country in the South Asian region that adopted market economic policies liberalising the economy way back in 1977. He emphasised that even though the country faced severe economic challenges triggered by foreign exchange shortage in the last year, now the economy of the country is back on track from all fronts and invited attendees to make use of a vast array of trade and investment opportunities available in the country.  Chairman of DC Innovation Summit as well as President of the ‘Wharton Club of DC’ Alan Schlaifer, in his address, thanked the Ambassador and the staff for organising such a reception creating an important platform for the members of the Club to engage with the Embassy in promoting mutual interests. Minister (Commercial), Charitha Yattogoda of the Mission ran a detailed presentation to the audience briefing them about promotional opportunities for exportable Sri Lankan products in the US market while highlighting investment opportunities available in the country from the US perspective covering key potential areas such as manufacturing, ICT and IT -Enabled Services, logistics, tourism and leisure, renewable energy and in the Port City Colombo, inviting the attendees to consider Sri Lanka as their next trade and investment destination. Additionally, the investment-related promotional materials received from the Board of Investment of Sri Lanka and Port City Colombo (Pvt) Ltd, were distributed among the participants in addition to including key areas therein in the detailed presentation. On this occasion, the Embassy took the opportunity to boost tourism in Sri Lanka by exhibiting vivid photographic sceneries and screening tourist-oriented videos promoting diverse tourist attractions in the country while allowing the attendees to choose tour packages that suit them to visit Sri Lanka through a Washington, D.C. based tour operating company, ‘VoyagX’ that joined the event. A cultural recital showcased the talents of ‘Serendib Dance Troupe’ in Washington, D.C. captivating the attendees. Dances of both up-country and low-country styles that depicted Sri Lanka’s rich traditional dance heritage were performed. The talents of the troupe of ‘Ceylon Bera’ enthralled the crowd with the rhythms of Sri Lanka accompanied by instrumental music. A Bharatanatyam dance depicting the culture of the Tamil community was performed by the ‘Natraj School’ showcasing the vibrant diversity of Sri Lankan culture. Attendees were treated to a sumptuous authentic Sri Lankan dinner buffet with flavours of Ceylon spices prepared by a Sri Lankan chef with a live station serving ‘Hoppers’ and ‘Kottu Roti.’ The Embassy, to promote Ceylon Tea, made arrangements to serve all the visitors a freshly brewed cup of hot and iced Ceylon Tea sponsored by ‘Basilur’ and ‘Shan Teas’ (Sri Lanka) and ‘QTrade Teas & Herbs’ (California, USA) in a specially set up tea corner that demonstrated different types of tea. The event concluded with a raffle draw offering prizes of complimentary hotel packages for stays in reputed hotels in Sri Lanka from Siddhalepa Ayurveda Health Resort in Wadduwa, Theme Resorts & Spas, Cinnamon Hotels & Resorts, Tree of Life Nature Resort, Kandy and Theva Residency Boutique Hotel Kandy. The event was held parallel to the 9th Annual Wharton DC Innovation Summit hosted by the ‘Wharton Club of DC’ which is a business-focused membership organisation that provides opportunities for networking and lifelong learning to entrepreneurs and business leaders as well as professionals from elite/top universities and business schools, on 22 June in Washington, D.C.

title: PTC in case against Fowzie on 4 August
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Navaratne Marasinghe yesterday (27) fixed further hearing of the Pre-Trial Conference (PTC), of the lawsuit filed against former Minister A. H. M. Fowzie, to 4 August. The former Minister has been charged before the High Court, by Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC), of causing a loss of profit to the State, over the private use of a luxury vehicle, which had been set aside for the Disaster Management Centre (DMC) and thereby flouting Provisions contained in Sections of the Bribery Act. When the case was taken up for hearing, Judge Marasinghe fixed further proceedings of the PTC, to the said date. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: SL Consul General participates in Chariot Festival in Scarborough
author: Author not found
Content: The Consul General of Sri Lanka in Toronto participated in the Annual Chariot Festival of Chandramouleeshwara Sivan Temple in Scarborough on 24 June at the invitation of the Chief Priest of the Temple. This celebration was attended by over 1,500 Sri Lankan Tamil devotees, the Members of the Provincial Parliament and the Councillors of Municipalities. Addressing the gathering, the Consul General stated that the Sri Lankan Tamil community in Canada has become a dynamic force in the Canadian economy and its culture. The strong Tamil business community and the highly educated young Tamil professionals are the driving force behind the smooth integration of the Sri Lankan Tamils into Canadian society. The Consul General invited the Sri Lankan Tamil Canadian community to constructively engage in the reconciliation and economic development process of the Government of   Sri Lanka led by the President for a better future for all ethnic communities in the island.

title: Eleven schools closed down in Ncp – CTU President
author: Author not found
Content: President of the Ceylon Teachers’ Union (CTU) Priyantha Fernando said though the North-Central Province (Ncp) Governor continues to boast that he will ensure that the ratings in education in the province will be improved from the ninth position to first place by next year, 11 schools in the Province had been shut down since the appointment of the new Governor. He alleged that close to 50 schools were now on the verge of being closed down in the NCP due to haphazard decisions taken by the concerned Governor. Fernando added that before the appointment of the new Governor, the NCP had occupied the sixth position in islandwide results of the G.C.E. Ordinary Level Examination while in the Advanced Level results, it had been placed fifth. However, the trade unionist alleged that since 2020 the education sector of the NCP had begun to nosedive under the incumbent Governor. By Chula Bandara Kulasekera

title: ‘Aswesuma’ great injustice to Samurdhi beneficiaries – Namal
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) MP Namal Rajapaksa has expressed his concern regarding the Aswesuma survey, adding that it has resulted in great injustice to Samurdhi beneficiaries. According to him, deserving individuals have been overlooked while others who may not be eligible have received benefits. Rajapaksa emphasised the importance of conducting surveys properly and rectifying any mistakes promptly. He stressed that the survey should not be influenced by any political motives or biases. Instead, he urged the Government to approach this matter with compassion and take appropriate action to ensure that those who truly deserve prosperity receive the necessary support. He said, a fair and unbiased approach should be taken to the distribution of benefits, highlighting the need to prioritise the welfare of deserving individuals in society. By Dinithi Wijesundara

title: Navy launches mangrove planting programme
author: Author not found
Content: Taking a step towards coastal conservation, Sri Lanka Navy launched a mangrove planting programme in the lagoon area of Ullukkalei, Lankapatuna on 26 June. The event, which saw the planting of 1,000 mangrove saplings, was held under the patronage of Commander Eastern Naval Area and Commandant Volunteer Naval Force, Rear Admiral Dammika Kumara. On the directives of the Navy Commander, Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera, the Sri Lanka Navy is actively involved in planting mangroves in estuaries and lagoons as part of its ongoing mangrove conservation project across all naval commands. The recent initiative was yet another milestone of the timely project, organised by SLNS Lankapatuna in the Eastern Naval Command. Mangroves, known as the ‘forests of the sea,’ play a vital role in coastal ecosystems and provide habitat and breeding grounds for a wide range of marine and terrestrial species. Naval Officer-in-Charge (Trincomalee South) Commodore Asanga Rathugamage, a group of senior and junior officers, sailors, officials from government and non-governmental organisations in the area, schoolchildren and local residents were present on this occasion. (SM)

title: Court informed retirement age to be raised to 63
author: Author not found
Content: The Attorney General, yesterday (27), informed Court of Appeal that the health authorities have taken a decision to raise the retirement age of Consultant Specialist Doctors to 63 years. Additional Solicitor General Nerin Pulle PC, representing the Attorney General, informed Court that he had received instructions from the Secretary to the Ministry of Health regarding the decision to increase the retirement age of the petitioners to 63 years. He further stated that a Cabinet decision would also be taken to this effect. This was informed to Court in response to a writ petition filed by 176 consultant specialist doctors, who challenged the decision of the Cabinet of Ministers taken on 17 October 2022. The petitioners are Specialist Consultants in various fields of medicine, including Cardiology, Cardio-Thoracic Surgery, Oncology, Neurology, Obstetrics and Gynaecology, Haematology, Ophthalmology, Histopathology, Anaesthesia, Paediatrics, and Auto-Rhinolaryngology. They allege that the decision to lower their retirement age has been taken unlawfully and in violation of their legitimate expectation to continue in service until at least 63 years of age. ASG Pulle requested Court to allow him to file the motion and requested that the matter be mentioned on 30 June. President’s Counsel Sanjeeva Jayawardena, appearing for the petitioners, appreciated the decision to increase the retirement age and considered it a positive step. However, he strongly objected to the case being delayed until 30 June, as it would risk the petitioners having to retire by that date. He requested either to make submissions on the same day or for the case to be fixed for support on the following day, if a meaningful settlement could be reached by then. Jayawardena urged the Court to record the submission of the Attorney General. President’s Counsel Romesh de Silva, representing some of the petitioners, also requested for the matter to be fixed for support on the following day. In response to the requests, the Court of Appeal fixed the matter for support on the next day, 28 June, and recorded that the proposed settlement would allow all categories of medical professionals mentioned in the document marked A4 to continue in service until the age of 63.

title: Debt restructuring debate in Parliament this weekend – President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe, providing an update on the debt restructuring programme, told the French media ‘France24’ that the report on debt restructuring would be presented to the Cabinet on Friday (30) following its finalisation on Wednesday (28). Subsequently, it will be presented in Parliament before the Public Finance Committee and further discussed over the weekend. “Once approved in Parliament, the Government will proceed with the remaining negotiations with the creditors,” he pointed out. The President stressed that the Government’s objective was securing an extended repayment period for the debts and exploring the possibility of reducing the overall amount owed. Regarding the issue of USD 42 billion in debts, President Wickremesinghe explained the debt restructuring programme the government is working on. He highlighted that discussions are going on with all creditors, including China, although China has not officially joined the common platform for debt restructuring. “Nevertheless, China has actively participated in all meetings and has been kept informed through detailed information shared by Lazards, a financial and legal adviser hired by the government. China has also shared its information to Lazards, he said. The President expressed confidence in China’s alignment with the approach of other creditors. Reflecting on China’s recent deduction of credit from Zambia, President Wickremesinghe viewed it positively and mentioned the Chinese Prime Minister’s speech indicated China’s approach to Zambia’s debt restructuring programme. He acknowledged China’s assistance to Zambia and expressed hope that China’s approach would similarly align with Sri Lanka’s debt restructuring efforts.  Also, the President declared that the government has successfully met all the required benchmarks set by the World Bank, making them eligible for financial assistance of USD 700 million. In his interview, he emphasised the urgent need for this funding and highlighted its significant potential to strengthen the economy. The approval for this assistance will occur during the upcoming board meeting. The allocated funds from the World Bank will be utilised for budgetary and welfare purposes. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Eknaligoda abduction case put off to 24 July
author: Author not found
Content: The three-Judge Bench of the Colombo High Court yesterday (26) deferred, to 24 July, further hearing of the case against former Commandant of the Girithale Army Camp Shammi Kumararatne and eight other Army Intelligence Officers, accused of the alleged abduction and disappearance of journalist Prageeth Eknaligoda,. The case was taken up, before a Bench comprising Judges Sanjeewa Moraes and Mahen Weeraman. Later, the Bench, noticed three witnesses to the trial, to be present in Court at the next hearing. The Attorney General has indicted nine accused before the High Court on 17 counts, related to the alleged abduction and disappearance of Eknaligoda, on or before 25 January, 13 years ago, and for flouting Provisions contained in Sections 102, 356, 140, 146, 359, 32, 113, 355 and 296 of the Penal Code, via their actions. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: MCPA demands HRCSL act against Health Minister, officials
author: Author not found
Content: Medical and Civil Rights Professionals Association of Doctors (MCPA), demanded the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) move the law against Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella, Health Ministry Secretary Janaka Sri Chandragupta and several other top officials of the Health Ministry, for importing unregistered and substandard medicinal drugs which allegedly claimed the lives of some patients and rendered several others blind. MCPA President, Chamal Sanjeewa and several other civil rights organisations, filing a complaint, yesterday (26), with the HRCSL urged it to take action against the Health Minister, the Health Ministry Secretary, the Director General Health Services (DGHS), Dr. Asela Gunawardena, Additional Secretary to the Ministry Dr. Saman Ratnayake and the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA).  The People’s Movement against Bribery and Corruption, the MCPA and legal activists filed a complaint against the vision impairment and death of patients due to substandard drugs. The complainants alleged that despite the repeated cautioning, the Health Ministry and the NMRA continued to conduct emergency purchasing of unregistered and substandard medicinal drugs. It was reported that the Prednisolone used following surgery had caused a significant loss of vision in post surgical patients at the National Eye Hospital, Colombo, and the District General Hospital. According to reports it was also not possible to restore vision to the patients who had suffered its loss, the MCPA President lamented. Also, several deaths have been reported at the Teaching Hospital Peradeniya and Sirimavo Bandaranaike Hospital due to inferior anaesthetic drugs, he alleged observing that there were strong possibilities of there being unreported incidents across the island as well. Chairman of the People’s Movement against Bribery and Corruption Kamantha Roshan noted that this serious situation had occurred as officials were not afraid of bringing in substandard drugs because of the lack of law enforcement in the country. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: CBSL Governor explains reason for long bank holiday
author: Author not found
Content: Explaining as to why the bank sector was given a five-day holiday from 29 June, Central Bank (CBSL) Governor Dr. Nandalal Weerasinghe on Sunday (25) said the decision was taken in order to allow sufficient time for the implementation of Sri Lanka’s domestic debt optimisation strategy. In a special statement Dr. Weerasinghe assured the public that the restructuring of domestic debt would not have any negative impact on bank deposits or interest rates. He emphasised that all deposits in banks across the country would remain unaffected during this process. Despite June 30 being a bank holiday, the Governor clarified that banking activities such as internet banking, ATM withdrawals and fund transfers could be conducted as usual, whether the physical banks are open or not, he said. The CBSL Governor explained that the reason for declaring a bank holiday on 30 June was to provide enough days for the implementation of the domestic debt optimisation strategy. This strategy has been discussed extensively with the CBSL and the Ministry of Finance. Dr. Weerasinghe highlighted that it is crucial to announce and implement the strategy while obtaining the necessary approvals from the Cabinet, parliamentary committees and through parliamentary debates. This entire process requires approximately four days to be completed. Furthermore, Dr. Weerasinghe said the debt market and the economy market should not function during this period as the information regarding the strategy is highly sensitive and could significantly impact these markets. Therefore, it is essential to ensure that the proposals are not publicly discussed, allowing the sensitive markets to remain stable, he pointed out. (MD)

title: Activist Nikeshala arrested
author: Author not found
Content: Social activist Piyath Nikeshala was arrested by the Criminal Investigation Department (CID) yesterday (26) evening. The arrest was made in connection with his live streaming of the incident where protesters set fire to President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s private residence on 9 July 2022. Police Media Spokesman SSP Nihal Thalduwa confirmed the arrest and said Nikeshala was summoned earlier in the day by the CID to provide a statement regarding the incident. After recording his statement, he was subsequently arrested. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: President returns
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe returned to Sri Lanka yesterday (26), after concluding his tour of Europe, according to the Airport Duty Manager at the Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA), Katunayake. The President’s delegation, which accompanied him on the tour, has split up, with some members travelling to France after a two-day visit to England. A few members of the delegation also arrived at the BIA this morning. The remaining members are scheduled to arrive at the BIA from Dubai today (27) at 9.10 a.m.  As the President returned yesterday (26) morning, security measures were heightened at the airport, along the expressway, and in the surrounding areas. BY T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: CHEC to invest USD 1.2B in Port City – Ali Sabry
author: Author not found
Content: Foreign Minister Ali Sabry on Monday (26) met President of the China Harbour Engineering Company (CHEC), Bai Yinzhan, at the company’s headquarters in Beijing. During the meeting, Bai confirmed that CHEC would be investing USD 1.2 billion in the Colombo Port City project, with the initial focus on the International Financial Centre. Ali Sabry shared this information in a tweet. The CHEC Port City Colombo (Pvt) Ltd., a subsidiary of the State-run China Harbour Engineering Company, operates under the umbrella of the China Communications Construction Company Limited (CCCC). This collaboration between Sri Lanka and CHEC aims to develop and enhance the Colombo Port City. In addition to the meeting with President Bai, Ali Sabry also held discussions with the Chairman of the Export-Import Bank of China, in Beijing on Monday (26). The purpose of the meeting was to discuss Sri Lanka’s on-going debt restructuring process. In a tweet, Minister Ali Sabry expressed that the meeting was constructive and emphasised that China would support Sri Lanka’s economic recovery and growth. Furthermore, as part of his visit to China, Minister Sabry also had a meeting with Chinese State Councillor and Foreign Minister Qin Gang in Beijing on Sunday (25). (MD)

title: Court squashes summons issued on SDIG Tennakoon
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal issued an Order invalidating the communication issued by the Attorney General to the Inspector General of Police (IGP), naming SDIG Tennakoon as a suspect over his alleged failure to prevent attacks on protesters at Galle Face on 9 May 2022. The AG, in his letter had instructed the IGP to name Tennakoon as a suspect for abetting in commission of offences punishable under Sections 314, 316, 343 and 300 of the Penal Code. The judgment was delivered by a two-Judge Bench of the Court of Appeal, comprising Justices Nissanka Bandula Karunaratne and M.A.R. Marikkar. The writ petition was filed by Tennakoon. Furthermore, Court of Appeal on the same day (26) issued a writ order nullifying the summons issued by the Colombo Fort Magistrate against Western Province Senior DIG Deshbandu Tennakoon over the latter’s alleged involvement, in a sum of Rs. 17.8 million recovered by protesters inside the President’s House on 9 July 2022.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.
