title: No Chinese military base in SL – President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe denied the presence of a Chinese military base in Sri Lanka, while speaking to the French media ‘France 24’. He emphasised further that Sri Lanka will not allow its territory to be used as a base for any threats against India. He said there are no military agreements between the two countries and said China would not enter into a military agreement with Sri Lanka. Addressing speculations, he mentioned that the Chinese have been present in Sri Lanka for over 1,500 years and there has never been a military base. He clarified that the Hambantota harbour has been leased to China Merchants for 100 years, with the security of the harbour being controlled by the Sri Lankan Government. The President added that the Southern Naval Command will be relocated to Hambantota and already a brigade is stationed in the surrounding areas.  President Wickremesinghe highlighted that the same company, China Merchants, operates the CICT terminal in Colombo’s harbour, in the south port where warships often dock and there have been no complaints about it but only about Hambantota port. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Former Minister Cyril dies following elevator collapse
author: Author not found
Content: Former Minister of Health Dr. P.N.B. Cyril tragically passed away in the night of Sunday (25) when a temporary elevator, which had been installed outside his home in Siribopura, Hambantota, collapsed while he and his driver were inside. The incident occurred during repairs being conducted on the building’s third floor. Dr. P.N.B. Cyril, aged 89, entered politics in 1977 and successfully contested the Tissamaharama seat under the United National Party (UNP) banner. The former minister sustained severe injuries and was initially admitted to General Hospital in Hambantota. Due to the critical nature of his injuries, he was later transferred to Karapitiya Teaching Hospital, where he unfortunately succumbed to his injuries. The driver, who also sustained injuries, was admitted to General Hospital in Hambantota. Investigations into the incident revealed that the former minister and his driver were inspecting the on-going repairs to the building when the elevator collapsed. BY D.N. Jayasekara – Mattala

title: CTU against closure of schools with less than 100 students
author: Author not found
Content: President of Ceylon Teachers’ Union (CTU) Priyantha Fernando said, as part of the restructuring process of schools across the country and in line with the national education reforms project, a decision has been taken to close down nearly 2,000 schools islandwide which accommodate less than 100 students. He charged that as part of this concept around 300 schools with less than 100 students had been shut down since 2020. Fernando added that as the CTU, they were sternly opposed to this measure being undertaken by the Education Ministry and noted that they will continue to express their objections while standing up for rights of children to receive an education. BY Percy Kuruneru – Anuradhapura

title: Galle Face beggars to be relocated to Ridiyagama
author: Author not found
Content: In response to the hundreds of complaints received regarding alleged public harassment, the beggars at Galle Face Green, Colombo will be relocated at the Social Services Rehabilitation Centre at Ridiyagama in Hambantota. This was decided at a special discussion held on the directives for the SLPA and affiliated institutions to allocate funds, under Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR), on Sunday (25), at the Auditorium of the Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation. Subject Minister Nimal Siripala de Silva, Secretary to the Ministry of Ports Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, Chairman of Sri Lanka Port Authority (SLPA) Keith D. Bernard, a number of high officials from SLPA, affiliated institutions and the Police Department attended the discussion. It was discussed at the meeting that reports indicate that beggars at Colombo’s Galle Face Green have become a significant problem for visitors to the area. The number of beggars has noticeably risen in the vicinity where local residents, tourists from abroad, young individuals and families with children gather for leisure and relaxation. “It is estimated that approximately 150 beggars at Galle Face Green are causing numerous disturbances to the visitors throughout the week, making it a pressing social concern as highlighted in the reports,” the ministry said in a statement. , Accordingly, as a proactive solution to address the issue, it has been decided that these individuals will be relocated at the Social Services Rehabilitation Center in Ridiagama, in the Hambantota District. The Ministry of Ports, Shipping, and Aviation has given instructions on the implementation of a joint programme by both, the SLPA and the Police Department to oversee this initiative. Minister Nimal Siripala de Silva has issued directives to the SLPA and affiliated institutions to allocate funds for this, under CSR. These funds are intended to provide essential accommodation, food, and other necessary facilities for beggars who are to be transferred to the Ridiagama Centre. Speaking at the occasion, he said, “Persistent harassment inflicted upon the public, by these beggars, is a stain on Sri Lanka’s reputation, particularly when both local and foreign tourists visit Colombo. As a result, it has been decided to re-settle these beggars at the Social Services Rehabilitation Centre in Ridiagama, located in the Hambantota District. The project will be undertaken under the purview of the SLPA. Considering this a CSR initiative, the SLPA and its affiliates have pledged the requisite financial resources for this measure.” (SM)

title: Romania thanks SL for deciding to open Embassy in Bucharest
author: Author not found
Content: Romanian Minister of State for Foreign Affairs Traian Hristea thanked Sri Lanka for deciding to open an Embassy in Bucharest shortly. He was calling on Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena, at the Temple Trees, on 25 June, to discuss bilateral ties, economic cooperation, investments and employment issues. The Prime Minister thanked the Government of Romania for providing employment to a large number of Sri Lankans in recent years. Romania is the most favourable and preferred employment destination for Sri Lankans since 2016 and already, the Sri Lankan workforce in the apparel, construction, hospitality and agriculture sectors is assessed to be more than 32,000. Hristea said there will be additional employment opportunities for Sri Lankans as Romania is currently implementing several large scale infrastructure and other development projects. The Prime Minister urged Romania to consider investments in education, agriculture, railways, IT and tourism sectors. He explained the measures taken by Sri Lanka to solve the issues related to the current economic crisis and stressed the need for continuous support of the European Union. The Romanian Minister assured that his country would support Sri Lanka’s request for continuation of GSP plus duty concessions for Sri Lankan exports.

title: Student Parliament organised in Ratnapura
author: Author not found
Content: The Student Parliament of the Convent of The Child Jesus National School, Ratnapura was organised by the Public Outreach Division, of the Department of Communication of the Parliament of Sri Lanka, with the aim of opening the practical space to the school community, regarding democracy, responsibility and accountability as well as the importance of voting to school students. According to the traditions of Parliament, the Speaker was elected at the inaugural session followed by the official oaths and affirmation of the Ministers and Members of Parliament. A parliamentary debate was also held, presenting facts related to each subject area. The Director Legislative Services / Director Communication (Acting) of the Parliament of Sri Lanka H.E. Janakantha Silva gave a special address and the Director Administration of Parliament G. Thachchanarani provided a comprehensive understanding on the representation of Members of Parliament on behalf of the public. Student representatives, teachers and parents of six schools in the Ratnapura Education Zone also participated in this event. Books containing information about parliamentary proceedings were also distributed to the libraries of each school.

title: Elpitikanda villagers demand drinking water
author: Author not found
Content: About 4,000 persons belonging to 800 families in five villages in the Elpitikanda Grama Seva Division of Udunuwara, Kandy engaged in a protest in the village, demanding drinking water. Nonawatta, Fifty Acres, Elpitikanda, Wembiliwatta, and Bambaragahaela are these five villages. Out of this, 374 families were provided water by the National Water Supply and Drainage Board and Kandy Community Water Supply Department through the Diyatha organisation. The protesters said the water supply was discontinued five months ago due to non-payment of electricity and water bills by the society. The villagers produced their water bills and said, although they had paid the water bills on time, the situation has arisen because the society has not paid the money to the relevant institutions. They allege despite the amount being increased to Rs 2.8 million, the Water Supply Board or other State institutions who are in charge of monitoring this issue have overlooked it so they cannot find out what happened to the money collected from the public. The protesters say they have to travel two to three kilometres in search of drinking water. They added that they also have to travel four kilometres to Nikahetiya village to take a bath. Most villagers are daily wage coolies and it is very difficult for them to take a wash in the evening, find water for their daily chores, and find water for schoolchildren, and everyone is greatly inconvenienced. They said this situation has arisen because the water provided by the Water Supply Board comes through a community-based organisation. They also demand that a responsible person intervenes and resolves this issue. It is stated, in 2019, Rs 45,000 has been collected from one family and Rs 20 million has been given by the Government. The protesters say, while Rs 1.36 million has been allocated for water meters, this organisation collected Rs 2,000 each from 374 houses. When the Chairperson of the Prajamula organisation, Chandrika Herath, was queried about this allegation, she differed to the Treasurer. The Treasurer, Dissanayake said due to the increase in electricity charges and water bills, he was unable to pay those bills. However, these protesters said due to the delinquency of a few persons, about 4,000 villagers are suffering. They also demanded a formal investigation and restoration of the water supply. By Suranga Dilhan – Gampola

title: ‘Vedaduru Abhiman’ Presidential Award Ceremony
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Health and Department of Ayurveda, collaborated with Fadna and Lever Ayush, successfully organized the ‘Vedaduru Abhiman’ Presidential Award Ceremony on 20 June 2023 at the prestigious Bandaranaike Memorial International Conference Hall (BMICH) in Colombo. This distinguished event aimed to promote and empower indigenous medicine by recognising the exemplary contributions and achievements of registered Ayurveda practitioners across the island. The primary objective of the ceremony was to ensure that our local practitioners receive national recognition for their dedication and expertise in the field of Ayurveda, thus elevating the status of traditional medicine in our country. The event witnessed the presence of esteemed dignitaries, including Prime Minister of Sri Lanka, Dinesh Gunawardana, Speaker Mahinda Yapa, Sisira Jayakodi, the Minister of State for Indigenous Medicine of Sri Lanka, Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella, and Nimal Siripala, the Minister of Ports, Shipping, and Aviation of Sri Lanka. In addition, policymakers, researchers, academics, industry professionals, and Ayurveda practitioners from various parts of the country actively participated in the event.

title: Cargills Village to Home 19th programme to support local SMEs
author: Author not found
Content: Cargills launched its Village to Home programme in 2020 to provide vital support to the country’s small and medium entrepreneurs (SMEs) who were severely impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic and left without market access. Even though the pandemic is behind us, Cargills has continued the Village to Home program to empower local entrepreneurs. The 19th Village to Home program took place on 24 and 25 June at the Cargills FoodCity Torrington Square with the participation of 24 SMEs. Since its inception, the program has provided over 800 SMEs with a platform to showcase their products to the extensive customer base of Cargills. To address the hardships faced by SMEs, Cargills provides a platform for these entrepreneurs to generate additional income and also extends technical assistance to help them bring their products to market. Furthermore, the Cargills Bank extends crucial financial support to these entrepreneurs, enabling them to expand their production capacity. Cargills provides these monthly trade stalls free of charge, bearing all expenses associated with the program. Importantly, the entrepreneurs retain all the income earned through the program, ensuring a direct benefit to their businesses. As an extension of the program, selected SMEs are also provided with dedicated gondolas or bays inside Cargills Retail outlets to showcase their products. This opportunity allows them to reach an even wider customer base and drive further growth for their businesses. The recently concluded Village to Home program witnessed a diverse range of products, offering a vibrant shopping experience for customers. From traditional handicrafts to homemade food products, customers were able to explore and support local entrepreneurs while enjoying high-quality goods.

title: World Expo 2030 in Saudi Arabia
author: Author not found
Content: In a new achievement to be added to a series of great achievements that took place in all fields during the prosperous era of the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques King Salman bin Abdulaziz and his Crown Prince Muhammad bin Salman bin Abdulaziz, the Kingdom recorded a new victory in the arena of hosting international and regional exhibitions, conferences, festivals and events, through submitting an official bid to the organising body “Bureau International des Expositions (BIE)”, to host Expo 2030 in the capital city of Riyadh, from 1 October 2030 till 31 March 2031. Great Potential The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia is competing with four countries for the World Expo 2030, including Russia, South Korea, Italy, and Ukraine. The host country will be elected at the 173rd General Assembly of the BIE in November 2023, using a secret ballot based on the principle of “one country, one vote.” The Kingdom has received significant international support, with over 85 countries supporting its bid. Many International organisations have announced their support for Saudi Arabia’s bid. The Kingdom’s plans to host the “Expo 2030” are ambitious. Riyadh city is building one of the world’s largest public transport networks, creating a green space in the city which is four times larger than the “Central Park” of New York City, planting 15 million trees, and transforming Riyadh into an open art gallery without walls. Hosting the exhibition aligns with the Saudi vision of becoming a global investment powerhouse, diversifying its economy away from oil and embracing sustainable high-tech industries. The Kingdom is also launching large projects like NEOM and the Red Sea project to achieve this goal. Era of Change Saudi Arabia submitted its bid adopting a theme, namely “The Era of Change: Together (in our planet) for a Foresighted Tomorrow”. The International Bureau of Exhibitions (BIE) is set to host a World Expo in Riyadh, marking a significant milestone for the Kingdom. Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman bin Abdulaziz expressed confidence in the Kingdom’s ability to hold a historic version of the Expo, focusing on innovation and providing a unique global experience. He emphasised that the Expo would enhance the BIE’s role as a platform for understanding cultures and human exchange, reflecting the changing nature of the world. Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman bin Abdulaziz expressed confidence in the Kingdom’s ability to hold a historic International Expo, focusing on innovation and providing a unique global experience. He expressed confidence in the Kingdom’s commitment to organising the event. He also added Expo will coincide with the Kingdom’s Vision 2030 celebration, marking the culmination of efforts to achieve the vision’s goals. The Expo will provide a unique opportunity to share lessons and results from the Kingdom’s transformation, focusing on reducing oil dependence, advancing economic diversification, and developing public service sectors like health, education, infrastructure, entertainment, and tourism. Forecasting the future The Crown Prince emphasised the Kingdom’s vision for the future, focusing on creating a sustainable future for future generations. The Kingdom launched a promotional campaign on 28 March 2022 to host the World Expo, utilising its diplomacy machine to mobilise international support. The Royal Commission for Riyadh City, responsible for developing Riyadh, is leading the bidding, and hosting efforts for Expo 2030. The city has become one of the fastest-growing cities in the world, with a population of nearly 8 million people and a GDP of up to US$ 200 billion. The city is developing numerous projects to transform Riyadh into one of the 10 largest urban economies in the world and an ideal candidate for hosting the World Expo. By 2030, Riyadh aims to embody the World Expo’s aims of bringing together the best minds, ideas, and solutions to continue the progress of humanity. Exceptional version The Kingdom is working to organise an exceptional version of the World Expo with the International Bureau of Exhibitions. The mission of the BIE paid a five-day visit to Riyadh to discuss the Kingdom’s dossier for hosting the event. The delegation met with Prince Muhammad bin Salman bin Abdulaziz, Crown Prince, Prime Minister, and Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Royal Commission for the City of Riyadh. The mission also discussed technical aspects of the Kingdom’s candidature dossier for World Expo 2030, holding meetings and workshops with Ministers and senior officials. Experts in the exhibitions, conferences, and festivals sector believe that the Kingdom’s structural capabilities, tourist destinations, and experiences in various events confirm its ability to host the “Expo 2030” exhibition. The success of annual celebrations, exhibitions, and events in Saudi Arabia, such as book fairs, festivals, and international sports championships, as well as initiatives like the Green Middle East initiative and the Saudi Green Initiative, support the Kingdom’s candidacy and give preference to its submitted dossier over other countries competing to host World Expo 2030. By Khalidh Rizwan

title: Low fish harvest in shallow seas cause of high prices
author: Author not found
Content: The large decrease in the fish harvest in the shallow seas is the cause for the increase in fish prices, in the market, all around the country, said W. Jude, head of Negombo Fishermen’s Association. Consumers say, the price of a kilo of all types of sea fish is more than Rs 2,500  except for Salaya and Sudaya. Therefore, the customers said that they cannot afford to buy fish. Jude Namal further said that the increase in fuel price and the high cost of fishing equipment are also causes for the increase in fish prices. He also said, pumping of sand from the sea to the land has caused a reduction of the fish harvest in the shallow seas of the Western Province, the earth tremors that occurred in the last few days had reduced the fish resources in the Southern Province and the use of illegal fishing methods such as trawling and use of explosives in the Northern and Eastern seas have caused this situation. Jude Namal further said the warm waves in the seas around Sri Lanka, these days, had also caused the reduction of fish in the shallow seas.  BY Prasanga Pavuluhewa – Ja-Ela

title: Ancient stone inscription going to rack and ruin
author: Author not found
Content: A historic stone inscription, which is situated at the Madawala Muslim village has started to go to rack and ruin, residents say. The ancient stone inscription, had been built during the reign of King Parakramabahu VI (1412-1467) and handed over to blacksmith Siddawulle Paramaniya and his son Sooriya. Residents of the area allege that a concrete wall which had been constructed to ensure the beauty and safety of the monument had been removed and they urge the Department of Archaeology to take prompt action to preserve the stone inscription for future generations. By D. Wanniarachchi – Menikhinna

title: SL attracts 61,183 tourists in first20 days of June
author: Author not found
Content: According to provisional data from the Sri Lanka Tourism Development Authority (SLTDA), tourist arrivals to Sri Lanka reached a total of 61,183 in the first 20 days of June. This is a significant step towards the tourism industry’s goal of attracting 87,521 international visitors for the entire month of June, as Sri Lanka has already achieved 70 per cent of its target. For the period between 21 and 30 June, the country is expecting to welcome 26,338 tourists, which translates to an average daily arrival of 2,633 visitors. The cumulative tourist arrivals from 1 January to 20 June 2023, now stand at 585,669. In June, thus far, the average daily arrival has been 3,059. In the first week of June, Sri Lanka recorded 19,365 tourist arrivals, which increased to 20,541 in the second week. In the third week, there was a slight improvement with 20,986 tourist arrivals. India continues to be the largest contributer to tourist traffic in Sri Lanka, accounting for 28 per cent of the total arrivals in June. The Russian Federation holds the second position, representing nine per cent of the total tourist influx. The United Kingdom ranks third, contributing seven per cent of the total tourist arrivals. Australia holds the fourth position, while China has moved up to become the fifth-largest source of tourist traffic for Sri Lanka. Other notable markets for Sri Lanka’s tourism industry include Canada, Germany, the United States, Maldives, and France.

title: Premajayantha to attend COL Board meeting
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Education Susil Premajayantha will attend the 40th Board meeting of the Commonwealth of Learning (COL), in Vancouver, Canada, on 28 and 29 June. The Commonwealth of Learning is an international organisation that was established by Commonwealth member countries to promote and facilitate distance learning, open learning, and the development and sharing of educational resources and technologies. As the Asian region representative, Minister Premajayantha’s participation in the board meeting aims to enhance the quality of the education system in Sri Lanka. The initiatives undertaken by the Commonwealth of Learning have had a significant impact on programmes such as providing lunch for Sri Lankan schoolchildren. By engaging with the COL, the Minister intends to further improve the educational opportunities and outcomes for students in Sri Lanka.                                                                  (DW)

title: AG informs Court monkeys won’t be exported to China
author: Author not found
Content: The Attorney General yesterday (26) informed the Court of Appeal that the controversial decision, to export 100,000 Toque Macaque monkeys to China, will be halted. The Attorney General said so, during a hearing of a writ petition that challenged the proposed capture and exportation of these monkeys to China. Deputy Solicitor General Manohara Jayasinghe represented the Wildlife Department. Representing animal rights organisations and activists, President’s Counsel Sanjeeva Jayawardena expressed relief upon hearing this positive response from the authorities. He emphasised the importance of this decision, stating, “I am very happy to hear this because, otherwise, these monkeys would have ended up in Chinese restaurants.” Jayawardena urged the authorities to provide written confirmation of the decision. The Court of Appeal Bench comprising Justices Nissanka Bandula Karunaratne and M.A.R. Marikkar scheduled the next hearing of the petition for 7 July. Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera previously acknowledged the government’s consideration of a request by the Chinese Government to export 100,000 Toque Macaque monkeys, which are native to Sri Lanka. The proposed purpose of the export was their display in Chinese zoos. The petition challenging the Minister’s decision to export these monkeys was filed by several organisations and individuals concerned with wildlife and animal welfare. The Wildlife and Nature Protection Society of Sri Lanka, Rally for Animal Rights and Environment, Justice for Animals, Rescue Animals Sri Lanka and notable advocates such as Otara Gunewardene joined forces to contest the exportation. Prominent figures from various fields, including Ven. Matara Ananda Sagara Thera and Iromi Ahilya Salgado, also lent their support to the cause.

title: Development Officers pull out of Aswesuma scheme
author: Author not found
Content: All Ceylon Development Officers’ Association (ACDOA) stressed that henceforth they will be opting out of all work related to the ‘Aswesuma’ Social Welfare Scheme as its benefits have failed to reach the truly deserving people in the country. Its reps charged that those who were entitled to the benefits, via the welfare scheme, were left high and dry as those with means in society laid claim to it. ACDOA Chairman Anurada Seneviratne, addressing the media in Kandy yesterday (26) alleged that due to the benefits not reaching the deserving people its reps had begun to receive threats from those who were overlooked. He added that due to this unwelcome situation they decided to take a collective decision to opt out of all activities related to the aforementioned welfare scheme. Seneviratne stressed that they will only resume work after their safety is ensured and the benefits are channelled to the people that deserve it. BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Indian Police arrest a Lankan for people smuggling
author: Author not found
Content: Two agents have been arrested for allegedly duping Sri Lankan nationals on the pretext of sending them to Canada via India illegally. The accused have been identified as Mahenthiraraja (63), a resident of Sri Lanka and Selvakulendran (56), a resident of Tamil Nadu, the Indian Police said. A case was registered at the IGI Airport Police station on the complaint of an inspector who stated that while he was on patrol duty near Mahipalpur picket, he came across 10 people who were suspiciously standing there, a senior Police officer said. When asked for their proof of identity, they were unable to submit the same. They were then taken to the Police station for verification. All of them were found to be natives of Sri Lanka. One of them Mahenthiraja was the sub-agent who was guiding the others on the directions of Selvakulendran. They all were promised to be sent to Canada, the officer said. Later, Police found the location of Selvakulendran in Trichy, Tamil Nadu and arrestedhim, Deputy Commissioner of Police (airport) Devesh Kumar Mahla said. During interrogation, Selvakulendran disclosed that he charged Rs 200,000 each to send the people to Canada via Delhi. These Sri Lankan people were sent to him by his acquaintance in Sri Lanka named Vijay, the DCP said. Two mobile phones belonging to Mahenthiraja and two Canadian Visa stickers, in the name of two of the passengers, were recovered from him, while two Indian passports and two Sri Lankan passports were recovered from Selvakulendran, Police said. Apart from this, nine more agents were arrested in May in separate incidents, Police added. (PTI)

title: 911,689 passports issued in 2022 – Immigration Dept
author: Author not found
Content: According to the recently released annual performance report of the Immigration and Emigration Department, a total of 911,689 passports were issued in 2022. This figure represents the highest number of passports issued in the past five years, according to the Immigration Department. In comparison to 2021, an additional 529,138 passports were issued in 2022, indicating a significant increase. Among this number, 1,124,022 were Sri Lankans, while 864,648 were foreigners, as reported by the Immigration Department.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: There may never be another Ranil
author: Author not found
Content: UNP Chairman MP Wajira Abeywardena expressed doubts on whether Sri Lanka would have another leader like President Ranil Wickremesinghe who possesses exceptional diplomatic skills. Abeywardena also expressed concern about the spread of false information on social media regarding a complaint, contrary to facts. The UNP Chairman strongly condemned certain groups for making baseless allegations to confuse the public. He emphasised that as long as these practices persist, Sri Lanka’s future will remain uncertain. MP Abeywardena was speaking at the UNP Ambalangoda electorate working committee meeting held on Saturday (24). He highlighted President Wickremesinghe’s efforts in engaging in bilateral and multilateral discussions with influential countries to revive Sri Lanka’s economy, which has been impacted by the ongoing crisis. Abeywardena expressed confidence that many of these efforts are starting to yield positive results, and he firmly believed that Sri Lanka would soon regain its former glory. According to Abeywardena, several countries, including Sri Lanka’s friendly nations, are looking at Sri Lanka with optimism and are providing assistance to overcome the economic crisis. “President Wickremesinghe has already taken significant steps, with the support of powerful countries such as the United States, India, China, and others, to transform Sri Lanka into a developed nation. It will be difficult to find a leader in Sri Lanka who can engage with the international community as effectively as President Wickremesinghe,” Abeywardena said. He added that although mistakes have been made in the past, it is now time to rectify them and move forward. He emphasised the importance of working together, focusing on the future generations who will eventually take over the country, rather than attempting to gain political mileage. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: ‘Samurdhi beneficiaries left out of Aswasuma’
author: Author not found
Content: Claims have been made across various regions of the country that the names of Samurdhi beneficiaries have been removed from the eligibility lists for the Government’s proposed welfare benefits programme, Aswasuma. It is alleged that the names of Samurdhi beneficiaries have been unfairly excluded from the Aswasuma lists, while names of new individuals, who were not Samurdhi recipients, have been included instead. In the Kirindiwela Grama Niladhari Division, in Balangoda, out of 352 Samurdhi beneficiaries, only four names have reportedly been included in the Aswasuma programme. Similarly, numerous Samurdhi beneficiaries in Ampara have also been left out of the Aswasuma list. The people claim that despite assurances from the authorities that the names of those suffering from Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) would be included in Aswasuma, many affected families have been omitted from the new programme. This issue became a heated topic during last week’s parliamentary sessions, as both government and Opposition MPs joined forces to criticise the selection process for the welfare programme. However, State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe tweeted that individuals can personally submit their appeals and objections regarding the Aswasuma welfare benefits programme at the Divisional Secretariats throughout the country. “For those who are unable to use the online system to submit their appeals or objections, they can file them in the usual way. For any further inquiries, the general public can contact the hotline number 1924, which operates on weekdays from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.,” the State Minister added. BY Amith Maduranga Gamage, Hewa P. Karunaratne – Matale and Nalinda Waleboda – Balangoda

title: SriLankan Pilots Poorly Paid – Pilots’ Guild
author: Author not found
Content: Against a backdrop of criticism being levelled against SriLankan Airlines for its frequent flight delays and flight cancellations in recent times, the Airline Pilots’ Guild of Sri Lanka (ALPGSL) alleged that SriLankan Airlines pays its pilots some of the lowest salaries in the industry, well below standard rates, and slammed the top management for its “short-sighted and callous decisions,” which have left pilots overworked and facing numerous challenges. ALPGSL Secretary, Captain Manil Abeyaratne, highlighted that SriLankan Airlines presently has only 250 pilots, whereas a minimum of 330 pilots are required for the airline to operate at full capacity for designated flights. Over 70 pilots have resigned and more resignations are pending due to unresolved issues, exacerbating the shortage of flight crew. In a statement, the ALPGSL said additionally, during the Covid-19 pandemic, pilot salaries were slashed by approximately 50 per cent. The ALPGSL stated that prior to June 2023, pilots were being paid their salaries at an arbitrary USD value, capped at rates significantly lower than those set by the Central Bank. Initially, the rate was Rs 188, then Rs 225, and subsequently Rs 295 (since December), which was 40 per cent below the Central Bank rate. “Despite the salary cuts, the pilots continued to work diligently during the pandemic, contributing to the airline’s revenue generation. They played a crucial role in transporting critical medical supplies and fulfilling other essential requirements for the country during the crisis. It is worth noting that all pilots employed by the airline have funded their own education and training at SriLankan Airlines,” it said. “Over the past year, over 70 pilots have resigned from the airline, resulting in a severe shortage of pilots. This shortage was evident in a recent incident where no pilots were available for standby duty, leading to a flight departing over 12 hours after its scheduled departure time,” ALPGSL said.

title: Rewards for info on or seizing of unauthorised firearms increased
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Public Security has announced that on the instructions of Minister Tiran Alles, cash rewards for Police officers who seize unauthorised firearms and grenades, and those who provide information on same will be increased. The payments will be made for the unauthorised firearms and hand grenades seized between 25 June and 31 July. The decision comes in response to the rising number of firearm and hand grenade-related crimes reported. This increase in criminal activity poses a threat to the establishment of law and order and hampers efforts to create a safe and peaceful environment. Therefore, the ministry has emphasised the need to intensify search operations to uncover unauthorised firearms and grenades. To motivate Police officers and private informers, the value of the monetary rewards from the Police Reward Scheme will be increased The revised cash rewards from the Police Reward Scheme will be as follows: T56 (with the suspect): Rs 250,000 for both Police officers and private informers. T56 (without the suspect): Rs 200,000 for Police officers and Rs 250,000 for private informers. Repeater Rifle (with the suspect): Rs 50,000 for both Police officers and private informers. Repeater Rifle (without the suspect): Rs 25,000 for both Police officers and private informers. Pistol (with the suspect): Rs 150,000 for Police officers and Rs 250,000 for private informers. Pistol (without the suspect): Rs 100,000 for Police officers and Rs 250,000 for private informers. Revolver Gun (with the suspect): Rs 150,000 for Police officers and Rs 250,000 for private informers. Revolver Gun (without the suspect): Rs. 100,000 for Police officers and Rs 250,000 for private informers. Automatic Firearms (produced in other countries) (with the suspect): Rs 150,000 for Police officers and Rs 200,000 for private informers. Automatic Firearms (produced in other countries) (without the suspect): Rs 100,000 for Police officers and Rs 200,000 for private informers. Non-automatic Firearms (produced in other countries) (with the suspect): Rs 50,000 for Police officers and private informers. Non-automatic Firearms (produced in other countries) (without the suspect): Rs 25,000 for Police officers and private informers. Ammunition Guns (foreign produced) (with the suspect): Rs. 25,000 for Police officers and Rs 15,000 for private informers. Ammunition Guns (foreign produced) (without the suspect): Rs 10,000 for Police officers and private informers. Hand Grenades (with or without the suspect): Rs 25,000 for both, Police officers and private informers. By Sanjana Marzook

title: Dengue cases likely to increase with coming monsoon– Dr. Wijewickrama
author: Author not found
Content: Senior Consultant Physician Dr. Ananda Wijewickrama warned that with the upcoming monsoon season, there is a risk of dengue cases increasing rapidly and he urged that dengue control needs to receive more attention from all sectors. During an interview conducted by the President’s Media Division recently, Dr. Wijewickrama emphasised that everyone’s assistance is important for this because neither the Government nor the Health Authorities can control the dengue virus on their own. “There has been a clear increase in the number of dengue cases this year and over 47,000 cases have been reported since January. The majority of the patients recorded thus far are from the Colombo and Gampaha Districts and the Health and Security Forces will work together to launch a special initiative to clean up the garbage in those areas,” he said. Dr. Wijewickrama said 75% of reported cases involve those who are older than 15 years of age. “Nowadays, young people are more likely to contract the disease than small children, despite the fact that it used to spread among them more frequently. Dengue is a virus. As a result, there is a strong likelihood that dengue can be easily transmitted via mosquitos from one infected person to another,” he said Eliminating mosquito breeding places is vital. The dengue mosquito typically exists in in areas where clean water gathers. Anywhere, including waste plastic, used tires, flower pots, coconut and king coconut shells, serves as a breeding ground for dengue mosquitoes. Such areas should receive as much attention as possible and should be removed immediately. In addition, precautions should be taken to avoid mosquito bites, he pointed out. Furthermore, it is important to take precautions against mosquito bites in order to avoid spreading the dengue virus to others. For that, the body should be covered with clothing. Additionally, there are mosquito repellents. It can also control mosquito bites. But none of these approaches is completely effective. “The Local Government authorities, Public Health Inspectors, Health Departments and Security Forces have all stepped in to help control the disease by destroying mosquito breeding grounds. Special programmes are being implemented focusing on the provinces where dengue is spreading most. Within the coming week, a special initiative will begin, with a focus on the Colombo and Gampaha Districts, where the majority of cases are reported. There will be a clean-up of the garbage in such areas. It has been agreed to provide the labour contribution of the Army for this purpose,” he said. Even if water is removed from containers, mosquito larvae can remain. Therefore, they should be cleaned thoroughly and water should not be allowed to collect again. The typical lifespan of a mosquito is five to six days. Therefore, weekly cleaning of the surroundings is crucial. Keeping your surroundings clean is a must. Controlling dengue cannot be done by one person alone. And it cannot be done only by a few institutions. This requires the support of everyone in the country. Moreover, a person suffering from dengue should not work hard and rest is essential. “If not, the chances of complications are high. Any patient with fever should only be given Paracetamol, it has been advised. Paracetamol may occasionally fail to entirely bring down fever. However patients should not be afraid in such cases. Having a fever does not escalate to a major issue. Complications can be minimised through physical rest. Meanwhile, it is vital that fluid intakes are given to patients to keep them hydrated. King coconut water, orange, lime juice and Jeevani are generally recommended for this purpose,” he advised the public.

title: Minister Alles orders CID probe
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Public Security, Tiran Alles, has directed the Criminal Investigation Department (CID) to launch an investigation into the leak of an internal Police message, concerning the security of President Ranil Wickremesinghe, who is scheduled to return from an official visit to the UK and France. The Minister has instructed the CID to apprehend the individuals responsible for the leaked message. In a statement, the Ministry of Public Security dismissed the rumours, circulating on social media, about an assassination attempt on the President, emphasising that these claims are entirely false. The ministry clarified that standard security measures and procedures are in place for the departure and return of the President or Prime Minister during official foreign visits, which have also been implemented during the President’s current visit. These measures are routine and part of normal procedure, the ministry stated.However, the leak of the internal message caused significant unrest on social media platforms. Consequently, the Public Security Minister has instructed the CID to conduct an investigation and arrest those responsible for the leak. Sri Lanka Police have implemented necessary security measures to safeguard the President upon his return to the country from the UK and France, as is customary, the ministry added.
